headline: Where to Eat in North Texas
text: If you’re headed to Cowboys Stadium for the Super Bowl, Sam Sifton, The Times’s restaurant critic, suggests a few places to eat.

headline: For Fans With Texas-Size Appetites
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The faithful have started to arrive in this drab, featureless city a little closer to Fort Worth than to Dallas. They have come sweat-panted and reverent to stand along Collins Street to photograph Cowboys Stadium, to walk the sidewalk surrounding its $1.2 billion form.

headline: On Eating in Dallas
text: The sports desk sent me south last week to eat my way through the Dallas-Fort Worth metroplex in advance of Sunday’s Super Bowl between the Green Bay Packers and the Pittsburgh Steelers. I wrote an article about it for the Tuesday paper. And there is a multimedia feature that goes along with that piece.

headline: Envoy to China to Resign, Weighing ’12 G.O.P. Bid
text: WASHINGTON  The United States ambassador to China, Jon M. Huntsman Jr., delivered a letter of resignation on Monday to President Obama and intends to leave his position on April 30, a White House official said, clearing the way for him to explore a potential 2012 Republican presidential bid.

headline: Sotomayor Reflects on First Years on Court
text: CHICAGO  Justice Sonia Sotomayor, speaking at a law school here on Monday, said she had “taken heat” at her Supreme Court confirmation hearings two summers ago in part because she was the first Hispanic nominee.

headline: The Moment for Al Jazeera
text: Media reporter Brian Stelter examines the demand for Al Jazeera English during the Egypt protests.

headline: Cairo’s Ornate (or Odd) Portals to the Past

headline: Egypt’s Economy Is Near Paralysis
text: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt  Egypt’s economy approached paralysis on Monday as foreign commerce, tourism and banking all but halted, placing acute pressure on President Hosni Mubarak to find a way out of the weeklong chaos.

headline: Same Names, but Different Pedigrees
text: The fifth round of the English F.A. Cup offers a romantic if mind-boggling matchup between two teams called the Red Devils: mighty Manchester United and minor league Crawley Town.

headline: N.F.L. and Union Set Negotiating Meetings
text: DALLAS  Negotiating teams for the N.F.L. and the players union will hold a formal negotiating session here Saturday, and they have also agreed to a series of meetings over the next few weeks, the sides announced in a joint statement Monday.

headline: Race to the Top of What? Obama On Education
text: On the morning after the State of the Union speech was delivered, John Hockenberry, co-host of the NPR program “The Takeaway,” read aloud President Obama’s declaration that “we want to prepare 100,000 new teachers in the fields of science, technology, engineering and math.” Hockenberry commented: “You scientists, engineers and techies know who you are; but what about the rest of us?”

headline: Figures of an Infant Jesus, Dressed for a Feast Day
text: Norma Castro laid the familiar figure on the counter before her, next to a basket of poblano peppers. Then, ignoring the twangy bachata music that blared from a nearby market stall, she furrowed her brow, delicately plucked it up and admired it.

headline: Al Jazeera’s Egypt Coverage Is Deep, but Hard to Find

headline: Al Jazeera English Finds an Audience
text: White House officials have turned to Al Jazeera English among other television channels to monitor the mounting protests in Egypt. But most Americans lack the same ability to tune in to the broadcaster, which is based in Qatar, because cable and satellite companies in the United States have largely refused its requests to be carried.

headline: Napolitano Accuses Critics of Politicizing Border Issues
text: Sharpening a confrontation with Republicans over Southwest border enforcement, Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano said on Monday that crime and illegal crossings had dropped sharply along the border, and she accused lawmakers who say violence is out of control there of trying to “score political points.”

headline: Super Bowl Marketers Try to Score Points, Too
text: MOST marketers that typically advertise in the Super Bowl sell brands with broad appeal and long histories, the better to resonate with the mass audiences that watch the game each year.

headline: Obama’s Bid to End Oil Subsidies Revives Debate
text: WASHINGTON  When he releases his new budget in two weeks, President Obama will propose doing away with roughly $4 billion a year in subsidies and tax breaks for oil companies, in his third effort to eliminate federal support for an industry that remains hugely profitable.

headline: Treasury’s Warrior at the Negotiating Table
text: WASHINGTON — When David N. Miller joined the Treasury Department during the height of the financial crisis, the government’s bailout programs were not expected to break even, let alone turn a profit.

headline: Bush’s Daughter, in a Break, Endorses Gay Marriage
text: The Bush dynasty is no stranger to generational conflict: father and son differed over deposing Saddam Hussein, raising taxes and the role of the United Nations.

headline: Retiring Nicely After Betraying Public’s Trust
text: Guy J. Velella, a former state senator from the Bronx who died last week, was bidden farewell at a funeral service on Monday. His legacy, however, lives on. Among other things, Mr. Velella will be remembered for having turned a career of public service into one of public shame by taking bribes and going to jail for his corruption.

text: ORESTIADA, Greece  On a chilly night recently, a half-dozen young men huddled in the shadows of the tiny train station here, stamping their feet to stay warm, waiting, though they had no money, to board a train for Athens.

text: The grand jury testimony of Daniel J. Halloran III, the city councilman at the center of charges that a union slowdown left some neighborhoods snowbound after the Dec. 26 blizzard, was cut short on Monday as he and federal prosecutors argued a related matter before a judge.

text: Amanda Marcotte, left, of Pandagon and Mollie Ziegler Hemingway of GetReligion.org debate abortion and the Kermit Gosnell case.

headline: Report Lists Perils for Envoys After U.S. Leaves Iraq
text: WASHINGTON  The United States will not be able to protect its diplomats in Iraq adequately if it sticks to the plan to withdraw its last 50,000 troops by December, potentially hindering American efforts to reach out to the Iraqi people, according to a new report by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

headline: BMW Robbery Victim Is Called Trusting

headline: U.S. Pushes, but Reactors Are Lagging
text: WASHINGTON — In his State of the Union address, President Obama proposed giving the nuclear construction business a type of help it has never had, a role in a quota for clean energy. But recent setbacks in a hoped-for “nuclear renaissance” raise questions about how much of a role nuclear power can play.

headline: Hearst Agrees to Buy 100 Magazines From Lagardère
text: Hearst Corporation, the American magazine giant that publishes Cosmopolitan, Esquire and Good Housekeeping, said Monday that it had agreed to acquire more than 100 magazines from the French publisher Lagardère in a deal that would make Hearst the second-largest domestic magazine company and greatly expand its international footprint.

headline: Haiti Agrees to Issue Passport for Aristide, Lawyer Says
text: WASHINGTON  The Haitian government has agreed to issue a diplomatic passport to former President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, his lawyer said Monday, potentially dropping a major hurdle that has prevented Mr. Aristide from returning home after seven years in exile.

headline: U.S. Charges Fraud Scheme by 2 Fake Guggenheims and One Fake Countess
text: Of all the frauds charged in Manhattan federal court in recent years, few have offered as bizarre a cast of characters as those described in a complaint unsealed by prosecutors on Monday.

headline: G.O.P. Governors Take Aim at Teacher Tenure
text: Seizing on a national anxiety over poor student performance, many governors are taking aim at a bedrock tradition of public schools: teacher tenure.

headline: 10 Questions for Gene Sperling
text: Gene Sperling recently returned to the job of director of the National Economic Council, which he held during the Clinton administration. He sat down with John Harwood of the New York Times and CNBC to discuss the economic and budget outlook and what effect the turmoil in Egypt might have. Here is an edited and condensed transcript of their conversation.

headline: State Prisons and Medicaid to Face Cuts in Cuomo Budget
text: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo will seek to cut more than 3,000 prison beds, roll back scheduled spending increases on Medicaid and education by billions of dollars and make steep reductions to state operations, a move likely to lead to the loss of thousands of state jobs, according to people briefed on the budget he will unveil on Tuesday.

headline: Imam Stirs Confusion Regarding Islam Center
text: Two weeks after the developer of a controversial Islamic center and mosque planned near ground zero distanced himself from the imam who co-founded the project, the imam has raised confusion over who is in charge by suggesting that he would move the center to a less contentious space if an opportunity arose.

headline: More on Egypt and the U.S.
text: Mark Blumenthal of the Huffington Post links toward a different survey of Egyptian public opinion, this one by the pew Global Attitudes Project, which tells a completely different story. In contrast to the BBC study that we linked to this morning, which found relatively favorable attitudes toward the United States, the Pew poll finds that just 17 percent of Egyptians have a favorable view of the U.S. against 82 percent unfavorable. It also shows, again in contrast to the BBC study, that views of the United States declined somewhat between 2009 and 2010.

headline: U.S. Official With Egypt Ties to Meet With Mubarak
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has sent a diplomatic troubleshooter with close ties to Egypt on a mission to Cairo to meet with President Hosni Mubarak and other senior officials, as the administration struggles to gauge Mr. Mubarak’s intentions amid the fast-moving events there.

headline: Tuesday’s Forecast: Horrific
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Government budgets around the nation, already busted by the bad economy, now have a new nemesis: Mother Nature.

headline: When Microcredit Won’t Do
text: If you asked poverty experts to name the single most significant new concept in the field in the last few decades, chances are they would say microcredit.  Microcredit is the lending of very small amounts of money to very poor people to help them invest in things that have the potential to bring income later on — a loan of $50 to buy a sewing machine to make clothes, for instance, or piglets to raise and sell.  It reaches nearly 100 million clients in more than 100 countries.

headline: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Scrambles to Size Up ElBaradei
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama unexpectedly won the Nobel Peace Prize in 2009, one predecessor was quick to applaud his selection for the award.

headline: Apps Alter Reading on the Web
text: The DVR rocked the world of television by letting viewers skip commercials and build their own home viewing schedules. Now a handful of Web services and applications are starting to do much the same thing to online publishers.

headline: John Barry Dies at 77; Composed for Bond Films
text: John Barry, whose bold, jazzy scores for “From Russia With Love,” “Goldfinger” and nine other James Bond films put a musical stamp on one of the most successful film franchises of all time, and who won five Academy Awards as a composer for “Born Free,” “Dances With Wolves” and other films, died on Sunday in New York. He was 77.

headline: Sam Houston, We Have a Problem
text: Everything about Austin, a town of just 3,500 people on the banks of the crystalline Colorado River, was new. The very idea of being a part of the United States was still settling in: after all, in 1861 the American flag had been flying over the Lone Star state for just 15 years. Now it looked set to leave yet again.

headline: Smithsonian Official Defends Disputed Video’s Exhibit
text: WASHINGTON — A video that outraged some Roman Catholics and some members of Congress was suitable for inclusion in an exhibit at the National Portrait Gallery, a member of board that reviewed a decision to pull it from the show said Monday. But museum officials’ insufficient explanation of the work led to its hasty withdrawal, he said.

headline: State TV in Egypt Offers Murky Window Into Power Shift
text: CAIRO  As hundreds of Egyptian protesters filled Tahrir Square on Monday, many calling for their president to go into exile, one of the two state-owned television stations had its cameras focused elsewhere, capturing the steady flow of traffic on a Cairo bridge.

headline: $10 Million in Pay for Bank of America Chief
text: It was a tough year for Bank of America, what with the foreclosure mess and a sagging stock price. Its chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan, nonetheless received $10 million in his first year on the job.

headline: Pakistani Nuclear Arms Pose Challenge to U.S. Policy
text: WASHINGTON  New American intelligence assessments have concluded that Pakistan has steadily expanded its nuclear arsenal since President Obama came to office, and that it is building the capability to surge ahead in the production of nuclear-weapons material, putting it on a path to overtake Britain as the world’s fifth largest nuclear weapons power.

headline: Senate Passes Cuomo’s Property-Tax Cap
text: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s proposal to limit local property taxes won overwhelming approval from the State Senate on Monday, escalating the pressure on Democratic legislators in the Assembly who have expressed reservations about the bill.

headline: Debt Limit Follies
text: At a recent gathering of House Republicans, lawmakers made it clear that they intend to hold an increase in the nation’s debt limit hostage to major spending cuts.

headline: An End to Bush-Era Politics
text: Every White House since the days of President Jimmy Carter has had a political affairs office to assess the effects of policy on voters and make sure that presidents are aware of the nation’s political temperature. The office has grown in power alarmingly with each presidency, but the most recent Bush administration became so consumed with Republican politics that it crossed a legal red line, according to a new federal investigative report.

headline: Theft From PTA Is Suspected
text: The Police Department said on Monday that it was investigating whether the former treasurer of the PTA at Public School 29 in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, stole roughly $5,500 from the group’s account.

headline: Tuesday: Celebrity Guest Solver Mollie Katzen
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — So, I was sitting here wondering how to introduce today’s guest, when it occurred to me that what I needed was a really good segue. See if this works.

headline: Love Hurts, and for Some Couples, That’s the Point
text: “Gruesome Playground Injuries” — a blood-spattered twig of a play from the up-and-coming dramatist Rajiv Joseph — recalls that time in the 1960s when Hollywood was in thrall to what publicists liked to call “a different kind of love story.” Incarnated by a twitchy new breed of beauties that included Warren Beatty, Natalie Wood, Tuesday Weld and Anthony Perkins, a battalion of sensitive, damaged Romeos and Juliets took over American screens, writhing in romances that were more about pain than about pleasure, or perhaps the confusion of the two.

headline: Property Tax Ploy
text: Late Friday, Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York sent a radical bill to cap property taxes to the State Senate. It would devastate school districts in the state. The bill, which exempts New York City, was passed by the Senate on Monday.

headline: Difference Between No. 2 UConn And Third-Ranked Duke? 36 Points
text: STORRS, Conn.  For more than two seasons, the Connecticut women’s basketball team won every time it took the floor, peerless in history. Although its streak ended in December, the second-ranked Huskies are still the sport’s measuring stick.

headline: Mr. Pullman’s Compass
text: The austerity cuts in Britain  part of the government’s overly harsh deficit-reduction plan  have provoked many outcries, but few quite as eloquent as a speech given recently in Oxfordshire by Philip Pullman, author of the highly regarded trilogy “His Dark Materials.” The subject was the Oxford county council’s plan to stop financing 20 of its 43 libraries  because of cuts in national financing  and hope that they would be run instead by volunteers.

headline: Reach for the Skies

headline: G.M. Says Lawsuit Isn’t Affecting Mets

headline: The Quest for Dignity

headline: In the SEC, Winning on the Road Is Not Easy

headline: Dickey Is Happy for Some Security in New Deal
text: The knuckleballer R.A. Dickey was the best thing that happened to the Mets in 2011, emerging from a career on the fringe to go 11-9 with a 2.84 earned run average. He hustled in the field and on the bases, hit a robust .255 and impressed just about everyone around the team with his curiosity (a locker full of books), vocabulary and simple willingness to answer any and all questions.

headline: Somalia: Infighting Leaves 15 Dead

The shooting started when a government soldier tried to enter a hospital with a gun and was repelled by government security guards. A fierce firefight erupted, which killed soldiers and civilians in a nearby market.

headline: South Africa: Mandela Responds to Treatment for Respiratory Infection

Mr. Mandela went home Friday after spending two nights in the hospital.

headline: War Photographer Remembered at Paris Show
text: Among war photographers, the name Henri Huet once ranked alongside Robert Capa. He is remembered, by those who knew him, as among the bravest, the most soul stirring, the most tragic of his class of shooters. Now a new generation of Parisians and tourists have a chance to view his haunting work at “Henri Huet: Vietnam,” running Feb. 9 through April 3 at La Maison Européenne de la Photographie (5/7 rue de Fourcy; 33-1-44-78-75-00; www.mep-fr.org) in Paris’s Fourth Arrondissement.

headline: Helmut Lang’s Got a Brand New Bag
text: “I always carry my iPhone, keys, credit card and some gloss,” says Nicole Colovos, the co-designer for Helmut Lang. She and her husband, Michael, are gearing up for the first collection of bags to hit the stores since they took over the label in 2006. “We developed all new hardware and looked at bones and bird claws for inspiration and used hints of military finishes,” Michael says. Available this month, the bags come in tough washed creta leather and smooth napa and have a whole lot of zippers. Styles range from duffels and messengers to clutches and pouchettes — just the right complement to their edgy-yet-polished motorcycle-jacket-and-skinny-leather-pants aesthetic. The Syn, a spiraling half-clutch/half-shoulder bag made from Perch skin, blends Michael’s past as a commercial fisherman (straps have fisherman knots and braids) and Nicole’s penchant for utilitarian dressing. “We wanted to create something sculptural, in an interesting fabrication, yet keep it functional,” Nicole says. We couldn’t ask for more. Except maybe a shoe collection. Hint, hint.

text: If self-hurt and demotivational books ever become a publishing trend, you can bet that Sue Sylvester, the deliciously nasty cheerleading coach on the Fox musical comedy “Glee,” will have a best seller. In the meantime, Jane Lynch, who has won a Golden Globe and an Emmy Award for her portrayal of that character, hopes to take a more inspirational tone in a book of her own.

headline: King of Jordan Dismisses His Cabinet
text: AMMAN, Jordan  King Abdullah II of Jordan fired his government on Tuesday after weeks of demonstrations challenging his regime, part of a wave of demands of public accountability sweeping the Arab world that has brought throngs of demonstrators into the streets of Egypt.

headline: Eyes on Mubarak as Protests Grow
text: David Kirkpatrick, The Times's Cairo bureau chief, reports on the response by the Egyptian military and the Mubarak administration to the street rallies across Egypt.

text: BlackRock, the world’s largest asset manager, has awarded nearly $13 million in stock and options to its chief executive, Laurence D. Fink.

text: Indebted slaves to fashion.(Debt + Fashionista)

headline: 2012 Hopefuls Stake Out Positions on Egypt
text: Some potential Republican rivals to President Obama in the 2012 race are cautiously staking out positions on the unrest in Egypt, which is likely to figure prominently in discussions of foreign policy in the coming months.Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, said on “Good Morning America” on Tuesday that the president of Egypt, Hosni Mubarak, should leave office, and he urged Mr. Obama and his administration to signal more support for the protesters’ aims.

headline: Storm Stops Travelers as It Moves Across U.S.
text: A paralyzing 2,000-mile swath of winter at its snowy, icy, messy worst pushed eastward across the United States on Tuesday, disrupting the rhythms of everyday life and punctuating this season’s recurring lesson that humankind has no dominion over nature.

headline: Ever-Larger Protests Flood Cairo Streets
text: Hundreds of thousands of people in Tahrir Square on Tuesday demanded the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak, despite government efforts to block access to Cairo.

headline: Overkill Report: Lipton, the Angry Iced Tea
text: Eminem to Appear in Iced Tea AdIced tea sure has gotten angrier in the years since Don Meredith hawked Lipton. Eminem (or Mr. Marshall Mathers, as he is known around here) will appear in a Lipton Brisk commercial. He will appear in claymation form, meaning a duet with Gumby cannot be far behind. Our goal here at the Fifth Down is to question Eminem’s musical integrity in the hope that he responds by insulting us in a future rap. There’s no word yet whether rapper Ice T will endorse any candy-coated chocolate products in response to Eminem’s commercial.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Less Expensive Concierge Care
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Third Time Won’t Be the Charm
text: LOS ANGELES— Surely this will shock – shock! – everyone in Hollywood, but it seems even bad publicity is good publicity. Ricky Gervais, whose acerbic performance as the host of the Golden Globes overshadowed the awards themselves (quick: what won best comedy?), was asked to host the show again.

headline: Democrats Pick Charlotte for 2012 Convention
text: The Democratic Party announced Tuesday that Charlotte, N.C., will be the site of its 2012 national convention, with the city winning out over St. Louis, Minneapolis and Cleveland as the place to formally kick off President Obama’s re-election bid.

headline: S.&P. Proposes New Method for Rating Banks
text: Standard & Poor’s, one of the largest credit rating agencies, could soon overhaul its method for rating banks located across the world, according to a proposal that the company circulated recently.

headline: Rocco Landesman Weighs in, Again, on Arts Organizations
text: Last week, Rocco Landesman, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, prompted an outcry when he publicly suggested that perhaps the supply of arts organizations exceeded the demand for them. On Monday, Mr. Landesman weighed in on the debate his comments has generated.

headline: Dish Network Poised to Land DBSD for $1 Billion
text: After a drawn-out court battle, Dish Network is set to acquire the satellite operator DBSD North America for about $1 billion as it emerges from bankruptcy. Dish Network will also make a loan of $87.5 million available to DBSD.

headline: In the Rough, a Pair of Ferraris Seek Auction Records
text: As Rob Sass noted in his recap of last month’s Scottsdale, Ariz., vintage-car auctions, a faded paint job or a loose muffler might add to, not detract from, a vehicle’s allure. Cars in original but well-preserved condition fetched high premiums at the five major Scottsdale auctions, a trend that most likely will continue.

headline: For Top College Recruits, a Day No Longer Set in Stone
text: National signing day has transformed into a ritualistic process as much a part of college football as Notre Dame players’ slapping the “Play Like a Champion Today” plaque or the Ohio State marching band’s performing the Script Ohio.

headline: An Audio Guide to the Footsteps of Heroes
text: It might not quite feel like the Hollywood Walk of Fame — even aside from the lack of palm trees — but the downtown corridor between Battery Park and City Hall is a well-beaten path where heroes and celebrities have paraded to the cheers and confetti of the city’s residents.

headline: The Un-COLA Era
text: I’m still having fun with the Atlanta Fed’s sticky-price CPI data. These data go back to the late 1960s, and offer an interesting contrast between then and now.

headline: Filling In the Blanks on Himalayan Glaciers
text: Last year, the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change ended up with a bit of mud on its face when it had to retract an alarming claim in its landmark 2007 assessment: that the probability of Himalayan glaciers “disappearing by the year 2035 and perhaps sooner is very high.” Climate skeptics pilloried the panel for including what proved to be an unsubstantiated and, glaciologists said, unlikely figure. Rajendra K. Pachauri, the head of the panel, called the inclusion of the statistic a “regrettable error.”

headline: Space Zombies, Prepare to Meet Your Mower
text: Is there a place in mass entertainment for dismemberment, dementia, wails of anguish and the infernal corruption of children? Is there a place for a vision of future humanity in the grip of an eldritch religion that sees salvation in alien mutation? Is there a place for titillation in the form of gore, for human (and once-human) offal as an acceptable form of set decoration?

headline: Back to Iowa, Leaving a City in His Bones
text: Leaving New York is easy. Feeling New York leave you is the hard part.

headline: Baghdad Bureau Chief Answers Readers’ Questions on Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — Thanks to everyone who wrote, especially Jimmy from Dallas who asked if those of us working here “realize you are read.” We do, even if Iraq has receded so far from the center of public attention in the United States — as I noted about President Obama’s State of the Union address — that it can sometimes feel as if it has been forgotten, overshadowed by economic troubles at home, the renewed focus on Afghanistan and all the turmoil elsewhere in the world.

headline: Report From Tahrir
text: Especially at first, the people at Tahrir were overwhelmingly young men. But now the crowd is democratizing, and today there are lots of women and indeed lots of families making a party out of it. At right, a photo of the youngest protester I saw.

headline: Historic Black Enclave in Queens Gains Landmark Status
text: The predominantly African-American neighborhood of Addisleigh Park, an enclave of brick and stucco houses in southeast Queens and the former home of luminaries like Jackie Robinson, W.E.B. Du Bois and Ella Fitzgerald, is now a historic district, New York City’s 102nd.

headline: Following in the Footsteps of a Suburban Fisher
text: Roland Kays, curator of mammals at the New York State Museum and author of “Mammals of North America,” writes from Albany, where he is comparing the behavior of fishers in urban and wild settings.

headline: Court Counselor Sentenced to Four Years for Sex Assaults
text: A juvenile-justice counselor who almost got a no-jail plea deal last year in the sexual assaults of three young girls under his care was sentenced Tuesday to four years in prison, the maximum allowed, after a jury convicted him on sexual assault charges last month.

headline: Pyrrhic Recoveries
text: John Dizard hails the Estonian recovery, even while saying that it’s not a useful role model for other countries. But I’m puzzled by his dismissal of my assertion that it will be many years before Estonia and its neighbors make up the lost ground.

headline: In Mexico, Massacres and Claims of Progress
text: ACAPULCO, Mexico  Only a week into the new year, 15 human heads sat outside a gleaming shopping center on the other side of the lush hills that frame this seaside resort’s big tourist hotels. Within hours, several bodies turned up in a taxi and elsewhere, bringing the number of victims to 33 in a single weekend, scattered around a side of town few visitors see.

headline: EMI Taken Over by Citigroup, Making a Sale More Likely
text: Updated at 8:02 p.m. | Citigroup on Tuesday seized control of EMI from Terra Firma, ending the private equity firm’s disastrous ownership of the famous music company and most likely accelerating the search for new owners.

headline: The Rangers at the Top of the Stretch
text: Fifty-two games down, 30 to go, the All-Star break behind us and the final third of the regular season looming ahead. This is the time when the hockey gets serious and you start checking the standings — the right time to look at how the Rangers are doing, man by man. Their official N.H.L. record is 29-20-3, which really means they’re 29-23, but that’s still a quite-good .558 winning percentage. Coach John Tortorella’s team just might be going places, especially now that they’re starting to get their injured forwards back (Ryan Callahan and Vinny Prospal are the first, with Brandon Dubinsky and Eric Christensen soon to follow). Tortorella’s emphasis on conditioning has paid off in strong third-period performances (the Rangers lead the league in comeback wins with seven, two more than anyone else), and he has mellowed somewhat from the volcanic-tempered coach of the previous season.

headline: Natural Gas: It’s Not Easy Being Green
text: Natural gas has long enjoyed a clean-and-green reputation — at least in comparison with coal, its brethren fossil fuel and most immediate substitute in the electricity-generation game. And of course, T. Boone Pickens and others would like to see natural gas replace oil as the chief source for the nation’s transportation fuels.

headline: Sharks’ Cavanaugh Remembered for his Life, Not his Illness
text: The hockey world has paused a few times over the past weeks to remember former San Jose Sharks player Tom Cavanaugh.

headline: Discovery Names New General Manager for TLC
text: Bolstered by Kate Gosselin and Sarah Palin, TLC has been one of the most talked-about cable channels in recent years and one of the flagship channels for its parent company, Discovery Communications.

headline: Agency Investigates 400,000 Nissan and Infiniti S.U.V.’s for Suspension Failures
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety is investigating structural failures involving the front suspension on 400,000 Nissan Pathfinders and their sibling, the Infinti QX4.

headline: Ethics Committee Names Special Counsel to Aid in Ensign Investigation
text: The Senate Ethics Committee announced Tuesday that it has named a special counsel to help determine whether to bring formal charges against Senator John Ensign, the Nevada Republican who has been accused of using his political influence to help cover up an affair he had with the wife of a former top aide.

headline: Citigroup Takes Over EMI
text: Citigroup has taken over EMI, the British music label of the Beatles and Radiohead, under a restructuring of its debt, EMI announced on Tuesday.

headline: Walking Down Memory Lane
text: In healthy adults, the hippocampus — a part of the brain important to the formation of memories — begins to atrophy when we’re about 55 or 60. Now a team of psychologists has published an intriguing report suggesting that the hippocampus can be modestly expanded, and memory improved, in older adults by means of a low-tech, low-cost intervention with very few unpleasant side effects: regular walking.

headline: Mohamed ElBaradei Memoir Rushed to Publication
text: As Mohamed ElBaradei has emerged to become the face of the opposition in Cairo, the world has scrambled to figure him out.

headline: Explaining Egypt
text: [May 8, 3:50 p.m. | Updated | Researchers report in the journal Science that rising temperatures have hurt corn and wheat harvests in some countries, but not others (including the United States). They also fond that gains in other crops related to climate shifts and rising carbon dioxide levels have largely offset the overall impact of climate change so far. In a news report in Science, John Reilly, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology specializing in climate, cast doubt on the findings.]

headline: With Cuts, Cuomo Offers Shrunken Budget
text: ALBANY  Declaring New York State “functionally bankrupt,” Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo proposed a $132.9 billion budget on Tuesday that would reduce year-to-year spending for the first time in more than a decade, slash projected spending on education and health care, and slice the budget for state agencies by more than half a billion dollars in the next fiscal year.

headline: Free Time for Parents
text: For months after my son was born I kept a running time tally in my head of time I no longer had to myself. Television I wasn’t watching. Books I wasn’t reading. Conversations I wasn’t having. Sleep I wasn’t getting.

headline: Victoria Clark Joins ‘Sister Act’ on Broadway
text: Victoria Clark (“The Light in the Piazza”) will play Mother Superior in the coming Broadway production of “Sister Act,” the show’s producers announced on Tuesday. The musical, based on the 1992 Whoopi Goldberg film, has a score by Alan Menken, lyrics by Glenn Slater, and a book by Cheri and Bill Steinkellner. It will be directed by Jerry Zaks. The show is to begin previews on March 24 at the Broadway Theater, with opening night scheduled for April 20. As previously announced, the Olivier Award nominee Patina Miller will reprise her role as Deloris Van Cartier, the undercover nun with a disco past. She originated the role when the West End production of “Sister Act” opened at the London Palladium in June 2009.

headline: 'The Whipping Man'
text: A scene from the Manhattan Theater Club's production of Matthew Lopez's play. (Video courtesy of MTC)

headline: Iraq: Department of Clarification
text: BAGHDAD – The United States military in Iraq issued a statement on Tuesday that was bound to draw attention. “Iraq agrees to purchase 18 F-16 multirole fighter aircraft,” the headline went.

headline: His Sport Dismissed, Venezuelan Is Now Star
text: SAN DIEGO  Hugo Chávez, the president of Venezuela, is no friend of golf. He has called it a “bourgeois sport” played primarily by lazy, rich people in carts. He has closed six of the country’s courses and said the government should appropriate private urban land for public housing. “Do you mean to tell me this is a people’s sport?” he said in 2009. “It is not.”

headline: Checkmate for Gambit
text: This is the last post on the Gambit blog. Articles on chess will continue to appear in the Crosswords, Games & Cartoons section of The New York Times Web site.

headline: All in a Day’s Work: Developing ‘Soft Skills’ for Job Success
text: Overview | What skills do students need to excel and succeed in the professional world? In this lesson, students distinguish between “hard” and “soft” skills that are needed in the workplace and engage in activities that help them practice those skills. They then create a handbook of rules for the workplace for peers.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Solaris’
text: In this week’s Critics’ Picks, A. O. Scott looks back at Andrei Tarkovsky‘s rumination on memory and loss, “Solaris.” The film explores the boundaries between consciousness and reality within a science-fiction narrative. Mr. Scott appreciates how “Solaris” uses outer space to explore humanity and look at how “every individual human being’s emotions — love, grief, alienation, nostalgia — are as vast as the universe itself,” he says. Have you seen “Solaris?” Please share your thoughts.

headline: New President for Struggling Gap Inc. Unit
text: The head of Gap North America is leaving the company, one of a number of changes that Gap announced for its flagship brand after years of declining sales at the division.

headline: Whether Large or Small, They’re Big Dogs on Campus
text: Dr. Evil had his cat, Mr. Bigglesworth; President Obama has Bo; even Jabba the Hut had an interstellar critter named Salacious Crumb. And at the seats of power in some of New York City’s private schools, there’s sometimes something fluffy curled around the chair legs.

headline: Mercedes-Benz C63 AMG Resumes M3 Hunt
text: Daimler AG announced a lightly restyled and revised version of its Mercedes-Benz C63 AMG sedan on Tuesday. This should be welcome news for performance-minded followers of the German brand, who may have experienced some agita following its recent return to a 4-cylinder C-Class.

text: Jimmy Bradley, the chef and an owner of the Red Cat and the Harrison, two restaurants in Manhattan, said he is recovering from oral cancer, and will not be moving forward with plans to open J & S Food Hall in the Nolitan Hotel.

headline: Awaiting Health Law’s Prognosis
text: With a court decision on Monday declaring the health care law unconstitutional and Republicans intent on repealing at least parts of it, thousands of Americans with major illnesses are facing the renewed prospect of losing their health insurance coverage.

text: Term used to denote the absence of a politically and economically dominant country or bloc.

text: The NFL Network covered the Packers portion Super Bowl Media Day live this morning, allowing fans to experience the thrill of being a reporter: milling around and asking repetitive questions of bored athletes.

headline: In a Warm Room, the Globe Feels Hotter
text: As any climate scientist will attest, proof of global warming is found not in the warmth or cold of any given day or even a particular year, but in long-term trends in temperature averaged across the entire planet.

headline: Health Insurance Kicks In for Congress
text: Government-subsidized health insurance – one of many perks of serving in Congress – kicked in on Tuesday for new members.

headline: Diplomatic Scramble as Ally Is Pushed to the Exit
text: WASHINGTON — Last Sunday at 2 p.m., a blue-and-white Air Force jet left Andrews Air Force Base bound for Cairo. On board was Frank G. Wisner, an adroit ex-diplomat whom President Obama had asked hours before to undertake a supremely delicate mission: nudging President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt out of power.

headline: Guiding the Leap From Employee to Entrepreneur
text: Last week I wrote about Terri Maxwell, founder of Succeed on Purpose, a business incubator that specializes in transforming former employees, often layoff victims, into entrepreneurs. These would-be business owners face many common challenges because of the attitudes and habits they’ve developed while collecting a paycheck. Dismantling those employee mindsets is a priority for Ms. Maxwell.

text: Photographs from Egypt, Pakistan and Greece.

headline: BP Heads to Arbitration Over Rosneft Venture
text: A group of wealthy Russian businessmen won a British court order on Tuesday blocking BP‘s proposed joint venture with Russia’s state-run Rosneft to explore for oil in the Arctic and sending the dispute to arbitration.

headline: Focusing on the Stress of Prostate Cancer
text: Helping men cope with the stress of prostate cancer surgery before the operation may speed up both their physical and psychological recovery, new research suggests.

headline: Al Jazeera Finds New Paths In U.S.
text: New ways to watch Al Jazeera English in the United States keep popping up — but not on cable or satellite systems.

headline: Charting Lil B
text: Lil B is a member of the Bay Area rap group The Pack and a social network-obsessed solo artist who posts a dizzying array of songs, mixtapes and videos online. The artist Andrew Kuo charts one of his recent concerts at the Highline Ballroom in New York, where he performed some of his spacey ambient-rap music with off-the-cuff thoughts on religion, fashion and the Internet. Check out some of Lil B’s latest music here.

headline: Sanofi Plans to Raise Genzyme Bid
text: Sanofi-Aventis plans to raise its takeover bid for Genzyme by several dollars a share, in an effort to clinch a deal for the biopharmaceutical company, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Tuesday.

headline: Bloomberg Is Criticized for Arizona Gun Show Scrutiny

Bloomberg of New York City recently conducted at a Phoenix gun show, in which undercover detectives found two gun sellers apparently violating federal law.

headline: A Big Day for Red Shirt Nation
text: The news that Liverpool had agreed on the fee to buy striker Andy Carroll from Newcastle on Monday night sent so many visitors to  the club’s Web site that it crashed. But that might have been the only thing that went wrong at Anfield on Monday.

headline: Google Takes Street View Into Art Museums
text: Now that Google has conquered a majority of the earth’s major streets with its Google Street View project, the company is starting to move inside. It’s  creating the Google Art Project, a virtual equivalent of 17 major art museums, including the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Museum of Modern Art in New York, the Tate Britain and National Gallery in London, and the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam, among many others.

headline: Hollywood Foreign Press: Nice Try, Ricky
text: LOS ANGELES— There’s no such thing as bad publicity, as they say, and there’s no end to a he-said, they-said argument, especially when it generates more publicity. The Hollywood Foreign Press Association has responded to comments that Ricky Gervais made in Heat magazine, that the organization invited him back as a Golden Globes host even after his controversial barbed performance.

headline: Who Am I? Tuesday Edition
text: All week, the Fifth Down blog will post “Who Am I?” quizzes to test your knowledge of Packers and Steelers of the past. Peeking at Pro Football Reference just ruins the fun for everyone, so don’t do it!

headline: Risk of Inflation Puts Europe in a Tough Spot
text: Inflation in the euro zone is rising even before the European Central Bank has had a chance to end the European debt crisis. Consumer prices rose at an annual rate of 2.4 percent in January, according to European Union statistics released Monday, significantly above the central bank’s target of about 2 percent.

headline: Ready for the Next Argentine Invasion?
text: TORRONTÉS has been touted as the hottest thing to arrive from Argentina since the tango. Or at least since malbec. It’s a grape, and a white wine, and some say it will be as popular in the United States as pinot grigio.

text: Among the legal commentariat, which blogs its instant analysis after each turn in the health care litigation, one assertion in Monday’s ruling against the law by Judge Roger Vinson is receiving particular attention.

text: Huge swaths of Port-au-Prince were in ruins after an earthquake, and thousands of people were feared dead.

headline: Party Committees Burdened With Debt Heading into 2012
text: One measure of the intensity of the 2010 midterm election is that all of the major party organizations enter the next two years burdened with millions of dollars in debt even as they ramp up for presidential-year campaigns.

headline: Chanel Bridal Shot
text: What is happening in this picture, taken Jan. 24 in the Chanel studio? Karl Lagerfeld is holding the gold-embroidered train of Kristen McMenamy’s wedding dress while a seamstress makes an adjustment to the back. Ms. McMenamy has just told Mr. Lagerfeld that she won’t have a problem with the weight of the train if the neckline is opened a bit. That’s apparently what the atelier did before the show the next morning.

headline: Buzz Tracker
text: Fabulous Fab Fights Back Fabrice Tourre, the Goldman Sachs trader at the center of the Abacus controversy, is seeking information from financial institutions as part of his defense against a Securities and Exchange Commission lawsuit. He is seeking documents from the Royal Bank of Scotland and the hedge fund Magnetar Capital Partners among others. “The subpoenas seek relevant, non-privileged information demonstrating the sophistication and experience of the very entities who the S.E.C. alleges were misled, and the limited number of documents Mr. Tourre now seeks are thus critical to his defense,” says his filing in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Bloomberg News

headline: 11.2 Million Illegal Immigrants in U.S. in 2010, Report Says; No Change From ’09
text: About 11.2 million illegal immigrants were living in the United States in 2010, a number essentially unchanged from the previous year, according to a report published Tuesday by the Pew Hispanic Center, a nonpartisan research organization in Washington.

headline: Signing Day Q. and A. With Tom Lemming
text: Tom Lemming of CBS Sports is a leading college football recruiting expert, who will be featured during Wednesday’s signing day coverage on the CBS College Sports network. During a phone call, he answered a few questions about which teams were going to be happy on Wednesday and why the country’s No. 1 recruit is keeping people waiting to hear his decision.

headline: Playing to Hedge Funds, a Trophy Rises in Midtown
text: When the developer Harry Macklowe contemplated building a boutique office tower with unparalleled amenities at 510 Madison Avenue in the late 2000s, he expected it would be filled with hedge funds and other financial sector tenants who would pay rents well above $100 per square foot.

headline: More on Spotting A.T.M. Skimmers
text: To help readers better protect themselves from thieves who want to swipe their sensitive debit card information, we’ve shared pictures in the past of how to spot skimming devices on A.T.M.’s.

headline: The Invisible Devin Harris
text: New Jersey’s Devin Harris is entering the prime of his career, and yet a number of factors –- the sheer number of talented point guards in the league, an age that puts him just outside fetish range for a young player, and he plays for the 15-34 Nets -– have almost completely obscured him from public view. The Nets are a headline fixture this season, but almost exclusively for rumors related to Carmelo Anthony’s inevitable exodus from Denver. In those reports, rarely is Harris referred to as anything more than a salary-matching asset. It’s as if, because he’s not 22 years old with a lifetime of basketball ahead of him, Harris’ once-high profile has been all but erased.

headline: Best Western Offers New Labels Within Its Brand
text: Best Western has announced that this week it is designating two upscale tiers under its brand. In addition to Best Western, travelers now will be able to reserve rooms in Best Western Plus and Best Western Premier.

headline: Red Bull Takes Lead as Winter Testing Begins
text: Winter testing for the Formula One season began on Tuesday in Valencia, Spain, with the Red Bull team and its driver, Sebastian Vettel, world champions, setting the fastest times of the day.

text: Winter testing for the Formula One season began on Tuesday in Valencia, Spain, with the Red Bull team and its driver, Sebastian Vettel, world champions, setting the fastest times of the day.

headline: Report Puts a Number on Counterfeit Jerseys
text: Few sporting events generate as much passion – and spending – as the Super Bowl. Whether it’s T-shirts, televisions or Terrible Towels, retailers of all stripes try to cash in.

headline: The High Low | Asprey Scarf Belt

headline: Producer of Nissan Leaf’s Home Charger Strikes Distribution Deal
text: With the goal of making home-charger installation as easy as rigging up track lighting, a new partnership was announced Tuesday between Milbank Manufacturing — an electrical-equipment metering and distribution company — and AeroVironment, the official home-charger producer for the Nissan Leaf electric vehicle.

headline: An Interview With a ‘Genius’
text: LOS ANGELES — Does Jerry Bruckheimer throw around superlatives casually? (Don’t answer.) On Monday, Mr. Bruckheimer, the big-budget-entertainment producer, hosted a lunch for Geoffrey Rush to celebrate his performance in “The King’s Speech,” and called Mr. Rush – who also happens to star as Captain Barbossa in Mr. Bruckheimer’s “Pirates of the Caribbean” series – a “genius.”

headline: JBS Chief Is Replaced After Failed Sara Lee Bid
text: Losing out on a takeover battle appears to have consequences at JBS.

headline: Zarela Is Closing
text: Zarela, the Mexican restaurant that has been a fixture at 953 Second Avenue (50th Street) for 23 years, will close after dinner on Feb. 13.

headline: Report Says Secret Jails, Run by Iraq, Stay Open
text: BAGHDAD  Iraqi security forces controlled directly by Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki continue to hold and to torture detainees in secret jails despite his vows last year to end such practices, according to a statement from Human Rights Watch released Tuesday.

headline: Phantoms of the Mind, No Longer Shocking but No Less Haunting
text: Judith Guest’s 1976 novel, “Ordinary People,” and the 1980 film adaptation starring Timothy Hutton, were groundbreaking because they underscored Ms. Guest’s title. Mental illness could occur in the most ordinary families, these works suggested. It could happen to anyone.

headline: Gorman’s No. 1 Priority Is Fixing Fixed-Income
text: Two weeks after Morgan Stanley reported a loss in its fixed-income group, the firm’s chief executive, James P. Gorman, told investors at the firm’s financial services conference that fixing the unit was his No. 1 priority.

headline: A Dexterous Sextet Balances Trills and Tempos
text: Many new-music ensembles specialize in a particular aesthetic, but Eighth Blackbird, an adventurous sextet, explored contrasting corners of the compositional spectrum in its concert at Zankel Hall on Monday evening.

headline: The Paradox of Corporate Taxes
text: The Carnival Corporation wouldn’t have much of a business without help from various branches of the government. The United States Coast Guard keeps the seas safe for Carnival’s cruise ships. Customs officers make it possible for Carnival cruises to travel to other countries. State and local governments have built roads and bridges leading up to the ports where Carnival’s ships dock.

headline: Back at the Keyboard After a Difficult Interlude
text: Le Poisson Rouge is most closely identified with the world of new music, but since its founding it has also regularly featured traditional piano recitals. Its first classical music show, in 2008, featured the pianist Simone Dinnerstein playing the music of Bach and George Crumb, and the roster has since included Jonathan Biss in 2009, Marc-André Hamelin in September and, on Monday evening, the charismatic Hélène Grimaud.

headline: Clueless in Cairo
text: So President Hosni Mubarak has announced that he won’t run for office again in the September elections. That would have been a historic decision if he had made it two weeks ago, and it might have avoided the present mess. But today, it’s too little, too late. And if the White House has devoted its political capital to getting Mubarak to agree to such a half-measure, then I fear that there’s a measure of cluelessness on both sides.

headline: Senate Democrats to Allow Early Vote on Health Care Repeal
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats, answering a challenge by Republicans pushing to overturn President Obama’s health care overhaul, said the Senate would vote soon, perhaps as early as Wednesday, on a repeal measure, and that they were certain that it would be defeated.

headline: Senate Banking Staffer Joins Reed Smith
text: Mark Oesterle, the chief counsel to Republicans on the Senate Banking Committee, has joined Reed Smith’s financial regulatory group in the law firm’s Washington office.

headline: Post-Minimalism and Folk Ballads Fuel a Composer
text: Like most composers, Julia Wolfe is often in two places at once psychically: working on new pieces (with working defined as anything from cogitating and experimenting to actually putting the notes on paper) but also seeing that the backlist is getting attention. In recent weeks she has been putting the finishing touches on “Iron Maiden,” a new solo work for the percussionist Evelyn Glennie, and working on “Combat de Boxe,” for the Asko Ensemble of the Netherlands. And she has been gathering thoughts for a work for the Ethel string quartet and a vocalist.

headline: How Good Is That PMI Number?
text: A good manufacturing survey result. Mostly for my own edification, I thought I’d try to figure out how good that number really is. So, using FRED — which now makes it easy to take quarterly averages of monthly data, although the scatterplots aren’t quite there yet — we can plot PMI against the growth rate of GDP:

headline: Senate Won’t Allow Earmarks in Spending Bills
text: Bowing to the inevitable, Senator Daniel K. Inouye, the chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, announced Tuesday that the panel would not allow pet spending projects known as earmarks to be included in this year’s appropriations bills.

headline: Eugenio Arango, Cuban-Born Musician Known as Totico, Dies at 76
text: Eugenio Arango, better known as Totico, a Cuban-born percussionist and singer who was one of the most celebrated figures in the drumming, dancing and singing culture of New York rumba, died on Jan. 21 in the Bronx, where he lived. He was 76.

headline: And Now a Clarification From Ricky Gervais
text: LOS ANGELES — …And the headlines just keep coming. Ricky Gervais has offered a clarification to his remarks in Heat magazine. It wasn’t the Hollywood Foreign Press Association that suggested he might like to come back and barb them again; it was NBC, which broadcasts the Golden Globes.

headline: Comcast and Time Warner Sign Online Streaming Deal
text: In a first-of-its-kind deal, Comcast and Time Warner have signed a new contract that covers the online streaming of channels like TNT, TBS, CNN, and the Cartoon Network.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'The Whipping Man'
text: Matthew Lopez comments on a scene from his play.

headline: ‘The Bachelor’ Lifts ABC
text: ABC topped the ratings on Monday night as “The Bachelor” delivered its largest audience of the season, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The two-hour episode drew an average of 9.5 million viewers, leading at 8 p.m. but trailing at 9 behind CBS’s repeats of “Two and a Half Men” (11.2 million) and “Mike & Molly” (9.1 million). Despite a lineup of all reruns, CBS placed second over all. In third place, Fox broadcast a new episode of “Human Target” at 8 (7.8 million) followed by the season finale of “Lie to Me” at 9 (7.1 million). NBC was fourth with “Chuck” (5.6 million) and “The Cape” (5.3 million), but it won at 10 p.m. with “Harry’s Law” (10.9 million).

headline: Rosenfeld Returns to Lazard From Rothschild
text: Lazard said on Tuesday that it had rehired Gerald Rosenfeld as a senior executive, years after the banker left and joined a rival, Rothschild North America.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Egypt, Greece and Pakistan.

headline: Found: The Owners of That Mysterious Scooter
text: The New York City police on Tuesday solved the case of the serviceable and unsecured cream-colored Vespa that had been left for months in front of 1 Sutton Place South without being driven away, ticketed, towed or taken.

text: A chronology of Hosni Mubarak’s 30-year rule in Egypt and subsequent fall from power.

headline: Obama Urges Quick Transition in Egypt
text: Updated On Tuesday night, just hours after Hosni Mubarak announced he would not seek re-election to the presidency of Egypt, President Obama declared that an “orderly transition” in Egypt “must begin now,” but he stopped short of demanding that Mr. Mubarak leave office immediately. Read more…

headline: Why Dinan Worries About Fate of Small Hedge Funds
text: PALM BEACH, Fla. — For the head of a multibillion-dollar hedge fund, James G. Dinan worries a lot about the fate of the industry’s littlest players.

headline: A Place of Mystery and Elixirs
text: I KNEW I was lost within minutes of setting foot in the grooming and fragrance outpost MiN New York, a naïf in need of a road map.

text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#221", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

headline: Antarctic Cruise Ship Has Close Scrape
text: Yet another Antarctic cruise ship has a jarring scrape.

headline: Humans, Who Once Buried Their Treasures, Now Bury Their Dangers
text: I am tempted to call “Into Eternity” the most interesting documentary, and one of the most disturbing films, of the year so far, but such a pronouncement, always dubious in early February, seems especially absurd in this case. The film, directed by Michael Madsen — a Danish Conceptual artist, not the American tough-guy actor — takes an unusually long view. Mr. Madsen’s ruminative, even-toned narration is directed not at present-day critics but at viewers who may happen upon this visual artifact at some remote date in the future, as much as 100,000 years from now.

headline: The Details on Corporate Taxes
text: My column this week mentions several companies that have paid relatively little in corporate taxes in the last five years. Each company explained to me that it was complying with all tax laws, and I have no doubt that every one is.

headline: With No Charlie Sheen, CBS Mulls Its Monday Lineup
text: With Charlie Sheen, the star of the hit CBS comedy “Two and a Half Men,” now in rehabilitation for his persistent problems with addiction, the initial reaction at the network  and at the show’s production company, Warner Brothers  has been relief.

headline: Packers President’s Labor Perspective
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. -– Green Bay Packers President Mark Murphy has a unique perspective on the N.F.L.’s current labor strife. A former player, Murphy was the Washington Redskins’ union representative and a member of the players’ negotiating committee during the early 1980’s when the N.F.L. was also in the throes of a labor battle.

headline: Antiquities Chief Says Sites Are Largely Secure
text: A vast majority of Egypt’s museums and archaeological sites are secure and have not been looted, Zahi Hawass, Egypt’s chief antiquities official, said in a telephone interview on Tuesday. He also rejected comparisons between the current situation in Egypt and scenes of chaos and discord that resulted in the destruction of artifacts in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Competition for Preschool
text: I moved to the suburbs so that I would not have to put myself through preschool admissions. Yes, you read that right; I did it for me more than my children. I knew I didn’t have the stamina or ego strength to get through a process that weeds out three-year-olds based on their academic potential.

headline: Toasty Coasters to Protect and Serve
text: What do you mean by “toast”? These cork coasters from the Museum of Modern Art cover two definitions. They look like slices of bread and come in a plastic bag to suggest a loaf of supermarket multigrain. But then, of course, they hold your wine, beer or spirits after you lift a glass in celebration. They also double as trivets for a hot dish of hors d’oeuvres to go with the drinks.

headline: Dining Calendar
