headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Salumi, Cheese and Beer at a New Greenpoint Shop
text: Eastern District, the name of this spacious new store, was what they once called the industrial area of Brooklyn encompassing parts of Greenpoint, Bushwick and Williamsburg, said Beth Lewand, who owns the store, along with her husband, Chris Gray. A former Polish butcher shop, it’s lined with shelves and counters that feature about 50 cheeses and many cured meats, mostly American; and sweets including cupcakes from Robicelli’s in Sunset Park in flavors like Creamsicle and almond mocha truffle. They stock about 100 different beers and have a rotating selection on tap for filling growlers. And the shelves are lined with condiments and snacks, mostly bearing Brooklyn labels. They also sell cheese boards from Daskam & Dworkis, furniture makers nearby, who fashion the boards from scrap wood and barter them to Eastern District for cheese.

headline: Maple Syrup Slightly Spiked, and Vinegars With a Past
text: Aging maple syrup in charred-oak barrels used for bourbon has become something of a trend. Mikuni, a Seattle importer and distributor, uses barrels from Tuthilltown Spirits in Gardiner, N.Y., for its Noble Tonic 01, a maple syrup with a subtly spiked edge, and the flask-like bottle is so handsome I would put it on my breakfast table without decanting it into a pitcher. Once the syrup has been bottled, the company uses the same barrels to age 10-year-old Spanish sherry vinegar for another six months for Noble Tonic 03, giving it a more deeply mellow complexity. Noble Tonic 02 is a maple syrup flavored with vanilla and chamomile. They also age French chardonnay vinegar with Egyptian lemon, similar to Meyer lemon, for an added citric touch in their Noble Tonic 04.

headline: In Las Vegas, a Good Story Helps Sell Expensive Sakes
text: ERIC SWANSON was on a mission. He needed to track down the sake of the gods. Each time the Lunar New Year rolls around, casinos in Las Vegas begin bracing for an influx of “whales” from Asia — high-rolling gamblers who, when dining and drinking between marathon bouts at the gaming tables, tend to specialize in the grandest of gestures. When they’re eating at the top Japanese restaurants in town, the whales don’t want nice little $20 (or even $200) bottles of sake. The sake should be ambrosial, sure, but what they really want is something flagrantly expensive and difficult to find.

headline: Donatella
text: 184 Eighth Avenue (19th Street), (212) 493-5150, donatellanyc.com.

headline: Pepperoni: On Top
text: ACROSS the United States, artisanal pizza joints are opening faster than Natalie Portman movies. But inside those imported ovens, pepperoni — by far America’s most popular pizza topping — is as rare as a black swan.

headline: Heartbreak
text: 29 East Second Street (Second Avenue), (212) 777-2502, heartbreakrestaurant.com.

headline: Recalling the Reign of Taylor and King
text: Once upon a time in Lotus Land, the Troubadour, a 300-seat nightclub in West Hollywood, Calif., became the center of the singer-songwriter movement that dominated American pop during much of the 1970s. Created by Doug Weston, a wild-haired eccentric whose favorite attire was a green corduroy suit that earned him the nickname Jolly Green Giant, the club is fondly remembered in Morgan Neville’s documentary “Troubadours” as the place that kick-started a musical genre. Mr. Weston died in 1999, but the Troubadour still flourishes.

headline: TimesCast | February 1, 2011
text: President Obama speaks and Egyptians react after President Hosni Mubarak announces that he will not run again in September.

headline: Ward Backtracks From Criticisms of N.F.L.
text: In a round-table player discussion about head injuries published by GQ Tuesday morning, Pittsburgh Steelers receiver Hines Ward was rather candid: He said that “nobody paid attention” to the N.F.L.’s video about illegal tackles in October; that the league is “hypocritical” about player safety; and said that players are still hiding their concussions from doctors as passionately as ever.

headline: Talking About the ‘Black Swan’ Costumes
text: Some of you may have seen this interview with the costume designer Amy Westcott on the Clothes on Film blog, discussing “Black Swan” and her other work.

headline: M.L.S. All-Star Game at Red Bull Arena
text: Major League Soccer will play its 2011 all-star game, against an opponent to be determined, at Red Bull Arena in Harrison, N.J., on July 27.

headline: Portuguese Press Jostles for News About Murder Suspect
text: The moment Rodrigo Freixo posted on his Facebook page a message that he was headed to New York, his friends were quick to post snide advice.

headline: In Málaga, a Taste of Picasso (and Iberian Cuisine)
text: A good tapas restaurant can be a budget traveler’s best friend in Spain: a few small plates, free bread refills, a glass of house wine, and you’ve got a cheap meal.

headline: The Groundhog Develops a Sense of Nuance
text: The following is a work of fiction. Staten Island Chuck the groundhog does not talk. We know nothing of his handler’s personal life. Michael Kardos co-directs the the creative writing program at Mississippi State University. He will be reading at Freebird Books in Brooklyn on Saturday at its Punxsutawney Phil retirement party.

headline: Two Hints at Stepped-Up Media Rivalry in Online Streaming
text: The increasing importance of Internet rights for television channels and shows has been vividly demonstrated twice in the last few days.

headline: Obama Urges Quick Transition in Egypt
text: WASHINGTON – President Obama declared on Tuesday night that an “orderly transition” in Egypt “must begin now,” but he stopped short of demanding that President Hosni Mubarak leave office immediately.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,455 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Troy Vincent Says Once a Player Rep, Always a Player Rep
text: DALLAS

headline: Undercover Video Released by Anti-Abortion Group
text: An anti-abortion group Tuesday released undercover video taken in its latest attempt to discredit the Planned Parenthood Federation of America. The group, Live Action, said the video depicted an employee at a New Jersey Planned Parenthood clinic offering to help cover up a sex ring so that under-age girls could receive health services. Planned Parenthood said it had promptly notified federal law enforcement authorities after the visit, which was one of at least 11 made by the same imposters to clinics in six states. It said it was investigating whether the employee in the video, which it said had been edited, may have violated the organization’s policies.

headline: Pennsylvania: Ocean Liner Finds Buyer
text: A private group dedicated to saving the United States, a once-glamorous 1952 ocean liner that has been mothballed in Philadelphia since 1996, announced Tuesday that it had purchased the ship for $3 million. The SS United States Conservancy has been seeking development plans for the rusting hulk, a restoration job that could cost more than $200 million, according to Susan Gibbs, the group’s president. In November, the conservancy proposed making the liner part of a casino project in Philadelphia; competing plans for Miami and New York City are also under discussion. Ms. Gibbs called the New York idea “especially promising” but would not comment further. The group is seeking $1 million in donations to save portions of the ship’s engine rooms, which are largely intact, and for other preservation work. A $5.8 million gift from H. F. Lenfest, a Philadelphia philanthropist, covered the sale price and about 20 months of maintenance.

headline: Canadians Outraged After Report of Cruelty in Mass Killing of Sled Dogs
text: OTTAWA  During the Winter Olympics last year, the main attractions in Whistler, British Columbia, were the skiing and sliding events. But tourists looking for something different could also book dog sled rides pulled by teams of “energetic and lovable Alaskan racing huskies.”

headline: This Is Your Brain on Media Day
text: Nothing mixes the mundane and the insane like media day at the Super Bowl.

headline: Special Counsel Named in Ensign Case
text: The Senate Ethics Committee announced Tuesday that it has named a special counsel to help determine whether to bring formal charges against Senator John Ensign, the Nevada Republican who has been accused of using his political influence to help cover up an affair he had with the wife of a former top aide. Carol Elder Brown, a former Justice Department prosecutor and an experienced criminal defense lawyer, was appointed to the unusual role, according to a statement released by the committee. She will help with what the committee said is a “preliminary inquiry,” which follows an investigation by staff members that has already taken about a year. Mr. Ensign, who is up for re-election in 2012, has been cleared by investigators at the Department of Justice and the Federal Election Commission.

headline: Sabres Sold to an Oil and Gas Executive
text: The Buffalo Sabres’ owner, Tom Golisano, has reached an agreement to sell the club to the Pennsylvania oil and gas executive Terry Pegula.

headline: About Two Dozen Arraigned in Credit Card Fraud Scheme
text: About two dozen people have been charged with stealing credit card data and using it to make counterfeit credit cards that they used to buy and resell goods across the country, according to an indictment filed on Tuesday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

headline: Women at War
text: What do women have to do with the origins of the Civil War? Growing up in Virginia in the 1970s, I often heard this answer: nothing.

headline: An Apple E-Book Rule Tightens
text: When you see people flipping through e-books on iPads or iPhones, there is a good chance they bought the books through Amazon.com, not Apple.

headline: Rewards for Rebellion: Tiny Nation and Crown for Life
text: PRINCIPALITY OF HUTT RIVER, Australia  “Some people do think that Hutt River is really a new, young country, but I get a lot of German tourists through here, and I take pride in telling them that Hutt River is not really a new, young country.

headline: Ratings Agencies Keep Their Influence
text: Rating agencies were just branded “essential cogs in the wheel of financial destruction.” Despite the label from the commission studying causes of the crisis, rating firms are on the mend. Resurgent markets help. But policy makers, especially Basel officials, have failed to dilute their influence.

headline: Malaysian Forest Ebbing at Rapid Rate, Report Says
text: Malaysia is cutting down forests at more than triple the average rate of the rest of Asia, with the destruction concentrated in the highly biodiverse peatland forests on the island of Borneo, a new analysis of satellite data reveals.

headline: New Chief Revises Goals and Spending for Pfizer
text: Pfizer, the drug maker, announced plans Tuesday to slash its research spending by as much as $2.9 billion in the next two years, including closing the English labs that invented Viagra.

headline: Media Day: Brett Keisel
text: Brett Keisel's beard has gotten a lot of attention in Dallas.

headline: Egyptian Voices Heard Online
text: In response to the Egyptian's government's restrictions on the Internet, a new social media service allowed Egyptians to post audio recordings using phones and Twitter.

headline: Arrival of Nokia Bolsters a City’s Hopes
text: SUNNYVALE, Calif.  City officials are hoping that Nokia’s new building here, transformed in just six months to a gleaming corporate headquarters from a structural skeleton, will be the catalyst to revive a troubled 36-acre downtown redevelopment project after more than a decade of false starts by one developer after another.

headline: Can North Carolina Deliver Again?
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama signaled Tuesday that he would try to follow the same path to re-election that he charted in his first campaign, selecting Charlotte, N.C., to host the 2012 Democratic convention in a decision that instantly confirmed the state as a new presidential battleground.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Israel, Alone Again?
text: Jerusalem

headline: Ferries to Ply East River Far More Regularly Soon
text: For all their dominance on Staten Island, ferries have long struggled to muscle their way into the city’s mass transit mainstream. Experiments in Queens and Brooklyn have been held back by infrequent service, outsize operating costs and low ridership.

headline: Yes, the Diner’s Open. How About a Seat at the Counter?
text: IN a new commercial for Denny’s, a man orders chicken wraps at the counter, and when his waitress replies, “Anything else, hon?” he asks her if she calls everyone that.

headline: U.S. General Sees Success Even if Pakistan Doesn’t Act
text: WASHINGTON  Lt. Gen. David Rodriguez, the No. 2 commander in Afghanistan, said Tuesday that the United States and NATO could succeed in the war even if Pakistan refused to shut down a lawless frontier sanctuary that militants use for staging attacks on forces across the border in Afghanistan.

headline: Bet on Foreclosure Boom Turns Sour for Investors
text: David J. Stern may be the best-known beneficiary of the foreclosure boom, having made millions in recent years from evictions processed by his law firm, the largest of its kind in Florida. But when he took part of his firm public early last year, he had plenty of help from a constellation of investors also looking to cash in on people losing their homes.

headline: For Shields, Answers Weren’t in the Cards, but on the Cards
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Like anyone trying to learn a new vocabulary, Green Bay cornerback Sam Shields was lost. He could not make sense of his assignments, which was not a surprise considering he played only one year on defense in college and the Packers employ a kaleidoscope 3-4 scheme.

headline: Steelers Receiver Brown Made Key Plays in Playoff Victories
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  As the mayhem of media day unfolded all around him Tuesday, Antonio Brown retired to a far sideline at Cowboys Stadium. He wore a baseball cap turned backward and Gucci sunglasses, as if he wished to remain anonymous.

headline: Video: This Is Your Brain on Media Day
text: Nothing mixes the mundane and the insane like media day at the Super Bowl. To get an idea of what I’m talking about, watch the following video, which captures the scene from one end of Cowboys Stadium to the other. Can you make it to the end without getting motion sickness?

headline: Extra Sips of Sake
text: I picked up a lot of fascinating stories while I was reporting this week’s article about sake.

headline: Dakota Co-op Board Is Accused of Bias
text: The Dakota, the legendary New York apartment building, has long been famous for its celebrity residents, including Leonard Bernstein, Lauren Bacall and John Lennon.

headline: Keisel’s Beard Is the ‘Scruff of Legend’
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Jack Passion knows a thing or two about beards. With his orange-red “waterfall of hot lava,” as he called it, spilling from his chin, he is the country’s only full-time professional beard grower. It is not a lucrative job, really, but between the worldwide contests he wins and the book he wrote about beard growing, he can be considered an expert on the subject.

headline: City Workers Face Penalty After Storm
text: Tens of thousands of New York City employees who did not report for work during the snowstorm on Thursday could lose a day of leave  even though Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg sent out a predawn message that day saying that all city nonemergency offices and schools would be closed.

headline: Metro-North Cuts Service on the New Haven Line
text: With half of their fleet on the New Haven line knocked out by weather-related repairs, Metro-North Railroad officials said Tuesday that they could no longer run regular weekday service on that branch for the indefinite future.

headline: Two Cities, Two Parties, One Big Steam Bath
text: Charlotte and Tampa have at least two things in common. Both are likely to be baking in heat and humidity in the summer of 2012. Tampa will have the Republicans sweating, not just from the average high temperatures in August of 90 degrees but because if their nominee fails to impress in Florida, the party may well lose the election. Democrats in Charlotte may be only slightly cooler, as the average highs in September are in the mid-80s. But if President Obama loses North Carolina, he could still win re-election.

headline: Google to Microsoft: Search ‘Gotcha’
text: Google has weathered criticism in the past that it has copied some features of Microsoft’s Bing search engine, like background images. Now it has turned the tables, contending that Bing copies something much more important: search results.

headline: Panel Votes to Close 10 City High Schools
text: After six hours of public testimony, the Panel for Educational Policy voted early on Wednesday to close 10 city high schools and open a new charter school in the heart of the Upper West Side.

headline: Quiet Acts of Protest on a Noisy Day
text: CAIRO  The retired general in the blue suit walked alone, with a cane, as hundreds of Egyptian protesters surged past him, chanting and holding signs. He stopped to catch his breath, grabbing the railing of a bridge so he could look out at the Nile.

headline: Group Releases Hidden Tapes of Planned Parenthood
text: An anti-abortion group seeking to discredit Planned Parenthood released an undercover video on Tuesday that appears to show a clinic manager advising a sex trafficker how to get medical care for prostitutes as young as 14.

headline: Madoff Had Wide Role in Mets’ Finances
text: When Fred Wilpon’s son Jeff was married at Fresh Meadow Country Club on Long Island, Bernard L. Madoff and his wife were there. When Mr. Madoff’s son Mark was married at the same country club, Mr. Wilpon, the principal owner of the Mets, was a guest as well.

headline: States Diverge on How to Deal With Health Care Ruling
text: States took broadly divergent approaches on Tuesday to a federal judge’s ruling that invalidated the Obama health care law, while Congressional Republicans used the decision to build momentum for a vote on repealing the act.

headline: China Is Poised to Raise Rates Again, Bankers Say
text: HONG KONG  China’s government, increasingly worried about soaring inflation, plans to continue tightening its money supply and will probably raise interest rates again within the month.

headline: N.F.L. Union’s Ads Squashed by Network
text: The N.F.L. and its players have been throwing verbal barbs at each other in recent weeks as they try to work out a new labor agreement. The players union, though, appears to have lost at least one megaphone.

headline: Report Foresees Quick Gulf of Mexico Recovery
text: The Gulf of Mexico should recover from the environmental damage caused by the enormous BP oil spill last year faster than many people expected, according to new estimates in reports commissioned by Kenneth R. Feinberg, the administrator of the $20 billion compensation fund.

headline: A Hacking Case Becomes a War of the Tabloids
text: LONDON — It was a classic tabloid scoop: a young woman’s account of a two-year affair with the actor Ralph Fiennes, spiced up with racy details of what he liked to do and how he liked to do it. Three newspapers — The Sunday Mirror, The Mail on Sunday and News of the World — carried their versions of the tale on Feb. 5, 2006.

headline: Wednesday: Stirring Time
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Have you ever been in a group where someone tells an “in” joke that only a few people understand? Those people who are “in” break up with laughter, and the rest of us are left wondering why we don’t get it.

headline: Candles, Matzo, Wine and Some Unusual Hosts
text: New Yorkers both Jewish and gentile are probably aware that Seders come in all styles and sizes. But the ceremony honoring the first night of Passover in “The Whipping Man,” an atmospheric period drama by Matthew Lopez that opened on Tuesday night at City Center’s Stage I, surely has few equals in its arresting strangeness.

headline: Video: Brett Keisel at Media Day
text: There may not be a hotter topic right now in Dallas than Brett Keisel’s beard, which has 20,000 Facebook fans, a Web site and a song. Keisel has denied taking beard-enhancing drugs.

headline: Winter Storm Disrupts Much of the Country
text: As many as 30 states could be affected by the latest storm and its accompanying snow and ice.

headline: Union Rebuffed in Bid to Keep N.F.L. From Lockout TV Money
text: A court-appointed special master rejected on Tuesday the N.F.L. players union’s claim that the league should not have access to $4 billion in television payments if there is a lockout. But he awarded the union $6.9 million in damages in connection with two particular contracts, with ESPN and NBC.

headline: Piazza Working on Memoir, Not on Buying Piece of Mets
text: Mike Piazza earned more than $120 million in his playing career, and if he invested wisely, he might have enough to buy a share of his old team, the Mets. But Piazza, who led the Mets to their last pennant, in 2000, is not interested.

headline: Jerry Jones Says a 22-Game Season Would Be Doable
text: The N.F.L. will have no trouble playing 18 and even more regular-season games if it can persuade the players to accept an expanded schedule, Jerry Jones, the owner of the Dallas Cowboys, said Tuesday.

headline: Beyond Mubarak
text: The announcement from President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt that he would not run for re-election was welcome, if he means it, but it was unlikely to be enough. It is up to the Egyptian people to decide. But as a proud nationalist, Mr. Mubarak can best contribute to Egypt’s stability and future by stepping aside and letting an interim government take over until truly free elections can be held.

headline: 7th Youth Arrested in Bullying of Teenager in Philadelphia
text: PHILADELPHIA  A seventh teenager was arrested on Tuesday in a bullying incident in which a 13-year-old student was kicked and beaten before being hung by his coat from a spiked fence post, the police said.

headline: Judicial Activism on Health Reform
text: A ruling by a Federal District Court judge in Florida that the entire health care reform law is unconstitutional was a breathtaking example of judicial activism and overreach.

headline: Nassau in a Ditch, Again
text: There is no reason that Nassau County, one of the wealthiest counties in the United States and home to some of the highest property taxes and richest residents anywhere, should be in such a dire state  its budget $176 million out of whack and its finances now subject to a humiliating takeover by a state control board.

headline: A Food Manifesto for the Future
text: For decades, Americans believed that we had the world’s healthiest and safest diet. We worried little about this diet’s effect on the environment or on the lives of the animals (or even the workers) it relies upon. Nor did we worry about its ability to endure — that is, its sustainability.

headline: Justice and the I.G.

headline: Israel: Netanyahu Cancels Appointment to Top Army Post
text: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Tuesday canceled the appointment of Maj. Gen. Yoav Galant, left, as the Israeli Army’s incoming chief of staff. General Galant was supposed to take over from Lt. Gen. Gabi Ashkenazi in mid-February but his nomination has been challenged in court over accusations that he illegally took over land around his home in a village in northern Israel. Israel’s state comptroller said that General Galant lied in a court affidavit about the acquisition of the land. Israel’s attorney general ruled on Tuesday that he would not be able to defend Gen. Galant’s appointment. The Defense Ministry said in a statement that the deputy chief of staff, Maj. Gen. Yair Naveh, would assume the top post for up to 60 days.

headline: Shaken-Baby Syndrome Faces New Questions in Court
text: At 4 months, Noah Whitmer was an easy baby. Super tranquilo, remembers Trudy Eliana Muñoz Rueda, who took care of Noah at her home day care center in Fairfax County, Va. Rueda and Noah’s mother, Erin Whitmer, both noticed when he stopped taking his bottle well and napping as usual in the middle of his fifth month, in April 2009. Whitmer thought this was because Noah had just started eating solid food. She and Rueda talked about it early on April 20, both of them hunched over Noah in his car seat when Whitmer dropped him off.

headline: Phys Ed: More Bone (and Less Fat) Through Exercise
text: For those requiring additional reasons to show up at the running path or at the gym in the dreary heart of winter, science has come up with a compelling new motivation. Exercise can, it appears, keep your bone marrow from becoming too flabby.

headline: Mubarak’s Allies and Foes Clash in Egypt

headline: How Are You Handling This Winter Weather?
text: About six weeks ago, we asked you how you felt about winter weather. But that was before winter even technically began. So in honor of Wednesday’s observance of Groundhog Day, we ask: Are you ready for six more weeks of winter? Or do you hope that Punxsutawney Phil predicts that spring’s calmer, warmer days will come early this year? And if you live in a place that’s been very snowy this year, how are you coping?

headline: Wishing for the Feel of Hard Pavement

But for Ms. Vasquez, who was born with spina bifida, getting around can be a challenge. She can’t feel her feet, so she navigates the city in a manual wheelchair.

headline: At London Show, Art Meets Science

The fair, which runs Feb. 4 to 6, is a place to witness artists “harnessing the powers of nature and cosmic energy as a means of expression,” according to event organizers.

headline: There Are Two Kinds of C.E.O.
text: I recently had an interesting conversation with Rafael Pastor, the chairman and chief executive of Vistage, a leading organization for chief executives. He relayed a story that one of his members had told him. This particular C.E.O. has a school-age son who came home one day and asked if his father would call himself something other than a C.E.O. It seems that the boy’s classmates were giving him a hard time about the fact that his father runs a company — as if it were something to be embarrassed by. My first thought was, “What?” Maybe I could understand it if his father were a politician! But then I started thinking.

headline: Seeing Dance From the Cheap Seats
text: For Friday’s Weekend section, Claudia La Rocco is writing about seeing dance performances from the cheapest seats of some of New York’s important halls. As it happened, all four of The Times’s dance critics were in attendance at the Sunday matinee of City Ballet at the David H. Koch Theater. Roslyn Sulcas and Gia Kourlas in orchestra, the chief critic Alastair Macaulay a level up in the First Ring, and Ms. LaRocco in the Fourth Ring (specifically, three rows from the very top of the theater). As it turns out, it does make a difference but it’s not necessarily what you think.

headline: Woody Allen’s ‘Midnight in Paris’ Will Open Cannes Festival
text: As Europe continues to ship off its up-and-coming actors to play dashing American superheroes, the United States is apparently responding by sending one of its most virile specimens of manhood to that continent in exchange: namely, Woody Allen. Mr. Allen’s latest film, “Midnight in Paris,” will open the Cannes Film Festival on May 11, the event’s organizers said on Wednesday. The film, the 41st feature-length work that Mr. Allen has directed, is a romantic comedy whose cast includes Owen Wilson, Rachel McAdams, Marion Cotillard, Kathy Bates and Adrien Brody, though one cast member, Carla Bruni-Sarkozy, has received a bit more attention than the others. In a statement, Thierry Frémaux, the director of the Cannes festival, described “Midnight in Paris” as “a wonderful love letter to Paris,” adding: “It’s a film in which Woody Allen takes a deeper look at the issues raised in his last films: our relationship with history, art, pleasure and life.” The film will be released in France on the same day it makes its debut at Cannes, though an American release date has not yet been announced. The full Cannes Film Festival runs through May 22.

headline: A Wealthy Christopher Nolan and a Meta James Franco
text: Perhaps this will be a comfort to him: Christopher Nolan’s “Inception” was the big winner at the Visual Effects Society on Tuesday. His film picked up all four prizes for which it was nominated – Outstanding Visual Effects in a Visual-Effects Driven Feature Motion Picture; Outstanding Created Environment in a Live Action Feature Motion Picture; Outstanding Models & Miniatures in a Feature Motion Picture and Outstanding Compositing in a Feature Motion Picture – and Mr. Nolan himself was honored with the inaugural visionary award. In a bit of a surprise, “How to Train Your Dragon” bested “Toy Story 3” in the animated category. For the first time, the show will be broadcast on the Reelzchannel on Feb. 19.

headline: Rand Paul Makes First Speech on Senate Floor
text: With self assurance, eloquence and a soupçon of mild defiance, Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky gave his first speech on the floor of his new legislative home Wednesday, noting that while he would be sitting at the desk of “the great compromiser,” Henry Clay, he would not be taking many cues from the 19th-century Kentucky lawmaker and founder of the Whig Party.

headline: E.P.A. Plans First Rules Ever on Perchlorate in Drinking Water
text: The Obama administration announced on Wednesday that it planned to regulate toxic substances in drinking water more strictly and would issue the first limits ever on perchlorate, a dangerous chemical found in rocket fuel that has seeped into groundwater in at least 400 locations.

headline: Leading Off: Super Bowl Media Day Goes From Silly to Bitter
text: Perhaps the safest statement you could make in the run-up to the Super Bowl is that N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell is not a popular man in Steelerville. First, media day on Tuesday became embroiled in a “what he said” dust-up over comments Goodell made about the Ben Roethlisberger suspension for a Sports Illustrated profile. Let’s just say the Steelers weren’t happy the commish tossed them under a bus for not supporting their quarterback. Then the reporter, Peter King, quickly scrambled to clarify Goodell’s supposed comments, and Goodell declared them “misreported.”

headline: The View From Tahrir
text: Today President Mubarak seems to have decided to crack down on the democracy movement, using not police or army troops but rather mobs of hoodlums and thugs. I’ve been spending hours on Tahrir today, and it is absurd to think of this as simply “clashes” between two rival groups. The pro-democracy protesters are unarmed and have been peaceful at every step. But the pro-Mubarak thugs are arriving in buses and are armed — and they’re using their weapons.

headline: Dispute Derails Art Loans From Russia
text: Several paintings from Gauguin’s Tahitian period will probably be missing from a major exhibition of his work at the National Gallery of Art in Washington when it opens this month, as will a canvas in that museum’s coming show on the Venetian painter Canaletto and his rivals. At the Metropolitan Museum of Art a small but important exhibition of Cézanne’s famous card player paintings, opening next week, will almost surely be short one.

headline: E.P.A. Plans New Limits on Toxic Chemicals in Drinking Water
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Wednesday that it would impose limits on permissible levels of a new set of toxic chemicals in drinking water, including the first standards for perchlorate, a dangerous compound found in rocket fuel and fireworks that has contaminated water supplies in 26 states.

headline: Notes From the Underground | Adam Scher Dance Company
text: The Adam Scher Dance Company’s new piece, “Five Blind Mice,” which was presented last week at the Irondale Center in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, is a tour de force of choreography and technology. Kate Atherton, Molly Merkler, Veronica Carnero, Casey Loomis and Adam Scher performed separate vignettes, each specifically programmed by the technical director, Christopher Langer, to sync with the piece’s emotional core. As an opener, Merkler performed in almost complete darkness; a sensor strapped to her stomach detected her breathing and illuminated a light bulb overhead with every inhale. Later in the lineup, Atherton began her more up-tempo piece against the backdrop of a blank projection. As the piece went on, time-lapsed footage of her movements appeared in repetition every 30 seconds, creating an army of her own image that seemingly danced along with the real performer.

headline: Once-Reeling Devils Regroup Under Lemaire
text: NEWARK  The morning skate before the 50th game of a rough season for the Devils ended with Jacques Lemaire at center ice, peering at the defensemen, then at the forwards, then back and forth, over and over. He tapped the heel of his stick on the ice as he picked up details.

headline: An Online Movement to Help D.J. Kool Herc
text: The minute Jeff Chang heard that the pioneering Bronx hip-hop D.J. Kool Herc was having health problems, he knew it was time for payback. Mr. Chang, a prolific writer on politics and culture, was honored when Herc wrote the introduction to his hip-hop history book “Can’t Stop, Won’t Stop.” But this week he was alarmed that Herc, born Clive Campbell, was in financial straits because his lack of medical insurance was complicating his treatment for kidney stones.

headline: Marcos, Suharto, Mubarak
text: A quick thought about the Egyptian uprising. Many people have sought parallels either in the Philippines 1986 or in Indonesia 1998; I’ve done it myself. But there is a possibly important or revealing difference. As the chart above shows, both of those political crises followed on drastic economic crises — Marcos was caught up in the Latin American debt crisis of the 1980s (in some important ways the Philippines was in effect a Latin American economy at the time), Suharto in the Asian financial crisis. Nothing comparable for Egypt now.

headline: On Google’s Bing Sting
text: Every now and then, Microsoft undoes months or years of excellent work by pulling off a sleazy tactic. There was the time it hired a P.R. firm to write phony “grass-roots” letters to the editors of newspapers, defending Microsoft’s position in the government’s antitrust lawsuits. There was the time Microsoft bribed bloggers with free $2,500 laptops to “assist in their evaluation” of Windows Vista.

headline: In Peru, Two Houses and a Pool
text: A two-structure property with a combined seven bedrooms, is a few blocks from the beach in Chorillos, on the outskirts of Lima, Peru. It’s on the market for $900,000.

headline: House Hunting in ... Peru
text: A FOUR-BEDROOM HOUSE WITH A THREE-BEDROOM COTTAGE IN CHORILLOS, PERU

headline: Meet ‘Vera Stark': Sanaa Lathan to Star in Lynn Nottage’s Follow-up to ‘Ruined’
text: Lynn Nottage’s new Off Broadway play “By the Way, Meet Vera Stark,” her first since winning the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 2009 for “Ruined,” has announced its star: The stage and film actress Sanaa Lathan will play the title character, a black maid in Hollywood who pursues her dream of making it in the pictures while also grappling with racial stereotypes through decades of the 20th century.

headline: Darden Family Values Quicksilver Resources at $2.7 Billion
text: The Darden family, which holds a major stake in Quicksilver Resources, said in a regulatory filing that it believed the energy company was worth $16 a share, putting its total value at $2.7 billion.

headline: Convincing Even the Skeptics to Go Green
text: Centuries of burning fossil fuels to power our modern lifestyles is warming our planet and changing our climate. Or not. So goes the debate. Regardless of where you stand on this issue, making your business more environmentally friendly is just good business, according to L. Hunter Lovins, president of Natural Capitalism Solutions and co-author of “Climate Capitalism" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), which is set for release in April.

headline: Anti-Abortion Groups Step Up Campaign Against Planned Parenthood
text: Planned Parenthood has fired a clinic manager who was seen on videotape advising a man posing as a sex trafficker, and anti-abortion groups seized on the episode to step up their campaign to cut off public financing for the organization.

headline: Stuffed Cabbage With a Mediterranean Inflection
text: I don’t make stuffed cabbage all that often: perhaps once or twice a year. And I generally make it more or less the same way, using paprika, caraway and sauerkraut: a Hungarian inflection, if not a purely Hungarian recipe. A batch lasts through several meals, even when we have company to help eat it, and perhaps that is why I don’t need to make it more frequently than I do.

headline: Storm Snarls Travel
text: The effects of the storm that blanketed much of the country yesterday are being felt by travelers from the Great Plains to the Midwest to the Northeast, Michael Cooper and Monica Davey report. The weather affected those traveling by air, rail and road. Mr. Cooper and Ms. Davey reported that the storm resulted in the cancellation of 4,892 flights by Wednesday at 7:30 a.m., about 1,500 of them in New York’s three airports; the temporary closing and delays  of Amtrak service along the Northeast corridor, and the closing of Interstate 70 in Missouri.

headline: Cathie Black, Catching Flak, Gives Some Back
text: Updated, 4:21 p.m. | Cathleen P. Black, the new schools chancellor, faced an angry crowd of nearly 2,000 people as the Panel for Education Policy voted to close 10 schools. The meeting, at Brooklyn Technical High School, lasted more than six hours Tuesday night into early Wednesday as about 300 people spoke, some of them screaming and taunting Ms. Black until she could not take it any longer.

headline: Red, White and Blue: The White Stripes Break Up
text: A moment of silence for the White Stripes, please.

headline: Is Your Business Trying to Go Green?
text: It was a “no-brainer,” says Joe Santana, who is vice president of operations for Mi Rancho, a family-owned Tortilla-producer in San Leandro, Calif.

headline: On Our Radar: Take ‘a Fresh Look’ at Climate Change, Scientists Urge Congress
text: A group of leading climate scientists, including eight members of the National Academy of Sciences, call on Congress to take a “fresh look” at the science linking human activity to climate change, which they contend is strong. “The debate about climate change has become increasingly ideological and partisan,” their joint letter states. “But climate change is not the product of a belief system or ideology. Instead, it is based on scientific fact, and no amount of argument, coercion, or debate among talking heads in the media can alter the physics of climate change.” [The Hill]

headline: Gowanus Canal Inquiry Underlines Severity of Pollution
text: A yearlong investigation of the Gowanus Canal in preparation for its cleanup under the federal Superfund program has confirmed the severe extent of its contamination and the threat it poses to public health, particularly for people who eat fish from it or have repeated contact with its water or sediment.

headline: Fill-In | Wikipedia and Gender
text: Fill in the blanks in several paragraphs from the article “Define Gender Gap? Look Up Wikipedia’s Contributor List.”Use your own words and phrases, or click “read more” to choose from a scrambled list of the words or phrases that were removed.

headline: St. Nicholas Ave. and 169th St., 10:45 A.M.
text: Neither rain nor snow nor sleet nor gloom of day …

headline: Kepler Planet Hunter Finds 1,200 Possibilities
text: Astronomers have cracked the Milky Way like a piñata, and planets are now pouring out so fast that they do not know what to do with them all.

headline: U.S. Tries Open-Source Model for Health Data Systems
text: The government’s lofty vision of bringing health care into the computer age to improve care and curb costs will come to nothing, unless some mundane technical problems can be solved.

headline: As Rajaratnam Heads to Trial, Legal Skirmishes Flare Up
text: Raj Rajaratnam, the Galleon Group’s founder, is scheduled to begin trial on Feb. 28 on charges that he engaged in insider trading, and prosecutors and defense lawyers are aggressively sparring over a range of preliminary issues in an effort to frame their cases for the jury. While it is still possible the two sides will agree to a plea bargain, the intensity of the fight certainly makes it look like they are gearing up for one of the biggest insider trading trials ever.

headline: Triumph and Agony in Egypt
text: David Brooks: Gail, every few years we turn on the TV and we see the main square of some foreign capital filled with people and before too long, a dictator falls. This is truly a great time to be alive. Now, I understand all the worries that go along with this. I understand my Israeli friends who feel that they are in the process of losing the least bad Egyptian leader. But my bottom line is this: the world will be far safer when more of the world is normal, meaning mostly open and mostly democratic. If we have to go through a period of turmoil to get there, it is more than worth it. That’s especially true in the Middle East.

headline: Shippers Concerned Over Possible Suez Canal Disruptions
text: HOUSTON — As violence has broken out in Egypt, concern has turned to the risk of the blocking of the Suez Canal or nearby pipelines, which could pose a threat to world energy supplies.

headline: Inquiry Details Gowanus Pollution
text: The Environmental Protection Agency has issued the results of a study documenting the severity of the pollution in the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn. The agency redoubled warnings that New Yorkers should not swim or fish there, citing the risks to human health.

headline: Cheap Seats and Dance: When Children Are Involved
text: We asked The Times’s dance critics, who sat in different sections of the David H. Koch Theater for Sunday’s City Ballet matinee, to compare notes. Here’s Part 2 of their conversation, which ranged from dancers’ expressions to the best place to sit with kids. Check back for the final installment later today and be sure to share your experiences in different seats.

headline: Still a Home for Directors, and Big Foot
text: THE Sundance Film Festival has been very, very good for American cinema, and perhaps Hollywood most of all. Great American directors, including those magnificent Andersons, Paul Thomas and Wes (no relation), each made an early splash at Sundance in 1993 with their respective shorts, “Cigarettes and Coffee” and the first iteration of “Bottle Rocket.” Both might have found studio patronage without Sundance, but the festival ushered them into the larger film world.

headline: Surviving (Yet Another) Snow Day
text: According to the National Weather Service, 100 million people live in the path of the monster snow storm that has turned my driveway into a sheet of ice. (I am thinking of teaching the poor, confused dog to do an axel.)

headline: Los Angeles Has a Stadium Name, but No Stadium (or Team)
text: DALLAS – Maybe it’s the frigid temperatures outside, or the ever-present talk about how to increase the N.F.L.’s revenue, but football in Los Angeles – or the lack of it – has been a topic of conversation here.

headline: Rooney Method: Build Methodically and Await Rings
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Art Rooney II was glancing at the enormous video screen and plush seats, taking in Jerry Jones’s monument to revenue with a bemused smile. Pittsburgh will probably never have a home quite like Cowboys Stadium, which will be host to the Super Bowl on Sunday. But this week Rooney, an owner and the president of the Steelers, had something that Jones, the owner and general manager of the Dallas Cowboys, wanted desperately: the opportunity to explain how his team keeps returning to the Super Bowl every few years.

headline: Pre-Loading
text: Drinking quantities of mixed, cut-price alcohol before going out to bars and clubs.

headline: Central Figure in India Telecom Scandal Arrested
text: The former telecommunications minister whose handling of the sale of mobile telephone spectrum licenses may have cost the government as much as $39 billion in revenue has been arrested, officials said. A government report released last year accused the former minister, Andimuthu Raja, of selling the airwaves at giveaway prices to favored companies. The ensuing scandal shook what had been India’s most stable government in decades and raised questions about whether the nation’s rapid growth could be at risk because of rampant corruption. Mr. Raja and several associates were arrested on Wednesday.

headline: U.S. and E.U. Join to Show Support for Belarus Opposition
text: BERLIN — The United States and the European Union joined Wednesday in Warsaw in a show of support for the democratic opposition in Belarus.

headline: Shopping for Recliners With Kiel Mead
text: Kiel Mead, a furniture and lighting designer, went shopping for recliners that aren’t eyesores.

text: Well, that didn’t take long.

headline: In Ibiza, a House on Stilts
text: Enrique Polanco’s home was built to have minimal impact on the surrounding landscape.

headline: Artifacts | A Snow Queen for Our Time
text: As one of the most stringently modern skyscrapers in New York, Lever House is an outright snub to the 19th century. Or it was until last week, when the sculptor Rachel Feinstein turned its glass-enclosed lobby into an Old World storybook palace that must have the building’s architect, Gordon Bunshaft, turning over in his grave.

headline: Caring for the Chart or the Patient?
text: At a recent medical conference in Miami, I sat spellbound as Dr. Stephen Ferrara, a commander in the Navy, delivered a keynote address describing his work in a mobile hospital in Afghanistan.

headline: In Spain, Incorporating the Landscape Into the Design
text: IBIZA, SPAIN  When Enrique Polanco, an art fair promoter in Madrid, decided to build a second home on this island some 100 miles from the Spanish mainland, he said he set out “to escape from real life in Madrid.”

headline: No Way to Run a Republic
text: The State of the Union has been (appropriately) eclipsed by the events in Egypt, but before it fades entirely I want to take up something Matt Yglesias said, explaining why he doesn’t find the entitlement evasions of both the president and Paul Ryan particularly worrying:

headline: McCain and Obama  Meet in Oval Office
text: 5:35 p.m. | Updated There may be no relationship in Washington more fraught than the one between President Obama and his rival for the White House, Senator John McCain of Arizona.

headline: Haunting Images of Denim
text: THE publication in 2000 of a monograph that showcased the work of the Swiss photographer Karlheinz Weinberger  gritty images of Zurich teenagers who appropriated the look of the American rebel with intricately customized jeans and denim jackets  became something of a fetish for fashion designers.

headline: Pro and Anti-Mubarak Demonstrators Clash
text: Pro-Mubarak demonstrators clashed with anti-government protesters in Tahrir Square in Cairo on Wednesday.

headline: S.E.C. Hurt by Disarray in Its Books
text: WASHINGTON  If a company’s financial reporting were so bad that its auditor had pointed out significant weaknesses in its accounting for seven years running, the Securities and Exchange Commission would most likely be all over it.

text: 1. Northeast Africa. The Tunisnami.

headline: Franco Looks Likely to Join Kidman in ‘Sweet Bird of Youth’ on Broadway
text: The film star James Franco (an Academy Award nominee for “127 Hours”) and the theater director David Cromer (the acclaimed Off Broadway revival of “Our Town”) have had two meetings in recent months to discuss Mr. Franco’s making his Broadway debut as the gigolo and aspiring actor Chance Wayne in a fall 2011 revival of Tennessee Williams’s “Sweet Bird of Youth,” Mr. Cromer said in an interview on Tuesday.

headline: Slipping, Sliding and Watching for Falling Ice
text: Just when New Yorkers thought they had seen it all this winter, along came a new cause for alarm on Wednesday: ice, a danger on the ground and from above.

headline: Dive In (Not Literally) to Our Super Bowl Snacks
text: Before the Super Bowl, the only part of a newspaper more predictable than the sports section is the food section. It’s time for chili and dips, chicken wings and snacks, all touched up with flourishes like city-themed suggestions (“Make your jambalaya a Green Bay jambalaya by adding bratwurst!”), nods to simplicity (“If kickoff is approaching, you do not have to butcher your own hog,”) or healthy living (“Discourage guests from diving face first into the cream cheese dip”).

headline: Yielding to His Natural Self
text: THE sidewalks of the East Village were packed with chain smokers and European bar-hoppers, but Max Goldberg, a self-appointed organic-food guru, ducked into Commodities Natural Market, a modern health-food store on First Avenue. He was conducting product research.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Revolution
text: This week’s Bits: Tech Talk podcast takes a look at how technology is being used to press both for and against social and political change. Bettina Edelstein speaks to Matt Richtel, a New York Times technology reporter, about the impact and implications of the Internet shutdown in Egypt. And J.D. Biersdorfer speaks with David Perry, global director of education for the security firm Trend Micro, about how technology can be deployed as a weapon.

headline: Egypt’s Upheaval Hardens Israel’s Stance on Peace
text: TEL AVIV  With neighboring Egypt and other parts of the region in upheaval, Israelis contemplating their own future are taking refuge in familiar positions, and the prospect of the Netanyahu government’s making peace with the Palestinians, already distant, receded further.

headline: Upheaval Puts Militants in the Lurch
text: BAGHDAD  The ideology of radical Islam was developed in Egypt, and its cadres were hardened in the prisons of the country’s authoritarian president, Hosni Mubarak. But as antigovernment demonstrators battled it out with government supporters in Tahrir Square on Wednesday, jihadi groups found themselves curiously on the outside.

headline: Mulberry Project
text: YOU can’t heave a handmade sloe gin fizz these days without splashing a speakeasy-style lounge with mixologists, locavore plates and an in-crowd that revels in its erudite tastes. The latest is Mulberry Project, a basement lounge that opened in Little Italy in mid-January. The name, which sounds like an art installation, reflects a collaborative spirit: players include Matty Gee, a cocktail maker from Milk & Honey and the Boom Boom Room; Michael Camplin, a chef from Boqueria; and night-life veterans from GoldBar and Bagatelle.

headline: Kenny G Helps Audi Keep Old Luxury in Lockdown
text: It has been said that life’s greatest luxury is idle time. Yet Kenny G, the saxophonist who experienced his commercial high water mark sometime around 1996, has generously dedicated 2 minutes and 47 seconds of his ample supply to a new television advertisement for Audi.

headline: China Asks Penn to Remove All Artifacts From ‘Silk Road’ Exhibition
text: 5:40 p.m. | Updated It’s not an easy thing to mount a big exhibition of artifacts from China without any artifacts from China.

headline: When a Tax Isn’t Really a Tax
text: ALBANY – “I say no new taxes, period,” Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo declared on the day of his inauguration last month, echoing a top promise from his campaign. And after leafing through his first executive budget on Tuesday, lawmakers and others at the Capitol seemed to agree that Mr. Cuomo had indeed kept his pledge.

headline: Festival Films Have Minimalist Themes
text: LOS ANGELES — Guy walks into a bar. Maybe you already have enough material for a movie at South by Southwest.

headline: In Bay Area, New Peer-to-Peer Car Sharing Offers
text: Three San Francisco start-ups are hoping to persuade car owners to rent their vehicles to locals and out-of-town visitors. The three companies — Getaround, RelayRides and Spride Share — recently launched online services in the Bay Area to help car owners profit from their vehicles when not using them, while allowing drivers to book the cars at rates potentially lower than what major rental companies charge.

headline: Mapping 10 Forested ‘Hot Spots’
text: Over the last 8,000 years, forest cover on the planet has plummeted to around 13 million square miles from about 24 million square miles, the advocacy group Global Forest Watch estimates. Rain forests in particular are being felled at stunning rates.

headline: Former Lehman Executive to Lead Craftsman Brand
text: Need some tools? Scott Freidheim is your man.

headline: Clemens’s Co-Counsel to Question Pettitte
text: WASHINGTON  Roger Clemens told a federal judge Wednesday that he was not troubled by the fact that his lawyer briefly represented Yankees pitcher Andy Pettitte, who is expected to be a key prosecution witness in Clemens’s perjury trial later this year.
