headline: Freescale Hires Advisers for an I.P.O.
text: Freescale Semiconductor, the chip maker acquired by several buyout firms in 2006 for $17.6 billion, has hired a bevy of investment banks to underwrite an initial public offering, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday.

headline: Amos Lee Tops Billboard Chart in One of Industry’s Worst Weeks for Album Sales
text: Citigroup has barely owned EMI for a day, but it has already achieved a dubious distinction: a No. 1 album with notably low sales – even in a season of painfully low sales for the music industry.

headline: Mind and Body: Investigating the Health and Science of Meditation
text: Overview  | What is meditation? How have scientists explored the effects of meditation on the mind and body? In this lesson, students participate in a guided meditation, then learn about meditation and current research showing how meditation affects the brain and body. They then annotate diagrams of the brain and body with the information they’ve learned about meditation’s effects.

headline: Fortune Brands’ Big Breakup
text: CNBC discusses the planned split of Fortune Brands into three separate companies, a proposal supported by the activist investor William A. Ackman, who owns an 11 percent share of the company.

headline: Chick-fil-A Protests at N.Y.U. Are Muted
text: On some college campuses, students are agitated about the presence of Chick-fil-A, a purveyor of Southern-style chicken sandwiches that has run afoul of some proponents of same-sex marriage. But at a New York University cafeteria, the only place in the city where a craving for Chick-fil-A can be sated, the squawking has been limited.

headline: Paul and Nash Run the Pick-and-Roll in Style
text: The pick-and-roll is as foundational as N.B.A. plays come; it occurs on the professional level of the game in both pure and varied forms, in assorted rhythms and placements, all of which serve to modify its orchestration. The elasticity of the pick-and-roll is truly impressive, as the sequence always subscribes to the same basic action but can differ wildly in the style of its execution.

headline: The Insider | Joaquin Trias
text: Not yet 30 years old, Joaquin Trias is already revealing a certain kinship with his fellow Spanish designer Cristóbal Balenciaga (to whom his grandmother, Countessa Frida Trias, was model and muse). Trias’s aristocratic roots fostered his reverence for simple elegance, and his technical acumen and focus on innovation, perhaps picked up from his background with pattern makers and seamstresses, are apparent in every seam and silhouette. Gearing up for Fashion Week, Trias shares with us some of his day-to-day inspirations. Is he looking forward to it? “Yes,” he says. “Very much! Thank you.”

headline: Premier of Jordan Holds Talks With Rivals
text: AMMAN, Jordan  Jordan’s new prime minister began consultations with key political groups, including the Muslim opposition, on Wednesday. The talks came a day after King Abdullah II, caught in a regional wave of discontent, sought to stave off growing public unrest by firing his government and vowing reform.

headline: Behind the Collapse of the J. Crew Settlement
text: There was a heated exchange of letters on Tuesday as the J. Crew settlement over its proposed leveraged buyout collapsed.

headline: Buzz Tracker
text: ‘This is Not God’s Work’ Bill Gross: “Fifty years ago, the highest paid and most prestigious professions were that of a doctor or a 707 airline pilot who flew the “golden” route from Los Angeles to Honolulu. Today the yellow brick road begins on Wall Street or the City. Aside from supernova innovators such as Steve Jobs or Mark Zuckerberg, the money is made from securitizing things instead of booting and rebuilding America. . .. Almost a quarter of the 400 wealthiest people on Forbes annual richest list make their money from money, whereas only 8% could make that claim in its first issue in 1982, and probably close to 0% when I first read my economic primer in 1966. Having been part of this process and even a member of the rogue’s gallery itself, I know one thing for sure: This is not God’s work – it has the unmistakable odor of Mammon.” Pimco

headline: Cheap Seats and Dance: The Things You Learn
text: As part of an article coming Friday in the Weekend section, we asked The Times’s dance critics to compare notes after seeing the same performance (City Ballet on Sunday) from different parts of the theater. Here are Parts 1 and 2 of their conversation, which ranged from the performances themselves to the people you meet in the cheap seats and even dancers’ facial expressions, the subject that kicks off the final round:

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Egypt, Pakistan, and Iowa.

headline: Bush and McCain Daughters Reflect Age Divide on Gay Marriage
text: Barbara Bush, one of the twin daughters of George W. Bush, released a video on Tuesday calling on New York to legalize gay marriage.  Meghan McCain, meanwhile, has become an outspoken supporter of gay marriage. Their public support of same-sex marriage, while notable for conflicting with their famous fathers’ position on the issue, places them right in line with a majority of Americans in their age group (Ms. Bush is 29; Ms. McCain is 26).

headline: Who Am I? Wednesday Edition
text: All week, the Fifth Down blog will post “Who Am I?” quizzes to test your knowledge of Packers and Steelers of the past. Peeking at Pro Football Reference just ruins the fun for everyone, so don’t do it!

headline: Men in Hats
text: Having exhausted the usual narratives of power and gender as expressed through clothing, designers may have merely been casting about for new tools and communally fell upon the hat.

headline: The Cat in the Hat Comes Back
text: THERE was a time when only beggars went bareheaded. This was some while ago, a century or so. But up until World War II and the period just after, a gentleman was not considered properly dressed without a hat. Even the names of hats were rich in character and historical association. The bowler, or derby, with the rigid shape of an upended bean pot, was named for a 19th-century English earl who popularized the style. The fedora’s name came from a play of that title, written for Sarah Bernhardt by the otherwise largely forgotten French dramatist Victorien Sardou.

headline: Adding SNY to Mets’ Sale Pitch Would Increase Allure
text: When Fred Wilpon announced his plan to sell up to 25 percent of the Mets last week to one or more strategic investors, he kept the team’s majority ownership of the SNY network, which televises the team’s games, off the block.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Egypt, Pakistan and Iowa.

headline: Nabokov Meets Waiver Wire, in Song
text: You may have heard that Evgeni Nabokov isn’t happy. He recently went from signing a contract with the contending Detroit Red Wings to being claimed on waivers by the last place Islanders. So far he’s refused to report, but he may be running out of options if he wants to continue his career next season.

headline: This Old Thing? Actually, It’s New
text: WHEN Erin Ogg, 45, of New Orleans and her girlfriends sip cocktails at the Sazerac Bar in the city’s historic Roosevelt Hotel, they dress as if it’s the 1940s or ’50s; wearing dresses with cinched waists, or pencil skirts and blouses, accessorized with hats and gloves. “We get a lot of compliments,” said Ms. Ogg, a waitress and personal trainer. “It’s a feminine look with a lot more grace and style than a hoodie sweatshirt and Ugg boots.”

headline: Fifth Third Repays Bailout Funds
text: Fifth Third Bancorp, the large regional Midwestern bank, announced on Wednesday that it had repaid the $3.4 billion taxpayer bailout received at the height of the financial crisis.

headline: Pretty Little Underthings
text: Delicate and occasionally naughty bits spiced up spring collections from Alexander Wang to VPL. But what if your taste in underthings is for plain vanilla? Petit Bateau is going back to basics — circa 1893, the year the brand was born — with a new collection of vintage white Oeko-Tex cotton undergarments for men (T-shirt and boxers,$48), women (tank and briefs, $54) and children (baby jumper, $32). They serve as a reminder that sometimes good old-fashioned modesty is the sexiest thing of all.

headline: Young Sudanese Start Protest Movement
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The messages started going up on Facebook about two weeks ago, to any Sudanese who cared.

headline: Oppressor’s Tale, Written in Oppression
text: BOSTON  The Boston Lyric Opera, founded in 1976, presents only a handful of productions a year but clearly intends them to catch the interest of operagoers around the country. Its current season includes only one war horse, Puccini’s “Tosca,” and a few less-traveled works, like Handel’s “Agrippina” and Britten’s “Midsummer Night’s Dream,” that have significant constituencies.

headline: AT&T Sweetens Data Plans Before Verizon iPhone
text: After Verizon announced it would begin selling the iPhone on its network, the company introduced several data plan offerings to help strengthen its position against AT&T, the exclusive carrier of the iPhone in the United States for the last several years.

headline: Lighthearted, With a Soupçon of Self-Mockery
text: Brooke Shields came out swinging at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency, where she made her much-publicized nightclub debut on Tuesday evening. This beautiful strapping actress, model and sometime Broadway performer, now 45, is not one to “wimp out” (her words) when confronting a challenge. Resplendent in a black sequined dress, Ms. Shields, within minutes of taking the stage, compared her fear of making the leap into cabaret to getting married (which she has done twice), then plunged into a performance that had the feel of an Olympic sprint.

headline: Sizing Up National Signing Day
text: National signing day culminates the yearlong recruiting process for coaches and the seemingly boundless obsession of fans who track prospects through online sites. It is also a time for observers to take stake of how each program, and by extension each coach, fared in a given recruiting cycle.

headline: Turning Heads (but Don’t Call It a Perm)
text: TO get waves in her naturally straight hair, Kristi Koren, 36, used to dampen it, twist it in dozens of curlicues and then sleep on it. But after seeing Anne Hathaway’s effortlessly voluptuous locks in “Love and Other Drugs,” Ms. Koren, a mother of one 13-month-old and an entrepreneur in Raleigh, N.C., began wondering if there were a less time-consuming and a less uncomfortable way of creating long, flowing curls. As a child of the 1980s, it didn’t take her long to come up with the obvious (and yet terrifying) answer: a perm.

headline: Many Basic Weather Tools, but No Great Ones
text: Strange but true: four years after the iPhone’s debut, software developers and media giants have yet to build a truly great weather app.

headline: Medical Detectives Find Their First New Disease
text: Louise Benge’s medical problems started when she was 25. Walking became excruciating. Her calves got hard as rocks, and every step was agony. Her hands started hurting too. And the condition, whatever it was, only got worse over the next two decades.

headline: Art at MoMA: Tuna on Wheat (Hold the Mayo)
text: Only the sharp-eyed might have noticed something amiss at the lunch table of 12 last week in the second-floor cafeteria at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Beauty Spots
Ron Paul Schedules First Hearing on Fed
text: WASHINGTON — Critics of the Federal Reserve within the new Republican majority in the House will get their first chance to scrutinize the central bank next week.

headline: Public Theater’s Executive Director Resigns
text: Andrew D. Hamingson has resigned as executive director of the Public Theater after only two-and-a-half years as the company’s top financial executive, citing personal issues, Mr. Hamingson and the Public’s board chairman, Warren Spector, announced on Wednesday afternoon.

headline: In Egypt, the Dawn of ‘Sustainable Politics’?
text: Does the tide toward democracy in Egypt represent a durable death knell for despots and unrepresentative government?

headline: A Warm Reception ... Inside
text: FREEZING drizzle. Sleet. Ice accumulation. That is the death knell for most movie premieres, but for “Home,” a documentary about the perils of climate change, the forecast last Tuesday night was the perfect billing.

headline: Intricate Journey Contained in One Multifaceted Work
text: It scarcely matters whether there is any truth to the old legend about Bach’s “Goldberg” Variations: that they were composed to occupy the restless mind of Count Keyserlingk, the Russian ambassador to the court at Dresden, during bouts of insomnia. The point of the story is that if there is a work that could give an insomniac a universe of material to focus on, this is it.

headline: A Return to Power, Properly Punctuated
text: A big-name band instantly selling out a small room: it’s called an underplay, and it’s becoming a standard gambit to get a new album noticed. That’s why Panic! at the Disco, which headlined Madison Square Garden in 2006 on the momentum of its million-selling debut album, “A Fever You Can’t Sweat Out,” was at the Bowery Ballroom on Tuesday night, starting the promotional surge behind “Vices & Virtues” (Fueled By Ramen/Decaydance/Atlantic), its third album, to be released on March 29. The show coincides with the release of a single, “The Ballad of Mona Lisa”  not a ballad, but a midtempo rocker.

headline: Models, Plain and Fancy
text: Karl Smith argues that informal economic arguments — models in the sense of thought experiments, not necessarily backed by equations and/or data-crunching — deserve more respect from the profession. I agree, and not just because he cites my use of the baby-sitting coop, described in a wonderful but ignored article by Sweeney and Sweeney, as an example.

headline: Taking Your Own Passport Photos
text: Q. Can I take my own passport pictures with my digital camera or do I have to go to a place that specifically takes these portraits?

headline: How to Lower Your Heating Bill
text: With harsh winter weather hitting much of the country, many consumers are probably wondering about simple steps they can take to lower their heating bills.

headline: Instagram Raises Money
text: People sure do like taking photos on their iPhone. Just ask Instagram, the popular mobile photo-sharing Web service available on Apple’s mobile platform.

headline: Americans Discover America
text: The mutual fund trade group reports that funds specializing in American stocks have had net inflows of cash in each of the last three weeks. The last time that happened was last April. Then there were net inflows for four consecutive weeks.

headline: Inflation and Stock Prices
text: Scott Sumner sends us to David Glasner, who shows that stock prices have had a positive correlation with expected inflation since 2008, strongly suggesting that aggregate demand is at the heart of our problems.

headline: Class Action Suit Filed Against Jimmy Carter Book
text: Readers are often warned not to judge a book by its cover, but what about its publicity? That is the basis of a class-action lawsuit against former President Jimmy Carter and his publisher Simon & Schuster over his 2006 book “Palestine: Peace, Not Apartheid,” which was filed in Manhattan federal court on Tuesday.

headline: To Defend Against Disease, a Plant Checks the Clock
text: Plants, like many other organisms, have circadian clocks that help them anticipate various environmental and biological events that occur at precise times of the day. Processes like photosynthesis, fragrance emission and time of bloom are all regulated by this timekeeping mechanism.

headline: Asian Cup: Japan Is on the Up
text: TOKYO — Japan has just won the Asian Cup, moved into the top 20 in the FIFA rankings and is clearly the best team in Asia. And if you think it was a fluke, think again.

headline: The Dollar and Global Standing
text: From Barry Eichengreen (via Matt Yglesias):

headline: A Misjudged Late Discard Unravels the Defense
text: The most successful players at the District 3 Winter Regional last month in Rye Brook, N.Y., were R. J. Becker of New York and Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J. They had two firsts, one second and one third, collecting 67.63 master points.

headline: Karsan’s Taxi Introduces Itself to Potential Passengers
text: Karsan, the Turkish company whose taxi design is one of three finalists in New York’s Taxi of Tomorrow competition, showed off the first prototype of its body at a press event in Manhattan on Wednesday.

headline: Enduring Impression of a Fleeting Moment
text: Carl Kiilsgaard, 24, is a freelance photographer in Portland, Ore. He attended Western Kentucky University and has been an intern at The Napa Valley Register and The Palm Beach Post. In 2008, Reportage by Getty Images selected him as an “emerging talent.” His conversation with Kerri MacDonald for the Turning Point series has been edited.

headline: Stevie Wonder to Be Named to Apollo Theater’s Hall of Fame
text: The musician who first took the stage of the Apollo Theater in Harlem as Little Stevie Wonder at age 12 in 1962 and then went on to some very big things will receive an  honor from the theater later this year. The Apollo is to announce on Wednesday that it will induct Mr. Wonder – he’s just Stevie now, thank you very much – into its Apollo Legends Hall of Fame. Mr. Wonder, the best-selling pop and soul artist whose albums include “Talking Book,” “Innervisions” and “Songs in the Key of Life,” was a child performer on Berry Gordy’s Motown Revue when he made his Apollo debut, and returned several times to the theater for performances including its “Save the Apollo” concert in the 1980s and a series of solo shows in 2005, the theater’s press representatives said. Other artists already named to the theater’s Hall of Fame include Michael Jackson, Aretha Franklin, Quincy Jones, Smokey Robinson and Ella Fitzgerald. Mr. Wonder is to be officially inducted on June 13 at the Apollo’s annual spring gala.

headline: ‘Emperor of Atlantis’
text: The opera is a satire of Hitler that was written and first performed in a Nazi concentration camp.

headline: Falling Ice in Manhattan
text: Wednesday's storm created hazardous conditions for pedestrians in Midtown.

headline: Portraits of a Grounded Hawk
text: While we wait for Newshawk, the juvenile red-tailed hawk who injured his wing crashing into the glass-walled atrium at the headquarters of The New York Times a few weeks ago, to continue his recovery, we thought we’d share with you these drawings. They were done by Kaye Blegvad, an illustrator and designer based in London who happened to be visiting The Times that day.

headline: Documentary Drama at the Oscars
text: In 2007, when the journalists Sebastian Junger and Tim Hetherington set out to make a documentary following a military unit in Afghanistan, they had no awards aspirations.

headline: Peltz Reports Other Approaches for Wendy’s
text: Nelson Peltz‘s investor group, the biggest shareholder in the Wendy’s/Arby’s Group restaurant chain, said in a filing on Wednesday that it had recent discussions with potential suitors for the company.

headline: Street Battle Over the Arab Future
text: CAIRO  The future of the Arab world, perched between revolt and the contempt of a crumbling order, was fought for in the streets of downtown Cairo on Wednesday.

headline: Sex Scandals in Italy Fuel Discontent of Women
text: ROME  Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy has said he is laughing off his latest sex scandal, in which prosecutors are investigating whether he compensated a number of attractive young women, including a 17-year-old nicknamed “Ruby Heart-Stealer,” for sex.

headline: Rodriguez Reflects on His Departure
text: For the past 25 years, Rich Rodriguez had spent each day crossing items off a to-do list, a football coach always consumed by his next task. That has changed since he was fired from Michigan.

headline: A New Realm of Celebrity
text: On the world stage, Benjamin Millepied is in his newest and most public role, as companion to Natalie Portman.

headline: Benjamin Millepied Leaps Into the Spotlight
text: IT was the laugh heard around the Web. Natalie Portman, glowing in a pink Viktor & Rolf gown, bounded onstage at the Golden Globes last month to accept the award for best actress for her role in the psychological thriller “Black Swan.”

headline: Medical Detectives Find Their First New Disease
text: Louise Benge’s medical problems started when she was 25. Walking became excruciating. Her calves got hard as rocks, and every step was agony. Her hands started hurting, too. And the condition, whatever it was, only got worse over the next two decades.

headline: Ebersol Starts to Reshape Sports at Comcast
text: Dick Ebersol, who has run NBC Sports for nearly 22 years, is wasting little time putting his personal stamp on the sports properties of Comcast, which include the Golf Channel and Versus, and 11 regional sports networks.

headline: Activist Funds Oppose Smurfit-Stone’s RockTenn Deal
text: Three hedge funds, including Third Point Capital, announced on Wednesday that they opposed Smurfit-Stone‘s $3.5 billion sale to a competitor, the RockTenn Company, arguing the deal price was too low.

headline: Nomura Evolves, Just Not So Fast
text: Nomura, the Japanese firm, is evolving into a global investment bank even if it does not yet look like one. It reported a strong increase in investment banking fees for the final quarter of 2010, and its traders have begun to prove their worth. The gap with the big league is closing — slowly.

headline: Egyptian Crisis Gives CNN a Ratings Boost
text: CNN reaffirmed that it remains a brand for breaking news Tuesday evening, with the protests in Egypt providing the compelling story.

headline: New Tiles Based on David Hicks’s Designs
text: Popham Design, a tile company in Marrakesh, Morocco, has teamed up with the designer Ashley Hicks to produce three new designs inspired by work done in the 1970s by Mr. Hicks’s father, the late decorator David Hicks.

headline: A New Line of Lacquered Furnishings
text: Moste, a line of lacquered furniture and decorative accessories designed by Billy Cotton and Michael Bargo, “was inspired by Sottsass Memphis pieces, and Donald Judd,” Mr. Cotton said. Although most of the items are “not as simple as Judd and not as wild as Sottsass,” he added.

headline: Sales at Branca, Desiron and Garnet Hill
text: Branca, a home furnishings retailer in Chicago, is discounting everything in the store and online by up to 50 percent, through Feb. 12 (an AB Collection blanket, originally $225, is about $170; a medium-size black Cire Trudon candle with red medallion, regularly $65, is about $33; and a set of eight Louis XVI-style white-painted dining chairs upholstered in ticking, originally $19,000, is $15,000); information: (312) 787-1017 or branca.com.

headline: Recliners
text: THERE are few pieces of furniture that cause as much discord as recliners. For some, they’re a guilty pleasure; others consider them an eyesore.

headline: Retailers Try Their Hand as Gallerists
text: Design enthusiasts with small budgets, rejoice: there are now so many places to find affordable artwork that it is hard not to have impressive wall art.

headline: Nigel Coates at Cristina Grajales Gallery in SoHo
text: Nigel Coates’s Baroccabilly furniture and lighting, on display this month and next at the Cristina Grajales Gallery in SoHo, was inspired by the unrestrained style of baroque design and rockabilly music. And by a fantasy narrative Mr. Coates invented in which an imaginary character inhabits a landscape made up of forms, textures and shapes he designed. (As he put it: “Form follows fiction.”)

headline: Pictures at an Exhibition
text: To the Editor:

headline: In a Manhattan Studio, Everything Within a Swivel
text: Clever, thrifty touches abound in an Upper West Side apartment that measures just over 200 square feet.

headline: Fireside Chat
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Camellia Preserve on an Island Known for Tabasco Peppers
text: AVERY ISLAND, La.

headline: Margaret Russell Unveils the New Architectural Digest
text: “THE Age of Elegance,” states the cover of the March issue of Architectural Digest, sounding somewhat hopeful. The bright pink affirmation declares a new brief for a once-mighty title that has been struggling, and a statement of intent from its new editor, Margaret Russell, who was until last summer the very steady helmsman of a competitor, Elle Décor.

headline: Chicken Vanishes, Heartbreak Ensues
text: THE chickens of New York City, for the most part, live fairly sheltered lives, securely tucked into private backyards and padlocked community gardens. Our chickens, by contrast, are public figures — their yard faces 20 feet of busy Bedford-Stuyvesant sidewalk. The chickens themselves chose this bustling thoroughfare, decamping there even when they could have settled in our spacious, semiprivate back garden. They wanted to see and be seen — like so many New York transplants, they seemed to feed on the energy of the street.

headline: Emil Fiore on Searching Out Spider Webs
text: If you like authentic, there is nothing like a paperweight made out of an actual spider web, silvered (O.K., aluminum-ed) and preserved in an orb of glass. ABC Carpet & Home, in Manhattan, has been selling them for the past few months, for $45 to $110.

headline: 200 Square Feet and Room to Swivel
text: FOR Malena Georgieva, it’s been a long trip to the Upper West Side of Manhattan. A native of Plovdiv, Bulgaria, a provincial city about an hour from Sofia, she received a degree in Soviet-style industrial management just as the Soviet Union was collapsing. Adapting to the post-Communist world after emigrating to the United States in 1993, she enrolled in a master’s program at the University of New Haven, supporting herself as a hotel chambermaid for $4.50 an hour. (“I thought, if I ever make $10 an hour, I’ll be queen of the world,” she said.) Eventually, she was hired by Deloitte & Touche, beginning a career in risk management, and her simultaneous love affair with New York City.

headline: Gates for President? Not if He Can Help It
text: A nascent campaign to draft Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates as a 2012 presidential candidate to run against his boss, Barack Obama, is being driven by two 27-year-old Texas A & M graduates who say they had “informal conversations” with Mr. Gates about their effort this past Saturday night.

headline: Democrats Defeat Attempt to Repeal Health Care Law
text: WASHINGTON – Senate Democrats on Wednesday defeated a bid by Republicans to repeal last year’s sweeping health care overhaul, as they successfully mounted a party-line defense of President Obama’s signature domestic policy achievement.

headline: Brimming With Clues That Are Hard to Link
text: “The Death Instinct” opens on that September day when Lower Manhattan was blown apart, and Americans started wondering who could hate them so much. The day the word “terrorist” became part of our vocabulary, and the country rallied to war.

headline: Intel Chip Flaw Causes Delays for PC Makers
text: Computer makers have been forced to shut down some of their assembly lines because of a design flaw in chips produced by Intel.

headline: Readers’ Photos of the Winter Storm
text: A ferocious winter storm blanketed wide areas from the Great Plains to New England in deep snow and left a skin of ice over large sections of the Northeast.

headline: Lavish Centennial Plans Testify to the Strength of Reagan’s Influence
text: SIMI VALLEY, Calif.  Ronald Reagan would have turned 100 this Sunday, and nearly seven years after his death, one might think he were still alive and leading the Republican Party.

headline: Memorable, Too
text: Notable events from 1911, the year of Ronald Reagan’s birth:

headline: Printers Adapt to World of the Web
text: Now that you can view maps on cellphones, send pictures directly from a digital camera to photo frames and use a smartphone’s screen as a virtual airline boarding pass, who needs to print any more?

headline: Chicago Humbled by Powerful Storm
text: CHICAGO  When Jenny Theroux plotted her commute home Tuesday afternoon, she was certain she would arrive well before the full force of the blizzard hit. For the final leg of her trip, she turned onto Lake Shore Drive, this city’s wide and busy thoroughfare along Lake Michigan, at 4 p.m.

headline: Smoking Ban for Beaches and Parks Is Approved
text: After a bitter debate over individual liberties and the role of government, the City Council on Wednesday handily approved a bill to ban smoking in 1,700 city parks and along 14 miles of city beaches.

headline: Meeting Mubarak's Supporters
text: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof spoke to President Hosni Mubarak's supporters in Tahrir Square, Cairo, on Wednesday.

headline: What the North Got Wrong
text: In the years and months preceding the Civil War, the Republicans in general and Abraham Lincoln in particular made many mistakes or misjudgments. And these errors were vitally important in bringing on the war. But this is not to say that defective statesmanship was the problem. For the mistakes made were rooted in Republican ideology, and that ideology was, in turn, rooted in the social and economic conditions of the antebellum North.

headline: Hackers Shut Down Government Sites
text: The online group Anonymous said Wednesday that it had paralyzed the Egyptian government’s Web sites in support of the antigovernment protests.

headline: From Space, Giffords’s Brother-in-Law Speaks on Shooting
text: When Scott Kelly got word from Mission Control on Jan. 8 that the head of the astronaut office wanted to talk with him directly on a private line, he recalled, “I knew whatever it was, it wasn’t good.”

headline: City to Battle Mortgage Fraud With Computer Alert
text: Despite the bright spotlight that the housing crisis shined on mortgage fraud, officials say New Yorkers continue to be duped. Now, the city is taking aim at the perpetuators of mortgage fraud through a program that it hopes will root out questionable property transactions and alert officials and prosecutors when they happen.

headline: Park Service Seeks Quiet in the Grand Canyon
text: TUCSON  That the Grand Canyon is a visual spectacle is without question. But the constant droning of tourist aircraft overhead, which has worsened considerably over the years, has prompted the National Park Service to propose measures to make one of America’s premier natural areas much easier on the ears.

headline: In Book, Rumsfeld Recalls Bush’s Early Iraq Focus
text: WASHINGTON  Just 15 days after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, President George W. Bush invited his defense secretary, Donald H. Rumsfeld, to meet with him alone in the Oval Office. According to Mr. Rumsfeld’s new memoir, the president leaned back in his leather chair and ordered a review and revision of war plans  but not for Afghanistan, where the Qaeda attacks on New York and Washington had been planned and where American retaliation was imminent.

headline: A Sex Joke and Other Judicial Bad Behavior
text: One judge who was driving drunk led the police on a half-mile chase, and when he was pulled over, asked for “professional courtesy.”

headline: Officials Consider Requiring Insurers to Offer Free Contraceptives
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is examining whether the new health care law can be used to require insurance plans to offer contraceptives and other family planning services to women free of charge.

headline: Summers’s Crystal Ball
text: The peripatetic Larry Summers is once again back at Harvard, teaching a class on American economic policy with Martin Feldstein and Jeff Liebman – two other prominent former government economists – and reacquainting himself with the joys of free speech now that he is no longer President Obama’s director of the National Economic Council, President Clinton’s treasury secretary or Harvard’s 27th president. What better time, then, than winter to check in with the lion?

headline: Foreclosed Homeowners Go to Court on Their Own
text: ALBUQUERQUE  Saving your home from foreclosure is increasingly a do-it-yourself project.

headline: Judging How Birth Videos Affect a Lawsuit
text: Video is a particular worry in the delivery room because it picks up actions that a still camera might not and the sound can make a situation seem worse than it is.

headline: Energy Firms Aided by U.S. Find Backers
text: WASHINGTON  In late 2009, the federal government gave $151 million in grants to advance 37 clean energy ideas deemed too radical or too preliminary to attract much private financing  like electricity storage that mimics photosynthesis and batteries that double or triple the energy stored per pound.

headline: Sudden Split Recasts U.S. Foreign Policy
text: WASHINGTON — After days of delicate public and private diplomacy, the United States openly broke with its most stalwart ally in the Arab world on Wednesday, as the Obama administration strongly condemned violence by allies of President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt against protesters and called on him to speed up his exit from power.

headline: News Corporation Introduces The Daily, a Digital-Only Newspaper
text: Rupert Murdoch on Wednesday pushed the send button on The Daily, a news application designed for the iPad that he hopes will position his News Corporation front and center in the digital newsstand of the future.

headline: The Cheat: A Winter’s Tail
text: Here is a midwinter cook-up of deep fragrance and lingering heat, a trade-wind stew that emerged in Jamaica and made its way north. It is oxtail stew, brown and steaming, light with ginger and thyme, pungent with allspice and soy, a taste of the Caribbean to warm winter’s heart. You could make and eat it today while reading Derek Walcott poems as the afternoon vagues into indigo — or allow it to cure into greater magnificence overnight, and stretch out its gravy for the course of a week.

headline: Coconut-Scented Rice
text: 2 tablespoons unsalted butter 1 small yellow onion, peeled and diced small 2 cloves garlic, peeled and minced 2 cups white rice 1 tablespoon thyme leaves 1 13-ounce can coconut milk 1 Scotch bonnet pepper, whole (optional) 1 cup cooked pigeon peas 2 tablespoons chopped scallion, green part only Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper, to taste 1. Melt butter in a medium sauce pan set over low heat. When it begins to foam, add the onion and the garlic, stir, and allow these to soften in the heat, about 3 minutes. 2. Add the rice and the thyme, and stir to combine. Add the coconut milk and 2 ½ cups water, and turn heat to high. Bring liquid to a simmer, then lower heat. If using pepper, place it in center of pot. Cover. Cook until the liquid is absorbed and rice is soft, approximately 25 minutes. Remove from heat and fluff with a fork. If using pepper, remove it. Add peas and scallions, then stir to combine. Season to taste with salt and pepper, then cover pot again and keep warm until ready to serve. Serves 4.

headline: Jamaican Oxtail Stew
text: 3 pounds oxtails, cut into segments by a butcher

headline: Facebook’s New, Simple and Essential Safety Feature
text: Last week, the Facebook chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, found his personal account hacked. If it could happen to Mr. Zuckerberg, users realized, it could happen to anyone.

headline: Bloomberg Seeks a Sweeping Overhaul of City’s Pensions
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed sweeping changes on Wednesday to New York’s costly pension system, seeking to save billions of dollars by fundamentally altering long-established rules that have awarded generous retirement benefits to municipal workers and have deepened the city’s financial hole.

headline: A Diner Saved From Extinction Needs Saving Again
text: It seemed kind of sweet when it played out six years ago: one of New York’s retro diners hovering near death was saved and trucked off intact for a new life in the Catskills.

headline: Shake-Up at Network Carrying N.H.L. Games
text: Versus, Comcast’s second-tier sports network whose top offerings include N.H.L. games, is getting an expected overhaul after Comcast took control of NBC Universal on Jan. 28. Top officials lost their positions, and a name change could be in the store for the network. Richard Sandomir writes on Media Decoder:

headline: News Corp.’s Net Income More Than Doubles, Led by Its Cable Networks
text: Joining other media companies in reaping the benefits of a rebounding advertising market, the News Corporation said Wednesday that it had more than doubled its net income in the quarter that ended Dec. 31.

headline: On Gulf Oil Spill’s Effects, Doing Science With a Deadline
text: In mid-December, Wes Tunnell’s phone rang with a request that would ruin his holiday plans.

headline: And Down This Aisle, Many Whole Grain Options
text: CEREAL is a mainstay of the American breakfast, but deciding among the numerous varieties can be daunting — just take a trip down a supermarket’s cereal aisle and try to parse the ingredients on any box.

headline: For iPhone, Almost Heaven
text: It’s here. After almost four years of speculation, the iPhone will finally come to Verizon’s network on Feb. 10.

headline: Thrust From Margins Into a Big Game’s Glare
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.

headline: Faith-Healing Parents Get Probation
text: PHILADELPHIA  A couple who prayed over their dying son rather than taking him to a doctor were sentenced on Wednesday to 10 years’ probation, and ordered to ensure regular medical care for their seven surviving children.

headline: The Packers’ Modest G.M. Has Plenty to Brag About
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Ted Thompson stood behind a barricade, apart from the Super Bowl team that he constructed. He answered questions with eyes pointed downward and hands shoved into pockets, forever shy, reserved, uncomfortable, even now.

headline: F.D.A. Sued Over Drug Used in Executions
text: Lawyers in Washington sued the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday on behalf of death-row prisoners, demanding that a Federal District Court prohibit importation and use of sodium thiopental, a drug used in many executions. When the sole supplier of the drug in the United States stopped producing it, executions were delayed in several states, and states obtained the drug from overseas suppliers. The agency has long said it has no authority over executions. The lead lawyer in the suit, Bradford A. Berenson, said it was “not about halting executions but rather about ensuring that illegal drugs are not used in carrying out otherwise lawful sentences.”

headline: Lockout Not Inevitable, League Negotiator Says
text: DALLAS  A lockout on March 4 is not inevitable if the N.F.L. and the players union are close to forging a new collective bargaining agreement, Jeff Pash, the lead negotiator for the league, said Wednesday.

headline: Massive Storm Batters States
text: A massive storm debilitated towns and cities across the Midwest.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Charles H. Kaman, Helicopter Innovator, Dies at 91
text: Charles H. Kaman, an innovator in the development and manufacture of helicopter technology and, following a wholly different passion, the inventor of one of the first electrically amplified acoustic guitars, died on Monday in Bloomfield, Conn. He was 91.

headline: Frank Wisner, the Diplomat Sent to Prod Mubarak
text: WASHINGTON  Once a month or so, a coterie of aging diplomats convenes at the elegant Metropolitan Club of New York. Over lunch in a glass-enclosed restaurant overlooking Central Park, they engage in verbal thrust and parry over the foreign policy issues of the day.

headline: Joint Venture Creates a Rival For Concert Ticketing Services
text: In a challenge to Live Nation Entertainment, the music giant created last year by the merger of Ticketmaster and the promoter Live Nation, a rival concert company has made a deal for its own ticketing system.

headline: Google Updates Its Latitude Service
text: Android users who upgrade to Google Maps 5.1, available since Tuesday, will find a bunch of new features added to Latitude, Google’s location-based social network. The first is the ability to check in to actual places, like restaurants and stores. In the past, Latitude users could indicate where they were on a map, but the actual business or building they were in remained a mystery. (“I’m in Rockefeller Center” is not terribly helpful. “I’m in J. Crew” is.)

headline: U.S. Agency to Handle Drug Testing at Tour of California
text: The Tour of California, the most prominent road cycling race in the United States, has hired the United States Anti-Doping Agency to handle its drug testing instead of relying on cycling’s governing body to conduct those tests, a race official said Wednesday.

headline: Public Theater’s Finance Chief Quits With Little Explanation
text: Andrew D. Hamingson has resigned as executive director of the Public Theater after only two and a half years as the company’s top financial executive, he and the Public’s board chairman, Warren Spector, announced on Wednesday.

headline: Parking Rules for New York City
text: Because of the Asian Lunar New Year, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended on Thursday in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Price-Fixing by KeySpan Will Cost It $12 Million
text: Although price-fixing by an electricity company may have cost New York customers nearly $300 million, the federal government can close the books on the case by collecting a penalty of just $12 million, a judge ruled on Wednesday.

headline: When Water, Cold, Gravity and a Building Come Together
text: When ice starts falling from skyscrapers, as happened on Wednesday in New York, the temptation is to fault the modern architect, who is often viewed as long on aesthetic vision but short on practical details.

headline: An End to a Long Tenure Defending the Infamous
text: Leonard F. Joy, the lawyer who has led New York’s influential federal public defender’s office for the last two decades, is retiring this month, ending a tenure during which his office represented some of the most infamous defendants being prosecuted by the United States attorney’s offices in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

headline: Cuomo’s Budget Whittles at All Corners of the State
text: ALBANY  Homeless shelters in New York City could be forced to cut back on services. State support for cancer research could be curtailed. Some college students receiving help to pay for school could lose their money.

headline: As Crisis Unfolds Overseas, Diplomats Gather in Washington
text: WASHINGTON  Nearly all the top United States diplomats from around the world met here on Wednesday, summoned by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton to consider new strategies to energize diplomacy and streamline development, but their arrival coincided with one of the most tumultuous moments for American diplomacy in recent memory.

headline: Sell or Build? Devils Owners Clash Over How to Proceed
text: The Devils may be streaking back into contention, but the team’s majority owner, Jeff Vanderbeek, is becoming bogged down in a fight over the club’s future.

headline: Sony’s New PlayStation Portable
text: NGP (“Next Generation Portable”) is Sony’s code name for the successor to the company’s PSP Go portable gaming system.

headline: Aesthetics? This Architect Likes the Dirty Work
text: Karen Thomas worked for more than 20 years at architecture firms in New York, including Costas Kondylis and  Beyer Blinder Belle, after graduating from Pennsylvania State University in 1988. But she eventually realized she would rather manage the construction of complex buildings than draw their blueprints. In 2007 she established her own firm, Karen Thomas Associates, an owner’s representative for high-end residential projects. Ms. Thomas, 45, lives in Greenwich Village with her husband, Ralph Gillis, an architect and former employer of hers, and their 9-year-old son, Henry.

headline: Walking With a Jaguar
text: Tourists and volunteers can walk jaguars and pumas without any special training at Ambue Ari, an animal refuge in the Bolivian jungle.

headline: Early Maneuvering on Possible Shutdown
text: WASHINGTON  Democrats do not intend to shut up when it comes to a potential government shutdown.

headline: Thursday: Dash Away Home
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — My brain hurts.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,456 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: Yankees Acquire Potential Backup Outfielder
text: The Yankees continued to round out the fringes of their roster on Wednesday, acquiring the right-handed-hitting outfielder Justin Maxwell from the Washington Nationals. Maxwell, a career .201 hitter over parts of three seasons with Washington, could make the Yankees as a backup outfielder or, at the very least, improve their depth at Class AAA.

headline: Bloomberg’s Plan on Pension Changes
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed sweeping changes on Wednesday to the pension system for New York City’s municipal work force, including raising the retirement age for new employees and eliminating a bonus for retired police officers and firefighters.

headline: Return of the Videophone (Part 973)
text: WorldGate’s Ojo Vision digital videophone is an option worth considering for those who don’t want to sit in front of a computer or use a smartphone to make video calls.

headline: ‘Daily Show’ and ‘Jersey Shore’ Deals for Viacom and Hulu
text: Viacom and Hulu have finally come to terms to provide Web audiences better access to “The Daily Show” and “Jersey Shore.”

headline: Cuban Declines to Enter Chase for the Mets
text: Mark Cuban is a big baseball fan with a lot of discretionary income who would love the chance to own a major league franchise. But not now and not the Mets.

headline: Fund Official Not Neutral, Judge Rules
text: Kenneth R. Feinberg, the administrator of the $20 billion fund to compensate victims of the Gulf of Mexico oil spill, should not claim that he is fully independent of BP, a federal judge overseeing litigation against the company ruled on Wednesday.

headline: Out for a Leisurely Stroll in the Middle of a Jungle
text: AMBUE ARI, Bolivia  The mosquitoes descend so ferociously that residents simply call them “the plague.” Piranhas patrol streams. Caiman lurk in ponds. Then there are the monkeys. Visiting volunteers at this jungle outpost have written verses about their propensity to urinate on human belongings.

headline: Egypt’s Bumbling Brotherhood
text: AS Egyptians clash over the future of their government, Americans and Europeans have repeatedly expressed fears of the Muslim Brotherhood. “You don’t just have a government and a movement for democracy,” Tony Blair, the former British prime minister, said of Egypt on Monday. “You also have others, notably the Muslim Brotherhood, who would take this in a different direction.”

headline: For Debt-Ridden French Region, a Famous Son Is Now an Expensive Proposition
text: SARRAN, France  Corrèze is the most indebted of all of France’s 100 departments, and former President Jacques Chirac appears to be the prime reason.

headline: India: Arrests in Telephone Scandal
text: The former telecommunications minister whose handling of the sale of mobile telephone spectrum licenses may have cost the government as much as $39 billion in revenue has been arrested, officials said. A government report released last year accused the former minister, Andimuthu Raja, of selling the airwaves at giveaway prices to favored companies. The ensuing scandal shook what had been India’s most stable government in decades and raised questions about whether the nation’s rapid growth could be at risk because of rampant corruption. Mr. Raja and several associates were arrested on Wednesday.

headline: Knicks Are Inconsistent at Both Ends of Floor
text: The offense came in big, loud bursts and disappeared just as quickly. Danilo Gallinari hit shot after shot, then faded into the background. Amar’e Stoudemire rumbled for 21 points in the first half, and none in the second half.

headline: Senate Rejects Repeal of Health Care Law
text: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats on Wednesday defeated a bid by Republicans to repeal last year’s sweeping health care overhaul, as they successfully mounted a party-line defense of President Obama’s signature domestic policy achievement.

headline: New Hampshire: Early Release for Farmer
text: A farmer sent to prison for waving a gun at a trespasser won early release on Wednesday after an outpouring of community support. The farmer, Ward Bird, 49, of Moultonborough, was convicted of criminal threatening with a firearm after warning a woman who said she was lost to get off his property in 2006. Mr. Bird denied brandishing the gun. The case struck a nerve with gun and property rights supporters. After Gov. John Lynch would not allow Mr. Bird to be pardoned, the New Hampshire Executive Council voted unanimously to free him, two and a half months into his three-year sentence.

headline: Barney Hajiro, Medal of Honor Recipient, Dies at 94
text: After Barney Hajiro, an Army private, single-handedly wiped out two German machine gun nests and killed two snipers in a gallant charge in World War II, his superiors recommended him for the Medal of Honor.

headline: Hardware, Not Jewelry, for Belichick and Brady

headline: Zimbabwe: Mugabe Opponents Beaten
text: As President Robert Mugabe and his party, ZANU-PF, push for elections this year, political violence in Harare, the capital, and its impoverished suburbs  carried out by youths chanting ZANU-PF slogans  has surged in recent weeks, civic groups and independent journalists reported this week. Doctors said in a written account on Wednesday that they had treated nine supporters of Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirai, Mr. Mugabe’s rival. On Monday, they were assaulted with logs and stones and kicked by assailants wearing boots in Mbare, a suburb. Three of the victims were hospitalized with what the doctors described as “grave injuries.”

headline: No Way to Run a Trade Policy

Last month, a conflict over imported sleeping bags between a company in Alabama and a rival in Kentucky led Senate Republicans to block the extension of the Generalized System of Preferences, or G.S.P., which has granted preferential access to some $20 billion worth of imports from developing countries.

headline: Gov. Cuomo’s Budget
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo was right this week when he said New York cannot allow special interests and inertia to keep driving up state spending. He was right that painful cuts must be made to close a $10 billion deficit in the state’s projected $96 billion operating budget.

headline: What Will the Future Be Like?

What will we do for fun? What will your city or town look like? For inspiration, have a look at the drawings that depict New York City’s “future that never was,” predictions from planners and visionaries of the 20th century of what New York City should be.

Oh, and you are there to waltz. This imaginative evening isn’t a dream sequence — it’s time once again for the annual Prague Opera Ball, scheduled this year for Feb. 5.

headline: Avoiding I.T. Slip-Ups When Going Global
text: Dean Jerrehian, founder and chief executive of JadeYoga, a high-end yoga-mat manufacturer in Conshohocken, Pa., recently stumbled on a trove of his grandfather’s letters. Mr. Jerrehian had to laugh when he saw what the man had to go through to set up meetings with clients in his real estate business 70 years ago. “It took him months of letters to arrange to meet someone by the side of road,” he said. “And this was for a client who was all of 40 miles away. I was complaining the other day because it took me three days of swapping e-mail to nail down a deal in Jakarta. Just in the last few days I’ve been dealing with customers in Indonesia, Australia, Japan, Israel and Turkey.”

headline: 2011: The Year of the Anniversary
text: What connects Horace Greeley, Gypsy Rose Lee, the city’s first black police officer, the Manhattan street grid, City Hall, the New York Public Library building on Fifth Avenue and the Triangle Shirtwaist fire? Their centennials or bicentennials are being commemorated this year.

headline: Australians Take Cover as Cyclone Lashes Coast
text: SYDNEY, Australia  One of the most powerful cyclones ever to strike Australia ripped dozens of houses from their foundations, uprooted trees and shredded millions of dollars worth of sugar and banana crops when it slammed into Queensland’s northeastern coast in the predawn hours on Thursday.

headline: Updates on Day 10 of Egypt Protests

Updates below mix alerts on breaking news and reports from bloggers and journalists posted on other news sites and social networks. A stream of Twitter updates on the protests is in this blog’s right column. Readers can share information in the comment thread below or send photographs or video from Egypt to pix@nyt.com.

headline: Seeing Things | Louis Kahn’s Italian Idyll
text: “Kahn in Venice,” an exhibition at the Italian Cultural Institute in Los Angeles, celebrates the architect Louis I. Kahn’s special relationship with Italy. His unbuilt 1968 project for a congress hall in Venice is the centerpiece of the show, which was organized in collaboration with the Architectural Archives of the University of Pennsylvania, and which also includes many of Kahn’s lush, expressive travel sketches of buildings, gardens, bridges and street scenes in Venice, Rome and the hill towns of Tuscany. (The exhibition, which is on view through March 19, was curated and designed by the Los Angeles architects Barton Myers and David Karp, both of whom were Kahn’s students and apprentices.)

headline: Gangs Hunt Journalists and Rights Workers
text: Journalists covering the revolt against President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt have found themselves the targets of widespread anger and suspicion in an apparently coordinated campaign that is intended to stifle the flow of news that could further undermine the government.

A few scrums ensued and DiPietro met his netminding counterpart, Brent Johnson, at the Islanders’ blue line. Both shed their blockers and gloves.

Other performers already scheduled for the show, which will be broadcast live on CBS: Eminem, Lady Gaga, Arcade Fire, Justin Bieber and Usher, Katy Perry, and the very intriguing combination of Cee Lo Green with Gwyneth Paltrow and the Jim Henson Company Puppets.

headline: A Very Laid-Back Front-Runner
text: In our column today, the Bagger looks at the documentary race, where there may actually be some drama. Not that you would know it from the behavior of the presumed front-runner, Charles Ferguson, the director of “Inside Job,” his dissection of the financial meltdown. Mr. Ferguson, an early Internet millionaire, is soft-spoken and unconcerned with appearances; he’s been known to show up at awards shows in sneakers. He’s been through the Oscar process before, with his first film, “No End in Sight,” in 2008. What’s changed in his approach since then? “I have an agent now, which I never did before,” he said. “I’ve spoken to the Sony publicity people a few times.” (Sony Pictures Classics is the distributor of “Inside Job,” which is being re-released in theaters on the back of its Oscar nomination.) “But,” he added of the Oscar race, “this is totally not my department.”

headline: Now Opening | Honor
text: With only one season under her belt, Giovanna Randall, the designer behind the New York-based label Honor, is opening a shop in the meatpacking district. But there is more in store than Randall’s girlie cocktail dresses and long chiffon evening gowns. Like the label that shares its name, Honor is all about the prettier, finer points of a woman’s pleasures. “I started asking myself, ‘What do you think Sophia Loren’s couch looks like?’ or ‘What kind of typewriter would Grace Kelly have used?’ ” the designer says. Randall plans to display her collection alongside vintage and new books. Cafe treats like Bellocq tea and espresso are a small step toward Randall’s dream of turning Honor into a multidimensional lifestyle brand. “I fantasize about coming by the shop and being able to pick up a lovely party dress and wonderful bouquet of flowers en route to a friend’s birthday dinner.” So do we.

headline: He Can Serve, but He Can’t Run
text: Joseph Chirlee is an American citizen and a private in the United States Army stationed in Colorado. He is also a world-class marathoner with a shot at qualifying for the 2012 Summer Olympics. He had hoped to run in the national cross-country championships Saturday in San Diego.

headline: Daniel Bell, Master Builder
text: With the death last month of Daniel Bell, America lost its last great 20th-century big thinker, though this is not necessarily the impression many now have of him. One reason is that Bell was most prolific during a period, 1950-80, bounded by the cold war, that has receded into the half-forgotten past. Another is that for most of his career, Bell was seen less as a singular figure than as one of a club of intellectuals whose pedigrees were so similar they seemed interchangeable — New York City-reared Jews trained in factional combat at City College and groomed as journalists in the pages of small-circulation magazines (The New Leader, Commentary, Partisan Review, Encounter, The Public Interest), with detours into the Luce empire (Bell was for a time the labor editor of Fortune) and university perches (in Bell’s case Columbia and Harvard).

In a small circle, they kept the ball in the air, passing it to one another. For Bolton Wanderers, an English Premier League team, there was a playfully cruel twist to the game: the first man to let the ball touch the ground would have his ears flicked by every member of the team.

headline: Another Challenge to Greenhouse Gas Regulation
text: Three Republican lawmakers have joined the bandwagon of opponents of Environmental Protection Agency regulation of climate-altering gases. Senator James Inhofe of Oklahoma and Representatives Fred Upton of Michigan and Ed Whitfield of Kentucky are circulating a draft of a bill dubbed the Energy Tax Prevention Act of 2011 that takes aim squarely at the E.P.A.’s authority to impose limits on emissions of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping gases.

headline: As Islamist Group Rises, Its Intentions Are Unclear
text: WASHINGTON  After maintaining a low profile in protests led largely by secular young Egyptians, the Muslim Brotherhood, the country’s largest opposition force, appeared to be taking a more assertive role on Thursday, issuing a statement asking for President Hosni Mubarak to step aside for a transitional government.

headline: City’s High Abortion Rate Defies Easy Explanation
text: At a time when evidence suggests that people in New York City are smoking less, eating better and biking more, one health statistic that has not budged is the abortion rate.

headline: President and Opera, on Unexpected Stages
text: During a panel discussion about “Nixon in China” on Tuesday at the Metropolitan Opera, Peter Gelb turned to the team of onetime artistic rebels who created this work for its Houston Grand Opera premiere in 1987 and suggested that back then, surely, no one involved had had any ambitions for the Met. Other than “for its dismantlement,” Mr. Gelb added.

headline: Alexander the Great
text: One of the most exciting lines I saw during this recent men’s show season in Paris was off the runways, in a small gallery on the rue de Turenne in the Marais. Alexandre Plokhov, a co-founder of the much-missed Cloak label and the recently departed designer of Versace’s men’s-wear line, introduced his new namesake collection of architectural suiting and design-minded sportswear pieces. Before walking through the racks of clothing, I was shown a short film by Douglas Keeve, whom Plokhov met during the filming of “Seamless,” a documentary featuring young designers vying for the first CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund. (Plokhov lost first prize to Lazaro Hernandez and Jack McCullough of Proenza Schouler.)

headline: Palin Will Skip Conservative Gathering
text: Sarah Palin has declined an invitation to join leading Republicans in appearing at the next Conservative Political Action Conference, a key gathering of party activists who hold an influential voice in the Republican presidential nominating contest.

headline: With Subtraction and Addition, Haiti Sets Its Presidential Runoff
text: MEXICO CITY  After a nearly two-month standoff with international donors over its disputed presidential election, Haiti’s electoral council on Thursday announced that it had removed the government-backed candidate from the second round of voting in favor of a popular musician whose supporters had protested fiercely when he was initially excluded.

headline: Photo of the Week – Guess Where This Is
text: For our Photo of the Week this week, we’re bringing back one of our favorite features, Guess Where This Is. The rules: We provide a hint and you guess the location in comments below. We’ll provide the answer later this afternoon.

headline: Union Membership Rate Lowest in 15 Years
text: New York and New Jersey may have stopped shedding jobs in 2010, but their labor unions have not, a report released Thursday by the federal Department of Labor shows.

headline: Keeping Score: Kevin Love’s Rare Combination of Talents
text: Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Portland Trail Blazers.

headline: Many in Pakistan Fear Unrest at Home
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Protests over crippling prices and corrupt leadership are sweeping much of the Islamic world, but here in Pakistan this week, the government blithely dismissed any threat to its longevity or to the country’s stability.

headline: Pride of Place in Every Drop
text: For Joe Santos, producing and distributing his own gin was a way to say goodbye to the lock-step march of the corporate world and hello to creativity and originality. He wanted to give the gin a name that communicated that. So he invoked a certain New York City borough, the one currently outpacing the others in self-satisfaction.

headline: Clashes Continue in Egypt
text: Clashes continued near Tahrir Square in Cairo on Thursday. Violence overnight left at least five dead and more than 800 wounded.

headline: The Drawing Center Expands Beyond Its Lines
text: After years of casting around for a new home, the space-starved Drawing Center has found a way to stay put and expand its galleries.

headline: Virginia to Ask Supreme Court to Rule on Health Law
text: Virginia’s attorney general announced on Thursday that he hoped to bypass an initial appellate review by asking the United States Supreme Court to consider the constitutionality of the Obama health care law on an expedited basis.

headline: Norris and Leonhardt on Jobs
text: 4:41 p.m. | Updated In advance of Friday’s jobs report, two Times columnists — Floyd Norris and David Leonhardt — talk about the state of the economy and the job market. [Their conversation continued on Friday morning, after the report was released.]

headline: Bernanke Takes Sides on Debt Limit Vote
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, warned Congressional Republicans on Thursday not to “play around with” a coming vote to raise the government’s legal borrowing limit or use it as a bargaining chip for spending cuts.

headline: King Moves to Widen Outreach in Jordan
text: AMMAN, Jordan  King Abdullah II, struggling to stave off growing public discontent, widened his political outreach on Thursday and met with the Muslim Brotherhood for the first time in nearly a decade. He also asserted in a statement that he would fight corruption and foster a broad national dialogue.

headline: Nepal Selects a Premier, Ending a Stalemate
text: KATMANDU, Nepal  Nepal’s bitterly divided legislature elected a new prime minister on Thursday, ending a stalemate that had paralyzed the country for months as competing political parties fought to control the government in this strategically located Himalayan nation.

headline: Andy Pettitte Decides to Retire
text: The Yankees’ frustrating off-season took another discouraging turn with the news Thursday that Andy Pettitte would retire. Pettitte called Hal Steinbrenner, the team’s managing general partner, to tell him his plans. The Yankees confirmed in a news release that Pettitte would make a formal announcement on Friday at 10:30 a.m. at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Relive the Forgotten Great Super Bowl
text: The folks at Hulu.com are counting down the top 10 Super Bowls of all time, as selected by my colleague Aaron Schatz of Football Outsiders. No. 10 on the list is a forgotten classic: Super Bowl XIV. The Rams threw a scare into the mighty Steelers on Jan. 20th, 1980, but the Steelers pulled away late in the fourth quarter for a 31-19 victory.

text: Citigroup has taken control of the British music company EMI Group in a deal that significantly cuts EMI’s debt. Now that its balance sheet is improved, will suitors emerge to bid for EMI?

text: It was a moment long planned and carefully prepared for  a moment that had twice been delayed by snow. But when the moment finally arrived, the main protagonist was missing.

headline: How Aggressive Is Your Hospital?
text: One morning during my training, I noticed that the belly of a patient in the I.C.U. had grown rounder and tighter overnight. The patient had gone through a difficult liver transplant a day earlier and was bleeding, it seemed, into his abdomen. I was the newest member of the transplant team, but even so, I knew what had to be done right away: We had to take this man back to the operating room.

headline: TD Ameritrade Pays $10 Million to Settle Charges
text: TD Ameritrade agreed on Thursday to pay $10 million to settle federal charges that it misled customers about the dangers posed by one of its mutual funds that owned commercial paper issued by Lehman Brothers.

headline: Honoring Art, Honoring Artists
text: WHEN the Denver Art Museum’s signature American Indian art galleries reopened last week after a seven-month overhaul, the biggest change wasn’t the new display cases or the dramatic lighting. Rather, it was in a less obvious place: the wall labels.

headline: N.B.A. Fines Knicks $200,000 for Prohibited Workouts
text: The N.B.A. fined the Knicks $200,000 and one of their scouts $20,000 after concluding that the scout, Rodney Heard, conducted workouts of college prospects that violated league rules.

headline: Could Prizes Emerge From the Gowanus Muck?
text: As if the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn weren’t contaminated enough by toxic chemicals, investigators with the federal Environmental Protection Agency say that debris of all shapes and sizes — bulkhead fragments, construction materials and even a few sunken vessels – is pervasive throughout the waterway, as I reported in Thursday’s paper.

headline: In Afghanistan, a Lot of Luck Goes a Long Way
text: Late Tuesday morning, two American infantry platoons and an Afghan National Army team were driving along a dirt road through rural Ghazni Province, heading back to their company outpost after finishing an early-morning sweep of Ali Jan Kala, a village where the Taliban is strong. The American soldiers were riding in MATV armored vehicles and the Afghans were in an armored Humvee, picking their way along the road at modest speed.

headline: A Ride on the YikeBike
text: The YikeBike, an electric bike with top speeds of 15 miles per hour, folds down so you don't have to lock it to a tree.

headline: Deaccessioned Items Exceed Estimates in Sales at Sotheby’s
text: Items that the Cleveland Museum of Art and the J. Paul Getty Museum were deaccessioning as part of a routine turnover in their collections both exceeded estimates in sales last week at Sotheby’s in New York. Of 30 lots from Cleveland comprising 32 old-master paintings — two lots were pairs — Sotheby’s sold 26 for a total of $1.8 million. (The estimate had been $700,000 to $1 million.) Of 15 works from the Getty, 12 sold for $3.7 million. (The estimate had been $1.4 million to $2.1 million.)

headline: Zach Randolph’s Quiet Stardom
text: On Wednesday night, Minnesota’s Kevin Love nearly saw his streak of consecutive double-doubles come to an end against Memphis. Love was physically dominated, moved easily in the post and boxed out by an opponent who clearly got the better of him. After 35 minutes of action, Love would eventually eke out 10 points and 10 boards to keep his streak alive, but there was little question as to the victor of this particular individual matchup.

headline: A D.J. Gets Control of His Lifestyle as Well as His Tunes
text: Luis Cedeño knows a thing or two about the right mix. In the 1970s, entranced by D.J. Kool Herc’s mastery of the turntables, he got behind the wheels of steel himself and gained fame as Disco Wiz, a trailblazing Latino hip-hop D.J. Three decades later, he is still obsessed with the mix — the one found on his plate.

headline: Elmo’s World Now to Include the National Children’s Museum
text: Let other museums have their Picassos and Monets; when the National Children’s Museum opens in Prince George’s County, Md., in 2013, the big names in the galleries will be Cookie Monster, Elmo, and Oscar the Grouch. On Thursday, the museum announced a partnership with Sesame Workshop, the nonprofit organization behind Sesame Street, in which the workshop will help the museum develop programming for young children, and Sesame Street characters will be woven into the exhibits.

text: Why do otherwise good kids seem to make bad decisions when they are with their friends? New research on risk taking and the teenage brain offers some answers.

headline: Shorty Tang’s Sesame Noodles Are Alive and Well
text: Those interested in a taste of 1970s Sichuan cooking in New York City will do well to visit Court Street Grocers on Thursday afternoon, where Gilley and Casey Tang are preparing their family’s cold sesame noodles in honor of Chinese New Year. Their grandfather, Shorty Tang of Hwa Yuan restaurant on East Broadway in Chinatown, is thought by some to have cooked the best version of that dish ever to be served in Manhattan. And their father, Jerry Tang, had a long career in New York restaurants. Andrew Burman, the Grocers chef, has prepared red-cooked pork belly as well.

headline: The Commuter Bike Redesigned and Electrified
text: This week, most people on the East Coast were hunkering down indoors, prepared for this winter’s fourth Snowstorm of the Century. I, on the other hand, was riding around a hotel ballroom on a YikeBike. And I’ll be straight with you: I had kind of a Segway moment.

headline: Parents Seek More Action on PCBs in Schools

headline: To the N.F.L., Babies Were (Full-Priced) People Too

headline: From 1983, Hope for Jobs in 2011
text: The unemployment rate declined four-tenths of a percentage point in one month. There had not been a monthly decline that large in many years, but economists were unimpressed. After all, the decline was caused in no small part by a surprising reduction in the labor force, which could be an indication that more workers were discouraged and no longer looking. That would hardly be an encouraging development.

headline: State of the Union | Vera Wang’s White Collection
text: It’s official, ladies: You can now get married in Vera Wang for less than $1,500. Although the price may scream ABS by Allen Schwartz, design-wise, White, is all Vera. From the draped bodices to the flouncy hems, the swirls of tulle and hand-appliquéd lace, the inspiration comes straight out of Wang’s two-decades-plus archive — including, yes, the dresses she created for Victoria Beckham and Chelsea Clinton.

headline: $1 Million to Inventor of Tracker for A.L.S.
text: BOSTON  Tracking the inexorable advance of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, the deadly neuromuscular ailment better known as Lou Gehrig’s disease or A.L.S., has long been an inexact science  a matter of monitoring weakness and fatigue, making crude measurements of the strength of various muscles.

headline: Bloomberg Loving Bloomberg? He Loves It
text: He is depicted as the ultimate narcissist: a man so content with himself that hearts spring from his head when he gazes into the mirror and a box of Valentine’s Day chocolates by his side is labeled, “To: Me.”

headline: Questioning Authority: Evaluating Wikipedia Articles
text: Overview | If Wikipedia is a collaborative project open to all, why are fewer than 15 percent of the site’s contributors women? How authoritative and complete do Wikipedia articles tend to be? In this lesson, students evaluate Wikipedia articles and consider the factors that contribute to the articles’ reliability.

headline: App Smart Extra: Android Market Gets an Upgrade
text: A few weeks ago when I decried the current state of Android app stores, I reserved the sharpest blows for Google’s Android Market. For a company that’s in the business of helping people find things, it was an embarrassment.

headline: In Pa., Obama Pushes Investment in Clean Energy
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — President Obama brought a message of economic innovation and clean energy to this key swing state on Thursday, even as his administration continued to grapple with the rapidly changing uprising in Egypt.

headline: Buzz Tracker
text: Lords of Leverage Bethany McLean is struck by the amount of Wall Street leverage that is described in the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission’s report: “From 1978 to 2007, the amount of debt held by the financial sector increased twelvefold, from $3 trillion to $36 trillion. Maybe underneath all the idiocy, deception and delusion, and all the complexity of financial instruments like mortgage-backed securities and collateralized debt obligations — maybe under all that, the real lesson of the financial crisis is really quite simple: Steeply rising debt isn’t healthy for people, and it isn’t healthy for banks.” Slate

headline: Theater Talkback: What Rocco Landesman Should Speak About Next
text: Rocco Landesman probably doesn’t need a new nickname, but it’s tempting to give him one anyway: Cowboy Mouth. With thanks to Sam Shepard and Patti Smith, the authors of a play of that title, it seems a useful handle for the outspoken chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, whose fondness for cowboy boots was well known when he was the head of Jujamcyn Theaters.

headline: 36 Hours in Santiago, Chile
text: LIKE the on-again, off-again construction of the city’s Costanera Center, which will include South America’s tallest skyscraper, Santiago is reaching for the skies while progress moves forward in fits and starts, thanks in part to natural disasters like the 8.8 magnitude quake that rocked the country last year. Still, there’s a spirit of enterprise in the capital, which was the top destination in the New York Times Travel section’s “The 41 Places to Go in 2011” feature. From a growing fashion movement to government initiatives to create a Silicon Valley of the South, there is an energy that just can’t be suppressed. Long gone are the days when the city was derided for its food scene or seen as sleepy and staid. Arts sites like the Centro Gabriela Mistral, which opened in September, along with cutting-edge galleries, boutiques and stand-out restaurants, attest to an urban scene that has blossomed in the wake of a repressive dictatorship now long dead.

headline: A Weekend in Santiago
text: Santiago is reaching for the skies while progress moves forward in fits and starts, thanks in part to natural disasters like last year’s earthquake.

headline: Roger Deakins, the Susan Lucci of Cinematography
text: Roger Deakins is almost the Susan Lucci of cinematography: he’s been nominated for an Oscar nine times, starting with “The Shawshank Redemption” in 1994, and never won. He’s on deck again this year, for the Coen brothers’ “True Grit.” Many of his honors came from his collaboration with the Coens; he has been their go-to cinematographer since “Barton Fink.” They first met more than two decades ago, at a coffee shop in Notting Hill, in London. “By then they were great cult filmmakers,” Mr. Deakins said, in a phone interview from his home in Santa Monica. “I don’t know why they had chosen to meet with me, but they did and we got on.” Does he understand them any better now? “I guess,” he said, laughing. But Mr. Deakins professed as much surprise as the Coens have about “True Grit” being such a box office hit. “It’s maybe more accessible than most of their films,” he said. “I think it’s a great movie, but I think most of their films are great movies.” He is currently working on “Now,” a futuristic thriller from the director Andrew Niccol (“Gattaca”), his first experience shooting in digital. What does he make of the divide between film and digital? “I don’t really see the point of the argument,” Mr. Deakins said. “You use images and light and texture and camera movement to tell a story. I think it’s a technical argument, and films aren’t really made by technique.”

headline: Google Executive Remains Missing in Egypt
text: Google engineers spent last weekend working with Twitter to build a service for people in Egypt without Internet access to post messages to Twitter by leaving a telephone voicemail.

headline: ‘Cheerful News’ on Crime Data and the Integrity Thereof
text: The three panelists Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly tapped to evaluate the integrity of his department’s crime-recording system will be visited on Friday by a longtime academic, author and criminologist: Prof. Franklin E. Zimring of the University of California, Berkeley.

headline: ‘Last Tango in Paris’ Star Maria Schneider Dies
text: Maria Schneider, the French actress whose sex scenes with Marlon Brando in “Last Tango in Paris” set a new standard for explicitness onscreen, died on Thursday in Paris. She was 58.

headline: Charlie Peprah's Mother Reflects
text: Excerpts from an interview with Charlie Peprah's mother. Peprah's grandfather, General I.K. Acheampong, was the head of state in Ghana before he was executed. Peprah's mother, Elizabeth, talks about her father's legacy in relation to her son.

headline: Let It Roll | Santa Fe’s Art A Go-Go
text: It’s the logical extension of the food truck: Axle Contemporary, the newest addition to Santa Fe’s robust art scene, is rolling out culture to the masses. “We’re blending the high and the low, the exclusive and the democratic, and taking those boundaries and crossing them,” says Axle’s co-founder Matthew Chase-Daniel of the old Hostess delivery truck — refashioned with track lighting, plastered walls and skylights — that serves as his gallery.

text: The dark basalt sand dunes around the edge of Mars’ North Pole are approximately the size of Texas and stand more than 100 feet high.
