headline: Political Contribution Limits Are Increased for 2012
text: Donors will be able to open their wallets a little wider for their favorite politicians in 2012 under new contribution limits issued by the Federal Election Commission today.

headline: A Brand Where Storytelling Is Part of the Design
text: URBAN Inc., the Philadelphia-based retail empire that includes the folksy, peripatetic stores Urban Outfitters, Anthropologie and Free People, has quietly segued into a higher-end market with Leifsdottir, a Scandinavian-inspired brand sold at Bergdorf Goodman, Neiman Marcus and Bloomingdale’s that is achieving a kind of stealth success with trendsetters and shoppers alike.

headline: Jordan Faces a Rising Tide of Unrest, but Few Expect a Revolt
text: MAFRAQ, Jordan  The tribal elders sat in their gowns and keffiyehs, fingering worry beads and smoking cigarettes, an immense woven image of King Abdullah II on a wall above their heads.

headline: Can Entertainment Renew American Inquiry?
text: What does this parody of a Lady Ga Ga video have to do with efforts to renew American inquiry and innovation?

headline: Europe Moves to Stabilize Its Energy Supplies
text: BRUSSELS  European leaders agreed on Friday to give unprecedented leeway to the bloc’s executive agency to help negotiate contracts with energy exporters like Russia in an effort to improve security of supplies and safeguard investment.

headline: Paterson Pays the Price Over His Series Tickets
text: The New York Yankees’ loss in the first game of the 2009 World Series seemed costly at the time only for their hopes for another title. In the end, it proved far costlier to former Gov. David A. Paterson.

headline: Letter: More Than Cheese Steaks
text: To the Editor: Regarding “Philadelphia Evolves Its Palate” (Jan. 23): Yet another article on Philadelphia restaurants trotting out the hoary notion that the city is barely a sautéed onion and a glop of Cheez Whiz away from some culinary wasteland. I don’t know where your writer has been or whom she’s been talking to, but the restaurant scene in Philadelphia started “evolving” about 30 years ago.

headline: Hotel Review: La Amada in Playa Mujeres, Mexico
text: BASICS

headline: Mexico City: Hiking Mecca?
text: “WHO knew that this was here?” said Alejandro Escalante, a young businessman from Mexico City, his suit jacket flapping like a flag in the wind. Above us loomed the serrated edge of Nevado de Toluca, a 15,000-foot-high extinct volcano an hour’s drive and a short hike from the Mexican capital. From deep within its crater, two shallow emerald lakes reflected patches of snow that, by last spring, still stubbornly clung to the mountain’s broad shoulders.

headline: A Midwest Beer Tour to Cure Winter Blues
text: ICICLES hung from the red awning of the South Shore Brewery in Ashland, Wis. The door opened and a frigid gust off Lake Superior blew a few more folks inside, their collars upturned and stocking hats pulled down past their eyebrows. At the bar, I turned back to the pint glass of midnight black stout with a foamy head. The beer’s bouquet tickled my nose — zingy peppermint, brisk as the wind off the lake.

headline: In New Orleans, Early Mardi Gras Parades Are Family Fare
text: THERE’S a phrase that New Orleans residents use to describe Mardi Gras that never fails to draw incredulous reactions from visitors to the city: “family friendly.”

headline: Lost in Las Vegas
text: THE minute I walked into the steakhouse, I knew I was in the wrong place. Or maybe exactly the right place. This was N9ne, at the Palms Casino Resort, a few blocks from the Las Vegas Strip, and it was definitely not my scene. The slick design — leather in muted colors, steel and aluminum accents, and silly lighting — was one thing, but I’ve dealt with worse. No, it was the clientele: big men with vigorous, voluminous hair, a penchant for untucked dress shirts, done-up women at their sides and a kind of frat-boy bluster that terrifies a balding, neurotic little Brooklynite like me.

headline: Driving Through Cambodia: A Road Trip Through Ruins and Unexplored Highways
text: A LIGHT rain started to fall as we drove up to the entrance of Bokor National Park in southern Cambodia. Up ahead lay the decaying remnants of a French hill station where colonists used to while away their weekends when they ruled this Southeast Asian country.

headline: In Delhi, an Arty Village Rises by Ancient Ruins
text: Hauz Khas Village, a cluster of cafes, restaurants, bookstores and boutiques, has emerged as a contemporary gateway to the history nearby.

headline: Lost in Las Vegas
text: Armed with wary disdain and little else, a visitor to Sin City makes it his own.

headline: S.E.C. Names New General Counsel
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced on Friday that was promoting Mark D. Cahn to be its next general counsel.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Karen Russell
text: This week: Karen Russell discusses her first novel, “Swamplandia!”; Lee Siegel talks about the dark side of the Internet; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

headline: Unmentioned Luxury
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Savory Breakfast Department: Progress
text: I have this “Japanese” shelf or, more accurately, a shelf that holds some of my ingredients for Japanese cooking. Thanks to the no-fish sushi piece I wrote last spring, and thanks to a soba story I’m working on for the magazine, that shelf is a little heavier than usual, and it features an embarrassing abundance of nori seaweed, in large part because I misinterpreted a mail order form and order 10 packages instead of 10 sheets.

headline: LeBron James’s Indulgence of Possibility
text: Thursday night’s TNT double-header featured two premier matchups, both of which delighted national audiences by living up to their billing. For the first game, the ever-prominent Miami Heat played the latest in its season series (and budding rivalry) against the quasi-contending Orlando Magic. In the second, the best team in the West, the San Antonio Spurs, teed off against the honorary best team in the West, the Los Angeles Lakers. Tremendous individual performances, game-winners, strong defense, and highly competitive play ruled the day.

headline: JetBlue’s Facebook App Offers Rewards
text: Facebook can often be a time suck, but a new initiative by JetBlue offers rewards for logging onto the site.

headline: Barneys’s New Chief Explains Those Changes
text: “I’m a worker, not so much a talker,” Mark Lee, the chief executive of Barneys New York, said Friday morning, explaining his reluctance these last few months to publicly discuss his makeover plans for the store. Mr. Lee, the former chief executive of Gucci, arrived at Barneys in September.

headline: Germany and France Roll Out Plan to Boost Euro
text: BRUSSELS — Initiating a bold effort to strengthen the euro, Germany and France on Friday laid down far-reaching plans to deepen integration among the 17 nations that use the currency. The move prompted immediate opposition, but could lead to embryonic economic government for Europe.

headline: Final Volleys Over the Airgas Poison Pill
text: The final briefs have been filed in Air Products and Chemicals’ legal battle to gain control of Airgas, and a ruling in Delaware Chancery Court is expected next week. The briefs are fine pieces of work, no doubt worthy of the hundreds of thousands of dollars spent to write each of them.

headline: Tavern on the Green
text: To the Editor:

headline: Special Delivery | A.P.C.’s New Digs
text: Unlike the majority of fashion labels, which are subject to a constant wax-and-wane credibility cycle, A.P.C. is ever cool. That’s due in large part to the brand’s founder, Jean Touitou, a man to whom the conventions of fashion — trend-based collections, high-profile ad campaigns — are so many canards, a conviction that his loyal customers, many of whom wouldn’t wear any other jeans, wholeheartedly endorse. A.P.C.’s second Manhattan shop will open next week at the corner of Perry and Bleecker Streets in the West Village, to be followed this summer by a third location just a few blocks away. “The West Village is classy. SoHo is getting a bit commercial. Every time you turn around, there’s a new store. Of course, who am I to talk? I’m opening new stores.” Touitou said with typical candor when The Moment rang up his Paris office to chat. Here, he talks to us about the fashion habits of 19th-century British aristocrats, the pleasures of sewing and why the classics aren’t as simple as they look.

headline: Mary Sansone
text: To the Editor:

headline: Super Bowl Ads Live On at YouTube and Facebook
text: Do you remember which team won the Super Bowl last year? Do you remember which was your favorite ad?

headline: A Hefty Payoff for a Comic (and Steelers Fan)
text: Right about the time the Pittsburgh Steelers were starting a run to another Super Bowl, Billy Gardell, a lifelong fan and native son of the Steel City, was beginning his own season as the star of a new CBS sitcom and taping his first prime-time stand-up comedy special – a show that will appear the night before his team takes the field in Dallas.

headline: Super Bowl’s Bit Players Get Their Due
text: Not every Super Bowl feature is about Ben Roethlisberger, Troy Polamalu, or the price of a 30-second commercial. Role players, backups, and coaches suddenly become media darlings, as hometown papers profile neighborhood kids who grew up to become backup linebackers and news outlets cast a wide net for undiscovered coverage angles. No Super Bowl participant is too obscure for a few candelas of the limelight, not even:

headline: On Our Radar: Rare Aerial Footage of Isolated Amazon Tribe
text: A film crew accompanying a researcher with Brazil’s Indian Affairs department captures rare aerial footage of a highly isolated tribe living deep in the Amazon rain forest, near the Peru-Brazil border. Advocates for the region’s indigenous people say illegal logging in Peru is driving other isolated tribes across the border into Brazil, causing conflicts over resources and territory. Responding to the release of video and images of the tribe, Peruvian authorities said this week that they would work to stop the intrusion of loggers into protected areas.  [Survival International]

headline: Some Taxes Went Up
text: A reader thinks I owe you a correction for saying, in my column today:

headline: Not Pennies and Not Quite From Heaven
text: THE forecast is in for Super Bowl weekend, and once again, it looks like rain. At least that’s the word from Dallas, where news reports surfaced this week that Hines Ward and other members of the Pittsburgh Steelers huddled at the Dallas Gentlemen’s Club one night, with some of them indulging in a strip-club ritual known as “making it rain,” i.e., showering dancers with fistfuls of cash.

headline: Jessica Phillips and Greg Minah
text: WHAT if you held a wedding but no one came — and that’s just the way you wanted it?

headline: In New York’s Little Egypt, the Young Get a New Awareness

headline: Shumway to Return Money to Investors
text: Chris Shumway learned a tough lesson in November, when he announced that he was stepping down as chief investment officer of his giant hedge fund, Shumway Capital Partners.

headline: Arts & Leisure Preview: Matthew Perry, ‘That Championship Season,’ Vidal Sassoon and More
text: “I used to spend a lot of time just thinking about myself, thinking that the party started when I showed up. I’m far from that man, now.”—Matthew Perry, who is producing and starring in a new comedy, “Mr. Sunshine.”

headline: Off the Menu: Jones Wood Foundry
text: Despite his French training and a previous stint at Orsay, the chef Jason Hicks has gone back to his roots in a Cotswolds village for Jones Wood Foundry, a pub in a part of the city once called Jones Wood. It’s opening on Feb. 14.

headline: Super Bowl vs. Hockey, Compare and Contrast
text: It’s a great weekend to be a sports fan. The N.H.L. has a packed schedule through Sunday afternoon, at which point the Super Bowl takes over the spotlight. But while the games will be entertaining, the transition may be jarring.

headline: Bank of America to Create Troubled Loans Unit
text: Bank of America said Friday that it would create a unit to handle 1.3 million soured mortgages as Brian T. Moynihan, the bank’s chief executive, tried to distance the company from the fallout of the mortgage crisis.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Savoy, which is serving a daily cassoulet special in February, is hosting a tasting festival Saturday at the restaurant, 70 Prince Street (Crosby Street), from 12:30 to 3:30 p.m. Chefs from Back Forty, Cookshop, Fatty Johnson’s, Nuela, Vinegar Hill House and WD-50 will prepare different versions of cassoulet. The $65 ticket includes wine, but not tax or gratuity.

headline: Lawsuits Claim Tesla Executive Negligent in Airplane Crash
text: Doug Bourn, the Tesla Motors executive who was killed last year when the airplane he was piloting struck high power wires in East Palo Alto, Calif., had not flown for 18 months before the day of the crash, according to two lawsuits filed against his estate by the families of the other men killed in the accident.

headline: The Elephant in the Showroom
text: INFINITI has a new hybrid on the way. The M35h, due in the spring, is said to be the only vehicle to offer more than 350 horsepower along with a 30 mile per gallon economy rating on the highway. That’s an admirable achievement, and I’m sure that plenty of Infiniti buyers will take note of the new hybrid as they stroll past it on their way to buy a new 400-horsepower, 5,850-pound QX56 4WD. As the sales charts prove, the death of the S.U.V. has been much exaggerated.

headline: Fortune Brands on Track For Breakup
text: Fortune Brands, in its fourth-quarter earnings announcement on Friday, said the company was on track to split into three businesses.

headline: Erica Rosen, Daniel Stellar
text: Erica Rosen and Daniel Stellar were married Saturday evening at Thalassa Restaurant in Manhattan. Claire Slemmer, a friend of the couple who became an officiant for the occasion through American Marriage Ministries, performed the ceremony.

headline: Piraye Yurttas and Nicholas Beim
text: Piraye Yurttas and Nicholas Frederick Beim were married Saturday evening at the main branch of the New York Public Library. E. Leo Milonas, the retired chief administrative judge of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan and a friend of the bridegroom’s family, officiated. On March 19, the couple will take part in a celebration incorporating Turkish wedding traditions at Esma Sultan Mansion in Istanbul.

text: Jessica H. Mozeico and Jordan J. Blair were married Saturday on the Kohala Coast on the Big Island of Hawaii. The Rev. A. J. Di Mauro, a Community of Christ minister, officiated at the Fairmont Orchid Resort.

text: Carla Stuart and Habib Azar were married Thursday at the Mandarin Oriental, a hotel in New York. Former Mayor David N. Dinkins officiated. On Feb. 15, the couple are to take part in a Masai wedding ceremony at the Whistling Thorn Camp in Tanzania, which is to be conducted by two Masai elders, Kirikindawa Ming-Arana and Sakaya Lomnyaki.

headline: Exploding Bombs and Wounded Eyes: From Blindness Back to Patrol
text: By any reasonable measure, Specialist Peter Sprenger, a radio operator in an Army infantry company, could easily have been dead. It was Dec. 19, 2003, in Talafar, Iraq. An Iraqi man driving an explosives-laden car had breached his company’s perimeter. American soldiers fired at him with light machine guns, but the driver accelerated toward the company command post.

headline: ‘Dogtooth': No Indifference Allowed
text: In the Oscar competition for best-foreign language film, the entry from Greece, “Dogtooth,” is definitely the outlier – and underdog. In one fashion or another, all four of the other films are outwardly directed, addressing aspects of relations between the West and the Third World. “Dogtooth,” in contrast, is hermetic, a study of a family in which the parents have decided to literally wall their children off from the rest of the world in order to protect them from malign outside influences.

headline: Liszt, the Chick Magnet, Tickled Ivories and More
text: Liszt is sometimes remembered as a purveyor of pianistic bling, a virtuoso who wrote flamboyant music that was entertaining but rarely profound. He was undeniably a showman, a 19th-century rock star who seduced his female fans with his jaw-dropping technique. But he was also a devout Roman Catholic who renounced his socialite lifestyle for a brief stint in a monastery, a compositional rehab during which he wrote sacred choral works and piano scores with religious themes.

headline: A Violinist and Novelist, and, Yes, Composer
text: The violinist Eugene Drucker is well known as a founding member of the Emerson String Quartet; until recently, few knew that he was a composer as well.

headline: China’s Currency Avoids ‘Manipulated’ Ruling Again

headline: From Sputnik to SunShot
text: The energy secretary, Steven Chu, was publicly using the phrase “Sputnik moment” two months before President Obama picked it up in the State of the Union speech to describe the need for a national effort to improve competitiveness in a technical field. Now he has moved on to a new space-challenge term: SunShot.

headline: The Gamble of Lending Peer to Peer
text: When peer-to-peer online lending first became possible in the United States five years ago, using the Web to make money by lending it to fellow citizens in need seemed wonderfully subversive.

headline: Peer-to-Peer Lending: What the Future Holds
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I take a look at the two leading peer-to-peer lenders, which are both trying to exit their awkward adolescent phases.

headline: Remembering Fondly the Tallest Guy at the Table

headline: Appreciating Nene
text: The Carmelo Anthony trade saga has been one of this season’s dominant storylines. With all the focus on whether or not Anthony will still be a Nugget after this season’s trade deadline or next summer, the fact that the Nuggets are currently the best offensive team in basketball has been lost in the shuffle. The Nuggets’ defense has kept them from being one of the West’s elite teams this season, but they have done an excellent job of surrounding Anthony with efficient offensive players. And no Nugget has been more efficient than Nene.

headline: Playing That Outgrows a Cozy Space
text: Three intimate concerts for $64, the New Music in the Rose series of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is one of New York’s great deals. But while the Rose Studio has cozy charm, it was heartening to hear the preconcert announcement on Thursday evening that next season the series will move to the adjacent, larger Kaplan Penthouse because of overwhelming demand for tickets.

headline: A Super Bowl Minus the Pompoms
text: DALLAS  A substantial wing of the Dallas Cowboys’ suburban headquarters is devoted to the Dallas Cowboys Cheerleaders. On Thursday afternoon, in an immense dance studio, members of the world’s most famous cheer squad rehearsed for one of their dozens of appearances surrounding the Super Bowl this week.

text: WHEN it comes to dessert, my husband is a man of simple tastes, perfectly content as long as chocolate features prominently, and preferably in the form of chewy, dark brownies.

headline: Short Allows Ivanchuk to Overtake Him at Gibraltar
text: Open tournaments are often sprints to the finish. Give up a draw, or lose a game, and first place may be out of reach.

headline: School Production Of Wilson Play Delayed
text: A student production of “Joe Turner’s Come and Gone” that overcame the objections of a school superintendent in order to proceed has been temporarily halted by Mother Nature. The Waterbury Arts Magnet School in Waterbury, Conn., had planned to perform that August Wilson play this week, but postponed the performances after the recent heavy snowfalls in the Northeast. Dana Manning, the school’s fine arts coordinator, told The Republican-American newspaper of Waterbury that the bad weather had prevented rehearsals. Additional performances planned for next week were also likely to be rescheduled and new dates were not immediately announced. The Waterbury Board of Education said in January that the school’s production of the play, set in 1911 at a Pittsburgh boardinghouse where several freed slaves reside, could proceed, overruling an earlier decision by the superintendent, David L. Snead. Mr. Snead, who is black, had sought to cancel the play because the word “nigger” appears multiple times in its dialogue. During the board meeting at which the decision was announced, the production was defended by the high school students in its cast, as well as by James Bundy, artistic director of Yale Repertory Theater, where “Joe Turner” and other Wilson plays were developed.

headline: Goldman’s Buyout Unit Nears Deal for Applebee’s Operator
text: Goldman Sachs‘s private equity unit is nearing a deal to buy Apple American Group, the biggest franchisee of Applebee’s Neighborhood Grill and Bar, a person briefed on the matter said Friday.

headline: Death at Soho House
text: SYLVIE CACHAY started the morning of Dec. 8 the same way she started every day before it, wondering what she could do to get her swimwear business back off the ground. She was a promising young designer, but one who was frustrated by having to work for someone else’s company, not her own.

headline: A Loophole in a Verizon iPhone Rule
text: In my review of the Verizon iPhone this week, I noted that, because it’s a phone that works on a CDMA network (the type Sprint and Verizon use), you can’t make a phone call and surf the Web simultaneously. That’s a crucial difference between the Verizon and AT&T versions of the iPhone.

headline: The Teapot, an Object of Practical Beauty
text: MORRIS TOWNSHIP, N.J.

headline: Archive of the American Songbook Finds a New Home in the Heartland
text: Michael Feinstein is perhaps best known as a singer and pianist and the owner of a cabaret on Manhattan’s Upper East Side that bears his name. He’s also well known as a passionate historian of American song and for his vast collection of memorabilia. Now his collection will be housed at a new performing arts center in Carmel, Ind., a three-hour drive from his childhood home.

headline: Coney Island, 4:32 P.M.
text: N.Y. See: a perfect afternoon to fly a kite on a snowy, deserted beach.

headline: Let’s Sing About People Who Don’t Speak Like Us
text: There’s good news for those who find hilarity in the idea that people who are not native English-speakers tend to speak English imperfectly: “The Road to Qatar!,” a new musical from the York Theater Company, stands ready to pummel them with that fact for 90 intermissionless minutes. But anyone with a higher threshold for humor, or with a low tolerance for mocking people of different nationalities, will find little to laugh at here.

headline: Chrysler Chief Marchionne Unhappy With Terms of U.S. Loans
text: From our colleagues at DealBook:

headline: Returning the Blessings of an Immortal Life
text: If there was one thing Rebecca Skloot was certain of when writing “The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks,” it was that she did not want to profit from the Lacks family without giving something in return.

headline: House Tour: Southport, Conn.
text: A home’s surroundings give the impression that it’s in a rural setting, though the village, harbor and beach are nearby.

headline: Where Math Is a Pleasure, Not a Problem
text: Garden City, N.Y.

headline: A Tiny, Shared Space for Creative Types
text: PEEKSKILL, N.Y.

headline: What to Expect When Fairy Tales and Reality Are Just as Strange?
text: There’s nothing like seeing the seats next to you wrapped in black plastic garbage bags to give you a slight feeling of unease about the performance to come, particularly when a theater employee politely asks people to keep their coats tucked away. Liquids? Bodies?

headline: Among the Muslim Brotherhood
text: It is almost impossible to convince yourself that a band of young men holding machetes, pipes and two-by-fours have only your safety in mind when they stop your car. Even after the 20th checkpoint, your heart still beats faster, and that tingle ripples over you until one of the men pops up your windshield wipers, signaling for the next group down the road that your car has been checked.

headline: It’s Vaudeville Without the Tomatoes
text: On the first day, the House of Ninja visited the house of worship. And the people in St. Mark’s Church saw that it was good.

headline: Pursuing a Prodigal Son, Who’s Strayed to the City
text: “This is heavy, heavy for me,” sings a mighty chorus of basses in “Lost in the Stars,” the latest offering from the City Center Encores! series. “O this is heavy, heavy for me.”

headline: The Tale Those Strings Can Tell
text: You might think that writing program music automatically provides a composer with a structure for a long piece. The way this genre has typically been practiced, the music is supposed to illustrate a story. As long as the story has structure, the music should too.

headline: A Gallery of Presidents, as Seen in Magazines
text: WHITE PLAINS

headline: The Risks of Setting Up an Overseas Bank Account
text: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan writes that recent disclosures of the names of people holding accounts in overseas banks mean that the wealthy are taking their chances if they think those accounts will remain secret.

headline: Hardcover Business Best Sellers
Paperback Business Best Sellers
5 Likable Players of the Blame Game
text: Everybody plays the blame game sometime. In Melissa James Gibson’s “This,” at TheaterWorks in Hartford, Tom is a pro at it.

headline: Democrats Promise No Corporate Money for Convention
text: Democrats announced Friday that they will finance their national convention in the summer of 2012 without the benefit of corporate contributions or unlimited donations from wealthy individuals.

headline: Apple Patents a Stylus to Reach Students
text: It’s quite strange that Apple chose the name iPad for its tablet computer as you can’t actually use it the way one would use a pad of paper, specifically when it comes to drawing or writing with a pen.

headline: A Faithful but Strained Adaptation
text: It seems certain that a knowledge of Mandarin, and of the folkways of contemporary Beijing’s moneyed classes, are necessary to get all the jokes in “What Women Want,” a Chinese remake of the American romantic comedy that starred Mel Gibson and Helen Hunt. But as you watch this strained, lifeless imitation, it also seems pretty certain that knowing the language wouldn’t make the film actually — what’s the right word? — funny.

headline: Building a Band, and a Place for It to Play In
text: WEST SIMSBURY, Conn.

headline: In Venezuela, an American Has the President’s Ear
text: CARACAS, Venezuela

headline: A Bloodless Ripoff Substitutes Sex for Suspense
text: Substituting sex for suspense and pop music for ideas, the director Christian E. Christiansen drags “The Roommate” — a bloodless ripoff of Barbet Schroeder’s deliciously trashy 1992 thriller, “Single White Female” — from limp beginning to lame conclusion. And while Mr. Schroeder could conjure knife-blade tension from an episode of “Antiques Roadshow,” Mr. Christiansen succeeds only in conjuring monotony.

headline: Better Penmanship, Less Pain
text: SCIENCE has proved that memory does far better at fashioning simple, meaningful stories about one’s childhood than objectively preserving truth in amber. Small wonder, then, that memories and narratives often differ  if not outright clash  depending on whom they belong to and whom they serve.

headline: Yoga’s Stress Relief: An Aid for Infertility?
text: KIMBERLY SORANNO, a 39-year-old Brooklynite undergoing an in vitro fertilization cycle as part of her quest to become pregnant, had gone to her share of yoga classes, but never one like that held on a recent Tuesday night in a reception area of the New York University Fertility Center. There were no deep twists or headstands; just easy “restorative” poses as the teacher, Tracy Toon Spencer, guided the participants — most of them women struggling to conceive — to let go of their worries.

headline: Lacking Peace Talks, Israel Offers Economic Package for Palestinians
text: JERUSALEM  Israel announced on Friday a package of steps meant to develop infrastructure and encourage economic growth in the Palestinian territories, in what appeared to be an effort to mollify the Western-backed Palestinian Authority leadership and allay international criticism in the absence of peace talks.

headline: 3 SUNY Graduates File Suit to Get a Tuition Break
text: RAQUEL BALSAM enjoyed four memorable years at Binghamton University, majoring in English, playing club tennis, hosting her own television show and volunteering for a local youth program. As an out-of-state student at Binghamton, which is part of the State University of New York, she paid $36,000 in tuition, almost twice as much as in-state students.

headline: 40 Years On, Detective Sees Light Shed on a Killing
text: The front door was locked, so police officers broke into the Upper East Side apartment from the back. They found a dead woman lying against an overturned bed, with a rope tied around her neck. Her bra had been pulled up over her head, and someone had bitten her left breast.

headline: In Census, Young Americans Increasingly Diverse
text: WASHINGTON  Demographers sifting through new population counts released on Thursday by the Census Bureau say the data bring a pattern into sharper focus: Young Americans are far less white than older generations, a shift that demographers say creates a culture gap with far-reaching political and social consequences.

headline: American Makes Best of Second Chance in England
text: CHORLEY, England  The practice session began as it would for most soccer players across England, with a juggling drill. In a small circle, they kept the ball in the air, passing it to one another. For Bolton Wanderers, an English Premier League team, there was a playfully cruel twist to the game: the first man to let the ball touch the ground would have his ears flicked by every member of the team.

headline: Ringmaster of the Royal Bachelor Party
text: LONDON

headline: Martin Assesses His Hall of Fame Chances
text: DALLAS — Curtis Martin’s career with New England and the Jets was much like the man himself: understated, consistent, workmanlike. Only Martin and Barry Sanders topped 1,000 rushing yards in each of their first 10 seasons. Only Emmitt Smith, Walter Payton and Sanders gained more rushing yards than Martin’s 14,101.

headline: California Law to Curb Greenhouse Gases Faces a Legal Hurdle
text: SAN FRANCISCO  California’s landmark law on curbing greenhouse gases, which is well on its way to taking effect, has hit a legal snag in the form of a tentative judicial ruling that state environmental regulators failed to follow legally required procedures.

headline: A Mere Shovel? Show the Snow Who’s Boss
text: It will be beautiful as it falls and magical as it dusts the ground, and seconds later, New York’s next snowfall will be an urban nuisance, slipping your step, burying your car and lining your curbs with the slushie of doom.

headline: How to Grow a Social Business
text: In Tuesday’s column, “When Microcredit Won’t Do,” I wrote about microconsignment, a way for village entrepreneurs to sell innovative and important products for which there is no established market — such as solar lamps, water purifiers, stoves and reading glasses — without having to take on debt.  Instead, village women are given the products and the training to sell them.  Once they make the sale, they repay the supplier and keep a portion of the proceeds.  Done right, microconsignment provides new businesses for village women — and helps make life healthier and more prosperous for her neighbors.

headline: Lawyer Disputes Portrayal of Detainee
text: WASHINGTON  The lawyer for a prisoner at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, who died this week, apparently of a heart attack, is criticizing the Defense Department for its portrayal of the man’s connections to Al Qaeda.

headline: Request for an Emergency Rule on Border Gun Sales Is Denied
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Friday rejected a request for an emergency rule requiring gun dealers along the Mexican border to report bulk sales of assault rifles, a proposal intended to make it harder for drug cartels to smuggle weapons.

headline: Leader of Players Union Misses Chance to Make His Case
text: Dallas

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Justice Thomas’s Wife Sets Up a Conservative Lobbying Shop
text: WASHINGTON  The wife of Justice Clarence Thomas, who has raised her political profile in the last year through her outspoken conservative activism, is rebranding herself as a lobbyist and self-appointed “ambassador to the Tea Party movement.”

headline: Raw Milk Cheesemakers Fret Over Possible New Rules
text: Federal regulators are considering whether to tighten food safety rules for cheese made with unpasteurized milk  and the possibility has cheesemakers and foodies worried that the result will be cheese that is less tasty and not much safer.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: U.S. Says Farmers May Grow Engineered Sugar Beets
text: The Department of Agriculture said on Friday that American farmers could resume growing genetically engineered sugar beets that had been barred by a federal judge.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to the Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Super Bowl Ads Will Leave a Religious Question Unanswered
text: If you watch one football game all year, it will probably be Sunday’s Super Bowl. And if you happen to glance at the signs held up in the end zone, at least one will probably say “John 3:16.”

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Annual Talk by Goodell Is Dominated by Labor Issue
text: DALLAS  The N.F.L. and the players union will hold three negotiating sessions in the next week starting Saturday with one month to go before their collective bargaining agreement expires.

headline: Questions About New York
text: Q. Can you explain why some Metro-North train cars have two sets of doors and some have three? And why are the middle doors kept closed on many runs?

headline: Women and Children First
text: Off Cape Hatteras, Feb. 5, 1861

headline: Discontented Within Egypt Face Power of Old Elites
text: CAIRO  It was proclaimed as “the Friday of departure,” but neither the demonstrators who proved their staying power as a force for change nor their nemesis, President Hosni Mubarak, left. Now a prolonged collision is shaping up between a staggering but entrenched old guard and an outpouring of Egypt’s discontented over how fast and how deep the changes will be.

headline: In Politics, Every Day Is a Workday
text: Sheldon Silver, 66, who has been speaker of the New York State Assembly since 1994, grew up on the Lower East Side, where he still lives with Rosa, his wife of 44 years. Mr. Silver works many Sundays, but also spends time at family meals and takes some of his 18 grandchildren on outings. HELAINA HOVITZ

headline: Obama Faults Spy Agencies’ Performance in Gauging Mideast Unrest, Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama has criticized American spy agencies over their performance in predicting and analyzing the spreading unrest in the Middle East, according to current and former American officials.

headline: In the Taliban’s Heartland, U.S. and Afghan Forces Dig In
text: PASHMUL, Afghanistan  If the commander of coalition forces, Gen. David H. Petraeus, has sounded triumphant lately  telling his officers they have their teeth in the enemy’s jugular  this newly conquered patch of southern Afghanistan is one reason for that.

headline: ‘Day of Rage’ for Syrians Fails to Draw Protesters
text: DAMASCUS, Syria  In stark contrast to several other Arab capitals, where hundreds of thousands of people have demonstrated against their governments, a planned “Day of Rage” in Damascus on Friday failed to attract any protesters against President Bashar al-Assad, a sign that the opposition here remains too weak to challenge one of the region’s most entrenched ruling parties.

headline: U.S. Trying to Balance Israel’s Needs in the Face of Egyptian Reform
text: WASHINGTON  The demonstrations against President Hosni Mubarak’s government in Egypt are rocking the relationship between the United States and its most important Arab ally. But they are also rocking an even more fundamental relationship for the United States  its 60-year alliance with Israel.

headline: Jet From J.F.K. Came Close to 2 Air Force Cargo Planes
text: WASHINGTON  An American Airlines jumbo jet that took off from Kennedy International Airport on the evening of Jan. 20 heading southeast toward Brazil came within a mile of a formation of two Air Force C-17 cargo planes, the National Transportation Safety Board said Friday. The board has begun a major investigation.

headline: Iraqi Leader, With Eye on Discontent, Says He’ll Cut His Salary in Half
text: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq said Friday that he would cut his salary in half, apparently in an effort to defuse growing dissatisfaction among Iraqis about the lack of government services.

headline: A Sports Bar Without the Pickup Lines
text: Second Avenue can seem like one long line of watering holes connecting the Upper and Lower East Sides, with high-spirited crowds spilling out from shamrock-adorned pubs, neon-lighted dives and, naturally, sports bars. But BB&R  for Blonde, Brunette and a Redhead  is something of a hybrid, a cozy hangout between 89th and 90th Streets that offers organic India pale ale, Veuve Clicquot by the glass and prosciutto-topped pizza along with the requisite Bud Light and 13 televisions screens that can display their own games in the two rooms. With exposed brick walls accented by panels from wood wine crates, a Ping-Pong table and a pool table, and a photo booth, the bar attracts its share of sports fans, groups of young men and women out for a drink after work and, on Wednesday, two residents of the neighborhood. DIANE CARDWELL

headline: E-Readers Catch Younger Eyes and Go in Backpacks
text: Something extraordinary happened after Eliana Litos received an e-reader for a Hanukkah gift in December.

headline: It May Be a Sputnik Moment, but Science Fairs Are Lagging
text: Rarely have school science fairs, a source of pride and panic for generations of American students, achieved such prominence on the national stage. President Obama held one at the White House last fall. And last week he said that America should celebrate its science fair winners like Sunday’s Super Bowl champions, or risk losing the nation’s competitive edge.

headline: In Panel’s Votes to Close Low-Performing Schools, Rage and Foregone Decisions
text: They knew how the script was going to end. Still, on Thursday night, 2,000 students, parents, teachers and union officials filed into Brooklyn Technical High School, voicing their frustration for five hours.

headline: @bergdorfs
text: TWEETING SINCE January 2010

headline: Awards That Best Predict Oscar Voting Favor ‘The King’s Speech’
text: Nate Silver is providing awards-season insight for Carpetbagger leading up to the 83rd Academy Awards on Feb. 27. Mr. Silver is the author of The Times’s FiveThirtyEight blog, which is devoted to the analysis of statistics and data in politics and other areas.

headline: Cuomo Takes Aim at Fixed Spending Increases
text: ALBANY  The Sunrise Nursing Home and the Manor at Seneca Hill nursing home sit just a few miles from each other in Oswego County near the shores of Lake Ontario. They each have 120 beds and serve comparable patient populations.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Welcome to Jerry’s World
text: DALLAS  The most visible owner in Super Bowl history held his own news conference Tuesday. He talked, as only Jerry Jones can talk, for 75 minutes.

headline: Awards That Best Predict Oscar Voting Favor ‘The King’s Speech’
text: Since I last wrote about this year’s Academy Award nominees for Best Picture, there has been a significant shift in the conventional wisdom about the probable winner. “The Social Network,” which was once considered as likely as 90 percent certain to win by betting markets, is now given only about a 20 percent chance. “The King’s Speech,” instead, has become the heavy favorite.

headline: District Liked Its Earmarks, Then Elected Someone Who Didn’t
text: In the villages, towns and cities of the 19th Congressional District north of New York City, the signs of federal largess are all over: money for a library in South Salem, road improvements in Peekskill, renovations on an aging bridge in Dover and a communications network for the Police Department in Tuxedo.

headline: Caribbean Warmth
text: Elouise Moulton, whose nickname is Tunie, grew up in St. Ann Parish, Jamaica, helping out at her mother’s restaurant. She says she “always knew how to cook.” So it is no surprise that Pon Di Riva, her new restaurant just steps from the Ossining train station, feels a bit like the Caribbean, especially when it comes to warmth.

headline: Authentic Thai Food That Stands Apart
text: ALTHOUGH I’d heard that Bangkok Spice in Shrub Oak was a strong and authentic Thai spot, I had my doubts, having found much of the Thai offerings in Westchester numbingly similar and often greasy. But after a couple of recent visits to this unassuming restaurant, where the sauces are excellent, the preparation reliably good and the menu a bit more than standard fare, I had to agree — it does stand apart.

headline: Politics and the Court
text: When it comes to pushing the line between law and politics, Justices Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas each had a banner month in January.

headline: Wilpon’s Ownership of Mets Is Threatened
text: Fred Wilpon’s ability to hold onto the Mets was cast into more doubt Friday when a lawsuit filed by the trustee in the Bernard L. Madoff fraud case was unsealed and revealed in vivid detail the depth of Madoff’s involvement in nearly every aspect of Wilpon’s empire, particularly his team.

headline: Saying It’s Time, but Sounding Less Certain
text: On a scale of 1 to 10, Andy Pettitte’s level of certitude seemed to be a 5. Halfway convinced he couldn’t grind out another year with the Yankees in New York, he opted for an unforced retirement in Houston to watch his children play sports and begin to figure out what to do with the rest of his life.

headline: Enough for a Polish Banquet
text: Polish Delicatessen is so true to its East European origins that it would be quite at home on a Krakow street corner. Shelves are stocked with jars, boxes and cellophane-wrapped packages of foods made in or near Poland, and many of the magazines for sale are in Polish.

headline: Balancing the Tastes of Thai Cuisine
text: THE gentle charm of Ayuthai Royal Thai Cuisine, a family-owned restaurant in Guilford, reveals itself quietly throughout the meal — in good food that is consistently fresh and light, and unobtrusive service that is just formal enough to make the meal feel like a night out.

headline: No Frills, Just Sweet Treats
text: Fay Da Bakery, an expanding chain based in New York, has had its only New Jersey outpost tucked inside the Hong Kong Supermarket in East Brunswick since 2000.

headline: Saturday: Red Wear for Speedy Gonzales
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I started this puzzle at the bottom for a change of pace, and I’m glad I did. It’s a very cool ending, even though I think it’s a tad bossy of Mark Diehl to insist that I get dressed up to solve his puzzle.

headline: Cuisine to Match a Striking Setting
text: IT’S hard to imagine anyone more eager for the Big Thaw this spring than the owners of Maritime Parc in Jersey City, tucked away in Liberty State Park flush up against the Liberty Landing Marina. It is also flush up against what was once the eastern end of the Morris Canal, which for much of the 19th century linked Pennsylvania coal country to the Hudson River. That bit of Industrial Age history is lost these days, though, amid the bobbing pleasure craft and imposing views of Jersey City and Lower Manhattan to the north and east, and of the Statue of Liberty off to the south.

headline: Knife, Fork and Candy Bar
text: Michael Mignano, the chef and owner of Main Street Bakery and Cafe in Port Washington, serves his specialty candy bar on a plate, with a knife and fork (or sliced).

headline: Sudan: North-South Clash Kills 9
text: At least nine people, including a United Nations staff member, have been killed in clashes between southern and northern soldiers from a joint-integrated unit, officials said Friday. The fighting began Thursday evening after soldiers from a joint unit in Malakal were ordered to redeploy to the north, and a group of southern soldiers refused. “The situation is still very dangerous,” said Bartholomew Pakwan Abwol, a state government spokesman. “We don’t know how many have died.”

headline: Blighted Area? These Business Owners Beg to Differ
text: Damon Bae’s commercial laundry on Third Avenue in East Harlem may never be mistaken for the kind of glamorous businesses found near Wall Street, Times Square or Madison Avenue, but it is a thriving concern in this neighborhood of three- and four-story buildings and vacant lots.

headline: Corrections
text: NEW YORK

headline: Old-Fashioned Charm, Updated
text: FOR over half a century the Old Fields Inn has been a fixture in Greenlawn. Known for its marinated steaks, it was the place where the Kiwanis and Lions Clubs met. When I last visited, a couple of years ago, it was tired and lackluster. Last June, David and Christine Tunney bought the venerable old place, took five months to renovate it and reopened it in November with a shortened name: Old Fields.

headline: Britain: Cricket-Fixing Charges
text: Prosecutors said Friday that three members of the Pakistani cricket team that toured England last summer would be tried on charges of “spot-fixing” elements of a five-day contest in London in August. The three men  Mohammed Amir, Salman Butt and Mohammed Asif  will face charges of conspiracy to accept bribes and conspiracy to cheat. Their agent, Mazhar Majeed, was also indicted. The four are alleged to have accepted tens of thousands of dollars in illicit payments from a News of the World reporter posing as a middleman for Asia-based betting syndicates.

headline: Maker That Sold Gloves to Fire Dept. Closes Plant
text: The manufacturer that sold the New York City Fire Department $800,000 worth of flawed fire-retardant gloves sent word to its workers and others this week that it was closing its plant, in Arkansas, officials said. The company, the Glove Corporation, hinted in its announcement to its workers that its difficulties were a direct result of the troubled contract with New York.

headline: China: Officials Say Tibetan Lama Is Not a Chinese Spy as India Says
text: A Chinese official, Xu Zhitao, has denied accusations by Indian officials that a revered Tibetan leader living in India is a spy for the Chinese government, Chinese news reports said this week. Indian officials first accused the Tibetan, the 17th Karmapa Lama, left, of being a spy after Indian police officers seized $1.5 million worth of foreign currency, including Chinese renminbi, last month from the lama’s home in Dharamsala. There is a dispute over the Karmapa Lama; a rival candidate who has close ties to Indian intelligence officials claims he is the true lama. Tibetan Buddhism’s spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, backs the one in Dharamsala, seen by many Tibetans as a possible future leader.

headline: Even the Middle Ground Is Perilous in Cairo
text: Photographers of the increasingly violent upheaval in Egypt are being forced — in the interest of personal safety — to adopt practices that limit their range of coverage at exactly the moment the world is hungriest for as many images from as many perspectives as possible.

headline: Health Fund Adds Fraud Checks
text: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria announced steps on Friday to strengthen antifraud safeguards, including doubling the budget for internal investigations. The group acted after a Jan. 23 article by The Associated Press described corruption in grants to Mali, Mauritania, Zambia and Djibouti. The fund said it was seeking to recover $34 million from those and other countries, an amount it said was less than 1 percent of the $13 billion in aid it has disbursed in 145 countries.

headline: Iraq: Plane Crash Kills 7
text: A private plane crashed in the northern city of Sulaimaniya shortly after takeoff on Friday, killing all seven passengers and crew members, officials said. The plane, bound for Ankara, Turkey, was carrying several businessmen, including an American, according to local officials and an American official. The airport director said the crash was believed to have been caused by technical problems, and there were no indications of terrorism.

headline: Bloggingheads: Stability or Human Rights
text: David Corn of Mother Jones and James Pinkerton of Fox News debate Egypt and American foreign policy.

headline: 76ers Beat Knicks, Continuing to Surge as Knicks Struggle
text: PHILADELPHIA  The ball found Shawne Williams in the left corner, his corner, the spot where he is most comfortable and where, just seconds earlier, he had hit a critical 3-pointer.

headline: CNN Rises to the Top in Egypt Coverage
text: Pro-Mubarak forces once again clashed with anti-Mubarak forces on Friday. The brutal set-to didn’t take place in Tahrir Square in Cairo, where as many as 100,000 demonstrators managed to assemble peacefully. The brick-throwing was on cable television, as Fox News and MSNBC anchors continued knocking heads over what’s worse: the dictatorship we know or a democratic rebellion we can’t control.

headline: Drury’s Knee Swells, Saving Coach From Tough Call
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  If ever an injury could be called timely, the one revealed when Chris Drury, the Rangers’ captain, missed practice Friday would qualify.

headline: Why Yemen Won’t Fall
text: London

headline: Photo Replay: Feb. 4
text: A view of the day in sports from a world record attempt in Edmonton, Canada, to snowy conditions in Dallas.

headline: Hiring Financier for Advice, Mets Owners Didn’t Take It, Lawsuit Says
text: Saul Katz, the certified public accountant who in 1972 started Sterling Equities with his brother-in-law Fred Wilpon, almost never met a Bernard L. Madoff idea he did not like, according to a lawsuit brought by the trustee in the Madoff fraud. The Katz and Wilpon families, who own the Mets, had some 90 percent of their securities positions tied up in Madoff’s brokerage for the nearly 25 years they did business with him.

headline: The Know-Nothing Mets? There’s a Pattern Here
text: The owners of the Mets keep saying they did not have a clue what was going on in the matter of Bernard L. Madoff.

headline: Too Much of a Good Thing
text: When Mayor Michael Bloomberg began his campaign against cigarette smoking eight years ago, most New Yorkers breathed a sigh of relief. The great indoors  bars, restaurants, hotels, office buildings  all are now smoke-free by law, making New York City a healthier place. And, for those already addicted or tempted, the city offered kits to help people stop smoking and gruesome television ads to try to keep them from starting.

headline: The Disappearing Ethics Act
text: In a woeful signal to the new Congress, the House ethics committee has decided that when it comes to money and ethics, money nearly always wins.

headline: The Kindling of Change
text: It is impossible to know exactly which embers spark a revolution, but it’s not so hard to measure the conditions that make a country prime for one.

text: To the Editor:

headline: More Trade Follies
text: It’s been more than three years since the Bush administration signed a trade agreement with South Korea. And for more than three years Congress has been balking at it. To overcome that opposition, the Obama administration got Seoul to improve the terms for American carmakers. Capitol Hill seemed happy  until it wasn’t.

headline: The Siege of Planned Parenthood
text: As if we didn’t have enough wars, the House of Representatives has declared one against Planned Parenthood.

headline: Bewitched by the Numbers
text: The data zealots have utterly discombobulated themselves.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Newark Bears Hire Leyritz
text: The former Yankee catcher Jim Leyritz was hired as a pitching coach for the Newark Bears, an independent minor-league team. In November, Leyritz was cleared of manslaughter charges stemming from a fatal 2007 car accident. He was convicted of driving under the influence. ¶The Yankees agreed to minor-league deals with infielders Ronnie Belliard and Eric Chavez that included invitations to spring training. Belliard, 35, who hit .216 last season for the Dodgers, is primarily a second baseman but has experience at all four infield positions. Chavez, 33, a third baseman who won six Gold Gloves with Oakland, has 230 career home runs, but injuries have limited him to 154 games over the last four seasons. chavez BEN SHPIGEL

headline: Nocturnalist | How the Horses Got to the Ball
René Verdon, French Chef for the Kennedys, Dies at 86
text: René Verdon, whose position as the White House chef during the Kennedy administration helped him project the allure of classic French cuisine to the American public, died on Wednesday in San Francisco. He was 86.

headline: Lena Nyman, Star of ‘I Am Curious’ Films, Is Dead at 66
text: Lena Nyman, the Swedish actress whose performance in the sexually explicit movie “I Am Curious (Yellow)” raised the hackles of censors in the 1960s and helped turn the film into a box office bonanza, died on Friday in Stockholm. She was 66.

headline: Gil Brandt Sees Overtime Game for Super Bowl
text: DALLAS – Gil Brandt, the former longtime vice president for player personnel for the Cowboys, has been to 42 of 44 Super Bowls. And he believes Super Bowl XLV is as closely matched as any of them.

headline: Palin Keeps Position Clear and Intentions Vague
text: SANTA BARBARA, Calif. – Sarah Palin opened a weekend centennial celebration to Ronald Reagan by declaring that the United States was lurching toward a “road to ruin,” a nation so beleaguered by debt and out-of-control government spending that an urgent change in direction was needed in Washington.

headline: The AgeLab at M.I.T.
text: The AgeLab at M.I.T. is partnering with businesses to develop new technologies geared toward helping seniors stay healthy, active and independent.

headline: The Aging of America
text: Baby boomers began turning 65 in January, heralding a seismic shift in demographics worldwide. In the United States, by the year 2035, 1 in 5 people are expected to be age 65 or older.

headline: Classic Ad: Requiem for the Tape Deck
text: In this Sunday’s Automobiles section, Stephen Williams documents the dying throes of the car stereo cassette deck, which as of the 2011 model year is no longer available as factory equipment — standard or optional — on any new car sold in the United States. (The 2010 Lexus SC 430 appears to have been the last holdout.)

headline: Updates on Day 12 of Egypt Protests
text: The Lede provided updates on Saturday on the street protests and related developments in Egypt. For a summary, read the current version of our main news article from our colleagues in Cairo. Our updates mix breaking news alerts with reports from bloggers and journalists posted on other news sites and social networks. A stream of live Twitter updates appears in The Lede’s right column. Readers can share information in the comment thread below or send photographs or video from Egypt to pix@nyt.com.

headline: Voice Recognition, Still Imperfect
text: I’ve been experimenting with Google Voice, which provides text versions of voice mails on my cell — quite useful. But not exactly 100% on recognition. My executive editor at Worth Publishers, which does Krugman/Wells, left a voice mail telling me that some student volunteers and the university president wanted a photo shoot before the Worth cocktail party, which they promised would only take about 5 minutes. At least that’s what I think he said. The text version said:

headline: Are You Paying Too Little in Taxes?
text: In a provocative article in the latest issue of Inc. magazine, Max Chafkin takes a look at the relationship between taxes and entrepreneurship. For the piece, Mr. Chafkin spent two weeks in Norway, which ranks higher than the United States in effective income tax rates and has a 1.1 percent wealth tax — but also has more entrepreneurs per capita and higher rates of start-up creation. The case of Norway, Mr. Chafkin writes, should give us pause: “What if we have been wrong about taxes?”

headline: Protesters Remain in Tahrir Square
text: Protests in Egypt went for for a twelvth day, demonstrators are demanding the ousting of longtime President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Exchange Rates and Price Stickiness (Wonkish)
text: I mentioned recently that the correlation between nominal and real exchange rates is one key piece of evidence that we live in a Keynes-Friedman world of sticky prices, not the classical, perfect flexibility world of real business cycle theorists. Now that I have a few moments, let me elaborate on that.

headline: Inflation, an Old Scourge, Plagues Argentina Again
text: BUENOS AIRES  Damian Vásquez used to regularly update the prices of household cleaning products on the sign outside his store. Today he often does not bother. Inflation has been causing prices to rise so fast that he grew tired of the effort to keep up.

headline: Tuviah Friedman, Tireless Pursuer of Nazis, Dies at 88
text: In the months before and after the end of World War II, Tuviah Friedman tirelessly hunted Nazis as part of a militia in liberated Poland, and he reveled in his nickname, the Merciless One.

headline: Iraq Restores Monument Symbolizing Hussein Era
text: BAGHDAD  As hundreds of thousands in Egypt protested the iron rule of that country’s president, Iraq quietly began restoring a bronze fist of its former dictator, Saddam Hussein.

text: The Times reports this morning on the development of technologies that may help to keep aging Americans out of long-term care facilities.

headline: In Turkey’s Example, Some See Map for Egypt
text: As Egypt struggles to reinvent itself, many experts in the region say that it might look to Turkey for some valuable lessons.

headline: Preapproved: Well, It Sounded Good
text: MELISSA CALDERONE was ready for a fresh start when she made plans last year to move to Florida from New Jersey. Recently remarried, she signed a contract in mid-March on a house to be built in Windermere, Fla., by Pulte Homes, the nation’s largest homebuilder. The neighborhood had good schools for her three children and two stepchildren. It was also close to where Ms. Calderone’s parents lived.

headline: Afghan Rights Fall Short for Christian Converts
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The jail commander had remained silent as the prisoner, Sayed Mussa, told a reporter about his journey from Islam to Christianity: his secret baptism nine years earlier, his faith in Jesus Christ and the promise of heaven.

text: Members of the Packers and Steelers talk about the emotions they expect to be dealing with on Saturday night.

headline: U.S. and Russia Activate an Arms Control Treaty
text: MUNICH  The United States and Russia on Saturday exchanged documents that formally activated New Start, a strategic arms control treaty. It was the final step in a protracted negotiation marked by difficult talks with the Russians and even more difficult talks with Republican holdouts in the Senate.

headline: Variety: 3-D Word Hunt
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Be vewy, vewy quiet. We’re hunting wabbits. Sorry, I mean, words. Your puzzlemaster, Will Shortz, is back with his 3-D Word Hunt. Here are the directions, in case you missed them:

headline: Maliki Says He Won’t Seek Another Term
text: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki said Saturday that he would not seek re-election as leader of the Iraqi government after his current term ends in 2014. The statement came a day after Mr. Maliki, who began his second term in December, said he would cut his pay in half.

headline: Soaring Food Prices
text: What’s behind the surge in food prices? The usual suspects have made the usual claims — it’s all about the Fed, or it’s all about speculators. But I’ve been looking at the USDA World supply and demand estimates, and what stands out from the data is mainly that we’ve had a huge global harvest failure.

headline: Capers and LeBeau Created and Share Defensive Blueprint
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Dom Capers is trying to complete in Green Bay what he started in Pittsburgh 19 years ago.

headline: A Second Tour as C.E.O.
text: I GREW up in Del Mar, Calif., north of San Diego. I got my first job the summer after eighth grade at a small Internet service provider. I called the owner, Christopher Alan, one day and asked if he had a summer internship or a job, and he took a chance on me. My mother would drive me to the train, and I’d take along my skateboard to go from the San Diego train station to the office.

headline: Cracking the Male Code of Office Behavior
text: FOR the last nine years, I’ve been engaged in some of the most fascinating work a woman can do: talking to and surveying thousands of men to investigate what they think  and then writing books about it.

headline: Rookie Unmoved by a Rapid Rise
text: FORT WORTH  As invisible as black ice during the regular season, James Starks awoke on Thursday to find his photograph on the front page of a national newspaper. Starks, the Green Bay Packers’ rookie tailback, did not seem impressed.

headline: Clouds Part for Fab Five’s Coach
text: SAN DIEGO  San Diego State has never won an N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament game, yet has enough talent to win this year’s national championship. The team, which has sold out eight games in the program’s history, now faces logistical problems with 1,500 students lining up for tickets before dawn on game days.

headline: Cameron Criticizes ‘Multiculturalism’ in Britain
text: LONDON  Faced with growing alarm about Islamic militants who have made Britain one of Europe’s most active bases for terrorist plots, Prime Minister David Cameron has mounted an attack on the country’s decades-old policy of “multiculturalism,” saying it has encouraged “segregated communities” where Islamic extremism can thrive.

headline: Palin, Rallying Base, Paints Dark Picture of Obama’s Policies
text: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.  Sarah Palin opened a celebration of Ronald Reagan this weekend by declaring that the United States was lurching toward a “road to ruin,” saying the nation had become so weighed down by debt and excess government that a new direction was urgently needed in Washington.

headline: Hackers Gained Access to Nasdaq Systems, but Not Trades
text: Computer hackers have breached the systems of the company that runs the Nasdaq stock exchange in New York but did not penetrate the part of the system that handles trades, Nasdaq said Saturday.

[Feb. 9, 6:50 p.m. | Updated  Many more views on the up side of gaming are here.]

headline: Players Preparing for Chance the Checks Will Stop
text: DALLAS — In the best of times, some N.F.L. players have trouble saving their money. Because of an urge to help family and friends, or an inability to sock away some of their paychecks, a distressing number of athletes end up with little in the bank at the end of their careers.

headline: Super Sunday in England, Too
text: In another country, another time zone, another sport, one of the most anticipated games of the English Premier League season will be a nice Sunday brunch (kickoff 11 a.m. Eastern on Fox Soccer Channel) to the day’s main course in the United States — the Super Bowl (which will be carried on the mother ship, Fox).

headline: Egypt Stability Hinges on a Divided Military
text: WASHINGTON  A classified cable sent to Washington from the United States Embassy in Cairo in 2008 reported that a disgruntled midlevel Egyptian officer corps referred to the country’s powerful defense minister, Field Marshal Mohamed Tantawi, as “Mubarak’s poodle”  incompetent and archaic but intensely loyal to his now-besieged president.

headline: Why Some Twitter Posts Catch On, and Some Don’t

text: WHEN colleges and universities finally decide to make full use of the Internet, most professors will lose their jobs.

headline: Ripples? Yes. Waves? Maybe.
text: IN 1972, Edward N. Lorenz gave a talk that turned out to be a landmark in the development of chaos theory. Its title was “Predictability: Does the Flap of a Butterfly’s Wings in Brazil Set Off a Tornado in Texas?”

headline: Early America, Ripe for Counterfeiters
text: “THERE is properly no history; only biography,” Ralph Waldo Emerson wrote in 1841. In “Moneymakers: The Wicked Lives and Surprising Adventures of Three Notorious Counterfeiters” (Penguin, $27.95), Ben Tarnoff lends ample credence to that notion. He shows how three con men were able to thrive in America’s early days because of a weak central government, an often-chaotic banking system, a turbulent economy and an entrepreneurial populace.

headline: Protest Threats Derail Bush Speech in Switzerland
text: WASHINGTON  A planned trip by former President George W. Bush to Switzerland this week has been canceled in the face of threatened large-scale protests and calls for an investigation into whether his administration committed human rights abuses in the fight against terrorism.

headline: A Dot on the Map, Until the Earth Started Shaking
text: GUY, Ark.  Everybody around here is getting used to the earthquakes, and that does not sit well with Dirk DeTurck.

headline: Prime Number
text: 39.8: Chicagoans tend to shrug at blizzard forecasts with the knowledge that, after all, they’re from Chicago. But the city, which recorded a snowfall of 21.2 inches Jan. 31-Feb. 2, can’t hold a ruler to some other metropolises. Its record snow total of 23 inches on Jan. 26-27, 1967, ranks a middling 13th among the 29 biggest cities (those whose metropolitan areas have two million-plus people). All figures shown here are for snow events up to three days in duration.

headline: Champion Quarterbacks Sooner and Later
text: The best quarterbacks are celebrated for the strength of their passing arms, their accuracy in winging a ball to receivers, their wisdom in recognizing defenses, their agility in escaping blitzing linebackers, their instinct for changing a play at the line of scrimmage and their command in the huddle.

text: The Packers' defensive coordinator, Dom Capers, talks about working with the Steelers' defensive coordinator, Dick LeBeau, during their time in Pittsburgh.

headline: Fighting Words
text: A class-action lawsuit was filed last week in Federal District Court in Manhattan against former President Jimmy Carter, claiming his 2006 book, “Palestine: Peace Not Apartheid,” was falsely marketed as an accurate account of peace negotiations in the Middle East.

headline: Damage to Metrodome Is Felt Beyond N.F.L.
text: MINNEAPOLIS  For visitors entering the University of Minnesota baseball office, the first framed poster on the left grabs the eye. It depicts the Metrodome at night, the Teflon roof lighted to a brilliant white, with the backdrop of the Minneapolis skyline behind it.

headline: Unpredictable Uprisings
text: With upheaval gripping several Arab nations ruled by oppressive or corrupt regimes, here is a historical sampler of the twists and turns of revolutions. Many start out broad-based, but often not for long.

headline: Love, Family and Change in Brooklyn
text: Russell Frederick has been documenting the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood in Brooklyn as part of an ongoing project since 1999. Mr. Frederick, 40, is a member of  Kamoinge, a New York-based collective and is working on his first solo exhibition “Black.” Mr. Frederick spoke with me this week in New York. The conversation has been edited.

headline: Little Consolation in Third-Place Game
text: It was an N.F.L. postseason game with several official and unofficial names and no meaning at all. The Playoff Bowl was one name. But you might have called it the Bert Bell Benefit Bowl (for a former commissioner), the Pro Playoff Classic or the Runner-Up Bowl.

text: WASHINGTON —  If the United States is, as so many presidents have said in so many speeches, the world’s pre-eminent champion of democracy, then why does the drama unfolding in Cairo seem so familiar?

headline: Ruling May End Long Dispute in a Queens Neighborhood

headline: Wallflowers at the Revolution
text: A month ago most Americans could not have picked Hosni Mubarak out of a police lineup. American foreign policy, even in Afghanistan, was all but invisible throughout the 2010 election season. Foreign aid is the only federal budget line that a clear-cut majority of Americans says should be cut. And so now  as the world’s most unstable neighborhood explodes before our eyes  does anyone seriously believe that most Americans are up to speed? Our government may be scrambling, but that’s nothing compared to its constituents. After a near-decade of fighting wars in the Arab world, we can still barely distinguish Sunni from Shia.

headline: Meant to Be Broken? Maybe Not This Time
text: WASHINGTON  The mechanics of legislating should be simple: bring a bill to the floor, fight over amendments, vote the measure up or down and move on to the next one.

headline: Working Constantly, Thanks to Technology
text: I am as guilty as the next person when it comes to reflexively and repeatedly swiping my iPhone to check e-mail, Twitter and LinkedIn. Trust me when I tell you that I am not expecting any earth-shattering updates. Still, as with any bad habit, I have to scratch the itch or suffer mild symptoms of withdrawal.

headline: On the Hill
text: Mechanics of legislating should be simple: Bring a bill to the floor, fight over amendments, vote the measure up or down and move on to the next one. But in the Senate, that approach had been largely replaced by partisan procedural brawls, writes Carl Hulse in his On The Hill column, “Meant to Be Broken? Maybe Not This Time.” Now, though, there appears to be growing support for going back to those civics-book basics.

headline: The 40 Percent Nation
text: In the 1990s, at the height of the democratic revolutions, many people assumed that getting rid of the dictator was the hard part. If the people in a country could topple the old regime, then their country would make the transition toward democracy.

headline: Knicks Hire Warkentien as Pro Personnel Director
text: Mark Warkentien, a former executive of the year, has joined the Knicks as director of pro player personnel, the team announced Saturday.

headline: Republican Congressman Takes Aims at Tester’s Senate Seat in Montana

headline: Coach’s Death Both Saddens and Inspires
text: ALTOONA, Pa.  Mike Lang might have found the inspiration behind the recent 16-game winning streak by the La Roche College men’s basketball team. In the office of his younger brother, Scott, the former head coach, he came across some recruiting papers.

text: WASHINGTON  Put away your copy of the Constitution. Take out your calculator. It’s time for some judicial arithmetic.

headline: Dutch Returns

This desire was a surprise to those around the former president. He had never shown any interest in Tampico, Ill.

headline: Bankers and Their Bonuses
text: Bankers are done with contrition. Lloyd Blankfein, chief executive of Goldman Sachs, paid himself a $12.6 million stock bonus for 2010, 40 percent more than in 2009, despite plummeting profits. Brian Moynihan of Bank of America got $9 million in restricted stock despite the bank’s $2.2 billion loss.

headline: Stock-Hedging Lets Bankers Skirt Efforts to Overhaul Pay
text: Intent on fixing a banking system that contributed heavily to the recent financial crisis, lawmakers and regulators pushed Wall Street to overhaul its pay practices. Big banks responded by shifting more compensation into stock, a move intended to align employees’ interests more closely with those of investors and discourage excessive risk-taking.

headline: Milton Rogovin
text: In 1994, I was asked to interview the photographer Milton Rogovin because I’d written a book about the old Polish East Side of Buffalo. Rogovin, who recently died at 101, had spent years photographing Buffalo’s downtrodden Lower West Side. In a way, it was like a visitor to Portland, Ore., talking to a resident of Portland, Me., because they both knew something about Portland.

headline: Bruins’ Ference Criticizes Teammate’s Hit
text: Supporting and defending one’s players and teammates are ingrained in hockey culture. So it was unusual on Thursday when Boston defenseman Andrew Ference did not back up his teammate Daniel Paille, who was given a major penalty and a game misconduct for a blindside hit to the head of Dallas forward Raymond Sawada.

headline: Tura Satana, Cult Actress, Dies
text: Tura Satana, the actress whose authoritative presence, exotic looks and buxom frame commanded the attention of viewers of Russ Meyer‘s 1965 cult movie “Faster, Pussycat! Kill! Kill!”, died on Friday evening in Reno, Nev.

headline: Sunday: What’s That, José?
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — David Kahn tells us a joke today, and what starts out as a pleasant reunion of sorts concludes with one of those appallingly embarrassing moments that we all dread. If you’re “of a certain age”, you might have even had a conversation like the one in this puzzle. Of course, I’m nowhere near that age, so you can just forget all about my being able to totally relate to the joke, thank you very much. Let’s move on, shall we?

headline: With Power Play on Blink in Montreal, Rangers Drop Their Fourth Straight Game
text: MONTREAL  The Rangers had better start looking behind them. They lost to the Canadiens, 2-0, here on Saturday and became the first N.H.L. team to complete two-thirds of its schedule.

headline: From the Frontlines to the Farm
text: Programs are sprouting around the country to train veterans and active-duty service members interested in organic farming.

headline: Three Cases of Cholera Are Confirmed by City Officials
