headline: Helping Soldiers Trade Their Swords for Plows
text: VALLEY CENTER, Calif. — On an organic farm here in avocado country, a group of young Marines, veterans and Army reservists listened intently to an old hand from the front lines.

headline: The Strange Victory of the Palmetto State
text: Less than two months separated South Carolina’s decision to secede from the United States and the creation of a new country, the Confederate States of America. In that time six other states, comprising the entire Deep South — Mississippi, Florida, Alabama, Georgia, Louisiana and Texas — had followed.

headline: Detentions, and Aide’s Role, Anger Egyptians
text: CAIRO  Vice President Omar Suleiman of Egypt has won the blessing of both the Mubarak and Obama administrations as the leader of a political transition toward democracy in Egypt. But human rights advocates say that so far Mr. Suleiman, who also is in charge of Egyptian intelligence, has shown no sign of discontinuing the practice of extra-legal detention of political opponents  a hallmark of President Hosni Mubarak’s nearly 30-year rule that is a central grievance of the protesters in the streets.

headline: Some of Obama’s Favorite Programs to Face Cuts, Budget Director Says
text: WASHINGTON — The budget that President Obama will release next week reflects scores of “tough calls” that cut deeply into programs that the president supports, in keeping with his proposed five-year freeze on a broad category of domestic spending, according to the administration’s budget director.

headline: Movement Began With Outrage and a Facebook Page That Gave It an Outlet
text: If there is a face to the revolt that has sprouted in Egypt, it may be the face of Khaled Said.

headline: Sweat | 92 Years Old, and Still Ruling The Squash Court
text: With just a few concessions to age, Victor Elmaleh keeps much younger players scampering after the ball.

headline: Sanders and Faulk Headline 2011 Hall of Fame Class
text: DALLAS — With a stacked list of finalists hoping to be selected for induction into the Pro Football Hall of Fame on Saturday, little was certain about who would be a part of the 2011 class. But from the start, there was little doubt that Deion Sanders would be the one headlining the group.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Feb. 6
text: Super Bowl XLV fever hits the Sunday television talk shows, as policymakers, diplomats and football players split airtime assessing the matchup between the Green Bay Packers and the Pittsburgh Steelers. But the political turmoil in Egypt remains the center of attention.

headline: To Erving, Once a Net, Always at Net
text: Julius Erving took his electrifying high-flying act to three teams and two pro leagues on his way to the Basketball Hall of Fame. But his heart is still with the Nets, and he thinks the team has a bright future landing in Brooklyn, even if it has to share the city with the Knicks.

headline: Joining to Bid Farewell to an Almost Unknown Soldier
text: A retired hospital chaplain, Ray Deabel speaks at 80 or so funerals a year, many for fellow military veterans. That is an honor. But sometimes only a handful of mourners show up. That is a shame. At the service for one World War II veteran a few years ago, only the chaplain and the funeral home director were there to say thank you and goodbye.

headline: City’s Inequities Belie World-Class Imagery
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Everybody Hates a Blizzard, but Pity the Politicians Whose Wards Got Short Shrift
text: The day after the blizzard, with election day less than three weeks away, Alderman Freddrenna Lyle (6th Ward) listened wearily to a stream of constituents who phoned to complain that unplowed snow was still keeping them from driving.

headline: The Pulse: Alderman Stone, Checking In
text: Alderman Bernard L. Stone (50th Ward), the 83-year-old statesman of the City Council and the vice mayor, can add “mayor of City Hall” to his title, courtesy of the social-networking Web site Foursquare.

headline: New Emanuel Ad Provides Fresh Grist
text: Ahead of what is being described as a major budget-platform announcement scheduled for Tuesday, Rahm Emanuel released his latest campaign television ad, in which he states that “city government is not an employment agency.”

headline: Marathon’s Tiny School District Grabs at a Lifeline
text: MARATHON — If you close the school, you close the town.

headline: As Mubarak Digs In, U.S. Policy in Egypt Is Complicated
text: Twelve days into an uprising in Egypt that threatens to upend American strategy in the Middle East, the Obama administration is struggling to determine if a democratic revolution can succeed while President Hosni Mubarak remains in office, even if his powers are neutered and he is sidelined from negotiations over the country’s future.

headline: A Drug Used in Executions Becomes Very Hard to Get
text: A combination of market forces and European objections to the death penalty have left the nation’s busiest execution chamber with only enough of a key drug  sodium thiopental  to use for two convicted murderers scheduled to die later this month.

headline: Looming Over Combs, Abortion Issue in 2014
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

headline: Rodney Crowell’s Audacity of Spirit
text: Admittedly, a taco stand in Jacinto City would have been the ideal place to eat breakfast with Rodney Crowell, as East Houston isn’t just the setting but virtually the primary character in that singer-songwriter’s new memoir, “Chinaberry Sidewalks.”

headline: Political Changes in Cairo
text: On a day of political maneuverings, protesters trying to overthrow the Egyptian government found themselves ringed by a much heavier troop presence than usual.

headline: Researchers Evaluate Who Is Old Enough for Body Checks
text: The predominant opinion among researchers of serious injuries in boys’ hockey favors pushing back the age for introducing body checking to 13, and USA Hockey is considering that proposal.

headline: Get Married, Save Thousands on Tuition
text: Students worldwide compete to attend the University of California, Berkeley, considered one of the best universities in the United States.

headline: Flashy Sanders and the Versatile Faulk Headline the 2011 Hall of Fame Class
text: DALLAS — Only a player with a résumé that includes taking a helicopter from a major league baseball game to an N.F.L. game could be elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame and have that be the second-biggest event of the day for him. Elected in his first year of eligibility, in a class co-headlined by Marshall Faulk and Shannon Sharpe, Deion Sanders seemed much more concerned with the fact that his Truth youth football team had lost to a team coached by Snoop Dogg earlier in the day.

headline: Children’s Fairyland
text: The United States’ first storybook theme park opened in 1950 near Lake Merritt. Admission ranged from 9 to 14 cents, depending on the visitor’s age. The park, Children’s Fairyland, still prospers, delighting those young at heart with 10 acres of gentle rides, storybook sets, animal pens and theater stages.

headline: PG&E Still Sails Smooth, and That’s the Rub
text: Jonathan Weber writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Oakland Mayor and Police Chief Share Uneasy Alliance
text: During a news conference at Oakland City Hall on Monday, Anthony Batts, the police chief who recently applied  unsuccessfully  for the same position in San Jose, was asked if he intended to stay at the helm of the embattled Oakland Police Department.

headline: Cheers, Gibes and a Loss in Lavin’s U.C.L.A. Return
text: LOS ANGELES  On Saturday, Steve Lavin returned to the scene of his crime, the same crime committed by seven others who have served as coach of the U.C.L.A. men’s basketball team. They failed to live up to the impossible standard set by John Wooden.

headline: A Victory to Remember for a Young American
text: Until a week ago, the short list of the greatest American tournament victories was limited to Hastings in 1895, Cambridge Springs in 1904, AVRO in 1938 and Palma de Mallorca in 1970.

headline: States Struggle to Disarm People Who’ve Lost Right to Own Guns
text: By law, Roy Perez should not have had a gun three years ago when he shot his mother 16 times in their home in Baldwin Park, Calif., killing her, and then went next door and killed a woman and her 4-year-old daughter.

headline: Super Bowl XLV: Squaring Off on Defense
text: The Steelers-Packers game features two of this season’s stingiest defenses.

headline: Palin Criticizes Obama on Egypt
text: SANTA BARBARA, Calif. — As Sarah Palin delivered a weekend address here, paying tribute to Ronald Reagan on the centennial of his birth, she directed a forceful line of criticism at President Obama and his administration, though she did not mention the crisis in Egypt. But in a subsequent television interview, she took Mr. Obama to task for his handling of the matter.

headline: Pandit Bhimsen Joshi Dies at 88; Indian Classical Singer
text: “Even Gods Must Die.”

headline: Mary Cleere Haran, Cabaret Singer With a Big-Band Style, Dies at 58
text: Mary Cleere Haran, a classic popular singer and writer much admired for her cabaret shows celebrating the American song book, died on Saturday in Deerfield Beach, Fla., two days after a cycling accident. She was 58 and was living in Florida, having taken a break from a career that saw her perform in every major New York supper club.

headline: Vows: Louis & Mark
text: After a guy Mark went on a date with suggested that Mark would be compatible with his boss, Lou, Mark sent Lou a Friendster message and the two have been dating ever since.

headline: Lottery Numbers
30 Seconds With Packers’ John Kuhn
text: Fullback John Kuhn is the only active member of the Green Bay Packers with a Super Bowl ring, which he earned during the 2005 season as a member of Pittsburgh’s practice squad.

headline: Should We Worry about Egypt Becoming Democratic?
text: My answer is: No.

headline: Dangerous and Deadly 24 Hours on New York Roads
text: On a day when the weather made most New Yorkers want to stay holed up indoors, a series of frightening and fatal car accidents reinforced the sentiment.

headline: The Easy Cuts Are Behind Us
text: Washington

headline: Sorkin and Nolan Triumph at ‘Introverted Emmys’
text: On Saturday night, the Writers Guild of America awards – or the “introverted Emmys” as the New York host, Kristen Schaal, put it – doled out their prizes simultaneously and bicoastally, as usual. The group honored Aaron Sorkin and Christopher Nolan for their adapted (“The Social Network”) and original (“Inception) screenplays, respectively. Both were in Los Angeles to accept. “Inside Job” won for best documentary; the director and lead writer, Charles Ferguson, was also in Los Angeles.

headline: Looking to Egypt’s Future, Merkel Recalls Her Past
text: MUNICH  With an eye to her past in trying to build new democratic institutions in former communist East Germany, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany spoke at the annual Munich Security Conference on Saturday about how Europe should respond to the extraordinary events unfolding in North Africa and the Middle East.

headline: After First Talks, Egypt Opposition Vows New Protest
text: CAIRO  Leaders of the Egyptian democracy movement vowed Sunday to escalate their pressure for the resignation of President Hosni Mubarak, even as his government portrayed itself as already in the midst of American-approved negotiations to end the uprising, now in its 13th day.

headline: Mumbai to Hold Second Annual Restaurant Week
text: In the last few years, Mumbai has witnessed something of a culinary explosion. In 2010, two internationally acclaimed chefs — Ian Kittichai, who is Thai, and Vineet Bhatia, an Indian — brought their considerable talents to the city. This year, two prominent global restaurant brands, Megu and Hakkasan, will open outposts here. But most of the city’s gourmands will tell you that fine dining options in Mumbai are still woefully inadequate. Mumbai’s population hovers somewhere around 14 million, but there are perhaps no more than 40 high-end restaurants in the city.

headline: Super Bowl Hasn’t Happened Yet, According to Onion
text: The Onion:

headline: Reader Photos: Your Super Bowl Snacks
text: Send us photos of the over-the-top food at your local Super Bowl party — pork shoulder shaped like a football, a Vince Lombardi Trophy made of nachos and other creations that are delicious, regrettable or both. The best will appear here on Diner’s Journal on Sunday night.

headline: For Countries That Own Shorter Web Site Suffixes, Extra Cash From Abroad
text: Logging on to Facebook? You can use the social networking site’s full Web address, or you can type www.fb.me.

headline: Super Bowl, Commercial Interruption
text: A recent survey found that nearly half of the audience for the Super Bowl will be watching for the commercials, for the halftime show or “just for the fun of it.”

headline: Kubica Involved in Rally Accident
text: Updated | 9:42 a.m.

headline: Kubica Involved in Rally Accident
text: Updated | 9:42 a.m.

headline: What to Watch While You Wait
text: Looking for a break from the Super Bowl pregame show? Sunday is a sports fan’s delight beyond the big game in Dallas. Before the Steelers and the Packers kick off, there is an English Premier League grudge match, the resumption of a heated N.H.L. rivalry, a Big Ten basketball showdown and a rematch of the N.B.A. Eastern Conference finals. (All times Eastern.)

headline: When to Avoid Using A.T.M.’s
text: In a recent Bucks post, “More on Spotting A.T.M. Skimmers,” John Pearce of the security company ADT Security Services shared tips for spotting the devices, including inspecting the A.T.M. and the area around the A.T.M.

headline: In Tehran, Trial Begins of Americans Held as Spies
text: TEHRAN — The trial of the three American hikers accused of espionage and illegally entering Iran began behind closed doors on Sunday, and not guilty pleas were entered on their behalf, their lawyer said.

headline: Q. and A. With Kurt Warner
text: Kurt Warner, the most valuable player of Super Bowl XXXIV for the St. Louis Rams, is the only quarterback to pass for more than 300 yards three times in the Super Bowl. The N.F.L.’s M.V.P. in 1999 and 2001, he also played for the Giants and the Arizona Cardinals.Warner, 39, retired after a 12-year N.F.L. career and became an analyst for the NFL Network and Fox Sports last year. He is a spokesman for Nutrilite vitamins and Duracell, and founder of the First Things First Foundation, which is dedicated to promoting Christian values.

headline: Updates on Day 13 of Egypt Protests
text: On Sunday, The Lede continues to follow the street protests in Egypt. For a summary of the latest developments, read the current version of the main news article from Times reporters in Cairo. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with eyewitness accounts from bloggers and journalists in Egypt. A stream of Twitter updates on the protests is in this blog’s right column. Readers can share information in the comment thread below or send photographs or video from Egypt to pix@nyt.com.

headline: Food: The Late Surge
text: Just a note, mainly to myself, about global food prices: food was actually a latecomer to the commodity price surge. Here are IMF indexes for all commodities and just food since the early-2009 low, shown as natural logs so that the slope represents the growth rate:

headline: Protests Continue Amid Talks
text: Representatives of the Egyptian democracy movement vowed Sunday to escalate their pressure for the resignation of President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: A DreamWorks Rout in a Flawed Contest
text: LOS ANGELES— Think about a big homecoming football game featuring cross-town rivals. And then only one team shows up. Kinda makes for a lopsided victory, right?

headline: Many Want Rare Earths, but Few Are Mining Them
text: "RARE earth” is a historical misnomer. Elements that fall under this label were identified mostly in the 18th and 19th centuries, when the word “earths” was used to describe a group of geological materials. At the time, a subset of these was thought to be uncommon.

headline: Blinis, Gossip and Gogol, Snob-Style
text: What would Gogol eat?

headline: Cheney Has Kind Words for Mubarak
text: WASHINGTON – As protesters in Egypt pressed forward with calls for the resignation of Hosni Mubarak this weekend, former Vice President Dick Cheney said that the longtime Egyptian leader had been a “good friend” to the United States who deserved to be treated well.

headline: Culinary Comfort in a Tumultuous Middle East
text: After the shocks of 9/11 many New Yorkers turned their thoughts  and their lonely stomachs  to comfort food, to reassuring combinations like macaroni and cheese and Ben & Jerry. We got a bit plump.

headline: Leading Off: Now, They Have to Play
text: Today marks the end of the two-week purgatory sports fans live in before every Super Bowl. Yes, after two weeks of blather the Steelers and the Packers will actually play a game and the collective sigh of relief will be enough to power a giant wind farm. Sometime this evening, you can take your finger off the mute button and tune back in.

headline: The Super Bowl of Yellow Pants
text: After two weeks of non-stop, searing comparative analysis of the Super Bowl matchup, you might ask: what’s left to discuss?

headline: Poll: Packers Have Rooting Edge
text: If public opinion can be used as a predictor, the Green Bay Packers will win the Super Bowl. In the latest CBS News poll, 34 percent of the American public would like to see the Packers win, while 25 percent prefer the Pittsburgh Steelers. More than 40 percent of the 1,137 adults surveyed last week don’t care or don’t have an opinion about the outcome of the game.

headline: Fisher Thanks Titans Fans
text: If Titans fans are feeling a little queasy about their team after the messy breakup between the owner Bud Adams and Coach Jeff Fisher, they might have felt even more queasy after seeing that Fisher took out a full-page ad in The Tennessean Sunday morning to thank them. That served as a reminder of how classy a guy Fisher is and the fact that Adams has not yet hired his replacement.

headline: Super Bowl Parties Go Big in Texas
text: DALLAS — Despite the snow, the ice, the storms, the cab strike and all the other issues here at Super Bowl XLV, the nightlife thrived. Of course it did.

headline: Finish Line Nears for Sanofi-Genzyme Talks
text: After months of wrangling, a successful end may be near for the merger talks between Sanofi-Aventis and Genzyme.

headline: Live Analysis: Super Bowl XLV, Packers Beat Steelers, 31-25
text: The Times’s staff provides analysis, pithy commentary and on-the-scene commentary from Super Bowl XLV between the Pittsburgh Steelers and the Green Bay Packers in Arlington, Tex.

headline: Stirring Chicago’s Corruption Stockpot
text: Chicago has largely been brought to us on fictional television through the defibrillator. So many pulses were revived over so many years on “Chicago Hope” and “ER” that the city came to seem like some sort of Lourdes for secularists. “Chicago,” you could envision a tourist slogan saying, “the place to be when you need an emergency triple bypass.” Natives must have hungered for a more expansive evocation of their hometown, one that explored the dirty genetics of a place that gave rise to both Al Capone and Rod Blagojevich. Citizens were possibly even irritated when Baltimore received rich dramatic excavation in “The Wire” before their own city had even been skimmed. Chicago taught Baltimore everything it knows.

headline: Stoudemire Snaps Knicks Out of Latest Funk
text: Whenever the Knicks lose, Amar’e Stoudemire can be found in some corner of the locker room with his head down, voice low and legs wrapped like a mummy from the costs of another wasted effort. Stoudemire then pledges that the Knicks have yet to accomplish anything of substance and notes the urgency to snap out of whatever malaise that is on the verge of setting in.

headline: White House Super Bowl Menu: Salts, Fats, Sugars and Bipartisan Brews
text: When the government set out dietary guidelines last week advising Americans to cut back on salts, fats and sugars, perhaps one critical omission was whether the recommendations applied to semi-official national holidays.

headline: At War With a Taliban Shadow Government
text: The Third Battalion of the 187th Infantry Regiment arrived in Ghazni Province, in eastern Afghanistan, in September to establish an official government presence in an area where the Taliban had set up an underground rule of its own.

headline: Sacred Heart’s Enduring Sideline Presence
text: FAIRFIELD, Conn.  The final seconds ticked off the clock on Sacred Heart’s 13-point loss. Coach Dave Bike walked the handshake line in front of the scorer’s table, then turned and headed diagonally off his home court, head down, a stocky 63-year-old grandfather in a gray sports jacket and a matching mood.

headline: Bare Bones, Fleshed Out With Music
text: Why hasn’t Miro Magloire been offered more opportunities in the ballet world? Companies, after all, are always looking for new talent, and Mr. Magloire creates clean, contemporary work that also has an old-fashioned respect for ballet steps and etiquette.

headline: Isn’t It Post-Romantic (and Lush, Too)?
text: Young singers don’t have it easy. Before they can play plush recital halls, they have to play chilly rooms with pipes clanging, children chattering and seltzer bottles fizzing.

headline: Obama and O’Reilly Talk Mubarak and Football
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama once again passed up the opportunity to publicly call for President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt to resign, but said that Egypt will not go back to the country it used to be before the democracy protests started.

headline: Expressing the Pain of Being Left Behind
text: The cumulative lesson of Summation Dance Company could go a little like this: An emotional beginning doesn’t automatically lead to a stirring finale. This all-female troupe, which made its debut on Friday night at the Baryshnikov Arts Center with “Keep Your Feathers Dry,” isn’t one for subtlety; instead it’s the kind of company in which dancers list their astrological signs in their biographies: “Sumi is an imaginative Aquarius who comes from California”; “Taryn is an analytical Virgo who hails from Wisconsin.”

headline: Change Ahead for League Chief Executive
text: Jay Baum, the chief executive of the American Contract Bridge League since 2002, has announced that he will retire next year. The league is looking for a replacement who plays bridge, knows the tournament and business worlds and is willing to relocate to the Memphis area. (The office is in Horn Lake, Miss.) Details are on league’s Web site.

headline: Guitarist, in Charge, Plays Well With Others
text: Eliot Fisk has found a way to enliven the confining format of the solo guitar recital: invite friends and share the spotlight, though not so much that a listener might mistake the concert for a chamber music program. At the 92nd Street Y on Saturday evening Mr. Fisk had two guests who played solo works and duets with him. But his own performances remained the center of gravity.

headline: Easygoing Look at Determined Women
text: The singer Anika Noni Rose is not one to push a point. On Saturday evening at the Allen Room, where she made her New York cabaret debut, Ms. Rose chose an easygoing effervescence over showy diva posturing. Certainly Dinah Washington, Eartha Kitt and Nancy Wilson, three of the stars she saluted and to whose music she was introduced by her grandmother, were nothing if not assertive. Ms. Rose is 38, but she radiated the wholesome ingenuousness of someone half her age.

headline: Outré Dance Music That Revels in Otherness
text: In some recent interviews Robyn, the Swedish dance-pop semi-star, has expressed ambivalence about her coming tour mate, the medium-wattage yet far more famous pop-tart headliner Katy Perry. The friction had a 1990s familiarity: high versus low, alternative versus mainstream. But this is just a slick sleight of thought: if anything Robyn, a battle ram with uncanny songwriting gifts and only occasional moments of complexity, offers a more straightforward proposition than the quirky Ms. Perry.

headline: Orchestral Extremes: From a Pizza Shop to Carnegie Hall
text: The Cleveland Orchestra must have been champing at the bit when it arrived at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening for the first of two concerts that, along with a finale in Newark on Sunday, would end a two-week American tour. The players and their music director, Franz Welser-Möst, started with a three-day residency at Indiana University, then escaped the Midwestern snows for balmy Florida, only to plunge back into the blizzards. Instead of moving on to Chicago, where they were to have performed in the venerable Symphony Center on Wednesday, they remained stranded in Ann Arbor, Mich., where several of the players joined a jam session in a pizza joint.

headline: Unafraid of Altering a Winning Formula
text: Many a band promises to reinvent itself. Few have done so as thoroughly as Linkin Park, which played Madison Square Garden on Friday night. Its 2010 album, “A Thousand Suns,” is strikingly different from the music that made Linkin Park a blockbuster band in the early 2000s, when it was a major instigator, or perpetrator, of rap-rock. At Madison Square Garden, Linkin Park was like two bands sharing a stage: the old hard-riffing rap-rock band and its newer, statelier, electronics-loving successor.

headline: In the State Where It All Began, a Cunningham Farewell
text: DURHAM, N.C.  The Merce Cunningham Dance Company was founded in North Carolina, at Black Mountain College, in 1953; over the weekend it danced its last North Carolina performances. Farewells are the pattern for the company this year. Having announced after Cunningham’s death in 2009 that it would give its final performances on New Year’s Eve 2011 in New York, it is saying goodbye to cities and to dances. What makes this so hard is that with the current company Cunningham still seems alive. It feels as if a continually investigative thought process  no mind in dance was ever more exploratory  is at work in the movement.

headline: The Work of Art in the Age of Google
text: If art is among your full-blown obsessions or just a budding interest, Google, which has already altered the collective universe in so many ways, changed your life last week. It unveiled its Art Project, a Web endeavor that offers easy, if not yet seamless, access to some of the art treasures and interiors of 17 museums in the United States and Europe.

headline: The Artistry Is Apparent, So Where’s the Audience?
text: The quandary in which Teddy Thompson, one of the most gifted singer-songwriters of his generation, finds himself is symptomatic of the confusion and uncertainty that pervade the crumbling record industry. With his abundant talent and commercial potential Mr. Thompson, the son of the British folk-rock aristocrats Richard and Linda Thompson, would seem to have everything.

headline: Monday: Come to Pass
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Ssshh. Is it DAYBREAK where you are?

headline: A Gallery of Species Lost and On the Brink
text: A few of the tens of thousands of species that scientists say have gone extinct or become critically endangered over the past 30 years.

headline: Slide Show: Readers’ Super Bowl Party Food
Elvis Costello’s Big Wheel
text: Elvis Costello has announced plans for “The Revolver Tour” beginning in May. This United States tour, backed by the band the Imposters, will resurrect Mr. Costello’s Spectacular Spinning Songbook, a giant game-show-style wheel listing 40 of his song titles. He first used the wheel on tour in 1986. During performances, audience members are selected to spin the wheel to determine the next tune on the band’s set list. The Imposters include Steve Nieve on keyboards, Pete Thomas on drums and the bass guitarist Davey Faragher. The tour is to begin on May 7 at the Grand Sierra Theater in Reno, Nev., and end on May 23 at the Beacon Theater in New York.

headline: Footnote
text: Christie Brinkley, below, will make her Broadway acting debut in the musical “Chicago” this spring, she said on “The Oprah Winfrey Show” on Friday. Ms. Brinkley, who began her acting career in 1983 by driving a Ferrari opposite Chevy Chase in “National Lampoon’s Vacation,” will play Roxie Hart during an 11-week engagement, April 4 through June 19, at the Ambassador Theater.

headline: Kevin Spacey Plans Middle East Academy
text: The actor and theater producer Kevin Spacey, below, has announced plans to start a theater arts academy in the Middle East, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Spacey, who appeared at a news conference on Sunday in Dubai, on his way to host the Laureus sports awards in Abu Dhabi on Monday, said the Middle East Theater Academy would be a joint project of the Kevin Spacey Foundation and Badr Jafar, executive director of Crescent Petroleum and chief executive officer of Crescent Investments. Mr. Spacey said the academy was to have no specific home but would travel across the region to provide instruction in all aspects of theater and offer a path for Middle Eastern works to travel to Broadway and other international sites. Mr. Spacey is currently the artistic director of the Old Vic theater in London.

headline: Los Angeles Schools Block Jamie Oliver
text: Jamie Oliver, the British chef, food reformer and reality television personality, is having a hard time revolutionizing the cafeterias of Los Angeles high schools. Permits for “Jamie Oliver’s Food Revolution” to film at local high schools were revoked last week after Mr. Oliver, left, failed to provide the Los Angeles Unified School District with a proposal of his plans for the show, according to Robert Alaniz, a spokesman for the school district, The Los Angeles Times reported. Mr. Alaniz said the district had had a bad experience with another reality show in the past. He also talked of the “conflict and drama” associated with Mr. Oliver’s show in Huntington, W.Va., saying, “We’re not interested in that.” Speaking at U.C.L.A.’s School of Public Health on Wednesday, Mr. Oliver said his filming permit was terminated because he could not promise the school district it would “look good.”

headline: Kate McGarrigle Tributes
text: The family of Kate McGarrigle, the Canadian singer and songwriter who died last year, has announced two tribute concerts in her honor. Her children, Rufus Wainwright and Martha Wainwright, and McGarrigle’s sister and longtime musical partner, Anna McGarrigle, are scheduled to perform on May 12 and 13 at Town Hall in Manhattan. They will be joined by their third sister, Jane McGarrigle, as well as by Jimmy Fallon, Emmylou Harris, Antony Hegarty, Justin Bond and several other performers, including Michel Pepin on guitar, Chaim Tannenbaum on mandolin and banjo, and Joel Zifkin on violin, all of whom were regular members of the McGarrigle band. “Everyone who met my mother, no matter how briefly, was struck by her worldly character matched with an otherworldly artistic aura,” Mr. Wainwright said of the tribute in an e-mail. “It’s all in the songs now. I can’t wait to hear them performed by all of these incredible artists.” Ms. McGarrigle learned she had a rare form of cancer in 2006 and died at her home in Montreal in January 2010. She was 63. All proceeds from the shows will go toward the creation of the Kate McGarrigle Sarcoma Research Fund, in association with the Sarcoma Foundation of America. Tickets go on sale at noon on Monday: (800) 745-3000; ticketmaster.com.

headline: A Sleepy Winter Continues at the Box Office
text: Movie audiences in North America spent about $75.4 million on tickets over the weekend, a 24 percent decline from a year earlier. The soft result extends Hollywood’s losing streak to 13 “down” weekends in a row. “Avatar,” which was still raking in box office cash at this time last year, is only part of the explanation. A ho-hum batch of releases in recent weeks has also contributed to lackluster sales. For the weekend, a traditionally slow one because of the Super Bowl, “The Roommate” (above, with Minka Kelly, left, and Leighton Meester), a horror entry from Sony Pictures Entertainment, was No. 1 with an estimated $15.6 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. “Sanctum,” a 3-D horror film set in underwater caves, was second, selling about $9.2 million for Universal Pictures and Relativity Media. The romantic comedy “No Strings Attached” (Paramount Pictures) was third with about $8.4 million for a new total of $51.8 million. “The King’s Speech” (the Weinstein Company) was a close fourth with roughly $8.3 million ($84.1 million total). “The Green Hornet” (Sony) chugged away in fifth place with $6.1 million, lifting its total to $87.2 million.

headline: Lawyers Try to Stop Lifetime Movie on Killing
text: Lawyers for Amanda Knox and her ex-boyfriend, Raffaele Sollecito, who were found guilty of killing Ms. Knox’s roommate in Italy in 2009, are trying to block the showing of a Lifetime movie about the murder, The Associated Press reported. Carlo Dalla Vedova and Luca Maori, the lawyers, said that they had warned the network that they would try to have “Amanda Knox: Murder on Trial in Italy” sequestered by a United States court if it was not canceled and a promotion for the movie taken off the network’s Web site. There was no comment from Lifetime, according to Les Eisner, a spokesman for its parent company, A&E Television Networks. Ms. Knox and Mr. Sollecito are appealing their convictions. The movie, which features Hayden Panettiere as Ms. Knox, is scheduled for Feb. 21.

headline: Ad Watch: The Super Bowl Commercials
text: Stuart Elliott, The Times’s advertising columnist, is taking a running look at some of the evening’s Super Bowl commercials:

headline: Mayoral Sign-Out Sheet? Secretive Jaunts Spur a Thought
text: His poll numbers have slid. His first choice to lead the city schools turned him down. And the budget deficit? Don’t even ask.

headline: Merce Cunningham Dance Company
text: Photos from the troupe’s performance in Durham, N.C.

headline: Donors Demand a Bigger Voice in Catholic Schools
text: Private philanthropists have changed the face of public education over the last decade, underwriting the rise of charter schools and promoting remedies that rely heavily on student testing and teacher evaluation.

headline: A Sardi’s Meal in Michigan
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: The Decline of Web-Based E-Mail
text: The number of visitors to Web-based e-mail sites, like Gmail and Yahoo mail, declined 5.9 percent from November 2009 to November 2010, according to comScore, a firm that tracks Internet traffic.

headline: Egyptians React to U.S. Policy
text: Protesters in Egypt insisted that President Obama could not stop their revolt.

headline: Fighting Congo’s Ills With Education and an Army of Women
text: BUKAVU, Democratic Republic of Congo  Eve Ensler has an audacious plan.

headline: A Crisis of Faith in Britain’s Central Banker
text: LONDON  A central banker need not be loved, but at the least he should command respect  and in Britain these days Mervyn King cannot count on either.

headline: Restaurant Nutrition Draws Focus of First Lady
text: WASHINGTON  After wrapping her arms around the retail giant Wal-Mart and trying to cajole food makers into producing nutrition labels that are easier to understand, Michelle Obama, the first lady and a healthy-eating advocate, has her sights set on a new target: the nation’s restaurants.

headline: Obama and U.S. Business Sheath Weapons for Now
text: For Bruce Josten, the feisty top lobbyist for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, it got personal last fall on a Sunday talk show whenPresident Obama’s spokesman invoked his name.

headline: Cold Hopes, Warm Dreams, Chilly Schemes
Al Jazeera Hopes Reports From Egypt Open Doors in U.S.
text: DOHA, Qatar  “Our bureau in Cairo has been attacked.”

headline: Economic Reports for the Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Scheduled for this week are consumer credit data for December (Monday); weekly jobless claims and wholesale trade inventories for December (Thursday); trade deficit for December and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index (Friday).

headline: Five Beloved Myths of the Mortgage Market
Just 2 Candidates, but Worries for Haiti’s Runoff

text: LONDON  As the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange fights extradition to Sweden to face allegations of sexual wrongdoing, a dozen of his former colleagues are creating an alternative Web site for leaks to be governed by what they characterize as a revised vision of radical transparency.

headline: Breach Tied to Nasdaq May Have Wider Effect

headline: Optimism About Missing Google Executive in Egypt
text: After disappearing in Egypt more than a week ago, leaving an ominous message on his Twitter account, Wael Ghonim, who leads Google’s marketing efforts for the Middle East and North Africa, is expected to be released by Egyptian authorities to his family on Monday afternoon, a friend of the Ghonim family said Sunday night.

headline: Egypt’s Ire Turns to Confidant of Mubarak’s Son

headline: F.C.C. to Propose Expanding Broadband Service to Underserved Areas
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Communications Commission on Tuesday will propose the first steps toward converting the $8 billion fund that subsidizes rural telephone service into one for helping pay to provide broadband Internet service to underserved areas, according to commission officials.

headline: Hundreds With Tickets but No Seats

headline: As Ice Thaws, Body Is Found Inside a Car in Queens

headline: Ridiculed, an N.F.L. Owner Goes to Court

headline: Planets Galore
text: Not that long ago, the possibility of finding planets outside our solar system was merely theoretical. In 1995, astronomers began to be able to detect Jupiter-sized “exoplanets” by their gravitational effect on the stars they orbit. And with the launch of the Kepler satellite in March 2009 and the release last week of the data it has so far gathered, astronomy has crossed a major threshold. The Kepler has discovered 1,235 potential planets.

headline: Droughts, Floods and Food
text: We’re in the midst of a global food crisis  the second in three years. World food prices hit a record in January, driven by huge increases in the prices of wheat, corn, sugar and oils. These soaring prices have had only a modest effect on U.S. inflation, which is still low by historical standards, but they’re having a brutal impact on the world’s poor, who spend much if not most of their income on basic foodstuffs.

headline: Regulating Big Coal’s Bad Actors
text: The Obama administration is proposing tougher mine safety regulation in the wake of the West Virginia explosion that killed 29 miners last April. The disaster highlighted hundreds of violations by the mine owner, Massey Energy, and the endemic failure of federal regulators to shut down the industry’s worst offenders.

headline: Personal Privacy and the Right to Know
text: For 45 years, the Freedom of Information of Act has invigorated American democracy by obliging the executive branch to make public a splendid range of documents. It serves the people’s right to know, while leaving out data whose disclosure could be harmful.

headline: Obama the Realist
text: On the campaign trail in 2008, Barack Obama played to two very different foreign policy constituencies. Often he presented himself as the tribune of the anti-war left  the only candidate who had opposed the invasion of Iraq from the beginning, the man who could be trusted to civilize the global war on terror, and the perfect figure to smooth the transition to a post-American world order. To more bipartisan audiences, though, he cast himself as a cold-eyed realist  the rightful heir to George H. W. Bush, if not Henry Kissinger, who would pursue America’s interests without pretending (as the younger President Bush often did) that they matched up perfectly with America’s democratic ideals.

headline: In Eastern Afghanistan, at War With the Taliban’s Shadowy Rule

The man, who gave the name Muhammad Mir, confessed, saying he wanted to gauge the security force’s reactions to a Taliban attack, according to American intelligence officials.

headline: The Apollo, Uptown’s Showbiz Incubator
text: The exhibition “Ain’t Nothing Like the Real Thing,” which opens on Tuesday at the Museum of the City of New York, really ain’t anything like the real thing, but that is not really its fault. The “real thing” in this case is almost beyond the reach of a museum show. It is to be found not in Louis Armstrong’s trumpet or Miles Davis’s flugelhorn, or James Brown’s black jumpsuit studded with rhinestones spelling “Sex,” or Ella Fitzgerald’s orange dress or Michael Jackson’s fedora (all of which are on display here), but in the music those performers made while wearing these clothes and playing these instruments.

headline: And Sae The Lord Be Thankit

headline: Happily, Bryn Mawr Wins in a Coin Toss
text: In November 2009, Hannah Smith, then a senior at the University Laboratory School in Baton Rouge, La., wrote an essay for The Choice — as well as a follow-up post in response to reader comments — in which she discussed her reasons for wanting to apply to women’s colleges. Today, she provides an update on where she ended up, and why, and describes her freshman experience thus far. — Jacques Steinberg

headline: Monday Reading: The Value of an ‘Elite’ College
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Now Booking | Glass House Tours
text: Along with the news that Punxsutawney Phil didn’t see his shadow, here’s another harbinger of spring: At 9 a.m. on Feb. 15, tickets for the 2011 tours of the Philip Johnson Glass House in New Canaan, Conn., will go on sale. To mark the program’s fifth year, the Glass House (a National Trust for Historic Preservation site) is adding several new tours to its already varied menu. (The tour season runs from May through November.) Three new two-hour, $45 tours will focus on specific aspects of the 47-acre site: the architecture; the art (Johnson and his partner, David Whitney, assembled a significant collection of postwar and contemporary painting and sculpture); and the landscape, which includes everything from historic trees to Whitney’s idiosyncratic succulent gardens.

headline: Unrest Continues in Egypt
text: Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak came under more pressure on Monday to step down as opponents said concessions offered in landmark talks were not enough to halt a revolt against his 30-year rule.

headline: The White House Waits
text: By late last year, the Middle East peace process had become a process in name only. The Obama administration’s hopes of brokering talks between Israel and the Palestinians collapsed after the Israelis dug in their heels over the Palestinian demand for a freeze in settlement construction, a demand backed by Washington. And neither side showed much enthusiasm for the indirect talks mediated by George Mitchell, the State Department envoy to the region. This was the dismal state of play when the Arab world was jolted by an eruption of “people power” in Tunisia, Egypt and elsewhere. Is it possible that these electrodes can shock some life into the inert peace process?

headline: A Plan for Peace That Still Could Be
text: The street demonstrations roiling the Arab world have riveted and moved many Americans, who have visions of democracy sweeping through northern Africa and the Middle East. As I write this, Hosni Mubarak, Egypt’s president, has announced he will not stand for re-election, as has Yemen’s longtime ruler, Ali Abdullah Saleh. Tunisia’s ruler fled, and the nation has a new government; King Abdullah of Jordan replaced his own cabinet and now has a prime minister who promises reform. There are even stirrings in Syria. President Obama has signaled his determination to support democratization in the region, as promised in his 2009 Cairo speech, and not to remain tied to authoritarian regimes.

headline: This Week’s Health Industry News
text: The Food & Drug Administration will have a busy time on Tuesday, when an advisory committee is meeting to review information about a variety of cancer drugs.

headline: Checking In With Wall Street’s Cheesehead
text: DealBook told you in September about Aaron Nagler, the biggest Green Bay Packers fan on Wall Street. In his off time, Mr. Nagler, a staff member in the public affairs department of the Blackstone Group, runs CheeseheadTV.com, the most popular fan-run Web site about the Packers.

headline: Super Bowl Morning After: Mike McCarthy in His Words
text: Did Mike McCarthy have a Rex Ryan moment?

headline: Bonhams at the Grand Palais: A Rarified Setting for Rare Metal
text: PARIS — The scene of gleaming cars and motorcycles positioned beneath a vast iron and glass vault could have come from an early 20th century engraving, if not for the near-total absence of hats worn by the ladies and gentlemen present. The setting, the Grand Palais, is a masterpiece of the machine age, an opulent temple of industrial progress built for the Universal Exposition of 1900.

headline: Art Directors Give Some Oscar Clues
text: Everyone except the Pittsburgh Steelers had an awards-riffic weekend. While fans of the black and yellow, like the Bagger, were crying into their Iron City beer, in Hollywood and New York writers, animators and art directors were celebrating. The latter group presented its prizes on Saturday, and “The King’s Speech,” “Inception” and “Black Swan” won, for period, fantasy and contemporary film, respectively.

headline: Losing Patience With the Open House
text: For six months, Emily Huters and her husband, Trey Hatch, spent five hours every Sunday morning taking turns caring for their son, Henry, so they could clean up their loft for open houses.

headline: Leading Off: The Game’s the Thing
text: The first thing N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell should have done Monday morning was announce A) there would be no lockout and B) he was doubling the Super Bowl shares of the Packers and the Steelers. And he should consider delivering the checks to all of their houses in person. Because although Goodell would never admit it (because his league is dead set on grabbing as much money away from the players as it can), those players bailed out his Super Bowl. The whole production was rapidly descending into one of the league’s most embarrassing fiascoes when they interrupted the chaos by playing a magnificent football game.

headline: Bobcats Struggle With Jackson’s Volatility

headline: Ask an Expert About A.D.H.D.
text: Doctors are becoming increasingly aware that attention problems in childhood may not be something that a child simply outgrows. While attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, or A.D.H.D., is one of the most common behavioral disorders in young people, affecting up to 7 percent of the school-age population, up to 4 to 5 percent of adults have A.D.H.D. The disorder can interfere with most domains of life, including education, work, family, relationships and health.

headline: More Animals Found in Urban Forests
text: Roland Kays, curator of mammals at the New York State Museum, writes from Albany, where he is comparing the behavior of fishers in urban and wild settings.

headline: What Would Robin Hood Say?
text: In a bid to raise much-needed government cash, the British authorities are pushing forward with a controversial plan to sell or lease much of the publicly managed woodlands and forests in England over the next decade, an area of nearly 1,000 square miles.

headline: Wayne and Garth’s Most Excellent Oscar List
text: You know we’re close to D-Day when “Saturday Night Live” does not one but two Oscar-related sketches (or it might just be, you know, low on material). This weekend’s show opened with the guest host, Dana Carvey, reprising his “Wayne’s World” character with Mike Myers, riffing on this year’s nominees. (Their best picture pick: “Winter’s -” uh – “Bone.”) And the “Weekend Update” segment included Paul Brittain’s impression of the multi-tasking James Franco, who revealed that he’s not just hosting the Oscars and a nominee. “I’m also working the coat check room and smelting all the awards in my foundry. I like having jobs!”

headline: ‘Love Never Dies’ Leads Nominations for Britain’s Olivier Awards
text: It was arguably the most anticipated new musical of the season and then, just as arguably, one of the most critically derided. It struggled with technical problems and last-minute revisions once the production was already on its feet. And now it has received the most nominations in a prestigious theater-award competition.

headline: A Hidden Treasure Struggles in Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES  The Watts Towers rose up against a clear blue sky as James Janisse unlocked the 10-foot-high gate that surrounds the soaring outdoor sculpture. “Behold the work of the man,” said Mr. Janisse, a tour guide, and his audience took it in: the Gaudiesque mashup of towers, cathedrals, fountains and ships, constructed from pipes, broken bottles, seashells and cracked ceramic, climbing 100 feet into the air.

headline: AOL Buys Huffington Post and Another Crack at a Future

headline: In Japan: Young, Numb and Violent
text: Foreign-language novelists who have success in the American market tend to have one trait in common: a veneration of American pop culture. Stieg Larsson is fond of gangster films; Umberto Eco opines about comic books, “Starsky & Hutch” and pornography; Roberto Bolaño plumps for Mark Twain, David Lynch and “Easy Rider”; and Haruki Murakami drops the Lovin’ Spoonful, Cream, Duke Ellington, Herb Alpert, Burt Bacharach, J. D. Salinger, Raymond Carver and several thousand other proper nouns.

headline: In Speech to Chamber of Commerce, Obama Urges Businesses to ‘Get in the Game’
text: President Obama urged American businesses on Monday to “get in the game” by letting loose trillions of dollars being held in reserves, saying that they can help create a “virtuous cycle” of more sales, higher demand and greater profits that will put people back to work and turn around the sluggish economy.

headline: Snubbed Fans Given Tickets to Next Super Bowl
text: Commissioner Roger Goodell said Monday morning that the N.F.L. took responsibility for the unfinished temporary seats that kept 400 ticket holders from attending Sunday’s Super Bowl and that it would give those fans tickets to next year’s game in Indianapolis.

headline: Fitness: A Walk to Remember? Study Says Yes
text: In healthy adults, the hippocampus  a part of the brain important to the formation of memories  begins to atrophy around 55 or 60. Now psychologists are suggesting that the hippocampus can be modestly expanded, and memory improved, by nothing more than regular walking.

headline: Support Grows for Tiered Risk System at Airports
text: One reason airport security measures frustrate travelers is that screening procedures tend to treat all passengers the same: as potential terrorists.

headline: Two Anti-Communists at Odds
text: Daniel Bell, who died last week at 91, is closely associated with a group of New York intellectuals who included Irving Kristol, Nathan Glazer and Daniel Patrick Moynihan. But as I write in an essay for the Feb. 13 Book Review (published early online), Bell deserves our attention as a singular — and singularly ambitious — thinker and writer, who followed in the system-building tradition of Karl Marx and Thorstein Veblen, both heroes of his. Like them, Bell could be impatient with those he judged to be on the wrong side of history or ideas, even in those post-war years remembered for their cozy political “consensus,” as is clear from Bell’s correspondence with William F. Buckley Jr. in 1955.

headline: Jane Harman to Leave Congress
text: LOS ANGELES – Representative Jane Harman, Democrat of California, is leaving Congress to become president of the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, party officials said on Monday.

headline: DNA Sheds New Light on Polynesian Migration
text: New genetic research reveals that the migratory story of the Polynesians may be more ancient and complicated than previously thought.

text: Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president, was fined $2,000 by the New York City Conflicts of Interest Board for using his chief of staff as his lawyer when he bought a home in 2009, the board announced on Monday.

text: Mahler, Mozart and Mary are the touchstone names for next season at the Los Angeles Philharmonic. The orchestra announced its 2011-12 season on Monday, the third under the baton of Gustavo Dudamel.

headline: For Some, a Recession-Proof Marriage
text: Economic setbacks like unemployment or mortgage woes are linked to big declines in marital happiness, but a minority of married Americans say the recession has deepened their commitment to their spouse, according to a new report.

text: Have you ever whispered to protect your voice before a performance or speech? As today’s “Really?” column explains, whispering appears to do more harm than good, putting extra strain on vocal cords.

headline: Sudan Leader to Accept Secession of South
text: KAMPALA, Uganda  With the announcement of final voting results, President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan said Monday that his government would accept the choice of the long-embattled region of southern Sudan to separate from the north, setting the stage for the creation of the world’s newest country this summer.

headline: Google Executive Who Was Jailed Said He Was Part of Facebook Campaign in Egypt

headline: Q. and A.: PCBs in School Classrooms
text: As I reported last week, many parents in New York City are worried about the presence of the chemicals known as PCBs in light fixtures and caulking in school buildings. The latest spot inspection by the federal Environmental Protection Agency — on Jan. 29 at Public School 68 in the Bronx –- turned up lighting ballasts that were leaking PCBs above the regulatory level of 50 parts per million in 10 of 13 samples taken, the agency announced Monday. Over the past several weeks, the E.P.A. found similar contamination at all three other city schools that it inspected, too.

headline: Coming to Terms With Your House as an Open House
text: High on the list of the inherent tensions involved in selling your home is this: On the one hand, prospective buyers need to be able to take a look around; on the other hand, it’s still your home, and you still live there, and what are all these strangers doing traipsing through? In an era when properties sit on the market longer than they used to, the rituals of the open house get particularly draining.

headline: Packers Rewrite Winning Formula
text: DALLAS  Mike McCarthy, the Green Bay Packers’ coach, spent time last week looking at the lockers of the players his team had placed on injured reserve this season. It was a curious exercise for a coach with the biggest game of his life ahead, but it was impossible to ignore the 15 stalls that had been mostly empty in Green Bay this season.

headline: ‘Big Love’ Watch: Rhonda Volmer’s Return
text: I am still applying smelling salts to counter the shock of Rhonda Volmer’s return on Sunday night’s episode of “Big Love.” Rhonda! Venal, manipulating, lying, obfuscating, scary Veda-in-“Mildred Pierce” Rhonda!

headline: Watch the Oscars Lunch Live
text: This year’s Super Bowl delivered great ratings, which is probably making the producers of the Oscars – the second-most-watched event in the U.S. after the ball game – extra antsy. This year the producers and the telecast’s network, ABC, are aiming to increase viewership among younger people, with younger, weirder hosts (James Franco and Anne Hathaway), hipper singers (Florence of Florence and the Machine) and a promotional campaign aimed at breaking down the event’s perceived fustiness. The campaign, called “You’re Invited,” opens up the red carpet and backstage experience to viewers at home via “ambitious live streaming” – a first, according to Ad Age.

headline: Mayor Tells Legislature That Lost Aid Will Ensure Layoffs
text: ALBANY — A week after he criticized Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s budget as unfair to New York City, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appeared before lawmakers on Monday and offered grim examples to prove his point.Classroom crowding would worsen, he said. More than a third of the city’s senior citizen centers would close. The scale of layoffs, in the schools and at government agencies, would be “devastating.”

headline: Outbreaks: A Tool to Track Animal Diseases May Help to Protect Humans
text: VIENNA  A new online mapping tool will enable scientists and the public to track outbreaks of animal diseases that might jump to humans.

headline: Robert Kubica, Formula One Driver, Is Recuperating After Crash
text: As reported Sunday by our colleagues at the Formula One blog, Robert Kubica, one of the most fearsome drivers on the Formula One race circuit, sustained multiple fractures on Sunday when he crashed his car in northern Italy.

headline: Drugmakers’ Fever for the Power of RNA Interference Has Cooled

headline: Prize for Phylicia Rashad
text: Phylicia Rashad will receive the lifetime achievement award at the 19th annual Pan African Film Festival, officials said on Monday. The festival, which will take place in Los Angeles Feb. 16 to 23, showcases films by and about people from the African diaspora. This year’s a lineup includes more than 120 films representing more than 30 countries.

headline: Former UBS Exec Joins Emerging Global Advisors
text: Marten S. Hoekstra, the former chief executive of UBS Wealth Management Americas and a member of UBS’s Group Executive Board, has joined Emerging Global Advisors as the asset management firm’s chief executive.

headline: The Matriarch of Modern Cancer Genetics
text: Dr. Janet Davison Rowley, 85, is the matriarch of modern cancer genetics. Without her 1970s finding that broken and translocated chromosomes were a factor in blood cancers, we might not have the treatments for leukemia that are commonplace today. We spoke earlier this winter at her University of Chicago offices and also at the Hyde Park home she shares with her husband of 62 years, Donald Rowley, a research pathologist. An edited and condensed version of the interviews follows.

headline: How to Keep Winter From Taking a Toll on Your Back
text: This is your back speaking, and now is the winter of my discontent. With all the snow and ice and cold that have descended on much of the country, there are so many ways I can get hurt. So I want you to know what you can and should do to protect me and keep yourself out of debilitating and disabling pain, now and in the future.

headline: Los Angeles Museum  and Getty Trust Jointly Acquire Collection of Mapplethorpe Works and Letters
text: The Los Angeles County Museum of Art and the J. Paul Getty Trust said on Monday they had jointly acquired a huge collection of the prints, negatives and letters of Robert Mapplethorpe, further strengthening California’s position as a major center for 20th-century photography.

headline: Ensuring Domestic Tranquillity During Sleepovers
text: In every iteration of the interminable discussion of the new book “Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother,” someone inevitably brings up the crucial issue of the sleepover  the childhood ritual in which the author, Amy Chua, wouldn’t let her daughters take part.

headline: Real vs. Virtual: Examining Works of Art Online
text: Overview | How do the experiences of looking at works of fine art in real life, in photo reproductions and in digital forms compare? What can be revealed by perusing an online trove of paintings and other works? In this lesson, students engage in one or more activities using Google’s Art Project to reflect on key issues and questions about art.

headline: Barea Offers Glimpse Into Mavericks’ Future
text: When the calendar rolled over into 2011, the Dallas Mavericks were born anew. As of New Year’s Eve, the Mavericks were contenders; the acquisition of Tyson Chandler was paying considerable dividends, Dirk Nowitzki was in the midst of possibly his most efficient season to date, and a talented supporting cast had elevated the Mavs’ defense while keeping the offense afloat.

headline: An Addict Crosses a Line, and Is Pulled Back
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Gregory Reeve could hardly have picked a more Canadian way to become a heroin addict: a hockey puck in a game with friends shattered his jaw.

headline: Tribesmen in Jordan Issue Urgent Call for Political Reform
text: JERUSALEM  Several dozen Jordanian tribesmen, historically core loyalists to the monarchy, have issued a rare statement calling for urgent and far-reaching political reform in Jordan. They said that without it, the country was headed down the path taken by Tunisia and Egypt.

headline: Washington Invests in Making Wind Pay

headline: Egypt, Inkblots, Agendas and Feeding 9 Billion

headline: Michael Moore Sues Weinsteins Over ‘Fahrenheit 9/11’
text: “Fahrenheit 9/11,” Michael Moore’s 2004 documentary about President George W. Bush, is still generating heat. Mr. Moore on Monday filed suit against Bob and Harvey Weinstein, who formed Fellowship Adventure Group to distribute “Fahrenheit 9/11” in an alliance with Lionsgate and IFC Films, claiming that the Weinsteins defrauded him of at least $2.7 million in profits from the film. The suit, filed in Los Angeles County Superior Court, charged the Weinsteins with “accounting tricks and financial deception” in connection with “Fahenheit 9/11,” which took in about $222 million at the worldwide box office, and millions more on home video. Bert Fields, a lawyer for the Weinsteins, said Mr. Moore had been paid everything he was due, and was trying to make a public spectacle out of what he called “a routine kind of auditing” dispute. “Mr. Moore has put in a number of very inflammatory claims designed for the press,” Mr. Fields added. “He should be ashamed of himself.” Larry Stein, a lawyer for Mr. Moore, said in a statement that Mr. Moore had never sued anyone in his filmmaking career and that “it’s very sad that it had to come to this.”Mr. Moore and the Weinsteins have worked together on several films, including “Sicko” and “The Big One.”

headline: Buffalo Billionaire Lifts Soccer in English Town
text: BEDLINGTON, England  The phone first rang a year ago in January. The caller identified himself as Bob Rich, a billionaire American businessman and sports team owner. He had English royals among his ancestors. For Christmas, his wife had bought him the title Lord of Bedlington. And he wanted to do something, well, lordly.

headline: Why All the Noise About Muni Bankruptcies?

text: Walk into my apartment and you’d most likely be hard-pressed to find a book or dish towel out of place. headline: Armstrong and Huffington on the AOL-Huffington Post Deal
text: AOL‘s chief executive, Tim Armstrong, and The Huffington Post‘s founder, Arianna Huffington, discuss on CNBC how the purchase of the news site fits into AOL’s strategy. Mr. Armstrong likens AOL to Disney, where many brands exist under one umbrella, and explains how the deal positions the portal well for the strong digital advertising growth he expects. Ms. Huffington expresses her confidence in managing the array of AOL brands while ensuring high-quality content is produced.

headline: Russia Expels a British Journalist

headline: Super Bowl Ratings Cap Record Year for N.F.L.

headline: Stress of Sliding Plates Builds Near Chile
text: When a magnitude-8.8 earthquake struck off the coast of Chile last February, geophysicists and seismologists were not surprised. The quake’s epicenter was on a roughly 200-mile stretch of a fault where stresses had been building for nearly two centuries, and experts had expected that one day the strain would be relieved in a cataclysmic event.

headline: ‘My World’ and Welcome to It
text: Scooter Braun, the stubble-cheeked 29-year-old who serves officially as Justin Bieber’s manager and sometimes unofficially as the baby sitter of his legions of young admirers, was having trouble getting them to behave on Wednesday night.

headline: Just One Look | Missoni Pre-Fall Collection

headline: Quips From an Oscar Luncheon
text: Did you watch? The Academy nominees’ luncheon may still be live-streaming nearby, but we decided to take a break to update you on the proceedings. Once upon a time, the Bagger worked in politics, and the luncheon reminded us of the many, many glad-handing events where, before anything actually happened – if anything actually did – there was first a laundry list of acknowledgments for all the officials, bigwigs and F.O.B.s in the room. With 151 nominees present – the largest nominee luncheon ever – this was a laundry list of institutional proportions.

headline: Amid Egypt Turmoil, More Clashes in Sinai
text: JERUSALEM  Attacks in recent days suggest that provocateurs are trying to take advantage of the political turmoil in Cairo to spread unrest in Sinai, the desert peninsula that lies between Israel and the main territory of Egypt and near Saudi Arabia and Jordan.

headline: Big Lots Shares Surge on Sale Talk
text: Shares of Big Lots, a discount retailer, surged more than 15 percent in late afternoon trading after Bloomberg News reported that the company was exploring its options, including a sale.

headline: Lawmakers’ End of Earmarks Affects Local Programs Large and Small
text: WASHINGTON  Gone for now are the likes of the taxpayer-financed teapot museum, or studies on the mating habits of crabs.

headline: On Evolution, Biology Teachers Stray From Lesson Plan
text: Teaching creationism in public schools has consistently been ruled unconstitutional in federal courts, but according to a national survey of more than 900 public high school biology teachers, it continues to flourish in the nation’s classrooms.

headline: Bit by Bit, Business Is Improving
text: Manufacturing companies around the world agree: Business is getting better.

headline: Hearts on Sleeves! | How the Fashion Flock Says, ‘Be Mine’
text: The fashion flock is putting the amour in glamour this Valentine’s Day. With that in mind, T caught up with the supremely adored, singles and pairs alike, to find out what they have planned for the Hallmark holiday.

headline: Time Runs Out for Snowbound Cars
text: “Move your car, people!” yelled a Sanitation Department worker as he marched down East 64th Street west of Lexington Avenue on Monday morning. “Today, sir!” he shouted at Jesus Moreno, a 51-year-old chauffeur who was waiting out the no-parking period in his client’s BMW S.U.V.

headline: New High Note for ‘Glee’
text: A football- and zombie-theme episode of “Glee,” featuring a guest appearance by Katie Couric and a musical mash-up of Michael Jackson’s “Thriller” and the Yeah Yeah Yeahs’ “Heads Will Roll,” received a big boost in the ratings on Sunday from its time slot following the Super Bowl. According to Nielsen’s estimates, Fox’s “Glee” attracted 26.8 million viewers, a record for this hit musical comedy and more than any other scripted series on television in three years. In comparison, however, ratings for the episode fell short of those for last year’s occupant of that highly desirable time slot, CBS’s reality show “Undercover Boss,” which garnered 38.7 million viewers. Final audience figures for “Glee” and Fox’s Super Bowl coverage were not immediately available on Monday; however, Nielsen’s preliminary overnight estimates from the major media markets were up about 3 percent from a year ago, when CBS’s Super Bowl broadcast set a ratings record with 106.5 million viewers, the largest television audience in United States history. Opposite the ratings juggernaut on Fox, CBS fared the best with 3.9 million viewers for a rerun edition of “60 Minutes” at 7, followed by reruns the rest of the night. ABC was third, averaging 2.7 million viewers for the 2007 movie “Knocked Up,” while NBC finished fourth.

headline: Swimming Against a Demographic Tide in Macao
text: The Macanese, whose roots are found in many places of the former Portuguese empire, retain their own culture and their own language, Patuá.

headline: Family Dramas of the Rich and Famous
text: One of the reasons we are transfixed by celebrities is because they represent our lives writ large. What is gossip, after all, if not a moderator of social norms. The chatter about other people’s conflicts and choices helps us map our own.

headline: Big Banks to Pay More to Insure Deposits
text: Big financial institutions will pick up a greater portion of the cost to protect deposits when banks fail, under a plan adopted Monday by federal regulators.

headline: For Obama, Political Risks in Projecting Powerlessness

text: Sleepovers and slumber parties are now an intrinsic part of childhood, but a night away from home can create problems for both children and parents, writes Dr. Perri Klass, a pediatrician, in the “18 and Under” column.

headline: Fire in Rio Damages Carnaval Preparations and Dims Hopes of Many Performers
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil  An early-morning fire in a warehouse district on Monday destroyed the costumes and dimmed the hopes of at least three prominent samba schools competing in Rio de Janeiro’s annual Carnaval parade. But city officials vowed that the event would go forward.

headline: Navigating Bromances and Romances
text: The first question likely to arise over “Traffic Light,” a comedy beginning on Tuesday on Fox, is: What’s up with the name? It suggests transit police, speeding tickets, fender benders, turf wars — a heretofore untapped world of municipal action, much in the vein of “Parks and Recreation.”

text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  They came, they smiled, they poured on practiced you-deserve-it-not-me humility. Behind it all? Daggers and crossed fingers that half the room will go kersplat in the immediate future.

headline: A Long Run Before a Much, Much Longer Trek
text: Around dawn late last month, Pat Farmer joined a smattering of New Yorkers braving the snow, the slush and the cold to get in a jog through Central Park.

text: The Op-Ed columnist on American foreign policy and the new reality in Egypt.

headline: Science and Religion on a Collision Course at Galileo’s Trial
text: Over the centuries, Galileo’s trial in 1633 for defending heliocentrism  that Earth orbits the Sun, not the other way around  the Inquisition’s finding that he was “vehemently suspect of heresy” and his recantation have grown far beyond just a seminal clash between science and religion. The Galileo affair has become general shorthand for speaking truth to power, a cautionary tale to invoke whenever new ideas challenge the established order.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Egypt, Tunisia, Mexico and Bangladesh.

headline: Tibetan Lama Faces Scrutiny and Suspicion in India
text: DHARAMSALA, India  His daring escape from Tibet seemed out of a movie. Then only 14, Ogyen Trinley Dorje was one of Tibetan Buddhism’s most revered incarnate lamas, and his journey through the icy passes of the Himalayas was viewed as a major embarrassment for China. The youth arrived in India in early 2000 to a euphoric greeting from Tibetan exiles.

headline: A Noticeable Absence at Oscars Luncheon
text: Beyond the quips at this year’s installment of the Oscar nominees’ luncheon, one of the highlights was expected to be the Scott Rudin/Harvey Weinstein show. These rivals, who have tangled in the past over cinematic awards bait, are both racing hard for best picture this season — Mr. Rudin with “The Social Network” and “True Grit,” and Mr. Weinstein with “The King’s Speech.” But as our colleague Brooks Barnes reports from the lunch at the Beverly Hilton, Mr. Weinstein got to work the room alone. Mr. Rudin was said to be home sick with pneumonia.

headline: Democratic Leadership Council Suspends Its Operations
text: The Democratic Leadership Council, which for more than two decades preached a centrist brand of politics embodied by President Bill Clinton, is suspending its dwindling operations, the organization’s founder said in a statement e-mailed to The Caucus late Monday.

headline: Harbinger to Sell Remaining Inmarsat Stake
text: Harbinger Capital Partners, the hedge fund controlled by Philip A Falcone, will sell its remaining 14 percent stake in satellite operator Inmarsat, according to regulatory filings.

headline: With a Voice and a Spirit, Triumphing Over Racism
text: Barbara Smith Conrad, a black child of the segregated South, did not seek to vote or to ride in the front of the bus. She just wanted to sing.

headline: Eyebrows Raised Over Envoy to Cairo
text: The White House on Monday faced criticism over its decision to send Frank Wisner, a retired ambassador and diplomat, to Cairo last week. At the same time, his seeming support for President Hosni Mubarak put Mr. Wisner’s employer, a powerhouse lobbying firm, on the defensive about its business dealings in Egypt.

headline: World’s Top Chess Players on Hand for Aeroflot Open
text: The Tradewise Gibraltar Chess Festival, which ended last week, is a popular tournament, attracting many strong players. And the World Open, which is held every year in the Philadelphia area around Independence Day, usually has more than 1,000 players between all its sections.

headline: Men’s Fall Fashion 2011 | Ralph Lauren
text: Continuing our illustrative coverage of men’s fall 2011 fashion, Richard Haines will be traveling alongside me during the New York shows to bring you our favorite looks in vivid color. We lead off with Ralph Lauren, who presented his new collection last week. I was struck by the elegance and purity of the relatively new Black Label Sportswear line. This refined olive cashmere jacket with a hunting patch at the shoulder and bellows pockets was a great distillation of the military mood we’ve been seeing. Paired with gray flannel trousers and brown Chelsea boots, it is the perfect country-weekend-in-the-city look.

headline: Time to Tighten Loose Money
text: The stagflationists are losing the argument. The world is inflating and that’s a worry. But inflation is coming from growth that seems increasingly strong and from money that’s looking far too loose for a reviving world. The risk is that oil and other commodities will soar much higher now, as they did in 2008, only this time the spike may not recede quickly.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,457 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the death of the following American:

headline: A Pregame Interview Prediction Falls Short
text: The Super Bowl set an audience record for the Fox network, but the Fox News Channel’s biggest star couldn’t quite match his own expectations for his pregame interview with President Obama.

headline: A Bedroom Voice to Match His Eyes
text: What a difference a few months can make. The return engagement of Paulo Szot, the smoldering Polish-Brazilian baritone, to the Café Carlyle, singing largely the same program he performed there in his nightclub debut last fall, is an encouraging example of an opera singer belatedly finding his pop mojo. That’s not to say that Mr. Szot, in treading the treacherous crossover path that has stymied many other singers before him (most notably, José Carreras), has turned into Barry Manilow or even Josh Groban.

headline: Top Recruit Impressed by Clemson’s Class
text: Although national signing day was last Wednesday, there is still plenty of intrigue surrounding the nation’s top recruit, Jadeveon Clowney, who has put off announcing his decision until Feb. 14.

headline: Distinct Mix Holds On in a Corner of China
text: MACAO — Long before words like “multiculturalism” and “fusion cuisine” entered the modern lexicon, Aida de Jesus and her forebears were mashing up food, language and DNA from far-flung corners of the globe.

headline: Obama Presses Business Leaders to Hire and Invest
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama urged American businesses on Monday to “get in the game” by letting loose trillions of dollars that they are holding in reserve, saying that they can help create a “virtuous cycle” of more sales, higher demand and greater profits that will put people back to work.

headline: Kindle Books Get Page Numbers and Social Features
text: Kindle e-books are about to become more social. They will also be getting a small change that will make many Kindle owners rejoice: page numbers.

headline: Iran’s Opposition Seeks Rally to Back Egypt and Tunisia
text: TEHRAN  With democracy tremors rocking the Arab world, Iran’s opposition has challenged its hard-line leaders to allow a peaceful demonstration  ostensibly in support of the uprisings in Tunisia and Egypt.

headline: Texas: Inquiry Sought Into Youth’s Beating
text: Representative Al Green, a Houston Democrat, on Monday asked the Justice Department to begin a civil rights investigation after a videotape surfaced that shows Houston police officers beating and kicking a 15-year-old burglary suspect last March as he lay on the ground. Four officers are awaiting trial on misdemeanor charges of official repression in the case, but prosecutors had blocked release of the tape, arguing that it would taint a trial. An ABC television affiliate, KTRK, obtained a copy and broadcast it on Wednesday, reigniting anger over the arrest. On the video, the teenager appears to be clipped by a police car during a chase. He falls, flips onto his stomach and puts his hands behind his head. Several officers rush in, punching and kicking him as they arrest him. “We are outraged at what occurred,” Mr. Green said. The teenager, Chad Holley, was later sentenced to probation for burglary.

headline: Planned Parenthood to Retrain Public Staff
text: Reacting to the release of videotapes in which its staff members advise an apparent sex trafficker, Planned Parenthood said Monday that it would retrain thousands of staff members across the country on its rules for reporting possible dangers to minors, and would automatically fire anyone who violated them.

headline: A Safe Place
text: In Vancouver, a controversial strategy against H.I.V. and AIDS includes a site where drug users can inject themselves using clean needles -- then get tested and treated if they have the virus.

headline: A Tampa Bay Redesign
text: Ed O'Hara, C.E.O. of SME Branding, walks through the process of redesigning the logo for the Tampa Bay Lightning.

headline: Company Settles Case in Firing Tied to Facebook
