headline: A Bad Document’s Good Idea
text: The Southerners who gathered in Montgomery, Ala., a century and a half ago saw themselves as the true inheritors of the original Founding Fathers. Indeed, the Constitution they approved — its sesquicentennial is today — was more imitation than innovation. “We the people of the Confederate states,” said their preamble, “establish justice, insure domestic tranquility, and secure the blessings of liberty to ourselves and our posterity.”

headline: No Guarantees in Life, Not Even a Booked Room

headline: Ex-Dow Scientist Is Convicted of Selling Secrets in China
text: A jury in Baton Rouge, La., on Monday found a former Dow Chemical scientist guilty of conspiring to steal company secrets and sell them to firms in China, the Justice Department said.

headline: Chicago Conductor Undergoes Successful Facial Surgery
text: A surgeon on Monday successfully repaired broken bones in the face of Riccardo Muti, the music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, who was injured after fainting on the podium during a rehearsal last week, officials said.

headline: With One Plan for a Hudson Tunnel Dead, Senators Offer Another Option
text: New Jersey’s two Democratic senators, Frank R. Lautenberg and Robert Menendez, have been trying to revive the idea of a trans-Hudson train tunnel ever since Gov. Chris Christie upset them by halting construction on the one that New Jersey Transit started to build last year.

headline: What Is Academic Work?
text: In previous columns I have argued that academic work is distinctive — something and not everything — and that a part of its distinctiveness is its distance from political agendas. This does not mean that political agendas can’t be the subject of academic work — one should inquire into their structure, history, etc. — but that the point of introducing them into the classroom should never be to urge them or to warn against them. I have never felt that my attempts to explain this point have been entirely successful, but I am moved to try again by the recent experience of a conference that, I believe, exemplifies the point in action.

headline: An H.I.V. Strategy Invites Addicts In
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — At 12 tables, in front of 12 mirrors, a dozen people are fussing intently in raptures of self-absorption, like chorus line members applying makeup in a dressing room.

headline: In Egypt, U.S. Weighs Push for Change With Stability
text: WASHINGTON — Vice President Omar Suleiman of Egypt says he does not think it is time to lift the 30-year-old emergency law that has been used to suppress and imprison opposition leaders. He does not think President Hosni Mubarak needs to resign before his term ends in September. And he does not think his country is yet ready for democracy.

headline: Wall St. Joins S.E.C. in Plea for Bigger Budget

headline: Down and Out on Rodeo Drive

headline: As Hoboken’s Riverfront Crumbles, the Cost for Repairs Soars
text: In Hoboken’s evolution from blue-collar port to upscale pocket of bistros and condominiums, the waterfront underwent the most profound transformation. Factories and docks gave way to promenades and parks with drop-dead views of Manhattan, drawing crowds that fed the nearby hotels and shops along the much-promoted Gold Coast.

headline: U.S. Plan to Replace Principals Hits Snag: Who Will Step In?
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio  The aggressive $4 billion program begun by the Obama administration in 2009 to radically transform the country’s worst schools included, as its centerpiece, a plan to install new principals to overhaul most of the failing schools.

headline: Copper Prices and Incidences of Copper Theft Rise
text: Thieves broke into a muffler shop in Chillicothe, Ohio, and stole cash  and 130 catalytic converters. Pervasive thefts of copper wire from under the streets of Fresno, Calif., have prompted the city to seal thousands of its manhole covers with concrete. And in Picher, Okla., someone felled the town’s utility poles with chain saws, allowing thieves to abscond with 3,000 feet of wire while causing a blackout.

headline: Muslims to Be Congressional Hearings’ Main Focus
text: WASHINGTON  The new chairman of the House Homeland Security Committee said Monday that he planned to call mostly Muslim and Arab witnesses to testify in hearings next month on the threat of homegrown Islamic terrorism.

headline: Among Nation’s Youngest, Analysis Finds Fewer Whites
text: WASHINGTON  Whites continued to decline as a share of the American population in 2009, and they now represent less than half of all 3-year-olds, according to a Brookings Institution analysis of census data released Monday.

headline: J. Paul Getty III, 54, Dies; Had Ear Cut Off by Captors
text: J. Paul Getty III, who was a grandson of the oil baron once believed to be the richest man in the world and who achieved tragic notoriety in 1973 when he was kidnapped by Italian gangsters, died Saturday at his home near London. He was 54.

headline: Huffington Deal Raises Question: What Site Will Be Sold Next?

headline: For Mets’ Owners, Court Fight Could Be Costly

headline: Ken Olsen, Who Built DEC Into a Power, Dies at 84

headline: Mothers-to-Be Are Getting the Message
text: We’re used to hearing about public initiatives that get mired in politics or entangled in bureaucracy, but we rarely hear about programs that exceed expectations. So here’s one: last week marked the one-year anniversary of a program called text4baby, a service that sends free text messages to women who are pregnant or whose babies are less than a year old, providing them with information, and reminders, to improve their health and the health of their babies.

headline: Big Personality and Behind-the-Scenes Executive Prove a Top Media Team
text: The Huffington Post broke into public consciousness based on its namesake and Arianna Huffington’s A-list Rolodex, but it never would have merited a $315 million payday if those gilded elements had not been married to sophisticated technology and careful brand management.

headline: League Rescinds Technical Foul From Stoudemire
text: The N.B.A. rescinded the technical foul that Amar’e Stoudemire received against the Philadelphia 76ers on Sunday, reducing his total for the season to 13. Stoudemire is still close to the threshold of 16 technicals, at which a player receives a one-game suspension. On Sunday, Stoudemire poked the ball away from Philadelphia’s Spencer Hawes and was called for a foul. He reacted by racing up the court, and the official Bob Delaney called him for the technical under the N.B.A.’s new policy to curtail player complaining.

headline: Spring Is Hardly Just Around the Corner, but Baseball Is
text: Around much of this winter-battered country, grass is only a rumor. Winter is but halfway over, and already enough snow has fallen in Boston to blanket its star second baseman, Dustin Pedroia, who stands 69 inches tall. Undoubtedly, another storm — or three — are coming.

headline: Most New York Students Are Not College-Ready
text: New York State education officials released a new set of graduation statistics on Monday that show fewer than half of students in the state are leaving high school prepared for college and well-paying careers.

headline: A Seer on Banks Raises a Furor on Bonds
text: If one stock-picker emerged intact from the wreckage of the financial crisis, it was Meredith Whitney. With a prescient warning about bank stocks in 2007  as well as a gift for the perfect sound bite  she became a media darling, celebrated in a Fortune cover article and in frequent television appearances as a market seer.

headline: Third Trial for Suspect in ’96 Killings Is Under Way

headline: At Citi Field, Stains Are Not From the Grass
text: Citi Field, home of the New York Mets, is a pleasant stadium  handsome, easily reached by public transportation, child-friendly and packed with diverting food choices in those all-too-frequent moments when the team itself loses its entertainment value. In fact, one of the few things that feel wrong with Citi Field is its name.

headline: A Terrible Divide
text: The Ronald Reagan crowd loved to talk about morning in America. For millions of individuals and families, perhaps the majority, it’s more like twilight  with nighttime coming on fast.

headline: Former Philippine Defense Secretary Is Dead
text: MANILA — A former defense secretary and military chief of the Philippines who was implicated in a major corruption scandal in the armed forces died Tuesday morning in an apparent suicide, officials said.

headline: Parrying the Big Cuts
text: After months in a defensive crouch, Democrats are arising to challenge the severe budget cuts planned by House Republicans, which would almost certainly make unemployment worse. And it is not a moment too soon because when the stopgap resolution that is financing the government expires on March 4, the House will have significant leverage to get its way. Without a new spending bill, the government will shut down — a prospect that seems to delight many newly elected Republicans.

headline: No One Size Fits All
text: For much of the euro crisis, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany has acted as though it were someone else’s problem. As Europe’s biggest economy, biggest creditor and biggest contributor to the European Union budget, Germany must play a central role in any euro-zone solution.

headline: Expensive Prisons
text: In the last decade, crime rates and the prison population have declined significantly in New York State. Yet prison costs have soared. As part of Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s search for ways to cut spending, his new budget proposes two sensible steps toward the long overdue goal of closing down unnecessary prisons.

headline: Equal Rights Ascending

headline: Rangers Fire 47 Shots at Red Wings Goalie, but Not Enough Past Him
text: DETROIT  Coach John Tortorella has tried just about everything to get the Rangers’ anemic power play on track. But it might have been the one thing he did not try Monday night that helped cost his team its fifth straight defeat, a 3-2 loss to the Red Wings.

headline: Top Recruit’s Delay To Sign May Aid Clemson
text: When Jadeveon Clowney, a defensive end from Rock Hill, S.C., who is widely considered the nation’s top recruit, put off his decision on a college until Feb. 14, it may have helped Clemson’s chances. Clowney said he had narrowed his choices to Alabama, Clemson and South Carolina. “Clemson had a good recruiting class,” Clowney said. “If I go, they would have an even better one.”

headline: Is Citi Field in Need of a Name Change?
text: Clyde Haberman wonders what is to be done about one of the few things that continues to feel wrong about the Mets home, Citi Field. After all, for an ownership group dealing with its own financial stain, that name above the ballpark entrance hardly helps the situation. Read the article here and click on this post to comment.

headline: Canceled NASA Rocket Could Return as Part of Low-Cost Space Taxi
text: Take a canceled, over-budget NASA rocket, stack a workhorse European satellite launcher on top of it, and the result could be a powerful, low-cost alternative for taking people to space.

headline: Anthony Dream Deal May Yet Be a Reality

headline: Cavaliers Lose a Record 25th Game in a Row

headline: Johannes Somary, Conductor of Neglected Works, Dies at 75

headline: The Dirty Little Secret of Successful Companies

headline: Zero Overhauls Its All-Electric Motorcycle Product Line

headline: Aaron Rodgers’s Very Long Draft Day
text: In this video clip, ESPN’s Chris Berman, Chris Mortensen and Mel Kiper Jr. try to buck up Aaron Rodgers on draft day in 2005. At that point, Rodgers had already been handed the role of “guy stuck in the green room.” He was dropping on the draft board and being treated as if he had a contagious disease. The draft had only reached the 15th pick. Rodgers had nine more slots to fall, and many more minutes to squirm.

headline: Gradual Trends and Extreme Events
text: I’ve spent a lot of the last several days reading about climate change, extreme weather events, food prices, and so on. And one thing that became clear to me is that there’s widespread misunderstanding of the relationship between the gradual trend of rising temperatures and the extreme weather events that have become so much more common. What I’m about to say may seem obvious, because it is obvious, at least if you approach it the right way; but I still think it needs saying.

headline: A Lawsuit to Welcome Harvey Weinstein Back
text: He was a high-flying, sometimes-vilified character and he was hanging by a thread – no, we don’t mean Spider-Man. We mean, of course, Harvey Weinstein, the other entertainment behemoth we love to puncture, and caricature. With a dozen Oscar nominations for “The King’s Speech” and a few others scattered elsewhere, Mr. Weinstein is officially back, a turn of events proclaimed by our own David Carr, and solidified twice over, by a lengthy new profile in Vanity Fair, and by a lawsuit. As our colleague Michael Cieply reports, Michael Moore filed suit in Los Angeles against the Weinstein brothers, Harvey and Bob, over profits from “Fahrenheit 9/11,” alleging “accounting tricks and financial deception” that defrauded him of at least $2.7 million in profits from his blockbuster 2004 documentary (or docbuster, as his acolyte Morgan Spurlock calls them).

headline: Schools Facing Cuts if Lunches Aren’t Paid For

headline: Buoyed by Strong Earnings, Asahi in the Hunt for Deals

headline: Robert Sean Leonard Joining ‘Born Yesterday’ on Broadway
text: The doctor is out, temporarily, and headed back to Broadway: Robert Sean Leonard, who plays the infinitely patient oncologist Dr. James Wilson on the hit Fox medical drama “House,” will return to the stage in the coming revival of “Born Yesterday,” its press representatives said on Tuesday. Mr. Leonard is set to join the production as Paul Verrall, the journalist tasked with educating Billie Dawn, the showgirl and gal pal of the crooked mogul Harry Brock. This latest revival of the Garson Kanin play, which is to begin previews at the Cort Theater on March 31 and open on April 24, previously announced that it would  star Jim Belushi (of “According to Jim”) as Brock and Nina Arianda (“Venus in Fur”) as Dawn, and would be directed by Doug Hughes (“Doubt”). The original 1946 Broadway production starred Paul Douglas, Judy Holliday and Gary Merrill, and the 1950 film version starred Broderick Crawford, Ms. Holliday and William Holden.

headline: Doughnut Plant Is Set to Open in Chelsea Hotel

headline: Does a Drilling Boom Beckon?
text: The announcement this week by the offshore drilling giant Ensco that it will buy Pride International for $7.3 billion is only the latest sign that oil companies see a bright future for offshore drilling, despite the BP well blowout in the Gulf of Mexico last year. That accident left 11 dead, poured millions of barrels of crude into the sea and put the country’s deepwater drilling on hold.

headline: Don’t Stop Believin’ (or Tourin’): ‘Glee’ Cast Hitting the Road Again
text: Based on recent episodes of  “Glee” and the ever-changing loyalties of its characters (not to mention their ever-intertwining love lives), we have absolutely no idea where this hit Fox musical-comedy is headed in the weeks to come. But we know where the cast members will be in May and June: they’ll be hitting the road for another tour of North American arenas and performance spaces. On Tuesday Fox said that a 16-city “Glee Live! in Concert” series will begin on May 21 at the Mandalay Bay Events Center in Las Vegas and conclude on June 18 at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, N.Y. (Another performance in the New York area will be on June 16 at the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J.; interestingly, no performance has been scheduled on June 12, the date that the Tony Awards are presented.) A statement from Fox said that the show, conceived by the “Glee” co-creator Ryan Murphy, will feature songs performed on the series, including “Empire State of Mind,” “Toxic,” “It’s My Life” and – deal with it – “Don’t Stop Believin’.”

headline: Broad Majority of Americans Sympathetic to Egyptian Protesters

headline: A Conversation With Tobias Moskowitz

headline: Disobeying Sorkin’s Musical Orders
text: The elements behind the success of “The Social Network,” as its makers rarely tire of telling us, were an odd mix. There were no stars, save for a pop singer; a subject that was an Internet punch line even before the Internet heard its actual punch lines; directed by a visual mastermind, David Fincher, and based on the pulsing dialogue of Aaron Sorkin – both of them big personalities with opposing styles. Mr. Fincher has been nominated for an Oscar and Mr. Sorkin has already been rewarded; he just won the Writers Guild of America award for best adapted screenplay and is likely to pick up the Oscar in that category as well. At the Writers Guild ceremony in Los Angeles, he made sure to spread the credit to his collaborator. “I wrote a good screenplay,” he said, “but David Fincher made a great movie.”

headline: Mayor Testified in Case Against Campaign Aide
text: Prosecutors on Tuesday revealed that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had given secret grand jury testimony in the case against John F. Haggerty Jr., a campaign aide who is accused of stealing $1.1 million from the mayor.

headline: Fight the Fed
text: If the Fed is buying, perhaps you should sell.

headline: An Insider Trading Defendant’s ‘Tool of the Trade’
text: How are Tuesday’s insider trading charges against four hedge fund employees different from all the other cases?

headline: Drivers on Call
text: Dottie Macdonald, 81, got to the annual crafts fair in Portland, Me., this winter the same way she always does: with six big bins of dolls and quilts and artwork stacked in the back of a 2002 Dodge Caravan, the one her husband, Bob, 86, always drives because Mrs. Macdonald never learned how.

headline: Iranian Dissident Says Planned March Will Test Regime
text: Mehdi Karroubi, an Iranian opposition leader, said Tuesday that a demonstration planned in Tehran next week, nominally in solidarity with the protest movements in Egypt and Tunisia, was a test both for the Iranian government and its opponents.

headline: Secrets of the White House Press Secretaries
text: What happens when you get four former White House press secretaries spanning two decades of political history into a room?

headline: Prosecutors to Recommend Trial for Berlusconi
text: ROME  Prosecutors in Milan said Tuesday that they would seek to try Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi on criminal charges related to prostitution and abuse of office  but in Italy’s unique political climate, the scandal so far has not forced him from office.

headline: The Winklevi Step Up Their Facebook Offensive
text: It’s always a good day for the Bagger when there is Winkelvi news. Happily, Cameron and Tyler Winklevoss, the 6’5” Olympic rowers and Harvard grads (if you listen to everybody) and actual founders of Facebook (if you listen to them), are pretty comfortable in the spotlight. They are featured in a video interview in The Daily, the new iPad publication from Rupert Murdoch (with a logo that’s startlingly Facebook blue), in which they again assert their claims to the social networking site, and to looking extremely fit. Their real problem, they maintain, is that Mark Zuckerberg — a real founder of Facebook, according to most courts and viewers of “The Social Network” – believes that the situation is “all about him.”

headline: Roy’s Speedy Return Raises Questions
text: Now is this time for basketball fans — and those patriots of the sovereign Blazer Nation — to hope that Brandon Roy and the oft-criticized Portland Trailblazers’ medical staff know what they’re doing.

headline: 1,676 Geese Died for Human Air Travel Last Year
text: Updated Wednesday, 10:35 a.m. | One question that remained from last summer’s Prospect Park goose slaughter was just how many geese the United States Department of Agriculture rounded up and gassed in an effort to improve air safety.

headline: Uncertain Coda for Mansion With a Musical Heritage
text: Up the hill, past where the garbage trucks go when they need a little work, the for-sale signs are on the wrought-iron fence. The mansion  yes, on a forlorn block like this is a mansion, an Italianate villa from when this stretch of Astoria, Queens, was weekend-getaway country  is on the market.

headline: Revolt! Comparing Historical Revolutions
text: Overview | What is a revolution, and how is it different from other kinds of revolts and conflicts? How do the protests in Egypt compare with historical revolutions? In this lesson, students work together to define revolution and engage in research to help them create infographics that represent various historical revolutions around the world.

headline: The Beginning of a Drilling Boom
text: The news on Monday that the offshore drilling giant Ensco will buy a rival, Pride International, for $7.3 billion is only the latest sign of a bright future for offshore drilling.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Tootsie’
text: In this week’s Critics’ Picks, A. O. Scott looks back at Sydney Pollack‘s 1982 comedy “Tootsie,” about an actor (Dustin Hoffman) who dresses as a woman to land an audition and creates myriad problems. While the film deals with feminist themes and plays for laughs, “Tootsie,” Mr. Scott says, “is neither a sermon or a farce.” Instead, he says the film is about “discovering who you really are by pretending to be someone else.” Have you seen “Tootsie”? Please share your thoughts.

headline: F.D.A. Offers Device Proposals
text: The Food and Drug Administration, responding to criticism that it is hindering innovation, proposed a new system on Tuesday that would speed the approvals of pioneering medical devices.

headline: What’s New in California? Don’t Ask Robert Parker
text: And so came the announcement over the weekend that Robert M. Parker Jr. was shuffling the lineup of reviewers at The Wine Advocate, the wine review he founded in 1978.

headline: Mexico Hesitates to Intervene as Rising Peso Pressures Its Exports
text: MEXICO CITY  Six years ago, Benjamín Hernández turned his family’s small metal-stamping company into an exporter. Although the firm barely survived the global economic crisis, it bounced back last year. But now he has a new worry.

headline: Samurai Shopper | Floral and Hardy
text: For St. Valentine, there were no hearts and flowers. Whichever of his ancient legends you buy, they all end with the devout man getting brutally beaten and beheaded on February 14 in a three-digit year. Not to bum you out or anything, but the Samurai Shopper believes there’s a lesson here: whatever lives, dies. Of course, no one deserves St. Valentine’s fate. Death by chocolate would be far nicer: some passion-fruit filled morsels, from Kee on Thompson Street, say? And wouldn’t it be nice if we could preview the peonies, dahlias, zinnias et al. that people send for our funerals, assuming anyone loves us enough.

headline: Buzz Tracker
text: The $100 Million Woman How much is Arianna Huffington getting from the deal with AOL? A Wall Street analyst, Laura Martin, estimates a cool $100 million. The Washington Post

headline: Griffin Takes Dunk Show to Garden
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Mike D’Antoni’s eyes lighted up when asked to describe Blake Griffin’s athleticism. In doing so, he used the word unbelievable, stretching it in a way to make Griffin’s athleticism sound even more, well, unbelievable.

headline: TimesCast | February 8, 2011
text: Cairo’s protests spread to the Parliament; a TV interview inspires Egyptians; and Julian Assange is back in court.

headline: Fed Casts A Wide Net In Defining Systemic Risk
text: Federal regulators on Tuesday took an expansive view of the types of companies that could be deemed essential enough to the financial system that they should be subjected to greater oversight.

headline: A Bit of Old New Orleans in Williamsburg
text: Habitués of the famous Olde Absinthe House in New Orleans may execute a double-take when walking into Maison Premiere, the new Big Easy-flavored oyster bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Perched on an island within the graceful, marble-topped, horseshoe-shaped bar is an uncanny replica of one of the ancient absinthe fountains found inside the French Quarter watering hole — jade-colored marble column, quartet of brass spigots, Napoleon statue and all.

headline: In Good ‘Company': Patti LuPone and Stephen Colbert Join Philharmonic Production
text: When the New York Philharmonic announced in December that it would present a new semi-staged production of “Company” in the spring starring Neil Patrick Harris, it raised the questions of (a) where the peripatetic Mr. Harris finds the time for so many extracurricular activities and (b) what stars would share the stage with him in that Stephen Sondheim musical.

headline: Lymph Node Study Shakes Pillar of Breast Cancer Care
text: A new study finds that many women with early breast cancer do not need a painful procedure that has long been routine: removal of cancerous lymph nodes from the armpit.

headline: Winklevoss Brothers, Redux. Again.
text: Facebook was born at Harvard University in early 2004, and since then, the company has gone through a lot of changes. But one thing has not changed: the bad feelings between Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s founder, and his fellow Harvard students, Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss, memorably dramatized in the film “The Social Network.”

headline: Egyptian Government Paid for Visit, French Official Says
text: PARIS  Prime Minister François Fillon admitted on Tuesday that he had accepted free lodging and transportation for his family from the Egyptian government during a Christmas vacation. His statement came as the foreign minister, Michèle Alliot-Marie, again refused to resign for accepting two free flights from a Tunisian businessman close to Tunisia’s former first family.

headline: Looking Back at ‘Tootsie’
text: Sydney Pollack‘s 1982 film, “Tootsie,” which stars Dustin Hoffman as an actor who poses as a woman to land a television role, made an impact on the Academy, receiving 10 Oscar nominations, including best picture. Jessica Lange, who was nominated in two categories that year, won the supporting actress Oscar for her performance in the film. This week’s Critics’ Picks video looks back on the comedy and sheds some light on why it struck such a chord. A. O. Scott’s video can be found on our sister blog, ArtsBeat.

headline: Elizabeth Bishop, Fighting The New Yorker Over Extra Commas and Steaming Cowflops
text: “What I think about The New Yorker,” the poet Elizabeth Bishop wrote in 1940 to her mentor, Marianne Moore, “can only be expressed like this: *!@!!!@!*!!”

headline: Reviewing Hunan Kitchen of Grand Sichuan
Behold the Bobbing Fish Head
text: JERRY TANG, a son of the late Chinese chef Shorty Tang, was talking about the business of running Chinese restaurants in New York. This was last week, during Chinese New Year, over coffee in Brooklyn.

headline: Disney Parks Help Drive Gain in Profit
text: LOS ANGELES  People are in the mood to spend on leisure time again, if Mickey Mouse is any guide.

headline: A Building Forms a Bridge Between a University’s Past and Future
text: I’m sure that a few preservationists are already grumbling about the new interdisciplinary science building at Columbia University. It certainly doesn’t fade politely into its brick surroundings. But they’d be wrong to think that it disrespects history.

headline: Page Numbers for Kindle Books an Imperfect Solution
text: Since the dawn of the Kindle, there’s been one quirky little feature that has baffled or thrilled the multitudes: page numbers.

headline: War and Peace on Champollion Street
text: CAIRO — As I write this I can hear the sounds of bullets, banging and shouting on Champollion Street, close to Liberation (Tahrir) Square in central Cairo.

headline: A Young Voice Talks to Schools’ Powerful
text: The Panel for Educational Policy meeting on Feb. 1 offered the spectator a little bit of everything, including humorous moments, like when a parent criticized the city’s take on education reform by singing her own lyrics to the tune of Sam Cooke’s “Wonderful World.” (“They know a lot about charter schools, and they think that merit pay is cool.”)

headline: Musical Survivor Hustles for a Second Chance
text: A couple of years ago Nicole Atkins, a promising songwriter from New Jersey with a bold siren call of a voice, found herself in splitsville with the two big relationships in her life: she was dropped by her record label after one album and broke up with her live-in boyfriend. Back at home with Mom, and rounding 30, she contemplated a question mark future but was still determined to create.

headline: Russia Plays Down Expulsion of British Journalist
text: MOSCOW  The Russian Foreign Ministry on Tuesday sought to play down the expulsion of a British correspondent based in Moscow, saying that he had violated rules for journalists but that he could return if he agreed to abide by them.

headline: Fox Builds Night On a Strong ‘House’
text: Fresh off a record-breaking Super Bowl Sunday audience of 111 million viewers, Fox delivered its best Monday night ratings of the season. According to Nielsen’s estimates, Fox’s “House” attracted its highest ratings of the season, with 12.3 million viewers at 8, while the network’s new crime drama “The Chicago Code” earned a solid start in its debut at 9, with 9.4 million. For the night over all, Fox ranked second to CBS and its comedy lineup. CBS’s “Two and a Half Men” drew the night’s largest audience, as usual, with 15.1 million viewers at 9, while “Mike & Molly” led at 9:30 with 12.7 million. CBS’s “How I Met Your Mother” (10.1 million) and “Rules of Engagement” (9.5 million) fared well at 8 and 8:30, while CBS’s “Hawaii Five-0” topped the ratings at 10 (10.9 million), outperforming ABC’s “Castle” (9.3 million) and NBC’s “Harry’s Law” (9.1 million). ABC finished a close third behind Fox, as an average of 9.7 million tuned in to “The Bachelor” from 8 to 10. NBC was fourth, with “Chuck” at 8 (5.4 million) and “Chase” at 9 (4.6 million).

headline: Friday Night Fights
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#43", 592, 420, true, chameleonData);

headline: Piano Trios From a Pair of Kindred Masters
text: What did Brahms see in Beethoven, whose marble bust stared down at him while he composed? Someone in many ways much like himself: fascinated by the past but restlessly innovative. Over the next month, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center offers Manifest Legacy, five programs charting Beethoven’s influence on Brahms. (Beyond the thematic hook, it is no coincidence that the society is featuring two of the biggest draws for its subscribers.) On Sunday at Alice Tully Hall, the first concert juxtaposed piano trios by the composers.

headline: Data Centers Offer Hope for St. Louis Office Market
text: ST. LOUIS  Several recent transactions are raising the possibility that this city’s downtown, a depressed office market with an overall vacancy rate of over 22 percent, may become a regional hub for computer software and data-center companies.

headline: WikiLeaks Cables on Egypt
text: A selection of WikiLeaks cables on Egypt.

headline: Sunny Town, Gloomy Boss
text: If humor lies in the unexpected, then optimism is funny — it’s so uncalled for.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Egypt, Germany and Cambodia.

headline: A Parking Ticket Windfall as Parking Rules Resume
text: With New York’s alternate-side parking rules finally back in effect, one might think that the city would show some leniency toward the unmoved.

headline: Working Both Ends of Farm to Table
text: Charleston, S.C.

headline: A Southern Chef Doesn’t Stray Far
text: CHARLESTON, S.C.

headline: Some of Charleston’s Best: McCrady’s, Husk and Martha Lou’s Kitchen
text: A look at three restaurants in one of the great eating towns of the American South.

headline: Beef With Farro, Egg, Kimchi Purée and Broccoli
text: Adapted from Sean Brock, McCrady’s, Charleston, S.C.

headline: Actors and Their Roles for $300, HAL? HAL!
text: Does the idea of a machine that’s as smart as you are inspire fascination? Or fear? From “2001” to “The Terminator,” science fiction has conditioned us to dread the metal tap on the shoulder. But “Smartest Machine on Earth,” a gee-whiz episode of the PBS series “Nova” on Wednesday night, puts a friendly face on artificial intelligence.

headline: Tea Party Magazine Making Debut This Week
text: The first issue of the Tea Party Review, which describes itself as “the first national magazine for, by, and about the Tea Party movement,” will make its debut during the Conservative Political Action Conference scheduled to begin in Washington on Thursday.

headline: George Clooney Answers Your Questions About Malaria
text: My former travel buddy, George Clooney, caught malaria in January on a trip to Sudan (see what happens when I’m not around to look out for him?). This seemed an opportunity to shine a spotlight on malaria, one of the scourges of much of the developing world, and George agreed to respond to reader questions. Thanks to all for submitting your questions–and I’m truly sorry that the answers were delayed. We were about to post these answers when Egypt intervened and I was too busy dodging pro-Mubarak thugs in Cairo to focus on this. So without further ado, George and I are finally responding.

headline: Airgas Ruling Still to Come
text: A decision on the challenge to Airgas‘s poison pill defense will come in the next few days, the judge in the case said on Tuesday afternoon.

headline: Wells Fargo’s C.F.O. Abruptly Retires
text: Howard I. Atkins, Wells Fargo’s chief financial officer and senior executive vice president, abruptly retired on Tuesday, citing personal reasons.

headline: Following the Tracks
text: Tracking a fisher hunting the forests of a highway cloverleaf interchange.

headline: How to Be a Frugal Traveler
text: The most common question I get from readers is, “How can I get your job?” while the most common question I field from friends is, “How can you stand your job?”

headline: Maybe Those Frog Teeth Weren’t Useless After All
text: Dollo’s Law, a theory proposed by the scientist Louis Dollo in the 1800s, states that when a particular trait is lost in a species, it never comes back.

headline: Gender Balance and Book Reviewing: A New Survey Renews the Debate
text: Why do magazines and periodicals review many more books written by men than women, and choose many more men than women to review them?

headline: London and Toronto Exchanges to Merge
text: 5:45 a.m. | Updated

headline: Less Surgery for Breast Cancer?
text: New York Times reporter, Denise Grady, reports on a new study that finds lymph node surgery may not be necessary.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Early Reviews Set Off a Storm
text: In a rare departure from custom, most of the nation’s leading theater critics filed their long-anticipated reviews of Broadway’s “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” for publication on Tuesday, even though that musical had not yet opened. They drew a sharp protest from the production about the fairness of assessing a show while its creative team is still at work.

headline: Senate Democrats Go Off to Brainstorm
text: The Senate went dark for a few days on Tuesday as Democrats headed for a policy and political brainstorming session in Charlottesville, Va.

headline: A Bipartisan Push to Cut the S.B.A.?
text: Republicans on Capitol Hill have made no secret of their desire to cut deeply and broadly across discretionary spending by the federal government. But a letter sent in late January from leaders of the Senate Small Business Committee must have come as something of a surprise to its recipient, Karen Mills, the head of the Small Business Administration. The letter, drafted by Senators Mary Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, and Olympia Snowe, Republican of Maine, called on Ms. Mills to recommend “programs within the S.B.A. that you believe could be eliminated or substantially reduced without undermining the S.B.A.’s ability to serve the needs of small-business owners.”

headline: Canon’s New SLR Cribs Some Sweet Features
text: There may be a certain déjà vu to the new Canon EOS Rebel T3i. Not just that it shares DNA with its popular predecessors, but its new features — a swivel-out screen and built-in photography guide — look a lot like those found on a pair of Nikon cameras.

headline: Warner Music’s Revenue Fell 14% in First Quarter
text: Warner Music Group lost $18 million in the last three months of 2010, or 12 cents a share, as new albums by artists like Josh Groban, Michael Bublé and Kid Rock fell short of expectations, the company announced on Tuesday,

headline: Facebook Friends a New Campus
text: Facebook announced Tuesday that it is moving its more than 2,000 employees — and 600 million friends — to a new campus in Menlo Park, Calif.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Wellness in Schools

headline: For That Special Valentine, Sugar Flowers and Licorice Hearts
text: Tiny pink and white heart-, ball- and flower-shaped sugars are among the specialties of a 270-year-old company in Nagoya, Japan, that makes them by hand from sugar grown in Japan. Consider them for a tea tray, for your Valentine, for baby showers or as hostess gifts. In addition to these miniatures, there are larger rounds and cubes decorated with flowers, and others in amber and white.

headline: Millionaire’s Meatloaf
text: Adapted from David Burke

headline: Doughnut Plant to Open at the Chelsea Hotel
text: Mark Isreal (above), who has been sending forth creative, multihued and myriad-flavored doughnuts from his Doughnut Plant shop on the Lower East Side for 16 years, will open his second New York store, in the Chelsea Hotel on Monday.

headline: Passport in Hand, Honey Mussels Inch Their Way to New York
text: The honey mussel, which made its debut in British Columbia several years ago and has been inching its way eastward ever since, has started to show up in New York, mostly in restaurants. The name refers to its exceptionally sweet flavor and also to the touches of amber on the shell. Dale Williamson, who runs the B.C. Mussel Company, said it was developed through selective breeding over many generations.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Hot or Not? A Model Turned Guru on What to Eat
text: YOGI CAMERON thought I was hot. Which, I figured, was a flattering thing to hear from a man whose cheekbones used to earn him thousands of dollars a day.

headline: Sports Bar Menus Change, but Not Too Much
text: THE shiny 10-inch-wide tin of nachos enticing Carolyn Thalin at the mahogany bar of the Stadium Grill in Manhattan was not your normal gloop-coated pile of tortilla chips. Inspired by the chef David Burke’s can o’ cake at his high-end restaurant Fishtail, it was constructed with layers of chips, cheese, black beans, more chips, cheese and beans, and — once baked, topped with salsa, sour cream, jalapeño, guacamole, scallions and more cheese — it was devised to be suffused with flavor right to the very bottom of the tin.

headline: Mile End
text: EARLY evening at Mile End, and the air is heady with the scent of meat. A few breaths, and the head swims. It is unsubtle, reckless, potentially ruinous. A vegetarian, accidentally stumbling by, might wake up the next morning and not remember a thing.

headline: On Our Radar: Rhino Poachers Killed in South Africa
text: Four suspected rhino poachers were shot and killed by rangers in two parks in South Africa over the weekend, the authorities said. Three of the poachers were shot in Kruger, one of the nation’s premier safari destinations, while another was killed in KwaZulu-Natal national park, another popular safari location. More than 333 rhinos were poached in the country in 2010, triple the amount from 2009. [Associated Press]

headline: Recipes for Romance
text: Dishes that contain some of the ingredients that experts say may be aphrodisiacs.

headline: What Not to Bring to Tahrir Square
text: CAIRO — It is rare that the most important piece of equipment in your bag is the bag itself, even more rare for that bag to be a black plastic trash sack slung over your shoulder as you walk past pro-government thugs on a bridge over the River Nile. The trash bag’s purpose, of course, is to conceal your large nylon camera bag, which is likely to get you grabbed off the street by the aforementioned thugs.

headline: Anelka to M.L.S.? Not So Fast
text: Try a Google search on the words “Anelka” and “L’Equipe,” and be ready to scroll down a list of articles posted last week when the French sports daily L’Equipe passed along a snippet of information about the Chelsea striker Nicolas Anelka.

headline: José Rafael Moneo’s New Building at Columbia
text: Columbia University’s new interdisciplinary building is anticipated as a gateway to a campus planned for West Harlem.

headline: When the Puppets Called a Sex Strike
text: For modern viewers, Aristophanes’ “Lysistrata” may be easier to admire than to like. The story, of course, compels: Lysistrata leads the Athenian and Spartan women in a sex strike to end the war between their cities. But all that ribaldry and priapism can be tough going. (Hell, perhaps, is other people’s bawdy comedy.)

headline: Lohan Faces Felony Theft Charge
text: LOS ANGELES — The actress Lindsay Lohan can now add the prospect of a grand theft charge to her legal woes.

headline: The Arts of Cuba, Set to Wow New York
text: The Cuban rumba and dance troupe Los Muñequitos de Matanzas hasn’t performed in New York in nearly a decade. Danza Contemporánea de Cuba, which mixes Afro-Caribbean dance and classical European ballet and was founded in 1959, has never been to the United States. Neither have the socially conscious photographers Adonis Flores and Cirenaica Moreira.

headline: ‘Less Is More’ Is Mattering Most
text: TOM FORD’S fashion show at his Madison Avenue store last fall was a tour de force of image control. Staged with little fanfare, documented by a single photographer and attended by no more than a hundred hand-picked guests, the show was a signal departure for Mr. Ford, who, during his tenure at Gucci in the 1990s, was a master of the super-size spectacle.

headline: New York Fashion Week Is Here
text: Thursday marks the official start of Fashion Week, with more than 250 designers showing their fall 2011 collections at dozens of locations around the city, including Lincoln Center, now in its second season as home of Mercedes-Benz New York Fashion Week.

headline: Ben Heppner Drops Out of the Met’s ‘Ring’
text: 12:53 p.m. | Updated The Metropolitan Opera’s new “Ring” cycle has lost its Siegfried. Ben Heppner, one of the best Wagnerian tenors around, withdrew from performances of the last two installments of the cycle, “Siegfried” and “Götterdämmerung,” next season.

headline: For China, Shock Could Be a Good Policy
text: When China raises interest rates, speculators quake. The after-hours move on Tuesday had a nearly instantaneous effect on global markets, initially sending copper back below $10,000 a metric ton and crude oil below $100 a barrel. If only the Chinese economy were so responsive.

headline: South Africa: Mines to Stay Private
text: The mineral resources minister, Susan Shabangu, said at a mining industry conference in Cape Town on Tuesday that nationalization of the mines was “not an option for South Africa.” The industry had been concerned about a nationalization campaign by the African National Congress Youth League, and government officials had worried the debate was scaring off investors.

headline: Ivory Coast: Fire at the Treasury
text: A fire at the Treasury building in downtown Abidjan on Tuesday destroyed financial records on at least three floors, officials said. The fire comes at a time of increasing fiscal strain for the president, Laurent Gbagbo, who is facing international financial sanctions because he has refused to step down after losing an election in November. Last week, the United States ambassador, Phillip Carter, said Mr. Gbagbo had been extorting businesses to pay their taxes in advance.

headline: Texas Governor Offers Optimism on Budget Shortfall
text: AUSTIN, Tex.  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas cannot be faulted for lack of optimism. Facing a two-year budget gap of at least $15 billion, Mr. Perry struck a defiant stance in his annual address to the Legislature, calling the state economy “the envy of the nation” and promising the budget would be balanced through spending cuts alone.

headline: West Bank: Elections Set for July
text: The Palestinian Authority announced on Tuesday that it would hold delayed local elections on July 9. The vote was originally scheduled for last summer, but it was postponed by disagreements over candidates within the Fatah movement. In December, a Palestinian court ordered the authority to go ahead with the elections, and the quick decision is widely attributed to the democratic momentum created by the uprisings in Tunisia and Egypt. Elections were supposed to be held in both the West Bank and Gaza, but Hamas, which rules in Gaza, has said it would not allow them to take place. No election has been held in either territory since 2006.

headline: Canada: Quebec Prosecutors Strike
text: Quebec’s 450 prosecutors went on strike Tuesday, severely disrupting the province’s legal system. Only a skeleton staff remained in the courts to handle bail hearings and trials in which juries had been selected. The prosecutors’ union says its members in Quebec earn about 40 percent less than their counterparts in other parts of Canada.

headline: Ailing Cyclist Is Said to Cite a Transfusion on Himself
text: The Italian professional cyclist Riccardo Riccò was admitted to a hospital in Modena, Italy, in critical condition Monday after performing a transfusion on himself with blood that may have turned bad, according to several Italian news reports.

headline: Görgl Edges Mancuso; Ailing Vonn Is Seventh
text: Elisabeth Görgl of Austria, a veteran of the World Cup circuit whose résumé lacked a major title, won the women’s super-G Tuesday during the opening day of the world ski championships. The American Julia Mancuso, meanwhile, again saved her best skiing for the biggest events, finishing five-hundredths of a second behind Görgl to win a silver medal.

headline: Facing Title IX Pressure, Cal May Restore the Teams It Cut
text: When the University of California, Berkeley, announced it was eliminating five varsity teams last fall, the decision was sold as a necessary sacrifice by a university reeling from severe cuts in state aid.

headline: First Lady Taking Health Work Global
text: WASHINGTON  Michelle Obama, who has planted a vegetable garden, swiveled a hula hoop, done yoga poses, lobbied Congress and crisscrossed the United States to promote the virtues of healthy eating and exercise, wants to take her campaign to reduce childhood obesity to a bigger audience: the global one.

headline: A Divisive Indian Official Is Loved by Businesses
text: GANDHINAGAR, India  In a soaring, unfinished conference hall in western India, thousands of businessmen and diplomats from around the world gathered recently for an investment meeting. They were there to pay homage to a politician for accomplishing something once thought almost impossible in India: making it easy to do business.

headline: A Cordless Phone That Plays Nice With Wireless Phones
text: You can go without a land line and just use your smartphone. People do it all the time.

headline: Health Law Provision Raises Antitrust Concerns
text: WASHINGTON  The new health care law encourages collaboration by doctors and hospitals for cost savings, but a split has developed here as to just how far they can go without running afoul of antitrust laws.

headline: Some Diamondback Investors Pull Out Their Money
text: Investors in Diamondback Partners, one of four hedge funds raided by federal authorities in November amid a widening investigation of suspected insider trading on Wall Street, have asked for more than $500 million back from the firm, according to the fund’s latest investor letter..The amount, totaling $534 million, represents around 9.4 percent of Diamondback’s total assets, according to the letter, defying expectations that the firm would experience enormous outflows after it was implicated in the investigation. Diamondback has told investors that the raid was focused on one of its portfolio managers and that the fund itself was not a target of the federal inquiry.

headline: Mystery Over Detained American Angers Pakistan
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — The case of Raymond A. Davis, a former United States Special Forces soldier who is being held in connection with the deaths of two Pakistanis, has stirred a diplomatic furor, sending the precarious relationship between the United States and Pakistan to a new low, both sides say.

headline: What’s Always Been So Great About Green Bay
text: In more than 50 years of writing about professional football, my favorite trip was always to Green Bay.

headline: Former Judge Is on Trial in ‘Cash for Kids’ Scheme
text: SCRANTON, Pa.  A former Pennsylvania judge went on trial in federal court on Tuesday, charged with racketeering, bribery and extortion in what prosecutors say was a $2.8 million scheme to send juvenile delinquents to privately run prisons.

headline: Robber’s Suicide Was Planned, Authorities Say
text: A gunman who held up a central New Jersey jewelry store this week and shot and killed the owner before turning the gun on himself had planned all along to commit suicide, the authorities said Tuesday.

headline: Tribe’s Plan for Catskill Casino, Backed by Paterson, Faces Rejection in Washington
text: A proposed Native American casino on 333 acres in the Catskills is likely to be rejected by federal authorities next week, only three months after Gov. David A. Paterson approved the $560 million project in the waning days of his administration.

headline: Are Democrats Better Off Than They Were 25 Years Ago?

headline: Is ‘Eat Real Food’ Unthinkable?

Even with all this big, powerful input, we know nothing that we didn’t know last year. We do, however, have a new acronym; unfortunately, it’s not the one we need.

But few voices have been as urgent, insistent or persuasive as those of Egypt’s neighbors.

headline: Latest Hidden Video by Abortion Foes Shows Bronx Clinic of Planned Parenthood
text: An anti-abortion group released a videotape on Tuesday of a man whom the group said was posing as a pimp and a woman who was posing as a prostitute on a visit to a Planned Parenthood clinic in the Bronx. They appear to get information from a receptionist about how to obtain abortions and treatment for sexually transmitted diseases for under-age sex workers.

headline: Malpractice Bill Raises Issues About a Lawsuit
text: The lawmaker and retired obstetrician sponsoring a Congressional bill to sharply cut medical malpractice awards was involved in a $500,000 settlement of a malpractice lawsuit. The action was brought by a pregnant woman who charged that inappropriate care caused the loss of her fetus and other complications.

headline: Asbury Park’s Boardwalk Revival Moves Inland
text: ASBURY PARK, N.J.  For about a decade this Jersey Shore town, immortalized on a Bruce Springsteen album cover, has been on a slow upward trajectory  most visibly along its boardwalk, where dozens of new businesses have opened since 2007, when Madison Marquette of Washington stepped in as developer.

headline: Obama Plans to Rescue States With Debt Burdens
text: President Obama is proposing to ride to the rescue of states that have borrowed billions of dollars from the federal government to continue paying unemployment benefits during the economic downturn. His plan would give the states a two-year breather before automatic tax increases would hit employers, and before states would have to start paying interest on the loans.

headline: New Gums With Vitamins, Herbs and Varied Claims
text: BEYOND tasting good and freshening breath, chewing gum today increasingly promises dental benefits, like reducing cavities, whitening and even strengthening teeth. Some sugarless brands, including Dentyne, Extra and Orbit, even carry seals of approval from the American Dental Association, for helping to reduce cavities.

headline: Young Egyptians Spread Their Message
text: Young protesters have turned a downtown Cairo apartment into a secret hiding place, recharging after long days of protesting and uploading homemade documentaries about life in Tahrir Square to a shared Facebook page.

headline: Toyota’s Acceleration Problem
text: The finding that Toyota’s problems with uncontrolled acceleration were not caused by glitches in its electronic controls is good news for Toyota and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. But it doesn’t dispel concerns about the weaknesses of the nation’s vehicle safety regulation.

headline: What Are Social-Impact Bonds?
text: My column this week describes a new strategy for improving the performance of government programs. In short, private investors — typically foundations — pay the costs of a new program in its early years, and the government later repays the investors, often with a bonus, as long as the program meets its goals. If it fails, taxpayers pay nothing.

headline: Case Dismissed in High-Rise Fall Death
text: A real estate broker was cleared on Tuesday of misdemeanor charges that he served alcohol to the under-age daughter of a United States ambassador before she fell to her death from a Midtown high-rise building in August.

headline: What Are They Waiting For?
text: We applauded back in December when the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives announced that it was seeking an emergency rule requiring gun dealers near the Mexican border to report multiple purchases of high-power semiautomatic rifles that use a detachable magazine. It looked as if the Obama administration was finally awakening to the urgent need to combat the illegal trafficking of AK-47s and other assault weapons across the border and into the hands of violent drug cartels. It turns out that we were wrong to applaud.

headline: A Conservative Gathering Will Test G.O.P. Hopefuls

headline: The Kilogram to Come
text: The official kilogram, a cylinder of platinum and iridium maintained by the International Bureau of Weights and Measures, is more than 130 years old. It is stored under three glass domes in a safe in a basement in Sèvres, France, and can be accessed only with three independent keys.

headline: Patrician Clan That Clings to Its Foibles
text: There are not many fixed verities in the world of the theater, but one of the few is that when A.R. Gurney returns to home territory — writing about the manners and morals of the white Anglo-Saxon Protestant upper class — the results will most likely be gratifying. Mr. Gurney’s “Black Tie,” which opened on Tuesday night at the 59E59 Theaters, is one of this prolific writer’s most enjoyable plays in years, a modest but effortlessly engaging comedy about the generational shifts in the subset of humanity Mr. Gurney has been writing about with warmth, humor and insight throughout his career.

headline: Administration Pitches Big Rail Projects
text: The Obama administration, whose efforts to bring high-speed rail to the United States were sidetracked by Republican governors in a couple of states, pressed ahead with its vision of building a national rail network on Tuesday when it called for spending $53 billion on passenger trains and high-speed rail projects over the next six years.

headline: Emotions Rev Stoudemire, but May Stall Him
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Amar’e Stoudemire responded like the perfect company man during the preseason when addressing the N.B.A.’s mandate to curtail excessive complaining by issuing technical fouls.

headline: South Carolina: Newborn Abandoned in Restroom
text: The police are reviewing surveillance video to find a woman who gave birth in a restroom stall in Greenville and then left the baby in the toilet. The infant boy is in stable condition, after being discovered Friday by custodians at an arena where a circus had taken place. Dozens of people have volunteered to adopt the 6-pound baby, the police said. The baby is believed to have spent at least an hour in the toilet before custodians heard him crying.

headline: Letters: The Boy Who Kicked the Hornet’s Nest
text: Bill Keller’s fascinating account of his behind-the-scenes maneuvering with WikiLeaks is one that I will now assign to my journalism students as required reading. But isn’t it unfair for Keller to dump so heavily on Julian Assange, who made it possible for The New York Times to acquire and exploit these documents in the first place? Whatever Assange’s personal failings, his indisputable bravery and skill have unearthed important secrets about the foreign policy that our government is waging in our name. Indeed, WikiLeaks’s ability to thwart censorshipand expose wrongdoing threatens corrupt regimes worldwide — and may prove to be a seminalevent in the history of investigative journalism.

headline: Theft Case Offers Window on Bloomberg’s Bid for Re-election
text: It appeared to be a run-of-the-mill campaign e-mail: in October 2009, a Republican political consultant wrote to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s two top aides, Kevin Sheekey and Patricia E. Harris, about Election Day operations.

headline: Letters: Martin Peretz Is Not Sorry. About Anything.
text: Stephen Rodrick’s vivid picture of Marty Peretz underplays one ofthe man’s essential characteristics: his extraordinary kindness to young people. As a Harvard sophomore in the late ’60s, on scholarship in a place that could make you feel unnoticed, I took one of Peretz’s extraordinary seminars on McCarthyism. The recently departed ’50s seemed musty and irrelevant — until you sat down at one of Marty’s anything-goes lunchtime discussions, not only with people who had seen Communism as a genuine internal threat but also with others who had been blacklisted for years. Marty was available, enthusiastic, funny, biting, attentive to whatyou were doing and what you had to say. And yes, unorthodox in his opinions and relentless in probing yours. In other words, he was a thrilling teacher.

headline: Capacity Crowd at Lambeau, Cheering a Title
text: GREEN BAY, Wis.  The mayor of Green Bay, Jim Schmitt, was walking briskly toward the entrance of Lambeau Field on Tuesday afternoon, his green-and-gold scarf whipping in the frosty breeze. His hands gripped a long, flat, rectangular object that was wrapped in paper.

headline: Judge Rules for N.F.L. in Supplement Case
text: In an apparent victory for the N.F.L., a state appeals judge in Minnesota upheld a lower court ruling that allowed the league to suspend two players on the Vikings who were found to have taken StarCaps, a supplement that included a banned substance.

headline: Patriot Act Extension Fails in House
text: The House defeated a bid Tuesday to extend for nine months the government’s authority to conduct roving wiretaps of terror suspects, along with two other expiring provisions of the Patriot Act. The vote, 277 to 148, fell short of the two-thirds majority needed. Representative Lamar Smith said he hoped to bring up the legislation in two days under rules allowing passage by a simple majority.

headline: Walrus on Endangered Species Waiting List
text: Government biologists conclude that the Pacific walrus deserves protection under the Endangered Species Act, but has to wait awhile for that protection.

headline: Ohio: Health Law Challenge on Fast Track
text: A second appellate court has set an expedited schedule for hearing a constitutional challenge to the new health care law. The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, announced Tuesday that it would hear oral arguments during a term that stretches from May 30 to June 10. The appeal stems from a decision upholding the law by a federal judge in Detroit. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, Va., has already announced it will hear arguments in mid-May in the Obama administration’s appeal of a Virginia judge’s decision to strike down a central provision of the law.

headline: No Brodeur Is No Problem as Devils’ Surge Continues

Altmann, a Jewish refugee who in her 80s waged a successful legal battle all the way to the United States Supreme Court to force the Austrian government to return paintings by Gustav Klimt that had been seized from her family by the Nazis, died on Monday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 94.

headline: A Mexican City’s Troubles Reshape Its Families

headline: What Cause Would Get You Into the Streets?
text: Much of the coverage of the demonstrations in Egypt has focused on how ordinary citizens there have begun publicly expressing their desire for greater freedom. What idea or cause would spur you to join in a public demonstration? On what ideas would you like to express your views to a wider audience — even to the whole world?

headline: New Roman Museum Highlights Baroque Church
text: Lovers of Baroque art and architecture can add one more stop to their Rome travel itinerary: the recently inaugurated Museo Missionario di Propaganda Fide. The new museum, which documents four centuries of the Catholic Church’s missionary work, has opened in part of the 17th-century Palazzo di Propaganda Fide, a masterpiece of Baroque architecture designed by the period’s leading architects, Francesco Borromini and Gianlorenzo Bernini. Visitors to the museum will have access to halls and chapels in the Palazzo that are open to the public on a permanent basis for the first time.

headline: Keep an Eye on Bolton’s Coyle
text: Last November, Bolton Wanderers Manager Owen Coyle was in Belfast, Northern Ireland, to watch his team’s second-string take on a local soccer team, Cliftonville, in a friendly. Most coaches would have been content to sit back and keep warm on a frosty night.

headline: Update on Refrigerator Perry
text: William Perry, better known as the Refrigerator,  nearly died in 2009. He had Guillain-Barre Syndrome, and he was neglecting his health.

headline: Labor Actions in Egypt Boost Protests
text: CAIRO  Labor strikes and worker protests that flared across Egypt on Wednesday affected post offices, textile factories and even the government’s flagship newspaper, providing a burst of momentum to protesters demanding the resignation of President Hosni Mubarak, even as his government pushed back with greater force against the opponents’ demands.

headline: Prosecutors Seek Immediate Trial for Berlusconi
text: ROME  A defiant Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi said Wednesday that he would continue to govern Italy even as Milan prosecutors filed a request to try him on criminal charges related to prostitution and abuse of office.

headline: Now Showing, an iPad That’s Almost a TV

headline: A Good Deed by DeSean Jackson
text: The Fifth Down still thinks DeSean Jackson should wait until he crosses the goal line before celebrating. But he and two of his Eagles teammates deserve credit for appearing on “The View” to support a boy who spoke about an egregious case of school bullying. The look on the boy’s face upon seeing Jackson, his favorite player, is worth a click.

headline: Testing the Entrepreneurial Life
text: In two recent posts (here and here) I wrote about the business incubator Succeed on Purpose, which  coaches corporate layoff victims who want to start their own businesses. The incubator taps into the desire to be your own boss, common among both downsized workers and valued employees. But years of working for someone else can make the prospect of self-employment daunting. To gather insight, I spoke with Pamela Slim, author of “Escape from Cubicle Nation” (Portfolio, 2009) and a coach who helps would-be defectors through the transition. An edited version of our conversation follows.

Jackson, the E.P.A. administrator, has been called to testify before the House Energy and Commerce Committee’s Subcommittee on Energy and Power. The subcommittee is chaired by Edward Whitfield, Republican of Kentucky, a sponsor of a bill that would restrict the agency’s powers. The hearing opens at 9:30 a.m.; a live Webcast is planned here.
