text: The British Treasury said on Wednesday that it had struck a long-sought deal with the country’s largest banks on two burning issues: lending and compensation.

headline: Johnson & Johnson Deal for Crucell Moves Forward
text: Shareholders of the Dutch biotechnology company Crucell voted on Tuesday to change the company’s bylaws and the makeup of its supervisory board, two moves that will pave the way for Johnson & Johnson‘s 1.75 billion euro ($2.4 billion) takeover.

headline: Freddie Official Says He Has No Duty to Shareholders
text: As the Obama administration works to determine the fate of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, a director of one of the mortgage finance giants says he has no fiduciary duty to the company’s shareholders.

headline: Paulson Donation to Finance Research on the Euro Zone
text: The hedge fund manager John A. Paulson has donated more than £2.5 million to the London School of Economics and Political Science to foster research on Europe in the post-crisis financial world.

headline: A Bond to Save Lives
text: Health care is an obvious place that could benefit from social-impact bonds, even though the White House is not including health care on its list of areas for pilot projects. (To review, the bonds let governments wait to see that a program is working before spending any taxpayer money on it.)

headline: Violence, Hope and an Oscar Nomination
text: Of the five nominees for this year’s Oscar for best foreign-language film, four are based on original scripts. The exception is Canada’s “Incendies,” which its director, Denis Villeneuve, adapted from the French-language play of the same name, written by the Lebanese-born Canadian playwright Wajdi Mouawad and known in English as “Scorched.”

headline: In Tokyo, a Crackdown on Sexual Images of Minors
text: TOKYO  In a manga comic book that is well known here, “My Wife Is an Elementary School Student,” a 24-year-old teacher marries a 12-year-old girl as part of a top-secret social experiment.

headline: Updates on Day 16 of Egypt Protests
text: The Lede continues to follow the protest movement in Egypt, now in its third week. For a summary of new developments, read today’s main news article from our colleagues in Cairo. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists in Egypt. A stream of Twitter updates on the protests is in this blog’s right column.

headline: Public-Worker Unions Skip Albany Ad Blitz for New Tactics
text: ALBANY  The airwaves are virtually silent. The fiery criticism of years past has given way to conciliatory press releases. And the halls of the Capitol ring not with angry protests but with the quiet hum of lawmakers and lobbyists making their daily rounds.

headline: Teaming Tenants and Landlords for Energy Savings
text: Last week I wrote about how small businesses are going green by taking steps that reduce waste and energy use. While personal convictions may drive many business owners to reduce their environmental impact, most still make decisions based on a model that requires a quick return on such an investment.

headline: A Role for Gaming in Learning
text: My post over the weekend on growing recognition of a role for gaming in learning generated a great mix of responses that are worth highlighting and building on here.

headline: Jargon-aut
text: Those fond of using bureaucratic terms.  (Also Jargonaut.)

headline: Developer Chosen to Start Long Island City Housing Complex
text: The Bloomberg administration announced Wednesday morning that it had selected a development team led by Related Companies to build the first phase of a development on the Queens waterfront, which, when completed, will be the largest middle-income complex built since the 1970s.

headline: A Closer Look at Bose’s New (and Only) TV
text: I spent several hours Sunday with Leonardo DiCaprio, Aaron Rodgers, Ben Roethlisberger and Dr. Amar Bose.

headline: Ristretto | Fashion Week Coffee
text: Skip the coffee at the tents: there’s a better buzz to be had during Fashion Week.

headline: Beyond the Acronyms
text: The comments so far on my Opinionator piece today are lively and engaging enough to keep you entertained for a bit, but if you’re interested in seeing some of the material I read before writing the column, here it is, with comments of my own.

headline: St. Joe Explores Sale
text: 10:37 a.m. | Updated

headline: Dot Earth: Games as Learning
text: Andrew C. Revkin explored the idea of a role for games in learning on Dot Earth in a post over the weekend. The piece focused on Will Wright, the mind behind Spore and The Sims, and solicited questions for Mr. Wright as well as others’ views on the notion that virtual experiences can help fit infinite human aspirations on a finite planet.

headline: In Congress, Bernanke Faces Questions About Inflation
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, parried tough questions Wednesday about rising gasoline prices in the United States and the soaring cost of food and grains in the emerging world as he defended the central bank’s $600 billion program to shore up the recovery.

headline: Defense Agency to Scrutinize Industry Deals Carefully
text: The Defense Department will be keeping close tabs on industry deal-making.

headline: It’s Alive: U.S. Movie Theaters to Show Danny Boyle’s ‘Frankenstein’
text: When the Bagger last spoke with Danny Boyle on Oscar nominations day, he was treating himself to a cab ride home after rehearsals for his stage production of “Frankenstein.” The play, now running at the National Theater in London, stars Benedict Cumberbatch and Jonny Lee Miller, who are alternating in the roles of Victor Frankenstein and the Creature; the first 10 weeks are sold out. But American audiences will get a chance to see it anyway; according to a new announcement, it will be broadcast in American movie houses on March 17. Add your own “It’s ALIVE!” joke here.

headline: Hyundai Veloster Rally Car and 2012 Genesis Unveiled in Chicago
text: During Wednesday’s news media previews at the Chicago auto show, Hyundai introduced a purpose-built rally version of its coming Veloster coupe, as well as a refreshed and refined Genesis luxury sedan.

headline: Wednesday Reading: How to Be a Frugal Traveler
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Official Is Killed In Southern Sudan
text: KAMPALA, Uganda  A leading official of the government of the secessionist region of southern Sudan was shot dead by his brother-in-law on Wednesday morning, according to officials who said the motive was personal and unrelated to the region’s recent vote for independence.

headline: Can the Catholic Church Atone for Its Sins in Ireland?
text: Sex-abuse scandals involving priests have shaken a nation to its core, but will the anger translate into a separation of church and state?

headline: The Irish Affliction
text: Andrew Madden is one of a relatively new breed of Irish celebrities who would just as soon be less well known. He was among the first people in Ireland to go public about being sexually abused by Catholic clergy — one of those who set off the intense bout of soul-searching that has racked the country lately. When I met Madden last fall in Dublin, the early rumbles of the collapse of Ireland’s economy were shaking the country, and throughout much of a pub lunch he talked about the failures of the government and the banks. It was only later, once we were driving around his old neighborhood, past the pebbledash house where he grew up and where his parents still live, that he began to talk about his childhood. As we sat in his car in front of Christ the King Church, where he spent much of his youth as an altar boy and a choir member, he outlined the four years of torment he suffered in the late 1970s at the hands of the Rev. Ivan Payne, one of the infamous serial sex offenders among the Irish Catholic clergy whose stories have transfixed the country over the past year and a half.

headline: Commitment and Accounting in Title IX
text: 1:49 p.m. Feb. 11 | Updated: Cal Restores Three Varsity Sports

headline: How to Find Cruise Line Deals
text: WITH cruise bookings on the upswing, bargains are tougher to find this year. But it’s still possible to nab a deal, if you act quickly.

headline: Numberplay: Are Virgos Bad Drivers? Solution
text: Allstate research suggests Virgos are rather accident-prone: They had 700 percent more accidents than Scorpios during 2010, for example. Yet Allstate does not consider astrology in setting rates. Why?

headline: 15,000 New Stars Take Form in Empire State Building
text: It took Alfred E. Smith, by then a former governor and a failed presidential candidate, 410 days to get the Empire State Building built with help from an army of construction workers.

headline: Minority Students and A.P. Program, a Mixed Report Card
text: More minority high school students are achieving success on Advanced Placement exams that can get them college credit, but they are still underrepresented in the nation’s A.P. classrooms, according to a report just released by the College Board, which administers the program.

headline: A New Musical From Bernhard and Bond
text: The downtown music scene will get an extra dose of glam this spring at a reading of a new musical written by the actress and comedian Sandra Bernhard, the downtown drag artist Justin Bond, and the Scissor Sisters lead singer Jake Shears.

headline: Houston Opera Still Embraces Bold Ventures
text: HOUSTON  Whatever happened to the Houston Grand Opera? That this renowned company’s international media profile has slipped since the departure of David Gockley, its general director from 1972 to 2005, is obvious. But precisely why is something of a mystery, given the level of performance seen in the company’s accounts of its winter repertory, Jake Heggie’s “Dead Man Walking” and Donizetti’s “Lucia di Lammermoor.”

headline: Banksy + Cats = Movie Magic
text: As Oscar campaigns go, the street artist Banksy’s is unusual – never showing up to schmooze (as far as we know), insulting other contenders, making a documentary that seems liked a hoax and leaving fellow filmmakers to debate whether that matters. A new video parodying his film, “Exit Through the Gift Shop,” takes his uncampaigning even further. The “Exit Through the Pet Shop” trailer imagines what Banksy’s movie would look like if it were populated by Keyboard Cats and I Can Has Cheezburger.

headline: Ratings Down for Rangers, Islanders, Devils
text: The television ratings for the local broadcasts of the 30 N.H.L. teams are in, and the news is not good for the three New York metropolitan area clubs. Audiences for the Devils and Islanders are down, and somewhat surprisingly, so are the Rangers’.

headline: Battier Plans for Life After Basketball
text: Shane Battier is only 32, but he’s already thinking about his life after basketball.

headline: A Grammy Awards Tribute for Aretha Franklin
text: With Mick Jagger already signed on to perform at the Grammy Awards in a tribute to the singer Solomon Burke, who called himself “King Solomon” and who died in October, it’s only fitting that Aretha Franklin, the still-reigning “Queen of Soul,” should also be honored at the awards ceremony on Sunday in Los Angeles. Christina Aguilera, Jennifer Hudson, Martina McBride, Yolanda Adams and Florence Welch will participate in the homage to the 68-year-old Ms. Franklin. Grammy sponsors are describing it as a “valentine” and a “get-well card” to Ms. Franklin, who has won 18 Grammys herself. She was hospitalized in Detroit late last year, underwent surgery for an undisclosed ailment and canceled several months’ worth of scheduled performances.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diner’s Journal.

headline: Steven Tyler Escapes From Idolatry
text: FAME isn’t all gold, honey and massage oils; it’s also the successful navigation of a steady stream of unlikely and uncomfortable situations.

headline: Condom Rule Sought for Sex-Film Sets
text: LOS ANGELES  The clinic that for the last decade had monitored the health of those working in the multibillion-dollar pornography industry abruptly shut its doors in December.

headline: Johnny Reb Economics
text: Mike Konczal has a post about Ron Paul’s first hearing on monetary policy, in which he points out that the lead witness is a big Lincoln-hater and defender of the Southern secession.

headline: Chris Cannon Names New Chefs at Convivio and Alto
text: Chris Cannon has hired new executive chefs for Convivio and Alto restaurants, the two restaurants that he and his partners control after the recent split with Michael White’s Altamarea Group.

headline: Quote Unquote | Poor Baby
text: –Rachel Zoe tells Elle about her latest fashion accessory. Sorry Tavi, you will no longer be the youngest in the front row.

headline: Senator Webb Will Not Run for Re-election
text: 2:10 p.m. | Updated Senator Jim Webb, Democrat of Virginia, has decided not to run for re-election, avoiding a blockbuster rematch with the man he beat in 2006, George Allen, and giving Senate Republicans another opportunity to help them reclaim the majority.

headline: The N.F.L.’s Public Relations Problem
text: Being Darth Vader, apparently, is in.

headline: Steven Tyler: ‘Idol’ Anchor or Liability?
text: Many wondered whether “American Idol” could survive the departure of Simon Cowell, and the addition of Steven Tyler to the judges panel struck some as proof that the ratings powerhouse was entering its twilight.

headline: Do Women Shun Science?
text: The absence of women — particularly mothers — in the sciences is making news again.

headline: The Rising Cost of Identity Theft for Consumers
text: While the estimated number of identity fraud victims fell steeply last year from the year prior, consumers’ out-of-pocket identity fraud costs rose, according to a new report from Javelin Strategy & Research.

headline: From Tahrir Square to Parliament
text: Demonstrations demanding the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak spread from Tahrir Square to the streets around Egypt's Parliament building.

headline: Emanuel Has Commanding Lead in Chicago Mayor’s Race
text: CHICAGO – With less than two weeks to the mayoral election, a poll released on Wednesday shows Rahm Emanuel, the former White House chief of staff, with a commanding lead, drawing support from 54 percent of those surveyed.

headline: Breast Cancer and Lymph Nodes: Q. and A.
text: An article in Wednesday’s Times describes how a routine procedure for the treatment of early breast cancer — the surgical removal of cancerous lymph nodes from the armpit — has been found unnecessary for many patients. The finding turns 100 years of standard medical practice on its head.

headline: Tout Sweet | The New French Chocolate
text: Toss a praliné truffe in any direction in Paris, and you’ll hit a chocolatier, whether an award-winning master or a modest neighborhood peddler. But lately the city seems particularly cuckoo for cocoa, as a new breed of chocolate artisans has opened up salons, boutiques and bars all over the city.

headline: Ackman’s Long and Short on Investing
text: William A. Ackman of Pershing Square Capital Management and Prof. Michael Porter of Harvard Business School talk to CNBC about the tensions that exist in capital markets. Is there a natural conflict between short- and long-term investing? The two discuss whether financial markets are in fact serving the needs of the economy, as opposed to just creating investment vehicles.

headline: Protests Spill Beyond Tahrir Square
text: Egypt’s antigovernment activists called on supporters Wednesday to expand their demonstrations in defiance of the vice president’s warning that protests calling for President Hosni Mubarak’s ouster would not be tolerated for much longer

headline: JPMorgan Asks to Move Madoff Trustee’s Lawsuit
text: No one thought that JPMorgan Chase was going to take the claims of the trustee representing the victims of Bernard L. Madoff‘s Ponzi scheme lying down, and it hasn’t disappointed.

headline: Tim Wu, Creator of the Term ‘Net Neutrality,’ Joins the Federal Government
text: The Federal Trade Commission on Tuesday named Tim Wu, author of the book “The Master Switch,”  a senior adviser for consumer protection and competition issues that affect the Internet and mobile phones.

headline: Changes to Medicare
text: Even as the federal courts kick around the new health care law, certain improvements for Medicare recipients are nonetheless under way.

headline: Zuckerberg Gets Animated
text: Now that the major Oscar races appear decided, the Bagger is feeling the liberty to take some coverage detours (because seriously, how many “King’s Speech” dinners can we go to, anyway?). So: the Taiwanese company Next Media Animation has produced another of its infamous cartoon news reports, this time about Mark Zuckerberg (the protagonist of “The Social Network”) and his alleged stalker. It somehow joins the outcry over Facebook’s privacy settings with John Cusack’s boombox moment from “Say Anything.”

headline: Yielding to Complaints, Groupon Revises Commercials
text: Groupon is changing the commercials that so many viewers complained about on Super Bowl Sunday.

headline: Saving Lives From Anal Cancer
text: Paulette Crowther’s three children were grown and she was plotting a midlife career change when a routine colonoscopy picked up cancer, but not of the colon — of the anus.

headline: Sotheby’s Plans Chinese Contemporary Art Sale
text: In Asia, Chinese contemporary art is still a hot collecting area. So it was with great fanfare that in Hong Kong on Wednesday morning, Sotheby’s announced the forthcoming sale of 106 works dating from the 1980s and early 1990s. The works belong to Guy Ullens and his wife, Myriam, Belgium collectors who opened the Ullens Center for Contemporary Art in a former munitions complex in Beijing’s Dashanzi warehouse arts district in 2007.

headline: The Insider | Sydney Albertini
text: A spring-summer 2011 daydream: There is a collision of vehicles carrying bolts of material. Prada’s stripes are unfurling in the street near a billowing pouf printed with lemons, grapefruits and oranges (Stella McCartney!). A band of wayward women have wrapped themselves in the cloth, like victorious marathoners. This imagined scene surfaces when presented with the paintings of Sydney Albertini. The East Hampton, N.Y.-based artist is perhaps best known for her whimsical pottery and quilting but is now ready to present her true love: painting. On the occasion of “Sydney Albertini: ephemere,” a show of 20 large charcoal and oil works opening tonight at New York’s French Institute Alliance Francaise, she shares her (kaleidoscopic) world.

headline: Paterson Remains the Virtual Governor
text: ALBANY — Here at the State Capitol, former Gov. David A. Paterson has most definitely left the building. But his digital presence apparently has not.

headline: Sanofi Says It May Extend Genzyme Offer
text: Sanofi-Aventis may seek another extension of its tender offer to acquire Genzyme, Christopher A. Viehbacher, chief executive of Sanofi-Aventis, a French drug maker, said in an interview on Wednesday.

headline: It’s Collaboratin’ Time: Spider-Man to Join the Fantastic Four
text: Spider-Man didn’t get the kindest reception on Broadway, but in his Marvel Comics adventures he’s about to receive a much warmer welcome. The web slinger will become a member of the Fantastic Four – or, more precisely, join the surviving teammates of that superhero group to form a new team – whose exploits will be chronicled in a new series called FF, Marvel Entertainment said on Wednesday.

headline: S.E.C. Seeks to Reduce Reliance on Credit Ratings
text: The nation’s largest credit rating agencies are ingrained in Wall Street’s DNA.

headline: Aide Says Giffords Is Speaking ‘More and More’
text: PHOENIX — Representative Gabrielle Giffords has begun speaking, an aide said Wednesday, telling hospital personnel at one point that she wanted some toast — an encouraging sign a month after being shot in the head at a political event outside Tucson.

headline: Where to Roost During Fashion Week? The Line Starts Here, Here and Here
text: GIVEN how, twice a year like clockwork, fashion’s feathered throng swoops down on New York to roost in tent rafters and crow about next season’s plumage, it’s tempting to think of them as some species of migratory bird.

headline: Dodge Treats Family Movers, Muscle Models to SRT8 and R/T Makeovers
text: Although Chrysler Group introduced new models for its three brands at both the Los Angeles and Detroit auto shows, it reserved a bit of marketing heat for the Chicago show, which opened to the news media on Wednesday.

headline: A 23-Year-Old Steve Jobs on TV
text: When Steven P. Jobs, founder of Apple, walks out on stage in front of thousands of people for a new product announcement, he looks more comfortable than an old man taking a nap in a La-Z-Boy. But the charismatic C.E.O. wasn’t always this calm in front of large audiences.

headline: Obama Plans to Step Up Talks on Free Trade Pacts
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Wednesday pledged to “immediately intensify” talks with Colombia and Panama on two free trade agreements with the aim of submitting the accords to Congress by the end of the year.

headline: Let’s Talk About Social Security
text: Gail Collins: David, we’ve been agreeing too much lately. So let’s talk about Social Security.

headline: Vocabulinks
text: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

headline: Trailer: 'Traces'
text: Excerpts from the North American tour of "Traces" by the company 7 Fingers. (Video courtesy of Traces USA)

headline: Sharing an Ayurvedic Lunch With a Yogi
text: If there was an unexpectedly maddening aspect of my lunch with Yogi Cameron, aside from the inevitable plunge in confidence that comes whenever you sit across a table from someone who looks like that, it was the oddness of eating without a glass of cold water at hand.

headline: Nicki Minaj Tops Billboard Chart
text: After hovering close to the No. 1 spot on Billboard magazine’s music charts since November, Nicki Minaj has finally gained the top slot. “Pink Friday,” the debut CD by this 26-year-old singer, sold 45,000 copies last week — up 18 percent from the previous week and enough to nudge cumulative sales of the CD past one million.

headline: How Will Webb’s Retirement Affect Virginia Democrats?
text: After a couple of cycles in which an above-average number of incumbents have lost their seats in Congress, it’s easy to forget that being an incumbent is normally an extremely powerful advantage. Political science models have generally found that the incumbency advantage amounts to 6 to 10 percentage points for a senator, meaning that an incumbent Democrat would be expected to get 56 to 60 percent of the vote in a state where a nonincumbent Democrat would get about 50 percent.

headline: All Eyes on Four Not-So-New Designers
text: IT’S fitting that the movie that fashion people are mad for is “Black Swan.” It’s about a bulimic girl obsessed with perfection, poise and control who is really  really!  dying for her breakout moment at Lincoln Center so the world can see how talented she is. Of course, the film is set next door at a fictional ballet company, and the girl is trying to break out of the corps, not the fashion pack. But every year, as the fashion flock gets larger, it’s harder to spot the cob or pen  boy swan or girl swan, of course  that could rise above the rest, on track to a spotlight in Vogue, a C.F.D.A. nomination and an order from Bergdorf Goodman.

headline: Quote Unquote | Runway-ing on Empty
text: –The modeling agent Carole White reveals to The Daily Mail just how much times have changed in the industry. No wonder Naomi used to throw phones at people — she was hungry.

headline: Dangerous Precedent
text: The Times reports today:

headline: Bloomberg’s Battle for More Say in the Pension Process
text: New York City’s labor force was in revolt in the late 1960s and early ’70s. Teachers, sanitation workers and policemen had all been on strike. City officials and unions were at loggerheads.

headline: Olympic Sailing Looks to Go Extreme
text: The world’s top Olympic sailors were in South Florida reading wind and waves aboard two-person dinghies, keelboats and windsurfers at the recent Rolex Miami Olympic Classes Regatta. The sailing lineup has not really altered much in the last 20 years.

headline: Artifacts | Francesco Vezzoli’s Temple of Obsession
text: For his first solo show in a New York gallery, Francesco Vezzoli chose an apt title: “Sacrilegio.” Its irreverence starts with his redesign of that gallery, the expansive Gagosian space on West 21st Street. It is now a stripped-down, dimly lit Gothic church that is painted an Armani gray and is dedicated to a real Madonna, the source of Vezzoli’s diva complex – his own mother.

headline: Powell’s Books Announces Layoffs
text: The rise of e-books and declining store sales have led to layoffs at Powell’s Books, the landmark bookstore in Portland, Ore. The store’s management said on Tuesday it would lay off 31 employees as part of its “response to the unprecedented, rapidly changing nature of the book industry.” Ryan Takas, the union representative for the employees who were laid off, said that the 31 employees make up more than 7 percent of the store’s 400-person unionized work force. Mr. Takas said that Powell’s had reduced its work force by about 40 employees in the last year through attrition, but still felt that layoffs were necessary because of a decline in sales of new books and a rise in health care costs. It was the first round of layoffs since the store’s workers formed a union in 2000.

headline: So Close, He Brought the Barbecue
text: Jonathan Taggart, 26, a photojournalist based in Vancouver, British Columbia, focuses largely on the indigenous communities of Canada. He is a 2008 graduate of Ryerson University in Toronto and teaches photography to aboriginal youths. His work has been published in The Globe and Mail and in Toronto Life Magazine. He is a founder of Boreal Collective, a documentary photo group. Kerri MacDonald’s conversation with Mr. Taggart for Turning Point has been edited and condensed.

headline: Small-Business Credit Markets, Assessed by a Loan Broker
text: Up until summer 2009, Ami Kassar was a nine-to-fiver, working for Advanta, one of the largest providers of credit cards to small business. But then the company went bust, another victim of the credit crisis, and the newly unemployed Mr. Kassar decided to strike out on his own.

headline: Is the Small-Business Credit Crisis Over?
text: In an interview we’ve just published, Ami Kassar, a business loan broker, assesses the current state of the small-business credit markets. Among other things, Mr. Kassar, who started his company, MultiFunding, last year, has the following to say:

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. A bill in the Arizona Legislature would allow the state to ignore any federal laws it deems unconstitutional. While everyone else is stuck with the prix fixe, Arizona hits the legislative buffet.

headline: For New Yorkers, a Leak Alert
text: Almost buried among the 100 initiatives put forth in a plan released on Wednesday by New York City’s Department of Environmental Protection are a couple of helpful measures for water customers, including a free notification program that would alert consumers to leaks in their faucets, toilets and internal pipes.

headline: H.P. Introduces a Tablet and New Phones
text: 11:14 a.m. | Updated  More details on availability of tablet added.

headline: Tracing Roots of Belief Across a Quarter-Century
text: In 1985 Ronald K. Brown formed a dance company and named it Evidence. That word, strong and unequivocal, traces a line to truth with the same kind of spiritual elasticity that Mr. Brown has long epitomized in his choreography. For him evidence, or grounds for belief, is rooted in dancing.

headline: Sputnik Redux: Creating Science Fair Projects
text: Overview  | What is the “Sputnik moment” to which President Obama referred in his State of the Union address, and how do educators place this comment in the context of science education? What questions and ideas do students have that can generate innovative science projects? In this lesson, students consider the current state of science fairs, explore the role of creativity and ingenuity in science, and develop science fair project proposals.

headline: Super Bowl Ads Assessed, From A to Z
text: For Madison Avenue, the mad rush to create and produce Super Bowl commercials is finished for another year. Now comes the scrutinizing of the results of myriad polls and surveys, which evaluate what consumers made of all the commercials that ran during the game.

headline: City Audit of the Water Club Reveals Holes in the Books
text: A boatload of cash — whether dinghy-sized or freighter-sized, no one can say — has washed away at a destination restaurant on the East River, potentially shortchanging the city when it needs every penny, according to an audit that the city comptroller’s office issued on Wednesday.

headline: Brown Cancels California Lease-Back Deals
text: SACRAMENTO – As states across the country struggle to deal with massive budget deficits, a number — including California — have resorted to attempting to sell state office buildings, pouring the proceeds into the general funds, and lease back the space. Arnold Schwarzenegger, the former governor of California, was one of those, moving to sell and lease back 11 state office buildings, providing $1.2 billion in revenues to a state budget that sorely needs it.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Browsing Authentic Local Fashion, Beyond the Tents
text: Stores to explore for those in town for New York Fashion Week: Assembly New York, End of Century, Gargyle and Life: Curated.

headline: Take a Number, Mr. Walrus
text: The Pacific walrus is imperiled by climate change, which is melting its icy Arctic home, and merits protection under the Endangered Species Act, the federal Fish and Wildlife Service said this week. Yet protections must wait until threats to higher-priority species are addressed, the agency said.

headline: Sites That Answer Your Money Questions
text: A recent New York Times story, “The Answers Are Out There, and New Q. and A. Sites Dig Them Up,” described how entrepreneurs were betting that there was an opportunity for a new generation of sites where users asked and answered questions. It also discussed how venture capitalists were showing their support for new question-and-answer models.

headline: Rainbow of Fireworks Strews Blackened Bouquets in China
text: BEIJING  Eardrum-piercing explosions. Choking plumes of sulfurous smoke. Showers of sparks that cascade onto homes and heads.

headline: In Nokia’s Overhaul, an Opportunity for Deals
text: Nokia’s chief executive, Stephen Elop, issued a call to arms last week, warning his troops that the company was standing on a “burning platform.”

headline: In Anguilla, Beachfront With Caribbean Style
text: A home on Anguilla is on the market for $1.75 million. It is divided into two apartments and sits on one acre of land with 200 feet of waterfront.

headline: ‘Broadway Backwards’
text: Photos from the gay-themed benefit for Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS.

headline: From the Heart | Vivienne Westwood Goes to the Palladium
text: Dame Vivienne Westwood’s collections have gone through more transformations than Jocelyn Wildenstein. From bohemian to punk and even paganism, Westwood’s pieces channel her ideas through fashion. Her latest offering, the Get a Life jewelry collection (produced in conjunction with the Palladium Alliance International), is intended to represent “hope, renewal and preservation.” Launching during London Fashion Week with a kickoff soiree at the Wallace Collection (London’s answer to the Frick), the pieces are made entirely from — you guessed it — palladium, a natural material. All of the pieces are inscribed with messages from Westwood’s eco-conscious spring/summer 2010 collection, which was called Planet Gaia. What better way to wear your heart near your sleeve? The necklace will be available to order this spring at Vivienne Westwood boutiques in Los Angeles, or go to viviennewestwood.co.uk.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Iraq, Egypt, Gaza City and Greece.

headline: TimesCast | February 9, 2011
text: Labor strikes in Egypt; a vigil in Tahrir Square; and a rare tour of Pixar's studios.

headline: House Hunting in ... Anguilla
text: A WATERFRONT HOME DIVIDED INTO TWO APARTMENTS

headline: House Republicans Take E.P.A. Chief to Task
text: WASHINGTON  Congressional Republicans on Wednesday opened a formal assault on the authority of the Environmental Protection Agency to regulate greenhouse gases, raising doubts about the legal, scientific and economic basis of rules proposed by the agency.

headline: A Fresh Face Behind a Comeback
text: GUILLAUME HENRY, the young designer behind the resurrection of the French label Carven, likes things in the middle.

headline: Another Hirschfeld of Flowing Lines. But Bloodlines? That’s a Puzzle.
text: When “Colin Quinn Long Story Short” opened at the Helen Hayes Theater in November, producers presented Mr. Quinn and the show’s director, Jerry Seinfeld, with a Hirschfeld caricature of the two.

headline: Ukraine Raises the Pressure on Opposition Leaders
text: KIEV, Ukraine  A year after taking office with a vow to pursue close ties to Russia, the Ukrainian president is overseeing a broad crackdown on the pro-Western opposition that mirrors the kind of pressure tactics used by his allies in the Kremlin.

headline: Boehner Says Republicans and President Found ‘Common Ground’ Over Lunch
text: The speaker of the House, John A. Boehner, said Wednesday that he and his fellow Republican leaders found “common ground’’ with President Obama during a lunch at the White House, but failed to reach any specific agreements on how to cut spending to reduce the federal deficit.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Iraq, Egypt, Gaza City and Greece.

headline: Republicans Fault Democrats on Vote
text: When House Republicans suffered an embarrassing defeat Tuesday in trying to pass an extension of the Patriot Act, they pointed a finger not at defiant members of their own party, but at Democrats who didn’t play along as expected.

headline: Fans Sue Cowboys and N.F.L. for Seating Fiasco
text: The seating fiasco Sunday at the Super Bowl, in which 1,200 temporary seats at Cowboys Stadium were deemed unusable shortly before the game, has produced an expected response from some angry fans: a class action lawsuit with accusations of fraud and breach of contract.

headline: Homes for $1 Million
text: An 18th-century former Quaker meetinghouse in New Jersey, a southwestern-style house in New Mexico and an architect’s bungalow in Los Angeles.

headline: Philadelphia Has the Best Lineup and It Isn’t Enough
text: The Philadelphia 76ers don’t have a go-to scorer, a promising core, a positive salary cap outlook, or the hope of championship contention in the near future. What they do have, however – as was pointed out by John Schuhmann of NBA.com -– is the single most effective lineup in the league.

headline: Just One Look | Bottega Veneta Pre-Fall Collection
text: The pre-fall collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.Tomas Maier may live in a city where it is summer pretty much year-round, but he knows that a light hand with fabric and a strong one with color can help ease the transition into fall. His pre-fall collection for Bottega Veneta was inspired largely by “Red Desert,” Michelangelo Antonioni‘s first color film. Still, it was this dress — in graphic black and white — that caught our eye.

headline: Shopping for Candelabra With Bentley Meeker
text: The Manhattan lighting designer selected candleholders to set the mood for Valentine’s Day.

headline: Medical Treatment, Out of Reach
text: Late last year, Biosensors International, a medical device company, shut down its operation in Southern California, which had once housed 90 people, including the company’s top executives and researchers.

headline: Buzz Tracker
text: A Weak WikiLeak? Remember all the noise about the Bank of America data dump being prepared by Wikileaks? Reuters reports that Julian Assange has told people that the material is dated and that “he personally was unable to make much sense of it.” Reuters

headline: What You Get for ... $1 Million
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Afghan Rights Groups Shift Focus to Taliban
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — International and local human rights groups working in Afghanistan have shifted their focus toward condemning abuses committed by the Taliban insurgents, rather than those attributed to the American military and its allies.

headline: Madison Avenue Turns to Executive Moves and Deals
text: The week or so before a Super Bowl, the flow of industry news in advertising usually slows. That makes sense, given that Super Bowl Sunday is the biggest day of the year for Madison Avenue as well as for football fans.

headline: For Rihanna’s Perfume, a Video Meant for Rewatching
text: WHEN new perfumes are introduced, fragrance companies typically mount introductory advertising campaigns that run widely in women’s fashion magazines, often including sample strips.

headline: Regulating Student Health Plans
text: Federal regulators proposed a new rule on Wednesday that would make sure the health plans offered to college students by their respective schools would have to comply with regulations in place under the health care law, according to a release from the Department of Health and Human Services.

headline: Take Me to the Revolution
text: This is the writer’s third post from the Tahrir Square protests.

headline: Sharing a Profession and Much More
text: GARANCE DORÉ, a French street-fashion blogger and illustrator, experienced the sort of shutter-quick rise that only seemed possible a few years ago, when fashion blogs were in their infancy.

headline: Conversation for Four, With Homeric Accents
text: There are moments, in the tumble of a typical improvisation, when the saxophonist Chris Potter seems to be embarked on a hero’s journey. With his strong, focused tone and top-to-bottom proficiency on the horn, he brings a robust physical presence to his playing and an onward-driving sense of purpose. His deployment of notes, parceled into staccato bursts or gracefully arcing phrases, suggests a split-second calculation of risk and reward. He works with an intuitive logic, venturing far from a theme and only gradually returning there, all the while responding to the changing conditions set by his band.

headline: The Way to Her Heart | A Valentine’s Day Cheat Sheet
text: Guys, a word to the wise on Valentine’s Day: jewelry. It’s hard to go wrong. But that doesn’t mean any old diamond bauble will do. Ask yourself, Who do you love? And shop accordingly. Silver or gold, rubies or pearls, trendy or vintage – we’ve put some thought into your Valentine’s Day gifts so you don’t have to.

headline: Pinpointing Pedestrian Deaths in New York
text: In addition to being home to the Great White Way, the Canyon of Heroes, and many other important and important-sounding things, Broadway has the dubious distinction of being the city’s deadliest street for pedestrians, according to a report released on Wednesday by the Tri-State Transportation Campaign.

headline: Psyched to Buy, in Groups
text: You might think that this column is about Groupon.com, the white-hot Web site whose coupons save you 50 to 90 percent at local businesses. But it’s not. It’s about psychology.

headline: New Light, Long After His Sun Set
text: WHEN the curtain fell on Broadway on the last night of “The Night of the Iguana” in September 1962, it would have been impossible for anyone to foresee what the next two decades would bring for its author, Tennessee Williams. Though possessed of an imagination as gothic as anyone’s, Williams probably could never have fathomed how grim the last acts of his career would become.

headline: Photos From the Broadway Backwards Benefit
text: Broadway Backwards, an annual benefit for Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS and the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual & Transgender Community Center, re-interprets the songs of musical theater by featuring women singing songs originally written for men and men singing songs written for women. This year’s show, held Monday night at the Longacre Theater, raised $281,243.

headline: Cisco Results Top Forecasts, But Growth Is Sluggish
text: SAN FRANCISCO  John T. Chambers, Cisco Systems’ chief executive, did little Wednesday to lift the dark cloud hanging over his company by reporting sluggish growth in its fiscal second quarter and making a disappointing forecast.

headline: Getting His Close-Up for Hollywood’s Top Lobbying Job: Senator Dodd
text: As the search for a new chairman of the Motion Picture Association of America grinds on, a longtime candidate has entered into negotiations for the job.

headline: Closed Captioning on Netflix Movies
text: Q. On a Roku XD player, is there a way to get closed captions on those Netflix movies that offer them? I am hard of hearing and closed captions are crucial to me.

headline: The Many Faces of ‘Black Swan,’ Deconstructed
text: Few ballet films excite popular fascination, and almost none to the degree of “Black Swan.” This month, it’s up for five Oscars. So why has it so intrigued academy voters and the public alike? Surely because it exerts its lurid appeal on multiple levels.

headline: Iranian Claims Chess Record
text: To the intense rivalry between Israel and Iran add another facet: the game of chess.

headline: ‘NCIS’ Lifts CBS
text: Despite attracting 26.8 million viewers following the Super Bowl on Sunday, Fox’s hit musical series “Glee” drew only slightly better ratings than usual on Tuesday. According to Nielsen’s estimates 11.5 million tuned in to “Glee” at 8 p.m., up modestly from the 11.1 million who watched the show’s last Tuesday episode in December. Although “Glee” led the night among 18-to-49-year-old viewers, the show’s audience paled in comparison with the 20.3 million who watched CBS’s “NCIS” in the same time slot. CBS ranked No. 1 over all, winning both the 9 and 10 p.m. time slots with “NCIS: Los Angeles” (17.1 million) and “The Good Wife” (11.8 million). After “Glee” Fox earned lower ratings for its comedies “Raising Hope” (6.8 million) and “Traffic Light,” which garnered a disappointing 4.6 million viewers in its premiere at 9:30. NBC was third, and ABC placed fourth.

headline: Checking Out a Lot of Beers, Without the Hangover
text: My attention was elsewhere when the craft beer craze started, so I was caught off guard when my friends started talking about ales with a kind of snootiness one normally finds at a Grand Cru wine tasting.

headline: App Can’t Replace Confession, Vatican Says
text: A new application being sold on iTunes, “Confession: a Roman Catholic App,” cannot be used as a substitute for confession with a priest, the Vatican said Wednesday. The application was developed by American entrepreneurs with the help of two priests and the blessing of a bishop. It features a questionnaire of sins, and is promoted as a tool both to revive interest in confession and to help Catholics prepare for the sacrament. But some media reports cast the app as a “virtual priest” for Catholics who do not have time for church, prompting the Rev. Federico Lombardi, the Vatican spokesman, to respond, “One cannot speak in any way of ‘confession by iPhone.’ ”

headline: François Nars: Behind the Makeup, a Low-Profile Artist
text: TODAY, the first stand-alone store of Nars, the makeup brand known for its sleek black packaging and luscious color range, will open on Bleecker Street in Manhattan. Like its creator, the Frenchman François Nars, the store is a study in contrasts. Close to Marc Jacobs’s cluster of boutiques and the Magnolia Bakery, it has Old World charm, with moldings and a marble fireplace from Chesney’s. In line with today’s eco-conscious imperatives, its distressed black-stained wood floors are reclaimed from the Ohio River Valley.

headline: The Sex Life of Parents
text: As Valentine’s Day approaches, thoughts turn to romance. If you have young children, Lisa Tucker McElroy writes in a guest post today, those thoughts are not what they once were.

headline: A Playwright Whose Time Seems to Be Now
text: Writing a play about the death penalty should put you squarely in the middle of a moral debate. Yet Nathan Louis Jackson, whose “When I Come to Die” traces the emotional turmoil of an inmate whose execution goes mysteriously awry, insists that his play is not political and that it takes no sides.

headline: Conservative Leader Steps Down on Eve of Conference
text: David Keene, the longtime leader of the group that sponsors the annual Conservative Political Action Conference, officially stepped down on Wednesday, a day before the 2011 conference begins.

headline: E.P.A. and Carbon Dioxide: The Prequel
text: As a committee of the Republican-controlled House settled in to interrogate the Environmental Protection Agency’s administrator, Lisa P. Jackson, about her agency’s efforts to regulate greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide, a senior House Democrat released three-year old documents showing that the Bush administration’s E.P.A. sought to follow exactly the same course.

headline: Inflation, in One Picture
text: On Capitol Hill, members of Congress are grilling Ben Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, about his attempts to lift economic growth by reducing long-term interest rates — the Fed’s so-called Q.E.2 program, or quantitative easing. Some members of Congress think Mr. Bernanke is fighting the wrong battle. They want him to take steps to stamp out inflation, which they believe is dangerously high or soon will be.

headline: Social Apps for Losing Weight
text: These apps and Web sites can help you lose weight the social way.

headline: A $60,000 Payday for Parkinson’s Disease
text: Zeke Jabbour of Boca Raton, Fla., an eight-time national champion, organizes an annual charity bridge event for the Parkinson Foundation. This year’s, held last month at St. Andrews Country Club in Boca Raton, raised nearly $60,000.

headline: A 16th-Century Palazzo in Palermo
text: In Italy, two art collectors established a home and a gallery in a building that once belonged to a prince.

headline: Apps to Share Your Pride at the Gym
text: About four years ago, when I started working at home, I plugged into a laptop to write about Silicon Valley. I made thousands of new friends on Facebook and Twitter, and, thanks to the proximity of my refrigerator, put an additional 35 pounds on an already rotund body.

headline: A Toyota Timeline
text: On Tuesday, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration ruled that no software glitches or electronic malfunctions would have caused Toyota vehicles to accelerate against their drivers’ wishes, instead faulting previously identified mechanical problems. As Matthew L. Wald wrote in The New York Times,

headline: 15% of High School Seniors Passed an A.P. Test Last Year
text: 12:07 p.m. Thursday | Update

headline: As Investors Become Savvy, an Intermediary Loses Favor
text: After the financial crisis, the Alberta Teachers’ Retirement Fund decided to reassess its strategy. At the time, the Canadian pension had roughly $150 million, or 3 percent of its assets, devoted to private equity, with the bulk in so-called funds of funds that invest across several different portfolios.

headline: Animation Advocacy, Pixar Style
text: EMERYVILLE, Calif.  Sheriff Woody was doing some unnatural things. Of course, he’s a cartoon character, an invention of the wizzes at Pixar, but on the screen in front of me, Woody  voiced by Tom Hanks in the “Toy Story” franchise  was spinning his neck uncontrollably, torquing it to “Exorcist” angles and grinning while he did it. I moved the mouse and watched him convulse. Oh, man, animation is fun.

headline: Scotland Yard Expands its Hacking Inquiry
text: After reopening its investigation into telephone hacking by the News of the World, Scotland Yard said Wednesday that it was going to contact more people who may have had their voicemail messages illegally intercepted by reporters at the London newspaper.

headline: Iran’s Chief Prosecutor Criticizes Planned Rally Backing Revolts
text: TEHRAN  Iran’s chief prosecutor on Wednesday called an opposition request to hold a rally in support of the uprisings in Tunisia and Egypt “divisive” and “political.” His comments suggested that officials would not grant permission for the rally, planned for Monday.

headline: New York Congressman Resigns Over Shirtless Photo
text: Update, Feb. 10 Read the final version of this article that ran in Thursday’s newspaper.

headline: When Hats Had Heart
text: Remember when hats were hattier?

headline: Downtown Skyscraper for the Digital Age
text: Many New Yorkers have been following the construction of the new residential tower at 8 Spruce Street, just south of City Hall, with a mix of awe and trepidation.

headline: New York Congressman Resigns Over Shirtless Photo
text: Representative Chris Lee of New York, caught in the midst of a scandal involving a shirtless photo he reportedly sent to a woman on the Internet, has stepped down, according to a senior Congressional official. Read more on City Room…

headline: Success of Spina Bifida Study Opens Fetal Surgery Door
text: For years, surgeons have been trying to find ways of operating on babies in the womb, reasoning that medical abnormalities might be more easily fixed while a fetus is still developing. But with tremendous risks to babies and mothers, and a mixed record of success, fetal surgery is mostly used when babies are likely to die otherwise.

headline: An Oscar Front-Runner Amps Up the Campaigning
text: The Oscar front-runner, “The King’s Speech,” hasn’t stopped with the campaigning, holding dinners and picking up even more awards on both coasts, as Melena Ryzik writes on the Carpetbagger blog.  (The post, which had been here, has moved to Carpetbagger, where it belongs in this awards season.)

headline: Race Directors Raise Concern Over Proposed Police Fee
text: In an effort to generate revenue to cope with the city’s budget deficit, the New York Police Department wants to charge the organizers of the New York City Marathon and dozens of other races the full cost of controlling traffic and other services.

headline: An Oscar Front-Runner Amps Up the Campaigning
text: As promised, back to our regularly scheduled programming. Where were we? Oh yeah: at this point, who isn’t in the tank for “The King’s Speech”?

headline: A Seamless Addition to the Skyline
text: Frank Gehry’s new residential tower at 8 Spruce Street, clad in a rumpled stainless-steel skin that helps it blend into the skyline, stands at the northern edge of the financial district.

headline: Piet Oudolf’s Cold Weather Landscapes
text: A look at how the Dutch designer uses form and texture in his winter gardens.

headline: Q&A: Piet Oudolf on Designing a Winter Garden
text: GARDENS in winter are typically deemed dormant, but Piet Oudolf believes that they shouldn’t be. Mr. Oudolf, who is Dutch, is the leading exemplar of the New Perennials landscape movement, which holds that plants should be chosen for shape and texture more than for color.

headline: In a 16th-Century Palazzo, Home for Art
text: Palermo, Italy

headline: Sales at Aero, Alessi, Modani and OLighting
text: At the Aero sale, through March 5, lamps, furniture, rugs and baskets are at least 25 percent off, and some vintage furnishings and holiday items are as much as 75 percent off (a Chippendale occasional chair in bone leather, originally $2,997, is $950; the Dara bar stool by Thomas O’Brien for Hickory Chair, regularly $1,386, is $550); 419 Broome Street (Lafayette Street), (212) 966-1500, aerostudios.com.

headline: A Feng Shui Cube Brings Intimacy to a Loft
text: THERE was a time when Liu Ming, a teacher of Chinese traditional medicine and feng shui in Oakland, Calif., did a few hundred prostrations a day as part of his practice of Tibetan Buddhism  full prostrations, that is, in which you begin standing and end with your head on the floor. That wouldn’t work these days, as Mr. Liu’s meditation area is on top of an eight-foot cube in his loft. Were he to stand up, Mr. Liu would hit his head on the ceiling.

headline: Oxo Introduces a Children’s Collection
text: “There were 27 babies born to employees of our company in the five years prior to launching this line,” said Alex Lee, president of Oxo, explaining the company’s foray into children’s goods with the Oxo Tot line.

headline: Diane Von Furstenberg Moves Into Housewares
text: Everything happens in bed, Diane Von Furstenberg was saying last week while explaining the latest spinoff from her wrap-dress empire, DVF Home.

headline: Backgammon Tables, Without the Clubby Feel
text: “To us, a backgammon table is like a fireplace — you’ve got to have one,” Louise Brooks, a partner in Oomph, said of the design company’s latest creation. “We felt there was a huge need for a backgammon table that didn’t look like it belonged in a men’s club. Something more fun than mahogany with ball-and-claw feet.”

headline: Candelabra
text: BENTLEY MEEKER, a Manhattan designer, has been in business for 20 years, creating lighting for events as diverse as weddings (he did Chelsea Clinton’s) and concerts (Kanye West, Aerosmith and Elton John are all clients).

headline: A New Act for a Midcentury Sofa
text: Like a great midcentury screen siren, the Valentine sofa refuses to be upstaged by anyone or anything in the room.

headline: Speck by Speck, Dust Piles Up
text: THE world has a dust problem. There is more of it than there used to be. Apparently, the amount of airborne dust doubled in the 20th century, according to a recent scientific paper in the journal Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics.

headline: Annie Modica on Turning Crafts Into Collectibles
text: If you are an artsy-craftsy sort whose friends are always saying you should take those fabulous whatevers you make and start a business, you might want to meet Annie Modica, of Mill Valley, Calif. Ms. Modica started out making decoupage trays in her dining room about 15 years ago, and last year she billed about $750,000. Her decoupage home accessories — every one of which bears her fat and happy signature — are carried by Saks Fifth Avenue and Gracious Home, and they are not inexpensive. Her trays can run as much as $400.

headline: Poems of Pain, the Raw and the Remembered
text: Cancer and racism, immigration and terrorism: each topic is a predictable way station on the circuit of the 24-hour news cycle. In the following books, though, poets wrestle with these staples of newspaper and TV headlines (and much more) and alchemize them from eye-glazing abstractions into well-wrought literary gold.

headline: Cuomo Says He’ll Push for Vote to Legalize Same-Sex Marriage
text: ALBANY  Fourteen months after the State Senate soundly rejected legislation that would have legalized same-sex marriage, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is preparing to pursue another vote on the matter in the next few months.

headline: A Rapper Loves America, but Don’t Expect Another British Invasion
text: In the back of S.O.B.’s on Tuesday night, the members of N-Dubz, a sort of British version of the Black Eyed Peas, were being filmed by their own videographer as they did, well, not very much. They weren’t there to perform, so they stood and looked at the stage. Sometimes they whispered to one another. Sometimes they mouthed along to the songs playing over the loudspeaker. Throughout, the camera, unlike the people in the room, stayed focused on them.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Kitchen Technology
text: This week’s Bits: Tech Talk show gets into the kitchen. Bettina Edelstein chats with Jeff Potter, author of “Cooking for Geeks: Real Science, Great Hacks and Good Food.” Mr. Potter, who has a background in software engineering, says one of his goals is to explain how cooking works. His book also includes recipes and interviews with food scientists, food bloggers and technologists. If you’ve ever wondered how to make ice cream in 30 seconds using liquid nitrogen, he’s your man.

headline: Yuzu Chiffon Cake
text: For the cake:

headline: Japanese Coffee Products
text: A. The woodneck has a cloth filter that makes a coffee with exceptional clarity. The device is also called a “nel drip” — “nel” is short for “flannel.”

headline: A Circus That Lets Its Freak Flag Fly
text: Los Angeles

headline: Coffee’s Slow Dance
text: A few years ago, I mothballed the fantasy of getting a professional-grade espresso machine and setting it up in the kitchen next to the meat slicer. In part, I gave up because of cost. It turns out a starter machine runs about $600, and if I wanted to own the same technology and firepower as what’s on the counter of the coffee bar around the corner, the price jumped to $6,500. Thermal-stable dual-boiler systems, assembled by hand in Italy, don’t come cheaply.

headline: Another Season, Another Show
text: AT the close of Joseph Altuzarra’s fashion show in Chelsea last September, spectators sprang to their feet, jostling toward the far end of the runway to congratulate the designer, or maybe just to bask in his glow. Within moments, industry power brokers like Linda Fargo, the sleekly imposing fashion director of Bergdorf Goodman; Simon Doonan of Barneys New York, and a visibly captivated Hamish Bowles of Vogue were rushing backstage to throw their arms around Mr. Altuzarra and to pose for the scrum of paparazzi bellowing their names.

headline: Stepping Carefully in Commodities Markets
text: IS there a way to invest in inflation-tracking vehicles that also benefit from growth in emerging markets?

headline: Yankees Add Luis Ayala to Bullpen
text: The Yankees agreed to a minor league deal with the right-handed reliever Luis Ayala, who has not pitched in the majors since 2009.

headline: Innovation Far Removed From the Lab
text: Daniel Reetz loves trash bins. A big one in Fargo, N.D., was where he found most of the materials he used to build a scanner that was fast enough to scan a 400-page book in about 20 minutes without cracking the binding. The two Canon PowerShot A590 cameras and two lights that he lashed together with a few pieces of acrylic and wood cost him about $300 in all, considerably less than the $10,000 commercial book scanners that were on the market.

headline: In This Market, Safe May Be the New Risky
text: EVEN though the bear market officially ended nearly two years ago, investors have shown a stubborn aversion to risk since then. The usually reliable steps taken to protect portfolios may prove ineffective, however, some investment professionals warn. In this market backdrop, safe may be the new risky.

headline: The Hands-On Investor
text: JEANNIE KRIEGER is not your average widowed grandmother.

headline: Certainty on Tax, but Just for Two Years
text: WHEN Robert Hassler of Larchmont, N.Y., went to see a lawyer last fall about devising an estate plan, he received two pieces of unexpected advice: wait until Congress enacted changes in tax law, which it did in December, and remain flexible in your planning, so that whatever you do will withstand further changes from Congress.

headline: What Level of Risk Can You Tolerate?
text: WERE you among the millions of investors who stampeded out of stocks in 2008 and corralled most of your liquid assets into bonds?

headline: A Late Oscar Push for ‘Inception’
text: LOS ANGELES— Warner Brothers has had a nightmarish Oscar season. First, “The Town” ran out of gas. Clint Eastwood’s “Hereafter” didn’t seem to have any to begin with. Then Christopher Nolan failed to get a directing nomination for “Inception.” But none of that is stopping the studio from making another campaign push, doubling down on its dreamworld thriller.

headline: Efforts to Avoid Probate Can Carry Their Own Risks
text: THE new tax law signed by President Obama in December gives many people a reason to revise their estate plans. In the process, some will try to avoid probate. Others may be surprised to find that much of what they leave behind will not go through probate anyway.

headline: Tax Cut Deal Could Benefit Charities
text: ALTHOUGH many critics have denounced the tax deal reached in December by Congressional leaders and the Obama administration as tax cuts for the rich, personal wealth advisers who specialize in philanthropy also foresee benefits for charities.

headline: As Their Attendance Falls, Mets Try Giving Tickets Away
text: By most standards, the Mets have had an off-season to forget. Yes, they hired a new manager and several high-profile executives, including Sandy Alderson as general manager. But, despite two straight fourth-place finishes, the Mets have not signed any star players, and they let several key players go, including the pitchers Pedro Feliciano and Hisanori Takahashi.

headline: Dead Zone for iPhones No More
text: Four years and a few upgrades ago, the first iPhones were sold in the United States.

headline: Adjusting Insurance to Fit Your Needs
text: WHEN a 1930 Duesenberg Dual Cowl Phaeton came up for bidding at a recent vintage-car auction in Scottsdale, Ariz., Jim Fiske, an insurance executive, surveyed the clutch of well-heeled bidders.

headline: A Battle Across the Border in Recruiting
text: Patrick McCarron, 16, is a defenseman with the St. Michael’s Buzzers in Toronto, a team owned by his father that plays in provincial Junior A hockey. Last summer, McCarron was drafted by the Oshawa Generals of the Ontario Hockey League. The Generals put a contract in front of him, but he would not sign it.

headline: Russia: Expelled British Journalist Offered New Visa
text: A British journalist who was expelled from Russia over the weekend is considering an offer from the Russian Foreign Ministry to receive a new visa and return to work in Moscow, his newspaper said Wednesday. The journalist, Luke Harding of The Guardian, left, was detained after landing at a Moscow airport and sent back to London despite having a journalist’s visa in his passport. Russian officials at first refused to explain why Mr. Harding was deported, then said that he had violated rules for foreign correspondents because he did not pick up a press card. Mr. Harding and his editors have suggested that he was expelled because Russian authorities were displeased with his coverage. On Wednesday, it appeared that the Russian Foreign Ministry was all but acknowledging that the authorities had made a mistake and were trying to persuade Mr. Harding to return.

headline: Life Lessons for Children on a Family Vacation
text: JOHN-PIERRE L. CONTE approaches family travel planning the same way he approaches other aspects of his busy life. “I hire the best people, they start out with a template, and I do the editing,” said Mr. Conte, a single father of four children, ages 2 to 12, and chairman of Genstar Capital, a private equity firm based in San Francisco.

headline: Britain: Crematory to Heat Swimming Pool
text: Sharp government spending cuts have forced contentious choices on local authorities, perhaps none more so than one council’s decision to heat a community swimming pool with energy diverted from a crematory. The council in Redditch, near Birmingham, has approved the diversion of waste heat from the crematory’s incinerator to a next-door leisure center and its new pool. Councilor Carole Gandy said the plan was consistent with the need for energy efficiency and had been widely backed by local residents once officials had explained the technology involved, which she described as common elsewhere in Europe. Labor union officials said the plan encapsulated the extremes forced on local authorities by national austerity cuts. Roger McKenzie, regional secretary for Unison, Britain’s largest public sector union, condemned the plan as “sick and an insult to local residents.”

headline: The New Knits of M. Patmos
text: New York Fashion Week starts Thursday, right? Not quite. A number of independent designers got a jump on the season with small presentations around the city, and one of the sharpest shown on Wednesday belonged to Marcia Patmos. (See the full collection.)

headline: Counting by Race Can Throw Off Some Numbers
text: The federal Department of Education would categorize Michelle López-Mullins — a university student who is of Peruvian, Chinese, Irish, Shawnee and Cherokee descent — as “Hispanic.” But the National Center for Health Statistics, the government agency that tracks data on births and deaths, would pronounce her “Asian” and "Hispanic." And what does Ms. López-Mullins’s birth certificate from the State of Maryland say? It doesn’t mention her race.

headline: Israel: Unions Threaten to Strike Over Rising Prices
text: Israeli union officials threatened Wednesday to call a general strike to protest recent price increases that have sent the cost of gasoline, water and basic foods spiraling upward. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is expected to announce measures to ease the burden on the public on Thursday. A news conference was originally planned for Wednesday but was postponed after Finance Minister Yuval Steinitz was hospitalized, suffering from flu and exhaustion. Mr. Netanyahu is facing growing public anger over the increases: the cost of gasoline has gone up by 13 percent, the price of water has increased by more than 100 percent and many basic food items have risen by up to 8 percent over the past year.

headline: Tax-Free Life Insurance: An Untapped Investment for the Affluent
text: IT’S viewed as an insider’s secret for the affluent: a legal way to invest in hedge funds and other potentially lucrative assets, all without paying taxes on the gains.

headline: France: President Tells Ministers to Vacation at Home
text: President Nicolas Sarkozy tried to put a lid on the political furor over senior ministers’ taking free flights in Tunisia and Egypt last Christmas by telling his cabinet to vacation in France. Mr. Sarkozy said that government ministers would now have to get permission from the prime minister’s office before accepting invitations to visit other countries. Prime Minister François Fillon vacationed with his family last year at the invitation and expense of the Egyptian government. Foreign Minister Michèle Alliot-Marie vacationed in Tunisia when demonstrations were already under way and accepted two free flights from a businessman close to the family of Tunisia’s president, who was later ousted.

headline: Birding in the Lower Rio Grande
text: The Rio Grande Valley is South Texas’s birding mecca.

headline: Fake Twitter Accounts Get Real Laughs
text: WASHINGTON — When a blizzard blanketed Chicago last week, “Rahm Emanuel” took to Twitter to chronicle his day — making a snow angel on Lake Michigan, shoveling out David Axelrod’s Civic, drinking whiskey in an igloo made by a tireless campaign intern named Carl.

headline: Jordan: New Cabinet Members Are Sworn In
text: Eight days after King Abdullah II fired his cabinet and named a new prime minister, the rest of the new government was sworn in on Wednesday. The 27-member cabinet included a number of holdovers  notably the foreign, interior and economy ministers  as well as a few leftists. The opposition Muslim Brotherhood, which declined an invitation to be part of the government, said it was less interested in who held the portfolios than what they would do. Prime Minister Marouf al-Bakhit promised to institute a fairer election law and a more liberal public assembly law. The government was expected to maintain its close ties to the United States.

headline: Isles, Their Luck Long Gone, Are Nearly Out of Goalies, Too
text: Kevin Poulin, the 20-year-old Islanders goaltender who had been the latest replacement for the often-injured Rick DiPietro, will miss the rest of the season after dislocating his left kneecap while warming up for a game Tuesday, the team said.

headline: Doing Well After Not Knowing What to Do
text: When Gregory Auditore balked at the time and expense required to get a college degree, his mother, Margaret, a nurse, suggested a compromise: Put in two years of study, become a certified radiology technician, and start making $25 an hour. (His first job paid $32 an hour, a windfall.) Mr. Auditore, 21, graduated from the School of Radiologic Technology at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn in 2009 and is employed by Continuum Health Partners as an X-ray technician at Beth Israel Medical Center. He lives on Staten Island with his parents.

headline: New Questions Raised in Mortgage Financing
text: Banks have been fighting with disgruntled bond investors and insurers for months, arguing that they do not need to buy back soured mortgages they placed inside securities before the financial crisis.

headline: Wake Forest Baseball Coach Donates Kidney to Player
text: ATLANTA  When Wake Forest offered him a baseball scholarship, outfielder Kevin Jordan focused his research on what any high school athlete would: the opportunity for playing time.

headline: Costs Soaring, New Jersey Bond Rating Is Lowered
text: A top credit-rating firm lowered New Jersey’s bond rating on Wednesday, citing ballooning pension and other costs, and Gov. Chris Christie and Democrats in the Legislature wasted no time in blaming each other.

headline: Hotels Offer Their Own Fashion Events
text: Hotels in New York City have long offered after-parties during fashion week. But this season, the trend extends beyond inviting well-paid international DJs to spin for the fashion set when the shows are over. Hotels are increasingly taking their marketing a step further by pairing up with designers and fashion purveyors to host their own shows and events. Here’s what a few lodgings are doing this season:

headline: Playing Catch-Up, Nokia and H.P. Try to Innovate

headline: House Republicans Battle Turmoil in Their Ranks
text: WASHINGTON — Under pressure to make deeper spending cuts and blindsided by embarrassing floor defeats, House Republican leaders are quickly discovering the limits of control over their ideologically driven and independent-minded new majority.

headline: U.S. Proposes Aquaculture Guidelines
text: The federal government on Wednesday issued the nation’s first policy guidelines for aquaculture, opening the way for farm-raised seafood to be produced in federal waters as long as the operations do not threaten wild fish stocks or saltwater ecosystems.

headline: Delay of State Money for Merger May Force a Hospital in Brooklyn to Close
text: A struggling Brooklyn hospital is making plans to shut down in March after a decision by the Cuomo administration to delay grants to help finance a merger intended to rescue the institution, officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Cloud Follows UConn as It Changes Course
text: The University of Connecticut men’s basketball team is in the midst of an abrupt and surprising turnaround. After finishing 18-16 last season, the Huskies are ranked 10th nationally, have a star in guard Kemba Walker and appear poised for a top seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Team Chosen for Work on Big Middle-Income Complex in Queens
text: The Bloomberg administration announced Wednesday that it had selected a team led by the Related Companies to construct the first phase of a development on the Queens waterfront that will be the largest middle-income complex built in the city since the 1970s.

headline: New Star in the Front Row
text: FOR two reasons, the choice of Emmanuelle Alt as editor in chief of French Vogue, in January, was anticlimactic. First, there was all the weirdness of her predecessor’s departure. Was Carine Roitfeld, who held the post for 10 years, fired or did she resign, as Condé Nast maintained? Second, the swift promotion of Ms. Alt from the No. 2 position of fashion director suggested that her bosses weren’t looking for much change. As she herself said, “They know my work by heart, and probably they felt like it was safe for them.”

headline: City Settles Suit in Death of an Inmate
text: The City of New York has agreed to pay over half a million dollars to settle a wrongful death lawsuit filed by the family of a South Carolina man who was killed  while in custody on Rikers Island in 2009.

headline: Even if Loughner Doesn’t Testify, Jurors Could See Videos, Officials Say
text: TUCSON  Videotaped messages recovered from a computer at the home of Jared L. Loughner, the man accused of opening fire at a congresswoman’s public event in Tucson last month, could mean that a jury will hear from Mr. Loughner in his own words even though he is unlikely to testify at trial, law enforcement officials said.

headline: As Verizon’s iPhone Sales Begin, Gauging the Effects on AT&T
text: The race between AT&T and Verizon Wireless kicks into hyperdrive on Thursday as Verizon begins selling the iPhone 4 to new customers, ending AT&T’s exclusive hold on the phone in the United States.

headline: Century Club Letters About the Garrick
text: Letters from the Century club’s president and its members show differing opinions on whether to continue a relationship with the all-male Garrick club in London.

headline: Charges Against Muslim Students Prompt Debate Over Free Speech

text: THE pale yellow dress by Isabel Toledo she wore at the inauguration. The Jason Wu ivory chiffon gown she danced in. Thakoon Panichgul’s magenta frock she packed for Europe.

headline: Lawmakers Hear of Threat by Domestic Terrorists
text: WASHINGTON  The House Homeland Security Committee on Wednesday opened a wide-ranging review of terrorist threats facing the United States as the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks approaches.

headline: Brown Cancels Predecessor’s Deal to Sell State Buildings
text: SACRAMENTO  As states across the country struggle to deal with overwhelming budget deficits, a number of state officials, including those in California, have resorted to trying to sell state office buildings, pouring the proceeds into the general funds, and then leasing back the space.

headline: New York Congressman Resigns Over E-Mails
text: WASHINGTON  Representative Christopher Lee of New York abruptly resigned on Wednesday night after a shirtless photo of himself, which he had e-mailed to a woman, was published on the Internet.

headline: Virginia Democrat Opts to Stop at One Senate Term
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Jim Webb, Democrat of Virginia, has decided not to run for re-election, avoiding a blockbuster rematch with the man he beat in 2006, George Allen, and giving Senate Republicans another opportunity to try to reclaim the majority.

headline: Implications of Study on Breast Cancer
text: An article on Wednesday described how a routine procedure for the treatment of early breast cancer  the surgical removal of cancerous lymph nodes from the armpit  has been found unnecessary for many patients. The finding turns 100 years of standard medical practice on its head. The author of the article, Denise Grady, answered questions online from readers about the finding and its implications. More at nytimes.com/science.

headline: North Carolina Man Admits to Aiding a Jihadist Plot
text: Daniel Patrick Boyd, a North Carolina man whose arrest on terrorism-related charges surprised the residents of his bucolic town, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court in New Bern, N.C., on Wednesday to conspiring to assist violent jihadists and to participate in attacks in foreign countries, Justice Department officials said.

headline: Obama Recognizes Men Who Died in the Collapse of a Radar Tower in 1961
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Wednesday recognized 28 men who died when their cold war radar station collapsed into the Atlantic Ocean 50 years ago.

headline: Police and Firefighters Vow to Fight Bloomberg’s Plan to Cut a Retirement Benefit
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s proposal to strip a treasured perquisite that retired police officers and firefighters won under the Lindsay administration four decades ago has driven a deep wedge between himself and the unions representing uniformed personnel.

headline: Wired and Shrewd, Young Egyptians Guide Revolt
text: CAIRO  They were born roughly around the time that President Hosni Mubarak first came to power, most earned degrees from their country’s top universities and all have spent their adult lives bridling at the restrictions of the Egyptian police state  some undergoing repeated arrests and torture for the cause.

headline: Two Construction Workers in Fatal Fall Are Recalled as Dedicated Family Men
text: The two men worked in construction for 30 years, their passion for building equaled only by the dedication they had for their families.

headline: Thursday: Red Hot Chili Pepper
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Where do you start in a crossword puzzle? Some people insist on starting at 1 Across every time. Me, I look for any easy entry into the grid. And because I’m basically an overgrown child, my first conquest today was 24 Across: MERRIE Melodies.

headline: Unions to Press Chase on Modifying Additional Mortgages
text: Leaders of two large New York City unions said Wednesday that they would push for their pension funds to sell their stocks and bonds in JPMorgan Chase if the bank did not help more struggling homeowners avoid foreclosure.

headline: Gawker’s Scoop Draws Eyes to a New Format
text: Representative Christopher Lee’s sudden resignation on Wednesday was triggered by an article on Gawker, the Manhattan-based gossip Web site.

headline: Judge’s Rush for Vacation Marred Murder Trial, Appeals Lawyer Argues
text: The 2009 conviction of a Queens doctor for hiring a relative to fatally shoot her husband outside a Queens playground was marred by hearsay and a distracted judge who wanted to get to a tropical vacation, the celebrity lawyer Alan M. Dershowitz argued in an appellate hearing on Wednesday.
