headline: Toronto Exchange Merger May Be Capitalist Test for Canada
text: More than the queen’s visage on their money binds the financial centers of London and Toronto. They are two of the world’s preferred destinations for raising capital in the mining and metals businesses. So sort of a merger of equals, like the one announced by the TMX Group and the London Stock Exchange, carries strong industrial logic.

headline: Syria Restores Access to Facebook and YouTube
text: The Syrian government began allowing its citizens Wednesday to openly use Facebook and YouTube, three years after blocking access to Facebook and other sites as part of a crackdown on political activism. Human rights advocates greeted the news guardedly, warning that the government might have lifted the ban to more closely monitor people and activity on social networking sites.

headline: Jeers and Big-Game Feel Greet High-Profile Visitor
text: For a good part of this season, the Knicks have not stunk as badly and as regularly as they did in the past decade. This made it possible for New Yorkers to remember they actually love this sport, not hate it, the way so many fans had begun to feel.

headline: Missouri: Busch Friend Died of Drug Overdose
text: The woman found dead last month at the home of August Busch IV, the former head of Anheuser-Busch, died of an accidental overdose of oxycodone, a powerful prescription painkiller that is sometimes used recreationally, the St. Louis County medical examiner said Wednesday. The woman, Adrienne Martin, 27, had been in a relationship with Mr. Busch, 46, who was C.E.O. of the company his family founded when it was sold to a Belgian company, InBev, three years ago. The rest of the results, including a toxicology report that would show whether any other drugs were in her system, were forwarded to the county prosecutor’s office, which is investigating the case, and not released.

headline: Mark J. Hulkower, Who Prosecuted Aldrich Ames, Dies at 53
text: Mark J. Hulkower, who successfully prosecuted one of the nation’s most notorious traitors and followed up by defending high-profile executives accused of white-collar crimes, died on Saturday in Arlington, Va. He was 53.

headline: At a Club for Civil Discussions, Polarizing Debate
text: A prominent author was startled by the ferocious tone of the debate. “Some of the rhetoric,” she said, “was scary.” A wealthy art collector stopped logging into his e-mail account, for fear of discovering yet another new screed. And by the end, an acclaimed cultural critic could barely stand to look at people she had once considered close friends. “I just try not to think of what they said when I see them,” she said.

headline: What Would Shirley Do?
text: The news that 41 percent of pregnancies in New York City end in abortion was eye-catching enough, but what really caught my eye in a report on the statistic were the comments of a New York legislator, State Senator Rubén Díaz Sr. “They might think that we will take over, and that they’ve got to stop us,” Senator Díaz was quoted as having told a group of fellow anti-abortion ministers last month. “What they did, they are killing black and Hispanic children.”

headline: Stoudemire Says Focus, but Knicks Don’t Listen
text: Blake Griffin did not venture outside the laws of gravity. He did not bend minds or rims or emasculate any Knicks on Wednesday night in his Madison Square Garden debut.

headline: What Egyptian Repression Looks Like
text: In my column today, I talk about two videos that demonstrate the brutality exhibited by elements of the Egyptian regime. Both have been on TV, but if you haven’t seen them take a look. They’re stomach-churning, and I think that after seeing them you’ll find that it’s harder to counsel stability, patience, and order.You understand more clearly why young people want change so fervently and are so distrustful of the regime.

headline: Police Say Worker Took Late-Book Fees
text: A Yonkers woman has been charged with stealing more than $160,000 from the Yonkers Public Library over seven years  money that came in large part from overdue book fines, the authorities said on Wednesday.

headline: Françoise Cachin, a Director of French Museums, Dies at 74
text: Françoise Cachin, a museum director who helped found the Musée d’Orsay in Paris, organized major exhibitions of modern art and wrote important books on 19th-century French painting, died on Friday. She was 74.

headline: Alan Slifka, Who Promoted Arab-Jewish Ties, Is Dead at 81
text: Alan B. Slifka, a New York investment manager who used his fortune to promote harmony among Israeli Arabs and Jews and to give the Big Apple Circus its start, died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 81 and also had a home in Manhattan.

headline: Digging a Hole Instead of a Tunnel
text: With states and cities in such a bad way, it is worth remembering how a previous generation rebuilt America during the Depression’s bleakest years. The elegant George Washington Bridge opened in 1931. The Triborough Bridge followed five years later. Ribbons were cut for the Lincoln Tunnel in 1937, and La Guardia Airport opened officially in 1939.

headline: Don’t Worry. Be Happy.
text: In troubled times it’s important to pace yourself. There’s only so much you can worry about at once, and we’ve already got Egypt, the weird weather, rising food prices and unemployment. Plus, the secretary of homeland security says the terror threat is really high. It would be at least reddish-orange if we hadn’t gotten rid of the color code.

headline: A Debate Bigger Than Reform
text: While the federal courts consider whether the health care reform law is constitutional, there is an intense and even wider debate playing out in political and legal circles about the Constitution and Congress’s power to solve national problems.

headline: Obama and Egypt’s Future
text: In Tahrir Square, I saw a young man holding a sign over his head. The sign urged President Hosni Mubarak to flee the country: “Hurry up! My arms are tired.”

headline: Relief for States and Businesses
text: So many people now receive jobless benefits that 30 states have run out of their unemployment trust funds and are borrowing $42 billion from the federal government. Three of the hardest-hit states  Michigan, Indiana and South Carolina  have borrowed so much that they triggered automatic unemployment tax increases on employers, and the same thing is likely to happen to 20 more states this year.

headline: .24 Karat Gall
text: When we last wrote about National Collector’s Mint, in 2004, the company was in trouble with New York’s attorney general for selling Sept. 11 commemorative coins that it claimed were legal tender from the Northern Mariana Islands, supposedly struck from silver recovered at ground zero. It was a galling case of deceptive advertising for which the state extracted more than $2 million in fines and penalties.

headline: North Korea Reacts Angrily to Breakdown of Talks
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea reacted angrily Thursday to the breakdown of preliminary military talks with South Korea, saying the "scoundrels” and "traitors” in the South were not interested in a genuine dialogue and were trying to derail the resumption of six-party talks involving the North’s nuclear programs.

headline: Queens Little League Coach Is Accused of Sex Assault

headline: Hackers Breach Tech Systems of Oil Companies
text: At least five multinational oil and gas companies suffered computer network intrusions from a persistent group of computer hackers based in China, according to a report released Wednesday night by a Silicon Valley computer security firm.

headline: Dozens Killed at Pakistan Army School

headline: Q&A: Red Bulls’ Joel Lindpere
text: Joel Lindpere, a tenacious but largely unknown and decidedly unglamorous Estonian midfielder, joined the Red Bulls on a free transfer last year. From his first game, when he scored the first goal at Red Bull Arena, Lindpere proved he was one of the finds of the season, an adept move by the club’s sporting director/general manager, Erik Soler. Lindpere, the team’s most valuable player in 2011, spoke with The Times’s Jack Bell late last week before the club left for preseason training in Mexico.

headline: Video Exclusive | Shirin Neshat Models for Ohne Titel
text: Flora Gill and Alexa Adams named their label Ohne Titel (German for “no title”) after Anselm Kiefer, the German artist who frequently left his works untitled and who inspired their first collection in 2007. So it stands to reason that they would again turn to the art world when recently casting for a new model. The new Ohne Titel spring 2011 campaign, which goes live tomorrow, stars the Iranian-born, New York-based artist Shirin Neshat, whose work often deals with the politics of appearances and the complex theater of female personae.

headline: What Are Your Best Sleepover Memories?
text: Sleepovers have “apparently become an essential part of childhood, for boys as well as for girls,” writes Perri Klass in “Ensuring Domestic Tranquillity During Sleepovers.” Though this article was written for parents of younger children, it inspired us to ask what you remember about great sleepovers you’ve attended, whether as a younger child or now. What makes for a fun sleepover? When, if ever, have you had an unpleasant sleepover experience? What advice do you have for younger children going on their first sleepovers?

headline: Madrid’s ARCO Art Fair Hits Its 30th Year

With works ranging from the historical avant-garde to acclaimed contemporary pieces, it draws hundreds of artists, collectors, critics, curators, museum directors, academics and other members of the art-loving public, some interested in Picasso prints, others crazy about Bill Viola videos.

headline: Republicans Begin Regulation Battle
text: This week, Congressional Republicans fired their opening salvos against the Obama administration’s regulatory apparatus. On Wednesday, Representative Sam Graves of Missouri, chairman of the House Small Business Committee, held a hearing on the health care law provision that expands 1099 reporting*, and the Energy and Commerce Committee questioned the Environmental Protection Agency administrator, Lisa P. Jackson, on global warming limits. On Thursday, Representative Darrell Issa of California, continues the assault in the Oversight and Government Reform committee, with a hearing on “ Regulatory Impediments to Job Creation.”

headline: Afghan Government Says Prisoner Directed Attacks
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A cell of suicide bombers active in Kabul was run for three years by a Taliban commander operating from the city’s main prison, Afghan officials said Thursday.

headline: Bank of England Keeps Rates Unchanged
text: Caught between weak growth data and rising price pressures, the Bank of England chose Thursday to leave unchanged interest rates as well as its broad asset buying program.

headline: Paris in Springtime May Not Include the French Open

headline: Requiem for the Bears?
text: In a recent article, I wrote about the unusual weather patterns of the last two winters, with excessive cold and snow in the eastern United States and western Europe occurring at the same time as unusual warmth in parts of the Arctic. One thing I did not mention in that story was what the likely effect on Arctic wildlife would be if this sort of thing continues.

headline: White House Outlines Wireless Spending and Bandwidth Sales

headline: Updates on Day 17 of Egypt Protests
text: The Lede continues to follow the protest movement in Egypt, now in its third week. For a summary of new developments, read today’s main news article from our colleagues in Cairo. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists in Egypt. A stream of Twitter updates on the protests is in this blog’s right column.

headline: Tweet, Tweet! It’s Fashion Week
text: A picture may paint a thousand words, but what can 140 characters tell you about Fashion Week? A lot, actually. Throughout New York Fashion Week, our writers will be posting live updates on T’s Twitter feed, http://twitter.com/themoment, giving you our impressions from the shows as well as from attendant parties and events. This season, we are also following some of our favorite up-and-coming designers and live-blogging their “crunch time” via Twitter. Today from 12 p.m. to 2 p.m., we will be going backstage at the Wes Gordon show, and from 3 p.m. to 7 p.m. we’ll be at Jonathan Simkhai, to give you a behind-the-scenes look at the busiest and most exhilarating moments before the shows.

headline: Och-Ziff Posts Increase in Earnings and Assets
text: 3:42 p.m. | Updated

headline: Paying for Health Care Results (Cont.)
text: Jon Baron, the president of the Coalition for Evidence-Based Policy in Washington, agrees that health care is a promising area for the government to issue social-impact bonds. (A short description of the bonds is here, and a longer one is here.) Mr. Baron offers a few other candidates for health-care bonds, in an e-mail:

headline: The Investors Behind the Exchange Mergers
text: The owner of the New York Stock Exchange is in advanced talks on a deal that could see Deutsche Börse shareholders own 59 to 60 percent of a combined company that would be incorporated in the Netherlands. In addition to the United States and Germany, the merged entity would have exchange operations in 12 European nations.

headline: Galderma Raises Q-Med Bid to $1.2 Billion
text: Galderma, a joint venture between L’Oréal and Nestlé, said on Thursday that it was raising its bid for the Swedish beauty products maker Q-Med to 79 kroner a share, or 7.9 billion kroner ($1.2 billion) for the entire company.

headline: N.Y.S.E. Must Keep Its Name, Florida Congressman Says
text: Many details of the planned merger of NYSE Euronext and Deutsche Börse need to be ironed out. But one American legislator is already making one demand: the New York Stock Exchange must keep its name.

headline: Leprosy, Plague and Other Visitors to New York
text: When New York City’s health department revealed last weekend that three people had contracted cholera, it was a reminder that the city is not just a world capital of arts, business and the like  but also of exotic diseases.

headline: Blast Kills 5 in Pennsylvania
text: ALLENTOWN, Pa.  For the residents of a block of brick row houses here on North 13th Street, Wednesday night went from ordinary to horrific in one unexpected flash.

headline: Bombing Kills Shiite Pilgrims in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  A car bomb exploded near a procession of Shiite Muslim pilgrims south of the holy city of Samarra on Thursday, killing nine people, including one child, and wounding 39 people, 5 of them children, a police official said.

headline: Search for Low Airfares Gets More Competitive
text: The familiar world of online air travel search is about to get a major shake-up.

headline: Chanos’s Short Story on the Markets
text: James Chanos, founder and president of Kynikos Associates, talks to DealBook’s Andrew Ross Sorkin on CNBC about his bearish views on some sectors, including the Chinese property market and integrated oil.

headline: Kathy Griffin Coming to Broadway
text: The salty comedian and reality TV star Kathy Griffin has two Emmy Awards, a best-selling autobiography and a Grammy Award nomination. And she’s not being shy about her desire to add a Tony Award to her résumé when she makes her Broadway debut in a new one-woman show next month.

headline: Banksy Shenanigans Not Welcome at Oscars
text: The will-he, won’t-he riddle about Banksy and the Oscars – will he show up? won’t he be in disguise? – has a solution. After the Oscar nominees luncheon on Monday, Steve Pond reports, the Academy president, Tom Sherak, and executive director, Bruce Davis, “huddled at a table” with Jaimie D’Cruz, a producer of “Exit Through the Gift Shop,” Banksy’s Oscar-nominated documentary. They worked through the potential situations of Banksy winning and having to appear on stage, which he would presumably do in costume, his costume of choice being a monkey mask. Undignified, the Academy felt. “If Banksy isn’t comfortable showing his face on the Kodak stage, Sherak said, then the Academy isn’t comfortable having him on that stage,” Mr. Pond writes. Instead, the Academy officials and Mr. D’Cruz agreed, if the movie wins, Mr. D’Cruz will accept “without any additional shenanigans.”

headline: Bachmann Opens Conservative Conference
text: The Conservative Political Action Conference opened Thursday morning with an address by Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota, who accused President Obama of being a socialist and urged the conservative faithful to focus on “making Barack Obama a one-term president.”

headline: Yet Another Route to Cellulosic Ethanol
text: There are myriad routes to making car fuel from waste, using mix-and-match technologies assembled in novel ways, but none has worked yet on a commercial scale. On Wednesday, Ineos Bio, the subsidiary of a major international chemical firm, broke ground on a plant that aims to use yet another combination.

headline: Profile in Style | Jenné Lombardo
text: The pint-size branding genius behind the Terminal Presents, which oversees Fashion Week’s M.A.C. & Milk events hub, has fierce personal style, mixing cutting-edge designers with semi-destroyed garage-sale and flea-market finds. More…

headline: Galleon Founder’s Trial Is Pushed Back
text: A federal judge on Thursday pushed back by a week the trial of Raj Rajaratnam, who has been accused of being at the center of an insider trading network.

headline: Peering Into a Reclusive Life
text: The well-known dedication of J. D. Salinger’s “Raise High the Roof Beam, Carpenters and Seymour: An Introduction” reads: “If there is an amateur reader still left in the world  or anybody who just reads and runs  I ask him or her, with untellable affection and gratitude, to split the dedication of this book four ways with my wife and children.”

headline: Afghan Proposal Would Clamp Down on Women’s Shelters
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  After her parents threw her out of the house for refusing to marry a 52-year-old widower with five children, Sabra, 18, boarded a bus that dropped her, afraid and confused, in downtown Kabul. She slept in a mosque for days, barely eating, until a woman took pity on her and put her in touch with human rights workers, who escorted her to a women’s shelter.

headline: Can Gay Marriage Save State Budgets?
text: Legalizing gay marriage in Rhode Island could bring the state an additional $1.2 million over a three-year period, according to a study from the Williams Institute at the School of Law at the University of California, Los Angeles.

headline: That Hair! Those Eyes! His Fans!
text: Jon M. Chu’s “Justin Bieber: Never Say Never” is billed as a concert documentary, but fewer than half of its 105 minutes are devoted to Mr. Bieber onstage. That was the right choice, because he’s more engaging as a star than he’s ever likely to be as a performer.

headline: Zoobiquity
text: An approach to health care that combines knowledge from human and veterinary medicine.

headline: It Was the SilverCup Hotel; Now It’s the Vetiver
text: The not-yet-open SilverCup Hotel in Long Island City, Queens, which was locked in a trademark dispute with the nearby Silvercup Studios, changed its name on Wednesday to the Hotel Vetiver.

headline: Poetry Pairing | Feb. 10, 2011
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

headline: Popcast: The Grammy Awards and an Interview With Betty Wright
text: This week Popcast, The Times’s weekly music podcast, takes a look at the 53rd annual Grammy Awards, which will be broadcast live from Los Angeles on Sunday night at 8 p.m. Eastern time.

headline: Asked & Answered | Lauren Santo Domingo and Aslaug Magnusdottir
text: We live in an age of instant gratification, where everything our hearts desire — news, information, groceries — can be had with the click of a mouse. And starting on February 16 at 11 a.m., you can add fashion to that list. Yes, there are plenty of shopping sites out there, but Moda Operandi, a new e-tail concept from Lauren Santo Domingo and Aslaug Magnusdottir, will allow shoppers to see and purchase their favorite looks right off the runway.

headline: A Life of Melting the Status Quo
text: LYNDA BENGLIS has gone her own way since first taking on the New York art world in the 1960s. She one-upped Jackson Pollock’s action paintings in the late 1960s by pouring pools of swirling pigmented latex directly on the floor and obscuring the distinction between painting and sculpture. She challenged the rigidity of Minimalism in the early ’70s with her hardened flows of polyurethane careening off walls and bristling with allusions to the body and landscape. She lampooned both the machismo of the art world and the way artists were expected to promote themselves in a market-driven system by exposing herself, with a dildo between her legs, in a 1974 Artforum advertisement that she paid for, earning her as many fans as detractors.

headline: Leaked Cables Reveal U.S. Concerns Over Saudi ‘Peak Oil’
text: Saudi Arabia’s ability to boost oil production much above current levels is questionable and the country’s overall crude reserves may have been overstated by up to 40 percent, American diplomats in Riyadh warned in confidential cables written between 2007 and 2009. The dispatches were released by Wikileaks and published on Tuesday by The Guardian newspaper in Britain.

headline: Pushing Paladino to Take His Bat to the Beltway
text: An unlikely message ricocheted across the blogosphere on Wednesday: “Run, Carl, Run!”

headline: New Details Emerge About Morgan Stanley and Citi In the Crisis
text: Big banks like Citigroup and Morgan Stanley, which were battered by the 2008 financial crisis, are once again on solid ground.

headline: In New California Gold Rush, Old Mines Reopen
text: SUTTER CREEK, Calif. — Standing in a cramped, slanted and slippery crevice some 500 feet below the earth’s surface, David Cochrane turned his eyes to a ribbon of marbled quartz — mainly gray, amber and white — and found the one hue he was actually looking for.

headline: How to Make Your Google Account More Secure
text: We all know there are risks to storing personal information online, yet few of us take even the most basic precautions, like choosing unique and hard-to-guess passwords.

headline: Sole Fed Governor With Close Ties to Conservatives Resigns
text: WASHINGTON  Kevin M. Warsh, who was the Federal Reserve’s chief liaison to Wall Street, will resign from the central bank’s board at the end of March, giving President Obama yet another chance to leave his stamp on the Fed.

headline: On Edge-Pushing Statistics and Climate Basics
text: Feb. 11, 3:40 p.m. | Updated There’s a young field at the interface of science and mathematics called spatial statistics. It’s so new that its first international conference* is taking place next month in the Netherlands.

headline: Arizona’s Kyl Latest Senator to Retire
text: PHOENIX — Senator Jon Kyl of Arizona said Thursday that he would not run for re-election in 2012, a long-rumored announcement that will end a 25-year political career and prompt a fierce scramble to succeed him.

headline: At Chicago Auto Show, Throaty V-8s and Man Vans
text: A blizzard that stranded hundreds of cars on Lake Shore Drive, followed by a series of subzero nights, might have left Chicago motorists vulnerable to dreams of summertime tire burnouts and top-down drag races. Automakers will gladly stoke those fantasies during the Chicago auto show, which will open to the public on Friday and run until Feb. 20.

headline: Are Baby Boomers Ready to Exit Their Businesses?
text: It’s official: as of Jan.1, the oldest of America’s baby boom generation started turning 65 at a rate of 10,000 a day — a trend that will last for the next 19 years. As articles like this one point out, the coming wave will mean big business for many industries. Many of us who offer financial services linked to retirement have been anticipating the day when the largest wealth transfer in our nation’s history officially begins.

headline: Deconstructing ‘Black Swan’
text: The Bagger’s colleague and pal Alastair Macaulay, the chief dance critic of The New York Times, takes a stroll through “Black Swan” today, and finds a lot to talk about.

headline: Options for Travelers Headed to Egypt
text: This was meant to be a banner year for Egyptian tourism. The ministry of tourism was anticipating more than 14 million visitors in 2011, a record. It was hardly unrealistic, considering that Egypt had 12.5 million visitors in 2009, and in the first nine months of 2010, despite the continuing global recession, had already seen 10.5 million visitors pass through the country.

headline: A Witness Sees History Restaged and Rewritten
text: WHAT’S it like to watch your own experience turn up as grand opera: in my case, finding my reporting about Nixon in China suddenly evoked by the Metropolitan Opera’s production of John Adams’s “Nixon in China”? Very weird. I kept imagining myself onstage in the prepositioned press crowd as Air Force One dropped from the sky in Beijing. And there I was again among the toasters clinking glasses that night at Chou En-lai’s banquet for the president.

headline: Dish Network and EchoStar a Fit for AT&T, Report Says
text: As Dish Network expands its broadband spectrum, the satellite television provider is becoming an attractive target for AT&T, according to a Credit Suisse analyst report, released on Thursday.

headline: Just Buy a Verizon iPhone? Here Are the Best Apps
text: So you’ve gotten a new iPhone on Verizon‘s network. Mazel tov. For those new to the iPhone ecosystem, you may want to check out our many guides to the various apps available for your new smartphone.

headline: Maximal Flavor for Minimal Cash
text: This week there are questions from visitors: some have a budget in mind, others are focusing on a celebration. As always, send your queries to dinejournal@nytimes.com.

headline: Men’s Fall Fashion 2011 | Gilded Age
text: Stefan Miljanic of Gilded Age brought his guys in from the cold for an urbane take on outdoorsy layering. Great washed and worn leather jackets, including one with a fur hood, topped hand-knitted patterned sweaters and denim jackets that were belted and worn with tucked-in jeans and boots. All of these looks could have easily walked right out of the presentation and onto the snowy streets, making them Lower East Side- and climate-appropriate.

headline: Thursday Reading: The Marginal Cost of Children

headline: When Patients Share Their Stories, Health May Improve
text: A gifted artist in his early 60s, the patient was a liver transplant candidate who learned he had hepatitis B some 20 years earlier. Despite the worsening fatigue that accompanied his liver failure, he threw himself into preparing for his transplant. He read everything he could about the procedure and the postoperative care, drilled doctors with endless questions and continued to drag himself to the gym each day in the hopes of being better prepared to withstand the rigors of the operation.

headline: Theater Talkback: Good Glitch, Bad Glitch
text: The woman I was sharing a taxi with the other night, after a dinner party, told me that she would rather report from a high-risk combat zone than do what I do for a living. This, by the way, is a quintessentially urban woman who values highly her creature comforts. So what she was saying to me was that theater was, to her, a form of unspeakable torture.

headline: Straight-Up Olive Oil Brownies
text: Without coconut, the brownies that I wrote about this week are more savory and exotic tasting, with a pronounced snappy bite. To make them, leave out the coconut, and instead of 3/4 cup olive oil, use 1/2 cup plus 2 tablespoons olive oil, plus 4 tablespoons melted butter. Make sure to sprinkle the top with a flaky sea salt like Maldon or fleur de sel, and be generous. Biting into a crunchy flake is the best part about these – next to the chocolate, that is.

headline: Photo of the Week – Guess Where This Is
text: Last week, every reader who guessed the location of the Photo of the Week was correct. This week, we’re reviving the guessing game, but with fewer clues.

headline: Fashion Week Drinking Game
text: Maybe it’s the curse of my nature, or the nature of my curse, but I’m partial to a drink. I like to bend the elbow in much the same way that, say, Richard Burton liked the odd whiskey. So it should surprise exactly no one that I am also fond of drinking games. My favorite involves having a sip every time a character on a reality-TV show says the word “journey.” (It’s become such a cliche that unless you have Burton’s constitution, I recommend a sip instead of a shot.) As far as games go, it’s as elastic as a pair of Spanx and works equally well while watching the crimes against fabric on “Project Runway” or the unbeweavable hair don’ts on “Hair Battle Spectacular.” But real-life fashion people care more about instant gratification than the process. I suggest, then, that you turn to the person next to you, toast and gulp every time you see a ponytail on the runway or hear someone mention one of the following:

headline: A Little Stress to Go With the Pixar Fun
text: If you’ve taken the behind-the-scenes tour of Pixar Animation or read about what it’s like to work there, you may think it’s a non-stop fun factory. We were googly-eyed pretty much the entire time we were there.

headline: Ford Beats Ferrari in Name Dispute
text: Remember in 1991 when the Ferrari team dropped its world champion driver, Alain Prost, for calling the illustrious racing car “a truck”? Well, this year the team named the car after a truck – at least, that is what Ford Motor thinks.

While announcing its latest financial results, the big game publisher Activision Blizzard revealed that it would not release a Guitar Hero or DJ Hero game this year and that it was disbanding its Guitar Hero publishing division.

headline: Consultant in City Fraud Case Pleads Guilty

headline: Kitsch of the Day | Mandy Smith’s ‘I Just Can’t Wait’
text: Stripes are big this season, and few people wore them better than the English tween sensation Mandy Smith. For a short time in the mid-1980s, Smith’s multitracked voice conquered the airwaves and she ruled European and Japanese teen magazine covers with her hyper-teased mane of blond hair, oversize shoulder pads, tiny waist and pouty Lolita looks. Her breakthrough single was “I Just Can’t Wait” (her signature striped sweater appears at 0:39 in the video above), a fluffy tune about a love story against all odds produced by the ’80s hitmeisters Stock Aitken Waterman.

headline: Can You Outgrow A.D.H.D.? Or Get It as an Adult?
text: If you have attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, or A.D.H.D., as a child, do symptoms ease with age? Can you have adult-onset A.D.H.D.? These are among the questions recently posed by readers of the Consults blog.

headline: A Quiet February
text: My already-intermittent blogging will cease for most of this month. Real posting will resume once I’ve figured out how to successfully juggle punditry and fatherhood.

headline: Updates to the Campaign Finance API
text: Political campaigns don’t have an off-season, but the brief lull between last November’s general election and now has given us time to make some updates to our Campaign Finance API. This round of changes focuses on additions to committee and filing responses, with particular emphasis on customizable collections of electronic filings and PAC contributions to candidates. We’ve also added support for JSONP requests. And in saying hello to the 2012 election cycle, we’re saying goodbye to Version 2 of the API, so all users should now be using Version 3.

headline: Gingrich Would Put Obama on Guest List

headline: For Oil Exec, an Electric Car Can Wait

Chevrolet’s Volt and Nissan’s Leaf are the talk of the car world, city governments are installing battery chargers, and the Obama administration has promoted them. Even the TV commercials for the battery chargers are cool.

headline: Stroke Rising Among Young People
text: More young people and adults in their 30s and 40s are being hospitalized for stroke, even as stroke rates are dropping in older people, new data show.

headline: Irish Eyes Not Smiling Over Bloomberg Remark
text: The gathering was meant to be a carefree celebration of the city’s St. Patrick’s Day Parade. But it took a different tone when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg made some off-the-cuff remarks.

headline: Passion Prompts: Sentence Starters for Writing About Relationships
text: Love may be a many splendored thing, but it’s not always easy to write about. In honor of Valentine’s Day, we thought we’d offer some sentence starters to help.

headline: Fashion Week Video | ‘Casting Call’
text: For every breakout runway star there are hundreds of aspirants each season. In this video above, Greg Kessler — the photographer of Model-morphosis, our popular interactive beauty feature — drops in on the casting director Natalie Joos and turns the spotlight on some of the new faces who are hoping that this will be their moment.

headline: Yahoo Opens a Digital Newsstand
text: Yahoo on Thursday announced the debut of Livestand, a publishing platform that aims to deliver personalized content to mobile devices. As The New York Times first reported on Sunday, the platform, a digital newsstand, will offer a continuous stream of programming based on users’ interests. Yahoo plans to push the platform across multiple formats, including tablets, smartphones, and Web browsers, according to the company’s press release.

headline: Waze iPhone App Crowd-Sources Info on Road Hazards
text: If you ever harbored ambitions of being a traffic reporter, here’s your chance.

headline: SXSW After Dark
text: What do a skateboarding hedgehog, a video game dance whiz, a right-wing Argentinean terrorist, an alien-fighting teen gang and a hobo (with a shotgun) have in common? They’ll all be wreaking havoc in Austin, Tex. next month as part of South by Southwest‘s midnight features lineup. Fantastic Fest, the fall film festival that has become known for its wild genre programming, will present a series called SXFantastic. Included in that lineup is “The FP,” which turns the popular video game “Dance Dance Revolution” (here dubbed “Beat-Beat Revelation”) into an all-out turf war.

headline: Bucks Pay for Off-Season Spree Sooner Than Expected
text: After surging in the second half of the 2009-10 season and making a somewhat unexpected trip to the playoffs, the Milwaukee Bucks looked to improve their roster in the most straightforward way possible. They had a woeful lack of free throw attempts, so General Manager John Hammond traded some roster fodder for Corey Maggette, who has made a career out of consistently getting to the line. They were below average in offensive rebounding, so Hammond signed Drew Gooden, a proven glass cleaner. Then, in an effort to take two steps forward without taking that dreaded step back, Hammond locked up John Salmons, who had been so crucial to the Bucks’ march into the postseason.

headline: Obama Unveils Wireless Expansion Plan
text: MARQUETTE, Mich.  Declaring that “we can’t expect tomorrow’s economy to take root using yesterday’s infrastructure,” President Obama traveled to this snowbound town in a remote corner of Michigan on Thursday to make the case that expanding wireless access is critical to the nation’s economic recovery.

headline: The Art of Dating in New York City

headline: So What is Hu Jintao Thinking Now?
text: As I prepare to watch Hosni Mubarak give his speech, I’m wondering what Chinese President Hu Jintao of China is thinking these days. Tahrir Square today is so reminiscent of Tiananmen Square in 1989, which I also covered — although it looks as if the ending will be different (touch wood).

headline: Busy Tonight? I Know a Nice Subway Ride...
text: MY date and I had perused the Brooklyn Flea and were on the Q train heading back to Manhattan for a snack. As the subway rumbled toward the Manhattan Bridge, I saw from the corner of my eye a colorful flicker on the tunnel wall.

headline: ’Tis Nobler to Dive in Front of a Train? Discuss
text: In “The Sunset Limited,” an HBO film directed by Tommy Lee Jones and starring Mr. Jones and Samuel L. Jackson, two men are locked in a room but have almost nothing in common save their time together. In the movie, based on the play by Cormac McCarthy, White, Mr. Jones’s character, is a college professor at the end of the line, a man so pummeled by despair that he attempts to throw himself in front of a train driven by ... Black, a redeemed, religious ex-convict played by Mr. Jackson. White is brought back to Black’s spare New York tenement, and they commence a mortal, desperate debate about the value of life and whether ending it  taking the Sunset Limited  is a valid choice given the amount of misery and alienation that can go hand in hand with everyday existence.

headline: The Ethics of Free Cellphone Calls
text: When I last wrote about the quest to get free phone calls forever, a number of readers wrote to point out a very sneaky trick that lets you achieve that frugal heaven — even from your cellphone. Yes, it’s a way to get free cellphone calls, without listening to an ad, without being in Wi-Fi, without using any minutes.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: amfAR Turns 25
text: A galaxy of stars turned kicked off New York Fashion Week last night at the Foundation for AIDS Research event at Cipriani Wall Street.

headline: No More Looking Backward: Professor Has Camera Removed From His Head
text: The New York University professor who had a camera inserted in the back of his head as part of an art project was forced to remove part of the camera on Friday because his body had rejected it, the Chronicle of Higher Education reported. The camera was to take a photograph every minute as the professor, Wafaa Bilal, went about his day. The project, which raised privacy concerns at the university, was called ”The 3rd I,” and was organized by a new Qatari museum called Mathaf: Arab Museum of Modern Art. According to the Chronicle, the device, which was installed by a body modification artist in a tattoo shop in Los Angeles, was originally mounted on three posts that were attached to a titanium plate implanted between Mr. Bilal’s skin and his skull. But Mr. Bilal’s body rejected one of the posts, despite treatment with antibiotics and steroids, and he was in constant pain. So on Friday he had the post removed. While the wound heals, he is tying the camera to the back of his neck. Why didn’t he do that in the first place? “It’s a performance,” he told the Chronicle. “With the performance comes endurance. But also it’s a commitment. And I didn’t feel that strapping something around my neck would be the same.”

headline: A ‘Winning’ Slogan for the History Books?
text: To the long list of presidential slogans – the New Deal (F.D.R.), the New Frontier (J.F.K.) and the Great Society (L.B.J. ) — we can now officially append “Winning the Future.’’

headline: Wheelies: Geneva Calling Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Galleon Founder Objects to Evidence
text: Lawyers for Raj Rajaratnam — the billionaire founder of the Galleon Group facing insider trading charges — are objecting to some evidence they expect the government to present at trial in early March.

headline: Pogue’s Posts: The Ethics of Free Calls
text: David Pogue discusses on his blog a very sneaky trick that lets you make free phone calls from your cellphone, a way to get free cellphone calls, without listening to an ad, without being in Wi-Fi, without using any minutes. He writes:

headline: Less Hopes to Be More at Williamstown Theater Festival
text: Williamstown Theater Festival has announced three mainstage productions for summer 2011: a Broadway-bound revival of Moss Hart and George S. Kaufman’s “You Can’t Take It With You,” directed by Christopher Ashley; Oliver Goldsmith’s Restoration comedy “She Stoops to Conquer,” directed by Nicholas Martin; and “Ten Cents a Dance,” a celebration of the songs of Rodgers and Hart, directed by John Doyle.

headline: Second Day of N.F.L. Labor Meetings Canceled
text: Efforts to jump-start N.F.L. labor talks seem to have stalled just days after the owners and players promised to work harder to reach a deal before the collective bargaining agreement expires on March 3.

headline: WikiLeaks Angry About Ex-Staff Member’s Book
text: LONDON  WikiLeaks said it is taking “legal action” over a tell-all book to be released Friday by a former staffer that is critical of its founder, Julian Assange, and says the Web site was disabled by a spate of defections last year.

headline: House Tour: Piermont, N.Y.
text: A house for sale in the tiny downtown of Piermont, N.Y., was once a fire station and has a balcony with Hudson River views.

headline: House Tour: Piermont, N.Y.
Vonn’s Racing Plans Uncertain After Concussion
text: Lindsey Vonn has crashed many times in her nearly 20 years of ski racing. But since falling last week in training  she was flipped backward, the back of her head smacking the hard snow  she has entered the murky world of concussions, and it has left her uncertain in the middle of the biggest races of the year, the world ski championships.

headline: New Nikons for Dark and for Distance
text: Nikon just released the specifications on eight new cameras, many with upgrades from existing models, but two with notable advances.

headline: Piling On at Richard Chai
text: Fashion Week started in earnest this morning with Richard Chai’s 11 a.m. show, and the mood in the audience seemed a tad impatient. There was such a short gap between the prefall collections and the fall collections this year that this Fashion Week is running the risk of feeling tired before it begins.

headline: The Pharaoh Refuses to Go
text: 7:33 p.m. | Updated with video.

headline: Time-Warped at Vena Cava
text: The preshow music at Vena Cava was blaring — you couldn’t talk to the person sitting next to you — so there wasn’t much to do during the wait except read the cute magazine that the designers, Lisa Mayock and Sophie Buhai, had left along the seats. It was called “Zina Cava.” Heh, heh.

headline: Trump Tells Conservative Audience He’s Presidential Material
text: Donald Trump wanted the crowd of activists at the Conservative Political Action Committee to know just who he thinks has the skills, smarts and guts to be president: Donald Trump, of course.

headline: Neighborhood Joint | Babycastles
text: An independent video game arcade in Ridgewood, Queens, with a low-fi, do-it-yourself aesthetic.

headline: Notes to Lady Hamilton, Who Drove Admiral Nelson Wild
text: Emma Hamilton preserved a paper trail of her love affairs. As a teenager in the 1780s, she was passed around as a mistress among British aristocrats, and is perhaps most famous for running off to a London suburb with Adm. Horatio Nelson while they were each married to other people.

headline: Brooklyn Museum Experiments With First Impressions
text: Ever since she read Malcolm Gladwell’s 2005 best seller, “Blink: The Power of Thinking Without Thinking,” Shelley Bernstein has been pondering ways to use what she learned about the impact of first impressions. As the chief of technology at the Brooklyn Museum, she was specifically interested in marrying the wisdom of the museum’s loyal Web followers with the more conventional knowledge of a curator.

headline: Lincoln Moves
text: With this post, Disunion begins two weeks of daily reporting on the historic railroad journey of President-elect Abraham Lincoln, as he traveled from Springfield, Ill., to assume the presidency in Washington, D.C.

headline: An Arcade to Make Gamers Cry
text: ON my first visit to Babycastles, an independent arcade in Queens, I watched as two young women explained to a friend the rules of a video game. It didn’t involve fighting, special moves or guns, but it was full of big-headed cartoon characters wandering through a jewel-toned landscape.

headline: Workers at Rest: Smoking and Playing Cards
text: “Cézanne’s Card Players,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, sounds like a show for our high-stakes moment. But the real appeal of this mini-blockbuster is its modest vision of a rural pastime, rendered with infinite patience. The big players who dominate the art world today would have a hard time identifying with Cézanne’s peasants and laborers: men quietly passing the time, happy enough with the hand that life has dealt them.

headline: Court Revives Suit Over Blackstone I.P.O.
text: A Federal Court of Appeals reinstated a lawsuit that accuses the Blackstone Group of inadequately disclosing information in its initial public offering documents — claims that echo an oft-heard criticism about the opaque business results of publicly traded private equity firms.

headline: Effort to Provide TV Ratings by Brand Moves Ahead
text: For decades, advertisers and agencies involved in advertising on television — meaning, practically all of Madison Avenue — have been seeking something their counterparts overseas have long had: brand-specific ratings, or the ability to track TV ratings on a commercial-by-commercial basis.

headline: Want a New York Landmark? Act Now!
text: And so it has come to this: Trading begins not with the customary ringing of the bell, but with the blast of a French horn. Pierre squints at the big board, yanks off his beret and shouts “À vendre! À vendre!” (“Sell! Sell!”). Outside on Wall Street, the steakhouses, cigar bars and elite private clubs stand empty, as brokers and traders stream into beer halls for steins of pilsner and plates of hot schnitzel.

headline: Calculating the Annual Percentage Rate
text: THE lending industry has tried to make it easier for borrowers to understand the true cost of a mortgage by disclosing both its interest rate and its annual percentage rate, or A.P.R. But consumers may often wonder which figure they should focus on when buying or refinancing a property.

headline: 2011 Oscar-Nominated Shorts
text: Images from the films nominated in the three shorts categories for the Academy Awards.

headline: Egypt: The Cultural Revolution
text: The festive protests that broke out on Jan. 25 in Cairo’s Tahrir Square have become a window into what Egypt might look and sound like without the regime of Hosni Mubarak. Tahrir’s troubadour collective has specialized in the invention of slogans that are witty, abusive and aimed directly at the president, e.g., “Mubarak, you rhinoceros (kharteet), / get out, get out, you pest (ghateet).” Sometimes, perhaps to signal a certain gravitas, they dispense with rhyme and say it straight: “The people want the fall of the regime.” Along with the chanting, there has been much baladi music — a catchy, popular style, heavy on hooks and reverb — as well as poetry recitations and effigy hanging. This is Egypt’s folk culture: profane, bawdy, politically sophisticated. It stands as a direct challenge to the version of culture propagated by the Mubarak regime and its predecessors.

headline: Exhibit Designer Chosen for Museum of African American History and Culture
text: The National Museum of African American History and Culture, the new Smithsonian museum set to open in 2015, has chosen a designer for its exhibitions. The museum has hired Ralph Appelbaum Associates, whose past projects include the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, the William J. Clinton Presidential Center, several major permanent exhibitions at the American Museum of Natural History and the U.S. Capitol Visitor Center. In a conversation earlier this week, the museum’s director, Lonnie G. Bunch III, said that Mr. Appelbaum had brought together a group of young, culturally diverse designers to work on the project. The Smithsonian will pay Mr. Appelbaum’s firm roughly $3 million to design of the museum’s planned 82,000 square feet of exhibition space.

headline: Victims Who Deserve Their Fate
text: The securities laws of the United States “substitute a philosophy of disclosure for the philosophy of caveat emptor,” Justice Arthur Goldberg wrote in a Supreme Court decision nearly half a century ago.

headline: An Innocent Abroad, at a Convention in Iowa
text: Everything’s up to date in Cedar Rapids, which not only has skyscrapers, but also a hotel with a pool sparkling in the atrium like a blue diamond. For Tim Lippe (rhymes with yippee), the 34-year-old naïf at the center of this wistful, equally tender and raunchy comedy of self-discovery, also called “Cedar Rapids,” the hotel and the pool signal that he’s reached the big time. What he can’t yet know is that by entering the hotel, having guilelessly said no to the friendly neighborhood prostitute outside, he has crossed a Rubicon. He’s on his way to a moral awakening in a story laced with Oedipal overtones and giddy with longing and smut.

text: Around Town

headline: More Figures From the Police Watchdog
text: In the news business, timing and freshness are everything. It was just a week ago that the Civilian Complaint Review Board trumpeted the news that complaints against city police officers had dropped 18 percent for the first half of 2010 – figures that were widely reported, debated and analyzed.

headline: A Move in the Direction of ‘More Life’
text: THOUGH Anne Bauso grew up in Middle Village, Queens, she was always fond of Brooklyn. Her parents were from Bushwick, and on Saturdays she went there with her father and brother, visiting the extended family and shopping for food in the Italian section of Knickerbocker Avenue. “I had very warm feelings for Brooklyn from the start,” she said.

headline: Hospitals Shift Smoking Bans to Smoker Ban
text: Smokers now face another risk from their habit: it could cost them a shot at a job.

headline: Schools Use Celebrity Wake-Up Calls to Battle Truancy
text: If the phone rings one morning and you hear a cheery “good morning” from Magic Johnson on the other end of the line or the R&B singer Trey Songz telling you to “get your education,” don’t hang up and roll over, bury yourself under your blanket and go back to sleep. This is no prank call. It’s the city’s latest attempt to get students who persistently skip class to start showing up more often.

headline: Farewell Tour Brings Jackson to the Garden
text: BOSTON  Phil Jackson can tell you about Madison Square Garden’s eccentricities, about the way the floor sometimes “jumps” when the crowd reaches a fever pitch.

headline: A Weekend in Brooklyn, New York
text: Brooklyn, New York City’s most populous borough, is a destination in its own right.

headline: 36 Hours in Brooklyn
text: THE Brooklyn Cruise Terminal on the Buttermilk Channel has picturesque views even when the Queen Mary 2, which docks there regularly, is at sea. There is verdant Governor’s Island across the water and, behind it , the heaving, jagged rise of Manhattan. To the north are the great bridges of the East River. To the west, the Statue of Liberty. And to the east, beyond chain link and forbidding streets, there is Brooklyn itself, New York City’s most populous borough, a destination in its own right.

headline: Back Then, a Man’s World of Loyalty and Adventure
text: “The Eagle,” a solemn and muscle-bound tale of valor and brutality on the northern fringes of the Roman Empire, treads the boundary between old school and retrograde. Following a Roman military commander’s lonely mission to retrieve the golden bird of the title, the movie, directed by Kevin Macdonald, plays less like a 1950s Technicolor sword-and-sandal epic than like a western of the same era, but with foggier visuals and skimpier political and sexual subtext. Lumbering along for a bit less than two hours, which passes like three, it feels more like a chore than like an adventure.

headline: ‘Top Gear’ Is Renewed for Second Season
text: Despite a lukewarm initial reception, the American version of “Top Gear,” which airs Sunday nights on the History cable channel, has been renewed for a second season, Jalopnik has reported.

headline: Arizona Sues Federal Government for Failing to Enforce Immigration

headline: Tyson Settles U.S. Charges of Bribery
text: When top executives of Tyson Foods discovered that the company’s Mexican chicken plants were paying bribes to government inspectors, they not only allowed the practice to continue, they formed a committee to find a more acceptable way to make the illicit payments, according to federal court documents released on Thursday.

headline: Consider an Apple, Consider the World
text: The women and few men sitting at their desks in the film “Poetry” have open faces and smiles. They’re good pupils, these older people who have come to the cultural center to learn. Perhaps because they have chosen to be there, they don’t have the look of sullen resentment and cultivated boredom that glazes the faces of the high school students glimpsed now and again. Instead these latter-day bards gaze at the man who has come to say something to them about art and maybe life. Instead he holds up an apple and talks about seeing.

headline: The Other Valentine’s Day
text: Indifferent, hurt, on the run or dumped? Too busy, too gloomy, too independent, too guilt-ridden, too too? What are we supposed to do on Valentine’s Day: crawl into bed and weep into our Kindle covers? Not all of us are ready to whip out the flowers and chocolate or snuggle up over a mortgage-size bottle of Champagne and some celebrity chef’s five course tasting. In fact, Valentine’s Day as packaged by the Valentine industry is a big to-do for the very few — the happily mated, romantically inclined and reasonably solvent. Which is why we need the Other Valentine’s Day, a day of celebration for those who would rather not celebrate romance right about now. At least not that way. Here is a gift list for us.

headline: "Rachmaninoff's Second Concerto" Performed by Lang Lang
text: Listen to an excerpt of "Rachmaninoff's Second Concerto" performed by Lang Lang with the Orchestra of the Maryinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, conducted by Valery Gergiev.

headline: ‘J. D. Salinger: A Life’
text: In the opening lines of The Catcher in the Rye, Holden Caulfield refuses to share his parents’ past with the reader, deriding any recount of “how they were occupied and all before they had me, and all that David Copperfield kind of crap.” “My parents,” he explains, “would have about two hemorrhages apiece if I told anything pretty personal about them.” This apparent elusiveness on the part of Holden’s parents was imported directly from the attitudes of Salinger’s own mother and father. Sol and Miriam rarely spoke of past events, especially to their children, and their attitude created an air of secrecy that permeated the Salinger household and caused Doris and Sonny to grow into intensely private people.

headline: A Night of High Drama in Cairo
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘The Social Network’ Takes the Top Prize at London Film Critics’ Circle Awards
text: Tut tut: the world’s most English film did not sweep the London Critics’ Circle Film Awards. Instead “The Social Network” took the top prize over “The King’s Speech,” and it won best director (David Fincher) and best screenwriter (Aaron Sorkin) to boot. In what could be cold comfort to Londoners, Andrew Garfield won best British actor in a supporting role — for playing a Brazilian-American Harvard student in “The Social Network.”

headline: Iraq Tells Refugees in Egypt and Yemen: We’ll Pay You to Return
text: BAGHDAD  As unrest shakes Egypt, Iraq is seizing the moment to make an audacious pitch to thousands of its citizens living abroad: Come back  we’re stable by comparison.

text: It’s 1912, and Pablo Picasso is in Paris, thinking: All right, what’s next?

headline: A Potential Hazard of Electronic Keys
text: CONCERN over the implications of a 2006 revision to a federal safety standard is spurring regulators at the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to reconsider their change. At issue is whether the change, which redefined what constitutes a car’s ignition key, has effectively increased the possibility of accidents caused by a vehicle rolling away.

headline: A Single Brownstone Remains Between 62nd and 63rd
text: YOU can barely see it now, the little 1871 brownstone at 815 Fifth Avenue, concealed by construction netting. Indeed, all its peers have vanished, too, although those were lost to the wrecker’s ball. This block of Fifth, between 62nd and 63rd Streets, had the earliest town house on Fifth Avenue opposite Central Park, and its thumbnail biography paints a picture of Fifth as a street of single, not multiple, dwellings.

headline: An Oscar Film Festival, All in One Screening
text: In addition to the 10 candidates for best picture and the smattering of contenders in other major categories, there are 15 movies whose titles will be mentioned at the Oscars on Feb. 27 that very few nonvoters are likely to have heard of. These are the nominees for best short film, which are divided into three groups: animated, live action and documentary. In the past, opportunities to see the shorts were scarce, but lately they have been showing up in theaters and also on iTunes and cable.

headline: It’s the Craftsman, Not the Singer or the Song
text: “Guitar Heroes,” an exceptionally interesting exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has nothing to do with the video game that enables nonmusicians to imagine themselves playing like rock stars. The heroes here are three craftsmen known for producing some of the most sought-after jazz guitars of the last seven decades: John D’Angelico (1905-1964), James D’Aquisto (1935-95) and John Monteleone (born 1947).

headline: Inside the List
text: BRAVE NEW WORLD: “The Hidden Reality” is the title of the latest mind-bender by the physicist Brian Greene, which enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 4. But it could also describe the strange new vistas on the publishing multiverse opened up by the redesigned best-seller lists, which make their debut this week. In addition to the familiar hardcover and paperback lists, this column will now have two entirely new sets of rankings to ponder. The e-book list tracks the top fiction and nonfiction titles available across a range of e-reader platforms. And the combined list ranks the titles that readers are clamoring for in all formats: e-book, hardcover, trade paperback, mass-market paperback.

headline: Plot Twist? If Viewers Say So, Let It Be

Maybe it was the cramped space of the presentation room at the Paley Center for Media, the vintage photographs of John Lennon that hung on the wall or the sound of AC/DC’s “Back in Black” blaring from the sound system.

headline: Keeping Score: The Story Arc of the 3-Point Shot
text: Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Portland Trail Blazers.

headline: Modernism From a World in Convulsion
text: There are pros and cons to “The Great Upheaval: Modern Art From the Guggenheim Collection, 1910-1918” at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. It exemplifies a museum trying to make the most of its permanent collection, combining fiscal sense with in-house creativity. Money is tight, and collections are often roomy, full of underexposed artwork awaiting the illumination of curatorial insight. This is a good thing.

headline: First Round of Republican Cuts
text: This is a preliminary list of cuts proposed by Republicans on the House Appropriations Committee for the rest of the fiscal year ending Sept. 30.

headline: A Ray of ‘Sunshine’ for ABC
text: “Mr. Sunshine,” ABC’s new sitcom with Matthew Perry, made a promising start on Wednesday, even as Fox’s “American Idol” and its round of San Francisco auditions led the night with 23.7 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The new ABC comedy drew 10.6 million viewers and delivered ABC’s best ratings of the season for a series premiere in the demographic of adults 18 to 49. The show benefited from a time slot following “Modern Family,” which earned 13.1 million viewers at 9 p.m., as well as from not having to compete directly opposite “Idol,” which trounced ABC’s sitcoms in the 8 p.m. hour, “The Middle” (8.8 million) and “Better With You” (6.8 million). ABC ranked third over all, struggling at 10 with “Off the Map” (5.6 million), while CBS trailed Fox in second place with strong results for “Criminal Minds” (14.3 million) and “Blue Bloods” (12.5 million).

headline: Japanese Isle in Sea of Contention Weighs Fist Versus Open Hand
text: YONAGUNI ISLAND, Japan  This remote island in the rough East China Sea is known for its gigantic moths, fiery Okinawan alcohol and an offshore rock formation that some believe to be the submerged ruins of a lost, Atlantis-like civilization.

headline: Pointed Choreography, Rooted in South Africa
text: The South African choreographer Robyn Orlin has a long history of annoying people, but from talking to her, you would never know it. She is candid to a fault, thoughtful and rather adorably scattered. Her e-mails are filled with exclamation marks and signed with x’s, denoting kisses. And yet Ms. Orlin, 55, has long been one of her country’s most provocative artists, a white woman from the comfortable Johannesburg suburbs fearlessly confronting the truths and myths of a complex political and social history.

headline: By the Water, but Down to Earth
text: ON a recent frigid day, crusty snow covered the deck of a boat named Paradox, docked at the Halloween Yacht Club in Shippan Point, a section of Stamford that juts into Long Island Sound.

headline: Abstract and Fluid Jazz
text: Back when the Wayne Shorter Quartet made its first tour, in 2001, it sometimes gave the impression of holding back. It seemed infinitely elastic, as if its members could theoretically push the music far into abstraction and still make sense but that they preferred to work within limits.

headline: Mario Cuomo to Mediate Mets-Madoff Case
text: A federal judge on Thursday appointed former New York Governor Mario M. Cuomo to try to resolve the $1 billion dispute between the owners of the Mets and the trustee representing victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s financial fraud.

headline: Warming Up to a Cold Run
text: DREAD. That’s the first word that pops into my head when I think about running in the winter. But it’s quickly followed by fat, a fate I would like to avoid. When I was a child, my mother had to buy me clothes in husky sizes. In my 20s I maxed out at about 220 pounds. These days, just shy of the big 4-0, I’m about 165, but the psychology of having been overweight remains, so keeping up with exercise, particularly in winter, is important.

text: An increasingly multiracial nation strives to get a better portrait of its people, and, in many ways, it is successful in gathering more information. But it also sows some confusion in the process, perhaps making it harder for researchers to detect racial and ethnic injustice.
