text: On my first visit to Babycastles, an independent arcade in Queens, I watched as two young women explained to a friend the rules of a video game. It didn’t involve fighting, special moves or guns, but it was full of big-headed cartoon characters wandering through a jewel-toned landscape.

headline: Shooting Fashion, but Not Too Much of It
text: Ruth Fremson and Shayla Harris faced an obstacle Monday when they arrived at the workroom of the fashion designer Joseph Altuzarra in Lower Manhattan. The last thing Mr. Altuzarra wanted them to photograph was the very thing everyone wanted to see: his latest collection.

headline: A Beep Too Soon
text: Our neighbors’ high school-aged son is picked up by a carpool every morning, promptly at 7:25. The driver signals her arrival with two sharp blasts of her car horn. It jolts me awake every day, and probably disturbs others on our block, too. Does this behavior seem as rude and as inconsiderate to you as it does to me? There must be some other way of letting the boy know his ride has arrived without startling everyone within earshot. May I speak with our neighbor, or will that make me seem difficult?

headline: Protesters’ Anger Spills Over After Speech
text: CAIRO  Hours before the president’s speech, through dark, downtown streets, groups of young men and women stepped over the rocks of recent battles and walked toward the lights in Tahrir Square.

headline: The Stars Realign. Do We?
text: THE tarot cards had long predicted that Matthew Foster was destined to fall in love with a Sagittarius. Then in 2009 he met Ben Mattson, a man he liked very much but who was a Capricorn.

headline: Some Lessons in Renting Out a Second Home
text: I’ve been renting out two homes in Litchfield County, Conn., since the early 2000s, and in all this time, I have just one horror story. But it is a doozy.

headline: Citing Lawsuit Against Mets’ Owners, Moody’s Reassesses Citi Field’s Bonds
text: Although Citi Field is not a target of the lawsuit against the Mets’ owners by the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s fraud, the bonds that financed it have a new black mark against them.

headline: Walgreens Launches Campaign to Push Store-Brand Products
text: THE next time consumers visit a Walgreens drugstore looking for something to soothe their achy heads, the company hopes they will reach for its private-label pain reliever and not a brand name.

headline: Under Tucson’s Shadow, Democrats To Search for Senate Candidate
text: The situation in Arizona, where Republican Senator Jon Kyl announced Thursday his intentions to retire, is a little trickier to sort out than some of the other cases that we’ve looked at recently. So let’s start with the basics: what is the overall partisan orientation of the state?

headline: SUNY Leaders Argue for Regular, Modest Tuition Rises
text: ALBANY  In his budget last week, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo proposed sharp cuts in state financing for public colleges and universities. But in a nod to the difficult financial circumstances many New Yorkers face, Mr. Cuomo did not seek to raise tuition to offset his cuts.

headline: Covenant-Lite Loans Prove Less Risky Than Thought
text: Loans with fewer restrictions on them may not be so dangerous after all. So says Tony James, president of the Blackstone Group, the private equity firm. And the numbers suggest he could be partly right. So-called covenant-lite loans are borrower-friendly but have been considered risky for lenders. As it turns out, they perform no worse, or a bit better, than debt with covenants.

headline: GPS on a Path to the Heart
text: IS there a proven strategy for finding love? If so, I suspect millions of people would like to know. In six years of editing this column, I have received so many stories from the baffled and the frustrated that even tsunami metaphors can’t convey the volume.

headline: Iran Presses Opposition to Refrain From Rally
text: TEHRAN  Iran’s authorities have increased pressure on the country’s political opposition days before a rally proposed by opposition leaders in support of the popular uprisings in Tunisia and Egypt.

headline: In Montana, A Bid to End Medical Use Of Marijuana
text: HELENA, Mont.  The Montana House of Representatives voted Thursday to repeal the state’s six-year-old medical marijuana law.

headline: Breast-Feeding Supplies Win Tax Breaks From I.R.S.
text: Ending a long-running dispute with pediatricians and breast-feeding advocates, the Internal Revenue Service announced Thursday that it would grant nursing mothers a tax break on pumps and other breastfeeding supplies.

headline: Canada Women’s Soccer Players Back Coach, Planning Boycott
text: Canada’s preparations for this summer’s Women’s World Cup in Germany were thrown into disarray this week when the resignation of the national team coach led her players to announce plans to boycott any international matches unless officials succeed in getting her to change her mind.

headline: Philadelphia Priests Accused by Grand Jury of Sexual Abuse and Cover-Up
text: PHILADELPHIA  A grand jury on Thursday accused the Archdiocese of Philadelphia of failing to stop the sexual abuse of children more than five years after a grand jury report documented abuse by more than 50 priests.

headline: U.S. Proposes New Forest Management Plan
text: The federal Department of Agriculture unveiled a new plan on Thursday to manage the national forest system that government officials said would give them more flexibility in responding to modern stresses like climate change while also heading off lawsuits.

headline: Behind a Push for Parole in Chicago, a Prisoner’s Old Neighborhood
text: CHICAGO  At a cafe in the heart of this city’s exuberant Puerto Rican community, in the neighborhood of Humboldt Park, a waitress serves up favorites from the island: café con leche, rice and beans and guava pastries. On the counter, a framed photograph of a white-haired man sits next to a stack of petitions calling for his release from prison.

headline: Military Caught Between Mubarak and Protesters
text: WASHINGTON  Even as prodemocracy demonstrations in Cairo riveted the world’s attention for 17 days, the Egyptian military managed the crisis with seeming finesse, winning over street protesters, quietly consolidating its domination of top government posts and sidelining potential rivals for leadership, notably President Hosni Mubarak’s son, Gamal.

headline: Emory Bellard, Creator of Wishbone Offense, Dies at 83
text: Emory Bellard, the coach who was credited with introducing the wishbone formation to college football, providing the framework for many of the great running teams of the 1970s, died Thursday in Georgetown, Tex. He was 83.

headline: Mario Cuomo to Mediate Dispute in Wilpon-Madoff Case
text: Mario M. Cuomo, the former New York governor, will serve as a mediator in the standoff between the trustee for the victims of the Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme and Fred Wilpon, Saul Katz and Sterling Equities, who are accused of profiting from Mr. Madoff’s actions, The New York Times reports.

headline: 50 Feet Below Midtown, Injured Worker Is Rescued
text: The injured payload operator was unable to move and lying in the dirt and water of a cavernous construction area 50 feet below the streets of Midtown Manhattan — a dark, cold ditch far from the firefighters’ grasp.

headline: A Kitsch-and-Tell Movie of Garden Variety Love
text: Instead of toys, lawn ornaments: ceramic garden gnomes, to be precise. In the 3-D animated “Gnomeo and Juliet,” as in the “Toy Story” movies, these kitschy items twitch to life only when the humans aren’t looking, which seems to be most of the time.

headline: Arizona: State Countersues Over Immigration Law
text: Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona said Thursday that she will raise private funds to countersue the federal government for failing to enforce immigration laws. The claim was filed in the Justice Department’s challenge to Arizona’s immigration law, parts of which have been struck down by a federal judge. At a news conference, Ms. Brewer and Attorney General Tom Horne said the Obama administration had failed to prevent illegal immigrants from crossing the border in huge numbers and stuck the state with the cost of dealing with its failed policies. Arizona officials dispute statistics showing that crime along the border is down significantly. In their legal challenge, the state intends to argue that it is being “invaded” by illegal immigrants from Mexico. A spokesman for the Department of Homeland Security, Matt Chander said in a statement in response, “A meritless claim such as this does nothing to secure the border.

headline: For Ex-Hostage, Lawsuit Against Iran Is Unfinished Business
text: Barry Rosen’s fascination with Iran began in 1967, when he went there from his native Brooklyn for a two-year adventure as a Peace Corps volunteer. He taught English and he learned Farsi, the Persian spoken by Iranians. “Iran became, in many ways, a second home for me,” he said the other day.

headline: Boxer Secures Citizenship in Olympic Quest
text: Erick De Leon, a 19-year-old boxing champion living in Detroit but born in Mexico, had said that if he obtained his United States citizenship, winning the gold medal in the 2012 Olympics could be a piece of cake, or pan comido in Spanish. Now, it looks as if De Leon will at least get his opportunity to fight for it.

headline: J. D. Salinger’s Love and Squalor
text: J. D. Salinger spent the first third of his life trying to get noticed and the rest of it trying to disappear. He would have hated “J. D. Salinger: A Life,” Kenneth Slawenski’s reverent new biography, which comes to us just a year after the writer’s death and creditably unearths and aggregates the facts and reads them into the fiction — reanimating the corpse without quite making it sing.

headline: Trafficking Investigations Put Surgeon in Spotlight
text: ISTANBUL  For a surgeon wanted by Interpol and suspected of harvesting human organs for an international black-market trafficking ring, Dr. Yusuf Sonmez was remarkably relaxed as he sipped Turkish red wine in a bustling kebab restaurant facing the wind-whipped Sea of Marmara.

headline: The Road to True Love Is Paved With a Whole Lot of Lying
text: I should start by confessing that I spent a lot of time before the screening of “Just Go With It” — and a few stretches while it was actually going on — trying to remember what the darn thing was called. I may have to look up the title a few more times before this review is done, and the movie is likely to live on in my memory (to the extent that it will) as “that one with Adam Sandler and Jennifer Aniston in Hawaii.” Which pretty much sums up both the appeal and the limitations of this passive-aggressive, naughty but nice, sometimes obnoxious and occasionally quite funny late-winter romantic comedy.

headline: Wayne Lee’s Renaissance
text: Over just a few seasons, Wayne Lee, one of the rising stars of the young designer scene, has pretty much changed her entire look. She’s gone from a designer of trendy contemporary clothes with just a hint of edge to someone who fully embraces a tougher street look. Her collections, now more grown up, make a statement of strength.

headline: TimesCast | February 10, 2011
text: David Kirkpatrick assesses what Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak's refusal to step down means for the thousands of protesters in the streets.

headline: A Somber Show at Christian Siriano
text: All right, I’ll admit it. I liked the Christian Siriano show. And I’m not the only one.

headline: Web Words That Lure the Readers
text: The Huffington Post has hired veteran journalists to beef up its news coverage. But a significant chunk of its readers come instead for articles like one published this week: “Chelsy Davy & Prince Harry: So Happy Together?”

headline: President Obama’s Statement on Egypt
text: President Barack Obama issued this statement on Thursday in response to developments in Egypt:

headline: For Republicans, Too, a Broad Power Shift After the Elections
text: WASHINGTON  Three months have passed since the Congressional elections upended the balance of power in Washington, yet the Tea Party wave continues to ripple across all facets of politics. The best example, perhaps, is the Republican Party itself.

headline: Privately, Public Employees See Cuts as Inevitable
text: UNION, N.J.  The meeting of the public-workers’ union had ended, the rallying cries about hostile lawmakers and ominous contract deadlines had given way to a buffet dinner.

headline: The Next Step for Egypt’s Opposition
text: Cairo

headline: ’60s Snipper Extraordinaire
text: “Vidal Sassoon: The Movie” opens with a blast of hyperbole from an assembly of disembodied voices: “I think it’s impossible to overestimate the importance of Vidal Sassoon.” “He built something that rocked the world.” “He was one of the greatest if not the greatest hairdresser who ever lived.” One commentator even compares Mr. Sassoon, now a spry, fit 83, to Einstein and Muhammad Ali.

headline: Obama Faces a Stark Choice on Mubarak
text: WASHINGTON  President Hosni Mubarak’s refusal to step down on Thursday, after a day of rumors galvanized the crowds in Cairo, confronts the Obama administration with a stark choice: break decisively with Mr. Mubarak or stick to its call for an “orderly transition” that may no longer be tenable.

headline: Crime Down, Bills Up: How Snow Affects the City
text: With no snow for days, and none in the immediate forecast, the city is moving out of its period of being buried, which began the day after Christmas and never seemed to end. But as the snow melts, and as city officials tally the cost of this record-breaking winter, other price tags are becoming clear  whether they be financial, emotional, even electrical.

headline: Ex-C.I.A. Agent Goes Public With Story of Mistreatment on the Job
text: WASHINGTON  In many ways, the personal injury lawsuit looked routine: In late 2001, a government employee and his family sued the agency he worked for, saying it had placed them in a mold-contaminated home that made them sick and required nearly all their possessions to be destroyed.

headline: Out of Touch, Out of Time
text: CAIRO

headline: Lebanese Bank Is Accused of Money Laundering
text: WASHINGTON  The United States accused one of Lebanon’s largest banks on Thursday of laundering hundreds of millions of dollars a month for a multinational drug trafficking organization with ties to Hezbollah.

headline: City Taxi Commissioner Says He Is Seeking Changes to TV Service in Cabs
text: Can’t stand Taxi TV? Even New York’s taxi commissioner feels your pain.

headline: The Freedom Alliance
text: Over the past few weeks, I’ve had a chance to interview some amazing people. I sat down with Bill Gates, who was in Washington to try to keep the looming budget cuts from decimating the foreign aid programs.

headline: Murder Trial in Tucson Shows Rift in Minuteman Border Movement
text: TUCSON  In the weeks since Tucson buried Christina-Taylor Green, the 9-year-old victim of the shooting rampage outside a Safeway supermarket, a trial under way in the county courthouse here has struggled to account for the earlier murder of yet another child of the same age.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Europe’s Foreign Policy Chief, Struggling for Mandate, Faces Criticism on Uprisings
text: PARIS  After President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt refused to step down on Thursday night, infuriating demonstrators in his country, the European Union’s foreign policy chief, Catherine Ashton, issued a sharp statement saying that “the time for change is now” and that Mr. Mubarak “has not yet opened the way to faster and deeper reforms.”

headline: Abraham Lincoln, Inflationist
text: There was a time when Republicans used to refer to themselves, proudly, as “the party of Lincoln.” But you don’t hear that line much these days. Why?

headline: Crooked Lawyers and Broken People
text: Set in a featureless corner of Buenos Aires called La Matanza, “Carancho” dives into a nocturnal world of crooked lawyers and broken people.

headline: Assisting Suicide to Be Focus of Trial in Motivational Speaker’s Death
text: The man in the black car was approaching people on an East Harlem street corner, asking to buy a gun and saying he “wanted to do a Kevorkian.” Kenneth Minor said he shooed the man away, but he returned with a more outrageous request:

headline: Beyond Reason on the Budget
text: After two years of raging at President Obama’s spending plans, House Republican leaders have finally revealed their real vision of small government: tens of billions in ideologically driven cuts to job training, environmental protection, disease control, crime protection and dozens of other critical functions that only the government can perform.

headline: Justice Scalia’s Misstep
text: To the Editor:

headline: South Africa: President Announces New Spending on Jobs
text: President Jacob Zuma made tackling staggering unemployment the government’s top priority on Thursday. He announced $2.7 billion in tax breaks to encourage investment in manufacturing, and an additional $1.25 billion for job-creation undertakings, without offering specifics. The unemployment rate fell to 24 percent from 25.3 percent in the final quarter of 2010. When those who have given up looking for work are included, more than a third of the potential work force is jobless.

headline: Kicking Our Fossil Fuels Habit
text: About 65 minutes into “Carbon Nation,” a peppy documentary about all sorts of technologies that might help us kick our fossil fuels habit, the film acknowledges its biggest shortcoming.

headline: S.E.C.’s Budget Problems
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cameras in the Delivery Room
text: To the Editor:

headline: After a Retreat From Limelight, a Death, and Rekindled Anger
text: ST. LOUIS  There was a time when August Busch IV would enter bars here and approach total strangers, the ones bold enough to sip on a Coors or Miller in public. He would ask if he could buy them a Budweiser, usually politely but sometimes adding enough of a jostle to knock over the offending beverage.

headline: Jonathan Winters in the Spotlight
text: “Certifiably Jonathan,” a self-described mockumentary constructed around the 85-year-old comic genius and artist Jonathan Winters, is teeming with smart American humorists — and a passel of Arquettes — all unconditionally admiring. What’s astonishing, then, is that not one of them stepped in to dissuade their friend from participating in such an embarrassingly awful project.

headline: A Fork in Road to the White House
text: WASHINGTON  If you just can’t get enough of C-Span’s daytime programming and are inclined to watch all of the speechifying at the annual gathering of conservative activists here this week, then keep in mind that these potential Republican presidential candidates face a choice in the earliest months of this nascent campaign.

headline: Farewell to Springfield
Friday: Paparazzi Targets
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — When ballplayers “hit for the cycle”, it means they have hit a single, a double, a triple and a home run in a single game, although they don’t have to be in that order. The last professional player to have performed such a feat is Carlos Gonzalez of the Colorado Rockies on July 31, 2010. Congratulations. You have now witnessed the complete range of my knowledge of sports. Thanks, MLB.com!

headline: When the Final Curtain Doesn’t Fall
text: Human life is measured in inhuman ways in “When I Come to Die,” a sober, meticulously wrought drama by Nathan Louis Jackson set on death row in an Indiana prison. The coming of dawn brings no birdsong, or even the comforting blare of city horns. Time is measured by the clanging of cell doors and the mechanical blinking on and off of fluorescent lights. Each day brings the same cold routine, the same blank night.

headline: If You Go to the Show, You May Just Land a Role
text: Time to face it. You are probably not going to be making an appearance on “The Oprah Winfrey Show.” The waning days of that celebrated syndicated chatfest are upon us, and if you have not yet received the call, it is unlikely that you will be joining Ms. Winfrey on the plush couches under the comforting lighting to discuss your memoir of a miserable childhood, your new aromatherapy line or your discovery that sex just gets better in middle age.

headline: Judge Fogel and the Death Penalty
text: On Tuesday, Judge Jeremy Fogel of the Federal District Court in northern California toured a new facility at San Quentin State Prison for executing inmates. Five years ago, in Morales v. Tilton, he ordered the state to halt all executions after he found that the way it administered its lethal injection created too much risk that an inmate would suffer extreme pain.

headline: N.B.A. Dean of Coaches Resigns Abruptly
text: Jerry Sloan and Larry H. Miller, the late owner of the Utah Jazz, had a gentleman’s agreement a few years ago. Sloan would agree to a one-year contract every winter, mull it over in the spring and officially commit in the summer. The process was as certain as the changing of the seasons.

headline: Protecting the Whistle-Blowers
text: All those Capitol budget hawks searching out waste, fraud and abuse should first find out why some mystery lawmaker killed a long-needed whistle-blower protection bill in the final hours of the last Congress.

headline: U.S. Indicts 31 in Crackdown on Newburgh Gangs
text: WHITE PLAINS  Continuing its offensive on the violent gangs that have run roughshod over Newburgh, federal authorities on Thursday unsealed a new indictment against reputed members and associates of the Latin Kings on charges that included murder, assault and racketeering.

headline: Marriage Equality in New York
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s pledge to make a strong push in the next few months to pass legislation legalizing same-sex marriage in New York State is a promising development. Speaking on Wednesday at Hofstra University, Governor Cuomo said he intends to ask the Legislature to take up the measure and that he will be “working very hard to pass it.”

headline: Fraternal Rivalry and Failed Ambition
text: The bond between two brothers becomes irretrievably twisted in “Lovers of Hate,” an unusually perceptive examination of fraternal rivalry and failed ambition.

headline: Yeshiva Fair Is a Bastion for Jewish Books of the Printed Variety
text: Those who mourn the metamorphosis of books made of paper into digital versions for e-readers can find some solace by taking a trip to Washington Heights in Manhattan.

headline: Mubarak’s Feb. 10, 2011, Speech
text: Interactive video and transcript of the speech given by President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt.

headline: New-Look St. John’s Continues to Make Garden Its Own
text: From its rafter-rattling victory over Georgetown earlier this season to its upset of Duke the last time it played at Madison Square Garden, St. John’s has brought the kind of vitality to the arena that was missing for nearly a decade when the Red Storm took the court.

headline: The Link Between Female Sexuality and Corporate Profits
text: “What does an orgasm mean to you?” the filmmaker Liz Canner asks of several women who appear in “Orgasm Inc.” The answers vary, but Ms. Canner is more interested in what orgasm means to the pharmaceutical industry. And by taking a playful approach to a deeply serious subject, she explores the link between female sexuality and corporate profits with a style that’s as entertaining as it is revelatory.

headline: Photo Replay: Feb. 10
text: Skiing in Germany, solace on a lake in a kayak, and more from the day in sports.

headline: Mexico: Kidnap Sentence Upheld; France Warns of Consequences
text: A Frenchwoman serving a 60-year sentence in Mexico for kidnapping lost her final appeal on Thursday, drawing a blistering response from France. The woman, Florence Cassez, left, has said she knew nothing about the kidnappings, which her boyfriend has confessed to. On appeal, she argued that the authorities violated several procedures, including staging her arrest for television. The court ruled that that had no impact on her conviction. In a statement, the French foreign minister, Michèle Alliot-Marie, said justice had been denied, warning, “This decision will weigh on our bilateral relations.”

headline: Return to a Spanish Village
text: In 2003 Mercedes Álvarez returned, with a video camera, to the village of her birth in a rocky, empty region of northern Spain. No one had been born there since she was, and now fewer than 20 people remained, one of whom died during the year she spent recording their lives for her documentary “The Sky Turns.”

headline: Dominican Trainer Accused of Sexual Abuse
text: A trainer of teenage baseball prospects in the Dominican Republic has been accused by two of his former players of sexually abusing them, adding to a list of recent scandals in the procurement of Latin American talent by Major League Baseball teams.

headline: China: Rights Group Says Couple Beaten for Making Video
text: A human rights advocacy group based in the United States, China Aid Association, said Thursday that a human rights lawyer and his wife were severely beaten by security forces for having recorded a video revealing the details of the lawyer’s detention. The video of the blind Chinese rights lawyer, Chen Guangcheng, who has been under house arrest since he was released from prison last September, was posted by the rights organization on Wednesday. According to the video, 22 people have been assigned to watch Mr. Chen’s home in Shandong Province around the clock, he is not allowed to leave, cellphone calls cannot be made from the home and security officials bar any visitors. The organization said that Mr. Chen and his wife were beaten so severely they were not able to move from their bed, and they were denied the right to go to the hospital for medical care. Mr. Chen was sent to prison in 2006 for his human rights advocacy, and in particular for pointing out forced sterilizations and abortions in official abuses of China’s one-child policy.

headline: Gulf Coast Wind Farms Spring Up, as Do Worries
text: SARITA  On the 400,000-acre Kenedy Ranch along the southern Gulf Coast, the wind coming off the water nearly flattops the clusters of oak trees. Towering above the trees, above the long grasses, sand dunes, grazing cattle and the occasional antelope, are scores of wind turbines, each about as tall as a football field is long.

headline: Symbolism, Not Savings, Is at Heart of Perry Budget
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

headline: China: Rain, Snow and Artillery Said to Ease Drought
text: Chinese drought control officials announced late Thursday that they had reduced their estimate of drought-affected land in China’s wheat belt by about a tenth after rain and snow fell in parts of northern China on Wednesday and Thursday, according to state media. The government used artillery to seed clouds, and has begun emergency irrigation efforts. Premier Wen Jiabao sought to reassure the public in televised remarks on Thursday that the supply and demand of grain were “basically” in balance, and that the government had stockpiles and would not let inflation rise sharply.

headline: Community Colleges Are Uneasy as Ax Hangs Over State Aid for Health Benefits
text: The Legislature’s initial state budget proposals calling for the closing of four community colleges caught many lawmakers off guard. But what largely escaped their attention  the slashing of health benefits across all such institutions  is what concerns community college officials the most.

headline: France: Courts Slow in Protest
text: Courthouses across France heard only urgent cases on Thursday as thousands of magistrates and police officers demonstrated after President Nicolas Sarkozy criticized the justice system’s handling of a grisly murder case. Last week, Mr. Sarkozy denounced the early release from prison of the primary suspect in the killing of an 18-year-old waitress. While the magistrates agree that the system had failed, they said it had stemmed from a lack of resources.

headline: The Mubarak Muddle
text: CAIRO

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for

headline: Mali: Details Sought on Land Deals
text: An opposition party has written an open letter to the government demanding that it account for hundreds of thousands of acres being leased to private investors and foreign governments. The government has said it needs foreign investors because it cannot afford the cost of developing its vast bushlands into productive farmland. The letter from the Party for National Renaissance questioned whether the government was giving the land away to countries including Libya, China and Brazil without ensuring that food sufficiency was the priority. It demanded that the government release the financial details of the leases, as well as the required environmental impact studies.

headline: Maybe the Deficit Needs to Get More Personal
text: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Driving Thrills or Thrilling Mileage: You Decide
text: The sweet smell of daffodils was in the air at McCormick Place on Wednesday as hybrid-electric Chevrolet Volts glided silently along a test track.

headline: Chef Hopes Miracle Berry Becomes the Sweet Taste of the City and Worlds Beyond
text: The tiny, red West African fruit known as the miracle berry, which tricks the tongue into perceiving sour tastes as sweet, has become the rage in recent years. Flavor-trippers nibble on the fruit, then sip Tabasco sauce or bite into lemons for a little added fun.

headline: Chibots Prepare for Debut in ‘Heddatron’
text: An hour before the start of Tuesday night’s penultimate dress rehearsal, half the cast of Sideshow Theatre Company’s “Heddatron” was making a lot of noise  lunging and stretching, their voices swooping through a range of warm-up exercises. Downstage, the cast members Billy-bot and Hans stood apart, occasionally flexing an arm or a neck joint, winking at curious onlookers and, when provoked, beeping loudly.

headline: Singapore and the U.N.
text: To the Editor:

headline: Data Confirm What Cyclists Knew: San Francisco Streets Are Hazardous
text: One September morning last year, Mary Jenn, a San Francisco massage therapist, was riding her bike to work when a police officer who was parked on O’Farrell Street opened the door of his cruiser in her path.

headline: After the Storms of January, Civility Settles Over City Hall
text: Late last month, the San Francisco Board of Supervisors considered the nomination of Richard Johns, a lawyer, for the Historic Preservation Committee.

headline: Knicks’ D’Antoni Counts Differences With Lakers
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  When Coach Mike D’Antoni considered the Lakers, he noted that their roster had stars worthy of playing in Los Angeles. How far do his Knicks have to go to reach that level? Let him count the ways.

headline: Lost for Years, a Trove of Chinatown Art Is Tracked Down
text: It’s a modern detective story, set in San Francisco’s atmospheric Chinatown.

headline: When the Dog Isn’t Yours, but the Fine for Its Waste Is
text: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Corrections
text: EDITOR'S NOTE

headline: Holding Flowers and Gun, Queens Man Kills His Ex-Wife and, Later, Himself
text: An armed man holding a bouquet of flowers walked into a Queens pharmacy on Thursday and shot and killed his ex-wife  who had an order of protection against him  and then went home and killed himself, the authorities said.

headline: Bloggingheads: Crime and Poverty
text: Vesla Weaver, left, of the University of Virginia and Heather Mac Donald of the Manhattan Institute debate the relationship between crime and poverty.

headline: Prosecutors Reduce Charges Against Bonds
text: Federal prosecutors reduced on Thursday the number of perjury charges against Barry Bonds, cutting the overall charges against him to 5 from 11.

headline: For Celtics’ Allen, a Moment to Cherish; for the Lakers, a Victory to Savor
text: BOSTON  On a night that was otherwise framed by rivalries and rough edges, Ray Allen was all hugs and heartfelt emotion.

headline: Mayor of Rust
text: At the Aspen Ideas Festival in Colorado last July, John Fetterman, the mayor of Braddock, a small Pennsylvania town 10 miles upriver from Pittsburgh, was introduced by Dana Gioia, former chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, as a man who demonstrates “how ideas can change the world.” It was four days into the weeklong festival, and Fetterman, a 41-year-old, 6-foot-8 white man with a shaved head, a fibrous black beard and tattoos up one arm and down the other, was presenting a slideshow about how art could bring social change to a town where one-third of its 2,671 residents, a majority of whom are African-American and female, live in poverty. Fetterman projected pictures of old, bustling Braddock, which steel made until the middle of the 20th century and unmade throughout the rest. Its main street was packed with shoppers, its storefronts filled with wares. Then he turned to Braddock as it is today.

headline: Word of the Day | sleazy
text: sleazy •\ˈsle-ze also ˈsla-\• adjective

headline: No ‘Moby-Dick’: A Real Captain, Twice Doomed
text: HONOLULU  In the annals of the sea, there were few sailors whose luck was worse than George Pollard Jr.’s.

headline: UConn Quarterback Has Plenty of Tricks
text: With the Bowl Championship Series title game a distant memory, college football fans may be forgiven for thinking it will be a tough few months before their favorite teams take the field again. Take heart! Watching Connecticut quarterback Johnny McEntee and his array of tricks is the perfect way to pass the time before next season kicks off.

headline: Timeline: A Day of Whiplash
text: A look at some of the events Thursday, when hopes rose among protesters that President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt would step down, but were met with disappointment.

headline: Perry, Sculptor of Geometric Forms, Dies
text: Charles O. Perry, a sculptor who created dozens of mathematically inspired works for plazas and sculpture gardens throughout the United States and abroad, died in Norwalk, Conn.

headline: Egypt Erupts in Jubilation as Mubarak Steps Down
text: CAIRO  An 18-day-old revolt led by the young people of Egypt ousted President Hosni Mubarak on Friday, shattering three decades of political stasis here and overturning the established order of the Arab world.

headline: Seizure Highlights Illegal Wildlife Trading
text: This week the authorities at Bangkok’s international airport intercepted a would-be wildlife smuggler, an Indonesian man whose three suitcases contained dozens of turtles and tortoises, 44 snakes, including pythons and two boa constrictors, assorted lizards and spiders — oh, and a parrot.

headline: Peggy Rea, TV Actress With Matronly Aura, Dies at 89
text: Peggy Rea, a matronly actress who had supporting roles on popular television series from the 1970s to the ’90s, died on Saturday at her home in Toluca Lake, Calif. She was 89.

headline: Charles O. Perry Dies at 81; Sculptor Inspired by Geometry
text: Charles O. Perry, a sculptor who created dozens of mathematically inspired works for plazas and sculpture gardens throughout the United States and abroad and created “Continuum,” the knotted black Möbius strip that stands in front of the Smithsonian’s National Air and Space Museum in Washington, died on Tuesday at his home in Norwalk, Conn. He was 81.

headline: News Quiz | February 11, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Pakistan Extends Jailing of American Held in 2 Deaths
text: LAHORE, Pakistan  A Pakistani court on Friday ordered an American official, arrested in the killing of two Pakistanis, to be held for another two weeks while the authorities prepared charges in what the police called a “coldblooded” murder.

headline: Morning T | Alan Cumming
text: In this installment of our video interview series, Horacio Silva sits down with Alan Cumming, who is currently starring as Eli Gold in CBS’s “The Good Wife.” Among the topics discussed: Cumming’s new fragrance, red carpet fashion, and rocking a man-frock at fashion shows.

Meanwhile, Nicky Minaj is at the top of the Billboard chart. What, or whom, are you listening to these days? headline: Ray Lucas Writes About Painkiller Detox on Facebook

headline: Does Higher Pay Make People More Loyal?

Discussing employee pay, she asked: “If your people are making a lot of money, do you find it makes them more loyal?” I didn’t give her an immediate answer, but the question has been in the back of my mind since then. Here’s my current thinking:

text: The Treasury Department’s long-awaited report on the future of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac recommends that the Obama administration “wind down” the government-controlled mortgage finance companies.

headline: Fashion Week Video | ‘Kruse’
text: Barnaby Roper doesn’t do things by half. But he is not against the idea of using a 16-part grid. In his latest high-impact video, ‘Kruse,’ created exclusively for The Moment, Roper turns his lens on Christina Kruse, a ’90s catwalk queen and a talented artist in her own right. Kruse’s image is carved up into a digital chopping block that twists and turns and squeezes her through a series of kaleidoscopic formations. Look out for more videos from Roper as the year progresses — assuming the technology can keep up.

headline: First-Time Queen’s Double Demands
text: DESPITE some recent requests for tickets there will be no performance of “Black Swan” at the David H. Koch Theater any time soon. That Oscar-nominated film has garnered so much attention that some potential audience members seem to think it’s an actual ballet. It isn’t, of course, but in a bit of interesting timing New York City Ballet is now presenting its version of the actual work the film bears some resemblance to, “Swan Lake.”

headline: The Husband’s Speech

He suffered a massive stroke only days before, one tailor-made to his own private hell. In the cruelest of twists for a novelist-professor obsessed with words, the stroke ravaged the language areas of his brain.

headline: An Ebert Cheat Sheet for Your Oscar Pool
text: If you’re already filling out your New York Times interactive Oscar ballot, and need a cheat sheet, check out Roger Ebert’s picks. An illustrious critic and Twitter maestro, Mr. Ebert has posted his choices for every category, from short documentary to best picture, and he, too, thinks it will be a near sweep for “The King’s Speech,” even in categories like best supporting actor and best score. Personally, though, he preferred “The Social Network.” (“It was not only the best film of 2010, but also one of those films that helps define a year,” he writes.)

headline: New Track Surface a Wild Variable at Daytona 500
text: The Nascar Sprint Cup Series opens its 36-race schedule on Feb. 20 with its premier event, the Daytona 500. This year’s race may turn out a little different — meaning, a little more exciting — than past runnings.

headline: Q & A: Philip-Lorca diCorcia
text: On Thursday night, at the start of Fashion Week, several hundred people came to the David Zwirner Gallery to see an exhibition of Philip-Lorca diCorcia’s photographs. Originally published in W magazine, between 1997 and 2008, the images are a remarkable record of a free-spirited period in publishing that seemed to come to an end with the recession and, as well, the Internet. They speak directly to the eye of Mr. diCorcia, with their capacity to excite and disturb, and to seek truth about human behavior in the most banal of scenes. These photographs were also the result of a fortuitous collaboration between Mr. diCorcia and Dennis Freedman, the former art director of W, who gave the artist carte blanche to shoot fashion stories in places like Havana, Cairo and New York. They have collected all 11 shoots in a new book, “Eleven” (Damiani Editions).

headline: Mass Effect 2 Takes Top Prize at Interactive Achievement Awards
text: LAS VEGAS — In an upset victory for Electronic Arts and its BioWare studio, the science-fiction adventure Mass Effect 2 won game of the year here on Thursday evening at the 14th annual Interactive Achievement Awards ceremony. Voted on by members of the video-game industry under the auspices of the Academy of Interactive Arts & Sciences, the Interactive Achievement Awards are the most prestigious in video games and are the industry’s equivalent of the Oscars. The awards are announced each year at the academy’s DICE conference, which stands for Design, Innovate, Communicate, Entertain.

headline: Give the City Your Thoughts on Livery-Cab Proposals
text: Should livery cabs be allowed to pick up street hails in the boroughs outside Manhattan? The city wants your opinion.

headline: With C-Max, Ford Plans a Comeback for the Tall, Small Wagon
text: WHETHER it’s called a small minivan or a tall wagon or a people mover or a multipurpose vehicle, the basic idea behind the redesigned 2012 Mazda 5 is one that has long been popular with manufacturers. But in North America at least, it hasn’t been all that popular among actual customers.

headline: Bei Gaotie
text: Chinese phrase for being forced to take expensive high-speed trains.(Bei is a Chinese character indicating a passive voice; Gaotie means high-speed train.)

headline: Spill Commissioners Call for Review of Energy Policy
text: Two members of President Obama’s commission on the Deepwater Horizon explosion and spill said at a Congressional hearing on Friday that regulatory failures and industry overconfidence helped lead to the catastrophe and called for an overhaul of federal oversight of offshore drilling and a transition to safer, cleaner forms of energy.

headline: Fun Stuff
text: Since January 2004, when this column first appeared, the American consumer zeitgeist has evolved. Some argue, in fact, that a decisive change has occurred, and that a result of the wrenching economic downturn is that we just don’t care about stuff anymore. I suspect this conclusion is rash. There are, however, interesting traces in the culture that suggest somewhat more subtle shifts — attempts, perhaps, to reconcile the more virtuously possession-resistant stance that some now strike with the stubborn reality that, ultimately, people really like stuff.

headline: When Med Students Post Patient Pictures
text: Some of my Facebook friends are medical students who post cellphone pictures of patients with what these friends believe to be comical maladies, with captions like “A 5-foot-9 Hispanic male walks into a bar . . .” under a picture of a patient with a piece of rebar piercing his abdomen. The postings don’t include faces or names but still seem questionable. Doesn’t this violate patient privacy? NAME WITHHELD, NEW YORK

It merits space here as a “Your Dot” contribution (a feature aimed at encouraging constructive non-anonymous discussions).

headline: Friday Reading: Refunds for Planned Travel to Egypt
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: A Hatchet Man Stands Up for ‘Mad Men’
text: If you’re among the devoted viewers of “Mad Men” who read Daniel Mendelsohn’s recent takedown of that period drama in The New York Review of Books with tears in your eyes and your hands clenching into fists, it may satisfy you to learn that another man of letters has fired back at Mr. Mendelsohn and his articulate evisceration of the show.  And that man is…Dale Peck?

headline: Morgans Hotels to Offer a Minibar Stocked With Conversation Starters
text: Imagine that you land in an unusual city. You’re whisked away to your luxury hotel room, where you drop your luggage and immediately lock eyes with your traveling companion. And then it hits you: You have absolutely nothing to talk about.

headline: At Pebble Beach, Caddies Are the All-Seeing Eyes
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  The invisible Monterey Peninsula is in plain sight, beneath tilting fairways and tiny, sloping greens. Subtle shifts of terrain over time have created nearly imperceptible bumps, hollows and breaks. Eagle-eyed golfers often cannot see them. Even high-definition television cameras cannot read the optical illusions that obscure a slope, pulling a putt right that should go left.

headline: Everyone Wins in Deals for Fisher and Beauchemin
text: A pair of Western Conference clubs improved their lineups for playoff runs this week by acquiring veterans for future assets. Continuing a trend from a year ago, when the Devils acquired Ilya Kovalchuk and the Maple Leafs dealt for Dion Phaneuf, the Nashville Predators and Anaheim Ducks did not wait until the Feb. 28 trade deadline to make their moves.

headline: Head of German Central Bank Is Stepping Down
text: FRANKFURT  Axel Weber took himself out of the running Friday to become president of the European Central Bank, leaving deep uncertainty about who else can handle a job that is crucial to the survival of the euro.

headline: Avoiding a New Pharaoh
text: So Hosni Mubarak is out. Vice President Omar Suleiman says that Mubarak has stepped down and handed over power to the military. This is a huge triumph for people power, and it will resonate across the Middle East and far beyond (you have to wonder what President Hu Jintao of China is thinking right now). The narrative about how Arab countries are inhospitable for democracy, how the Arab world is incompatible with modernity — that has been shattered by the courage and vision of so many Tunisians and Egyptians.

text: Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, called President Obama a “weak president” who had been caught unawares by world events, began an “expensive failed social experiment” and shrugged off the nation’s economic crisis by saying “it could be worse.”

headline: Dress Up Your Salad
text: If you’re using low-fat dressing on your salad, you’re cutting more than calories from the dish. That’s because many of the nutrients in leafy green vegetables are fat-soluble, which means they need to be eaten with some fat so that the body can adequately absorb the nutrients.

headline: A Wonderland at Sea
text: The Allure of the Seas is a cruise ship built for those longing to get lost in a strange, wondrous, digital world of lights and colors.

headline: Adam Smith, Marriage Counselor
text: WHEN my husband offered this one up  “I’m sorry I didn’t finish Ella’s preschool applications”  as we slogged through traffic somewhere between Exits 7 and 8 of the New Jersey Turnpike, I didn’t miss a beat. “Seriously?” I said. “I asked you to do that a month ago.”

headline: Terrible Swift Tongue
text: I cannot be the only person who read, with something of a sinking heart, the undeniably likable letter defending her mother that 18-year-old Sophia Chua-Rubenfeld published last month in The New York Post.

headline: Osama Bin Laden: The Specter
text: “Aye, aye! they were mine — my irons, cried Ahab, exultantly. . . . Aye, I see — wanted to part it; free the fast fish — an old trick — I know him.” For a good generation now, the former chief of the C.I.A.’s bin Laden unit, Michael Scheuer, has insisted that he knew the tricks of Osama bin Laden, that he was on to him from the start, that he and the unit he headed from 1996 to 1999 had given the government multiple chances to kill or capture the Saudi master terrorist. The bureaucracy had not gone along; indecisive leaders who didn’t know the man they were trying to snag, who didn’t read his writings, had thwarted and betrayed the hunt. And still, after the calamities, after all the disasters inflicted upon us by this elusive and cunning adversary, we haven’t yet understood what we are up against. A view has crystallized that the trail of terror now goes beyond bin Laden, that the man on the run no longer pulls the strings of the jihad. Scheuer has come forth to challenge this complacency.

headline: From Here to There and Back, Melody Swirls Its Way Around
text: “Why fleest thou throughe the worlde?” It’s a 16th-century question with resonance today for successful young artists like the composer Nico Muhly, who find themselves perpetually on the go. Mr. Muhly’s blog and Twitter feed are proudly cosmopolitan, but lately his music has explored his ambivalent emotions about airports and hotel rooms, planes and taxicabs.

headline: Flame Retardants Found in Butter
text: For about a decade, scientists have known that most Americans have minute quantities of flame retardants called polybrominated diphenyl ethers, PBDEs, in their bodies, but they were not sure how they got there.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diner’s Journal.

headline: Chaos, Food, Lodging
text: “Every college town is heaven,” Justin Taylor writes in “The Gospel of Anarchy,” his first novel, “each one different but the same.” This book may be set in Gainesville, Fla., but it will resonate with anyone who’s ever worked at a burrito joint in Chapel Hill, played Hacky Sack in Madison or fomented revolution in Eugene. These incubators of young adult weirdness — affordable and open-minded enough for even the crispiest burnouts — might be the last ecosystems in America able to sustain life at the fringes.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Vena Cava
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York Fashion Week. Here, the model Gracie Carvalho from Marilyn Management before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Christian McCulloch for M.A.C. and hair by Ted Gibson. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: Two Voices
text: Memoir has become in recent years a kind of hard-luck lit, and at first glance Henry Cockburn is just another young man dropped into trouble, as the sparks fly upward. Not that the particulars aren’t his own, or ­attention-grabbing. At 20, Cockburn hears a few trees request that he dance in some frostbiting February water. (“Oh that my words were now written!” even Job said. “Oh that they were printed in a book!” — so the confessional impulse, at least, isn’t entirely new.) Fishermen save Henry’s life; police officers reassign him from general to mental hospitals. He rides out the next seven years in more and more “secure” institutions, a prisoner guilty basically of skinny-dipping. The story is sad, but “Henry’s Demons” is more than just that.

headline: 2010 Marijuana Arrests Top 1978-96 Total
text: Updated, 12:55 p.m. | More people were arrested last year in New York City on charges of marijuana possession than during the entire 19-year period from 1978 to 1996, according to an analysis released this morning by the Drug Policy Alliance.

headline: This Weekend’s Top Matches
text: The outstanding matchups this weekend in soccer:

headline: Graphic Books Best-Sellers: I Think I Do
text: The ups and downs of planning a wedding are many: where to do it (and how much to spend), whom to invite (and what the invitation will look like), what to serve, how to entertain your guests and more. In “Scenes From an Impending Marriage,” which lands at No. 2 on our hardcover list this week, the cartoonist Adrian Tomine chronicles his own march down the aisle in a series of comic strips. The end result also served as an atypical wedding favor for the guests at his nuptials. The publisher, Drawn & Quarterly, has a six-page preview available for download.

headline: What Am I So Afraid Of?
text: The British journalist Allison Pearson’s frothy, peachy smoothie of a first novel, “I Don’t Know How She Does It,” surged with a certain inevitability to best-seller glory when it was published in 2002. So-called chick lit, about shopping and dating and cocktails, was on the wane, and its natural successor, mommy lit, was rolling in, with madcap tales of botched baking experiments, wayward nannies and extramarital e-mail flirtations. Could a wave of divorce narratives (split lit?) be far behind?

headline: Investigation Begins in Neighborhood Where Blast Killed 5
text: ALLENTOWN, Pa.  Investigators were preparing Friday to insert cameras into an underground gas pipeline here as they continued their hunt for the cause of an explosion that killed five people.

headline: Peter Som Tones It Down
text: It’s far too early in the season to be talking about fall trends, but there certainly has been some consensus among the first shows at New York Fashion Week, which have included an abundance of dark and somber designs. There have been great textural coats as well, some in athletic sportswear shapes, at Richard Chai, Wayne Lee and, this morning, at Peter Som, but perhaps that is to be expected after the winter we’ve seen in New York. (Is it a coincidence that both Ms. Lee and Mr. Som showed variations of baseball jackets in luxury fabrics?)

headline: A Chat With the Man Behind ‘Biutiful’
text: The Mexican director Alejandro González Iñárritu first met the Spanish actor Javier Bardem at the Academy Awards in 2001. Both had been nominated for the first time: Mr. Gonzalez Iñárritu’s “Amores Perros” for best foreign language film and Mr. Bardem for best actor in “Before Night Falls.” And while neither won, afterward “our loser’s party was the best,” as Mr. Bardem recalled, and the two of them talked about collaborating.

headline: Mubarak Steps Down
text: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof on President Mubarak's handover of power and his expectations for what comes next.

headline: A Brittle Leader, Appearing Strong
text: Hosni Mubarak’s legacy was supposed to be stability. During almost three decades in power, he rejected bold action in favor of caution. He took half-steps at economic liberalization, preserved the peace with Israel, gave his police force the power to arrest without charge and allowed only the veneer of democracy to take hold.

headline: Homage to Catalonia
text: In Graham Greene’s novel “The Quiet American,” a French police officer is “incongruously” smitten with his wife, a flashy blonde said to be sleeping with his subordinates. But the policeman turns out to be an uncommonly good detective, since, as Greene argued, “you cannot love without intuition.” In “The Second Son,” Chief Inspector Nikolai Hoffner is also skilled at reading people (he recognizes a British spy in minutes), and he too has a great capacity for love.

headline: Swashbuckling Spymaster
text: In January 1940, William J. Donovan sat in a Manhattan radio studio plugging “The Fighting 69th,” a Hollywood movie about the cocky, mostly Irish New York regiment whose exploits during World War I had made Donovan a national hero and earned him the Medal of Honor. The release of the film, starring James Cagney and Pat O’Brien, with George Brent as the rakishly handsome Donovan, put the then wealthy and well-connected corporate attorney back in the spotlight just at the moment President Franklin Roosevelt was looking for men who could help mobilize the country for war.

headline: Nuclear Reaction
text: The title of Elizabeth Stuckey-­French’s latest novel is playfully retro, hinting that the radioactive lady’s revenge will be nutty and kooky, not dark and messy. And if the lady in question is 77, how dangerous can she be?

headline: Revolution From Within
text: Nelson Mandela was circumcised as a 16-year-old boy alongside a flowing river in the Eastern Cape. The ceremony was similar to those of other Bantu peoples. An elder moved through the line making ring-like cuts, and foreskins fell away. The boys could not so much as blink; it was a rite of passage that took you beyond pain. They exclaimed, “Ndiyindoda!” (“I am the man!”). A brambly leaf was wrapped around the wound to stop the bleeding. The boys had to lie in a certain position, and at midnight they were woken. One by one, they went out into the cold and buried their foreskins in stony soil. For Mandela, the circumcision was something that linked him with his Thembu ancestors; in losing a part of his manhood, he became a man.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Duckie Brown
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#591", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

headline: Would You Like a Shake With That Workout?
text: The idea seems sort of silly, just another exercise gimmick. Stand for a few minutes on a platform that vibrates. Get off and try to do some weight lifting  squats, for example. Or try a short sprint. Or see how high you can jump. You are somehow supposed to be able to lift heavier weights, sprint faster, jump higher.

headline: The Computer Made Me Do It
text: Humanity is migrating to cyberspace. In the past five years, Americans have doubled the hours they spend online, exceeding their television time and more than tripling the time they spend reading newspapers or magazines. Most now play computer or video games regularly, about 13 hours a week on average. By age 21, the average young American has spent at least three times as many hours playing virtual games as reading. It took humankind eight years to spend 100 million hours building Wikipedia. We now spend at least 200 million hours a week playing World of Warcraft.

headline: Up, Up, Up
text: Edward Glaeser, a Harvard professor of economics, has spent several decades investigating the role cities play in fostering human achievement. In “Triumph of the City,” he has embedded his findings in a book that is at once polymathic and vibrant.

headline: Time and Possibilities
text: At the age of 54, in the middle of a distinguished career as a scholar of the Hebrew Bible, the Harvard professor James L. Kugel received a diagnosis of cancer and was given a few years to live. Seven years later, with his cancer in remission, he began writing a book about the experience. Or rather, he began writing a book, “In the Valley of the Shadow,” that uses his encounter with death to investigate and report on a state of mind notoriously resistant to literary exploration: the state of mind in which you intuit something on the order of God.

headline: The Parisienne
text: How can you not like a heroine who invents lascivious confessions to shock the priest and finds that kneeling in church makes “naughtiness” spring to her mind?

headline: Solving Bobby Fischer
text: In the summer of 1972, the world’s attention was directed toward Reykjavik, the capital of Iceland, to watch a championship chess match. Called “the Match of the Century,” the contest between the Russian champion, Boris Spassky, and the American challenger, Bobby Fischer, attracted that attention because of its cold war implications.

headline: Finding a Way
text: From the very first sentence of his unusual memoir, “House of Prayer No. 2,” Mark Richard brings together the vernacular and the performative. “Say you have a ‘special child,’ ” the book begins, at once inviting us in folksy terms to suppose this to be the case and commanding us to summon the child into existence through the sheer act of saying so. The opening pages, Genesis-like, call the child’s world into being, his early life created via a series of severe directives: “Birth him with his father away” and “Move the family to a tobacco county in Southside Virginia” and “Make the ­mother cry and miss her mother.” The special child in question, we come to understand, is Richard himself. It’s an uncommon way to introduce the protagonist of a memoir, but an apt way to frame this absorbing account of growing up in the 1960s South, living with a disability, becoming a writer and finding faith. Richard’s book attests to the power of words (and the Word) in shaping a life, while at the same time challenging some dearly held beliefs about memoir as a genre.

headline: Sudden Awakening
text: Long before publishers began branding the books of an author or illustrator with an identifiable look, Allen Say’s picture books have had a modest but singular and immediately recognizable design. His name and the title appear in a calm and unfancy font on the cover, anchoring a single image from the book. Endpapers are plain and the page design is consistent, with a brief text on white pages facing framed or full-bleed watercolor illustrations. Reading a book by Allen Say feels like looking through a succession of windows while someone quietly tells you a story — ­often a small but resonating incident from a person’s life that demonstrates bravery of one kind or another.

headline: Liberty or Death
text: The specter of full-grown adults festooned in tricorn hats may have retreated in the post-Tucson landscape, but the American Revolution and its reputed lessons are still in the air, making this an interesting time for Laurie Halse Anderson to publish “Forge,” her new novel about the Revolution and colonial-era slavery, and a sequel to her prize-winning “Chains.”

headline: Urban Myths
text: When a magical glass staircase appears over a lake in Central Park, 10-year-old Rose, trailing behind her father and brother, brooding about how much she wants a dog, is the only one who sees it before it disappears. Like the talking White Rabbit in “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland,” the sudden appearance of a curious impossibility in “The Steps Across the Water” propels the story into the realm of fantasy. But unlike Alice, who quickly pursues her new acquaintance down the rabbit hole, Rose returns to the routines of her daily life as a New York schoolgirl, keeping this secret to herself.

headline: Kristol’s Brute Reason
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Center of Attention
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘The Violence of Peace’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Up Front: E-Book Best Sellers
text: This week we introduce our revamped best-seller lists, the result of many months of planning, research and design.

headline: On Our Radar: Namibia Designates Entire Coast as National Park
text: Namibia designates its entire 976-mile coastline a national park, consolidating several existing preserves into the 26.6 million-acre Namib-Skeleton Coast National Park. The Namibian authorities have recently expanded wildlife conservation efforts in a successful effort to boost tourism; in one notable success, a population of lions has been re-established along the arid Skeleton Coast after being totally extinguished by hunting and poisoning in the 1980s. [The Telegraph]

headline: Inside the List
text: GREEN ACRES: Four years ago, Ree Drummond was just another sometime city girl turned Oklahoma ranch wife with a flock of home-schooled children and a blog. Now, she’s a full-fledged media star, with millions of page views a month at ThePioneerWoman.com, a long list of television appearances and a new memoir, subtitled “Black Heels to Tractor Wheels,” at No. 2 on the hardcover nonfiction list. (It’s also No. 8 on the e-book list, on Page 23.) Call Drummond the Prairie Dog Mother: she mixes the chipper can-do spirit of Laura Ingalls Wilder, the slick production values of Martha Stewart and steely domestic ambition that Amy Chua might approve. At her Web site, vicarious homesteaders can read instructions on topics ranging from how to load hay onto your feed truck and knock down fences to how to make Pasta ai Quattro Formaggi and spiff up digital photographs. (Photoshop’s “define and sharpen” feature is apparently “really good for animal hair.”) Drummond has said she started her blog mainly as a way of sharing photos with her mother. Now, she offers lavish down-home food porn like a 39-shot pictorial on “Perfect Potatoes au Gratin,” a perfect accompaniment to the copious beefcake shots of her Wrangler-rocking husband, a k a Marlboro Man, cuddling a baby or wearing chaps or “nourishing” cows, his face usually shadowed under the brim of a cowboy hat. “When my husband and I got married, we became one flesh,” Drummond wrote in a recent post. “So when he spends eight hours tearing down and building fence, it’s like I do, too. I just love the one flesh concept! It makes me one of the hardest workers I’ve ever met.”

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE NEAREST EXIT,  by Olen Steinhauer (Minotaur Books, $14.99.) Milo Weaver, the C.I.A. spy who first appeared in Steinhauer’s 2009 thriller, “The Tourist,” has grown sick of his trade and longs to settle down. But his stab at domesticity is cut short when he’s dispatched on a mission and becomes embroiled in the sordid world of human trafficking, a blackmail plot involving German intelligence officials and a search for a mole in the agency.

headline: Editors Choice’
text: SWAMPLANDIA!,  by Karen Russell (Knopf, $24.95.) Russell’s exuberant first novel, which works as a kind of expansion of her story “Ava Wrestles the Alligator,” concerns the pleasures and miseries of life in a failing alligator theme park in the Everglades.

headline: Artifacts Will Be on View at ‘Silk Road’ Exhibit
text: An exhibition of ancient Chinese artifacts will go forward at the University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archeology and Anthropology, after all. The exhibition, “Secrets of the Silk Road,” which includes materials, including two mummies, recently excavated at desert burial sites in western China, was organized by the Bowers Museum in Santa Ana, Calif., and was shown there last year and subsequently at the Houston Museum of Natural Science, where it closed on Jan. 2. It was scheduled to open at the Penn Museum on February 5, but last week, three days before the planned opening, the museum announced that China had requested that none of the artifacts be displayed. As a result, the museum would only show photographs, multimedia presentations, and a recreation of an excavation site; it offered refunds to those who had bought advance tickets and said that the exhibition would now be free.

headline: Twisted Trails
text: It’s getting harder and harder to tell the good guys from the bad guys in a modern western, of which Urban Waite’s first novel, THE TERROR OF LIVING (Little, Brown, $24.99), is one fine specimen. Phil Hunt, thoughtfully described as “a good man, made up of all the bad things in the world,” did a 10-year stretch in prison for killing a shopkeeper during a dumb robbery. But this flawed man was rescued by a strong woman who became his wife, and in the 20 years that Hunt has been out, they’ve made a quiet, decent life together on a small farm south of Seattle where they raise and board horses.

headline: Carmelo Anthony Flirts With High Efficiency
text: The prevalence of Carmelo Anthony trade rumors has brought forth an understandable amount of analysis and criticism concerning the exact nature of Anthony’s game. After all, in order to best understand how Anthony would fit with a team like the Knicks or the Nets, it is crucial to look closely at the way he plays with and without the ball. Some players are more compatible with certain systems or teams than others, in no small part because of the way those players go about contributing to their teams’ success.

headline: The IRS, Breast Pumps and other Updates
text: Some updates.

headline: Gauging the Chances of Euro Zone Defaults
text: 8:39 p.m. | Updated  to correct reference to countries in final paragraph.

headline: In Groupon Ad, Even the Mountain Was a Problem
text: There’s no question that Groupon is one of the hottest Internet start-ups, a small elite group that includes the likes of Facebook, Twitter and Zynga. But when it comes to playing in the big leagues of advertising, Groupon still has much to learn.

headline: Grilled Cheese Sandwich, the Appetizer Edition
text: What to serve with a predinner drink? When no one else is around, the answer is, often, another predinner drink. What passes for a cocktail hour in our house involves a glass of whatever wine or beer my wife and I are going to drink with dinner, followed by another glass of the same as we move from kitchen to table.

headline: Protesters Cheer Mubarak’s Resignation
text: The streets of Cairo exploded with jubilant cries of protesters after it was announced that President Hosni Mubarak had passed all authority to a council of military leaders.

headline: Andrew Mann
text: Mr. Mann, 55, is the managing director of the United States operations of Gardiner & Theobald, a project management and construction consultant with offices worldwide.

headline: Backstage Beauty | Peter Som
text: “Peter’s inspiration was a very fabulous American artist called Cindy Sherman,” said the (very fabulous French) makeup artist Tom Pecheux backstage at Peter Som. “She does self-portraits where she takes herself on a crazy journey. She always brings a twist into her face, so in terms of makeup we wanted to do that.” This translated into nearly nude skin (with a bit of rosy blush and a touch of shimmery powder topping cheeks), bare brows, lashes and eyelids, punctuated with a statement lip. “We started with a red lipstick, the definition of a grown-up woman,” said Pecheux, noting that the designer’s fall 2011 collection seemed more adult to him than previous seasons. “To twist it, we are adding a layer of metallic color.” Lips were lined with M.A.C. Cherry Lip Pencil, filled in with a lipstick color being tested for fall tentatively called Runaway Red (according to M.A.C., Dare You is the closest shade currently available), dusted with M.A.C. Invisible Powder, and then dabbed with M.A.C. pigments in silver, rose gold and melon. “I’m not a fan of a lip with shimmer, a frosted lip — I think it’s cheesy,” said Pecheux of his matte metallic creation. The look was paired with a hairstyle inspired by Tippi Hedren’s character in “The Birds,” using Wella Ocean Spritz for texture and extensions with roots dyed into them. “It gives the hairstyle depth, it makes hair look thicker, the minute you have a root it makes hair look thicker and a bit denser,” the hairstylist Eugene Souleiman, who crafted the look, explained of the extensions. “It’s a little like when I used to do Prada and Miu Miu. It has that ’90s take on the ’50s — it’s slightly minimal, but now it’s a bit more raw.”

headline: Is Inflation Baked In?
text: Whenever I write about inflation or the lack thereof, I get a lot of remarkably angry mail from people who are focused on commodity prices; they just can’t imagine how people like me or Ben Bernanke can be relaxed about the overall inflation picture when the prices of wheat, oil, etc. have risen so much lately.

headline: Groupon Withdraws Contentious Super Bowl Spots
text: Groupon is ending a campaign that made its debut on Super Bowl Sunday, days after making changes in response to considerable criticism of the ads.

headline: How to Groom Your New Facebook Profile
text: Facebook recently introduced a new profile format to all 600 million or so of its members. The new layout is more photo-driven, and allows you to customize your profile more meticulously than before. But unless you go digging, you may miss some of its better features.

headline: At 78, Clive Davis Still Commands the Stage
text: No figure in the music industry is more closely associated with the Grammy Awards than Clive Davis, who for more than 30 years has held his see-and-be-seen party at the Beverly Hilton the night before the show. This year Mr. Davis, 78, expects plenty of the usual pop stars and industry bigwigs at the fete, as well as boldface names from sports like Magic Johnson and Serena Williams — a guest list large enough that he has had to make some unpleasant choices in who doesn’t make the cut. “This year I really can’t go out to public restaurants,” he said in an interview.

headline: Donations Preserve 3 Varsity Teams at Cal but Can’t Save Baseball
text: The University of California, Berkeley, announced Friday that it was reinstating three of the five varsity teams it cut in September after a group of donors, alumni and fans raised as much as $13 million in private donations to restore the teams.

headline: Lucy Walked Tall, a Foot Bone Suggests
text: Lucy may well be the world’s most famous fossil hominid. She is the best-known specimen of the species Australopithecus afarensis, and her partial skeleton, found in 1974, revealed that she and her kin could walk upright.

headline: With Wal-Mart Silent on Plans, Critics Focus on Rumored Site
text: It isn’t much to look at, just a big empty lot packed with snow and some struggling cattail plants sandwiched between the Starrett City apartment complex and a shopping mall. But a field in the East New York section of Brooklyn has become one of the most hotly debated spots in New York City. All because it may  possibly, one day be home to the city’s first Wal-Mart store.

headline: Picking Up Good Vibrations at the Gym
text: In today’s Personal Best column, Gina Kolata writes about vibrating platforms used by some exercisers and athletes in hopes of improving performance.

headline: Battling Mold Infestations
text: TOXIC mold continues to be a problem in New York City. Last year the Department of Housing Preservation and Development issued 14,290 violations for mold in residential buildings.

headline: Interim Coach Has Pacers Winning Again
text: The Pacers started the season with a surprising 9-7 record, which at the end of November was good enough for fifth best in the Eastern Conference (percentage points ahead of the Miami Heat).

headline: In the Mood For Hot Pink
text: Just in time for Cupid-appropriate gifting, Agent Provocateur, the naughty but very nice English lingerie label, has opened a sprawling new flagship on Madison Avenue. Boasting black lacquer furniture, hand-painted silk walls and a giant vintage chandelier, the sexy, boudoirlike space has a mezzanine level for private appointments. Pieces in this hot-pink lace and peony print are $140 to $220; 675 Madison Avenue, (212) 840-2436.

headline: ‘It’s O.K. to Throw Up’
text: Midfielder Yael Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., native by way of the University of North Carolina, will be contributing to the Goal blog in the runup to the third season of Women’s Professional Soccer and as the United States women’s national team prepares to play in the Algarve Cup and the FIFA Women’s World Cup in Germany later this year.

headline: Emanuel Leads by 30 Points in Chicago Mayor’s Race
text: Rahm Emanuel, the former White House chief of staff, leads his nearest rival by 30 percentage points in the race to become the next mayor of Chicago on Feb. 22, according to the latest Chicago Tribune/WGN poll.

headline: In New York City’s Little Egypt, Infectious Joy
text: The jubilation in Egypt at news of the resignation of President Hosni Mubarak spread quickly to New York’s Little Egypt neighborhood in Queens, where hundreds of Egyptian-American Muslims and others massed at Friday prayers to offer thanks.

headline: Southern Sudan Suffers a Blow as Fighting Ends a Truce
text: KAMPALA, Uganda  Fresh battles between renegade soldiers and the southern Sudanese military in recent days have left more than 100 people dead in southern Sudan, sending tremors through a heavily militarized region that only days ago celebrated the final results of a referendum to separate from the rest of the country.

headline: Bronx Hospitals’ Medical Records of 1.7 Million People Are Stolen
text: Update, 3:15 p.m. | Some 1.7 million patients, staff members, contractors and vendors had their medical and other personal records from city hospitals in the Bronx stolen, the city’s Health and Hospitals Corporation said Friday. The affected hospitals were Jacobi Medical Center, North Central Bronx Hospital and two affiliated clinics. The “overwhelming majority” of those who had their data stolen were patients, the agency said.

headline: Habitats | NoHo
text: Zak Tucker and Vilmari Ayala acquired roof rights to turn their tiny top-floor co-op into a triplex.

headline: Thomas Campbell on Tapestry

text: Images from "Tapestry in the Baroque: Threads of Splendor" at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Splendid Threads Off the Walls of Monarchs
text: Forty-four tapestries will be on display as part of "Tapestry in the Baroque: Threads of Splendor," which opens Wednesday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Sweden ‘Toxic’ for Assange, Lawyers Contend
text: LONDON  Lawyers for Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, said Friday that he should not be sent to Sweden to face allegations of sexual abuse there because he was now seen as “public enemy number one” in that country.

headline: Globetrotters Head to the Hudson
text: While it may seem like a relatively new phenomenon, trick shots were invented and perfected by the Harlem Globetrotters over the last 85 years.

headline: Men’s Fall Fashion 2011 | Duckie Brown
text: In a fur-filled season, this curly shearling teddy bear coat from Duckie Brown, worn with gray flannel wrap-waist trousers, was an original.

headline: World Leaders Cheer but Remain Wary
text: As the streets of Cairo erupted in celebration, leaders and officials around the world greeted the departure of President Hosni Mubarak on Friday with full-throated expressions of support for the people of Egypt along with some measured words of caution ahead for an uncertain period of political transition.

headline: Weekend Competition: Conversation Stoppers
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to share conversation stoppers – comments guaranteed to end all social intercourse.

headline: Where Beauty Meets Substance
text: WHO was it who said all you need to know is that beauty is truth and truth beauty?

headline: The Accordion Apartment in NoHo
text: THE apartment in NoHo where Zak Tucker lives with his fiancée and the couple’s new baby has come a long way since he arrived seven years ago.

headline: Religion Is Relative
text: In a report by the Center for Applied Research in the Apostolate (CARA) at Georgetown University, which was released last week by the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops, there’s one small paragraph that has started me musing, once again, on what parents really want for their children when it comes to religion.

headline: Egypt Captivates World’s Attention — Except at CPAC
text: UPDATE, 4:35 p.m.: Three weeks of historic protests in Egypt upended President Hosni Mubarak’s regime on Friday with the world looking. But here at the Conservative Political Action Conference, hardly anyone took any notice.

headline: A New Way to Think About Valentine’s Day Gifts
text: In this weekend’s “Your Money” column, I take a somewhat grouchy look at Valentine’s Day gift-giving, in an attempt to prove that you don’t have to spend lavishly (or hand over anything at all) on Feb. 14 to have a successful marriage.

headline: Landry Fields’s Day Job at Modell’s
text: In this video, the Knicks rookie Landry Fields plays the part of “Leroy Jenkins, employee of the month” at Modell’s, and hilarity ensues.

headline: European Officials Urge Fourth Round of Financing for Greece
text: ATHENS  Officials with the European Union and the International Monetary Fund recommended on Friday that Greece receive its fourth round of bailout financing.

headline: Q & A
