headline: Double Duty: 88th Precinct and 88 Keys
text: Officer Ka Kit Yip of the 88th Precinct in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, is 5 feet 6 inches tall. On Saturday afternoon, he will face what some would consider an adversary that measures 6 feet 11 inches long.

headline: More Focus Groups for ‘Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark’
text: The going rate for your thoughts used to be a penny. Now the producers of the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” are offering $60 goodie bags to people who serve in focus groups that will respond to several performances. Two focus groups attended Thursday night’s performance, and four more are scheduled to be at Friday night’s show and the Saturday matinee. It’s not unheard of for Broadway producers to use focus groups, and the musical has used them before since preview performances began on Nov. 28. But these are the first since largely negative reviews of the show by theater critics across the country were published on Tuesday. OnTrack Research, a marketing and consulting firm, is coordinating the focus groups, and here’s the rub: participants only get to see Act I or Act II, not both. They are then asked to fill out surveys and join in discussions in a “V.I.P. room.” The details of the focus groups were outlined in an e-mail to participants from OnTrack Research. Here is the full e-mail, which a focus group participant passed along and which was authenticated by the production on Friday.

headline: Stalling Complaints Prompt Investigation of 97,000 TDI Volkswagens and Audis
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has expanded an investigation into stalling complaints involving 97,000 late-model Volkswagens and Audis equipped with 2-liter 4-cylinder turbodiesel engines.

headline: Dorothy Furlong and Charlie Hall
text: AN ice king married a snow queen on Feb. 5 in Minnesota, making for one of the warmest celebrations ever to grace the 125-year-old St. Paul Winter Carnival.

headline: When Love Outgrows Gifts on Valentine’s Day
text: As if we needed another sign that Valentine’s Day is getting awfully expensive, the coupon Web sites have now gotten into the game.

headline: Both Sides Are Braced for Debt-Limit Debate
text: WASHINGTON  With a showdown approaching over the need to raise the federal debt limit, White House officials feel they have the upper hand over Congressional Republicans who want to use the debate on the measure to force deep spending cuts, people familiar with the administration’s thinking say.

headline: Take the Stairs
text: For some buyers, only a duplex will do. Stairs create zones for sleeping and for everything else. And best of all, they suggest a house.

headline: Bonds's Journey to 756
text: The significant moments in the career of Barry Bonds, the all-time leader in career home runs.

headline: The Added Value in a Staircase
text: OF all the must-have items for a New York City apartment, stairs generally don’t figure very high on the list.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 1
text: Thursday night of Fashion Week began with a variety of parties, featuring young designers, animal rights supporters and a graffiti artist.

headline: Men, Women and A.D.H.D.
text: Do men and women exhibit different symptoms of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, or A.D.H.D.? What about boys and girls? These are among the questions recently posed by readers of the Consults blog. Dr. Russell A. Barkley, clinical professor of psychiatry at the Medical University of South Carolina and author, most recently, of “Taking Charge of Adult A.D.H.D.,”  responds to one reader whose wife has a “whopping case” of A.D.H.D.

headline: Suspect in Stolen-BMW Assault Case Dies in Florida Shootout
text: A former convict wanted on charges that he stole a BMW sports car last month and stuffed its critically injured owner in the trunk was killed Friday in a shootout with officers on a fugitive task force in Florida, officials said.

headline: The Fleet of 2011
text: With features like a water park and a culinary school, the new cruise ships of 2011 are trying to catch your attention.

headline: From African Rivers to French Impressionism
text: Cruise lines offer trips to more remote destinations, stay in port longer and designate new theme cruises.

headline: A Creative Corner in Wanchai, Hong Kong
text: The Star Street neighborhood in Hong Kong’s Wanchai district is quickly becoming a magnet for creative entrepreneurs, with new boutiques and restaurants cropping up alongside design firms in this pedestrian-friendly enclave.

headline: 14 New Cruises for 2011
text: IF your mental image of a cruise conjures a party boat island-hopping in the Caribbean with little passenger interest in its ports of call, think again. Though the Caribbean remains the most trafficked destination for cruise ships, cruise lines are now piloting trips to more remote destinations both at home and abroad. They are also staying in port longer and designating theme cruises that are far from singles mingles. The following is an overview of some of 2011’s most interesting new sailings.

headline: 10 Restaurants Worth Leaving the Ship For
text: Cruises rarely lack for dining options, but the times when ships are docked — either in ports along their routes or before they set sail — offer rare opportunities to explore local cuisines. Here, then, is a list of restaurants in ports of call around the world — some storied, some new — that should entice travelers to leave the comfort of the ship behind.

headline: A Bit of a Working Vacation
text: When it comes to shore excursions, travelers are often steered toward tourist-friendly entertainment rather than the reality that lies beyond souvenir shops. But this year, Crystal Cruises offers one volunteer excursion per cruise, providing a chance for travelers to give time to causes that benefit destinations on their itineraries.

headline: 25 Years on the Sea and Counting
text: ON April 15, 2010, in Cape Town, South Africa, Capt. Dag Dvergastein left the Regent Seven Seas Voyager after 18 years with the Seven Seas line. Passengers who had known him for years were beside themselves. Liz Ruwitch, 95, who had been on four world cruises with him, said that instead of going on the next Voyager world cruise as she had planned, she signed up for the South American one instead. Gladys Vallone, 82, who hardly ever misses a world cruise, decided to stay home this year with her husband in New Jersey.

headline: On the World’s Largest Cruise Ship, the Sea Is an Afterthought
text: I WAS standing in Central Park in the middle of the Caribbean Sea near an Indian mangosteen tree, a Malaysian olive tree, a number of elephant ears and a total of 96 other species of plant. Birds were tweeting and mothers, as diversely global as the plants, pushed strollers along the paths. A little girl twirled in a pink dress.

headline: Ship Designers Look ‘Outdoors’
text: Cruise lines are shifting their focus from interiors to design features that emphasize the outdoors.

headline: Cruising With the Stars
text: Cruise lines have their own celebrity culture, one that favors reality and cable TV stars as well as authors and politicos you’d expect to see on the lecture circuit.

headline: Brought to You by Your Favorite Sponsor
text: Corporations have enlisted cruise ships to extend their brands, resulting in a name-dropping spree on the high seas. Consider:

headline: When House-Hunting Is a Wild Ride
text: MUFFIN DOWDLE of Ginnel Real Estate in Bedford Hills has found resourceful ways of selling real estate in this harsh winter. When unable to slog through the snow via four-wheel drive, she saddles up one of her three horses and takes off, often with the other two in tow so clients can ride alongside her.

headline: Southwestern Water: Going, Going, Gone?
text: The glum projections of the growing gap between demand for water in the Southwest and the dwindling supplies have never been optimistic, but two new studies— one a research report based on satellite data, and the other an analysis of rainfall, water use and the costs associated with obtaining new water — make earlier forecasts seem positively rosy.

headline: Freescale Plans to Go Public
text: Freescale Semiconductor, the chip maker acquired in 2006 in one of the biggest technology leveraged buyouts ever, filed to go public on Friday, seeking to raise money to pay down its debt load.

headline: Chris Bosh and the Self-Fulfilling Prophecy
text: The sports analytics movement has given basketball decision makers more valuable information than they have ever had, but, in a way, their experience in implementing their findings is atypical in the information age. The modern world is marked by the rapid dissemination of incredible amounts of information to relevant and interested parties; people from all over the planet know more today about one another and the world they inhabit than any human beings have before, primarily because of how freely information is exchanged. When it comes to analytical data in sports, however, coaches in particular face a unique challenge in passing along the statistical information they deem important. It’s not enough to know that a player is most effective running one type of play or shooting from one area of the floor. Coaches today must also understand how to convey that information in a way that makes it digestible and useful.

headline: Look of the Moment | Elle Macpherson
text: The Look: Model citizen — from the tee to the boots, this look gives new meaning to the words “hot momma.”

headline: A Farmhouse Looks for a Home
text: IN 2009, a developer named Michael Davis paid $5 million for a 2.3-acre lot in the Sagaponack Greens subdivision, with plans to build a 7,000-square-foot English country-style mansion and sell it for close to $20 million. Before he could do so he had to decide what to do with the four abandoned structures on the former farm property: two old barns, an 1840s Greek Revival house and a 1930 American Foursquare.

headline: Geithner Takes Aim at Fannie and Freddie

headline: Race and the Oscar Race

headline: The Bohemian Fashion Muse
text: FLORENCE WELCH, the titian-tressed lead singer of Florence and the Machine, has become an idol of the frenetic indie set. But when she received word in December of her first Grammy nomination, for best new artist, she was lounging around her parents’ London home in classic languorous-bombshell mode.

headline: 3 Shot Dead, 3 Wounded in Virginia; Suspect Is Arrested
text: A 37-year-old illegal immigrant was under arrest Friday after three people were found shot to death and three others were wounded at two houses just blocks apart in the northern Virginia city of Manassas, the police said.

headline: Hollywood’s Whiteout
text: CRAMMED into this year’s field of 10 best picture Oscar nominees are British aristocrats, Volvo-driving Los Angeles lesbians, a flock of swans, a gaggle of Harvard computer geeks, clans of Massachusetts fighters and Missouri meth dealers, as well as 19th-century bounty hunters, dream detectives and animated toys. It’s a fairly diverse selection in terms of genre, topic, sensibility, style and ambition. But it’s also more racially homogenous  more white  than the 10 films that were up for best picture in 1940, when Hattie McDaniel became the first black American to win an Oscar for her role as Mammy in “Gone With the Wind.” In view of recent history the whiteness of the 2011 Academy Awards is a little blinding.

headline: Interview: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar
text: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar talks about his new documentary about the Harlem Renaissance (Photos by The New York Times. Associated Press, Smithsonian American Art Museum and Getty Images).

headline: Preparing for the Future: Improving College Readiness
text: This week’s education news includes the finding that fewer than half of New York City’s high school graduates were prepared for college or a well-paying career. Statewide, 77 percent of students graduate, but correlating state standards to college performance reveals that far fewer of those graduates are equipped for success in college or the workplace.

headline: Bill Would Make University Sell a Pollock for Scholarship Money
text: A bill that has been proposed in the Iowa state legislature would require the University of Iowa to sell Jackson Pollock’s “Mural,” an 8-by-20-foot painting, to pay for scholarships. The work was valued at $140 million in 2008, the Iowa City Press-Citizen reported on Thursday.

headline: Fashion Week Video | Siki Im Casting
text: Siki Im, the Ecco Domani Award-winning men’s wear designer, was born and raised in Cologne, Germany, and graduated from Oxford University with a first-class honors degree in architecture. After moving to New York 10 years ago, Im transitioned to fashion by working for Karl Lagerfeld and Helmut Lang before establishing his own men’s wear collection in 2009. The Moment caught up with Im as he and the stylist David Vandewal were creating looks, shooting a look-book and preparing for his fashion week presentation, which is at 9 o’clock Friday night at Metropolitan Pavilion.

headline: Quiet Worries as Israel Watches an Ally Depart
text: JERUSALEM  As the streets of Gaza exploded with celebration on Friday night with masked Hamas militants marching defiantly to cheer the resignation of President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, Israelis reacted with quiet and deep concern because the regional leader on whom they had relied most was suddenly gone.

headline: Screening: Doctors’ Group Urges Fewer Scans for Lower Back Pain

headline: Obama Leaves Wishy-Washy Behind
text: I’ve been critical of the Obama administration’s wishy-washy, weather vane approach to people power in Tunisia and Egypt. But President Obama’s statements yesterday were a big step forward, and his speech just now was pitch perfect. It’s our job as journalists to criticize, but I thought he got it exactly right. He put the United States unambiguously on the side of Egypt’s youth and future and freedom, all while making it clear that Egypt’s future is up to Egyptians to decide.

headline: Yale and Peru Sign Accord on Machu Picchu Artifacts
text: Three months after Yale University and the government of Peru announced a tentative accord under which Yale would return a group of artifacts excavated at Machu Picchu, Yale formally signed a partnership agreement on Friday with a Peruvian university to establish a joint center where the objects will be conserved, studied and displayed. The center will be at the Universidad Nacional de San Antonio Abad del Cusco, in Cusco, the city closest to Machu Picchu, and will be called the U.N.S.A.A.C.-Yale International Center for the Study of Machu Picchu and Inca Culture. It will include a museum exhibition space; a storage site for the archeological artifacts, which include stone tools, ceramics and human and animal bones; and a laboratory and research area. Students and faculty members from Yale are expected to visit the center for training, research projects and field work; students and faculty members of the Peruvian university will also visit Yale. Meanwhile, a small number of artifacts will be loaned to Yale for display at the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History.

Chang reviews the redesigned Mazda 5, a smallish minivan on which Mazda has deployed its Nagare design language (inspired by a concept car at the 2006 Los Angeles auto show). Mr. Chang writes that the 5 offers a generally pleasing blend of useful features at a relatively low price. And it proved adept on a family outing:

headline: Stockholm Design Week | From Modern to Mod
text: In most people’s minds, there are only two settings on the Nordic furniture dial: Then (meaning postwar Modern) and Now. While I went to this year’s Stockholm Design Week, which ends on Sunday, excited solely about the latter, it turned out that the fair had something to offer in the former department as well. The Danish manufacturer Gubi recently shifted its attention towards resurrecting mid-century design icons, and the first fruits of that effort are on display this week. It has reissued Greta Grossman’s 1947 Grasshopper lamp and the 1966 Stokke Chair by Jens Qvistgaard, and is now the sole owner of reproduction rights for the cult Hungarian designer Mathieu Mategot’s work, starting with a multicolored coat rack and two pieces in his signature perforated metal: the Nagasaki chair and the Dedal bookcase. Mategot fans accustomed to 1stdibs sticker shock should rejoice.

headline: Obama’s Parting Gift to Gibbs
text: When President Obama delivered the keynote address to the Democratic National Convention in 2004, he borrowed a pale blue tie from his press secretary Robert Gibbs, who has since gained a reputation for his love of pastel-colored neckwear.

headline: Fincher’s Musketeers Talk Shop
text: As a filmmaker, David Fincher has the reputation of an extreme perfectionist, so finely attuned to detail that he doesn’t trust anyone else to get even minor secondary shots. That vision earned him an Oscar nomination as the director of “The Social Network” – but what about the guys who have to work with him? While Mr. Fincher is celebrated for doing dozens and dozens of takes , what’s often forgotten is that other people then have to look at each and every one of those takes to put the film together. Apparently they don’t mind; the editors Kirk Baxter and Angus Wall, and the sound designer, editor and mixer Ren Klyce have all worked with Mr. Fincher multiple times, on films like “The Curious Case of Benjamin Button” and “Zodiac.” They are all Oscar-nominated for “The Social Network,” and are working with Mr. Fincher on his next film, “The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo.”

headline: Obama Presses Egypt’s Military on Democracy
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama heaped praise on the peaceful protesters who deposed Hosni Mubarak on Friday, declaring, “Egypt will never be the same,” even as his national security team acknowledged that the swift uprising would almost certainly upend American strategy in the Middle East.

headline: Artifacts | Philip-Lorca diCorcia’s Perfect Eleven

It has to dazzle the eye before anything else, and so do the photographs that sell it. It’s the image that counts and Philip-Lorca diCorcia is one photographer who knows from imagery. The fashion spreads he created for W magazine from 1997 through 2008 are lavish productions that don’t just illustrate a moment in style but tell a story about representation itself.

headline: Sensitive Revelations, Free of Anguish
text: Vulnerability is a quality that most male singers measure out in teaspoons. But for T. Oliver Reid, it isn’t a discreetly added emotional flavoring to a love song; it is its essence. To witness Mr. Reid infuse popular standards with the immediacy and intensity of diary entries on Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Room was to observe an unfaltering emotional high-wire act.

headline: Painting It Red: Midcareer Minnelli
text: VERMEER had his yellow, Yves Klein had his blue, and Vincente Minnelli had a shade of red all his own: a bursting, tactile one, with a texture somewhere between velvet and vegetable. It’s a shade that rendered particularly well in the color processes of the 1950s and early ’60s, when Minnelli was in his prime, and it bursts out all over the four remastered Minnelli films that have recently been released by the Warner Archive Collection: “The Cobweb” (1955), “Tea and Sympathy” (1956), “The Reluctant Debutante” (1958) and “Two Weeks in Another Town” (1962).

headline: Users of iPhones Put a Flourish in E-Signatures
text: WHEN it came to getting a cellphone, Ben Shine prided himself on being the last of his friends to do so. So when he bought an iPhone in 2009, he was afraid that the default signature appended to every e-mail (“Sent from my iPhone”) made him look like a conformist.

headline: Take a Look at His Life: They Sound a Lot Like Him (Well, Sometimes)
text: The skeletal mysteries of Neil Young’s songs humbled many and emboldened a few at “Music of Neil Young” on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall. It was the seventh annual songwriter tribute in a concert series produced by Michael Dorf of City Winery to benefit music programs for children. The format was crisp: 20 singers and groups performed one song each and got together for a finale. They included musicians directly indebted to Mr. Young (who didn’t attend) and some from more distant musical spheres, like the Roots, the Brazilian pop singer Bebel Gilberto and the New Orleans master Aaron Neville.

headline: Major Donation to Help Conserve L.A.’s Watts Towers

headline: A Romantic Classic, Subject to Revisions
text: WASHINGTON  The first six months of 2011 are bringing America a good many different productions of the old Romantic classic “Giselle.” In January there were live simulcasts from the Royal Ballet in London and the Bolshoi in Moscow. By the end of this month, the Alabama Ballet, Richmond Ballet and San Francisco Ballet will all have staged revivals. And coming up we can expect American Ballet Theater’s version and a new production by Pacific Northwest Ballet in Seattle that will try to restore many details lost since the 19th century.

headline: A Visitor Arrives, Armed With a Sprawling Score
text: It is hard for a technically adept conductor not to make a big impression with Shostakovich’s gripping Fifth Symphony. But it is just as hard for an interpretation of this well-known piece to stand out.

headline: Psst, So-and-So’s Got a Crush
text: MOST of us entertain little crushes on folks in the public eye. Don’t bother denying it. There may be dashes of physical attraction (hello, Rafa Nadal), but just as often, our fancies run to the wildly ingenious (Mark Zuckerberg), or wickedly funny (Amy Sedaris), the purely inspiring (President Obama in Tucson) or all of the above (Kim Kardashian  kidding!).

headline: Kitsch of the Day | Takarazuka
text: For the modern YouTube hunter the world of Japanese television and pop culture can be a seemingly bottomless treasure trove. Among some of the finest gems are clips like the one above of Takarazuka, a 98-year-old Japanese song and dance troupe that specializes in performing adaptations of Western pop songs, classic musicals, operas, plays, novels or films as well as Japanese folk tales. (The clip above shows the musical number “The Great Century,” which incorporates the ’80s soft rock anthem “Final Countdown.”) But in a bizarre twist on the idea of an all-male Shakespearean cast, the members of the ensemble are all women — making Takarazuka perhaps the only Vegas-style musical theater group in the world with professional drag kings on permanent payroll. But despite appearances, Takarazuka was never meant as an early-20th-century chorus line for Japanese women’s liberation. To this day, cast members are put through a rigorous and patriarchally organized training program for several years before they are even allowed to set one foot on stage, with “female” (musumeyaku) and “male” (otokoyaku) actresses strictly separated in classrooms and dormitories. The inevitable lesbian overtones were largely ignored until the mid- to late 1930s, when Japanese officials were alarmed to a point that a ban on contact between the “male” cast members and their passionate female fans was imposed. To this day, most of Takarazuka’s over-2.5 million-strong annual audience consists of women, and so do the performers: an attempt in the 1940s to introduce male actors was successfully boycotted by Takarazuka’s own disgruntled cast.

headline: Detroit Pistons May Be Sold Soon to Gores

headline: Lots of Beats, but No Drum in Sight

Instead people were clustered around the stage, watching dumbfounded as Araabmuzik pounded out live drumbeats with his fingertips on a pair of Akai MPC 2500s.

headline: The Grammy Awards Before the Grammys
text: BY the time Eminem, Lady Gaga and Arcade Fire are battling it out in prime time Sunday for the top Grammy Awards, 98 other statuettes will already have been handed out in a brisk pre-show Webcast. Those are the awards that seek to satisfy every niche in the recording business, and tucked into those niches are worthwhile recordings from way outside the mainstream. These nominations offer a brief chance for attention, and perhaps a few seconds of Webcast glory.

text: Scenes around the city from New York Fashion Week.

text: DETROIT  General Motors and Chrysler, which posted much-improved results last year after reorganizing in bankruptcy court in 2009, said Friday that they would pay bonuses to salaried workers in the United States.

text: Has Lincoln Center already lost its luster? The question may seem premature. It has been only six months, after all, since IMG, the producer of Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week, transferred its spectacle from Bryant Park to New York’s premier cultural campus.

headline: Medicare Recipients Against Handouts
text: You know, I’d always thought that the “don’t let the government get its hands on Medicare” contingent, while picturesque, wasn’t all that large. But noooo: 44 percent of Social Security recipients, and 40 percent of Medicare recipients, believe that they don’t benefit from any government social program.

headline: A Long Life That Peaks Quite Young
text: “Any Human Heart” is a kind of “Forrest Gump” for the literate: an intimate, picaresque chronicling of the life of a fictional British writer who intersects with notable events, ideas and personages of the 20th century in ways both amusing and catastrophic. Based on the novel by William Boyd, who wrote the teleplay, the story is an examination of dissipated ambition — an affecting look at the ways in which the burdens of love, and living, eventually erode the aspirations of youth. Though this surely makes the enterprise sound entirely dismal, the Masterpiece Classic series (beginning on Sunday on PBS) works tirelessly to squelch the overgrowth of its bleak roots.

headline: The Perfect Spot for a Date, or to Run Away From One
text: Even in a guide to restaurants for dating and dumping — with categories like “hottest servers,” about places where you can “ogle, flirt and get a not-so-hot reaction out of your date” — one section stands out. The one listing restaurants with multiple exits.

headline: Looks Familiar, but It’s Full of Surprises
text: EVEN on your first visit to Pepe Rosso 24 in Port Washington, the place may seem familiar. Chances are you’ve been to Italian restaurants like this before; nearly every town on Long Island has one. As you enter, there’s a pizza parlor to the right, a casual dining room to the left.

headline: A Versatile Boutique Winery
text: Clovis Point, a Jamesport vineyard planted in 2001, draws on history. It is named for Clovis points, stone spear tips attributed to the Clovis people, who were Paleolithic Indians believed to have inhabited the North Fork. Two such points, around 8,000 to 10,000 years old and now in the Southold Indian Museum, have been found in the area. A photo of one decorates the labels of Clovis Point wines.

headline: Top Public High Schools Admit Fewer Blacks and Hispanics
text: The percentage of black and Hispanic students offered admission to the city’s elite public high schools inched lower this year, continuing a decade-long slide, according to the results of the city’s admissions process released Friday.

headline: Amid All Those Words, An Animated Argument
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — It’s not every artist who will list prominently in her biography that her national nickname is “a permanent irritation.” But so the South African choreographer Robyn Orlin proclaims in program notes for “Walking next to our shoes ... Intoxicated by strawberries and cream ... We enter continents without knocking ...,” which had its American premiere on Thursday night as part of the Montclair State University’s Peak Performances series.

headline: Opening the Folkways of Perception: Outsider Art’s Wide World of Inclusion
text: I once asked an art dealer how he determined whether someone was an outsider artist, and he offered this criterion: anyone who called up and said he or she was an outsider artist was immediately disqualified. In his view, outsider artists don’t self-identify and they don’t operate telephones.

headline: Amid Marshmallow Mountains

headline: ‘Idol’ Reigns in Ratings
text: With the auditions over and the Hollywood round in full swing, “American Idol” led Fox to its fourth consecutive Thursday night victory in the ratings. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 21.7 million viewers tuned in to the show at 8, far more than any other program that night. Although “Idol” boosted Fox’s “Bones,” which delivered 10.1 million viewers at 9, that show trailed behind both ABC’s “Grey’s Anatomy” (10.4 million) and CBS’s “CSI” (12.6 million) in its time slot. CBS placed second for the night over all, with its largest audience at 10 for “The Mentalist” (14.7 million). ABC was third, while NBC finished fourth.

The polished, muted interior, warm welcome at the door and sophisticated appointments set the tone for a formal restaurant with some high-end prices.

headline: Cause of Muti Collapse Determined
text: The cause of Riccardo Muti’s fall from the podium during a rehearsal of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra on Feb. 3 has been determined. In a joint statement with Mr. Muti and officials of the orchestra, two cardiologists at the Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine, Donald Lloyd-Jones and Bradley P. Knight, reported on Friday that Mr. Muti had fainted because of “a common heart rhythm disturbance.” Although their tests reveal that he retains excellent heart function, they added, he has had a pacemaker installed to monitor his heart rhythm and deliver a small electrical charge if the heart rate should fall too low. “Patients with pacemakers live full and active lives with excellent prognosis,” the doctors concluded. Mr. Muti remains in Northwestern Memorial Hospital, where he is recovering from surgery for facial injuries incurred in the fall. He has canceled his remaining performances this winter, which were to run through Feb. 19. His next scheduled appearance with the orchestra is a concert performance of Verdi’s opera “Otello” on April 7, to be repeated twice in Chicago and, on April 15, in Carnegie Hall.

headline: After Saving a Jumper, The Chat That Ensues
text: “The Sunset Limited” on HBO is 90 minutes of Tommy Lee Jones, Samuel L. Jackson and Cormac McCarthy locked (symbolically, at least) in a room together. The two actors do everything they can to make that a tolerable situation, but they can never entirely distract us from the fact that they’re trapped in Mr. McCarthy’s dorm-room argument masquerading as a drama.

headline: Who Are You Calling Ugly?

So did Diego Rivera, who in a celebrated mural in Mexico City painted one baring its teeth at the invading Spaniards as they landed at Veracruz. Dolores Olmedo, a Mexican businesswoman and Kahlo’s rival for Rivera’s affections (and never a woman to be outdone) ditched the boring cocker spaniels she once favored in order to trump Kahlo by breeding so many of the strange native dogs called Xoloitzcuintli (SHOW-low-eats-QUEENT-lee) that she eventually assembled a mighty pack.

headline: Making the Text-to-Mom Connection
text: Earlier this week, I wrote about text4baby, a free service that sends text messages to pregnant women, or new mothers, to provide them with useful health tips. What struck me as most noteworthy about this program was how hundreds of different types of organizations — for-profit health care providers, nonprofit community groups, wireless carriers, government agencies, and many others — had collaborated to make it all work. Text4baby seemed to shed light on the question: How do you get a country — with all its diverse institutional strengths — to work as a team?

headline: Lakers’ Math on Anthony Equates to Defense

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City

Mr. Loera was issued numerous criminal summonses after he refused to comply with officers’ demands that he stop selling there.

headline: Phil Jackson’s Soft Spot for New York
text: There are few gaps in Phil Jackson’s cluttered coaching résumé. He has more N.B.A. championships than anyone and more victories than most. He won a title in the Continental Basketball Association, with the Albany Patroons. He even coached a few tours in Puerto Rico. Yet somehow, Jackson never made it back to his N.B.A. roots, back to his favorite city, back to the corner of 33rd Street and Eighth Avenue. Jackson interviewed with the Knicks three times over the last three decades but the timing was never right. In 1987, the Knicks passed up Jackson, then coaching the Patroons, to hire Rick Pitino. Jackson joined the Chicago Bulls’ staff. Twelve years and six championships later, Jackson — a free agent after leaving the Bulls — spoke with the Garden president Dave Checketts. The exploratory talks went nowhere and Jackson instead joined the Los Angeles Lakers. Jackson was a free agent again in 2005 when Isiah Thomas asked him to coach the Knicks. Jackson declined because he got a better offer: a return to the Lakers. Now 65, Jackson intends to retire from the N.B.A. after this season, and this time for good. The opportunity for a prodigal return has seemingly passed. But at least one authority on Jackson can still envision him joining the Knicks some day. “Phil is definitely a full-circle kind of a guy, and that would bring him full circle,” said Jeanie Buss, Jackson’s girlfriend and a Lakers executive.

headline: Vonn Quits Latest Event but Hopes to Race Sunday

headline: Mubarak’s Fall Prompts Double Takes by Anchors
text: It took 18 days to shake the world, but this time the revolution was shown live. People around the globe watched Egyptians rise up in an unarmed insurrection. They looked on, gobsmacked, as the Mubarak dictatorship crumbled on camera. Even the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989 didn’t quite have the same hypnotic pull and roller-coaster suspense  this was a long vigil that carried a constant threat of mass violence in high definition.

text: WHEN Tim Raphael, director of the Center for Migration and the Global City at Rutgers-Newark, compares his campus to a highway — specifically, to Queens Boulevard in New York — the connection between the two things might not be immediately obvious. It is diversity.

headline: Russia: Radical Art Collective Shortlisted for Ministry Prize
text: The radical art collective Voina has been shortlisted for a contemporary art award by Russia’s Ministry of Culture and the National Center for Contemporary Art for a project that consisted of a 210-foot penis painted on a drawbridge in St. Petersburg. The nomination came despite the fact that two of the group’s leaders await trial on hooliganism charges that could bring a sentence of up to seven years  the fallout from an action they called “Palace Revolution,” which involved running up to parked police cars and turning them upside-down. A St. Petersburg judge refused to grant bail for the two last month, despite an offer to pay from Banksy, the mysterious British street artist. Voina’s other actions have included an orgy in the State Museum of Biology and throwing live cats over a counter at McDonald’s, but they drew special attention for the drawbridge painting, which slowly rose to point at the St. Petersburg headquarters of the state security service, the F.S.B. It stood for several hours before the authorities had it scrubbed off.

Critics called the step window dressing and said it would not be enough to win the confidence of international donors and the International Monetary Fund, which have been urging wide-ranging reforms to shore up the faltering economy.

headline: O Oysters
text: When your next oyster arrives on the half-shell, pause to consider it. It is a remnant of a vanished ecosystem and a reminder of a time when New York was oyster city. You can almost imagine the wholesale oyster barges docked along the East River and the sight of oystermen working the waters around Staten Island in the mid-19th century. Those were mostly bedded oysters  brought in from other locations and grown to size within easy reach of New York.

text: One month after making a decision to close more than two dozen schools, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced on Friday that it was closing another school at the end of the school year.

headline: California: Benefactor for Watts Towers Steps Forward
text: The Watts Towers, an aging cultural landmark in Los Angeles that has become the subject of a major restoration effort, is receiving $500,000 from the James Irvine Foundation to help finance an evaluation of damage and small repairs. The grant was announced this week by the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, which is overseeing a project to renovate the towers. The grant is the first private donation toward care of the towers. The cost of fully repairing, stabilizing and endowing the towers has been estimated at $5 million.

headline: At Conference, G.O.P. Hopefuls Offer Criticism of All Things Obama
text: WASHINGTON  A series of potential Republican presidential contenders delivered forceful and personal condemnations of President Obama on Friday, criticizing his worldview, domestic agenda and economic proposals, while imploring fractious conservatives to unite around the goal of winning back the White House.

headline: Christians Embrace a Jewish Wedding Tradition
text: In a San Antonio chapel last August, after reciting their wedding vows and exchanging their rings, Sally and Mark Austin prepared to receive communion for the first time as husband and wife. Just before they did, their minister asked them to sign a document. It was a ketubah, a traditional Jewish marriage contract.

headline: Cavaliers Fall Just Short of Mark for Futility
text: CLEVELAND  The Cavaliers traded for Antawn Jamison, hoping he would one day hit a big shot, while the Quicken Loans Arena crowd roared, danced and cheered. On Friday, it happened. Jamison made his biggest one as a Cavalier, although it came late by a few months, a lot of losses and one noteworthy summer defection.

headline: Unrepentance Day
text: You’ve been out of public sight for four years, writing your autobiography, “Known and Unknown: A Memoir.” Do you miss the action? I just really loved serving in government, and I’ve also loved being out of government in business and doing other things, so I looked at it and what’s going on in current events and wish those folks well, but I have a distance from it.

Tweed, tartan and argyle — cut into thigh-grazing kilts and mini dresses — rule the day looks. (Um, no wonder Edward gave up the throne for her.) headline: Urban Forager | Salt-Loving Mushrooms
text: Though winter salt’s effects on the city are numerous — de-iced sidewalks, salt-splotched cars, canines sporting booties or cradled in the protective arms of owners — less immediately obvious is the impact on the natural environment, including the fungi underfoot. One byproduct of road salt may be the surprise appearance of autumn Agaricus bernardii, a relative of the white button mushroom found in supermarkets, long after all the snow and ice of the previous winter has melted.

headline: Backstage Beauty | Rag & Bone
text: From the looks of their fall collection, this winter has taken a toll on Rag & Bone designers David Neville and Marcus Wainwright. “There’s a lot of shearling; it’s Eskimo-inspired,” said the makeup artist Gucci Westman backstage. “It’s makeup you would do if you were on a trek in Bhutan or something. Like you’d use eyeliner because you heard it would keep bugs away.” Unfortunately, at least for John Galliano during a damp summer, this last part is not true — but nonetheless, Westman’s handiwork, all done using the products she’s created with Revlon, is very pretty. “I’m using a purple lipstick on the bottom [lid] and then brown shadow over it, and then I’m using black liner to rim the eyes. I’m bringing the shadow down further than normal. The cheeks are just windswept; I’m using that same purple color all over the cheeks and the lips.” The hairstylist Guido Palau crafted very loose braids of varying thickness and number to go with the reference. “It’s very clean and natural,” he said. “I want it to feel hardly in there, so there’s a point of reference but it’s not overly anything–like when a girl starts braiding her hair by herself. It’s kind of an easy one.” Exactly what you’d want when hiking through the Himalayas or, you know, Brooklyn.

headline: Emerging Markets as Partners, Not Rivals
text: IN his State of the Union address last month, President Obama set the stage for a coming policy debate and his re-election bid with a catch phrase. Six times, he called on Americans to “win the future.” And he used the variant “winning the future” three other times. But is this really a good way to frame the economic challenges we face?

headline: Estate and Gift Rules: Some Clarity, for Now
text: FOR estate planning, the big headline to emerge from the tax deal last December was that the estate tax exemption would be raised in 2011 to $5 million, or $10 million for married couples. Anything over those thresholds would be subject to a 35 percent tax.

headline: Bread and Protest
text: Laurie A. Garrett, a senior fellow for global health at the Council on Foreign Relations, spoke recently about the role rising wheat prices are playing in the unrest in the Middle East, particularly in Egypt, the world’s largest wheat importer. “If prices skyrocket, then you get a real sense of anger and injustice. A lot of governments have dealt with this problem by creating subsidies or price controls... But eventually, very few governments can really get away with it because they just can’t afford it.”

An acrostic may not be a traditional Valentine’s Day gift, but let’s open our minds and hearts for this one. I’m sure you’ll find it more than worth your while.

headline: Bomber Strikes Shiite Pilgrims’ Bus in Iraq

headline: Of Dreams and Tribes
text: Yesterday, I took the R train down to SoHo to see Rag & Bone, a thoroughly enjoyable blend of ski and Scotland (I’m drastically abbreviating) that included two-tone ribbed leggings, mini kilts and snug jackets in tartan, chunky boots with many straps, and romantic fleece coats. I said hello to one or two members of the fashion tribe I had not yet seen — you see everyone eventually in your dreams — and then I went out into the cold and walked to the Prince Street station. The subway was crowded, but I found a seat and listened to some young Chinese talking. I closed my eyes as we rocked and rattled to Times Square.

headline: Opposition Leader in Rwanda is Sentenced to 4 Years
text: KAMPALA, Uganda  A prominent Rwandan opposition leader, Bernard Ntaganda, who was accused of stoking ethnic tensions was sentenced on Friday night to four years in jail, Rwandan authorities said.

headline: Barbour to Conservatives: G.O.P. Is United

headline: The Economics of Blogging and The Huffington Post
text: When The Huffington Post announced earlier this week that it was being acquired by AOL for $315 million in cash and stock, one group felt slighted: a set of unpaid bloggers for the site, identifying by the Twitter hashtag #huffpuff, which claims that The Huffington Post has “built a blog-empire on the backs of thousands of citizen journalists.”

headline: The Closing of the American Erotic
text: Lenny Bruce used to ask why it was obscene to show sex in American movies but not violence. Fifty years later, our screens remain washed in red, with severed if not necessarily naked body parts. More than half of the mostly American titles that received R ratings last year contained some kind of violence (as in strong, bloody and “grisly bloody violence and torture”) while only a third had sexual content. No NC-17 ratings were handed out, which bar youngsters, the viewers the studios most lust after.

headline: Huff and Puff and Blow Your House Down
text: Under the weight of record snows, roofs across the Northeast have been buckling this winter, raining debris on children skating in ice rinks, crushing cows and tractors in farmers’ barns and even flattening a garage full of antique cars. In December, nearly 18 inches of new heavy snow brought down the roof of the Metrodome in Minneapolis, forcing the Vikings to temporarily relocate to Detroit.

headline: Obama’s Budget Seeks Deep Cuts in Domestic Spending

headline: At Prabal Gurung, a Return to Glamour

I think both of us were a little surprised at the shift seen on Mr. Gurung’s runway, from his clean and bright sportswear last season to full-on evening glamour for fall, with louche-ly draped dresses in vampy red and pink, feathers from top to bottom on some looks, lace prints that seemed to disintegrate on others and stockings with a pattern that suggested corset ribbons.

headline: The Negro Leagues Discovered an Oasis at Yankee Stadium

headline: Mubarak Family Riches Attract New Focus
text: After Hosni Mubarak’s younger son, Gamal, left his job as an executive with Bank of America in London in the mid-1990s, he joined forces with Egypt’s largest investment bank. Today he has a significant stake in a private equity company with interests throughout the Egyptian economy, from oil to agriculture to tourism, corporate records and interviews show.

headline: Rich in Land, Aborigines Split on How to Use It
text: BROOME, Australia  Australia is experiencing a natural resources boom, driven by China’s headlong modernization, that is often described as a once-in-a-century phenomenon. It has minted billionaires out of businessmen who deal in iron ore and coal, and it has enriched many Australians by increasing the value of their homes and creating well-paying jobs.

headline: Ohio State, the Last Undefeated Contender, Tumbles at Wisconsin
text: MADISON, Wis.  As the student section charged onto the court Saturday and the final undefeated team in college basketball left with its first loss, Wisconsin’s 71-67 upset of Ohio State raised an age-old question.

headline: China’s Railway Minister Loses Post in Corruption Inquiry
text: BEIJING  The railway minister of China, Liu Zhijun, has been removed from the top post in the ministry because he is being investigated for corruption, according to a report on Saturday by Xinhua, the state news agency. Mr. Liu is the most senior Chinese official to come under such investigation in years.

headline: At Last, Bernie Madoff Gives Back
text: WHEN Bernie Madoff was arrested in December 2008, America feasted vicariously on a cautionary tale of greed run amok. But like Rod Blagojevich, the stunt governor of Illinois who had been arrested days earlier, Madoff was something of a sideshow to that dark month’s main events. For a nation reeling from an often incomprehensible economic tsunami and unable to identify the culprits, he was, for the moment, the right made-to-order villain at the right time.

headline: Coveting N.H.L. Club, Quebec Builds From the Ground Up
text: Régis Labeaume, the mayor of Quebec City, rolled the dice last week in his effort to attract an N.H.L. club, announcing plans to build a $400 million arena financed entirely by the municipal and provincial governments.

headline: Trying to Hold Down Blue Language on a Red-Letter Day
text: CITRONELLE, Ala.  It’s shaping up to be a darn nice Valentine’s Day here in Mobile County.

headline: After Badgers’ Victory, a Packer Salutes Ryan
text: In Wisconsin, winners apparently appreciate other winners. After No. 13 Wisconsin beat No. 1 Ohio State, 71-67, on Saturday and ended the Buckeyes’ run at an undefeated season, Badgers Coach Bo Ryan was the subject of a laudatory Twitter message from Green Bay quarterback, and Super Bowl M.V.P., Aaron Rodgers that called him “the best coach in college basketball.” Not a bad day for Ryan: his team beats the No. 1 team in the country and he gets a major compliment from the state’s No. 1 folk hero. (Hat tip to Quickish for the Rodgers Twitter message.)

headline: To Defend the Accused in a Tucson Rampage, First a Battle to Get Inside a Mind
text: TUCSON  Judy Clarke, the public defender for the man charged in the Tucson shooting, Jared L. Loughner, has made motions on his behalf and entered a plea for him of not guilty. But one of her most essential acts of lawyering came when she patted Mr. Loughner on the back in court last month, leaned in close and whispered in his ear.

headline: What Egypt Can Teach America
text: It’s a new day in the Arab world  and, let’s hope, in American relations to the Arab world.

headline: Prabal Does Cocktail Couture
text: Keeping in mind dozens of fashion week parties can, well, start to blur, the designer Prabal Gurung has come up with a sort of forget-me-not for his after-party, which is being held tonight at Mr. H in the Mondrian Hotel. Detail-obsessed Prabal has teamed up with Sally Hansen and Belvedere Vodka to create a nail lacquer line and cocktail list, that match his own collection. A way to continuously serve up his modern take on Victorian-era style (he describes his fall collection as Miss Havisham meets John Singer Sargent’s ”Parisian Beggar Girl”), “Crinoline” is your classic Greyhound, and a White Cosmopolitan masquerades as “Dorian Grey.” Each drink has a coordinating nail shade available at Sally Hansen. Or, follow the recipes below to keep your fashion-week buzz going.

headline: Administration to Push for Small ‘Modular’ Reactors
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration’s 2012 budget proposal will include a request for money to help develop small “modular” reactors that would be owned by a utility and would supply electricity to a government lab, people involved in the effort say.

headline: They Did It
text: CAIRO

headline: Arthur Schatzkin, Who Studied High-Fiber Diet and Polyps, Dies at 62
text: Dr. Arthur Schatzkin, an epidemiologist whose investigations into the connections between diet and cancer yielded new analytic tools and led to the discovery that eating fiber did not prevent the recurrence of polyps in the colon, died on Jan. 20 in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 62.

headline: Conservatives’ Straw Poll Shows Unsettled Republican Field
text: 6:50 p.m. | Updated WASHINGTON — With the Republican presidential campaign poised to open, conservative activists signaled on Saturday that they were remarkably unsettled over who should win the party’s nomination, creating a wide-open race over the next year for the right to challenge President Obama.

headline: Service Couldn’t Be Better, and at $200 a Ton It Should Be
text: The 600,000 households in Chicago that rely on City Hall to collect and dispose of their trash enjoy first-rate service. Regardless of what residents leave in alleys, the city carts it away to a landfill at no extra charge.

headline: Simply the Worst
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Sunday: Home Under the Midnight Sun
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Did this seem like a tougher than usual Sunday to you? The puzzle, I mean. Not your day, which I hope is just peachy. I had a sprinkling of entries that I was able to salt into the grid at first, but it took me awhile to really get a toehold.

headline: A Patriot Act Surprise
text: Republicans have a long history of favoring small government except when it comes to surveillance and security, at which point civil liberties take a back seat. Last week, however, 26 Republicans in the House demonstrated a remarkable consistency by joining 122 Democrats to prevent the extension of three questionable provisions of the Patriot Act, the post-9/11 law created during the Bush administration.

headline: It May Make Them Think Twice
text: Financial regulators certainly took their time, but proposed new rules to curb bankers’ bonuses are a welcome step toward changing a compensation culture that encouraged irresponsible risk-taking and helped set off the financial crisis.

headline: Convenient Amnesia
text: House Republicans are vigorously denouncing the Environmental Protection Agency as a rogue agency engaged in a borderline-illegal effort to regulate greenhouse gases. If anyone believes this to be a principled position, it is useful to recall that under President George W. Bush, the E.P.A. argued for very similar policies, based on the same reading of its responsibilities.

headline: The Mob at the Feeders
text: Most days I see a male cardinal in the hickory tree behind the house, waiting to forage beneath the bird feeders. You don’t really “see” a male cardinal. The world collapses to a carmine point that puts everything else out of focus — the hickory, the snow, the woodsmoke from the village. For its character, modest and cautious, the cardinal is overdressed. But then what would living up to that plumage mean?

headline: The Law and Politics of Health Reform
text: To the Editor:

headline: Recruiting Teachers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Counsel for Foreclosures
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lincoln Elected (Again)
text: Cincinnati to Columbus, Feb. 13, 1861

headline: Poncho Villa at Alexander Wang
text: Alexander Wang’s show nearly put me to sleep. Actually, that’s a joke.

headline: New York Teams Strive for N.C.A.A. Berths
text: This could be the year. Maybe.

headline: Happier Days Before a Deadly Mixture
text: Two military veterans succumbed to medicines meant to combat the psychological effects of war.

headline: For Some Troops, Powerful Drug Cocktails Have Deadly Results
text: This article was reported by James Dao, Benedict Carey and Dan Frosch and written by Mr. Dao.

headline: Sometimes, Justice Can Play Politics
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Race, Religion and Other Perilous Ground
text: A “Japanese” man, a “white” woman, an “Irish Catholic” network executive  common descriptors, perhaps, in everyday talk. But put identifiers like these in a newspaper story and you are playing with fire.

headline: Corrections
text: METROPOLITAN

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Feb. 13
text: The political transition in Egypt reigns on the Sunday talk shows, two days after Hosni Mubarak ceded power to the military. And the emerging budget battle begins to take shape as the White House budget director and House Republicans preview their competing proposals.

headline: 2 Safety Violations for ‘Spider-Man’
text: The New York State Department of Labor has issued two safety violations against the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” over accidents last year that involved an actor falling more than 20 feet during the show and two other performers sustaining injuries while rehearsing a sling-shot technique, a state official familiar with the violations said Saturday.

headline: Egypt’s Path After Uprising Does Not Have to Follow Iran’s
text: CAIRO  Two Egyptian leaders have been struck down in 30 years: one by an Islamist assassin’s bullets, the other by the demands of hundreds of thousands of protesters in a peaceful uprising. The first event, the death of President Anwar el-Sadat, marked a spectacle of the most militant brand of political Islam. The revolution the world witnessed Friday, the toppling of President Hosni Mubarak, may herald the dawn of something else.

headline: 18 Days at the Center of Egypt’s Revolution
text: Tahrir Square, in downtown Cairo, was the epicenter of antigovernment protests that led to the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: At Gathering, Ron Paul Is No. 1 for 2012
text: WASHINGTON  With the Republican presidential campaign poised to open, conservative activists signaled on Saturday that they were unsettled over who should win the party’s nomination, indicating a wide-open race for the right to challenge President Obama.

headline: To Cut or Not to Cut: That Is the Budget Question
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Path of Suspected Brooklyn Killer, an Electronic Trail
text: The Brooklyn man who police said left a trail of violence and death across the city on Friday and Saturday also left a trail, of sorts, on a pager service that notifies news media members of breaking news in New York.

headline: Care for Public Spaces
text: To the Editor:

headline: Scorecard | Jason Wu Wins!
text: Minimalism is so last season. On day two of New York fashion week, designers cut through the shades of greige. Apologies to the queen of draping, but Scorecard knows Jason Wu proved it’s possible to get ineffably clean lines and to embellish with a spot of lace — or 15.

headline: No Argument: Thomas Keeps 5-Year Silence
text: WASHINGTON  The anniversary will probably be observed in silence.

headline: Pressures Build to Slash Costs of City Employees
text: Shortly after the November elections, an unusual band of labor leaders, along with Ben Rosenfield, the city controller, and Sean Elsbernd, the most fiscally conservative city supervisor, met in the posh offices of Warren Hellman, a San Francisco investor and philanthropist, with one goal in mind: Cutting a deal to slash the ballooning public employee costs weighing heavily on the city’s financial crisis.

headline: Pacific Herring Are Back in the Bay in Big Numbers, Three Years After a Major Oil Spill
text: The herring that have recently flooded into San Francisco Bay in dense schools have surprised fishermen and ecologists, who doubted that the generation of the silvery fish that was spawned during a devastating oil spill three years ago would survive.

headline: Keeping Twitter Here Presents a Rare Chance
text: Jonathan Weber writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: The Next Egypt
text: My Sunday column attempts to offer four lessons from our failures in the Middle East, Egypt included. My thought is we should get into position to do better for the next Egypt.

headline: Giant Sundial: Ingleside Terraces
text: At the end of a quiet cul-de-sac in San Francisco’s Ingleside neighborhood is an enormous sundial. It was installed almost a century ago as the centerpiece of a real estate development and adorns a small park. HANK PELLISSIER

headline: Scenes From the Conservative Political Action Conference
text: This year’s conference underscored the fluidity of the Republican field of candidates in the 2012 presidential election, and a dozen potential contenders addressed the group and tried to sum up their chances.

headline: Miriam Hansen, a Scholar of Cinema, Dies at 61
text: Miriam Hansen, a scholar of cinema who studied not only film itself but also the early 20th-century creation known as the film audience, died on Feb. 5 in Chicago. She was 61 and a Chicago resident.

headline: Lucky for Cutler, Chicago Can Be Forgiving
text: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: What Lincoln Meant to the Slaves
text: The enormous excitement and anticipation of the 1860 presidential election campaign spread into unexpected corners of the United States. Indeed, during the months surrounding the contest, and especially after Americans learned of Abraham Lincoln’s victory, reports circulated across the Southern states of political attentiveness and restlessness among the slaves.

headline: Mayoral Forum Entertains, but Wasn’t Quite a Night at the Circus
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: 41st Ward Race Attracts a Field of Diversity
text: With nine open races, the City Council is expected to have a large turnover in the Feb. 22 municipal election. One of those races includes 11 candidates trying to replace the Council’s lone Republican, Alderman Brian G. Doherty, in the 41st Ward on the far Northwest Side.

headline: A New Venue Expands the Possibilities for ‘Austin City Limits’
text: Most days, the staff members of the Austin Convention & Visitors Bureau hear a variation on the same two queries from tourists who are curious about “Austin City Limits,” the longest-running music series in American television history: Is it really shot outside? (No, it’s taped indoors on a soundstage.) And how can we get tickets? (You can’t, most likely.)

headline: Perry Fights to Cut Strings Doggett Put on School Money
text: The latest chapter in the feud between Gov. Rick Perry and Representative Lloyd Doggett over $830 million in federal money for education unfolded Tuesday, when, in his State of the State address, the governor called out a “certain Texas congressman” for singling out Texas “for punishment in pursuit of his own agenda.”

headline: With Stoudemire Out, Knicks Fashion a Win
text: NEWARK  From the moment he pulled on a blue cap, beamed and proclaimed a Knicks rebirth last July, Amar’e Stoudemire has been a constant, an immovable force and a reliable presence. He has defined every game, every practice and every conversation.

headline: One Coach, Many Young Champions
text: In the last five years, two Americans have won world youth championships: Daniel Naroditsky, who took the under-12 title in 2007, and Steven Zierk, the under-18 champion last year.

headline: How Hockey Makes Headlines in Nashville
text: When Ottawa traded the popular center Mike Fisher to Nashville for draft picks Thursday, the Senators created salary-cap space and a chance to start rebuilding from an awful season. The Predators, in the thick of the tight Western Conference race, received a playoff-tested, energetic performer.

headline: Altuzarra: Street Value
text: In his last fall collection, Joseph Altuzarra showed black wool suits trimmed out in glossy black goat hair and dresses with lacing. At once sensual and tough, the clothes made a statement. Retailers were impressed with Mr. Altuzarra’s sophistication. But there is another aspect of his talent that has shown itself before: a desire to be a little less constructed and formal. On Saturday night, at Milk Studios, Mr. Altuzarra played with that style for his loosest, most commercial collection to date. It wasn’t his most exciting, but it may relate easily to how young women like to dress. And it may supply Mr. Altuzarra with working capital for future collections.

headline: Assessing Sloan: Call Him Coach
text: Phil Miller covered the Utah Jazz for The Salt Lake Tribune from 2002 to 2007.

headline: New York Fashion Week | Meet Kevork Kiledjian
text: Kevork Kiledjian, the Paris-born designer who founded the Guilty Brotherhood line, recently moved to New York to start a new namesake women’s wear label from his Crosby Street atelier. The obvious question, especially if you are a booster of French fashion, is why leave the putative fashion capital of the world for New York? “How many new designers can you name that have come from Paris in the past five years?” asked Kiledjian when I caught up with him as he was putting the finishing touches on his debut collection, which will be shown on Monday at 6 p.m. at Milk Studios.

headline: A Photographic Pioneer Explored in Amsterdam
text: Can manipulated reality truthfully capture real life? Amsterdam’s photography museum, Foam (Keizersgracht 609; 31-20-551-6500; www.foam.nl), explores the question in “More Real Than Reality,” an engrossing retrospective of the great American photographer W. Eugene Smith, through March 16.

headline: What Next in Cairo?
text: With their principal demand met, demonstrators have differing opinions about what to do next and whether they should leave Tahrir Square in Cairo.

headline: New York Fashion Week Tweets | Sunday
text: Today from 10 a.m. to 11:30 a.m., we will be going backstage at Preen by Thornton Bregazzi, to give you a behind-the-scenes look at the busiest and most exhilarating moments before the show.

headline: Quick Help for the Rent vs. Buy Decision
text: Trying to figure out whether you should rent a home or buy one?

headline: Europe Turns on Its Axel
text: I have to say that Axel Weber has bowed out of the race for ECB head  gracefully; but this isn’t really about the person, it’s about the views. And I am therefore glad to hear both that he won’t be taking the job, and that the reason he bowed out was that euro-area leaders didn’t share his hard-money views. Tightening in Europe in the face of continuing very high unemployment and low core inflation is a very bad idea.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Patricia van der Vliet at BCBG Max Azria
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York Fashion Week. Here, the model Patricia van der Vliet at New York Models before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Charlotte Willer and hair by Neil Moodie. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: Egyptian Military Dissolves Parliament
text: CAIRO  The Egyptian military consolidated its control on Sunday over what it has called a democratic transition from nearly three decades of President Hosni Mubarak’s authoritarian rule, dissolving the feeble Parliament, suspending the Constitution and calling for elections in six months in sweeping steps that echoed protesters’ demands.

headline: Backstage Grooming | Richard Chai
text: For his fall men’s collection, the designer Richard Chai homed in on individuality, and the striking relationship between “unconventional beauties in refined clothes.” The hair stylist Kevin Ryan agreed backstage, explaining that “these men are not perfect, these are real men with flaws.” To create a “disheveled, slept-in feel,” Ryan first liberally applied Bumble & Bumble Surf Spray and Sumo Tech to create a matte, dry texture, then used his own R Session Tool “Root Control,” a ceramic heated comb, ideal for taming frizz and flyaway strands. And since the overall goal was to “make hair look rough and not too groomed,” styles were finished with spritzes of TIGI Rockaholic Dirty Secret Dry Conditioner. For mysterious, sultry eyes, the makeup artist James Kaliardos used M.A.C. Satin Taupe and Charcoal Brown eye shadows and M.A.C. Brush #213, which “created a smoky eye without looking like sharp eyeliner.” Kaliardos then pressed M.A.C.’s Brit Wit Creme Blush into models’ lips and cheeks, and patted M.A.C. Line Filler all over the face to minimize pores and even out complexion. Forgoing foundation altogether, Kaliardos used concealer minimally, to “veil the skin” and not disguise individual imperfections.

headline: On ‘S.N.L.,’ a Law Firm With a ‘Spider-Man’ Specialty
text: Just when things couldn’t get any tougher for “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” on a weekend when that musical was slapped with two safety violations by the New York State Department of Labor, Broadway’s favorite $65 million punch line was once again skewered by “Saturday Night Live.” Saturday’s “S.N.L.” included the above fake commercial for a law firm that specializes in winning settlements for audience members who have been injured by the show (including a certain Irish rock star who’s sustained irreparable damage to his reputation). That firm’s name? Gublin and Green, of course.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Billy Reid
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#22", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: Victoria Beckham Deconstructed
text: Victoria Beckham, right after her show, said she likes to surprise people, which is why, after six seasons of showing variations of her signature skintight and corseted dresses, she decided to loosen things up, even more than she did last season. Well, for that reason, and because she is pregnant, she confessed.

headline: A Measure of Normalcy Returns to Cairo
text: Egypt’s military started taking down the makeshift tents of protesters who camped out in Tahrir Square in an effort to allow traffic and normal life to return to central Cairo.

headline: Unlucky in Love: Readers Tell of Romance Gone Wrong
text: Apparently, an awful lot of things can go wrong on Valentine’s Day. Last week, we asked you to reach into the darkest cranny of the heart-shaped box where you store your memories of romantic torment, and share a tainted bonbon or two with us. Many of you did. Here they are.

headline: Backstage Beauty | Altuzarra
text: “It was kind of Kate Moss in her Johnny Depp days meets Oasis meets couture, to take the collection from a rock-n-roll feel to more of a womanly look,” explained the hairstylist Tina Outen of the directive that inspired the amorphous hair at Altuzarra. She was filling in on sound byte duty for Paul Hanlon, the show’s key hairstylist, who was busy presiding over the swarm of stylists — three per girl — busy scraping hair back from the face, dousing it in product (chief among them Frederic Fekkai Coiff Bouffant Lifting & Texturizing Spray Gel), clipping it into twists and coils, and setting with a blow-dryer. “When the clips come out, they’re going to start to destroy [the shapes] by pulling out pieces to make it more 3-D,” said Outen. “When [the models] are in the line, Paul’s going to do his magic.” In between, the makeup artist Tom Pecheux painted on a glamorous take on the ’90s Kate Moss cat-eye. “I was like, what is a young designer like? Who does he want to dress? And which kind of woman wants to wear a cool young designer? A rock chick,” said Pecheux. His take replaced that “rock chick” staple, black liquid liner, with M.A.C. Rich Purple Chromagraphic Pencil on the eye’s waterline and M.A.C. Keep It Cool Eye Shadow (available fall 2011), used to a soft liner effect, brushed out to the brows. “I went for silver on the inner corner of the eye, almost like a futuristic tear.” And the crimson lip? “It’s a huge controversy! Because that lip color is so ladylike, so bourgeois,” said Pecheux with a laugh. “But I was like, why not break the rules? A rock chick is a rock chick.”

headline: Yemeni Youth Square Off With Forces
text: SANA, Yemen  Young protesters in Yemen squared off against security forces on Sunday, and some marched on the presidential palace here, witnesses said, as a third day of demonstrations sought to emulate the revolution in Egypt.

headline: Clive Davis Still Draws Stars at Pre-Grammy Mixer
text: LOS ANGELES — To the general public, the Grammy Awards are three and a half hours of television in which about nine awards are quickly handed out between starry performance segments. But for the music industry, the ceremony — to be held on Sunday night at the Staples Center — is the culmination of a weeklong schmoozefest of private parties, daytime conferences and breakfast meetings in different hotel restaurants.

headline: Postcard From Cairo, Part 2
text: CAIRO

headline: As Egypt Calms Down, So Do Israeli Nerves
text: JERUSALEM  As Israelis began to adjust to the departure of President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, their staunchest and longest-standing regional ally, the alarm and anxiety that Israel has been projecting seemed to give way on Sunday to more nuanced tones, as well as some hints of admiration for the Egyptian people and sympathy for their cause.

headline: Russian Village Is Angry, but Not With Bomber
text: ALI-YURT, Russia  Residents of this run-down little settlement in the Caucasus Mountains, in the south of Russia, speak only kindly about the Yevloyevs, a tightknit family of six who lived in a one-story, red-brick home at the edge of the village.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Prabal Gurung
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#930", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: Some Amazing Grace from Derek Lam
text: Sunday morning, coffee and a sparkling Derek Lam show: not a bad start to the day. Invoking George Balanchine’s practical wisdom (“There are no new steps, only new combinations”), Mr. Lam showed classic sportswear shapes and fabrics in fresh ways. The show was a pleasure to watch. He had a variety of jackets: a smoky-blue wool peacoat, a trim bomber that combined ebony beaver and black nylon. And he paired them with sharp-looking trousers with a wide stripe down the side or, say, a pencil skirt in a nubby black-white-wine tweed.

headline: Thakoon Casting
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#907", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

headline: On TV, Monday Morning Quarterbacks Take On Egypt
text: Two days after Hosni Mubarak stepped down as president of Egypt, the morning talk shows on Sunday television filled with political posturing and diplomatic words of reassurance about what lies ahead for the region and the United States.

headline: After Concussion, Vonn Takes Second
text: GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany  It had been nearly two years since someone other than Germany’s Maria Riesch or Lindsey Vonn had won a women’s World Cup-caliber downhill race.

headline: Men’s Fall Fashion 2011 | Patrik Ervell
text: Patrik Ervell’s precise aesthetic and consistent references to technical fabrics made a perfect foundation for this tight, dramatic show. In his runway set, as in his clothing, he makes the most efficient and effective use of the seemingly simple:  overlapping opaque nylon parachutes furled in the wind provided by a series of fans. There was a stark uniformity to the clothing, both cohesively and militaristically. A navy cotton twill jumpsuit covered in zippered pockets and topped by a bomber style jacket was my favorite of the flyboy styles.

headline: Backstage Beauty | Derek Lam
text: Derek Lam’s last few collections have been tailored and somewhat minimalist, the type of clothing that often gets paired with a nearly nude face and natural waves on the runway. But Lam hasn’t shied away from making beauty statements: most recently, the electric coral eyeliner and ’60s waves for spring 2011 created by the hairstylist Orlando Pita and the makeup artist Tom Pecheux, both of whom were on hand early on this Sunday morning to work that magic again. “The collection today is inspired by uniforms, so I did this school-girl uniform hairstyle, where the girl scrapes her hair back and puts a barrette in her hair,” explained Pita. “But we’re not doing the barrette, to keep it a bit more streamlined.” The hair was straightened with a T3 iron, pulled into a clean half-ponytail and set with T3 Control Hairspray. Pecheux created a slate gray smoky eye using silver and black Estee Lauder shadows (available this fall), which he paired with a nude matte lipstick, brow pencil, and Estée Lauder Bronze Goddess Soft Duo Bronzer. “Derek Lam’s clothes are very feminine and very luxurious, but very graphic and minimal at the same time,” said Pecheux, a sentiment that was echoed by the manicure Jin Soon Choi paired it with. “It’s a wintery white from Estée Lauder called Porcelain — very clean, minimalistic, bright white,” she said. “White nail polish works on short to medium length nails, and I did a round shape — I’ve done it at a lot of shows, it’s more feminine.”

headline: Preen: The Remix
text: The sweeping appearance of remixed fabrics has been an early trend of the fall collections, where you’re as liable to find a cloth coat with fur sleeves as a dress made out of four kinds of tweed. What I liked about Preen’s fall collection was that the designers Justin Thornton and Thea Bregazzi combined fabrics in a way I haven’t seen anyplace else. Plus the show was darn good.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Alexander Wang
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#546", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: Tunisians Turn to Everyday Matters
text: TUNIS  Bakers have threatened to stop making baguettes unless their salaries are increased. Lawyers demanding judicial independence protested outside the Justice Ministry. Unemployed miners slept in the halls of the headquarters of a phosphate mining company, demanding more jobs.

headline: N.Y.S.E. Name Must Come First in Exchange Merger, Schumer Says
text: Senator Charles E. Schumer signaled on Sunday that he might support a merger of NYSE Euronext and Deutsche Börse — so long as the New York Stock Exchange‘s name comes first in the combined company.

headline: Suno: A New Formality
text: Suno, the label founded by Max Osterweis and designed with Erin Beatty, continues to expand its range of prints and knits, with long lines and somber colors giving the fall collection an almost formal cast. There are tunics, woven vests, fluid coats and layers in which the same print is repeated at a different scale. Wool caps come with extra-long earflaps.

headline: Lemieux Reacts Strongly to Penguins-Islanders Brawl
text: The Penguins owner Mario Lemieux reacted strongly Sunday to what he called the N.H.L.’s “failed” disciplinary measures in the aftermath of the Friday night brawl involving his team and the Islanders, in which 15 fighting majors and 346 penalty minutes were assessed.

headline: Spotlight | Greg Lauren
text: If you go to the third floor of Barneys’ men’s wear building today, you’ll wonder if you’ve wandered into an artist’s studio by mistake. Jackets and scarves in black, khaki and white hang like drying pieces of canvas from suspended bars while worn-out leather shoes and containers of paint litter the worktable. Welcome to Greg Lauren’s world.

headline: Poncho Twins
text: Alexander Wang and Joseph Altuzarra are good friends, so when each showed a poncho in roughly the same style, with a quilted lining, you figured it could not have been a coincidence. Was it a poncho design challenge? And who won?

headline: Yanks Abroad: A Little Traveling Music
text: Last month’s European transfer period made headlines with the pricey relocations of Fernando Torres (Liverpool to Chelsea; $79.5 million), Edin Dzeko (Wolfsburg to Manchester City; $42 million) and others, but dozens of lesser-known players changed clubs, too. In fact, quite a few American players were purchased or loaned in the last few weeks. Here is a quick look at how some of these Yanks are settling in at their new clubs.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Mandy Coon

headline: Calvin Klein: The Incredible Bulk

headline: Who’s Unemployed?
text: Larry Mishel emails me to second my concern about Charles Plosser’s blithe assertion that unemployment is about shifting workers out of construction. As Larry points out, the BLS provides data on the previous employment of the unemployed. There were 7.7 million more unemployed workers in 2010 than there were in 2007; of those extra 7.7 million, only 1.1 million had previously been employed in construction.

headline: Race, Sex and the Trials of a Young Explorer
text: In 1859, Paul Du Chaillu, a young explorer of French origin and adopted American nationality, wandered out of the jungle after a four-year expedition in Gabon.  He brought with him complete specimens of 20 gorillas, an animal almost unknown outside West Africa.  The gorilla’s resemblance to humans astonished many people, especially after Darwin published “On the Origin of Species” later that year.  The politician Edwin M. Stanton was soon calling Abraham Lincoln “the original gorilla” and joking that Du Chaillu was a fool to have gone to Africa for what he could as easily have found in Springfield, Ill.But the more common way to deal with our resemblance to monkeys and apes then was to fob it off onto other ethnic groups — typically black people, or sometimes the Irish.  A few white scientists even purported to find physiological evidence, in the configuration of the skull, for classifying other races as separate species, not quite as far removed as Caucasians from our primate cousins.  This undercurrent of scientific racism would play out to devastating effect in Du Chaillu’s own life.
