headline: Stillness Amid A Shifting World
text: The Palestinian director Kamal Aljafari’s elliptical film “Port of Memory” occupies ground somewhere between documentary and fiction. The port of the title is Jaffa in Israel, and Mr. Aljafari shows its streets, its crumbling walls, the interiors of its houses. He also shows people engaged in the banal activities of daily life: a woman washes her hands; people sit on a couch and talk. And is that the sound of gunfire in the background?

headline: Heritage Shouldn’t Reek of Mothballs
text: Heritage has been the prevailing buzzword in men’s wear since stylish guys started gravitating toward labels that suggest, as marketers like to say, “authenticity.” You know the look: Filson tin cloth hunting jackets and woolly plaid shirts from Pendleton or Woolrich worn with Red Wing work boots.

headline: Quad Q&A: Stanford Quarterback Andrew Luck

headline: NASA’s Second Close Encounter With a Comet

headline: In Spokane, a Mystery With No Good Solution
text: SPOKANE, Wash.  The bomb was sophisticated and potentially deadly, but it did not detonate. No one was hurt, and no one has been arrested. So Spokane became a mystery.

headline: New York Takes Step on Money in Judicial Elections

If built, it would affect a huge area of clear-running headwater streams and wetlands that feed the bay.

headline: Prime Times for Smartphone Use

headline: Betty Garrett, Antsy Cabby in ‘On the Town,’ Is Dead at 91
text: Betty Garrett, the brassy comic actress who played Frank Sinatra’s ardent, taxi-driving pursuer in the movie “On the Town,” Archie Bunker’s liberal foil of a neighbor in “All in the Family” and a sardonic landlady in “Laverne & Shirley,” died on Saturday in Los Angeles. She was 91.

text: A Queens man who pleaded guilty in 2004 to helping terrorists and had a connection to the leader of the 2005 bombings of the London transit system has been released from prison after serving a small portion of his sentence, according to federal court documents.

headline: A ‘Swan’ Of Complex Shades
text: Will Natalie Portman be dancing “Swan Lake”? I can’t help hoping the rumors are true: that people have called the ballet box offices in New York and London with that question. Certainly the film “Black Swan” helps explain why tickets to the New York City Ballet’s performances of “Swan Lake” are selling unusually fast.

headline: In Dark Temple, Antiquity’s Sober Doings
text: When the Metropolitan Opera gave the American premiere of Gluck’s “Iphigénie en Tauride” in 1916, the critic for The New York Times, Richard Aldrich, praised the work but added, “Whether the opera will make a place for itself in the admiration of this public is something of a question.” It was too sober, too strange, he said, to be popular.

headline: Student Players Leap Into Deep Water
text: It was brave of Mannes College the New School for Music to present its orchestra in a Maher program at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening. The works the Mannes Orchestra played  the Adagio from the unfinished Symphony No. 10, and “Das Lied von der Erde”  are hefty scores that make tremendous technical and interpretive demands on any orchestra, let alone a student group. And since this is a Mahler year  the centennial of his death  some of the world’s great orchestras have been bringing high-voltage performances of these pieces to New York.

headline: Deconstructing Sousa, And Other New Ground
text: Bang on a Can’s People’s Commissioning Fund uses small contributions from the organization’s fans to pay for new works scored for the Bang on a Can All-Stars. Three of those works were unveiled at the annual performance, on Thursday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, which this year was also part of the Kaufman Center’s Ecstatic Music Festival. It was streamed live on Q2, WQXR’s Internet-only station, and will have a later broadcast on WNYC (93.9 FM), as part of John Schaefer’s popular “New Sounds” program. (Mr. Schaefer, the concert’s host, conducted enlightening interviews with the composers and performers between the works.)

headline: A Touch Of ‘Finian’ Friskiness
text: Because the theater and Hollywood composer Burton Lane wrote the music for only two major Broadway hits (“Finian’s Rainbow,” with lyrics by E. Y. Harburg, and “On a Clear Day You Can See Forever,” lyrics by Alan Jay Lerner), he is perennially treated as an also-ran in the pantheon of great American songwriters. Lane, who died in 1997 at 84, was a natural melodist, but he didn’t fully come into his own until the late 1940s, when Harburg invited him to write the music for “Finian’s” and told him he wanted it to be as artistically lofty as “Porgy and Bess.” (George Gershwin had been Lane’s close friend and mentor.)

headline: Looking for Ms. Right, Online and in Sitcomland
text: In honor of Valentine’s Day I devote this review to new television about love, or more specifically to new television about how people get together in our crazy, frenetic, high-tech, isolating, fat-fearing world. As it is succinctly explained in “When Strangers Click,” an absorbing documentary about Internet dating (to be shown Monday on HBO2), women are terrified of meeting serial killers online; men are terrified of meeting women of above-average weight.

headline: A Team to Help Earnhardt Jr. Live Up to His Name
text: If it is sometimes a burden to own the name Dale Earnhardt Jr., with all the pressure of expectations that comes with it, then it surely must be a challenge as well to own the racecars he drives.

headline: Bright Melodies, Sometimes Offset by Dark Moods
text: Eliza Doolittle knows too much: How to be a slick, hungry soul singer, or a bashful jazz vocalist. How to write songs that make her sound modern, and how to write songs that make her sound like a well-preserved relic. How to use pouty lips and saucer eyes that stare out hard (with the certainty that few people will muster the temerity to stare back) to suggest that, just maybe, she knows even more than she’s letting on.

headline: Those Crazy Swans
text: With its unhinged ballerinas, lurid hallucinations, surfeits of blood and makeup, and one mad mother, the film “Black Swan” is hard to match as catnip for satirists of camp. The downtown theater artist Jack Ferver and his QWAN (Quality Without a Name) Company will take a stab with “Swan!!!,” a parody of the 2010 movie that will be staged as a dramatic reading from March 10 to 12 at Performance Space 122 in the East Village. The show is a follow-up to Mr. Ferver’s “Notes!!!,” a like-minded treatment of the Judi Dench-Cate Blanchett film “Notes on a Scandal“ that developed a cult following during performances downtown last spring and fall. According to production notes “Swan!!!” focuses on the ballerina Nina (Natalie Portman’s role in the film, played here by Jenn Harris), who is “freaking out because she is crazy.” Also crazy is her mother, played by Randy Harrison of Showtime’s “Queer as Folk” (and Barbara Hershey in the movie); her “Swan Lake” choreographer; and a former prima ballerina. Mr. Ferver will play the “hot new bad ballet girl in town,” Lily (Mila Kunis in the film), who becomes Nina’s frenemy. Mr. Ferver said in an interview that he had not gone through legal hoops with the creators of “Black Swan” because he and his collaborators were “appropriating the work into a camp spectacle,” meaning that parody is protected under fair-use exceptions to copyright law. “It is going to be insane,” Mr. Ferver promised. “Black Swan” has been nominated for five Academy Awards, including best picture and best actress for Ms. Portman; the Oscars ceremony is Feb. 27.

headline: At the Grammys, Spectacles and Upsets
text: LOS ANGELES  Asserting the power and versatility of the new Nashville, the country-pop trio Lady Antebellum was the big winner at the 53rd annual Grammy Awards, which were presented on Sunday night at the Staples Center arena here.

headline: Sandler Goes With It At the Box Office
text: Never bet against a crude Adam Sandler comedy. “Just Go With It,” about a man who pretends to be unhappily married to pick up women, was No. 1 at the box office over the weekend with about $31 million in ticket sales. It’s the 11th movie starring Mr. Sandler (above, with Jennifer Aniston) to open in first place, according to Sony Pictures Entertainment, which bankrolled “Just Go With It” to the tune of $80 million. Justin Bieber‘s 3-D concert movie, “Never Say Never,” was a close second for Paramount Pictures with an estimated $30.2 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. “Gnomeo and Juliet“ (Walt Disney Studios), with Elton John songs, was third with about $25.5 million, benefiting from a lack of animated competition in the marketplace and a hefty marketing campaign. “The Eagle,” a Focus Features release starring Channing Tatum as a Roman soldier, was a distant fourth with a projected $8.6 million. “The Roommate” (Sony) was fifth in its second week of release with $8.4 million, bringing the total for that low-budget thriller to $26 million.

headline: Iran in Brooklyn
text: Iran usually gets attention because of international politics, but the Brick Theater in Brooklyn wants to focus on the country’s rich cultural fare. From March 3 to 26 the Brick is hosting an Iranian Theater Festival with plays in Persian and English. The roster includes newly commissioned works from playwrights in Iran as well as plays by more established authors and groups, like the Iranian exile Assurbanipal Babilla‘s “Something Something Uber Alles” and “Two Stories That End in Suicide” by Piehole, an experimental theater group in Brooklyn. Audiences will also be able to see “The Hip-Hop Waltz of Eurydice” and “Quotations From a Ruined City,” two works by Reza Abdoh, an Iranian-born artist who died in 1995 at the age of 32. Most tickets are $15 and can be purchased online at bricktheater.com or by calling(212) 352-3101.

headline: Footnotes
text: ’s “Runaway” video featured ballerina characters last year. But a year earlier Prince’s “Crimson and Clover” video highlighted Misty Copeland of American Ballet Theater, and his association with the art form continues. Prince, left, has given Ballet Theater a $250,000 grant for arts education, along with gifts to the Uptown Dance Academy and the Harlem Children’s Zone, ABT announced on Friday. ... headline: Ten Years On, Nascar Yearns for Another Intimidator
text: The Nascar circuit makes its pilgrimage to Daytona International Speedway twice every year, visits that inevitably rank among the highlights of any season. But not for the racecar owner Richard Childress. Each time he drives through the tunnel to the infield and looks at the track around him, Childress finds himself staring at perhaps the most sorrow-filled stretch of pavement on that hallowed ground.

headline: A Dutch-British Hybrid Wins the NEC Cup
text: The 2011 NEC Cup, decided in Yokohama City, Japan, on Saturday, was captured by David Bakhshi and David Gold from England and Ricco van Prooijen and Louk Verhees from the Netherlands. They won by 142 international match points to 82, their opponents, Li Xiaoyi, Liu Haitao, Peng Jianfeng and Wang Kui from China, conceding after 48 of the scheduled 64 boards.

headline: Clashes Erupt in Bahrain as Tumult Ripples Across Mideast

One man fell instantly and was shot at as he squirmed on the ground. Another was trapped against a wall and writhed as an officer shot rubber bullets at him, again.

headline: A Fateful Call for Colin Firth
text: It wasn’t a total rout for “The King’s Speech” Sunday night at the Baftas, the British version of the Oscars. The ur-British movie did take home trophies for best film, best British film, best original screenplay, best score and best acting prizes for Geoffrey Rush, Helena Bonham Carter and Colin Firth. But David Fincher won best director for “The Social Network,” which also took best adapted screenplay for Aaron Sorkin. Mr. Sorkin attended, Mr. Fincher did not – he’s shooting “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo” – so his award was accepted by his stars Jesse Eisenberg and Andrew Garfield. But it was Mr. Firth’s speech that was the hit of the event in London on Sunday night. (Mr. Firth also won a Bafta last year, for “A Single Man.”)

headline: IFC Orders Second Season of ‘Portlandia’
text: The dream of the ’90s will remain alive at least through 2012: IFC announced on Monday that it had picked up a new batch of episodes of “Portlandia,” its original comedy series created by Fred Armisen of “Saturday Night Live” and Carrie Brownstein, a former guitarist and singer of the rock band Sleater-Kinney. The series, which chronicles a fanciful, not-all-that-alternate-from-reality version of the slacker paradise of Portland, Ore. (and which gave rise to hit viral videos like “Dream of the ’90s” ), has become a modest hit for IFC. The cable channel, which has been emphasizing a lineup of new and classic comedy programs alongside its schedule of independent films, said the first three episodes of “Portlandia” have been viewed by 1.1 million total viewers, with most of them in the 18-49 age group that recognizes the grunge bands referenced on the show and the cameo appearances by Kyle MacLachlan and Aimee Mann. IFC said the second season of “Portlandia,” consisting of 10 half-hour episodes, will make its debut in January.

headline: Head in the Stars, Feet on the Ground
text: BOSTON  Gazing upward I can see the skylines of Cambridge and Boston on the horizon as twilight falls. In the growing hush of full darkness, more than 9,000 stars appear, with so many gradations of intensity that binoculars can reveal more detail than the naked eye. And as I lean back in cushioned comfort, I am gradually swept off into the heavens.

headline: Afghan Guards Called Heroes After Thwarting Attack

headline: Confusion and Abs: Everybody!

And most participants do not come to class wearing a body suit with a fake penis, a tutu or an animal mask. But at Miguel Gutierrez’s “DEEP Aerobics” at Danspace Project on Thursday night, such was the attire of the instructor (Mr. Gutierrez) and audience members who opted to take part as students. (A “transformation station” was on hand for those who didn’t arrive in appropriate outfits.)

headline: ‘Big Love’ Watch: A Family in Crisis
text: “I’m the sunny face of polygamy.” Let’s just acknowledge that this line, delivered by Margene, was surely the best of Sunday’s episode of “Big Love.” Margene, who is getting deeper into the crazy pyramid scheme that is Goji juice, has also become the spokeswoman for a family increasingly in crisis. But before we get to that and the impending divorce proceedings, I have a bone to pick with the haphazard unfolding of the episode. The matter of Alby hiring Verland to attack Don during his ice fishing trip felt random and pointless. This is the best way the writers could think of for Alby’s getting back at Bill for getting Lura away from him? Even as the scene was transpiring it seemed as if the writers were doing it on a lark and were fully conscious that the plotting was arbitrary and almost jokey. (The jaunty music accompanying the attack made this especially clear.)Also: Bill’s mother’s dementia isn’t feeling fully integrated either. Her dementia may be relevant to the season’s theme of the Henricksons’ general deterioration, but beyond that symbolic value, it’s hard to see how Lois’s condition will matter much to the final outcome of the show. Another plot development that felt half-baked was the sudden turnaround of Bill’s fate at the legislature. The tabling of the impeachment felt way too abrupt.

headline: Gingrich’s Energy Policies Rile Conservative Critics

headline: A Renovator Gets a Taste of Compromise

headline: In Former C.E.O.’s Words, the Last Days of Lehman Brothers

headline: Backstage Beauty | Thakoon
text: “I was really looking at tribes, at the different sorts of tribes and tribal sensibilities and habitual things tribes do, from the Masai tribe culture to the people during the Rococo period,” the designer Thakoon Panichgual said backstage before his fall show. “There was a sense of uniformity about the way that they were dressing.” This translated into a collection he described as “electric,” and for the hair and makeup, Panichgual said he decided to go for bold instead of tempering the clothes with a basic look. The makeup artist Diane Kendal used Nars Velvet Matte Lip Pencil in Dragon Girl on eyelids and on top of it, and applied three blushes — Desire, Taj Mahal and Exhibit A, in that order from inner lid to outer lid to an ombre effect — which she blended out past the bleached eyebrows. “We wanted to have that feeling of sun and hotness but then also exotic,” Kendal explained. The hairstyle created by Odile Gilbert using Kerastase products echoed that sentiment, with pieces provided by the designer weaved into a complicated-looking updo. Panichgual explained, “The hair is superslick — almost posh, really — in the front, and then it’s pulled back and it’s got this weird chignon whipped up with yarn and hats that we’ve cut up and put into the bun. There’s a reality base there, but it’s a bit hyper.”

Sabathia can opt out of his seven-year contract at the end of the season, and for the first time he did not rule out the possibility of exploring free agency again.

Talented prospects can rush through a pick-and-roll or hurriedly execute a post-up, and more often than not they’ll do so to great effect. But what separates those young talents from sophisticated veterans is the discretion to isolate the right play and the patience to wait for it.

text: George Shearing, the British piano virtuoso who overcame blindness to become a worldwide jazz star, and whose composition “Lullaby of Birdland” became an enduring jazz standard, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 91.

headline: New Budget Includes Increase for the Smithsonian Institution
text: President Obama’s proposed budget for fiscal year 2012 includes $861.5 million for the Smithsonian Institution, an increase of $100 million over the Smithsonian’s last appropriation, in fiscal year 2010. The difference is accounted for by $125 million the administration is requesting for the construction of the National Museum of African American History and Culture, set to open in 2015. The Smithsonian’s 2010 appropriation included $20 million for the museum’s design and planning process. The museum’s total construction budget is $500 million, half of which is being paid for by the federal government.

headline: Even Paulson’s Friends Pitied His Subprime Bet

headline: A Long Snowless Stretch: 12 Days and Counting
text: Just when you were looking forward to an almost-shirtsleeve day with a predicted high of 52 degrees, let’s talk snow. But in a good way.

headline: Numberplay: The Musical Shuffle
text: Today is Valentine’s Day, a day when you want to set the romantic mood by choosing the perfect music. To inspire us, last night was one of the music world’s biggest nights: the Grammy Awards. All you have to do now is to pick the right songs – today’s digital musical players and smartphones make it a snap to select them from your playlist to suit every mood. But what if you were stuck with a player that (thanks to Apple’s marketing genius) makes a virtue of randomness, like the iPod shuffle? This is the conundrum that gives rise to a fascinating puzzle contributed by Dion Wong of Australia. Previously, in When Randomness Produces Certainty, we saw how randomness acting over and over can create order. The question that arises in Dion’s puzzle is: How can we optimally combine randomness and order? It’s a fitting question for today because, no matter how orderly a plan you might have made for a perfect Valentine’s Day, randomness might just intervene. And the connection of randomness to the Grammy Awards ceremony is clear too – what random pattern of clothes (or what passes for them) did Lady Gaga wear? That might take us too far afield, so without further ado, here’s the puzzle.

headline: Asked & Answered | Xavier
text: Artists as diverse as Ashford and Simpson, Lena Horne, Del Marquis of the Scissor Sisters and Bread and Puppet Theater have all had the pleasure of being sung to, backed by or collaborating with Xavier Smith, a dreadlocked, extremely tall (6’6″) fixture on the downtown Manhattan performance circuit. For the past several years, Smith — who grew up in New York, has a gently soulful voice and prefers to be called simply “Xavier” (“with a hard X,” he notes, “like Ex-ayvier”) — has produced a Valentine’s song as a love letter to his friends, fans and whomever he might have been in love with that year. It started in 2004 with a cover of the Beatles’ “In My Life,” and this year’s offering is a heartbreaking rendition of Curtis Mayfield’s “The Makings of You” set to a small orchestral arrangement. From Bushwick, Brooklyn, where Xavier lives with Dima, his once-vicious but now sweet Himalayan blue-eyed cat, Xavier told T why he does the yearly Valentine’s song.

headline: Aid Cuts Have Texas Schools Scrambling
text: HUTTO, Tex.  The school superintendent in this rural town outside the state capital has taken steps to trademark the district’s oddly un-Texan school mascot  the Hutto Hippo  in a frantic effort to raise cash. He is also planning to put advertisements on school buses and to let retailers have space on the school Web site.

headline: Obama’s Budget Proposes a Significant Increase for Schools
text: President Obama proposed a 2012 Department of Education budget on Monday that would, if approved, significantly increase federal spending for public schools, and maintain the maximum Pell grant  the cornerstone financial-aid program  at $5,550 per college student.

headline: Trade and Monetary Issues Top Agenda at G-20
text: PARIS  Developed economies still recovering from the financial crisis are looking for ways to regain momentum as the global economy shifts in favor of China and other emerging markets.

headline: Valuable Artifacts Missing From Egyptian Museum
text: A full inventory of the Egyptian Museum in Cairo has found that 18 valuable artifacts are now missing after a break-in on Jan. 28, Egypt’s antiquities minister, Zahi Hawass, wrote on his blog on Sunday. Previously, Mr. Hawass had only said that objects were damaged. Among the most important of the missing items are a limestone statue of the god Akhenaten holding an offering table and a gilded wooden statue of Tutankhamen being carried by a goddess. On Monday, however, CNN reported that 2 of the 18 objects — a heart scarab and a funerary statuette of the nobleman Yuya — had been found on museum grounds. Mr. Hawass also said that a storeroom at Dahshur was broken into on Saturday night. He told Ahram Online that eight amulets were missing. Meanwhile, there were accounts on Twitter of protests outside the offices of the Supreme Council of Antiquities, the government body run by Mr. Hawass, who was appointed by former President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Morning T | Michael Kors
text: In this installment of our video interview series, Horacio Silva sits down with Michael Kors, known to many of the television-viewing public as a judge on Bravo’s “Project Runway,” and to fewer as the designer whose disastrous show partly led to the creation of New York fashion week. Among the topics discussed: growing up in Merrick, Long Island, his fashion world bombast on “Project Runway,” and his 30 years in fashion. His advice to designers? “Stay light on your feet, and be ready for whatever’s gonna happen. Something always does.”

On Lens.

headline: Pacemaker, 1933
text: On Sunday, June 11, 1933, The New York Times reported on a meeting of the American Medical Association that would begin the next day. Along with exhibits on “high-voltage X-ray treatment” of cancer, on instruments used in famous murder cases and on poisons removed from the organs of homicide victims, it said, “Here will be demonstrated the ‘artificial pacemaker,’ by which hearts that have stopped beating may sometimes be resuscitated.”

headline: Backstage Beauty | Carolina Herrera
text: Few designers create pieces as timeless as Carolina Herrera, and backstage at her fall show, the beauty team was hard at work creating a look to match. The makeup artist Diane Kendal painted on what she called “a classic Carolina face”: black cream eyeliner on the top lash line only with a bit of a wing, M.A.C. Haute and Naughty Mascara only on outer lashes, M.A.C. Eye Gloss on lids and M.A.C. Blush in Angel on the cheeks. “On the lips we’re using a new [M.A.C.] color called Prince Noir, and we’re applying it with a lip brush and then blotting it with tissue so it gives a really beautiful stained burgundy look,” Kendal said. Nails were kept relatively short and painted with two coats of a shade from Creative Nail Design called Dark Ruby followed by a generous coat of Super Shiney Top Coat, “to contrast the matte textures such as fur, velvet, suede,” said CND’s Wanda Ruiz. The hairstylist Orlando Pita, who took the “big, beautiful necklines” into account when creating his polished, rolled bun-chignon hybrid using Moroccanoil products, clearly also had the Carolina Herrera client in mind. “I’ve seen messy updos for a long, long time, and I’m moving away from them,” he said. “This collection is too polished for that.”

headline: Transformers Land in New York, and the City Responds
text: As part of the American International Toy Fair in New York this week, Hasbro parked Optimus Prime, the hero of the “Transformers” movie series, on 41st Street near 8th Avenue in front of The TimesCenter, where Hasbro is displaying its line of toys.

text: Italo Zucchelli’s explored proportion and volume in addition to the signature tech-y fabrications he’s compelled by in his latest Calvin Klein show. In a nod to the late 80’s style of Rhythm Nation, models in caps and closely-cropped hair marched in oversized, drop-shoulder bomber jackets and slim pants in heavy felted wool in charcoal and olive drab. It made for a mildly militaristic look that was quite arresting.

text: Most medical devices recalled in recent years by the Food and Drug Administration because they posed a high risk to patients were not rigorously studied before being cleared for sale, according to a study in a medical journal released Monday.

headline: Backstage Grooming | Billy Reid
text: Unlike designers who approach collections with a particular theme or era in mind, Billy Reid, the recipient of this year’s CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund, designs his piece by piece, which explains his infectious passion for the unique. For his fall collection, Reid said backstage, “My focus was on construction, a lot of tailoring. I spent an inordinate amount of time perfecting each piece. My men’s looks are cleaner, with more subtle details than before.” In line with Reid’s penchant for individuality, the hairstylist Marcos Diaz created looks that were “groomed but not Don Draper.” Using just the newly launched Mat Forming Ground from Davines (a supermatte clay) and his fingers, Diaz formed a natural-looking side part and left the rest of the hair “dry-looking and clean.” Emphasizing approachability, Diaz said, “I’m interested in keeping hair more realistic, something you could easily create at home.” The makeup artist Nadine Luke relied on a few key players from M.A.C. and her belief of “a little goes a long way” for men’s makeup. Luke hydrated skin with Studio Moisture Fix, concealed as necessary, moisturized lips with Lip Conditioner, and tamed unruly brows with Brow Set (which she considers a guy’s “secret weapon,” as it instantly grooms both brows and mustaches). Luke finished the look with Mineralize Skinfinish, a shimmer-free bronzer that contours and provides a matte finish in a pinch, noting that “Billy Reid’s guy is someone you wouldn’t imagine grooming because he’s slightly rugged. But really, he’s a polished gentleman.”Runway slide show

headline: When Love Meant Letters
text: Speaking of love and the Army, there is an exhibit at the National Army Museum in London chronicling the letters exchanged between soldiers in battle and those they left at home. The hundreds of pages — some from as far back as 200 years ago — capture a longing and a loneliness that will sound familiar even to modern lovers who close the distance with tools like Skype.

headline: Dale Earnhardt Jr. Earns Daytona 500 Pole Position
text: Nearly 10 years after the death of his father at the same speedway, Dale Earnhardt Jr. averaged 186.09 miles per hour in his Chevrolet on Sunday to earn pole position for the Sprint Cup Series’ Daytona 500, scheduled for Feb. 20. It was the second consecutive Daytona 500 pole for Earnhardt’s team, Hendrick Motorsports, which also won the coveted starting-line position in 2010 behind Mark Martin’s qualifying performance.

headline: Fostering Progress on a Finite (and Budget Strapped) Planet
text: 9:13 p.m. | Updated Dueling budgets are now out from House Republicans and the White House, and particularly intense fights are already under way over what to slash and what to preserve — whether your interest is environmental protection or heating assistance for the poor.

headline: Overseas Travelers Set Record for City’s Airports
text: Despite the hard economic times around the world, New York City was more popular than ever for international travelers last year, according to statistics compiled by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

headline: Forsberg’s Sad Goodbye
text: Peter Forsberg’s latest comeback of sorts — all of two games long, neither of which was played in front of the Colorado Avalanche fans who adore him — is a tough way to bid goodbye to one of the game’s great players. Forsberg will never show up in a lot of all-time great lists because his career was hampered by injuries, but those who watched him in his prime can recount tales of one of the most gifted players on the planet. His two Stanley Cups, two Olympic gold medals, one Hart Trophy and 885 career points in 708 games are ample evidence as well.

headline: Wade’s Peculiar Struggles Against Boston Continue
text: The Miami Heat of last season were equal parts depressing and inspiring. The Heat roster (Dwyane Wade aside) was limited, and as a result, Jermaine O’Neal and Michael Beasley became the pillars on which Miami was forced to stand. Their season wasn’t one of disaster, merely of reality; although the Heat had the league’s sixth-best defense, they lacked competent offensive players to produce consistently or distract defenses away from Wade.

headline: Making a Mighty Sound for Berlioz, but Delicately
text: Given that practically every piece left to us by the French composer Hector Berlioz offers examples of his vivid, unruly imagination, it comes as no surprise that his Requiem, an 1837 adaptation of the Roman Catholic Mass setting, takes impracticality to an extreme virtually unknown in his day, and hardly more common in ours. Among its more outlandish features is the small army required to perform it: an orchestra 140 strong, including a small cadre of timpanists; 210 choristers; and additional phalanxes of brass players offstage.

headline: Talent Is What Made Him Dangerous
text: He was the very image of the quintessential American hero  loyal, unsentimental, plain-spoken. An idealist wary of causes and ideology. A romantic who hid his deeper feelings beneath a tough veneer. A renegade who subscribed to an unshakeable code of honor.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Under the Influence
text: Young designers like Joseph Altuzarra and Jason Wu are taking design cues from vetern designers like Oscar de la Renta and Carolina Herrera.

headline: A Soulful, Virtuosic Player Holding the Spotlight Alone
text: The Brazilian guitarist Odair Assad performs mostly as half of the Assad Brothers, and though his older brother, Sérgio, has pursued an independent musical life as a composer, arranger and player, Odair, until recently, seemed disinclined to build a solo career.

headline: Central Park, 1:37 P.M.
text: The juvenile red-tailed hawk that injured his wing crashing into the glass-walled atrium at the headquarters of The New York Times last month was released at Tupelo Meadow in the Ramble at Central Park, after a recuperative stay at Wildlife in Need of Rehabilitation and Rescue on Long Island.

headline: The Silence of the Fishers
text: Roland Kays, curator of mammals at the New York State Museum, writes from Albany, where he is comparing the behavior of fishers in urban and wild settings.

headline: Perez Tells Mets He Wants to Start
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. – Oliver Perez, one of the more vilified Mets in team history, was back on the field Monday and threw his first ball on a Mets mound since his last,  disastrous appearance, in the last inning of the last game of a very forgettable 2010 season.

headline: Superstar Tenor Grapples With the Operatic Canon
text: Even if it doesn’t know a thing about singing, even if it can’t tell Handel from Haydn, an audience perceives when a singer is uncomfortable. You can feel it in the air, hear it in the applause.

headline: Risks: Side Effects Fueled by High-Energy Drinks
text: A wide-ranging review of the effects of high-caffeine energy drinks on children and young adults finds that they have been linked to an array of serious events  including heart palpitations, high blood pressure and even cardiac arrest and death  and may pose special risks to young people who take medication or have chronic illnesses.

headline: As Games Shrink, an Industry Considers Growth
text: LAS VEGAS  Mike Morhaime, co-founder, president and chief executive of Blizzard Entertainment, is one of the most successful people in the history of video games. His company  home of the Diablo, StarCraft and Warcraft franchises  is known for spending many years and many millions of dollars making some of the world’s deepest and most extensive games.

headline: Wariness on Surgery of the Mind
text: In recent years, many psychiatrists have come to believe that the last, best chance for some people with severe and intractable mental problems is psychosurgery, an experimental procedure in which doctors operate directly on the brain.

headline: Carlyle Names Chief Financial Officer
text: The Carlyle Group has named Adena T. Friedman as chief financial officer, a move that will fuel further speculation that the private equity giant is moving closer to an initial public offering.

headline: Ridding a Moody Cunningham Work of Ambiguity, One Gesture at a Time
text: The small-scale New York Theater Ballet concentrates on repertory overlooked by larger troupes. Often enough its stagings of rare works add to the knowledge of most dancegoers. Sometimes the fare, however, makes it look merely quaint. Both aspects were on display in the “Signatures 11” program last weekend at Gould Hall, sometimes within the same offering.

headline: Extra, Extra! ‘Newsies’ Musical to Open Paper Mill Playhouse Season
text: Stop the presses! Or should that be, restart the presses? Either way, “Newsies,” the misunderstood but much-loved Disney movie musical about the New York City newsboys who organize a labor strike in 1899, is getting a second edition. On Monday, the theater said that a stage version of “Newsies” would be the opening production at the 2011-12 season of the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J., and would feature music by Alan Menken (the film’s original composer) and Jack Feldman (its original lyricist) as well as a new book by Harvey Fierstein.

headline: 'Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind'
text: A. O. Scott looks back at Michel Gondry and Charlie Kaufman's film about loss, memory and love.

headline: Web of Popularity, Achieved by Bullying
text: For many teenagers navigating the social challenges of high school, the ultimate goal is to become part of the “popular” crowd.

headline: Soaking Up the Sun to Squeeze Bills to Zero
text: GOLDEN, Colo. — The west-facing windows by Jim Duffield’s desk started automatically tinting blue at 2:50 p.m. on a recent Friday as the midwinter sun settled low over the Rocky Mountain foothills.

headline: Obama’s Shout-Out for Energy
text: Over all, the Obama administration has pledged to hold the line on “discretionary spending” in its budget for the 2012 fiscal year — that is, everything it can control, which leaves out areas like Medicare and Social Security. But on energy, it is still going gangbusters, at least as proposed on Monday.

headline: Last-Minute Primping
Excerpts From New York’s Doomsday Legal Manual
text: Following are excerpts from the “New York State Public Health Legal Manual,” published this month by the state court system and the state bar association. It is a guide for judges, lawyers and health professionals in large-scale emergencies like terrorist attacks, epidemics and mass contaminations. In trying to synthesize the law of calamity, it says that the patchwork of court decisions, agency rules and state and federal laws includes many guideposts for disasters “adopted at a time when recent emergencies could not have been foreseen.”

text: The artist Jane Moseley and friends play dress up in Rodarte's new collection for opening ceremony.

headline: A Legal Manual for an Apocalyptic New York
text: Major disasters like terrorist attacks and mass epidemics raise confounding issues for rescuers, doctors and government officials. They also pose bewildering legal questions, including some that may be painful to consider, like how the courts would decide who gets life-saving medicine if there are more victims than supplies.

headline: Mercedes-Benz C-Class Coupe Previewed Before Geneva Auto Show
text: Mercedes-Benz’s new-product parade continues apace, with the all-new C-Class coupe scheduled to be revealed at the Geneva auto show next month. In its base C250 trim, the coupe is powered by the brand’s new 1.8-liter turbocharged 4-cylinder engine, developing 201 horsepower and 229 pound-feet of torque, while the higher-spec C350 receives a 3.5-liter V-6 with 302 horsepower and 273 pound-feet of torque.

headline: Kitsch of the Day | Baptiste Giabiconi ‘Showtime’
text: Lovers of all things Lagerfeld are already familiar with Baptiste Giabiconi, whether it’s from Chanel couture shows, where the 21-year-old French male model and muse to Kaiser Karl invariably closed the show by sashaying around the runway with a giant lion’s head, or frolicking in the hay with Lara Stone. Or they might know him from his various photo shoots (signés Lagerfeld, of course) or public outings with his septuagenarian mentor, including a memorable St. Tropez trip in the summer of 2010, when Giabiconi and Lagerfeld stopped by a local newsstand, dressed to the nines and trailed by hordes of paparazzi and curious tourists. But being the male face for Chanel, Fendi and Karl Lagerfeld (as well as starring in a Coca-Cola Light campaign) is apparently not enough for the slightly cross-eyed little Corsican that could; in late 2010 Giabiconi also embarked on a singing career and released his first single, “Showtime.” Even though the song has been out for a few months and enjoyed considerable chart success in France, it’s gone largely unnoticed by the American public. Granted, under normal circumstances the epic video (above) accompanying the release of the heavily auto-tuned single would not be considered kitsch; its Wild West theme, with Giabiconi saving a bodacious brunette from her abusive boyfriend, complete with explosive super powers in the Californian desert, is pop video cliché at its best. And Giabiconi’s English (“Woz wrong wiz you, man?”) is certainly better than Lady Gaga’s French. But the fact that it has Karl Lagerfeld’s blessing and the remote possibility of him doing a special cameo as a Bond-style villain makes it all the more enjoyable. That sadly doesn’t happen, but then again, Giabiconi knows how to keep us on our toes: the video ends with a promising “To be Continued.”

headline: East 59th Street, 1:41 P.M.
text: For Valentine’s Day, “Gold Man” wears red hearts.

headline: Despite the Reviews, ‘Spider-Man’ Grosses Go Up
text: “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” had strong tickets sales last week, despite the fallout from largely terrible reviews, according to the first slice of box-office data to be released since critics weighed in on Tuesday before the oft-delayed show’s official opening.

headline: Putting Oscar Wilde on the Back Seat
text: It seems a worthy enough pursuit for a playwright to shift Lord Alfred Douglas, a k a Bosie, into the spotlight, rescuing Oscar Wilde’s troublesome bit of crumpet from the sidelines. But instead, Thomas Kilroy’s “My Scandalous Life” buries Bosie in the indignity of dramaturgical stodginess.

headline: Rewards Program Irks Some Southwest Loyalists

headline: City Opera’s New Chairman Is Singing an Uplifting Aria
text: It could not have sounded like the most enticing offer: become the chairman of New York City Opera, which had a $20 million deficit in 2009, raided its endowment to pay off debts and cut its season to just five productions. But Charles R. Wall, who took over as the opera’s chairman on Jan. 1, nonetheless signed on.

text: Marriott International announced plans on Monday to split into two separate companies — one focused on lodging and another on timeshares.

headline: Bridging a Gap Between Fear and Peace
text: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico  The short trek from danger to calm starts before dawn. First, there is the grind of a turnstile  total cost: 3 pesos, or 25 cents  then thousands of legs push forward, broomlike, onto the Paso del Norte bridge and away from Ciudad Juárez.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Kirsi Pyrhonen at Theyskens Theory

headline: Can Côtes du Rhônes Take the Heat?
text: ONCE upon a time you knew what you were getting when you opened a Côtes du Rhône. More than likely it would be a light-bodied red with flavors of spicy fruit and Provençal herbs. While these Côtes du Rhônes of old might have varied from undistinguished to highly pleasing, you knew that you could order a carafe, a bottle, maybe even two, and expect a wine that would go down easily. Indeed, Côtes du Rhône became something of a synonym for blithe, gulpable bistro wines.

headline: Iraqi Protesters Seek Not a New Regime, but Jobs
text: BAGHDAD  Iraq would seem to have virtually every ingredient for upheaval: crippling poverty, few good jobs, creaky public services, anger at an entrenched political elite and thousands of young people who meet online to vent their grievances and organize protests.

headline: Stoudemire and Gallinari Miss Practice
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Amar’e Stoudemire — the Knicks’ leading scorer, rebounder and relevancy revivalist — missed a game Saturday night, and his team surprisingly did not implode or disintegrate without him. Pushed by Raymond Felton and Wilson Chandler, the Knicks played just fine without Stoudemire, who sat out the 105-95 win over the Nets with an injured toe.

headline: Ratings Up for Grammys
text: CBS’s broadcast of the Grammy Awards on Sunday attracted the largest audience for the show in 11 years. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 26.7 million viewers tuned in to CBS’s live coverage, up from the 25.9 million who watched a year ago. CBS easily led the night over all, including the 7 p.m. hour preceding the three-and-a-half-hour show with a Grammy edition of “60 Minutes” (12.2 million) that included Anderson Cooper’s interview with Lady Gaga.

headline: More Than Meets the iPhone Lens
text: Like media and entertainment, fashion now unfolds across several platforms, with different audiences and levels of taste. Tory Burch’s presentation on Sunday — not a show per se but a continuous loop of models — drew top retailers but also a throng of enthusiastic young people, many of whom look at the clothes through their cameras or cellphones with a concentration seldom warranted by ’70s-style sportswear with an English twist.

headline: Berkshire Closes Out Its Bank of America Stake
text: Warren E. Buffett‘s investment company, Berkshire Hathaway, sold off its remaining five million shares in Bank of America last quarter, according to regulatory documents filed on Monday.

headline: A Cautious Faith in the Army
text: CAIRO — In December 2007, six weeks before Kosovo’s independence I was privileged to sit in Pristina with a group of young, idealistic rising stars in the Kosovar political scene, as they tirelessly discussed their thoughts, hopes and plans for their nation to be born strong, democratic, dynamic, and politically mature. And I felt jealous. And I hoped I would, one day, I would too have such an animated discussion on the future of my country.

headline: Reading at Some Private Schools Is Delayed
text: When Drake Roth was 18 months old, he would read the names of characters in “Thomas the Tank Engine” videos from his playpen as they flashed across the screen. At 2, he was onto cereal box labels; at 3, his preschool’s director told his mother to watch what reading material was within his reach on the kitchen table.

headline: Farewell to Il Fenomeno: Ronaldo Retires
text: Ronaldo, the gap-toothed Brazilian striker who once dominated world soccer with an astonishing blend of strength, speed and skill, announced Monday that he was retiring from the game at age 34. Worn down by knee injuries, fitness problems and nearly two decades as a professional, he tearfully confirmed his plans at a news conference in Sao Paulo.

headline: Partying Amid Poverty Stirs South Africa Debate
text: SANDTON, South Africa  Kenny Kunene, a former gangster turned businessman, gave what he called “the mother of all parties” for his 40th birthday. With his small paunch protruding from a white tuxedo and his eyes hidden behind Roberto Cavalli sunglasses, he ate sushi from the belly of a woman who was wearing nothing but black lingerie and high heels while hundreds of guests looked on.

headline: Common Cause Asks Court About Thomas Speech

headline: Investigators of Turkish Plot Detain 4 Journalists in Raid

text: SEATTLE  A plan to build the United States’ first West Coast facility for exporting coal to Asia has come under increased scrutiny after the disclosure of documents suggesting that the company proposing the project did not convey the full scope of its plans to state regulators here in Washington.

headline: Scorecard | Thakoon Wins!
text: In fashion one day you’re in, and the next… On the fourth day of New York fashion week, Scorecard knows designers were facing challenges like receiving less-than-luxe cashmere and silks from suppliers. Ever industrious, Thakoon Panichgul set to work marrying Masai checks with Marie Antoinettesque panniers. That move turned out to be better than any fringe benefits.

headline: Dog Show’s Rare Breeds Are Glimpse of History
text: As Baxter the otterhound bounded around the show ring at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show on Monday, his owner, Cathy Glenn, felt sure he would win best in breed — and not just because he had won the prize three years running.

headline: U.S. Policy to Address Internet Freedom
text: WASHINGTON —  Days after Facebook and Twitter added fuel to a revolt in Egypt, the Obama administration on Tuesday announced a new policy on Internet freedom, intended to help people get around barriers in cyberspace while making it harder for autocratic governments to use the same technology to repress dissent.

headline: A Nationwide Day for Honoring Charles Darwin, but Handled With Caution
text: There was trepidation on both sides when a squadron of biologists set out to celebrate Darwin Day in rural America during the weekend.

headline: Bold Step for Fair Courts in New York
text: New York’s chief judge, Jonathan Lippman, is taking on the problem of money in judicial elections. At his urging, a state judicial board is proposing to bar more than 700 elected judges from hearing cases involving any lawyer or party who contributed $2,500 or more to the judge’s campaign in the preceding two years.

headline: Quinn to Offer Proposals to Ease City Drivers’ Pain
text: New York City has gone out of its way in recent years to cater to the nonmotorized, turning part of Times Square into a pedestrian plaza and making room for bicycles on gridlocked streets.

headline: From Established Agency, Bets on Upstarts of the Future
text: JUST when it looked as though Kirshenbaum Bond Senecal & Partners was done reinventing itself, the agency has decided to add a new business to its suite of offerings with the announcement on Tuesday of K.B.S.& P. Ventures.

headline: Seward’s Folly
text: By February 1861 the Republican Party was on the verge of taking complete control of the federal government. But internally, the party was split in two by the secession crisis and how to respond: the first, by far the majority, believed that concessions to Southern demands would simply produce more threats and demands down the line; the minority, on the other hand, believed that such an uncompromising stance risked a suicidal civil war.

headline: The Obama Budget
text: On paper, President Obama’s new $3.7 trillion budget is encouraging. It makes a number of tough choices to cut the deficit by a projected $1.1 trillion over 10 years, which is enough to prevent an uncontrolled explosion of debt in the next decade and, as a result, reduce the risk of a fiscal crisis.

headline: Texas Coach Demands Best, Has Record to Prove It
text: GRANBURY, Tex.  At 7:15 a.m. on Monday, the girls’ basketball team at Granbury High assembled for practice. As always, shirts had to be tucked in, hair pulled back. If a shoelace came untied, it meant running the bleachers. Questions had two acceptable answers: Yes ma’am and no ma’am.

headline: In Love With Each Other, and With a New Country
text: Amr Abdo and his wife, Ghada Bayoumy, had “mixed feelings” about the big step they were about to take. Born in Egypt and wed there, but living in the United States the past 15 years, they were moments away from becoming newly minted Americans on Monday.

headline: Ecuador Judge Orders Chevron to Pay $9 Billion
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  A judge in a tiny courtroom in the Ecuadorean Amazon ruled Monday that the oil giant Chevron was responsible for polluting remote tracts of Ecuadorean jungle and ordered the company to pay more than $9 billion in damages, one of the largest environmental awards ever.

headline: More Shame
text: The Roman Catholic hierarchy in this country has promised accountability and justice for children sexually abused by priests. We fear it has a long way to go. A new inquiry has found that nearly a decade after the scandal engulfed the American church, children are still in peril and some leaders are still stonewalling investigations.

headline: Israel and a New Egypt
text: Hisham Hellyer, left, of the University of Warwick and Shadi Hamid of the Brookings Institution discuss Israel and Egypt's Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: Several ESPN Broadcasters Have Had Shoe Contracts
text: Erin Andrews, who signed an endorsement deal with Reebok last month, is not the only ESPN personality or member of its “College GameDay” team to have a contract with a major shoe company.

headline: On ‘Jeopardy,’ Watson Rallies, Then Slips
text: Two men stood on the bright blue set of “Jeopardy” Monday night, on location in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., to begin a three-day competition against a celebrity contestant: an IBM super computer named Watson.

headline: Arizona: Border Activist Is Convicted
text: Shawna Forde, the leader of a border security group, was convicted of first-degree murder Monday in the 2009 shootings of a man and his daughter. Ms. Forde, claiming to be a law enforcement officer, barged into the Flores home in Arivaca with accomplices. Raul Flores and his daughter, Brisenia, 9, were killed. The jury also convicted Ms. Forde of the attempted murder of Gina Gonzalez, Mr. Flores’s wife. Trials for Jason Bush and Albert Gaxiola, accused of accompanying Ms. Forde, are scheduled for this spring. Prosecutors said the attackers considered Mr. Flores a drug smuggler and wanted to use his drug proceeds for a paramilitary organization to seal off the border to immigrants.

headline: Warning on Thyroid Treatment
text: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Monday that it “strongly discourages” sending thyroid patients who receive radioactive iodine to hotels after treatment. Use of hotels has become common because some doctors who administer the drug work in places that cannot quarantine the patients while the radiation dies down. Critics said that could result in vulnerable hotel personnel receiving significant doses.

headline: N.F.L. Claims Union Is Not Bargaining in Good Faith
text: The N.F.L. filed an unfair labor practice charge against the players union Monday, alleging that the union has failed to bargain in good faith because, the league said, it plans to decertify.

headline: Obama Proposes Health Agency Cut but Spares Medicare Fees
text: WASHINGTON  Spending by the Department of Health and Human Services would decline in 2012 for the first time in the agency’s 30-year history under President Obama’s budget request.

headline: Clinton Says G.O.P. Cuts Would Hurt U.S. Interests
text: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton warned Monday that Republican-proposed cuts in foreign aid to be considered by the House this week would harm the nation’s security interests and standing across the globe.

headline: In Art, Recalling a Century-Old Tragedy
text: Anthony Giacchino thumbed through a stack of letters, all of them marked with yellow stickers, red stamps or a simple, final X slashed through the addressee’s names: Clotilde Terranova. Rosie Friedman. Rosaria, Lucia and Catherine Maltese. “Return to sender,” he said. “Return. Return. Return. It’s like, ‘Who is this person?’ They’re forgotten, and unfortunately there’s a lot of truth to that.”

headline: Villages Without Doctors
Would the Bard Have Survived the Web?
text: ARCHAEOLOGISTS finished a remarkable dig last summer in East London. Among their finds were seven earthenware knobs, physical evidence of a near perfect 16th-century experiment into the link between commerce and culture.

headline: Spain Supports Contador in Fighting Drug Charges
text: Alberto Contador has persuaded the Spanish cycling federation to clear him of all charges stemming from his positive drug test at last summer’s Tour de France, according to news reports Monday in Spain.

headline: To Stand Out, Retailers Flock to Exclusive Lines
text: To find Miley Cyrus’s line of clothes, shoppers head to Wal-Mart. For Selena Gomez’s, they go to Kmart. Jennifer Lopez’s line is at Kohl’s, and Demi Lovato’s at Target. Rachel Bilson dinnerware can only be found at Macy’s, while for the Kardashian Kollection, fans must go to Sears.

headline: Vanishing Act: ‘Advisers’ Distance Themselves From a Report
text: A new study backed by pro-business groups takes a harsh stance on rules intended to bring transparency to the $600 trillion derivatives market. The report, published on Monday, claims that proposed regulation could cost 130,000 jobs and could cut corporate spending by $6.7 billion.

headline: Seaport Museum Furloughs Staff Members
text: The struggling Seaport Museum New York put 32 staff members – about half its staff – on unpaid furloughs on Monday the museum’s chairman, Frank J. Sciame, said through a spokesman.

headline: The Experience Economy
text: Tyler Cowen’s e-book, “The Great Stagnation,” has become the most debated nonfiction book so far this year. Cowen’s core point is that up until sometime around 1974, the American economy was able to experience awesome growth by harvesting low-hanging fruit. There was cheap land to be exploited. There was the tremendous increase in education levels during the postwar world. There were technological revolutions occasioned by the spread of electricity, plastics and the car.

headline: Reagan and Reality
text: Early in Eugene Jarecki’s documentary, “Reagan,” you hear the voice of Ronald Reagan saying, “Someday it might be worthwhile to find out how images are created  and even more worthwhile to learn how false images come into being.”

headline: Westchester Officer Isn’t Indicted in Pace Student’s Death
text: A Westchester County grand jury concluded that there was “no reasonable cause” to indict a police officer who shot and killed a college football player in a car outside a bar last fall in Thornwood, prosecutors announced on Monday.

headline: Tuesday: Something Everybody Is Aware Of
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Do you have a favorite day of the week for solving?

headline: As Schools Face Cutbacks, a Debate Over What’s Fair
text: ALBANY  It is an annual tradition on the day the governor unveils his budget. Flipping page after page of stapled booklets collated by the state’s Education Department, lawmakers search through tiny print for a series of magic numbers.

headline: Britain to Look Into Freezing Assets of Mubarak Associates
text: LONDON — Three days after Hosni Mubarak resigned the Egyptian presidency, the British government announced on Monday that it would consult with its European allies on a request from the new authorities in Egypt to freeze the assets of “several former officials” in the Mubarak government.

headline: Grief, Unedited
text: EVER since Joan Didion’s book “The Year of Magical Thinking” began its long run as a best seller in 2005, a number of first-person accounts of losing a husband have been published. Among them are Kate Braestrup’s “Here If You Need Me,” Anne Roiphe’s “Epilogue” and Kay Redfield Jamison’s “Nothing Was the Same.” This week, they are being joined by Joyce Carol Oates’s memoir “A Widow’s Story,” which recounts the death of her 77-year-old husband, Raymond Smith, from complications of pneumonia in 2008. While these memoirs are often moving, they are also highly subjective snapshots that don’t teach us much about how we typically grieve, nor more important, for how long.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Marc Jacobs: The Beautiful People
text: One way to interpret the padded vinyl columns and mirrored runway at the Marc Jacobs show tonight was that it evoked the sophistication of a 1950s dressing room. Backstage, Mr. Jacobs, in a jovial mood, said he was thinking of New York this winter — hence the chilly arctic blue of the vinyl.

headline: Corrections
text: THE ARTS

headline: Westminster Dog Show Kicks Off
text: Poodles, corgis and terriers all made appearances as the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show began at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Argentina Accuses U.S. of Sneaking in Cargo
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil  Argentina has accused the United States military of trying to bring guns and surveillance equipment into the country under the cover of supplying a police training course, creating the latest diplomatic rift between the countries.

headline: Mounted Patrols Put Out to Pasture
text: Like police departments around the country, budget pressures have forced Charleston, S.C., to shut down its mounted police unit.

headline: When Principals and Teachers Are Replaced
text: To the Editor:

headline: Arrests of Brazilian Police Spur Drive Against Graft
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil  After the federal police arrested 30 police officers in Rio de Janeiro on Friday who were suspected of working with drug traffickers, José Mariano Beltrame, the state’s senior police official, said that rooting out corrupt officers would be a priority this year.

headline: At Arts Club, an Honest Cabby Is Rewarded
text: Around 3 p.m. Sunday, John James, twin brother of the longtime president of the National Arts Club, O. Aldon James Jr., hailed a taxicab on West 25th Street in Chelsea and directed the cabby to the club’s Victorian mansion on Gramercy Park South, where he keeps an apartment.

headline: Pakistan and Afghanistan to Get New U.S. Envoy
text: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton has chosen Marc Grossman, a retired senior diplomat and former ambassador to Turkey, as the Obama administration’s new special representative for Afghanistan and Pakistan, a senior State Department official said Monday.

headline: Backstage Beauty | Marc Jacobs
text: “You know those old women in the street who are a little bit eccentric? There’s always one living next to you. They put too much blush on and they don’t do their eyeliner quite well, but it looks fabulous in the end. That’s what the idea was,” explained the makeup artist François Nars backstage at the Marc Jacobs show. This translated to a black eyeliner NARS is releasing this fall called Via Venetto applied with a downward curve (“the opposite of Audrey Hepburn’s look,” explained Nars) and NARS Lokum Cream Blush applied low, near the mouth. “I think it looks like a grandmother who put lipstick on her cheeks,” said Nars with a laugh. The hairstylist Guido Palau gave this aging glamor girl a Croydon facelift, creating what he called “a dominatrix ponytail” using Redken Blow Away, a gel for blow-drying, and Shine Flash for serious gloss (models wore berets made of PVC by the milliner Stephen Jones secured with black chin straps). Nails were painted a shiny peach Jacobs chose from the polish brand Zoya. “Marc is very hands on,” said the manicurist Elisa Ferri, pun unintended. “He has an amazing eye.”

headline: Perez Arrives at Spring Training, but Wary Mets May Want Him Gone
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Spring training has not officially begun for the Mets, yet perhaps the most toxic issue from last year was revived Monday. Oliver Perez, one of the more vilified players in team history, threw his first ball on a Mets mound since his last, disastrous appearance in the last inning of the last game of a very forgettable 2010 season.

headline: First Things First: Jeter Will Be Leadoff Batter
text: TAMPA, Fla.  There will be competition for the two vacancies in the Yankees’ rotation and for bullpen jobs, for the backup catcher’s position and on their bench, but not for the spot atop the batting order. That was made unequivocally clear Monday by Manager Joe Girardi, who quashed speculation that Derek Jeter, coming off his worst season, would drop in the lineup.

headline: Sabathia Loses Weight and Keeps His Options Open
text: TAMPA, Fla.  C. C. Sabathia used to eat Cap’n Crunch by the box, not the handful, a habit conducive to maintaining his 315 pounds but detrimental to his long-term goals. Sabathia envisions himself pitching for another 8 years, maybe 10, and so after having surgery on his right knee in October, he consulted a chef and a nutritionist, improved his eating habits and began exercising twice a day.

headline: Inflation Hits Nearly 5 Percent in China, With Food Costs Soaring
text: BEIJING — Consumer prices in China rose 4.9 percent in January when compared with the same month a year earlier, the government reported Tuesday, as inflation continued to bedevil the economy.

headline: Word of the Day | estrange
text: estrange •\i-ˈstranj\• verb

headline: Report Details Sabotage of Birth Control
text: Men who abuse women physically and emotionally may also sabotage their partners’ birth control, pressuring them to become pregnant against their will, new reports suggest.

headline: Stabbed in Rampage, Brooklyn Cabdriver Is Then Put in Jail
text: He sat in the emergency room at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center in Brooklyn, thankful he was alive after being ambushed by a stranger who seemed set on killing him.

headline: Blanche Moyse, Music School Founder, Dies at 101
text: Blanche Moyse, a founder of the Marlboro Music School and Festival and, as a conductor, a leading interpreter of Bach’s choral works, died on Thursday at her home in Brattleboro, Vt. She was 101.

headline: Josefa Iloilo, Leader Who Revoked Fiji Constitution, Dies at 90
text: Josefa Iloilo, the president of Fiji who in 2009 provoked worldwide censure by tossing out the island nation’s Constitution, firing its judges and naming himself head of state, died on Feb. 6 in Suva, Fiji’s capital. He was 90.

headline: David F. Friedman, Horror Film Pioneer, Dies at 87
text: David F. Friedman, a film producer who cheerfully and cheesily exploited an audience’s hunger for bare-breasted women and blood-dripping corpses in lucrative low-budget films like “Blood Feast” and “Ilsa: She-Wolf of the S.S.,” died on Monday in Anniston, Ala. He was 87.

headline: News Quiz | February 15, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Iran’s Leader Derides Protests; Lawmakers Urge Death for Opposition Leaders
text: A day after the largest antigovernment protests in Iran in more than a year, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad on Tuesday dismissed opposition attempts to revive mass demonstrations as certain to fail, while members of the Iranian Parliament clamored for the two most prominent leaders of the protest movement to be executed.

headline: Pakistan: Kerry Visits in Hopes of Easing Tensions
text: Senator John Kerry traveled to Pakistan late on Monday to help defuse a diplomatic furor over the arrest of an American official accused of murder, White House and Senate officials said. Senator Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, planned to meet with senior Pakistani officials, and his visit was being coordinated with the White House. Tensions have been rising between the United States and Pakistan over the case of Raymond A. Davis, an American official who killed two motorcyclists in Lahore on Jan. 27 while driving his car. American Embassy officials say that Mr. Davis fired in self-defense when two armed men tried to rob him, but prosecutors in Pakistan have charged him with murder. American officials have insisted that he is protected by diplomatic immunity and should be released.

headline: In One Slice of Egypt, Daily Woes Top Religion
text: CAIRO  A generation ago, Ahmed Mitwalli’s parents were Islamists in this neighborhood along the Nile once nicknamed the Islamic Republic of Imbaba. But their son is not, and his convictions, echoed in the caldron of frustrations of one of the world’s most crowded quarters, suggest why the Muslim Brotherhood is not driving Egypt’s nascent revolution.

headline: Men’s Fall Fashion 2011 | Tommy Hilfiger
text: In the main skylit dining room of The Lion, Tommy Hilfiger trotted out suits, scarves, cropped jackets and overcoats sporting stripes akin to those on Hudson Bay blankets. It was a clever use of a preppy signature mashed up with sleeker shapes and richer colorations. The grey-on-grey asymmetrical toggle coat on the long haired blonde surfer looked very Love Story via Montauk.

headline: Barclays Profit Drops Less Than Expected
text: 7:17 p.m. | Updated

headline: Foster’s to Separate Wine and Beer Businesses in May
text: The Foster’s Group said on Tuesday that it would complete its plan to split its wine and beer businesses in May.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Feb. 15, 2011
text: Test your vocabulary skills with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the article  “‘King’s Speech': The Film to Beat and to Bad-Mouth.”

headline: Coming of Age in Dublin’s Underworld
text: Joy riding — stealing and destroying cars — is a rite of passage in the lawless but ritualistic world of disaffected youth in Ballymun, a community on the north side of Dublin. In “Joyrider,” through a series of cinematic black-and-white shots awash in light and movement, the photographer Ross McDonnell documented youths coming of age in a world of drugs, gangs and arson.

headline: What Are Your Ideas for School Fund-Raisers?
text: Many school districts around the country have been hit by serious budget cuts, prompting the need for creative fund-raising campaigns. Is your school or district facing a budget crisis? How do you think your school could raise more money? What fund-raisers do you think would be interesting and enjoyable and would attract more participants?

headline: Bahrain Takes the Stage With a Raucous Protest
text: MANAMA, Bahrain  Thousands of protesters poured into this nation’s symbolic center, Pearl Square, late Tuesday in a raucous rally that again demonstrated the power of popular movements that are transforming the political landscape of the Middle East.

text: From Today’s Times:

headline: A Prague Musical Returns, Funny and Dark
text: Homo sapiens are piggish and dirty — despite the species’ absurd pursuit of cleanliness through creepy beauty treatments. That is the darkly funny and often frightening theme of the musical “Here I Am Human!,” which plays (in English) from Feb. 20 to 22, at Archa (Na Porici 26; 420-2 21-71-63-33; www.archatheatre.cz), Prague’s leading alternative theater venue.

headline: Beyond Fannie and Freddie, a New Approach
text: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard and the author of “Triumph of the City.”

headline: The Champions League Returns
text: If it seems like months since you’ve seen a Champions League match, that’s probably because it has. But the wait ends this week and next with the first-leg Round of 16 matches, and the good news is that there are a couple of mouth-watering matchups to get everything restarted.

headline: Trial Is Set for Berlusconi in Prostitution Case
text: ROME  A Milan judge on Tuesday ordered Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi to stand trial in April on charges of paying an under-age girl for sex and abuse of office, dealing the most serious blow to his leadership in the 17 years that he has dominated Italian politics.

headline: The TV Watch: Man, Machine and a Trivial Pursuit
text: It’s not the match of the century, it’s more like the letdown of a lifetime. The first round on Monday in this week’s “Jeopardy!” competition between two former champions and Watson, the I.B.M. computer, was supposed to be a man vs. machine, guys against gadget, brain vs. Braun showdown. It was closer to “Bambi vs Godzilla.”

headline: Europe’s Economy Grew More Slowly Than Expected in 4th Quarter
text: FRANKFURT  The European economy grew more slowly than expected in the fourth quarter of 2010, a sign that some countries are still suffering from too much debt and not enough competitiveness.

headline: Money Buys a Lot, but Not Everything, in Soccer
text: LONDON — The Champions League is back in play, and so is the wealth league.

headline: New York Fashion Week Tweets | Tuesday
text: Today from 2 p.m. to 5 p.m., we will be going backstage at Sophie Theallet, to give you a behind-the-scenes look at the busiest and most exhilarating moments before the show.

headline: How Good a Boss Are You?
text: Last week’s post about subpar employees certainly got a spirited response. Not surprisingly, some people wanted to vent about subpar bosses. Fair enough. Let’s give that a look.

headline: Venture Between Two Tour Bus Companies Is Stopped
text: In the annals of antitrust cases it will fall somewhere below Standard Oil and Microsoft, but a decision by a federal transportation agency last week may at least please the city’s sightseers.

headline: Getting a Glimpse Into Hedge Funds’ Holdings
text: American hedge funds reported their quarterly holdings on Monday, offering the public a rare — albeit delayed — insight into the stocks held by top money managers.

headline: Afghan Official Says Women’s Shelters Are Corrupt
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistan’s top female official began a sustained verbal assault on women’s shelters on Tuesday, accusing them of corruption and mismanagement, and insisting that the government was determined to take control of them, whether or not donors continue to give financial support.

headline: Obama Budget Escapes Liberal Backlash, for Now
text: The response to President Obama‘s proposed 2012 budget from Republicans was predictably negative. But the reaction from what Mr. Obama’s spokesman once called “the professional left” was remarkably muted.

headline: Google Asks Users to Weigh In on Content Farms
text: Google has been facing swelling criticism from tech types over the quality of its search results because they often include links to sites like eHow, which critics disparagingly refer to as content farms.

headline: Singapore and Australian Exchanges Modify Deal
text: The Singapore and Australian stock exchanges said on Tuesday that they had revamped their merger proposal in an attempt to win regulatory support for the $8.4 billion deal consolidation in the sector gathered steam.

headline: A Reluctant Redgrave, on ‘Daisy’ and More
text: After more than 50 years of acting, Vanessa Redgrave understands the art of pausing and listening. At the heart of her latest Broadway play, “Driving Miss Daisy,” is a set of conversations between her snappish title character and James Earl Jones’s Hoke, Daisy’s chauffeur, whose decades-long friendship with Daisy forces her to face her own prejudice and frailties.

headline: Top 10 Composers: A Young Reader Responds
text: My two-week project to select the 10 greatest composers, which involved a series of articles, blog posts and videos, concluded with an article in the Arts & Leisure section on Jan. 23. But I continue to receive lively, interesting reactions from readers. My favorite was a hand-written letter from Lucas Amory, who is 8 years old and lives on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. Lucas is a serious piano student and the son of two noted violists, Misha Amory of the Brentano String Quartet and Hsin-Yun Huang.

headline: Twitter Wants to Go Multilingual Faster
text: BARCELONA, Spain — During the protests and rallies that erupted in Egypt, Twitter emerged as a crucial way for demonstrators to communicate and for journalists to quickly broadcast reports and observations from the ground.

headline: Federal Royalties for Gold and Copper?
text: A tiny item in the Obama budget puts the administration on the environmental side of one of the longest-running questions in the West: What do the companies that mine gold, silver, copper and other hard-rock minerals owe the Treasury for the valuable materials they extract from public lands?

headline: Lifestyles Of The Rich But Not Famous
text: OK, make that the fairly affluent. Today, David Brooks suggests that economic growth has slowed because these days the affluent are more into self-improvement and life quality than they are into money. In effect, we’re suffering from a decline in materialism.

headline: Morning Buzz | A Manual for Coping With Horror
text: Monday’s vernal temperatures are gone, replaced by a bright, brisk Tuesday with highs around freezing.

headline: Markets Retreat as Exxon Leads Energy Shares Down
text: Stocks retreated, pulling the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index down from a 32-month high, after a report showed retail sales increased less than forecast, and Exxon Mobil led a decline in energy producers.

headline: A Man Without a Face
text: It’s nearing the bitter end of the race, when even the most minor royals from “The King’s Speech” have spoken and every friending metaphor has been exhausted on “The Social Network.” But – and this is totally in the spirit of uncovering all there is to know about this season’s contenders and not at all meant as a last-minute notebook dump – the Bagger would like to direct you to our pals over at New York magazine’s Vulture, who have a behind-the-scenes look at how two distinct and (very) handsome men came to play the identical Winklevoss twins in “The Social Network.”

text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Russia Embraces Offshore Arctic Drilling
text: MOSCOW — The Arctic Ocean is a forbidding place for oil drillers. But that is not stopping Russia from jumping in — or Western oil companies from eagerly following.

headline: Obama Sets Tuesday Morning Press Conference
text: President Obama has scheduled a news conference for Tuesday morning, one day after unveiling his 2012 budget and just weeks before a potential showdown with Republicans over government spending.

headline: BATS in Talks to Create Brazilian Bourse
text: BATS Global Markets, a privately owned exchange operator in the United States, said on Tuesday that it was talking with the asset manager Claritas about setting up a new Brazilian bourse.

headline: Versteeg Joins Vanquished Stanley Cup Opponent
text: For the second time in less than a week, a contending team gave up a late first-round draft pick to acquire a second-line forward. The Flyers, in first place in the Eastern Conference, acquired right wing Kris Versteeg from Toronto on Monday night for first- and third-round selections in the June draft.

headline: A Rising Natural Rate
text: Lots of buzz about this San Francisco Fed paper on indications that we may have a “new normal” unemployment rate of between 6 and 7 percent. So a few notes on how to interpret the results.
