text: 8:34 p.m. | Updated

headline: The Calories Are Listed, but Teenagers Don’t Care
text: Researchers at New York University have found that calorie-posting in fast-food restaurants has little influence on the foods teenagers order.

headline: Police Horses Are Diminished in Number, but Not Presence
text: They are as woven into the fabric of Times Square as the Armed Forces recruiting center, or at least the Naked Cowboy. They pop up regularly around the Coney Island Boardwalk, outside Rockefeller Center, at Yankee Stadium, and at many of the street demonstrations that form a regular part life in New York City.

headline: Feb. 15: Updates on Middle East Protests
text: On Tuesday, The Lede continues to follow protests and unrest in Bahrain, Yemen and Iran, as well as Egypt’s post-Mubarak transition. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists on the ground. A stream of Twitter updates on regional protests is in this blog’s right column.

headline: In Egypt, a Panel of Jurists Is Given the Task of Revising the Country’s Constitution
text: CAIRO — The military officers governing Egypt on Tuesday convened a panel of jurists, including an outspoken Muslim Brotherhood politician, to revise the country’s Constitution in the first tangible evidence of a commitment to move the country toward democracy after President Hosni Mubarak’s ouster.

headline: CIT Profit Falls 35% in Fourth Quarter
text: The CIT Group, the small businesses and middle-market lender that emerged from bankruptcy in 2009, reported profit of $75 million for the fourth quarter of 2010, a 35 percent decline from the third quarter.

headline: A Cinematic Upset in the Making?
text: What makes a sure thing?

headline: A Valentine to Mom and Dad (Mostly Dad)
text: Midfielder Yael Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., native by way of the University of North Carolina, will be contributing to the Goal blog in the runup to the third season of Women’s Professional Soccer and as the United States women’s national team prepares to play in the Algarve Cup and the FIFA Women’s World Cup in Germany later this year.

headline: On Our Radar: Costner Is Sued Over Spill Technology
text: The actor Stephen Baldwin sues the actor and director Kevin Costner, asserting that he cheated Mr. Baldwin out of profits from an oil-spill cleanup device licensed to BP during the Gulf of Mexico oil spill last year. In a federal complaint, Mr. Baldwin and a business associate claim they were duped into prematurely selling their interests in the company behind the technology, which was dubbed the “Costner solution” despite the machines’ minimal impact on the spill. Mr. Costner denies any wrongdoing and has sought to dismiss the complaint. [The Los Angeles Times]

headline: T on Go Try It On
text: You might have seen Go Try It On’s 80s-inspired cursive logo plastered over downtown fitting room mirrors this past weekend. Now Marissa Evans, the founder and CEO of Go Try It On, has asked some of T’s fashion team to take a break from New York fashion week and virtually style her online community. The almost one-year-old social network site (they launched last year at SXSW) is committed to answering the eternal question “What should I wear?” with positive criticism only — negative or inappropriate comments and photos are screened and removed immediately, says Evans. An iPhone app allows members to easily upload images of outfits in question from any location, so go ahead, take the plunge and get fashion tips from our fashion editors on gotryiton.com. T’s Rae Boxer leads off today and will answer your questions between 12-1 p.m.

headline: Apple Offers Subscriptions for Apps
text: 8:31 p.m. | Updated Apple on Tuesday cleared the way for media companies to begin selling subscriptions to their magazine, newspaper, music and video content on the iPad and its other devices.

headline: A Handyman’s Special With Hot and Cold Running Rumors
text: LOS ANGELES  From Kirk Morgan’s perch, in a mansion at the top of Los Angeles, he can see it all: The snow-covered mountains from the vast windows in one of the seven bathrooms. The Hollywood sign, eye level from the kitchen. And, from the master bedroom, a sweep of Los Angeles stretching from downtown to the Pacific Ocean.

headline: At Rye High, Knicks’ Coach Is Just a Face in the Crowd
text: RYE, N.Y. — For the coach of the Knicks, the clamor of a high school gymnasium was a welcome diversion from the daily chorus of inquiry that comes with the territory. Here, there were no demands to explain away on-court misfortune or need to deal with the Carmelo Anthony distraction. Here, the responsibility of prepping the team for the next day’s must-win game was somebody else’s responsibility.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind’
text: This week, A. O. Scott explores the director Michel Gondry and the screenwriter Charlie Kaufman‘s film about the beginning and end of a relationship. Mr. Scott says that while most movies reduce love to a greeting card sentiment, “‘Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind’ treats it as a subject for extended philosophical inquiry.” He celebrates the film for being “cerebral, formally and conceptually complicated, dense with literary allusions and as unabashedly romantic as any movie you’ll ever see.”

headline: Near-Field Communication: Beyond Mobile Transactions
text: BARCELONA, Spain — Among the many buzz words — Androids, tablets, LTE — being tossed around the showroom floor here at the Mobile World Congress, there’s one that I still haven’t quite been able to wrap my head around.

headline: Expert Panel Is Critical of F.B.I. Work in Investigating Anthrax Letters
text: WASHINGTON  A review of the Federal Bureau of Investigation’s scientific work on the investigation of the anthrax letters of 2001 concludes that the bureau overstated the strength of genetic analysis linking the mailed anthrax to a supply kept by Bruce E. Ivins, the Army microbiologist whom the investigators blamed for the attacks.

headline: Pushing the Budget
text: Gov. Dannel P. Malloy of Connecticut spends a day promoting his budget ahead of his speech on the proposal, scheduled for Wednesday, Feb. 16.

headline: Connecticut Governor, Tackling Budget, Criticizes Christie’s Approach
text: HARTFORD  There is Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey: blustery and bellicose, hectoring the unions, enthralling fellow Republicans with his tax caps and spending cuts, already generating presidential murmurings after barely a year in office.

headline: Net Zero Energy, Transmuted Into Art
text: The relationship and, often as not, tension between hardheaded engineers and design-conscious architects is woven into the fabric of every great building.

headline: Clearing the Fog in Nursing Homes
text: The woman, who was in her 90s, had lived for several years at the Ecumen Sunrise nursing home in Two Harbors, Minn., where the staff had grown accustomed to her grimaces and wordless cries. She took a potent cocktail of three psychotropic drugs: Ativan for anxiety and the antipsychotic Risperdal to calm her, plus an antidepressant. In all the time she’d lived at Sunrise, she hadn’t spoken. It wasn’t clear whether she could recognize her children when they came to visit.

text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#880", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

headline: Burnett Reflects and Looks Ahead
text: TAMPA, Fla. – A. J. Burnett moved recently. Not far, just a few doors down in the Yankees’ clubhouse, to the corner locker on starters row once occupied by Andy Pettitte. The contrast was striking: where reliability dressed for more than a decade, volatility now hangs his designer T-shirts.

headline: Bloomberg Family Foundation to Support Arts
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s family foundation is planning to distribute $32 million in grants to arts organizations around New York City, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday. The announcement comes a year after the mayor ended a charitable program administered through the Carnegie Corporation of New York, which over a decade funneled $200 million of his personal fortune to arts and social-service groups around the city. (The Carnegie program was ostensibly supported by an anonymous donor, but that donor was widely known to be Mr. Bloomberg.)

headline: Bold Predictions: Always Enticing, Often Wrong
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

headline: When Mimi Met Duro
text: For newcomers like Mimi Plange, it is increasingly hard to stand out from the fashion fray. So a few days after showing her fourth collection, which is titled “Scarred Perfection” (a reference to African tribal scarification), Plange jumped at the chance to meet with Duro Olowu, the London- and New York-based designer who made a name for himself when his high-waisted “Duro dress” caught the eye of key editors in 2005, including T’s editor in chief, Sally Singer.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Alana Zimmer at Marc Jacobs
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York Fashion Week. Here, the model Alana Zimmer from Ford Models before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by François Nars for NARS and hair by Guido Palau for Redken. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: On the G-20 and a Leadership Void
text: The economist Nouriel Roubini and Ian Bremmer, president of the Eurasia Group, discuss what they perceive as a lack of global economic leadership, during an interview on CNBC.

headline: The Latest Museum Restaurant Will Be Untitled
text: Fitting its locale, the restaurant that Danny Meyer‘s Union Square Hospitality Group is to open next month in the lower level of the Whitney Museum of American Art will be called Untitled. The museum’s director, Adam Weinberg, came up with the name. Its chef will be Chris Bradley, who was the executive sous chef at Gramercy Tavern. It will serve breakfast and lunch on days when the museum is open, as well as dinner, with a set menu, on Saturdays and Sundays.

headline: Parents Without Parents
text: Allison Gilbert misses her parents. They both died before their grandchildren could remember them (her mother before her children were born, and her father when her oldest child was 18 months old) and every day she realizes anew that the loss was not hers alone, but also her son’s and her daughter’s. There is a hole in her parenting, she believes, where her own parents should be.

headline: Grabbing a Piece of the New York-German Deal
text: Putting together a merger as complicated as the deal between NYSE Euronext and Deutsche Börse — which are forming the world’s largest financial market for stocks and derivatives — is no easy task.

headline: Following Sloan, Corbin Seeks His Own Path
text: Talk about conflicting emotions. New Utah Jazz Coach Tyrone Corbin is happy to have his first N.B.A. head coaching gig, a great promotion after years of working hard. But the new position has come in the wake of his mentor and friend, Jerry Sloan, resigning Feb. 10 after leading the Jazz for 23 years.

headline: Kansas Is King for a Day

So there can be carnage and chaos in the rankings, No. 1s can fall like ducks in an arcade, unbeatable teams can be humbled and, in the end, they all still get to play it out.

headline: Now Sipping | A Cocktail Coco Would Have Liked
text: Fashion Week has helped inspire a new cocktail for ladies and dandies alike at Jimmy, the new rooftop bar at the James Hotel in SoHo. Chanel No 9 ($18), named after the venerable French fashion house, is a not-too-sweet blend of nine different floral and botanical liquors, including Chartreuse, St Germaine and Crème de Violette, topped with Champagne. “It’s not so different from a perfumer making a scent to mix these different liquors together,” said Johnny Swet, one of Jimmy’s owners. A Parisian melon baller is used to make tiny pearls of juicy strawberries (8 to 10 pearls per berry) that bounce up and down in the flute. Coco would approve.

headline: Anna Nicole, Jimi Hendrix and Handel in London

The company has clearly done a good marketing job. The opera’s tragic heroine is Anna Nicole Smith, the Playboy Playmate, model, actress and reality show host who died in 2007 from combined drug intoxication, according to forensics reports.

headline: The Sound of ‘Inception’
text: As the Bagger discovered last season, it’s almost impossible for even the Academy’s experts to predict who will win the Oscars for sound design and mixing. But over the weekend, the sound team from “Inception” won Baftas from the British Academy of Film and Television Arts , and the group — sound designer Richard King, recording mixer Ed Novick and re-recording mixer Gary Rizzo, along with his partner Lora Hirschberg — have been talked up all season long for their work on Christopher Nolan’s film, for which they are all nominated for Oscars. Creating a soundtrack for his multilevel dreamscape thriller involved technical and creative challenges born of multiple locations and complicated storytelling.

headline: Rodarte on the Prairie
text: The Mulleavy sisters of Rodarte, in their fall collection, picked up in much the same place as they left off in their hit spring collection. Some of the shapes, like high-waist pants with crisscross tops, and dresses with paneled overlays, were reprised here in new fabrics, embroideries, tablecloth lace and dotted prints that suggested they were looking again to the homespun corners of Americana for their ideas, and had settled somewhere in prairie life and the great migration to California in the 1930s.

headline: The $100 Paris Weekend
text: ONE Friday night last month, I stood watching a North African band called Daxar perform at the Satellit Café world music club in Paris and was considering having a beer. By the time the band had finished its Magrebian take on the Rolling Stones’ “Paint It Black” (“Do you know this one?” the band leader asked coyly. “It’s not ours.”), I had decided against it. Such luxury could cost me the Louvre on Sunday, or wine with lunch Saturday.

headline: Laurents-Hatcher Award Announced
text: The foundation of the Broadway director Arthur Laurents and his longtime partner, Tom Hatcher, announced on Tuesday that its first playwriting award, worth $150,000, would go to Jeff Talbott, a New York City actor who has branched out and will make his Off Broadway debut as a playwright next season. The award, which is to be given annually, provides $50,000 to the writer and $100,000 toward the production costs for mounting the recipient’s play. Mr. Talbott’s winning play, “The Submission,” described as an exploration of the importance of cultural authenticity in authorship, will be produced next season at MCC Theater, which is led by Robert LuPone, Bernard Telsey, and William Cantler. The Laurents/Hatcher Foundation Award is among the most generous in playwriting, and it is intended for emerging writers. Mr. Talbott, 46, has written only a few plays and, as a playwright, still lacks an agent. Mr. Laurents, the book writer for “Gypsy” and “West Side Story” and the Tony Award-winning director of the original “La Cage aux Folles,” created the award last year. At 93, he is still writing plays himself; Mr. Hatcher, his partner of 52 years, died in 2006.

headline: Pratt Institute Takes an Interest in Making a Neighborhood Nicer

But by the 1980s, the section of Myrtle that runs through the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Fort Greene and Clinton Hill had earned the nickname “Murder Avenue” for its high crime rate and derelict appearance.

They then apply their learning to their own communities or put them into historical context.

text: To help start their Brooklyn Heights restaurant, opening Thursday, the team developing Colonie used Kickstarter, the online system that lets entrepreneurs raise money through many small investors.

headline: The Swimsuit Cover? Runs in the Family
text: Last Friday afternoon, at Blue Ribbon Sushi on Sullivan Street in SoHo, two ebullient female editors of the Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue were seated at a table, about to order a lot of raw fish. With them was a 30-year-old photographer named Bjorn Iooss (that’s pronounced YOOOS). He was drinking a Sapporo, dressed in a stylish short-sleeved shirt with a tuxedo collar that was unbuttoned to his sternum. His curls, Grecian in their luster, fell like a mop around his chiseled face. Iooss says he likes to surf, and while he mostly does this in Montauk, N.Y., where he grew up, he somehow has a tan in February. He is exactly the kind of photographer around whom most models would automatically undress.

headline: Gore Vidal Political Play Returns
text: Are the Iowa presidential caucuses really less than a year away? How time flies. But an election year looms, as does the return of “Gore Vidal’s The Best Man,” the deliciously tart (when done well) play about politics, campaigns and the presidency. Jeffrey Richards and his fellow producers announced on Tuesday that they would revive that 1960 play in the spring of 2012 with hopes of catching election fever. Originally titled “The Best Man,” Mr. Vidal’s play involves a showdown at a presidential convention between two candidates, in essence an Adlai Stevenson character and a Richard Nixon type, brokered by an ill ex-president and complicated by secrets, machinations, and troubled marriages. Broadway had a revival of “The Best Man” not so long ago, during the campaign between George W. Bush and Al Gore and the subsequent legal battle in the fall of 2000. With political resonance and a cast led by Spalding Gray, Chris Noth, and Charles Durning, that production started off strong at the box office but had mixed reviews and declining ticket sales before closing in late December. (Mr. Gore had conceded two and a half weeks earlier.) That 2000 revival was the first Broadway producing credit for Mr. Richards, who has been a press agent since the 1970s and is now one of Broadway’s busiest producers. He is reuniting his producing team from 2000 — Jerry Frankel, Michael B. Rothfeld, and Darren Bagert — to mount this production. The director will be Michael Wilson (“The Orphans’ Home Cycle,” “Dividing the Estate”). No cast members have been announced.

headline: Bar Basque
text: THE codfish at Bar Basque is ethereal. It provides a taste of the North Atlantic that is as soft on the tongue as a cloud. The fish comes bathed in a gorgeous shellfish velouté that owes much to the Basque sauce known as pil-pil, an emulsion that uses olive oil to elevate the flavors of fish and garlic to lordly heights. Baby root vegetables sit around the plate as throw pillows might surround a feather bed.

headline: Chemistry and Showstoppers at the Oscars Ceremony
text: With the Academy Awards a mere 12 days away, details are beginning to leak out about the telecast – or rather, be meted out in a very methodical, public relations-managed way. The Oscar producers, Bruce Cohen and Don Mischer, told Entertainment Weekly that the early promos featuring the show’s hosts, James Franco and Anne Hathaway, were filmed on the first day they met, capturing their instant chemistry. “They really play very well off of each other,” Mr. Cohen told Mandi Bierly. “Anne is like this hilarious Type-A overachiever who will just try anything, and James can just kind of look at her, and it’s funny.” Both stars are pitching ideas to the writers, who include, as usual, the veteran joke-slinger Bruce Vilanch. (He’s already made some cracks about Ernest Borgnine in a “Black Swan” outfit.)

headline: ‘American Slavery Project’ Focuses on Black Playwrights

headline: Photographer David LaChapelle Sues Rihanna

Mr. LaChappelle, known for his candy-colored, sexually over-the-top images, claims in a suit filed Monday in federal court in Manhattan that Rihanna helped herself to too many of the images in the recently released video for her sexually over-the-top song “S & M.”

headline: Competing for the Cover of the Rolling Stone

But for the first time in its 44-year history, Rolling Stone editors are ceding to readers the final decision about what band to put on a forthcoming cover.

headline: Carter, Reagan and Freaky Times
text: The cultural politics of the 1970s is irresistible to historians, the way the decade’s dance music is irresistible to D.J.’s at weddings. Thus a book like Dominic Sandbrook’s “Mad as Hell: The Crisis of the 1970s and the Rise of the Populist Right” arrives in bookstores every six months or so. Nixon, Ford, Carter: there’s little greatness there, but these presidencies are so familiar that you can hum nostalgically, dismally along.

headline: For Cathleen Black, a First Test in Albany
text: ALBANY — One by one, school officials hunched over a microphone on Tuesday and appealed to lawmakers for relief from Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s proposed budget cuts. For many of them, the annual hearing was a familiar exercise, a wintertime rite marked by its tediousness more than anything else.

headline: France Presses Case of Woman in Mexican Prison
text: PARIS  Tensions between France and Mexico over the case of a Frenchwoman serving a 60-year prison sentence in Mexico City boiled over this week, complicating relations just as a symbolic yearlong celebration of friendship has gotten under way.

headline: When the Wave Hits Afghanistan
text: As reports of the riots in the Middle East continue to flood news outlets, I follow with a distance that is rather peculiar considering my history and interests. Having spent nearly seven months of my four years at West Point in Egypt and Tunisia, I hold a special place in my heart for the people of both countries. After all, they helped me learn their language, and thus gave me a conduit to understanding the depths of one of the world’s most misunderstood regions. And while a call for liberation is certainly worthy of praise, it’s difficult for me to feel proportionally excited for my friends in Egypt and Tunisia, because there is a third country close to my heart that few have considered in this equation: Afghanistan.

headline: Music Box Makes Its Bobby Fischer Move
text: It has been almost 40 years since Bobby Fischer won the world chess championship, and more than three years since he died. Now, thanks to a documentary that made its debut at the Sundance Film Festival last month, audiences who may not know the story of Fischer’s brilliant but disturbed life will get a chance to learn about it this summer and fall.

headline: The Ghost of Bill Blass
text: Mortimer’s glory years are long gone, and with them the hope of spying Gloria Vanderbilt or Anne Slater in her blue-tinted shades, seated at a window looking out on Lexington Avenue. But the passing of that fabled society haunt — it shuttered a dozen years ago — has not deterred young designers from drawing on its patrician charms. In Mortimer’s heyday, those charms were conferred by its patrons, and not less by their chum Bill Blass, who swathed his ladies in fox and the witty pinstripes and foulards that were the genteel uniforms of the Uptown set.

headline: Dangerous Visions, Seen Then Pursued
text: Do dreams, especially the portentous kind that you cannot easily shake off, predict the future? That question is investigated in “The Edge of Dreaming,” a deeply personal film by Amy Hardie, a Scottish science documentarian whose world was shaken after she experienced a series of related nightmares.

headline: Pennsylvania Employees Fired in Clinic Inquiry

Tom Corbett of Pennsylvania said Tuesday that several state workers had been fired and the state’s abortion clinics would be subjected to stricter oversight as a result of an investigation into a Philadelphia clinic where, according to the district attorney, a woman and seven newborn babies were killed in deplorable conditions.

headline: Rising Food Prices Push Millions Into Poverty, Study Says

And in a Bucks post on Friday, I noted that my better half and I did, in fact, plan to go out for dinner on Feb. 14, even though my column suggested that living (and eating) it up the night after Valentine’s Day might be a better bet.

text: Despite reports that it gives off hazardous porcelain dust and that there are traces of lead in the paint, one of the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei’s works “Sunflower Seeds’’ sold at Sotheby’s in London Tuesday evening for £349,250 ($559,394).

headline: Crazy Little Thing Called Love, in Some of Its Many Variations
text: The course of true love never does run smooth, as listeners at the New York Philharmonic’s Valentine’s Day concert were reminded during a lineup of songs about melancholic, suicidal and incestuous love.

headline: Bridges Can Still Exist in a Divided Land
text: Tariq Tapa’s debut feature, “Zero Bridge,” begins promisingly with a Kashmiri teenager being schooled in petty crime, a scene that’s reminiscent of the Chinese director Jia Zhang-ke’s “Unknown Pleasures” in its immediacy and bleak authenticity. The film loses momentum after that, handicapped by Mr. Tapa’s sometimes sketchy screenplay and the limitations of his nonprofessional cast. (His clumsy staging of their dialogue scenes doesn’t help.) But it remains a moving slice of life from a corner of the world usually seen only in news reports or as a mountainous backdrop for Bollywood musicals.

headline: House Members Offer Hundreds of Budget-Cutting Amendments
text: More than 400 times, members of the House of Representatives have proposed new and different ways to cut the federal budget, from dropping all efforts to block Arizona from enacting its new immigration law, to eliminating money for Planned Parenthood to saying to Department of Agriculture employees engaged in loans for marketing mohair — Sorry! No funds for you!

headline: Peltz Offers More Than $7 Billion for Family Dollar
text: The activist investor Nelson W. Peltz.

headline: The Edward I. Koch (Fill In Name of Landmark Here)
text: The bridge that links Manhattan to New Jersey bears the name of a former president, George Washington. The bridge that connects Manhattan, Queens and the Bronx carries the name of a former senator, Robert F. Kennedy. Two months ago, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said that he wanted to rename the Queensboro Bridge after another political figure, this time a quintessential New Yorker: the former mayor, Edward I. Koch.

headline: On the Scent of Psychopaths: Penetrating the Criminal Mind
text: Forest Whitaker, who played Idi Amin in the 2006 movie “The Last King of Scotland” so convincingly that he won an Oscar, has one of the most distinctive and off-kilter faces in Hollywood. So it says something about “Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior” that his wardrobe is so distracting that it almost overshadows his character.

headline: Tablets for Tots From Vtech and Leapfrog
text: Soon, it will be possible to hand your child their very own tablet computer, providing, of course, you can pry your smartphone out of their hands.

headline: TV Series Tries to Revive Civil Rights Cold Cases
text: The murder has never been solved: On Feb. 27, 1967, Wharlest Jackson, a father of five and the treasurer of the Natchez, Miss., branch of the N.A.A.C.P., was killed by a car bomb, making him just one of dozens of victims of racial violence during the civil rights era. To add an element of horror, Mr. Jackson’s 8-year-old son heard the explosion, bicycled to the scene and discovered his own father.

headline: For Cold Virus, Zinc May Edge Out Even Chicken Soup
text: Scientists still haven’t discovered a cure for the common cold, but researchers now say zinc may be the next best thing.

headline: An Oscar Turn for White House Decorator
text: What were we saying about the public relations Oscar drip? Oh, right. So this year the Academy Awards green room – sponsored for the ninth consecutive year by Architectural Digest – will be designed by Michael S. Smith, we’re now allowed to exclusively announce. Mr. Smith, who was chosen to help redecorate the White House, envisions the nominees and presenters lounging around in his “elegant, 1940s-style library — complete with a sophisticated color palette and furnishings that celebrate Hollywood’s golden era,” according to a statement from the magazine. Margaret Russell, the editor in chief, added that “though his design reflects midcentury Hollywood glamour, his interpretation of the space is state of the art.” Also, the space is officially called the Architectural Digest Oscar Greenroom, which is, we’re sure, how everyone will officially refer to it on the night of the show.

headline: Buzz Tracker
text: Don’t Sue Fabulous Fab: Lawyers for Fabrice Tourre, the Goldman Sachs trader accused of misleading investors on a mortgage investment, asked a judge to throw out the lawsuit filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission.BLOOMBERG »

headline: Knicks’ Stoudemire Ready for Rematch With Hawks
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Amar’e Stoudemire and Al Horford will be teammates Sunday at the All-Star Game in Los Angeles in a mostly friendly and largely ceremonially celebration.

headline: The Commercial War on Teacher Layoffs
text: When Cathleen P. Black, the schools chancellor, testified before the State Legislature on Tuesday about what she called the unavoidable teacher layoffs in New York City that would take place if the governor’s proposed education budget were approved, a line from her remarks might have rung familiar to regular watchers of television ads.

headline: Kerry Says U.S. Will Investigate Case of American Accused of Killing 2 Pakistanis
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Senator John Kerry, sent by the White House to win the release of an American official held in prison and accused of killing two Pakistanis, expressed remorse on Tuesday for the episode and pledged that the United States would conduct a criminal investigation once the official was returned.

headline: Lindsay Lohan to Read ‘Top 10’ on Letterman
text: One of David Letterman’s favorite subjects of jokes in recent monologues will now get a chance to deliver a few laughs on her own: Lindsay Lohan will appear on “Late Show with David Letterman” Thursday night to present that night’s Top-10 list.

headline: The Wristwatch Looks For a New Use
text: Last year while writing about students entering their first year of college I made an interesting observation: these newly commissioned freshmen don’t use wristwatches. In fact, the wristwatch is so alien to this group of late teens, that even the mere action of pointing to a wrist to ask someone the time is akin to speaking an unfamiliar foreign language. (They use mobile phones and laptops to tell the time.)

headline: Egypt Leaders Found ‘Off’ Switch for Internet
text: Epitaphs for the Mubarak government all note that the mobilizing power of the Internet was one of the Egyptian opposition’s most potent weapons. But quickly lost in the swirl of revolution was the government’s ferocious counterattack, a dark achievement that many had thought impossible in the age of global connectedness. In a span of minutes just after midnight on Jan. 28, a technologically advanced, densely wired country with more than 20 million people online was essentially severed from the global Internet.

headline: Planets Named for Banks, and Snobbish Robots
text: “Green” is a smart, evocative play title for the age we live in. But Chris Harcum’s “Green,” at the Metropolitan Playhouse in the East Village, has nothing to say about sustainable fuels or chemical-free foods or any aspect of environmentalism. Green is just a guy’s name.

headline: In-Laws Are Core Issue for This Adam and Eve
text: A satirical cartoon about an America increasingly enfeebled by its fear of anything outside the sanctioned norm, Lynn Rosen’s comedy “Apple Cove” is part eco-fable, part “Stepford Wives” riff, part cautionary tale for a hermetic society. This play is many things, just not as funny or clever as it should be.

headline: Air Products Bid Dies as Airgas Poison Pill Lives On
text: 7:02 p.m. | Updated

headline: A Playwright’s Fictions Stay Close to Real Life
text: CHICAGO  Midway through the second of the three “Trinity River Plays” at the Goodman Theater here, a small moment takes place that is hauntingly familiar to anyone with an elderly parent.

headline: 3 States Challenge Federal Policy on Storing Nuclear Waste
text: WASHINGTON  The attorneys general of New York, Connecticut and Vermont sued the Nuclear Regulatory Commission on Tuesday, challenging a new commission policy stating that nuclear waste can be safely stored at a nuclear power plant for 60 years after a reactor goes out of service.

headline: Secrets of a Mind-Gamer
text: How I trained my brain and became a world-class memory athlete.

headline: Laughter Lifts CBS in Ratings
text: CBS topped the ratings on Monday with new episodes of “Two and a Half Men,” starring Jon Cryer, above left, and Charlie Sheen, above right, and “Mike & Molly.” Those sitcoms delivered the largest audiences of the night, according to Nielsen’s estimates, with “Two and a Half Men” drawing 14.5 million viewers at 9 p.m. and “Mike & Molly” attracting 13.1 million at 9:30, a record for the series. CBS broadcast the premiere of its new comedy “Mad Love” (8.8 million viewers) at 8:30 p.m. after “How I Met Your Mother” (9.6 million). CBS’s “Hawaii Five-0” led the 10 p.m. time slot with 10.6 million viewers, outperforming ABC’s “Castle” (8.8 million) and “Harry’s Law” on NBC (8.5 million). ABC was second for the night, Fox was in third and NBC finished in fourth.

headline: 3-D Comes to Met Opera, but Without Those Undignified Glasses
text: Purveyors of entertainment, in the ever-urgent quest to grab audiences’ attention, have used 3-D imagery in movies and, more recently, television. Now it is coming to live theater.

headline: Another Day, Another Restaurant-Discount Web Site
text: Start-up restaurant-discount Web sites are becoming more numerous than those Chinese menus stuffed in New Yorkers’ mailboxes. Now comes DineTonite, which offers real-time reservations and discounts from 20 to 40 percent at nearly 30 restaurants. Most of them are neighborhood spots in Manhattan, and many are already moderately priced. The roster includes some of the Nino’s group of old-school Italian restaurants; the upscale Italian steakhouse Padre Figlio, and Nocello, the Tuscan standby near Carnegie Hall.

headline: Scientists See Success in Flu Vaccine Made by Faster Method
text: A flu vaccine made by a new, faster method works just as well as existing products, researchers reported Tuesday.

headline: Nonfiction: Print vs. E-Books
text: The 10 best-selling nonfiction titles and how their sales ranked in print — including both hardcover and paperback — and in E-book formats.

headline: Revisiting Escoffier: Grant Achatz’s New Restaurant, Next
text: A tryout dinner, painstakingly reproduced from the classical French repertoire, for the Chicago chef’s new restaurant.

headline: Little Marc Goes Long
text: Marc Jacobs did not apply the same degree of strictness to his Marc by Marc Jacobs collection (or Little Marc, as we like to call it) today as he did in his signature collection shown last night. But it did look more oriented toward grown-ups than usual, certainly with more tweedy pantsuits and long-sleeve silk dresses and less of the playful sportswear.

headline: At Westminster Dog Show, Familiar Breeds Get Little Respect
text: In the hours before a dog competes at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, tensions can mount as owners and handlers furiously prepare their canine divas for the ring. Hair is blown straight or teased into fanciful poufs. Snouts and paws are daubed with talcum powder. Wayward hairs and whiskers are trimmed with precision.

headline: Iona College Names a New President
text: Iona College, a Roman Catholic institution run by the Christian Brothers in New Rochelle, N.Y., has named the head of an Illinois children’s center as its next president.

headline: Chicago Is Now Smaller and Less Black, Census Shows
text: CHICAGO  As Chicagoans prepare to vote next week for their first new mayor in decades, the city itself looks different from how it did during much of the era of Mayor Richard M. Daley, who is retiring: it has shrunk, and black people in particular have left.

headline: Halston’s Disco Revival
text: The Halston collection for fall 2011, shown on Tuesday in an event space in Chelsea, wasn’t much different from the last couple of Halston collections by the designer Marios Schwab, nor, for that matter, from those shown by Halston himself in the 1970s. That’s not much of a surprise, as the company’s latest revival seems intent on sticking to the jersey dress formula.

headline: It’s Good to Know It’s Not All About Posing
text: Fashion is perversely and infinitely unfair. Both Marc Jacobs and Ralph Rucci possess know-how, no small thing in an era of disappearing hand arts and factories. Yet Mr. Jacobs is considered cool, and Mr. Rucci is not. And by offering his shows as conceptual and social experiences, Mr. Jacobs in a way acknowledges the breakup of traditional fashion over the last 20 years. Mr. Rucci continues to make elegant clothes.

headline: For Actresses, Is a Big Appetite Part of the Show?
text: MINKA KELLY, the “sexiest woman alive,” slides a fork into a tangle of spaghetti carbonara. Zoë Saldana has a basket of fried calamari. Jennifer Lawrence, an Oscar nominee for her leading role in “Winter’s Bone,” wants it known that a skimpy morning repast is not going to satisfy her.

headline: Sound Bites: Actresses on Their Love of Food
text: Actresses who have gushed to journalists about how much they love to chow down.

headline: A Cookie Paste Squeezed in the Middle of a Debate
text: EEKLO, Belgium

headline: From a Fashionista, a Candy That’s Loved in Brazil
text: For Brazilians, brigadeiro, a cross between fudge and a chocolate truffle, is an iconic sweet. Paula Barbosa (above), a fashion producer from Rio who moved to New York and who has been making brigadeiros since she was a teenager, started My Sweet Brigadeiro and makes them in a commercial kitchen in Lower Manhattan. Her lush candies come in several flavors: milk chocolate, white chocolate, coconut and pistachio. All can be ordered with toppings like chocolate sprinkles or coconut. Little brigadeiro cups and larger jars have the consistency of soft caramel (cue dulce de leche).

headline: Wild Blueberry Juice Offers a Sip of Summer
text: Sip some rich, intense Van Dyk’s Wild Blueberry Juice from Nova Scotia and instead of wintry gloom, think camping among the pines in August and berry picking near a meadow. You can enjoy it alone or over ice, without worrying about mosquitoes, but given its price, a little can do a lot to add dimension to afternoon tea, provide a base for a granité or sorbet and give new personality to that cosmo or martini. It has no sweeteners or other additives and is worth keeping on hand year-round.

headline: Off the Menu
text: OPENING

headline: Porsena
text: 21 East Seventh Street (Third Avenue), East Village; (212) 228-4923.

headline: Crackers With a Good New England Crunch
text: Taking the name to heart, the folks in Castleton, Vt., actually hand-crack the sheets of thin flatbread they make for their crackers. They have nailed the texture perfectly: sturdy enough for spreading and dipping, but flaky enough for nibbling like potato chips.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Tasting History

headline: A Skinny Clam That’s Big With Chefs
text: UNTIL recently, the long, narrow razor clam was easier to find on a beach than in a restaurant. Except in Asian places, it rarely made the cut.

headline: Razor Clam Ceviche
text: Time: 20 minutes plus 3 hours’ chilling

headline: Air Products Drops Its Bid for Air Gas
text: Air Products and Chemicals dropped its $5.9 billion hostile bid for Airgas Tuesday after a Delaware judge upheld Airgas’s main anti-takeover defense.

headline: I.M.F. Said to Have Harsh Assessment of Troubled Kabul Bank
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  An International Monetary Fund review of the Afghan government’s progress in determining what went wrong at the nation’s largest bank and the steps necessary to fix it has concluded that so little has been done so far that there is no possibility of renewing the fund’s program here, diplomats in Kabul said.

headline: Role for Teachers Is Seen in Solving Schools’ Crises
text: DENVER  Secretary of Education Arne Duncan, convening a two-day labor-management conference here on Tuesday, argued that teachers’ unions can help solve many of the challenges facing public schools.

headline: England Finds 2012 Olympics Don’t Spur Exercise
text: When London was awarded the 2012 Olympics, organizers promised an ambitious legacy: to get two million more people in England involved in sports and physical activity.

headline: A Crouching Yankee No More
text: TAMPA, Fla.

headline: The Perfect Menu. Now Change It.
text: CHICAGO

headline: Nourishing Family Roots to Help a Campaign Bloom
text: MANAGUA, Nicaragua  Among the portraits of Nicaragua’s most revered guerrilla hero, Augusto Sandino, in his trademark Stetson hat decorating a new exhibit in the central bank here is an unusual genealogical map linking him to another larger-than-life figure here: President Daniel Ortega.

headline: Riding the Clippers’ Roller Coaster
text: To say the Los Angeles Clippers have had an up-and-down season would be something of an understatement. First, the team lost 13 of its first 14 games and 21 of 26. Then the team got hot and won 14 of its next 21 games. The Clippers’ successful stretch included wins over the Bulls, Heat and Lakers, nine consecutive home wins, and a 47-point performance from All-Star rookie Blake Griffin. All of a sudden, the Clippers were a team on the rise. People even started talking about the possibility of the Clippers making the playoffs.

headline: WikiLeaks Allies Fight Order on Twitter Data
text: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — Lawyers for three Twitter users on Tuesday asked a judge to vacate an order requiring the social-networking Web site to turn over its account records to prosecutors who are investigating WikiLeaks for its role in disclosing secret government documents last year.

headline: Contador Is Cleared of Doping Charges and Will Return to Racing
text: The three-time Tour de France champion Alberto Contador, cleared on Tuesday by the Spanish cycling federation of doping charges from last summer’s Tour, called his exoneration bittersweet.

headline: For Egypt, a Fresh Start, With Cities
text: It would be easy to look at the images coming out of Cairo over the last few weeks and think of Egypt as a highly urbanized society. It would also be wrong.

headline: Red Bulls in Black … er Dark Blue
text: 12:34 p.m. | Updated  A Red Bulls spokesman pointed out Wednesday morning that although the picture of Tim Ream, right, the team used to promote its new away jersey appears to be black, it is actually dark blue. It is the team’s new away jersey, not a third jersey. Some old eyes are not what they used to be!

headline: Somalia: Government Forces Fire on Demonstrators, Killing 5
text: Witnesses and a local government official said that at least five people were killed and an additional 10 were wounded on Tuesday when government forces fired on a demonstration against the Shabab, a radical Islamist group that has taken over many parts of the country. It is not yet clear why the government forces, which are plagued by a lack of discipline, fired on the demonstrators, and the government did not issue a statement on the violence.

American Jews and Egypt
text: To the Editor:

headline: Iraqi Says He Made Up Tale of Biological Weapons Before War
text: WASHINGTON  The Iraqi defector whose claims that Saddam Hussein’s government had biological weapons became part of the Bush administration’s justification for the 2003 invasion of Iraq has admitted that he fabricated his story.

headline: For Mets to Move Ahead, Wilpons Must Step Back
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.

headline: Margaret K. McElderry, Children’s Book Publisher, Dies at 98
text: Margaret K. McElderry, a book editor who employed shrewd intuition, critical acumen and a nurturing way with authors to help shepherd children’s literature from a prewar cottage industry to today’s billion-dollar business, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 98.

headline: No Dice, No Money, No Cheating. Are You Sure This Is Monopoly?
text: You can still collect $200 when you pass “Go,” but not in piles of play money.

headline: Inflation Hits 4%, Double the Target, in Britain
text: LONDON  Inflation in Britain rose to 4 percent in January, the highest level in two years, after the government increased a sales tax and the price of oil rose.

headline: At the White House, Sports Have an Honored Place
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Knicks and Hawks Bracing for a Rematch
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Amar’e Stoudemire and Al Horford will be teammates Sunday at the All-Star Game in Los Angeles in a mostly friendly and largely ceremonial celebration.

headline: Legal Fees at Fannie Are Called Avoidable
text: WASHINGTON  When the government took over Fannie Mae, it could have voided the contracts that have since left taxpayers liable for more than $100 million in legal bills defending the mortgage company and its former executives, according to statements at a Congressional hearing on Tuesday.

headline: Antitrust Investigation of Google Digs Deep
text: Updated with statement from Google.

headline: Feeling Noirish
text: These days we tend to think of film noir  “The Big Sleep” and “Laura” top our list  as nothing less than masterpieces. But there was no such thing as film noir in the 1940s and early-1950s when the best of them first came out. Many of the classics of the category were, in fact, B films  lesser creations with a dark, brooding presence made at a time when movies were still filmed in black and white on actual 35 mm stock and not on the 1s and 0s of today’s digitally recorded movies.

headline: N.F.L. Labor Dispute: Words but No Talks
text: The N.F.L. on Tuesday defended the Carolina Panthers’ owner, Jerry Richardson, a critical figure in labor negotiations who has come under fire after a player said he spoke dismissively and condescendingly to Peyton Manning and Drew Brees during a recent negotiating session.

headline: From Prison, Madoff Says Banks ‘Had to Know’ of Fraud
text: BUTNER, N.C. — Bernard L. Madoff said he never thought the collapse of his Ponzi scheme would cause the sort of destruction that has befallen his family.

headline: 30 Steps to Better Government
text: Washington

headline: Dakota Hits Back at a Resident Who Claimed Bias
text: The Dakota, one of Manhattan’s most exclusive apartment buildings, has struck back at a former co-op board president who accused it of racial discrimination, releasing financial documents that suggested he did not have the resources to buy the apartment he was seeking.

headline: Bedouin Smugglers Abuse Africans Held for Ransom, Israel Group Says
text: TEL AVIV  About 1,000 African migrants trying to cross the Sinai Desert from Egypt into Israel have been systematically beaten, raped and held captive for ransom in the past year by the Bedouin smugglers they hired to help them make the journey, an Israeli advocacy organization said Tuesday.

headline: Ecuadoreans Plan to Pursue Chevron in Other Countries
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  Armed with a $9 billion ruling against Chevron in Ecuador but little chance of collecting it there, representatives for Ecuadorean villagers said Tuesday that they were looking at waging legal battles against the company in more than a dozen countries where it operates, hoping to force Chevron to pay.

headline: The Ashen Ruin
text: Washington, D.C., Feb. 16, 1861

headline: Why Aren’t G.M.O. Foods Labeled?
text: If you want to avoid sugar, aspartame, trans-fats, MSG, or just about anything else, you read the label. If you want to avoid G.M.O.’s — genetically modified organisms — you’re out of luck. They’re not listed. You could, until now, simply buy organic foods, which by law can’t contain more than 5 percent G.M.O.’s. Now, however, even that may not work.

headline: Defending Courts’ Budget, Top Judge Resists Cuomo
text: ALBANY  New York’s chief judge suggested on Tuesday that courts around the state might have to close if Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and the Legislature insist on cuts to the judicial system that match the broad budget limits the governor is imposing on executive agencies.

headline: What Do You Think About Genetically Engineered Food?
Worth a Bottle of Whiskey
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Hope and Protests
text: Iran’s autocrats have shown once again that they know absolutely no shame. Last week, they crowed about the ouster of Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and rushed to claim solidarity with the protestors in Tahrir Square.

headline: Google Praises Executive’s Role in Egypt Revolt
text: BARCELONA, Spain  Eric Schmidt, the chief executive of Google, said Tuesday that the company was “very proud” of Wael Ghonim, a Google executive who helped plan the protests that culminated in the resignation of President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt.

headline: Pacquiao, the Ringmaster, and His Traveling Circus
text: WASHINGTON  Late Monday afternoon, Manny Pacquiao and company, lots and lots of company, boarded Acela Express No. 2165 in the belly of Pennsylvania Station. Pacquiao entered his private car (cost: $10,000) flanked by two documentary film crews, promoters, publicists, advisers, his chief of staff and his wife, Jinkee.

headline: Protests Build in Bahrain
text: Thousands of demonstrators rallied in Bahrain’s symbolic center, Pearl Square, and mourners buried a protester who was killed on Monday.

headline: Cuomo’s Deep Reach Into Regulatory Territory Could Provoke Clash in Albany
text: ALBANY  When Andrew M. Cuomo was sworn in as New York’s chief executive six weeks ago, he took control of a multibillion-dollar budget, tens of thousands of state workers and hundreds of agencies.

headline: The Skirmish Over High-Risk Pools
text: As part of the new health care reform, the federal government and 27 state governments are establishing temporary high-risk pools to offer coverage for people with pre-existing conditions until the law takes full effect in 2014. The effort has gotten off to a slow start, and Republican critics have, predictably, seized on that as “proof” that the government will be incapable of managing the much more complex changes lying ahead.

headline: Obama, Conceding Budget’s Limitations, Seeks Consensus
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama conceded on Tuesday that his new budget does not do enough to resolve the nation’s long-term fiscal problems, but he counseled patience, suggesting that he would eventually come together with Republicans on a broad deal.

headline: Europe Finance Chiefs Delay Decision on Increasing Bailout Fund
text: BRUSSELS  European finance ministers want their permanent rescue fund to be able to lend more money to struggling countries, but held off Tuesday from making any formal decisions.

headline: Decentralizing the Internet So Big Brother Can’t Find You
text: On Tuesday afternoon, as Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton spoke in Washington about the Internet and human liberty, a Columbia law professor in Manhattan, Eben Moglen, was putting together a shopping list to rebuild the Internet  this time, without governments and big companies able to watch every twitch of our fingers.

headline: Lottery Numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut
A Conversation With Edward L. Glaeser
text: Edward L. Glaeser is a professor of economics at Harvard and a weekly contributor to this blog. I mention his new book, “Triumph of the City,” in my column this week about Egypt. The current issue of The Atlantic includes a version of his chapter on skyscrapers, and The Economist and The New York Times have reviewed the book. The Times Magazine profiled Mr. Glaeser in 2006. Our conversation follows.

headline: Watson Dominates ‘Jeopardy’ but Stumbles Over Geography
text: The brilliant IBM supercomputer may need a refresher course on United States geography.

headline: Lawsuit Says Military Is Rife With Sexual Abuse
text: WASHINGTON  A federal lawsuit filed Tuesday accuses the Department of Defense of allowing a military culture that fails to prevent rape and sexual assault, and of mishandling cases that were brought to its attention, thus violating the plaintiffs’ constitutional rights.

headline: 49 Suggestions for Cutting Billions in State’s Medicaid Costs
text: Personal shopping and cleaning services for the disabled would be eliminated, weak hospitals could be merged and brand-name drugs would be limited under a series of budget-cutting proposals announced on Tuesday by the New York State Health Department.

headline: Scorecard | Theyskens’ Theory Wins!
text: PVC pencil skirts, disco paillettes, George Condo portraiture, Edwardian collars, latex, spots and dots: these are just a few of the indications that on the fifth day of New York fashion week, he-who-rarely-misses-the-Marc was in in fine pastiching form. Yet as much as it pains Scorecard to say it, critical consensus was to support fashion’s erstwhile enfant terrible Olivier Theyskens’s new Theory that when it comes to a lot of look, less meta is more.

headline: U.S. Follows Two Paths on Unrest in Iran and Bahrain
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has responded quite differently to two embattled governments that have beaten protesters and blocked the Internet in recent days to fend off the kind of popular revolt that brought down Egypt’s government.

headline: Madoff Says Banks ‘Had to Know’ of Fraud
text: Bernard L. Madoff said he never thought the collapse of his enormous Ponzi scheme would cause the sort of destruction that has befallen his family, Diana B. Henriques reports in The New York Times.

headline: Mets Give Isringhausen Another Last Chance
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The bullpen mound on the minor league side of the Mets’ facility holds a featured spot on the wall of Jason Isringhausen’s parents’ home in Brighton, Ill. It is the scene for a treasured photograph of their son and Tom Seaver chatting after a workout in spring training, 1999, Isringhausen’s last as a Met.

headline: Dangerous Threats
text: Representative Denny Rehberg, a Republican and Montana’s House member, boasts that he brings Made-in-Montana solutions to Washington. His latest, proposed last week in a speech advocating states’ rights to the State Legislature, is to put a judge “on the Endangered Species List.”

headline: Wednesday: Parliament Residue
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Are you feeling lucky today? You should. Michael Barnhart tosses five “twenty ones” at us, each of a different kind. Maybe today is a good day to hit that casino you’ve been thinking of visiting.

headline: Montana: $9.4 Million to Protect Flathead River
text: Efforts to protect the Flathead River, which flows down from Canada in a wild region of the northern Rockies, got a boost Tuesday with a commitment of private conservation money to stave off mining development. Wildlife use the Flathead River basin as a corridor of migration, making it an anchor of a 10-million-acre swath of wilderness in Montana and Canada called the Crown of the Continent. The Nature Conservancy and Nature Conservancy Canada committed $9.4 million, which would be paid to lease holders of gold and coal claims in British Columbia pending completion of the deal. KIRK JOHNSON

headline: Ways to Avoid Obesity
text: To the Editor:

headline: German-American Ponders U.S. Team
text: Some members of the United States military who at one time were based in Germany are turning into inadvertent benefactors of the United States men’s national team.

headline: Sheriff Wants a Big Jail in New Orleans, but City Balks
text: NEW ORLEANS  Even in the context of Louisiana, which has the highest incarceration rate in the United States, which in turn has the highest incarceration rate in the world, the numbers stand out. This city, by any measure, puts a lot of people in jail.

headline: Justice Dept. Will Review Fatal Shooting of Pace Student by Officer in Westchester
text: The Justice Department said Tuesday that federal prosecutors in Manhattan would review “all of the available evidence” to determine whether civil rights laws had been violated when a police officer shot and killed a 20-year-old college football player outside a bar last fall in Thornwood, N.Y.

headline: What Does a Cheeseburger Mean?
text: I have a confession to make. I, too, have done the DIPE.

headline: Expense Account Questions at Abortion-Rights Group

headline: Pharaoh Without a Mummy

headline: Joanne Siegel, the Model for Lois Lane, Dies at 93
text: Joanne Siegel, who as a Cleveland teenager during the Depression hired herself out as a model to an aspiring comic book artist, Joe Shuster, and thus became the first physical incarnation of Lois Lane, Superman’s love interest, died on Saturday in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 93.

headline: Narciso Rodriguez: Not Trying to Be Groovy
text: The music for Narciso Rodriguez’s show on Tuesday night was throbbing, layered, with a kinky voiceover breaking into the beat. I was compelled to listen, just as I was interested at all times in the clothes. This was a terrific collection, different than what he has done in several years. It was looser, more abstract, with a downbeat attitude that felt true and fresh, and masculine elements that worked so smoothly into the collection that you didn’t really notice them at first.

headline: Yankees’ A. J. Burnett Knows Pressure Is On
text: TAMPA, Fla.  A. J. Burnett recently moved. Not far, just a few doors down starters row in the Yankees’ clubhouse, to the corner locker once occupied by Andy Pettitte. The contrast was striking. Where reliability dressed for several years, volatility now hangs his designer T-shirts.

headline: Israel: Four Foreign Missions Closed
text: Israel temporarily closed four of its diplomatic missions abroad in recent days because of suspicions that they were under threat of attack, an Israeli official said on Tuesday. He refused to specify their locations, for security reasons, but he said that two had partially reopened. The precautions were taken after “unusual occurrences were identified recently around a few missions abroad,” the Israeli government said in a statement. The Israeli Counter-Terrorism Bureau had issued a travel advisory on Friday warning of a heightened threat against Israeli and Jewish targets abroad because of anniversaries this week of the deaths of two senior Hezbollah figures. It listed Egypt, Turkey, Georgia, Armenia, Ivory Coast, Mali, Mauritania and Venezuela as countries with a heightened risk. Imad Mugniyah, a Hezbollah commander, was killed by a bomb in Damascus in February 2008, and Hezbollah blamed Israel for his death. Sheik Abbas Musawi, a leader of Hezbollah, was killed by Israeli forces in February 1992.

headline: Russia: 10 Die in North Caucasus Clashes
text: At least 10 people died Tuesday in clashes between the police and militants in the Russian North Caucasus. The police in Chechnya said that they surrounded a house where two militants were hiding, and that one of the fighters set off an explosion that killed both of them. Meanwhile, three police officers and five militants died during a shootout on the border between the regions of Karachayevo-Cherkesiya and Stavropol. The news comes a day after two suicide bombers blew themselves up in front of police stations in Dagestan, killing three and injuring 26. The two bombers, who police said they believed were a married couple, had been sought in connection with a botched suicide bombing planned for New Year’s Eve in central Moscow.

headline: A College That’s Pleased With Its Drop in Applicants
text: In an era in which universities are expected to draw more and more applicants each year  as if they were Fortune 500 companies being forced to show annual profits  Ursinus College, a liberal arts institution outside Philadelphia, would seem to have little reason to celebrate.

headline: Notes From the Underground | Amber Martin
text: Last week, the multitalented Amber Martin wrapped up a four-week run of her latest show, “Amber Alert,” in front of a sold-out house at the Wild Project in the East Village. Martin seamlessly floated between multiple costumes, personae and skits, never once leaving the stage, and carrying the calm of a seasoned performer through comedic routines, duets and classic vocal covers. Martin’s first such transformation was from “Daydra,” a walking trailer-trash disaster complete with raspy smoker’s voice and greasy mullet, into the very vision of a solo diva, in a floor-length gown and heels, launching into a pitch-perfect rendition of Dionne Warwick’s first hit, “Don’t Make Me Over.” Guest performers included the Scissor Sisters frontman Jake Shears, the hysterical Bridget Everett and the gender-bending guitarist NathAnn Carerra, with whom Martin performed a very curious duet.

headline: What ‘Urban Legends’ Are There About Places in Your Area?
text: According to About.com, an urban legend is “an apocryphal, secondhand story, told as true and just plausible enough to be believed, about some horrific, embarrassing, ironic or exasperating series of events that supposedly happened to a real person.” This Times story, about a “cursed” mansion in Hollywood, is one example. What urban legends are there about houses, parks, stores or other places in your area? Even if you can’t think of any, what places near you have you always been curious about? Why?

Now in its 48th year, France’s largest agricultural event is part fair, part trade show, part blue-ribbon tournament. A dizzyingly diverse array of activities will be on offer, from a sheep-herding competition to performances of traditional music and dance to gardening workshops.

headline: Staying Connected Overseas (Cheaply)
text: I do a modest amount of international business travel, including Asia. I pretty much always have multiple projects in various stages of production, which typically means I can’t afford to be out of touch for much more than a few hours. (Also, I want to be available for family emergencies, like the time the TV went on the fritz.) I’ve put a lot of effort into figuring out tricks for being reachable by phone and e-mail without spending a fortune. Trust me, it’s easy to run up a thousand-dollar bill on your cellphone in a single trip if you don’t know the ins and outs. And not being in touch at all can be even more costly. Here are some of the lessons I’ve learned:

headline: A Bohemian Marriage for the Met and Juilliard
text: For any savvy operagoer, an evening spent with “The Bartered Bride,” a rustic comedy by Smetana more widely known about than actually seen, is an evening spent waiting for the other shoe to drop. Introduced in 1866 and completed in 1870, this romantic frolic is built on a plot twist predictable from miles away, a triumph of true love over cynical calculation. The ending is never in doubt, yet the opera remains irresistible for its charming characters and lively pace, and, above all, for its rich, colorful score: part bubbly operetta, part Bohemian folk pageant.

headline: The Short Timeline in the Borders Bankruptcy

It seems to me that this is not so much about e-books as competition with a lower priced rival.

headline: Save on Your Next Trip With Local Deal Sites
text: I LIKE a good deal as much as anyone. So when daily deal sites like Groupon.com and LivingSocial.com, which negotiate major discounts from local businesses and distribute them via e-mail to those who sign up, became all the rage, I quickly signed up for as many as I could find. But I wanted to go beyond the “local” concept and search for travel bargains in other cities — a $129 surf lesson for $49 in Dana Point, Calif.; a $165 guided rock-climbing adventure near Denver for $55; a $159 dinner cruise for $90 in Chicago.

headline: Onstage, Only His Guitar Gently Weeps
text: At 58, Mark Vaccacio is the oldest of the four men in the band, but in his mop-top wig, dark glasses and pointy boots, he is also the most boyish. For he is by far the thinnest, swaying in his black suit as if he were an extension of the cord plugged into his vintage guitar. Mr. Vaccacio is the same weight as the young George Harrison he plays onstage, but not out of a sense of authenticity  all of his beloved Irish-bar cheeseburgers and onion rings and milkshakes do not add any pounds.

headline: Skiing Your Way to ‘Hedonistic Sustainability’
text: If you’re itching to visit the new advanced waste management plant that will open in 2016 in Copenhagen, be sure to bring your skis. An urban ski park will cover the plant, which will incinerate the waste from five municipalities to generate heat and electricity for 140,000 homes. While their trash is burning inside, locals will be able to take an elevator to the top of the building, then ski down one of three different slopes, graded by difficulty, that jointly run about 5,000 feet.

headline: A Sweet Show, With Blasphemy and Cussing
text: NOT long into Act I of “The Book of Mormon,” a new Broadway musical comedy written and composed by Trey Parker, Matt Stone and Robert Lopez, two young Mormon missionaries arrive in Uganda after an arduous journey from Salt Lake City, during which they have suffered a cramped flight and the theft of their luggage.

headline: Holy Terrors: A Conversation With the Creators of ‘The Book of Mormon’
text: What happens when you put Trey Parker and Matt Stone, the unrepentant provocateurs behind Comedy Central’s animated series “South Park,” together with Robert Lopez, who tarnished sacred childhood memories as a co-creator of the Tony-winning puppet musical “Avenue Q”? At the very least, you get “The Book of Mormon,” their new musical comedy — nearly eight years in the making — about a pair of young Mormon missionaries whose sunny dispositions and understandings of their faith are seriously challenged when they are dispatched to remote Uganda.

headline: Style Setters | Van Cleef & Arpels at the Cooper-Hewitt
text: In the late 1930s, the Duchess of Windsor proposed a fashionably novel and, for the time, technologically complex idea to Van Cleef & Arpels: make her a piece of jewelry that zips. More than a decade later, the duchess got her wish. “The necklace that resulted was really a kind of partnership,” says Sarah Coffin, the curator of the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum. “This wasn’t just a little brooch,” she says, noting the necklace’s intricacy and the intervening war, which brought French jewelry production to a near standstill. This piece and many other diamond-encrusted feats of ingenuity will be on display at the Cooper-Hewitt from Feb. 18 to June 5 as part of “Set in Style: The Jewelry of Van Cleef & Arpels.”

headline: CERV: A New Kind of Army Green
text: Just beyond the stands of mainstream manufacturers during last week’s Chicago auto show press previews, stood an unusual, rugged-looking vehicle. Though its crude appearance might suggest otherwise, the Clandestine Extended Range Vehicle, or CERV, is an all-wheel-drive diesel hybrid that $14 billion in federal financing for dual-use advanced technology helped to build.

headline: To Ecuador, With Sea Turtles in Mind
text: Lekelia D. Jenkins, a postdoctoral researcher at the University of Washington, writes from Ecuador, where she is studying factors in the cross-cultural adoption of marine conservation technologies like turtle excluder devices and circle hooks. She co-leads this project with Patrick Christie, who is an environmental sociologist and Associate Professor at the University of Washington.

headline: Go Hands-Free, or Risk Points on Your License
text: Drivers, put down your phones, for the good of your licenses. Starting today, a ticket in New York State for talking on a cellphone while driving will cost you two points, in addition to the $100 it has cost since 2001, way back when New York became the first state in the nation to ban hand-held phone use while driving.

headline: Louise Goldin Takes Manhattan
text: Louise Goldin, one of the bright young things of English design, chose to unveil her collection in New York this time round. “It’s because of my engagement,” says Goldin, 28, flashing her sparkling ring finger. “It’s always because of a guy.” Not that her work is taking a second seat to her man — today she leaves for Los Angeles to dress Rihanna for her birthday bash and then it’s back to London. It’s easy to imagine Rihanna loving the designer’s metal hardware leather and suede lace-up booties (Manolo Blahnik teamed up with her this season), cashmere knit body-con dresses and sweaters (inspired by South African murals). There is also a punky quilted leather skirt and a jacket lined with fox fur and embossed with a leather tribal print that is a nice addition to Goldin’s usual all-knit collections.

headline: ‘Best in Show II’ — This Time It’s for Real
text: Fred R. Conrad has been shooting for The Times for 34 years. There’s little he hasn’t experienced. When he set out to photograph the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show this week, he knew his dog portraits would have to be taken quickly and that he might have trouble with some of his subjects — or their handlers.

headline: The A, B, C’s of Limiting Climate Risk
text: There appears to be a breath of fresh air wafting through the environmental community, reflected in Degrees of Risk: Defining a Risk Management Framework for Climate Security, a new report from the Britain-based nonprofit group Third Generation Environmentalism, or E3G. The report is enthusiastically endorsed by Bill Becker, the head of the Presidential Climate Action Plan, in a guest post at Climateprogress.

headline: Snapshot of One College’s Admissions Process
text: The segment linked above, which was broadcast this morning on NBC’s “Today” show, takes viewers behind the closed doors of the admissions process at Grinnell College in Iowa. Grinnell, which has received nearly 3,000 applications for an incoming freshman class of about 400, follows an intensive, holistic process similar to those used at dozens of other selective (and in some cases fiercely competitive) colleges, both public and private.

headline: Make Art, Get Art in Return at Tribeca Film Festival
text: 2:22 p.m. | Updated

headline: Joking, to a Point, About a Property Tax Cap
text: ALBANY — Unable to afford shoulder pads, the members of the high school football team swaddle themselves with pillows before taking the field. Emergency dispatchers have been replaced by an automated system to save money. After teacher layoffs, school principals are calling for volunteers to teach basic subjects.

headline: Irrational Design, a San Francisco Start-Up, Tries to Fly Solo
text: Last April, Jared Cosulich and Adam Abrons founded Irrational Design, a technology company, in San Francisco. Since its debut, the start-up has introduced three online commercial products. The founders, who met while working at a software engineering company, Pivotal Labs, are determined to build a business that is free to take risks.

headline: Google Announces Payment System for Digital Content
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A day after Apple stirred up online publishers by announcing a digital subscription plan that some called too restrictive and financially burdensome, Google on Wednesday announced its own payment service for digital content that aims to be more publisher-friendly.

headline: Backstage Beauty | Narciso Rodriguez
text: “We’ve never done anything like this at Narciso,” the hairstylist Eugene Soulemain said backstage at the Narciso Rodriguez show. “I scared the life out of him.” The style, a simple and somewhat haphazard knot just above the nape of the neck, was roughed up further with the addition of a few pats of Wella Professionals Texture Touch pressed in near the hairline, followed by a few spritzes of Wella Professionals Shimmer Delight “to make it look like she’s been running and sweating.” Soulemain said the edgier cast of models, which included Jamie Bochert (who had never walked for Rodriguez), inspired the look. “Even though the clothes are incredibly expensive, not everything’s pretty and so fitted,” Soulemain explained. “It’s not a red-carpet feeling.” Clearly, Rodriguez was convinced, seeing as he rang the manicurist Deborah Lippmann at 3 p.m. yesterday with some color direction. “He said, ‘I want a color that’s not charcoal and not blue and not black, but strong’ — they wanted to have some strength and toughness,” Lippmann said. (The gray she created will be named by Rodriguez and produced later this year.) The makeup artist Dick Page lined eyes with Shiseido cream shadows in Purple Dawn and Caviar, a black (available this fall). “I’m trying to leave the skin alone as much as possible. Since we’re at the beginning of the season, there are no big skin disasters yet,” Page said, joking that his own disaster — a black eye he acquired last week — inspired the look. One skin care product even made it onto models’ faces: Shiseido Benefiance Full Correction Lip Treatment, which was smudged onto the lids just before the show to create a melty effect. “It’s a ridiculously expensive lip balm,” Page said (it’s $36). What, you expected the Narciso woman to use Carmex?

headline: Becoming My Grandmother
text: There is a moment when the lens shifts, and you see life through the eyes of the person you are becoming rather than the person you have been. “I am becoming my mother,” we say, and sometimes we are joking, but sometimes we have learned something deep.

headline: Moon Walk | Bernardo
text: Certain shoes have the aesthetic legs to stand the test of time. Consider the Bernardo sandal, that 1960s staple of Euro-hippiedom favored by Jane Birkin, fashion’s perennial boho. Dennis Comeau, president of Bernardo Vintage Couture, is realigning the brand for this century. ‘‘The difference with Bernardo is that you can put on a pair of sandals made in 1967 and look completely 2011,’’ Comeau says. Several classic styles are being reissued this month at Bergdorf Goodman. There’s a navy Bandeau platform, a chocolate Moon disc flat (updated from the original pink and priced at $225) and a jeweled thong called the Goldfinger.

headline: Jeff Wilpon Reiterates Family Won’t Sell Mets
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Jeff Wilpon, the Mets’ chief operating officer, spoke to reporters Wednesday for the first time since a lawsuit seeking as much as $1 billion from the team’s owners was unsealed on Feb. 4.

headline: A Heavy Chamberlain, a Reticent Cashman
text: 1:15 p.m. | Updated  Chamberlain said he felt “awesome” and that he was in better shape than last season.After answering a few questions about his weight, he called it a “dead issue” and said he wouldn’t speak about it again.

headline: Living Without Discretionary Fiscal Policy
text: Alex Tabarrok makes an interesting point: recent experience seems to suggest that Keynesian policies, even if appropriate, turn out not to be politically feasible when you need them. I don’t think we need to take that as an immutable fact of life; but still, what are the alternatives?

headline: Winners and Losers in the Airgas Poison Pill Case
text: The Air Products and Chemical’s hostile pursuit of Airgas ended with a legal whimper.

headline: A Lohan Booking Miscue for Letterman
text: It turns out that Lindsay Lohan won’t be reading David Letterman’s “Top 10″ list on Thursday night, after all.

headline: Feingold Forms Political Group to Combat Corporate Influence
text: Russ Feingold, the former Democratic senator from Wisconsin who lost his bid for re-election in November, has formed a new political organization aimed at countering the impact of corporate money in politics.

headline: Can You Start a Tech Company Without Venture Capital?
text: We just published a case study that highlights the challenges confronting Irrational Design, a tech start-up that is determined to bootstrap. Founded in April by Jared Cosulich and Adam Abrons, the company has introduced three products: a dating Web site, an application that serves as an online suggestion box for businesses and a goal-sharing message board.

headline: Budget Politics
text: David Brooks: Gail, over the past few days I’ve had a series of conversations with people in both parties about the budget. It’s like traveling to two different countries.

headline: Borders to Close 3 of 8 Stores in New York City
text: The giant bookstores that ate the smaller bookstores are not fit enough to survive, it turns out. And readers in Manhattan are going to feel it.

headline: Signs of Spring on Governors Island
text: Between seasons in an urban wild place.

headline: New Directors/New Films Series Sets Lineup
text: J. C. Chandor’s directorial debut, “Margin Call,” a feature that takes place over the course of 24 hours on the trading floor of an investment bank, will be the opening night feature of the 40th annual New Directors/New Films series, the Museum of Modern Art and the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Wednesday. “Margin Call,” one of 28 films that will be presented during the series, features a cast that includes Kevin Spacey, Paul Bettany, Zachary Quinto, Demi Moore, Stanley Tucci and Jeremy Irons, and chronicles “a day that brings layer upon layer of human and professional wrongdoing that jeopardizes the entire fabric of the banking system,” according to a statement from MoMA and the Film Society. The closing night film of the series, which runs from March 23 through April 3, will be Maryam Keshavarz’s “Circumstance,” about two Iranian women who begin to step outside the boundaries of their oppressive lives, and which won the Audience Award at this year’s Sundance Film Festival.

headline: Heidfeld Replaces Kubica at Lotus
text: The Lotus Renault GP team announced Wednesday that Nick Heidfeld would replace Robert Kubica to drive for the team this year, after the Polish driver injured himself in a rally accident.

text: The Lotus Renault GP team announced Wednesday that Nick Heidfeld would replace Robert Kubica to drive for the team this year, after the Polish driver injured himself in a rally accident.

text: When Brooklyn prosecutors vacated his murder conviction last year, granting him freedom after 16 years behind bars, Jabbar Collins was naturally elated.

headline: After Menu Labels, Parents and Kids Order Same Foods
text: Most parents and older children notice calorie counts posted in New York City fast-food restaurants, but the information doesn’t stop them from ordering their favorite burgers and fries, new research shows.

headline: New York City Can Buy More Watershed Land, State Says
text: New York City can continue to buy land to protect its watershed in the Catskills and Hudson River Valley from development under an agreement announced on Wednesday by the city and state.

headline: Life at the Dakota
text: To New Yorkers, there are few apartments more legendary than the Dakota, at the corner of 72nd Street and Central Park West. Most of us know that we could never hope to live there, assuming we did not win the state lottery a few times. But I had no idea just how expensive it was.
