text: The Metropolitan Opera, announcing next season’s program, said on Wednesday that it would mount its first production of Donizetti’s “Anna Bolena,” with Anna Netrebko portraying Henry VIII’s second — and headed for beheading — wife.

headline: Pujols and Cardinals Call Off Talks
text: JUPITER, Fla.  In explaining how the St. Louis Cardinals have reached the end of negotiations to extend the contract of Albert Pujols, the team’s owner, Bill DeWitt Jr., really did not have to utter much more than one short declarative sentence.

headline: The Illusory Importance of Starting
text: For N.B.A. players, being in the starting lineup is viewed as a broadcast of their worth as a player. That makes sense to a degree, but one has to wonder if the act of starting – of exchanging high-fives and half-hugs with teammates and opposing players while Van Halen or House of Pain blares over the loudspeakers – is often mistaken in importance for all that comes with it.

headline: Adopting a Look, No Boys Allowed
text: BACK in the dark ages of my misspent youth, the cost of used clothing was always inversely proportional to the difficulty of finding it. Dumpster diving, though the least expensive, was the biggest long shot, and potentially the most nauseating and dangerous experience. Next came straight thrift  i.e., any rummage store named for a Catholic saint or the Salvation Army (a k a Sal’s).

headline: N.Y.U. Fellow Resigns After Tweeting About Lara Logan

headline: CNN Is Back to Covering Fashion

headline: A Scent to Match the Socialite
text: PAMELA GROSS was the last guest to arrive for lunch at the Palm Court of the Plaza Hotel on a recent Tuesday. She was 20 minutes late, actually.

headline: MoMA PS1’s Young Architects Program Announces Winner
text: Interboro Partners, a nine-year-old New York architecture firm, has won the annual Young Architects Program competition to transform MoMA P.S. 1’s courtyard for its summer outdoor music program, the museum announced Wednesday. The architects took their inspiration from the community around the museum, which is located in Long Island City, Queens, interviewing the proprietors of local businesses and nonprofits about what materials might be of use to them and then incorporating those materials into their design, with the intention of donating them at the end of the summer.

headline: Ecuadorean Villagers May Hold Secret to Longevity
text: People living in remote villages in Ecuador have a mutation that some biologists say may throw light on human longevity and ways to increase it.

headline: Koch Says Let the Bridge Debate Play Out
text: A city councilman’s opposition to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan to rename the Queensboro Bridge after former Mayor Edward I. Koch might have gone unnoticed by Mr. Koch, who left Buenos Aires last week on a 16-day luxury cruise across the southern Atlantic.

headline: House Votes to End Alternate Jet Engine Program
text: In a sign that more than half the Republican freshmen are willing to cut military spending, the House voted 233 to 198 on Wednesday to cancel an alternate fighter jet engine that the Bush and Obama administrations had tried to kill for the last five years.

headline: Buzz Tracker
text: Rage Against the Money Machine Matt Taibbi is frustrated and angry at the lack of prosecutions stemming from the financial crisis: “The mental stumbling block, for most Americans, is that financial crimes don’t feel real; you don’t see the culprits waving guns in liquor stores or dragging coeds into bushes. But these frauds are worse than common robberies. They’re crimes of intellectual choice, made by people who are already rich and who have every conceivable social advantage, acting on a simple, cynical calculation: Let’s steal whatever we can, then dare the victims to find the juice to reclaim their money through a captive bureaucracy.” Rolling Stone

headline: How Green Is My School? Conducting an Energy Audit
text: Overview | How can new buildings be designed in ways that minimize their energy use? How can energy be used more efficiently in existing buildings? In this lesson, students learn about green building design, perform energy audits of their schools and then develop proposals for making their schools more energy efficient.

text: KABUL, Afghanistan — People of Afghanistan are very religious, but nowadays a lot of them are afraid of their own mosques and religious leaders.

headline: A Political Divide Over the Inquiry of the Financial Crisis
text: WASHINGTON  The government inquiry into the causes of the 2008 financial crisis was the focus of intense partisan bickering on Wednesday at a House hearing. Republicans called the final 545-page report a political exercise whose findings were mostly inevitable, while Democrats defended its main conclusion: that Wall Street risk-taking and regulatory negligence combined to produce an avoidable disaster.

headline: The Fed’s G.D.P. Forecast, in Context
text: Minutes from the Federal Reserve’s Federal Open Market Committee meeting released today revealed a somewhat more upbeat set of monetary policy makers, with a forecast for output growth of 3.4 to 3.9 percent this year. That’s slightly higher than their last projection of 3 to 3.6 percent, released in November.

headline: Medicare And Medicaid Are Big
text: Update: People: this isn’t my chart, it’s the government’s, as you would see if you clicked on the link. And the pie on the right adds up to 71 percent because, as the figure clearly shows, insurance accounts for 71% of total spending. Before you complain about a post, try reading it first.

headline: Christie Accuses Washington of Ignoring Fiscal Crisis
text: Chris Christie, the Republican governor of New Jersey, accused Democrats and Republicans in Washington on Wednesday of ignoring America’s fiscal crisis while they played a political game of chicken that threatens the future of the next generation.

headline: Vain Glorious | To the Moon With Cartier
text: Fragrance is the most ephemeral of subjects. If you follow such things, you rapidly lose the impulse to bat an eyelash when told a scent is inspired by a flower that actually has none (Marc Jacobs Daisy), a chick flick (Fresh’s Eat Pray Love trio) or the High Line (Bond No. 9) — especially when told by a well-dressed French person. So it doesn’t sound unreasonable (quite romantic, in fact) that the new fragrance Cartier de Lune is meant to smell like a bouquet picked in the moonlight, but the reality is that those of us without a trained nose (or fantastic imagination) have no idea how that smells.

headline: J.F.K. Security Agents Charged With Stealing $40,000
text: Updated 5:23 p.m. | Two federal officers assigned to work in security jobs at Kennedy International Airport have been arrested and charged with stealing $40,000 in cash from a piece of checked luggage, the authorities said.

headline: Video: Hacking Microsoft Kinect and a Roomba
text: As soon as the Microsoft Kinect came out last year, programmers and hackers pounced on it in the hope of using it for anything but its intended use as a wireless addition for the Microsoft Xbox that uses a person’s movement as a game controller.

headline: In Memoriam: Margaret K. McElderry
text: On Monday, the world of children’s publishing lost one of its last great 20th century editors, Margaret K. McElderry, who died at age 98. As Douglas Martin noted in his obituary today, Ms. McElderry came to be known as “the grande dame of children’s publishing.” She was the first children’s book editor to earn an eponymous imprint — Margaret K. McElderry Books — which continued, even after her retirement in 1998, and still publishes within Simon & Schuster today.

text: Ski-chalet style, and five bedrooms, for about $2.6 million

headline: Atlantic City to Get a New Golden Nugget
text: After an absence of more than two decades, the Golden Nugget brand is returning to Atlantic City. Landry’s, the casino’s parent company, announced this week that it would buy the Trump Marina Hotel and Casino and open a Golden Nugget on that site.

headline: Helping the Teenager With A.D.H.D.
text: Millions of people suffer from attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, or A.D.H.D., many of them teenagers who face problems in school. Here, Dr. Russell A. Barkley, clinical professor of psychiatry at the Medical University of South Carolina and author of “Your Defiant Teen” and other books, responds to concerns from parents of teenagers with A.D.H.D.

headline: Deputy Press Secretary Leaving White House
text: Bill Burton, who has been a deputy press secretary for President Obama, is leaving the White House to form a political consulting firm with Sean Sweeney, another West Wing veteran.

headline: New Hacking Tools Pose Bigger Threats to Wi-Fi Users
text: You may think the only people capable of snooping on your Internet activity are government intelligence agents or possibly a talented teenage hacker holed up in his parents’ basement. But some simple software lets just about anyone sitting next to you at your local coffee shop watch you browse the Web and even assume your identity online.

headline: Solutions for an Overstuffed Hard Drive
text: Q. The hard drive on my laptop is about to burst with all my pictures and music, and I’d like to be able to remove it all to external storage. I’ve tried external hard drives, but I use them only as back-up since they are cumbersome to use with a laptop if I want continual access to my files.

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend

headline: Mom Wakes, Dad Sleeps

headline: Mumford & Sons Get Big ‘Grammy Lift’
text: The Grammy Awards have always had an effect on record sales. But in the digital age that effect is felt more quickly than ever, since fans’ impulse buys made during the show on Sunday night register as part of the tail end of Nielsen SoundScan’s sales week.

headline: A Lawmaker’s Critique of Obama’s Energy Stance

headline: U.S. Cracks Down on Armenian Crime Syndicate
text: GLENDALE, Calif.  Law enforcement officials cracked down Wednesday on a growing Southern California criminal organization with extensive international ties, arresting 74 members and associates of the Armenian Power crime group.

headline: Iranian Warships Bound for Syria Are Set to Transit Suez Canal, Israel Says
text: JERUSALEM  Israel warned on Wednesday that two Iranian warships were poised to pass through the Suez Canal en route to Syria, something it called a provocation that had not happened in years.

headline: Revivals Are Nice, but Revel in the New
text: RECYCLING, though normally a virtuous activity, has been the essence of New York theater for far too long. So I’m celebrating the arrival of a slew of brand-new works from major playwrights, including Jez Butterworth, Stephen Adly Guirgis and no less than three Pulitzer Prize winners (David Lindsay-Abaire, Tony Kushner and Lynn Nottage). Also worth an anticipatory glass of Champagne: some singing Mormons, a reprise of Tom Stoppard and a horse with heart.

headline: A Famous Big Cat, and Stars on the Rise
text: AMID the increasing preponderance of starry nights at the theater this spring, one of the most intriguing is the arrival of Robin Williams in an exciting new play by an up-and-coming young writer, as opposed to a commercially driven revival. But some of the performances that most entice are from lesser-known actors with luminary potential: Nina Arianda, a breakout talent from last season; John Douglas Thompson; and the delectably odd Off Broadway mainstay David Greenspan.

headline: New York Fashion Week | Wine Time
text: As the New York shows approach the finishing line, it would seem that everyone from Alexander Wang to Victoria Beckham is serving the same thing for winter — a fruity yet rich Bordeaux. The color has been brightened and lightened, making it appear more like a Beaujolais nouveau rather than a deeper Pauillac, with bursts of fuchsia in the mix to provide balance. Although it appeared on upper-length leather gloves and platforms on heels, designers sought to liven up their looks with a new color. Olivier Theyskens’s second collection for Theory took a traditional approach with his wine-colored chunky knits, while Marc Jacobs played with the shade in all textures and lengths ranging from a pailette knee-length skirt to a pleated maxi version. The newcomer Prabal Gurung showed all varietals in a color-saturated fur coat over a sheer black dress, but no one did it like Posh, who provided standouts in the form of loose dresses in cashmeres and double-faced wools. As they say in Paris, santé!

headline: Homes for $800,000
text: A four-bedroom Queen Anne in Beaufort, S.C.; a modern ranch in Paradise Valley, Ariz.; and a two-bedroom condo in a 1921 building in Seattle.

headline: Raine Hire Signals Focus On Sports Media
text: The Raine Group, which is in the middle raising roughly $500 million for a private equity fund focused on media deals, has made one of its first big hires, signaling the firm’s focus on sports media.

headline: What You Get for ... $800,000

headline: Globetrotters Conquer the Hudson
text: As promised, the Harlem Globetrotters took to the Hudson River Tuesday, sinking 4-pointers from one Circle Line boat to another. Both Nate Lofton and Anthony Blakes connected from the 35-foot distance.

headline: Browsing: Shopping Picks for Feb. 17
text: The owner of Bird sees fuller silhouettes for spring; Alexander Wang opens a flagship; and Guess moves into a large space on Fifth Avenue.

headline: Shopping for Minimalist Pieces With Messana O’Rorke

headline: Stitch by Stitch and Block by Block
text: ON a recent blustery Friday night near McCarren Park in Brooklyn, Nayantara Banerjee, a k a the Williamsburg Seamster, was armored in a poncho sweater, knee-high snow boots from Urban Outfitters and a black-and silver-threaded scarf knotted over her long, jet-black hair. Despite the frigid air, Ms. Banerjee was happy to stretch her limbs. She had spent most of the day hunched over her sewing machine, one of five in her living room, hemming a damaged skirt, fixing a botched tailor job on a pair of pants and cinching the waist of a vintage leopard-print dress.

headline: Spaghetti and Meatballs
text: 1 loaf fresh ciabatta, crusts removed, whirred in a blender or food processor to make crumbs (about 2 cups)

headline: Cooking With Dexter: Busy Signal
text: My father left the office at 5. If he wasn’t home by 5:30, we knew he had hit traffic. To the opening theme of the 6 o’clock news, we sat down to eat the meal my mother prepared.

headline: The Oscar Envelope Gets a Makeover
text: LOS ANGELES— It’s the equivalent of discovering that the Oscar statuettes are purchased at Spencer’s Gifts. The sealed envelopes used at the Academy Awards apparently come from . . . Staples.

headline: When in Rome, Let Your Smartphone Do the Translating
text: You can use a smartphone to save a few dollars on an airline ticket, buy a Starbucks latte or gain the inside edge on draft news in fantasy sports leagues.

headline: In Memoir, Scott Brown Says He Was Molested As a Child
text: BOSTON — Senator Scott Brown reveals in his memoir that he was molested by a camp counselor as a child, according to a “60 Minutes” interview to be broadcast Sunday.

headline: Blaise Kavanagh | Something for the Ladies
text: This week, Blaise Kavanagh is quietly presenting his second collection and showing himself to be a serious craftsman. He makes his patterns and sews the majority of his samples himself. Part of that may be out of necessity — the 26-year-old is fresh out of Pratt — but more likely it is because he is passionate about what he does.

headline: Range Rover Autobiography Ultimate: $170,000
text: On the same Geneva stage as the 2012 Evoque — the lightest, most fuel-efficient model ever to wear the Range Rover name — Land Rover will unveil the Autobiography Ultimate edition: a limited-production S.U.V. festooned with teak, hand-stitched leather surfaces and the latest talisman of automotive chic, an Apple iPad. Make that two iPads.

headline: Skull-Cups in British Cave Conjure an Ancient Rite
text: The three human braincases, two from adults and one from a child, were carefully skinned and cleaned with flint tools. The soft tissue was removed and probably consumed, leaving a well-shaped cup, perhaps made for use in some sort of ritual.

headline: Signs of Beautiful Isolation, and Even Spring, on a Walk on Governors Island
text: On a brisk morning on Governors Island, as winter begins to surrender to spring, the fake palm trees that greet the ferry on Water Taxi Beach appear even more surreal than usual, poking up out of snow above the empty picnic tables.

headline: At Marc Jacobs, the Show Before the Show
text: EIGHT days before the Marc Jacobs show on Monday — the stylistic tent pole for the circus of New York Fashion Week — Robert Duffy, the president of Marc Jacobs, found himself running around Canal Street carrying a swatch of fabric necessary to create the quilted 20-foot columns for a runway show whose inspiration, Mr. Duffy said, only half-joking, was a padded cell.

headline: Fosse Revival Coming to Roundabout
text: Two years after scrapping its original plans, Roundabout Theater Company announced Wednesday that it would produce “Bob Fosse’s Dancin’ ” this fall at Broadway’s Studio 54 theater, with director Graciela Daniele recreating Fosse’s original choreography from his hit revue “Dancin’.”

headline: Uninhibited Color
text: A penthouse apartment in Berlin has a doughnut-style layout, with a circular flow to most of the rooms, each with a different color palette.

headline: Marchesa: Miss Havisham Regrets …
text: One thing you do not want to see on the way into a fashion show is an ambulance at the door. Walking on West 22nd Street this afternoon, a few editors en route to the Marchesa show were nearly run down when an ambulance pulled onto the sidewalk in an attempt to bypass the stalled traffic, but another had beaten them to the scene by turning onto the street from the opposite end. All this for what turned out to be a bloodied nose.

headline: Music in Review
text: MUSIC FROM JAPANBaruch Performing Arts Center

headline: CBS Reports Higher  Revenue
text: The CBS Corporation said Wednesday that its fourth-quarter revenue rose 11 percent over the same period in 2009, helped by growth in local advertising.

headline: In Berlin, a Penthouse’s Rainbow of Colors
text: BERLIN  Most German fashion designers are not known for their uninhibited use of color. That makes the eye-popping penthouse apartment here of the designer Mischa Woeste, the creator of the Smeilinener label, and her husband, Eghard Woeste, an architect, that much more remarkable.

headline: Prints of the City
text: Prova, Irini Arakas’s five-year-old accessories line of kaleidoscopic beads, jewels and scarves favored by Michelle Obama and the electro punker TK Wonder, now includes dresses. The patterns — in a short day dress and maxi style — have the deceptively slinky curves and sassy detailing of the ‘40s (sleeves! knee length!) with the louche glamour of the ‘70s (florals, animal prints and disco fringe!). Arakas says she’s found the zipper factor: “You know, when you zip yourself into a dress and it just feels so good and perfect and makes you happy.” By all means, zip us up. From $595, at Ikram (Chicago) and Blue Tree (New York), or go to kirnazabete.com.

headline: The Scene: Fashion Week Day 7
text: Scenes around the city from New York Fashion Week.

headline: Motown at the Apollo, Suspended in Time
text: Smokey Robinson said he was “tripping” to be back performing at the Apollo Theater on Tuesday night, calling the theater “the real beginning of my show business life.” He reminisced about doing five shows a day there as part of Motown’s “Motortown Revue” in the early 1960s, when the Apollo crowds’ reputation for booing acts offstage was so fearsome, Mr. Robinson said, that “I was afraid to look out in the audience.” Now, a few days before his 71st birthday on Saturday, Mr. Robinson wasn’t just engaging the audience. He was trusting it, and seducing a good part of it. What might have been an oldies show became a singer’s teasing, obsessive tour de force.

headline: Kaleidoscopes of Patterns Against Backdrop of Mozart’s Chivalry
text: High among my memories of the most illustrious dance performances are those that New York City Ballet gave in the early 1980s of Balanchine’s “Divertimento No. 15.” This ballet, with the most sublime choreography ever made to music by Mozart, creates an ideal realm in which courtesy, chivalry, brilliance, serenity and expansiveness coexist and give off light. In those performances, Balanchine style was at a peak of refinement: resplendent in line, dazzling in speed, calm in phrasing, tingling in musical precision. The huge box of stage space around the dancers was animated by their ardent three-dimensional physicality and their dynamics.

headline: In Surprise Finding, Bald Mice Find Their Fur Again
text: Mouse researchers conducting stress hormone experiments have stumbled onto a surprising new discovery — a potential treatment for hair loss.

headline: The Accomplished Joined by the Young and Promising
text: McCoy Tyner, the august and thunderous jazz pianist, had an assignment at the Blue Note this week. He didn’t seem too enthusiastic about it on Tuesday night. The engagement was billed as “A Contemporary Exploration of ‘John Coltrane & Johnny Hartman,’ ” referring to a beloved ballads album on which Mr. Tyner appeared as a sideman in 1963. Standing in for Coltrane was a trustworthy tenor saxophonist, Eric Alexander. Hartman’s role was entrusted to a young vocalist, José James.

headline: As U.S. Agencies Put More Value on a Life, Businesses Fret
text: WASHINGTON  As the players here remake the nation’s vast regulatory system, they have been grappling with a subject that is more the province of poets and philosophers than bureaucrats: what is the value of a human life?

headline: Players’ Boycott Could Affect Canada’s Bid for 2015 Women’s World Cup
text: Canada’s designs on hosting the Women’s World Cup in 2015 were tarnished a bit last week when members of the national team issued a threat to boycott coming international matches because the team’s successful Italian coach had tendered her resignation, as of July.

headline: In Florida Slough With the Gators and Family Ghosts
text: Karen Russell, author of the wave-making debut novel “Swamplandia!,” was on New York Magazine’s 2005 list of 27 impressive New Yorkers under the age of 26. In 2009 she received a 5 Under 35 award from the National Book Foundation. Last year she wound up on The New Yorker’s 20 Under 40 list. Nice numbers. But cut to the chase: Ms. Russell is one in a million.

headline: Excerpt: 'Diary of a Madman'
text: In this production of Nikolai Gogol's play, Geoffrey Rush plays a civil servant who is slowly being driven mad by bureaucracy. (Video courtesy of the Brooklyn Academy of Music)

headline: A Mission Documented With a Filter of Despair
text: “The Battle for Marjah” enters the crowded field of Iraq and Afghanistan battlefield documentaries, where films like “Restrepo,” “Gunner Palace” and “The War Tapes” have already made their marks. What will distinguish this British production for the American viewer is its mood of poetic fatalism, even despair.

headline: Canadians Who Still Have Fun Being Somber
text: Haunted songs by the Cowboy Junkies like “Lonely Sinking Feeling” and “To Love Is to Bury” won’t be turning up on “Glee” one day, but this band has turned somber into a mysterious sort of success for 25 years.

headline: Waris’s New York
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#421", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

headline: Newly Released Books
text: This being the month for romance, or at least a good marketing hook, February’s books are bound in red. A mean old man, a teenage runaway, a psychiatrist and an American student in Paris all get to fall in love. In the novel “Solo,” as the title suggests, a man remembers a life without it.

headline: Williams to Split Into Two
text: Breaking up, it would seem, is not that hard to do.

headline: Sound That’s Lush and Slow, Speedy and Precise
text: Hilary Hahn has been playing Jennifer Higdon’s Violin Concerto around the world since 2009, and Ms. Hahn’s Deutsche Grammophon recording of the work with the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic has been available since September.

headline: In a Boom, What’s a Bankruptcy Specialist to Do?
text: In the world of restructuring, few academics hold the stature of Edward I. Altman, the professor who created a widely used metric for predicting when a company might file for bankruptcy.

headline: The Dreamer Caught in the Spotlight
text: Dressed in white, her hair a corona of silver ringlets, Judy Collins suggested a seasonal Glinda the Good Witch ushering out one of the most punishing New York winters in memory on Tuesday evening as she sang “The Blizzard” at the Café Carlyle. One of her great later songs, for which she accompanied herself on piano, “The Blizzard” describes a brokenhearted woman driving alone through a winter storm in the Colorado Rockies and taking shelter with a stranger with whom she has a healing romantic encounter. The next morning she awakens in dazzling sunlight and continues her journey through the mountains, her faith in herself restored.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Producers Have Their Eye on Script Doctor with Superhero Credentials
text: The producers of the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” have asked Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa, a playwright who also written Spider-Man stories for Marvel Comics, if he is interested and available to help rewrite the script for the big-budget, critically assailed musical, according to two people familiar with the discussions.

headline: A ‘Requiem’ Unwraps Stillness Swathed in Silk
text: The dances of Jacqulyn Buglisi could be likened to a powdery musk. At first her work gives off an antique allure, but over time that bouquet turns into something oppressive. She sprays it on thick.

headline: Met Opera Plans ‘Anna Bolena’ and ‘Faust’
text: The Metropolitan Opera, announcing next season’s program, said on Wednesday that it would mount its first production of Donizetti’s “Anna Bolena,” with Anna Netrebko portraying Henry VIII’s second wife. David McVicar will direct the work, along with two other Tudor-era operas by Donizetti, “Maria Stuarda” and “Roberto Devereux,” in successive seasons. They will also be Met premieres.

headline: Planning Comeback, Democrats Huddle with Ousted Members
text: It’s never too early to bring the old faces back.

headline: Gender Blitz on a High School Gridiron
text: Who says girls can’t play football? Or that you don’t go to Bushwick in Brooklyn to see a play? And if you think deconstructionist, experimental theater must be dry and dreary, the Half Straddle, an emerging troupe, has another surprise for you.

headline: Cinema in Berlin
text: Images of some of the films in the Berlin International Film Festival.

headline: Tracing the Myth of a Chinese Leader to Its Roots
text: LIANGJIAHE, China  The cave is dim and narrow and musty. A platform bed covered with a reed mat sits by the door. A green canvas satchel and a lantern hang from two rusty nails on a wall  possessions supposedly left behind by a lanky teenage boy from Beijing sent here four decades ago to do hard labor.

headline: Bucking Trend, College Will Cut Price
text: For those who wonder how college tuition costs manage to keep rising year after year, apparently defying laws of economic gravity, Sewanee, a liberal arts college in Tennessee, has an answer: they can’t.

headline: The Musical Rhythms in Images Out of Time
text: I’ve gone only twice to see parts of Christian Marclay’s 24-hour video, “The Clock,” at the Paula Cooper Gallery in Chelsea, which closes on Saturday. Wish I could have seen more. The first time, for only half an hour, I took it in as a movie. On the second viewing, much longer, it felt like music.

headline: Flock Around ‘The Clock’
text: Even when they involve 14-foot tiger sharks preserved in formaldehyde or pictures of Jeff Koons in flagrante delicto, commercial art gallery exhibitions in New York don’t often draw capacity crowds. And they almost never move people to line up along the postindustrial streets of Chelsea on weekday winter mornings as if a sample sale were under way.

headline: Video: The iPhone for Advanced Beginners
text: With Verizon iPhones now out in the wild, many people are still figuring out how to use them. Here are a few tips for those who are ready to move beyond the basics.

headline: New Female Police Chief Is a First for Rio
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil  With a police corruption scandal growing in Rio de Janeiro, José Mariano Beltrame, the security chief for Rio de Janeiro State, has ousted the head of the beleaguered Civil Police and named the first woman ever to head the force in the city.

headline: The Sound and the Feel of Oscar-Worthiness
text: With just over a week to go until the little gold men are handed out at the Kodak Theater, film aficionados and cineastes are thinking one thing: How can I win my Oscar pool?

headline: Two Kings Against a Slam Prove to Be Not Quite Enough
text: Perhaps the diagramed deal featured the best declarer play during the NEC Festival of Bridge, which ended last Sunday in Yokohama City, Japan. It was described by West, Ron Klinger from Australia, on his blog.

headline: A Collector of Everyday Objects on His New Museum in Mexico City
text: Bruno Newman, the founder and a director of Zimat, a large communications firm in Mexico, has spent more than 50 years collecting various kinds of objects — more than 30,000, in 30 categories (including household products, food packages, medicine bottles, cosmetics and toys). Enough to open a museum, in other words. So that’s exactly what Mr. Newman, 66, did. El Museo del Objeto del Objeto, or the Museum of the Object of the Object, opened last fall in the Colonia Roma of Mexico City, in a 1906 Art Nouveau building that was once Mr. Newman’s home.

headline: Crash Puts Earnhardt Jr., a Daytona 500 Favorite, at a Raceday Disadvantage
text: Dale Earnhardt Jr., the 2004 Daytona 500 winner and the pole sitter for this Sunday’s race, crashed his Chevrolet in a practice session at Daytona International Speedway on Wednesday.

headline: He Rested on the Seventh Day
text: Buffalo, Feb. 17, 1861

headline: Obama Talks to Kaine About Running for the Senate
text: 8:02 a.m. | Updated President Obama talked on the phone Wednesday with Tim Kaine, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, two Democratic sources said, as the pressure mounts for Mr. Kaine to run for the Senate in Virginia.

headline: Computer Wins on ‘Jeopardy!’: Trivial, It’s Not
text: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y. — In the end, the humans on “Jeopardy!” surrendered meekly.

headline: Christie Proposes Ending Tenure for Poor Teachers
text: PRINCETON, N.J.  One month after Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey used his annual state address to call for an end to tenure for teachers, his administration unveiled a plan on Wednesday that would take away tenure from ineffective teachers but stopped short of eliminating it.

headline: Gauging the Fed’s Recent Forecasting
text: The Federal Reserve periodically polls the members of its Open Market Committee — board members and presidents of the regional Fed banks — on their economic outlook. Their expectations are worth looking at because those are the forecasts that affect monetary policy decisions, and are therefore more important than other forecasts whether or not they are better forecasters.

headline: Obama Calls Lara Logan of CBS
text: President Obama this afternoon called Lara Logan, the CBS News correspondent who is recovering at home in Washington after a brutal sexual attack last Friday in Cairo’s Tahrir Square, an administration official said.

headline: A Red Hook ‘Summer Cottage’
text: An uninhabitable 1899 carriage house in Brooklyn, transformed into a home with a vacation cottage theme.

headline: His Real Estate Agent? Craigslist
text: THOMAS WARNKE found his house on Craigslist, and he knows how odd that will sound to some people. “Normally one goes to Craigslist for used bikes and rentals, not properties in the hundreds of thousands,” said Mr. Warnke, 43, an architect who moved here from Germany 11 years ago. “And, of course, I was aware that for some other things it could be seen as a little sketchy.”

headline: France: Sarkozy Signals Support for Foreign Minister
text: President Nicolas Sarkozy sent a handwritten message of support to his embattled foreign minister, Michèle Alliot-Marie, on Wednesday, the day after embarrassing new revelations about her Christmas visit to Tunisia with her husband and her parents. Not only did she accept two free flights from a businessman close to the family of the deposed president, Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, but her parents bought a real estate company from the same businessman on the trip. Ms. Alliot-Marie said the investment had nothing to do with her, but there were new calls for her resignation, including in an editorial in Le Monde.

headline: A New Line of Chairs, Inspired by Paper Planes
text: The British designers Nipa Doshi and Jonathan Levien had math on their minds when creating the Paper Planes chair for Moroso, the Italian furnishings company. “Our inspiration was folded graph paper,” Mr. Levien said.

headline: Alpha Workshops Wallpapers to Be Offered by Thibaut
text: The hand-painted wallpapers and other finishes from New York’s Alpha Workshops, which trains people with H.I.V. and AIDS in such arts, have long been staples of high-end designers. Now, in partnership with the wallpaper company Thibaut, six of the nonprofit group’s patterns (the Ginkgo style, left) are becoming more accessible.

headline: A Touch of Spring From a Cherry Blossom Rug
text: Shirley Shivhon, an interior designer in Los Angeles, was working on a house in Maui in 2008 and planned a home office with a red chinoiserie desk and a rug decorated with cherry blossoms. But in designing the rug, she rejected the look of traditional Chinese paintings.

headline: Sales at Broadway Panhandler, Mxyplyzyk and Others
text: At Broadway Panhandler’s sale, through Monday, many items are as much as 70 percent off (a Le Creuset eight-inch skillet, regularly $135, is about $40); 65 East Eighth Street (Broadway), (212) 966-3434, broadwaypanhandler.com.

headline: Objects for Minimalists
text: BRIAN MESSANA and Toby O’Rorke, architects who run the Manhattan firm Messana O’Rorke, favor interiors that are white, bright and clutter-free.

headline: Shelter Strategies
text: To the Editor:

headline: Curator Moms
text: To the Editor:

headline: Warm Nights, Cold Noses
text: EVERY night for the last year, Kathy Ruttenberg has been taking a bath, putting on pajamas, turning on CNN and getting into bed with a little pig named Trixie.

headline: The Weavers
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Online Market 1stdibs Goes Brick and Mortar
text: The online marketplace 1stdibs, which functions as a portal to more than 1,000 art and antiques dealers in the United States and Canada as well as Paris and London, is opening a physical showroom Friday. The new space, 1stdibs@NYDC, will display the wares of 53 dealers and occupy all 33,000 square feet of the 10th floor of the New York Design Center in Midtown.

headline: Let it Snow. Then, Attack.
text: MAYBE it’s a New York thing.

headline: Earnhardt Goes From Pole to Back of Pack
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Dale Earnhardt Jr. crashed during practice at Daytona International Speedway on Wednesday, costing him the pole position for the Daytona 500 on Sunday.

headline: Chobani, Greek Yogurt Leader, Lets Its Fans Tell the Story
text: THE leading brand in a growing grocery category is introducing its first television advertising in an effort to stay ahead of a growing field of competitors.

headline: Calling on RoboCop to Help Detroit
text: DETROIT  On a list of Detroit’s biggest problems, the lack of a statue honoring RoboCop would seem to rank rather low.

headline: Heavy Rains Linked to Humans
text: An increase in heavy precipitation that has afflicted many countries is at least partly a consequence of human influence on the atmosphere, climate scientists reported in a new study.

headline: Looks That Pop From Anna Sui
text: The opening looks in black-and-white graphic prints at Anna Sui’s show on Wednesday night really popped. That’s saying something for a designer who doesn’t shy away from the psychedelic, the mod, the groovy, the Art Nouveau and the Art Deco, all of which made an appearance on her runway.

headline: Human DNA Contamination Seen in Genome Databases
text: Nearly 20 percent of the nonhuman genomes held in computer databases are contaminated with human DNA, presumably from the researchers who prepared the samples, say scientists who chanced upon the finding while looking for a human virus.

headline: Italy: Berlusconi Says He’s Not Worried About Trial
text: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi said on Wednesday that he was “not worried” about a judge’s order that he face trial on charges he paid for sex with an under-age woman and abused his office to help release her from police detention for theft. In his first comments since the ruling on Tuesday, Mr. Berlusconi said he had the parliamentary majority needed to carry out judicial and economic reforms. At a news conference with Finance Minister Giulio Tremonti, Mr. Berlusconi barely mentioned the sex scandal: “Out of love of my country, I won’t talk about this. I can only say one thing: I’m not worried at all.” The center-left opposition is calling for early elections, and political analysts say the government is not likely to last long.

headline: Mets’ Clickable Moment: Fans Want to Buy Team
text: In late 1999, three friends created a Web site to solicit fans to acquire the Jets.

headline: Senator Tells of Sexual Abuse and Shoplifting in Memoir
text: BOSTON  Senator Scott Brown reveals in his memoir that he was molested by a camp counselor as a child, according to a “60 Minutes” interview to be broadcast Sunday.

headline: Germany’s Economic Assertiveness Shakes Euro Zone
text: BRUSSELS  For decades, Germans wanted to become more European and took care not to be seen bossing around their allies on the Continent. But now that the government in Berlin wants Europe to become more like Germany, the temperature is rising.

headline: Ex-Freddie Mac C.F.O. May Face Civil Charges
text: 8:34 p.m. | Updated

headline: Fashion Week Power Source Upsets Neighbors
text: Some neighbors call the 311 help line. Others say they now take a different route to walk their dogs. Parents complain of headaches. Children say they cannot sleep.

headline: It’s a Tough Town, but It Dresses Well
text: Ah, the sidewalks of New York fashion! How many dead bodies can you walk on?

headline: China Acts to Tighten Grasp on Rare Earths Production
text: HONG KONG  Premier Wen Jiabao of China and his cabinet decided Wednesday to “streamline” the country’s rare earth industry by consolidating production, clamping down on illegal mining and clearly deciding which government agencies would oversee it, the government said.

headline: Scorecard | Rodarte Wins!
text: The sixth day of New York Fashion Week found America’s pre-eminent female designers fashioning diverging conceptions of national identity. So whose heroines were chicest? At Vera Wang, it was pleats, please. But Scorecard knows critics were over the rainbow with the Mulleavy sisters’ wearable distillation of their former wool cobweb-cheesecloth-macramé creations as tailored prairie dresses. That’s one way to do country strong.

headline: Contingent Rights Shouldn’t Catch On
text: Contingent value rights are a nice idea. The ones structured for Sanofi-Aventis’s purchase of Genzyme helped seal the $20 billion deal. But the drawbacks posed by these rights should limit their use to special cases.

headline: The Artwork Isn’t Offensive. But to Some, Well, the Very Idea of It ...
text: GREENWOOD LAKE, N.Y.

headline: Sure Recipe for Decline: Neglect and Gluttony
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Mexicans Knew They Shot U.S. Agents
text: MEXICO CITY — The gunmen who attacked two American law enforcement officials in Mexico on Tuesday, killing one and wounding the other, knew they were firing on foreign officers but proceeded anyway, current and former American officials said Wednesday.

headline: Heftier Chamberlain Arrives With Thud at Yankees Camp
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Joba Chamberlain arrived at the most important spring training of his young career listed at 230 pounds, just as he was all last season. This would not be a problem except that Chamberlain weighs more than 230 pounds, and the Yankees are hardly pleased that he does.

headline: Mubarak’s Funds Found by Swiss
text: Funds belonging to the family of Hosni Mubarak, the former Egyptian president, or his senior ministers have been discovered in Switzerland, a Swiss government official said Wednesday. But the official declined to specify how much money had been identified or who controlled the account.

headline: For Tough Baseball Man, a Hurt That Won’t Leave
text: CLEARWATER, Fla.

headline: Borders’ Bankruptcy Shakes Industry
text: After Borders, the 40-year-old retail chain that helped define the age of the book superstore, filed for bankruptcy protection on Wednesday, the struggling book industry was left wondering what was next  and maybe even who was next.

headline: Forecast at Northern Trust Open Sees Rain and Stars
text: LOS ANGELES  So what if the weather on the horizon is as forbidding as the maître d’ at Koi glaring at the common people? The specter of three days of rain in Southern California has not deterred the field at Riviera Country Club for the Northern Trust Open.

headline: Repaving Leads to New Racing Style at Daytona
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  A year after potholes led to embarrassing delays in the Daytona 500, a $20 million repaving job at Daytona International Speedway is helping to create another set of concerns for Nascar’s season-opening showcase event.

headline: Staying in Touch With Home, for Better or Worse
text: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan — Forget the drones, laser-guided bombs and eye-popping satellite imagery. For the average soldier, the most significant change to modern warfare might just boil down to instant chatting.

headline: Miles of Sewer Lines, and He Knows Them Well
text: New York City has 7,400 miles of sewer lines, more than any other city in the nation. Luis Baerga, 57, knows those miles better than most people: He is the longest-serving sewer inspector in the city. Mr. Baerga, a supervisor with the Department of Environmental Protection, has worked in the sewer system for 35 years. He was a 21-year-old former Marine when he started in April 1975. He lives in Brooklyn with his wife and three children.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: A Museum of Media
text: This week’s Bits: Tech Talk show features a look at site-specific digital art. Bettina Edelstein chats with the Adobe Museum of Digital Media’s first guest curator, Tom Eccles, and the first artist to exhibit on the site, Tony Oursler. Mr. Oursler, who created his piece “Valley” for the museum, explains that it reflects the human relationship to the Internet. And Mr. Eccles discusses his impressions of working with a digital environment.

headline: What the South Got Wrong
text: Between Lincoln’s election in November 1860 and his inauguration the following March, seven states of the Deep South left the Union. Each of them did so amid scenes of jubilation and rejoicing.

headline: How Goldman Killed A.I.G.
text: The conventional wisdom has it that the final report of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission was a low-budget flop, hopelessly riven by internal political disputes and dissension among the commission’s 10 members. As usual, the conventional wisdom is completely wrong. Actually, the report — and the online archive of testimony, interviews and documents that are now available — is a treasure trove of invaluable information about the causes and consequences of the Great Recession.

headline: Unrest Spreads, Some Violently, in Middle East
text: From northern Africa to the Persian Gulf, governments appeared to flounder over just how to outrun mostly peaceful movements, spreading erratically like lava erupting from a volcano, with no predictable end.

headline: A New Crackdown Yields 14 Indictments Against a Youthful Harlem Gang
text: All but one of the reputed gang members were born in the 1990s. The lone female among them was a student at Deerfield Academy, an elite Massachusetts prep school.

headline: A Case Against Helmets in Lacrosse
text: Camille Richardson has heard all the arguments, read all the comments, and sees the logic. But as a freshman midfielder for the Columbia women’s lacrosse team who is fully aware of the dangers of head trauma, Richardson makes one thing clear: She has no interest in wearing a helmet, as the men must.

headline: Boehner in His Element as Spending Cuts Elicit Free-Flowing House Debate
text: WASHINGTON  For Speaker John A. Boehner, the budget-cutting frenzy taking place on the House floor merges two of his animating political passions  the need to shrink federal spending and the willingness to risk a free-flowing debate.

headline: Court Considers Revising China’s Marriage Law
text: BEIJING — Sallying forth into the ancient battleground of extramarital affairs, China’s top court appears poised to side with wronged wives against philandering husbands and greedy mistresses.

headline: The Fate of a Patch of Open Space Stirs Anger and Accusations
text: Residents in densely populated Jackson Heights, Queens, are so desperate for public green spaces that they recently temporarily closed down a blocklong section of 78th Street and laid down clumps of synthetic grass bought, on Craigslist, from a suburban house in New Jersey.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Shy U.S. Intellectual Created Playbook Used in a Revolution
text: BOSTON — Halfway around the world from Tahrir Square in Cairo, an aging American intellectual shuffles about his cluttered brick row house in a working-class neighborhood here. His name is Gene Sharp. Stoop-shouldered and white-haired at 83, he grows orchids, has yet to master the Internet and hardly seems like a dangerous man.

headline: Secret Report Ordered by Obama Identified Potential Uprisings
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama ordered his advisers last August to produce a secret report on unrest in the Arab world, which concluded that without sweeping political changes, countries from Bahrain to Yemen were ripe for popular revolt, administration officials said Wednesday.

headline: Reaction to Arsenal-Barcelona
text: Roma might have been booed off its home field in a 3-2 loss to Shakhtar Donetsk on Wednesday, but there was nothing but praise for Arsenal and Barcelona after the Gunners’ 2-1 victory on Wednesday. A sampling of the principals’ reactions:

headline: Filet Mignon? Winner Turns Up Nose
text: It’s not every day that Max Klimavicius, the owner of Sardi’s, personally cuts a customer’s filet mignon into bite-size pieces. Then again, not every customer has just won Best in Show at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Band Device for Less Obese
text: People no longer need to be quite as obese as before to qualify for weight loss surgery.

headline: A Stickup on Arthur Avenue. Where? On Arthur Avenue?
text: Arthur Avenue in the Bronx is known for its Italian restaurants, its cappuccino cafes and its old-school Italian-American population. It is also known as one of the safer streets in the borough, a reputation that made a bold jewelry store robbery there on Wednesday all the more surprising.

headline: Freed by Egypt’s Revolt, Workers Press Demands

headline: Raymond D’Addario, Photographer of Nazis, Dies at 90

headline: True Grit and Title IX
text: Last week, the University of California at Berkeley announced that it will restore three varsity teams it eliminated last fall: women’s gymnastics and lacrosse and men’s rugby. It will not, however, restore men’s baseball and gymnastics. This Solomonic solution would very likely have been worse without Title IX, the federal law that bans gender discrimination in education.

headline: When the Mayor’s Away
text: Everybody deserves some corner of privacy, even the mayor of New York City. The problem comes when there is a big event  like a Christmas snowstorm  and the mayor has gone away (destination secret) and the deputy mayor is unavailable as well.

text: Are there any adults in charge of the House? Watching this week’s frenzied slash-and-burn budget contest, we had to conclude the answer to that is no.

headline: An End to Fannie and Freddie?
text: When Congress considers the Obama administration’s proposals to phase out Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, it needs to keep several goals clearly in mind. It must keep the jittery housing market going and reduce taxpayer risk while enticing private companies back into the mortgage business. And it must keep homeownership affordable to moderate-income and working families.

headline: The One-Man Political Machine
text: On a brutally cold morning in mid-December, Rahm Emanuel, hatless and wearing a glove on only his left hand, stood for an hour in front of the turnstiles at the Paulina el station, which sits in his old Congressional district on Chicago’s North Side. As the trains slammed and screeched overhead, he offered his hand to the mostly young and professional commuters heading downtown. Emanuel’s manner seemed more studied than spontaneous. He employed standard lines — “nice hat,” “good book” — and relied on the logos on riders’ head wear and jackets for conversation starters. He addressed both sexes as “man,” and when a woman asked about his plans for the Chicago Transit Authority, he was characteristically a trifle abrupt — “Here’s the deal,” he said to start — and egocentric. As he did with me, he told her the elevated line right above us was something “I built,” before saying “we,” apparently realizing he was discounting the work and leadership of many others. He hardly seemed like an irresistible force.

headline: Stolen Egyptian Statue Is Found in Garbage
text: Zahi Hawass, the Egyptian antiquities minister, said on Wednesday that a statue of the pharaoh Akhenaten holding an offering table, left, one of the most valuable objects revealed earlier this week to have been stolen from the Egyptian Museum, had been found. In an interview, Mr. Hawass also defended himself against charges that he did not report the missing objects promptly. In the days after the museum was broken into on Jan. 28, Mr. Hawass claimed that, while 70 artifacts had been damaged, none had been stolen. Last Sunday he said that, in fact, 18 objects were missing from the museum. Two of the other objects, a heart scarab and a funerary statuette, as well as the goddess from a statue of a goddess carrying Tutankhamen, were found earlier this week. The Akhenaten statue was found in the garbage near Tahrir Square, Mr. Hawass said, by a boy whose uncle was a professor at the University of Cairo. “His uncle called me today, and I sent some of the police and archaeologists, and they found it is the statue of Akhenaten,” Mr. Hawass said. “We are going to look inside all the garbage that they collected from Tahrir Square to find the rest of the objects.”

headline: Bahrain Turmoil Poses Fresh Test for White House
text: MANAMA, Bahrain  A brutal government crackdown on pro-democracy protesters here on Thursday not only killed at least five people but, once again, placed the Obama administration in the uncomfortable position of dealing with a strategic Arab ally locked in a showdown with its people.

headline: Rock Star
text: Deborah Pagani, a willowy Manhattan-based jewelry designer, may well be her own best model. A fashion lover who’s usually clad in cutting-edge ensembles by Azzedine Alaïa, Haider Ackermann and Rick Owens, she often gets stopped in shops and restaurants by women who want to know where she got her jewelry. “I’ve been tempted to sell things right off my body,” she jokes. Pagani (left, in a Versace dress and her own jewelry) describes her Queen Bee collection as a cross between Joan Crawford and Anita Pallenberg. “I don’t like classic stones by themselves,” she says. Instead, she mixes diamonds, sapphires and amethysts with moodier materials like jasper “zebra” agate, purple turquoise, Nubian opals and moonstones. “My pieces are a bit dark, but dark in a sophisticated way.” The earrings above are $16,105 at Ikram, in Chicago.

headline: Egypt’s Antiquities Minister Says Valuable Statue Found
text: Zahi Hawass, Egypt’s antiquities minister, said on Wednesday that a limestone statue of Akhenaten holding an offering table, among the most valuable of the objects revealed earlier this week to have been stolen from the Egyptian Museum, had been found among garbage collected at Tahrir Square. Mr. Hawass described the discovery, which he said he planned to announce formally on Thursday, in an interview in which he also defended himself against charges that he did not report the missing objects promptly and responded defiantly to protesters who have called for his resignation.

headline: Protesters Face Off for 7th Day in Yemen
text: SANA, Yemen  Yemeni police fired shots into the air on Thursday as thousands of demonstrators, some supporting President Ali Abdullah Saleh and some seeking his downfall, clashed for hours in central Sana, bombarding one another with a hailstorm of rocks on the seventh straight day of violent unrest here.

headline: Pakistan Delays Ruling on Jailed American
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A provincial court on Thursday gave the Pakistani government three weeks to decide whether the American official in custody for killing two Pakistanis has diplomatic immunity, a delay that is likely to intensify a standoff with the United States, the nation’s biggest donor and an ally in the fight against terrorism.

headline: Billionaire Russian Parliamentarian Said to Be Biggest Buyer of VTB Stock
text: Suleiman Kerimov, a Russian billionaire and member of Parliament, became the largest individual shareholder of the state-run bank VTB, buying a $500 million stake in its partial privatization, according to the business daily Vedomosti.

headline: What Obama’s Budget Means for the S.B.A.
text: In recent weeks, President Obama has traveled the country calling for renewed government spending to foster small-company innovation, but on Monday his administration unveiled a Small Business Administration budget (pdf) for 2012 that limits growth in its most important program, government-guaranteed general business loans. It proposes making cuts, modest and substantial, to other S.B.A. programs as well, and would eliminate two initiatives altogether. Still, over all the cuts are not as drastic as the administration may want to convey.

headline: In N.F.L. Labor Dispute, Remember the Little Guy

headline: One World Trade Center Is Halfway Up (By Our Call)
text: In 2010, so much progress was made at the World Trade Center that officials saw no need to cook up fabricated milestones, as they had in the past. But in December, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey showed that old habits die hard. It announced in a press release (accompanied by this picture) that 1 World Trade Center — the building formerly known as Freedom Tower — had reached “halfway to the top.” Meaning what? That the structural steel had reached the level of the 52nd floor in what will be a 104-story building.

headline: PPR Chief to Run Gucci Group Himself
text: PARIS  The French fashion and retailing magnate François-Henri Pinault surprised the luxury world on Thursday, saying he would personally take charge of the Gucci Group as he reorganized its parent company, PPR, to focus on the most profitable businesses.

headline: A Carriage House for Horseless Classics
text: Classic Car Club Manhattan, which offers a fleet of classic and contemporary sports cars to dues-paying members, will expand early next month from its original SoHo branch to the Upper East Side. “It’s a turn-of-the-century carriage house,” said Michael Prichinello, co-founder of the club, of the new outpost. “We chose it because physically it’s in the right area: easy to get in and out of town.”

headline: New Advice on Preventing Falls
text: For the first time since 2001, the American Geriatrics Society and the British Geriatrics Society have updated their guidelines for preventing falls in older people. The update includes two notable changes: One recommends tai chi — the meditative, slow-motion Chinese exercise — as an effective way to prevent falls, while another suggests that doctors review medication use by all elderly patients, with an eye toward reducing use of those drugs that increase the risk of falling.

headline: Cocktails With a Twist: Zing but No Alcohol
text: A column that celebrates drinking should pause every once in a while to celebrate not drinking, given that alcohol is a two-edged sword: catalyst for delight and engine of destruction; handled with restraint by some people, abused and best avoided entirely by others. It’s a drug, with all the attendant dangers, and it’s not the only way to experience liquid pleasure in a restaurant or bar. Others exist and warrant praise.

headline: A Chat With the Man Behind ‘Outside the Law’
text: The Franco-Algerian director Rachid Bouchareb has got to be hoping that the third time is the charm. He received Oscar nominations for best foreign-language film in 1996 for his “Dust of Life” and again in 2007 for “Days of Glory,” both of which are films that tackle difficult aspects of the relationship between the West and the Third World. And now he is back with “Outside the Law,” which addresses the long and violent struggle in which Algeria sought its independence from France, finally achieved in 1962.

headline: BP Says Spill Settlement Terms Are Too Generous
text: In the eight months since Kenneth R. Feinberg took over the $20 billion fund to compensate victims of the Gulf of Mexico oil spill, he has been attacked by many of those filing claims and by coastal state politicians who argue that the process is opaque, arbitrary and slow. Many of them have also argued that Mr. Feinberg’s recently published estimates of future damage to those in the gulf are too optimistic, and thus his offer of compensation in a final settlement is too low.

text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Foot Fetish
text: The Paris-based shoe designer Laurence Dacade, whose in-demand studded biker-style boots are sported by the likes of Vanessa Paradis and Erin Wasson, keeps her footwork in step with her vanity case. Her new mesh bootie, the Tiffany, was inspired by the scent of rose gardens. The crimson peep toe, which is sultry and light, is gracefully adorned with a trellis of satin petals. “It’s sexy and sensual-feeling,” Dacade says. “The effect is as subtle as a whiff of perfume.”

headline: Protests Spread to More Iraqi Cities

headline: Democrats Missing, Wisconsin Vote on Cuts Is Delayed
text: MADISON, Wis.  The fury among thousands of workers, students and union supporters rose to a boil on Thursday, as state lawmakers prepared to vote on landmark legislation that would slash collective bargaining rights for public workers. Protesters blocked a door to the Senate chambers. They sat down, body against body, filling a corridor. They chanted “Freedom, democracy, unions!” in the stately gallery as the senators convened.

headline: Banksy Sightings in Hollywood (of a Sort)
text: Banksy has made it to Hollywood, or at least some of his work has. In the last few days, several pieces by the British street artist have appeared around Los Angeles: a urinating dog (placed in Beverly Hills), a mischievous Charlie Brown and a drunk Mickey and Minnie Mouse, with the slogan “Living the Dream.” (All the images are viewable on Banksy’s Web site.) Though Banksy’s reps confirmed to The Los Angeles Times that the work belonged to him, they did not mention whether it was part of his ongoing un-campaign for his Oscar-nominated documentary, “Exit Through the Gift Shop.” But since Banksy rarely does anything without it being carefully thought out, we can assume it’s more than a coincidence.

headline: Princely Majesty, Sensuous Simplicity
text: IT’S true that 59 sounds ancient for a dancer, but the sight of Vicky Shick might change your mind. The lithe Ms. Shick has been dancing for most of her life, something that over the years has appeared only more effortless. She possesses the kind of considered grace that comes from another world  she was born in Hungary  and perhaps another time.

headline: Anticipating Glory From a Newcomer And a Guest Star
text: ALINA COJOCARU is a ballerina who makes you understand why that title should be reserved for a select few. Of course she has a fabulous classical technique and a beautiful line. Of course she has a weightless, airy jump and limpid, exquisite arms. Of course she is both musical and a superb actress. But Ms. Cojocaru, a Royal Ballet principal who will appear as a guest with American Ballet Theater this season, is even greater than the sum of those parts. In her heart-wrenching portrayal of a simple peasant girl betrayed by the man she loves in “Giselle”; in the extreme, imploding articulations of Wayne McGregor’s “Chroma”; or as the radiantly youthful princess of “The Sleeping Beauty,” she brings an ineffable combination of steely strength and lyrical delicacy to her dancing that is ever-changing and ever-fascinating.

headline: A Grand Finale: Cunningham’s Last Dances
text: AMID the world’s wide range of illustrious dancers, I draw attention to a rare species that may soon become extinct: the Merce Cunningham performer. Since Cunningham’s troupe’s began in 1953 it has consistently contained a number of the world’s most extraordinary dancers. But on New Year’s Eve, at the end of the two-year Legacy Tour, the Merce Cunningham Dance Company gives its final performance, and nobody knows yet if much of his choreography will survive in performance anywhere.

headline: A Competitor on Any Turf

headline: Standing Small, Singing Big, All Sulfur and Zest
text: COLORBLINDNESS on the opera stage is a fact of life, yet it never hurts for a singer to look the part, as the bass Kwangchul Youn recognizes. “It takes courage to cast a short Korean in parts where people expect a tall, blond European,” Mr. Youn said with a broad smile in 2008, after singing the betrayed King Marke in Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde” at the Metropolitan Opera for the first time. Mr. Youn stands a little over 5-foot-7 (1-meter-71, he says, not yielding a centimeter).

headline: Caught Unawares by an Anti-Immigrant Mood

headline: ‘Ring’ Resumes, With All Eyes on Brünnhilde
text: THERE is much at stake for the Metropolitan Opera with its new production of Wagner’s “Ring” cycle. So the premiere of “Die Walküre” (April 22), the second installment of Robert Lepage’s high-tech staging, will be the most anticipated event of the spring. The first installment, “Das Rheingold,” opened the Met’s season in September. It returns for two performances (March 30 and April 2), and I am eager to see it again.

headline: Calling All Orchestras: Bring a Creative Program
text: WHEN I moved to New York, in 1970, I haunted Carnegie Hall (even more than I do now). Still less than a decade into my late-found obsession with classical music, I couldn’t get enough of orchestras: Chicago, Boston, Cleveland, Philadelphia; occasionally even the London Symphony or the Berlin Philharmonic.

headline: At Tully Hall, the Norm Is a Festival
text: AT a time that advance ticket sales and season subscriptions have plunged because of economic concerns, arts presenters everywhere have turned to special events as a means to drum up excitement and shore up the bottom line. But now that celebrations are everywhere, how can any institution hope to compete? With Tully Scope, a monthlong series that starts on Tuesday, Lincoln Center proposes a novel solution: When festivals are the norm, why not make the norm a festival?

headline: Donizetti and Schwartz Fill Out Opera Program
text: AFTER a sparse season and a half of largely excellent productions under its general manager George Steel, New York City Opera is still struggling to attract audiences, a problem its eclectic spring season may address: there is something for everyone.

headline: Festivals of Cuba’s Finest And of the Avant-Garde
text: NEW YORK CITY music fans can get smug, thinking that sooner or later everything worth hearing will come to us. But some music has been in short supply. Musicians from Cuba, after a thaw in the 1990s around the Buena Vista Social Club, had a hard time negotiating performances in the United States during the Bush administration.

headline: Pop Sirens Flirt With Today And Yesterday
text: REMEMBER when it was just the coquette and the rebel? The current Lady Gaga mode of female pop star is both of those things and many more, all encased in latex and chains and ideas about the nature of performance. But about a decade ago, the rules were simpler. There was Britney Spears, injecting teen pop with knowing seduction, and a couple of years later came Avril Lavigne, a bratty mall punk who seemed to be the rejoinder to the hypersexuality of Ms. Spears (and Christina Aguilera).

headline: Metal, Electronica, Country and Jazz Are All on Tour
text: POP music festivals in 2011 face the same challenge as always: branding new dishes from the communal stew of touring bands. But through social media the tastemaking classes keep expanding, along with every alternative subculture; the festivals, in turn, keep swelling and diversifying, despite the economy.

headline: Backstage Beauty | Proenza Schouler
text: Fashion’s latest hairstylist darling, the charming Paul Hanlon, knows the Proenza Schouler girl quite well. Last season, he imagined she’d fallen asleep on a bus, and created what was meant to look like a French twist that had been battered by a long day (and a long commute, one assumes). This season, she’s grown her hair nearly to her elbows (Hanlon used 22-inch extensions) and pulled it into a low ponytail with some knotty nubs at the end. “When [designers Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez] called me in London, the first thing they said to me was that they loved the idea of the girls having really long hair. The first test we did, the girls had this really long straight hair, very blunt, but it didn’t feel like their woman — it was a bit army,” said Hanlon, adding that the boys were inspired by a cross-country road trip they’d just been on. As an alternative, Hanlon referenced photographer Edward S. Curtis’ portraits of American Indian women, their hair parted in the middle, heavy behind their shoulders. He began a very low braid, which he then tied with a black elastic, leaving the last loop halfway pulled through. After the tips of the hair were razor cut, the entire head was sprayed with Frederic Fekkai Sheer Hold Hairspray (through a net, a favorite Hanlon technique) for some “crunch.” “It’s like when girls go out and they leave their ponytail tucked into their jackets, and when they take it off it looks kind of wrong. I’m looking around at Diane’s assistants,” Hanlon said, referring to the makeup artist Diane Kendal, “and some of them walked in with their hair like that. It’s nice to have a wearable look. Hairstylists get a bit carried away sometimes.”

It was previously announced that Mark Rylance (of “La Bête”) and Mackenzie Crook (of Britain’s “The Office”) will reprise their roles as Johnny and his chum Ginger; they will be joined by Max Baker (“Cyrano de Bergerac”) as Wesley, Geraldine Hughes (“Translations”) as Dawn and Molly Ranson (“August: Osage County”) as Pea.

headline: Seeing Things | Donald Wexler, Desert Modernist
text: This weekend marks the kickoff of Modernism Week, Palm Springs’s annual celebration of all things midcentury modern. One of its highlights is “Steel and Shade: The Architecture of Donald Wexler,” an exhibition at the Palm Springs Art Museum. Wexler, 85, has practiced in Palm Springs for almost six decades, developing an architecture that is acutely sensitive to the extremes of the desert climate. Wexler’s all-steel Alexander houses, designed in 1962 with the structural engineer Bernard Perlin for the developers George and Robert Alexander, were sustainable before sustainability was trendy. Affordable, elegant and quick to assemble on site, thanks to a prefabricated structural system, Wexler’s houses (their framing, roofs and exterior siding are steel, with drywall interior siding) were the perfect answer to the postwar housing boom. “Steel, concrete and glass are ideal materials for the desert,” Wexler says. “They are inorganic and don’t deteriorate in the extreme temperatures of the desert.” And since these structures are relatively maintenance-free, the seven Alexander houses in a north Palm Springs enclave are as pristine today as they were almost 50 years ago.
