headline: Digging Deeper on Macondo
text: The commission appointed by President Obama to plumb the causes of the blowout of BP’s Macondo well in the Gulf of Mexico last year presented its findings a month ago. The seven-member panel essentially concluded that the accident and subsequent oil spill were the result of a cascade of management failures, regulatory oversights, missed signals and time-saving shortcuts that combined to take 11 lives and produce the worst offshore oil release in the nation’s history.

headline: Editor Outfits | Sara Moonves and Chelsea Zalopany
text: Sara Moonves, Fashion Editor“The Balenciaga boots are my all time favorite. I got them so many years ago and still wear them every winter,” says Moonves. “They are incredibly warm and although they look impossible to walk in, they are actually quite comfortable. It’s freezing this week and I’m always cold, so I pile up on shearling!” Moonves is also wearing: Givenchy coat, J. Crew T-shirt, Balenciaga skirt, motorcycle bag and boots.

headline: Agnotology
text: An interesting exchange between John Quiggin and Jonathan Chait on right-wing agnotology — that is, culturally-induced ignorance or doubt. The specific issue is birtherism, the claim that Barack Obama was born in Kenya or anyway not in America, which polls indicate is a view held by a majority of Republican primary voters.

headline: Budgetary Zugzwang
text: There is a situation in chess called zugzwang in which any legal move leaves the player worse off (in other words, he’d be better off to pass his turn). Oftentimes, in fact, the zugzwang is mutual: both players would rather that the other one move next. A typical situation — black’s only legal move would lead to a loss, but white’s only legal moves would turn an advantageous position into a draw — is illustrated below.

headline: Standoff in Yemen's Capital
text: Thousands of demonstrators, some supporting President Ali Abdullah Saleh and some seeking his downfall, clashed for hours in central Sana on Thursday.

headline: A Happy Orlando Homecoming for Lewis
text: The former Magic star Rashard Lewis found out Wednesday that warm feelings still flicker for him in Orlando. Lewis was traded to the Washington Wizards on Dec. 18, as part of a three-team deal that helped the Magic acquire Gilbert Arenas.

headline: Theater Talkback: Missing Maggie Smith
text: I am surely not the only theater fan suffering serious “Downton Abbey” withdrawal symptoms. “Masterpiece” may have surgically removed the word “theater” from its official title, as if the word were somehow a vestigial appendage of the pre-modern era. (Its presentations are now classified as “Masterpiece Classic” or “Mystery” or “Contemporary.”) But the pleasures afforded by this long-running television series overlap considerably with the satisfactions for which many of us look to the theater: a heightened literacy, refined wit, rich characterizations, absorbing narrative, plummy British accents.

headline: Digital Age Is Slow to Arrive in Rural America
text: COFFEEVILLE, Ala.  After a couple of days in this part of rural Alabama, it is hard to complain about a dropped iPhone call or a Cee Lo video that takes a few seconds too long to load.

headline: Daytona 500 Tribute Set for Earnhardt
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  The 10th anniversary of the fatal crash of Dale Earnhardt at Daytona International Speedway will pass Friday without an official tribute as a lower-level Camping World Series truck race is held at the track.

headline: Fiat to Recommend Premium Gasoline for 500 Subcompact
text: Prior to delivering the keynote address to the International Motor Press Association in midtown Manhattan on Thursday afternoon, Laura Soave, head of Fiat Brand North America, stopped by The New York Times to discuss the brand’s positioning in the American market.

headline: Guess Where This Is
text: Our guessing game last week may have been a little too easy. So this week, we’re trying something new: We’re asking you to guess the location of the photograph above, but we’re not giving you any hints.

headline: BP Challenges Spill Settlement Terms
text: BP is complaining that the proposed settlement amounts for people who suffered damages in the gulf spill are too generous, John Schwartz reports.

headline: Mizrahi: Let Them Eat Cake
text: It’s always such an annoyance that Fashion Week overlaps with the Westminster dog show, since few editors have time to keep up with the canine competition. A shame, too, considering there’s not that much difference between the two events — a bunch of preening poodles paraded around in a circle before an audience ready to point out their slightest flaws, or tell them they’re too fat.

headline: Now Streaming | Calvin Klein
text: The Fall/Winter 2011 women’s wear collection from Calvin Klein at New York fashion week, which will start at about 2:30 p.m.

headline: HTC Design Chief Talks About Its First Tablet, the Flyer
text: BARCELONA, Spain — Hardware makers are engineering new ways to make their mobile devices stand out. For HTC, the Taiwanese phone manufacturer, that meant revisiting an older idea: a tablet that can be scribbled on with a stylus.

headline: Some Spanish Savings Banks Want More Time to Recover
text: MADRID — Spanish savings banks, which have been ordered to raise more capital by the government, are facing an uphill struggle to persuade investors to help them improve their balance sheets.

headline: Hibernating Black Bear
text: A snoring black bear under infrared illumination during its hibernation in Fairbanks, Alaska.

headline: Progress Reported on Oil Plugging System
text: The big oil companies have a long way to go to recover from the BP well blowout that spilled millions of barrels of crude into the Gulf of Mexico. But on Thursday they took a step in the direction of drilling again by unveiling a new well-blowout plugging and spill containment system.

headline: Hibernating Bears Keep Thermostat Turned Up
text: Thanks to a few adventurous black bears that wandered too close to human communities in Alaska, scientists gained a rare glimpse into the species’ hibernation habits.

headline: Mattingly Provided Fitting Ending for His Biographer
text: PHOENIX – Mike Shalin’s biography of Don Mattingly will be published in March, a few weeks before Mattingly makes his managerial debut with the Los Angeles Dodgers against the reigning World Series champion San Francisco Giants.

headline: Family Maid Files Suit Against Author of ‘The Help’
text: JACKSON, Miss. – There is “The Help” and then there is the help. And she is not happy.

headline: Traction-Control Override a Possibility for 2012 VW GTI and Golf R
text: The sportiest Volkswagen models available in Europe for 2012 — the GTI, the Golf R and the Scirocco — will come standard with a new electronic stability system that can be fully disabled.

headline: A Historical Sleeper, on So Many Levels
text: LAST fall the Landmarks Preservation Commission extended the Upper East Side Historic District to include an odd, gangly patch mostly between Lexington and Third Avenues in the 60s and 70s.

headline: Visualizing Science
text: Some of the winning photographs and illustrations from the 2010 International Science and Engineering Visualization Challenge, sponsored by the journal Science and the National Science Foundation.

headline: Palin, on Long Island, Answers Budget and Worldview Questions
text: WOODBURY, N.Y. — Sarah Palin urged Congressional Republicans on Thursday to stand against raising the nation’s debt ceiling when the issue is debated this spring, declaring, “It doesn’t necessarily have to result in a government shutdown.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bahrain and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Bahrain, Yemen and Afghanistan.

headline: Weighing the New Subscription Services
text: Brian Stelter and David Carr discuss the new Apple and Google digital subscription models.

headline: Vocabulinks
text: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

headline: Google One Pass vs. Apple iPad Plan
text: Related: Google Announces Payment System for Digital ContentRelated: Apple Offers Subscriptions for Apps

headline: Mattingly Takes the Reins of the Troubled Dodgers
text: PHOENIX  It was Don Mattingly’s opening news conference at his first spring training as the Dodgers’ manager, and a seat at the head of a picnic table was reserved for him. Mattingly demurred and folded his 6-foot frame into another chair on an outdoor patio after casually brushing off a dried bird dropping stuck to it.

headline: Suez Canal Workers Join Broad Strikes in Egypt
text: CAIRO  Hundreds of workers went on strike on Thursday along the Suez Canal, one of the world’s strategic waterways, joining others across Egypt pressing demands for better wages and conditions. The protests have sent the economy reeling and defied the military’s attempt to restore a veneer of the ordinary after President Hosni Mubarak’s fall last week.

headline: A Word From Stieg Larsson’s Partner, and Would-Be Collaborator
text: PARIS – Eva Gabrielsson, the longtime partner of the late Swedish novelist Stieg Larsson, has written her version of their life together. “Millennium, Stieg and Me” is a slim memoir published in France, Sweden and Norway last month with a co-author, the French journalist Marie-Françoise Colombani.

headline: What Is President Obama Asking Tech Leaders?
text: Last year, I had an absolute blast “writing” a book called “The World According to Twitter.” The concept was this: every night, I’d pose a provocative question of my Twitter followers (then 500,000 of them; I’m @pogue on Twitter). I’d say, “Compose the subject line of an e-mail you really, really don’t want to open.” Or “Describe your first kiss.” Or “Tell the story of your brush with greatness.”

headline: Michigan Governor Proposes Budget Cuts and Lower Taxes
text: Rick Snyder, the newly elected Republican governor of Michigan, had promised to make big changes to state government on the campaign trail. When he released his first budget on Thursday, Mr. Snyder did just that by proposing huge spending cuts and lower business taxes.

headline: Asked & Answered | Charlotte Dellal
text: Nothing seems to faze her. Charlotte Dellal, the soul behind the soles of Charlotte Olympia, is in the middle of Fashion Week and her second pregnancy. She’s been traveling from London to New York and back to present her fall 2011 collection. Next up: Los Angeles for Coachella and, later this month, the premiere of charlotteolympia.com, her e-commerce site. Dellal is one-part Brazilian, one-part English and a total riot. She spoke with The Moment at the shoe salon at Bergdorf Goodman to reveal how she makes it all happen.

headline: Top Silicon Valley Execs to Meet With Obama
text: In the latest in a series of meetings involving President Obama and business leaders, a small group of top Silicon Valley executives plans to meet with Mr. Obama at a dinner on Thursday at the home of John Doerr, a prominent venture capitalist.

headline: Meet the Oscars, at Grand Central
text: Movie buffs eager to get up close to some Oscar glamour have a few options across the country. In New York, head to Grand Central for the Academy’s annual “Meet the Oscars” exhibit, in which you can put your grubby paws all over the naked little guy, for a few seconds at least. In Times Square, you can get yourself photographed with a virtual Oscar, and experience a few seconds of red carpet fame. But for the real deal experience we recommend getting a bunch of your photoblogger friends together and having them shout and point at you as you stand in front of a cardboard backdrop. Then stop to chat awkwardly with Ryan Seacrest, or maybe the Naked Cowboy.

headline: Military Crackdown in Bahrain
text: Thousands of people gathered at a hospital in Manama, the capital, just hours after the police opened fire on pro-democracy demonstrators camped in Pearl Square.

headline: Forecasting Is for the Birds (and Rats)
text: Apparently pigeons are better at forecasting than humans are. A reader sends along an article from The Durango Herald in Colorado, which says:

headline: Keeping Score: Sizing Up the All-Stars
text: Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Portland Trail Blazers.

headline: Excavating the Origins of Maya Civilization
text: Takeshi Inomata, a professor of anthropology at the University of Arizona, writes from Guatemala, where he and Daniela Triadan are excavating the Maya site of Ceibal, Guatemala.

headline: Q&A: Music and Lyrics on an iPod Touch
text: Q.

headline: Improving Elementary Education in India
text: A five-year-old project is trying to change how students are taught and tested in a country where rote memorization is the norm.

headline: Skipping Rote Memorization in Indian Schools
text: PANTNAGAR, India  The Nagla elementary school in this north Indian town looks like many other rundown government schools. Sweater-clad children sit on burlap sheets laid in rows on cold concrete floors. Lunch is prepared out back on a fire of burning twigs and branches.

headline: Palin, on Long Island, Takes Questions on Budget and Worldview
text: The Caucus blog, reporting from Woodbury, N.Y., on Long Island, has published a post on Sarah Palin’s speech there on Thursday. Speaking at a luncheon appearance before the Long Island Association, she urged Congressional Republicans not to shut down the government in order to pass the budget. Read the full post on The Caucus.

headline: Photo of the Day: New York Fashion Week
text: Mick Jagger at the L’Wren Scott presentation.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Jac Jagaciak at Ralph Lauren
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York Fashion Week. Here, the model Jac Jagaciak at IMG before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Tom Pecheux and hair by Guido Palau for Redken. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: Bieber Fever: Casting a Critical Eye on Celebrities and Popular Culture
text: Overview | What are pop culture idols and icons, and how do they both reflect and influence the prevailing culture? What does media coverage about popular stars say about them, the publications and the culture overall? In this lesson, students analyze the teenage singing sensation Justin Bieber through the lens of cultural criticism and consider some of the ways critics deconstruct other cultural heroes and heroines.

headline: A.D.H.D.: To Medicate or Not to Medicate?
text: Do drugs for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder need to be taken for life? Are they dangerous? Are there alternatives to medications? There are among the questions posed by readers of the Consults blog. Dr. Russell A. Barkley, clinical professor of psychiatry at the Medical University of South Carolina and author, most recently, of “Taking Charge of Adult A.D.H.D.,”  responds.

headline: ‘Whale Wars’ Waits on Japanese Government
text: Reports that Japan has suspended whaling in the waters off Antarctica and is considering canceling the remainder of its current season have whale lovers wondering whether their favorite seagoing mammals might get a permanent reprieve from hunting, at least in the Southern Hemisphere. But reality-television lovers have another question: What does this mean for “Whale Wars”?

headline: Bill Monroe, ‘Meet the Press’ Host, Dies at 90
text: Bill Monroe, a television journalist whose long career with NBC included stints as the network’s Washington bureau chief and moderator of its Sunday interview program, “Meet the Press,” died on Thursday at a nursing home in Potomac, Md. He was 90.

headline: House Forges Ahead on Spending Cuts
text: House Republicans on Thursday continued their steady march toward approving the largest spending cuts in modern history – a swift, huge slash of more than $60 billion from domestic programs and foreign aid that Republicans said would fulfill their promise to shrink government outlays, but Democrats said would harm the fragile economic recovery.

headline: Calvin Klein’s Controlled Take on the Season
text: Francisco Costa’s women’s collection for Calvin Klein was the last major show of New York Fashion Week, before editors head off to London, then Milan and Paris for more shows. Mr. Costa’s runway was, as usual, full of controlled and clean sportswear looks, some in the same materials we’ve seen popping up from runway to runway.

headline: When Trauma Lingers
text: Post-traumatic stress disorder doesn't only affect war veterans. It may also affect that young girl walking her dog down the street.

headline: Remedies: Clove Oil for Tooth Pain
text: More than a third of American adults use some form of complementary or alternative medicine, according to a government report. Natural remedies have an obvious appeal, but how do you know which ones to choose and whether the claims are backed by science? In this occasional series, Anahad O’Connor, the New York Times “Really?” columnist, explores the claims and the science behind alternative remedies that you may want to consider for your family medicine cabinet.

text: Bessemer, Ala.

text: DealBook's Andrew Ross Sorkin speaks to Felix Salmon, finance blogger at Reuters, about whether the recent merger between Deutsche Boerse and NYSE Euronext marks the impending death of exchanges.

headline: How Would You Tinker With Graduation Requirements?
text: Last week, New York State education officials released a new set of statewide graduation statistics showing that only 41 percent of students are leaving high school prepared for college and well-paying careers, even though 77 percent of students are graduating.

headline: Pogue’s Posts: What Is Obama Asking Tech Leaders?
text: On his blog, David Pogue writes about how he inspired an outburst of humor on Twitter with a message about President Obama’s meeting with technology leaders.

headline: In Belgium, Beer and Frites Honor Political Failure
text: BRUSSELS  What does it take to form a government?

headline: Lucas, Burns, Souter Among Those Named To New Commission on the Liberal Arts
text: As public and private colleges and universities have been forced to make painful budget cuts in the past couple of years, many educators have worried that the humanities are getting short shrift. To bolster support for teaching and research in the liberal arts, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences on Thursday announced the creation of a national commission on the humanities and social sciences. The panel was established at the request of a group of Democratic and Republican senators who asked the academy for a top 10 list of actions that government, educators and philanthropists could take to maintain excellence in the humanities and social sciences and strengthen civil society.

headline: The ‘Toy Story’ Gang to Ride Again
text: LOS ANGELES— “Toy Story” fans, rejoice. Pixar will release two new short films starring Woody and pals by year’s end. The first short, “Hawaiian Vacation,” will run with “Cars 2,” which will arrive in theaters on June 24. Pixar unveiled “Hawaiian Vacation” at a gathering of about 300 Disney investors and analysts in Anaheim, Calif., on Thursday. (Barbie and Ken try to stow away with Bonnie for a Hawaiian trip but get left home, to their enormous disappointment; Woody, Buzz and the other toys try to console the pair by improvising an island vibe but . . . it doesn’t go well.) The second short — a title was not announced — will run with “The Muppets,” a Disney feature film set for a Thanksgiving release.

headline: In Miami, Flames Take Vacant Art Deco Buildings
text: Someone is apparently trying to burn down vacant, but once grand, Art Deco buildings in Miami Beach, home to one of the world’s largest collection of such buildings.

headline: Guest List for Obama’s Dinner With Technology Leaders
text: President Obama will sit down for dinner with a dozen of the titans of the American technology industry Thursday night at the Silicon Valley home of the venture capitalist John Doerr, according to two people familiar with the president’s plans.

text: The United States' response to Bahrain's crackdown; Egypt's military economy; and evidence of illegal detention and torture in Egypt.

headline: 36 Hours in Downtown Los Angeles
text: The long-blighted center has become an accessible, pedestrian-friendly destination in recent years.

headline: 36 Hours in Downtown Los Angeles
text: THE sprawl, the scale, all that freeway time — for many, Los Angeles is an acquired taste. But not downtown. New York-like in its density and mishmash, the long-blighted center has become an accessible, pedestrian-friendly destination in recent years; Angelenos walk around en masse, using their actual legs. The immense L.A. Live entertainment complex is largely responsible for this comeback, but the studiously vintage bars and imaginative restaurants that seem to open every other day are also part of the revival. Skid Row and the drifts of homeless camps haven’t vanished altogether, and the grittiness still varies by block. But this part of town is alive again, in ways that make sense even to an outsider.

headline: Miley’s Father’s Regrets
text: Billy Ray Cyrus has regrets. In a long article by Chris Heath in the March issue of GQ he talks about watching his marriage unravel, and of seeing videos of his apparently stoned daughter, Miley, go viral.

headline: Fashion Week Parties, Night 7
text: Scenes from Wednesday night, including an uptown gala for Van Cleef & Arpels, and downtown fetes for Proenza Schouler and Adam Kimmel.

text: Editors’ Note: This post includes descriptions of the historical background similar to material the same author published in The Daily News in 2000. Had editors known of the earlier article, those passages would not have been used. Two other posts by this author also included descriptions similar to material he had previously written for The Daily News.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Wrap-Up
text: Eric Wilson highlights the fall season's emerging trends and the collections of Jason Wu, Marc Jacobs and Alexander Wang, which embraced lace, new silhouettes and big coats.

headline: Long After Fall, Countrywide’s Mozilo Defended His Legacy
text: More than two years after Countrywide Financial nearly collapsed under the weight of souring subprime home loans, Angelo R. Mozilo passionately defended the mortgage lender that he founded before a government panel.

headline: Artful Commentary, Oozing From the Walls
text: The New Museum has become a busy place this year, and it is not yet even March. In January it opened a popular tribute to the market-hardy paintings of George Condo. Now it is offering a startlingly excellent resurrection of the prescient Post-Minimalist renegade Lynda Benglis and her gaudy, multidexterous and often gender-bending segues among Process, Performance and Body Art.

headline: Cindy Sherman’s Guises All in a Single Place
text: A Cindy Sherman retrospective is planned for MoMA next year; Elizabeth Peyton has a show connected to Wagner opera at Gallery Met; and the Walther Collection Project Space is opening in Chelsea.

text: Photographs from Bahrain, Yemen and Afghanistan.

headline: When Enamel Wares Adorned China’s Imperial Courts
text: Many human beings evidently share with the magpie a gene causing an irrational attraction to bright and shiny objects. If you suffer from this disorder, you will love “Cloisonné: Chinese Enamels From the Yuan, Ming and Qing Dynasties,” a ravishing exhibition at the Bard Graduate Center.

headline: TimesCast | February 16, 2011
text: As protests spread across the Middle East, the United States delivers a different diplomatic message to its friends and its foes; and Nicholas D. Kristof from Bahrain.

headline: A Museum Isn’t Rebuilt Every Minute
text: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. — “This was the most contaminated room,” Kathleen Maher said, pointing to powdery debris, paint flakes and glass shards on shelves and carpeting in a dimly lighted ground-floor gallery at her work space. She is curator and executive director at the Barnum Museum here, where last June a tornado struck its 1890s brick building.

headline: Fight Club | Danielle Levitt’s ‘Pride of Lowell’
text: The photographer Danielle Levitt has an eye for disaffected youth. Her 2008 monograph “We Are Experienced” compiled more than 100 portraits of American teenagers taken over several years as Levitt hopscotched across the country shooting features and fashion editorials for Interview, Arena Homme Plus and The New York Times Magazine, among many others. Levitt began her career shooting a street style column for The Wall Street Journal, a natural window onto the downtown scene, and her work has evolved to include “werewolves” in Texas for Dazed & Confused and sissy bouncers for Arena Homme Plus. This fall, she was sent to Lowell, Mass., to shoot Mickey Ward and Dicky Eklund, the real-life characters behind David O. Russell’s Oscar-nominated film “The Fighter”; the magazine assignment turned into a new series of portraits and a collection of short films. “Pride of Lowell,” curated by Naheed Simjee, will opened on Wednesday at Los Angeles’s Known Gallery. T caught up with Levitt via e-mail to talk about the show.

headline: Met Backtracks on Drop in Average Audience Age
text: 5:52 p.m. | Updated

headline: Taking a Hard Line: Immigrants and Crime
text: After months of internal wrangling and confusion over an ambitious nationwide program allowing state and local police agencies to identify immigrants with criminal records, Obama administration immigration officials have decided to take a hard line against communities that try to delay or cancel their participation in the program, according to documents made public late Wednesday.

headline: Dress Code Snaps Back
text: My friend and I work as legal assistants at the same law firm. We both bought jeggings, and wore them to work with long tops. Her boss didn’t say anything, but mine told me they were inappropriate for the office, and that I shouldn’t wear them again. I don’t think that’s fair. What do you think?

headline: Where the Yarns, and the People, Are Colorful
text: THERE is a store on the Upper West Side where the walls are splashed with a thousand colors  deep indigo, lime green, creamy beige, grape-gum purple, reds, oranges, blues and black. But not from paint; the walls are lined with cubbies filled with knots of colored yarn.

headline: Buzz Tracker
text: Not a Bubble, a Pyramid Scheme Mark Cuban on the sky-high Internet valuations: “Remember the old chain letter, where you put up some money, then you got other people to put up some money, and you gave it to the people who were in the deal before you? That’s what’s happening today.” PE Hub

headline: Britain Begins an Overhaul of Welfare
text: LONDON  The British government on Thursday introduced legislation meant to simplify and reduce the cost of the country’s welfare system, saying that it wanted to change a culture in which welfare recipients risked losing income if they found jobs.

headline: Backstage Beauty | L’Wren Scott
text: “A dangerous eye — that’s what L’Wren said to me,” said the makeup artist Aaron de Mey backstage at L’Wren Scott. “It conjured up images of smokiness. I also love this kid Taylor Momsen very much — it’s interesting to see how a teenager would apply her makeup.” To wit, de Mey created an exaggerated version of the kind of black eye makeup he said Scott herself always wears, which included heaps of Lancome Hypnose Mascara (in black, of course) and black eye shadow layered over pencil for a gothic look. “There’s no highlight, no skin showing through,” he said. The hairstylist Serge Normant also was inspired by the designer: “The way L’Wren wears things, it doesn’t look overly done. The girls aren’t supposed to look like her, but I wanted that easiness.” Hair was brushed into a deep side part with volume added through the crown of the head for a “just woke up” look, which Normant set with products from his new namesake product line. The manicurist Yuna Park filled out the look with one coat of a gold-flecked black nail polish from Lancome called Noir 29, available this fall. You know you love it. XOXO.

headline: On Our Radar: Britain Drops Plan to Sell Forests
text: Conservative Party leaders in Britain abandon a controversial plan to sell off virtually all of the country’s publicly owned forests over the next decade. The proposal, which would have sold off even historic woodlands like the Forest of Dean and Sherwood Forest, generated widespread public outrage that had shown no signs of abating. “I am sorry, we got this one wrong, but we have listened to people’s concerns,” Environment Secretary Caroline Spelman told the House of Commons. [The Guardian]

headline: China Rail Chief’s Firing Hints at Trouble

headline: Stuck in Traffic, Woman Gives Birth at Lincoln Tunnel

headline: Castaways, Soldiers and a Good Car Chase
text: The programmers for Film Comment Selects possess the refined tastes of practiced cine-mixologists, along with a yen for the outré. For the 11th edition of this two-week annual festival, which starts on Friday at the Walter Reade Theater, they have exhumed the old and rounded up the new, unearthing treasures and curiosities to put next to recent movies with and without American distribution. This is one event in which you can see the latest from a giant of cinema like Claude Lanzmann and spend the rest of the time with French castaways, two of the fastest fists ever to fly out of China and a gang of British thieves whose whiplashing car chases in Peter Yates’s “Robbery” (1967) anticipate the burning rubber in his next film, “Bullitt.”

headline: The Scene: Fashion Week Day 8
text: Backstage scenes from the Isaac Mizrahi show on the final day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Relocating Tenants

headline: At the Bus Station, Who Else but Paris Hilton?
text: Spotted at the Port Authority on Thursday afternoon: Paris Hilton.

headline: An Artist Remembered
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Benefit to Keep Bartenders Healthy
text: Tipplers can drink to the future health of bartenders on Monday at Salud! Bartenders for Healthcare, a charity cocktail party co-sponsored by the United States Bartenders’ Guild. The event will be held on the second floor of Freemans, the Bowery-area bar that has produced some of the city’s best mixologists. Proceeds will help pay bartenders’ medical bills.

headline: The Band Plays On: An Economic Study
text: Rock stars normally hand out lessons about sex, drugs and trashing hotel rooms. But a battle between a dance-rock outfit, LCD Soundsystem and ticketing agents over the band’s “last” show offers a strange insight into the laws of supply and demand. On top of that, the kerfuffle reveals the distortions underlying the music business.

headline: Hoop Dreams Next for ‘Lombardi’ Producers: A Larry Bird-Magic Johnson Play
text: The producers behind “Lombardi,” about the storied Green Bay Packers football coach Vince Lombardi, are shifting to basketball for their next Broadway-aimed sports play. “Magic/Bird” will dramatize the fierce on-court rivalry and friendship between two Hall of Fame stars: Magic Johnson and Larry Bird.

headline: Bahrain: A Diplomatic Puzzle
text: Does the unexpected violent crackdown in Bahrain mean the U.S. will change its relationship with its close ally?

headline: One Prospect for President Isn’t Talking, but France Is
text: PARIS  The latest play to grip France might be called “En Attendant D.S.K.” Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, is absent, like Godot in Samuel Beckett’s famous play, “En Attendant Godot,” or “Waiting for Godot,” making it easier to argue about him.

headline: A Wagnerian Quest in Proper English
text: LONDON  The English National Opera introduced the German director Nikolaus Lehnhoff’s production of Wagner’s “Parsifal” in 1999, and since then this influential modern staging, which presents the Knights of the Grail as a spiritually decaying brotherhood in a bleakly gray, postapocalyptic and timeless setting, has traveled far. It was presented by the San Francisco Opera and the Lyric Opera of Chicago, the staging’s co-producers; it played the Baden-Baden Festival in Germany in 2004, where it was filmed for a DVD release; and it had a run at the Gran Teatre del Liceu in Barcelona.

headline: In His Own Words, a Singular Man’s Double Life
text: The British travel writer and novelist Bruce Chatwin (1940-89) had blond hair, flinty blue eyes and delicately firm features  he looked like a bookish member of the Police, Sting’s band, circa 1983  and the kind of narcissism that can be a byproduct of talent mixed with charisma.

headline: Canada Hit by Cyberattack
text: OTTAWA  A federal cabinet minister said Thursday that hackers, perhaps from China, compromised computers in two Canadian government departments in early January, leaving bureaucrats with little or no Internet access for nearly two months.

headline: Classical Mash-Up and Remix
text: The Tune-In festival at the Park Avenue Armory promises to explore musical connections between past and present, as well as a few philosophical notions, like whether music has the power to express anything. (Stravinsky said that it does not; others have disagreed.)

headline: A Soft Pop Chanteuse, Striking Delicate Poses
text: Poised and whispery, Vanessa Paradis played her New York City debut as a headliner at Town Hall on Wednesday night. In France, Ms. Paradis has been a pop star since she was 14, when her single “Joe le Taxi” was a No. 1 hit in 1987, and where she won the Victoires de la Musique award, the equivalent of a Grammy, for album of the year with her 2007 album “Divinidylle” (Barclay). Outside Europe, she is better known as an actress and model, but she has begun a world tour with her band, coinciding with the American release of her compilation “Best Of” (Decca).

headline: Space for Spices, Gadgets and Guests
text: AT his house in New Rochelle, Reginald Johnson cooked and baked in his dream kitchen, where he used a 60-inch-wide Wolf range to make delicacies like butternut squash ravioli and rosemary-olive-oil cake.

headline: Wall Street Pay Still Doesn’t Consider Risk, Study Finds
text: In the wake of the financial crisis, politicians, regulators and others slammed Wall Street for handing out supersize pay packages, saying they encouraged excessive risk-taking.

headline: Flamenco With Plenty of Volume
text: New York’s flamencophiles are deprived of their annual Flamenco Festival this year, thanks to financial cutbacks in Spain. (The hope is to continue it biennially instead.) In its place, however, is a weeklong season of the filmmaker Carlos Saura’s “Flamenco Hoy” (“Flamenco Today”) at City Center.

headline: A Doctor Beaten by Police
text: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof talked with the family of a physician who was beaten by police after he tried to help injured protesters.

headline: Disappearing People, Leaving a Lot of Clothes Behind
text: The something wicked that comes creeping like night in “Vanishing on 7th Street,” turning down the sun and seemingly sucking people right out of their homes, offices, cars and clothes, arrives without warning. One minute moviegoers are yukking it up at a multiplex in this generally nifty little horror flick, and the next minute they’ve disappeared, their emptied-out clothes a spooky reminder of their existence, one that brings to mind the silhouetted shadows left behind after the bombs decimated Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

headline: New York Winter Bird-Watching
text: While the birds travel far, New Yorkers don’t need to.

headline: Bloomberg Offers ‘Good News’ on New York’s Budget
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, in unveiling his budget proposal on Thursday, summed up New York City’s financial health with a phrase scarcely heard in the halls of government these days: “It’s good news.”

headline: The Puppets of 'Compulsion'
text: Matt Acheson talks about the puppets he designed for Rinne Groff's play "Compulsion."

headline: Geometry in Motion, With Costumes
text: Walter Dundervill is just fine with letting his imagination run wild, and that’s evident in “Aesthetic Destiny 1: Candy Mountain,” performed at Dance Theater Workshop on Wednesday night, where the terrain of the stage is decorated with colorful polygons of varying sizes.

headline: Tooth-and-Claw Life of a Dedicated Single Mother
text: One of the most urgent and certainly among the most beautifully shot documentaries to hit the big screen in recent memory, “The Last Lions” isn’t just another cute and fuzzy encounter session with a different species. It’s a pulse-quickening, tear-duct milking and outrageously dramatized story about the threats — wildfires, chomping teeth, stampeding hooves and, worst of all, unseen humans — that face a female lion trying to protect her cubs. Here, single motherhood doesn’t mean juggling family, work and PTA meetings: it means parking the tots in the bushes and then trying to take down a water buffalo the size of a jeep.

headline: Perfect, With Childbearing Hips
text: SEVERAL years ago I went to the California Cryobank’s Web site to buy sperm. I was single and a lesbian and wanted to have a baby. I’d always wanted a family and dreamed of creating one with a partner, but I’d proved to be a love loser. When it didn’t work out with anybody, including my most recent ex (after six years of couples counseling, meditation, acupuncture, hypnosis), I gave up.

headline: A Strong Debut for ‘Criminal’ Spinoff
text: Although a two-hour “Hollywood week” episode of Fox’s “American Idol” topped the ratings on Wednesday, CBS’s new series “Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior,” with Janeane Garofalo and Forest Whitaker, delivered a strong debut at 10 p.m. According to Nielsen’s estimates 12.9 million viewers tuned in to the new procedural spinoff, slightly more than the original “Criminal Minds” (12.8 million) at 9. The new show outperformed ABC’s “Off the Map” (4.3 million) and NBC’s “Law & Order: SVU” (7.3 million). Fox led over all with “Idol” from 8 to 10 (22.8 million), CBS was second and saw below-average ratings for its season premiere of “Survivor: Redemption Island” (11.2 million). ABC placed a distant third and NBC was fourth.

headline: Me, My Doppelgänger and a Dunk in the River
text: Liam Neeson’s latter-day renaissance as an unlikely action star should give hope to performers and viewers of a certain age (i.e., over 40) everywhere. While that irrepressible exhibitionist Helen Mirren, born in 1945, continues to inspire legions of AARP members, one discarded garment at a time, Mr. Neeson, a comparative pup born in 1952, is doing much the same, one hard-swinging fist after another.

headline: Weekend Miser
text: Next week is midwinter break for New York public schools, and parents all over the city are scrambling to find a way to occupy ... sorry, entertain, their kids.

headline: Kickboxing Express and Other 30-Minute Workouts
text: UNTIL recently, I was convinced that a worthwhile workout meant at least an hour. But my trainer challenged me to consider 20- to 30-minute programs that she promised would push me just as hard as our 60 minutes together. When these high-intensity sessions of jumping rope and other powerful movements became even more strenuous than my longer routines, I was a convert.

headline: Time Inc. Chief Executive Jack Griffin Out
text: The chief executive of Time Inc., Jack Griffin, is leaving the company after less than six months on the job — forced out over what company executives said was a widespread sense that his management style was brusque and did not fit the corporate culture there.

headline: Joyce Carol Oates’s Widow’s Lament
text: “Writing up a storm, eh, Joyce?” Shortly after the sudden death of Joyce Carol Oates’s husband, Raymond Smith, in February 2008, an acquaintance put that familiar question to her. A closer friend was sure that words were tumbling forth, too. “Knowing how you write,” the friend said in a condolence note, “you may already be completing the first of many novels that will help you explore what you’ve been experiencing.” Oates felt herself “shaking with cold, with a kind of choked fury.” The Wonder Woman of American Letters, as she learned an exhibitor of her vast array of books had christened her, could not compose even a thank-you note. “Yes it’s true that I used to be a writer — a writer with a very mixed reputation — ‘controversial’ is the kindest term,” she imagined trying to explain at a somewhat calmer moment. “But now — I am not a writer now. I am not anything now. Legally I am a ‘widow’ — that is the box I must check. But beyond that — I am not sure that I ­exist.”

headline: Stories of Love and Grief
text: When we speak of literary taste, we may imagine we refer to preferences regarding subject matter, genre, form and the varieties of narrative prowess. But much of what taste in reading boils down to is less conducive to objective analysis, less neatly parceled into scholarly-sounding brackets. Simply, it’s the extent to which we take pleasure in the company of the author — or rather, a facsimile thereof, a phantom version composed of and subsisting on words alone.

headline: Tales of Teenage Aliens
text: Strip away the uninspired mythology, and “I Am Number Four” is just your average high school movie with below-average drama. Fielding familiar classroom stereotypes — the bully, the science geek, the strutting alien female in the skintight cat suit — this turgid schedule filler is only marginally more fun than a week’s worth of detention.

headline: Morning T: Cecilia Dean

headline: Pride of Place, Brighter Than Ever
text: Rembrandt’s jowly, battered face glows like a night light in the great late self-portrait from 1658 at the Frick Collection. And it glows more brightly than ever now that layers of old varnish have been cleaned away.

headline: ‘Immigration Tango,’ International Love
text: It’s fine to employ a plot device that’s been used repeatedly. But you run into trouble when you use a familiar plot and do only the familiar with it.

headline: Where the Yarns, and the People, Are Colorful

There are reds, oranges, blues and black. But not from paint; the walls are lined with cubbies filled with knots of colored yarn.

headline: Send in the Russian Clown and His Pain and Alienation, Too

So here he is, all the way from St. Petersburg, Russia, the man who put the madcap in madness. Put your hands together for the stand-up stylings of Aksentii Poprishchin.

headline: ‘The Chaperone’: Wrestling With Laughs
text: It’s too bad that Paul Levesque is so, well, large. Mr. Levesque — a professional wrestler whose ring name is Triple H — is a perfectly tolerable actor, as he shows in “The Chaperone,” a lightweight comedy aimed, presumably, at tweeners and fans of World Wrestling Entertainment, whose film division generated this project. But the guy’s so outsize that we’re never likely to see him as anything other than a thug or a gentle giant.

headline: Among Egypt’s Missing, Tales of Torture and Prison
text: CAIRO  Ramadan Aboul Hassan left his house one night about three weeks ago to join a neighborhood watch group with two friends and did not return. The next time their relatives saw the three men they were emerging Wednesday night from a maximum security prison, 400 miles from home, run by Egypt’s military. Some family members said they bore signs of torture, though others denied it.

headline: A Go-Slow Approach in Patrick’s Second Year in Nascar
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  The Danica Patrick Nascar experiment enters its second season on Saturday at Daytona International Speedway, with expectations tempered but hopes raised.

headline: Loveless and Aimless in New York City
text: “Loveless” is an aimless film about an aimless fellow, but it’s not without its charms. It may be without a point, but hey, you can’t have everything in a no-budget film like this.

headline: Habitats | Upper West Side
text: Vivian Berger and Michael Finkelstein are the sole occupants of the 29th floor at Ariel East on Broadway and 100th Street. They have a 360-degree view from their four-bedroom apartment, and have added built-in shelves for their thousands of books.

headline: Been There, Done That, and Now Going to This
text: THE theater critics of The New York Times are not the only ones willing to opine on spring theater highlights. We also polled a random assortment of Tony Award winners and nominees from last season to find out what they are most excited about seeing in the coming months. Here are some of their answers; for more go to nytimes.com/theater. STEVEN McELROY

headline: On Long Island, Palin Opens Up and Plays Coy
text: WOODBURY, N.Y. — Sarah Palin did not visit Iowa or New Hampshire on Thursday, and she did not drop by South Carolina or Nevada. But inside a country club ballroom here, as she logged another stop as a paid speaker, she said she could not wait much longer to decide her future.

headline: Joe Frazier, Who Managed Mets in Turbulent Time, Is Dead at 88
text: Joe Frazier, the manager of the Mets in the turbulent period between the tenures of Yogi Berra and Joe Torre, died Tuesday in Broken Arrow, Okla. He was 88 and a longtime Broken Arrow resident.

headline: Comic Advice: Be Wary on Broadway
text: THE news that “Kathy Griffin Wants a Tony!,” as her Broadway-bound comedy show is titled, means even more crowding on Broadway this spring. It’s hard to remember a season in which more comedians and comic actors decided to give the stage a try, sometimes in roles that aren’t quite laugh-a-minute. Here’s a guide to the new arrivals, with advice from one who got there first: the stand-up comedian Colin Quinn, whose solo show “Long Story Short” opened on Broadway in November and plays through March 5.

headline: ‘We Are What We Are’: They Are What They Eat

text: Essentially a two-person play liberally sprinkled with gleaming, groovy, graphic sex, “Now & Later” exudes an amiably accessible vibe that softens the edges of its freewheeling explicitness.

headline: Willie Sutton Wept
text: There are three things you need to know about the current budget debate. First, it’s essentially fraudulent. Second, most people posing as deficit hawks are faking it. Third, while President Obama hasn’t fully avoided the fraudulence, he’s less bad than his opponents  and he deserves much more credit for fiscal responsibility than he’s getting.

headline: In Puerto Rico, Protests End Short Peace at University
text: SAN JUAN, P.R.  Months of unrest at the University of Puerto Rico seemed to be reaching a finale over the last 10 days. Scores of students were arrested or injured by riot police officers. Faculty and staff members held a two-day walkout. The president of the university resigned Friday, the police who had occupied campus were withdrawn Monday and an interim president arrived Tuesday.

And during New York Fashion Week, many designers, including Narciso Rodriguez and Joseph Altuzarra, used computerized prints.

headline: Looks Like Banks Lose on Risk Plea

headline: Allen Stanford, Indicted Financier, Sues Authorities

headline: Now Bahrain
text: King Hamad bin Isa al-Khalifa of Bahrain is the latest autocrat to choose brutality, rather than reform, to try to silence his people’s demands for a more just government. His actions are unconscionable and miss the lessons of Egypt and Tunisia where violence only fed popular anger. Hosni Mubarak and Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali are now gone.

headline: Live From a Favorite TV Show: Items Branded With It

Now, shelves are also filling up with merchandise bearing the names of the channels and networks on which the stars appear.

headline: The Thomas Issue

headline: As Online Communications Stymie Wiretaps, Lawmakers Debate Solutions
text: WASHINGTON  Leading Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee on Thursday reacted skeptically to the idea of overhauling surveillance laws to make it easier to wiretap people who communicate online rather than by telephone, a major priority for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

headline: Dispute Over Cancer Tied to Implants
text: When talking to patients about a rare type of cancer linked to breast implants, plastic surgeons should call it “a condition” and avoid using the words cancer, tumor, disease or malignancy, the president of the American Society of Plastic Surgeons advised members during an online seminar on Feb. 3.

headline: Daisy, Daisy
text: The most charming moments from Watson, the I.B.M. computer that clobbered two brilliant human champions on “Jeopardy!” were when Watson wasn’t certain or failed. Those moments did not come often, but virtual humanity seemed most at hand when they did. Then his/her/its wagers on the answers would turn cautious and Watson even flashed question marks of self-doubt, as if to acknowledge the lack of a brow to furrow.

headline: Tomorrow Never Comes
text: Jonathan Alter wrote a book about Barack Obama’s first year in office called “The Promise.” That’s a great title because it works on so many levels. For example, over the past four years, Obama’s career has been marked by a constant promise: He has continually said he is on the verge of doing something serious abut the national debt.

headline: Administration Seeks Clarity From Judge on Health Ruling
text: The Obama administration asked a federal judge on Thursday to clarify whether his recent ruling against the new health care law was meant to block its implementation pending appeals.

headline: IPad Service Draws Scrutiny
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple’s new subscription service for iPad and iPhone applications, which has drawn complaints from some publishers, has also drawn the attention of federal antitrust regulators, according to a person with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: House Spending Impasse Raises Risk of Shutdown
text: WASHINGTON — The House speaker, John A. Boehner of Ohio, said Thursday that Republicans would not agree to a short-term extension of the spending measure now financing the federal government without additional cuts, sharply raising the stakes in a war of wills with Democrats that officials say could lead to a government shutdown early next month.

headline: Egyptians Say Military Discourages an Open Economy
text: CAIRO  The Egyptian military defends the country, but it also runs day care centers and beach resorts. Its divisions make television sets, jeeps, washing machines, wooden furniture and olive oil, as well as bottled water under a brand reportedly named after a general’s daughter, Safi.

headline: New York Police Plan to Quit Bank Robbery Task Force
text: The New York Police Department has informed the Federal Bureau of Investigation that it plans to pull all six of its detectives from a joint task force that investigates armed bank robberies, according to law enforcement officials with knowledge of the plan.

headline: Planned Parenthood Financing Is Caught in Budget Feud

headline: Santana’s Return Is Still Months Away

headline: Madagascar: Ex-President to Return
text: The deposed president Marc Ravalomanana, left, living in exile since March 2009, announced Thursday that he would return to his island nation on Saturday even though the current government threatens to jail him. Speaking to reporters in Johannesburg, he repeatedly sidestepped questions about his possible arrest and the risk that his presence could incite civil war. “I will bring peaceful dialogue,” he insisted. Mr. Ravalomanana, twice elected Madagascar’s president, was ousted by a military-backed coup and then convicted in absentia on murder charges resulting from the killing of protesters by the presidential guard.

headline: Suit Suggests Political Party Knew of Fraud

headline: Two Pitching Stars From the Past Hope for a Future in Pinstripes
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Freddy Garcia dipped into his memory bank the other morning, his mind drifting to a Seattle special of an afternoon, cool and overcast, during the 2001 playoffs, when he was the 25-year-old ace of the Mariners. Garcia recalled how Bartolo Colon pumped fastball after fastball past his Seattle teammates to secure the division series opener for the Cleveland Indians.

headline: China: Deal With Russia Denied
text: The Chinese Foreign Ministry on Thursday denied a report that Chinese and Russian companies had agreed to start a joint venture in islands that are disputed by Russia and Japan. Kyodo News, a Japanese news agency, had reported that the companies intended to farm sea cucumbers, a delicacy among Chinese, on one of four islands near the northeast coast of Hokkaido, Japan. Russia has reportedly invited enterprises from other countries to invest in businesses there, but so far there has been no third-party investment. “The issue regarding the four northern islands is a bilateral issue between Russia and Japan, and we hope the two sides will properly handle the issue through talks,” said Ma Zhaoxu, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, according to official Chinese news reports.

headline: Tucson Firefighter Refused to Respond
text: PHOENIX  A Tucson firefighter refused to respond to the Jan. 8 shooting rampage that wounded Representative Gabrielle Giffords because of political differences with his crew, delaying his unit’s arrival at the scene, according to internal department records.

headline: China’s ‘Soft Prohibition’

headline: China’s Intimidation of Dissidents Said to Persist After Prison
text: DONGSHIGU, China  Chen Guangcheng is officially a free man, but it is hard to imagine a life more constrained. One of the country’s most prominent rights defenders, Mr. Chen is confined to his home 24 hours a day by security agents and hired peasant men armed with sticks, bricks and walkie-talkies. Visitors who try to see him are physically repulsed and sometimes beaten. Blinding floodlights illuminate his stone farmhouse at night.

headline: Va-Va-Voom Goes the Soprano

Commissioned by, no less, the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden? When the plans were announced, it sounded like a dubious idea, a tawdry way for a major opera house to look hip.

headline: Squashing the Ivies
text: One day in 1996, Trinity College’s new president, Evan Dobelle, called the men’s squash coach into his office. Dobelle was an unconventional hire. He didn’t complete his bachelor’s degree until he was 39, working in politics — mayor of Pittsfield, Mass., aide to President Carter, treasurer of the Democratic National Committee — then running first one, then another community college. But Trinity was a troubled institution, and the trustees weren’t looking for another tweedy scholar. Enrollment was down even as the liberal-arts school was accepting 65 percent of all applicants — a striking contrast to its rivals Amherst and Williams, which typically admit fewer than 20 percent of their applicant pools. The biggest problem was Trinity’s immediate surroundings, the crime-­ridden, blighted neighborhood of Frog Hollow in Hartford. So Dobelle started an ambitious $225 million public-private urban-renewal project to improve the area — including the construction of three schools and a performing-arts center — without pushing its residents out. Then he turned to the college’s sports programs, wondering if there might not be a quicker way to improve Trinity’s brand.

headline: U.S. Tries to Head Off Vote Against Israeli Settlements
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration was trying Thursday evening to head off an imminent vote in the United Nations Security Council that would declare Israel’s settlement construction in the West Bank illegal, but would not declare publicly whether it was prepared to veto the resolution.

headline: Argentina: U.S. Intended to ‘Respect’ Argentine Law
text: The United States responded Thursday to the seizure by Argentina last week of American military equipment, saying it had approached a planned joint police-training program with a “clear commitment to respect applicable Argentine law.” The diplomatic rift escalated Wednesday when Argentina’s cabinet chief, Anibal Fernandez, demanded an apology from the United States for what he called insults against his country’s foreign minister. Argentine officials had accused the United States of illegally trying to bring in guns, spying equipment and drugs under the guise of a training program for Argentine federal police. Mr. Fernandez suggested Wednesday that the equipment might be destroyed in accordance with Argentine customs regulations.

Turn right, and they would head to a hospital that has cared for protesters. Turn left, and into Pearl Square, the symbolic center of the nation, where the army was waiting.

headline: Clashes in Libya Worsen as Army Crushes Dissent

Muammar el-Qaddafi. Human rights groups said 24 people had been killed across the North African country, though activists say the count may be far higher.

Moses Kibwami, a carpenter and the father of 12, stood there in his swamp boots on Friday morning, cast a quick look over them and then stamped his thumb onto the paper.

headline: How Bad Could Upshaw Have Been?
text: “Look, Gene Upshaw was a friend of mine, but he was no labor leader, and he wasn’t going to be one if he lived to be 3,000. He just wasn’t. Unfortunately, the players have done this time and again. They have looked for leadership among ex-players like Upshaw and never into the regular trade-union movement.” — Marvin Miller, the former head of the baseball players union, to Terence Moore in an article Wednesday in FanHouse.

headline: Tesla Co-Founder Sizes Up President Obama’s E.V. Pledge
text: In his State of the Union address last month, President Obama renewed his campaign pledge to put one million plug-in hybrid and electric vehicles into service in America by 2015. Tesla Motors has contributed about 1,500 cars to the bottom line, but Marc Tarpenning, the company’s co-founder, says he believes the president’s promise could be half-baked.

headline: Complaint Box | The Running of the Dogs
text: I don’t mind admitting that I can be afraid of dogs — can be, rather than am, because it depends on their size and bark. But there’s a reason the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation requires that dogs in parks be leashed between 9 a.m. and 9 p.m., except in dog runs, and there’s a reason it regulates their behavior even in designated off-leash areas before and after those hours. Dogs are welcome at urban parks, but the parks are primarily for people, and while the vast majority of dogs are domesticated, acts of aggression by roaming dogs are, unfortunately, not uncommon.

headline: Mervyn King Greenspans Himself
text: Ed Balls is right: Mervyn King, governor of the Bank of England, has stepped way over the line by turning into a cheerleader for the current government’s policies. He’s wrong on the economics — front-loaded spending cuts are the wrong policy for a still-depressed economy — but that’s not the key point; rather, the point is that if you’re going to have an independent central bank, the people running that bank have to be careful to stay above the political fray.

headline: Ask the Carpetbagger
text: Borrowing on our grand tradition of gambits when we run out of things to write about, the Bagger would now like to go the crowd-sourcing route. What would you, dear readers, like to know about? One commenter has written asking for an interview with an Oscar-nominated costume designer; we’re working on it! What else do you have lingering questions about (that our film critic colleagues A.O. Scott and Manohla Dargis, can’t answer)? As we wrote last year (look, we’re too drained to even produce new copy!), the Bagger is open to any and all reasonable queries and will gladly use the power of having The New York Times as a last name to get your questions answered. Leave them in the comments below or e-mail us at carpetbagger@nytimes.com.

headline: Morning Buzz | Bloomberg’s ‘Good News’
text: The warmest day of the year so far, with the temperature reaching 63 degrees, but cloudy skies. Don’t pack your coats yet, though; winter weather is on its way back. Clouds and wind to continue through the weekend.

headline: Swede Spot
text: Our love for all things Swedish knows no bounds. Would that we could have a Little Stockholm right here in New York, a neighborhood where’d snap up our favorite Scandanavian duds (and meatballs). So imagine our excitement when we found out that the Swedish label Our Legacy has built a temporary corner shop at Odin that will be open throughout spring. It’s the largest selection of Our Legacy wares outside of Sweden, including a sizable pick from their latest collection, “Observations.” A one-stop spot for an entire wardrobe, the store sells eminently wearable pieces — go-anywhere tees, soft plaid Oxfords, lightly structured blazers, no-fuss pants — designed to be layered and assembled into an outfit as easily as an Ikea bookcase.

headline: New Radiohead Album Arrives Early
text: Radiohead has released its new album a day earlier than expected. On Monday the band said that the album, “The King of Limbs,” would be available for download on Saturday — for fixed prices, unlike the widely noted name-your-own-price experiment of its last record. But on Friday morning Radiohead said in a statement that “with everything ready on their website, the band decided to bring forward the release rather than wait until the previously announced date.” A video for the first single, “Lotus Flower,” is also available and can be seen above.

headline: Case Study | Mull This
text: I’ve never had a particularly great rapport with mulled wine, that staple of ski slopes and Christmas markets throughout Northern Europe. In theory it should be a tremendously restorative, literally heartwarming (one tries to avoid the reference to Gemütlichkeit) tonic from the alpine quiver, carried to table preferably by a St. Bernard. In reality, however, I couldn’t count how many frankly off-putting mulled wines I’ve choked down slopeside over the years: harsh reds gussied up with a load of sugar and overwhelming spices to cover their unpalatable edge, then cooked, which only intensifies the jangle. Nein, danke.
