headline: A Red Scare
text: “Whoa! That is definitely not poison oak,” Dr. Walter Larsen blurted as he entered the exam room in his Portland, Ore., office. The patient smiled ruefully. “I told you,” she said to the doctor. The 56-year-old woman had seen Larsen that Tuesday, two days earlier. Then she was concerned; now she was scared. She looked down at her hands and arms. Her fair skin was nearly hidden by vicious-looking streaks of red. “And it’s everywhere.” She lowered the office gown to reveal scarlet lines crisscrossing up her arms, across her neck, down her back, chest and abdomen. Larsen leaned in close to get a better look at the patient’s red-streaked skin. He didn’t know what this rash was, but it sure had become a lot uglier in just a couple of days.

headline: Tel Aviv Broadcast
text: It’s just after midnight on Saturday, and I’ve been watching images from the protests in Egypt for hours. The TV is on mute, but the raging faces of Cairo are deafening. I don’t want my son to wake up, and so I turn off the TV and sit down at my computer. My soccer team, Maccabi Petah Tikva, played Ashdod earlier today, and I surf over to Israel’s largest news portal to check the score. On the home page, above the headline reporting Petah Tikva’s solid 3-1 victory, the following item appears: “Palestinian killed in Samaria yesterday. Watch video footage.”

headline: This Ain’t Weird Al
text: The novelty song used to be popular, but it has never, ever been cool. Whether it was Allan Sherman making his 1963 hit “Hello Mudduh! Hello Fadduh!” or Weird Al Yankovic parodying Michael Jackson with “Eat It” in 1984, the comedian who made singalong spoofs was like the hip stand-up comic’s embarrassing country cousin. There were exceptions, of course, like the cerebral, political Tom Lehrer — but let’s just say that, in general, Lenny Bruce and George Carlin did not sing. The novelty song was an outlet for nerds, morning-show shock jocks and the kind of guys who put the word “weird” in front of their names. This might help explain why the era of the novelty song seemed to end right around the time that hip-hop came of age: the greatness of Weird Al’s “Straight Outta Lynwood” notwithstanding, the average funny-song singer was not cut out to spoof N.W.A.

headline: Hollywood Property Values
text: “The Social Network” poses this question: Did Facebook’s founder Mark Zuckerberg steal the idea for the site from Harvard classmates? My row at a Writers Guild screening of “The Social Network” posed this one: Isn’t it a little rich to examine that issue in a Hollywood movie, the product of an industry often portrayed as a snake pit, where one snake is apt to swipe the work of another? Isn’t it even richer now that the movie has garnered eight Oscar nominations?

headline: Magic and Loss
text: It has been more than 20 years since Tim Berners-Lee first proposed the World Wide Web as a shared system of hypertext that would give almost anyone access to the resources of the Internet. Nearly two billion people now surf the Web. They join up around the world from cellphones, fancy tablets, slender laptops and bulky desktops.

headline: Exit Interview
text: You resigned as the No. 2 at WikiLeaks in September, and you write in your new book, “Inside WikiLeaks: My Time With Julian Assange at the World’s Most Dangerous Website,” that you might resort to violence if you saw WikiLeaks’s founder, Julian Assange, in person again. Of all the awful things you describe him doing, what was the most hurtful?  He said he would destroy me, and he would hunt me down and kill me if I would endanger a source, although I never gave him reason to suspect I would. He also threatened to have me locked up.

headline: Celebrating Its Pony-Car Success, Camaro Goes Topless
text: TESTED Chevrolet Camaro convertible.

headline: Vegetable Hash for an Easy Dinner
text: Often families serve meat hash dishes as a way to reinvent leftovers. But in this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman creates five new hash recipes loaded with vegetables and flavor, inspired by the beef hashes she remembers from her childhood.

headline: SXSW Says It Is ‘Disappointed’ by Absence of Female Comedians
text: Whether or not you agree that comedy is a male-dominated field, it is hardly an industry with a male-to-female ratio of 30-to-1. Yet that was the gender breakdown on the initial lineup of performers announced for SXSW Comedy, a long-running component of the annual South by Southwest festival in Austin. Of the 31 comedians in this year’s lineup, including notable funnymen like Michael Ian Black, Thomas Lennon, Donald Glover and John Oliver, only one – Tig Notaro – is a woman.

headline: A Home for Two Households
text: THE journey that brought Vivian Berger and Michael Finkelstein to their spectacular aerie on the Upper West Side started more than a decade ago, with what might or might not have been a date.

headline: A Blog for the ‘Sixth Borough’
text: ON THE SCREEN Blogs that cover niche topics usually appeal to niche audiences. In this city, where there are more bloggers per square mile than perhaps anywhere else in the world, highly specialized blogs create zealously exclusive communities around topics as diverse as cupcakes (Cupcakes Take the Cake) and fixed-gear bicycle freestyling (Prolly Is Not Probably).

headline: G20 Leaders Voice Worry on Trade
text: PARIS  With the world’s economies moving at two different speeds, fast-growing developing countries are luring money at a pace that, if left unchecked, could set the stage for future problems, the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said Friday.

headline: Chevrolet Camaro Convertible
text: The new convertible is a welcome addition to the Camaro line.

headline: A Promising Space-to-Price Ratio
text: WHEN Xian Edwards began house-hunting over a year ago, he was looking for something not easy to come by in New York City: space, and lots of it.

headline: Living In | Williamsbridge, the Bronx
text: A north Bronx neighborhood — not to be confused with Williamsburg, Brooklyn — is dominated by single- to three-family homes, few of them more than 50 or 60 years old.

headline: Backstage Beauty | Post-Shows Glow
text: During fashion week, top skin specialists are called in to bring a slight calm to the chaos backstage. This time around, for example, Nude Skincare celebrated its second season working with Victoria Bartlett at VPL; Sunday Riley revived the faces of Jason Wu’s models; Skyn Iceland’s “stress squad” went backstage at Elise Overland; and Vermont’s Tata Harper was responsible for the glowing skin at Porter Grey and Bodkin. For a similar post-Fashion Week luster, consider the places and products listed below — on or off the runway, we all need a little pick-me-up right about now.

headline: Pizza With No Sauce, but With Plenty of Flavor
text: When making pizza at home, I’ve taken to dividing the dough in half and making two smaller pies with different toppings, one with tomato and one without. Usually, the one without is just drizzled with olive oil and sprinkled with coarse salt and an herb like rosemary. It comes out cracker-crisp in the middle, with great big bubbles and a nice rim of puffier crust at the perimeter. It tastes like focaccia; because of its crispness, however, it eats like pizza. My wife, Jackie, and I generally wolf it down in the kitchen while waiting upon the tomato/mozzarella/whatever pizza, which takes longer to bake.

headline: A Backstage Oscars Pass From ABC
text: LOS ANGELES— ABC, working feverishly to improve the digital components of this year’s Oscar telecast, unveiled a “backstage pass” app on Friday for iPad, iPhone and iPod touch users. Ho-hum, you say, another app. We’re worn out with app mania too, but this one is notable partly because it is designed to be used while you are also watching the show.

headline: Wisconsin Bill in Limbo as G.O.P. Seeks Quorum
text: MADISON, Wis.  The fight over a bill to slash collective bargaining for Wisconsin’s public workers came to a standstill on Friday, as Democratic state senators refused to appear at the Capitol, members of the State Assembly delayed a vote until next week and thousands of protesters, their numbers still growing, marched, screamed, sang and sat.

headline: An Organic Milk Experiment in Maine
text: Struggling dairy farmers in Maine are trying a new tactic to become profitable.

headline: House Set to Approve Cuts; Time Short to Stop Shutdown
text: WASHINGTON  House Republicans on Friday marched confidently toward approving the largest spending cuts in modern history, setting the stage for a standoff with Senate Democrats and the White House that each side has warned could lead to a shutdown of the federal government early next month.

headline: Government Crackdown in Bahrain
text: Mourners buried those killed in violent clashes between antigovernment protesters and security forces, as the government hardened its stance against the demonstrations.

headline: Parents Seeking Danger
text: After the  “60 Minutes” correspondent Lara Logan was brutally attacked in Cairo, one Web site asked today whether she was a bad mother for being on the scene in the first place.

headline: Further Reading on Genetic Engineering and Food
text: I could probably read about G.E. for the rest of my life and still not grasp the full picture, but I sure know more than I did a couple of weeks ago. Here are some of the most interesting articles I read in researching this week’s column.

headline: Winter, Fading
Rookie’s Strong Season Makes Islanders Look Smart
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Michael Grabner, a speedy right wing for the Islanders, has done so well lately, scoring almost at will for a team on a roll, that he does not want to talk much about the most difficult three months of his brief N.H.L. career.

headline: Geometry On Your Arm
text: ThreeASFOUR — the science-obsessed label designed by Adi Gil, Gabriel Asfour and Angela Donhouser— is synonymous with geometric bags. “It all started when Adi dreamt of the bag,” says Asfour, referring to the label’s kidney-shaped bag. Adds Donhouser, “The kidney reflects our fascination with human anatomy.” To celebrate its new e-commerce site, which goes live tomorrow, threeASFOUR is issuing the bag in two styles — a metal chain link version ($666) in black or pale gold snakeskin leather, and a split cell variety ($555) in bone or black canvas or leather. They join its perennially popular circle bag ($555). Available at planetofstyle.com.

headline: Week in Pictures, Feb. 18
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

headline: Once on This Island
text: Who could love a rat? And what could possess a man to sail to an uninhabited island, in defiance of law, and throw out vitamin K pellets as an antidote to a government-sponsored rat-poisoning program? Therapists and law-enforcement officers might come up blank on that one, but no motive is beyond the grasp of an imaginative fiction writer. In his new novel, “When the Killing’s Done,” T. Coraghessan Boyle proves his mettle by grafting a page from the strange-crime annals into a life-and-death story of evolution, shipwrecks and dominion over the earth.

headline: Deal With the Devil
text: In the decades since her death in 1979, Elizabeth Bishop has been recognized as an American original, as much ours and not ours as Whitman, Dickinson and that transplanted Yankee Robert Frost. A reader’s appetite for the lives of beloved poets can be hard to satisfy. Their mortgages are subject to scholarly study, their medical records sold in shadowy alleys, their childhood friends dunned to offer up nuggets of gossip. We would read their shopping lists if we could — such things make them more human, and therefore slightly inhuman, since how is it possible that the authors of “Leaves of Grass” or “Because I Could Not Stop for Death” or “North of Boston” could have needed new stockings, and hair oil, and cornflakes?

headline: New Visual Books
text: Images from books reviewed in Steven Heller’s column.

headline: Irreverence You Can Almost Touch
text: I recently subscribed to a well-known magazine that offers an interactive digital edition for my iPad. I was utterly disappointed. As a magazine geek for many dec­ades, I looked forward to complaining about how nothing is better than turning real pages, smelling real ink and caressing real paper. But sadly, I have finally come to recognize that after all that turning, smelling and caressing, what remains are piles of old magazines collecting dust. The new digital version may seem less substantial, but it doesn’t have those annoying loose subscription cards or peel-and-sniff perfume ads that induce headaches (and depressing sensory memories). What’s more, I don’t have to tie up digital magazines for disposal on recycling day. So I canceled all but one print subscription, and now I get my periodical enjoyment from an iPad. Which is actually why I am pleased to see new books devoted to printed magazines. Just in case the end of print comes tomorrow, we’ll never forget what we had.

headline: Up Front: Walter Isaacson
text: In his distinguished career, Walter Isaacson has been the chairman and chief executive of CNN and the editor of Time magazine. He is now the president and chief executive of the Aspen Institute.

headline: Wise Guy
text: The problem with writing a biography of Socrates, as Bettany Hughes merrily admits, is that he’s a “doughnut subject”: a rich and tasty topic with a big hole right in the middle where the main character should be. Despite his fame and his insistence on an examined life, Socrates never wrote anything, and our knowledge of him comes mainly from three contemporaries — his devoted pupils Plato and Xenophon, and the parodist Aristophanes — each of whom had his own agenda. He produced no great answers, only great questions, and the most enduring image we have of his life is his leaving of it, as the title of this book suggests.

headline: Misery Loves Company
text: In a survey of unhappy families, you’d be hard pressed to find one quite so spectacularly savage as the Goodyews of Kent. In Louise Dean’s darkly comic new novel, “The Old Romantic,” Nick Goodyew, an English solicitor specializing in divorce, hasn’t seen his father, Ken, in 15 years, his mother, Pearl, in over 20 — since Nick more or less broke up the family by revealing his father’s infidelities, then escaped to the loftier world of Cambridge. When Ken gets back in touch after years of silence, it’s largely to heap abuse on his son — “Oy! Big’ead! . . . You’re nothing! You’re a stuck-up, jumped-up . . . embarrassment” — before admitting that he’ll be requiring Nick’s services in divorcing his second wife, a squat, tittering woman whose banal chatter Ken likens to a “dripping tap.”

headline: Sandalista!
text: Mocking one’s younger self is a middle-age rite of passage. The jaded grown-up derides as naïve the idealistic or altruistic impulses of youth. (Silly us: we once had convictions!) Underlying this sneering condescension, of course, is grief. We’ll never be that tender, certain or passionate about anything again. Life is half over, the glass half emptied. We slouch toward death.

headline: Frontier’s End
text: We Americans love to uproot ourselves and head out for unfamiliar territories. Our reasons, if sometimes murky, are also manifold: a fear of what’s brewing at home or the ache for an ideal that virgin land might help realize. We want riches. We thrill at jumping into the uncertain void. “West of Here,” Jonathan Evison’s broad-spectrum new novel, plays host, gleefully and mischievously, to all of the above. More than a dozen central characters willfully flip their lives upside down and inside out, eyes on the horizon.

headline: Unkind and Unnecessary
text: To the Editor:

headline: Market Values
text: To the Editor:

headline: Paperback Row
text: UNION ATLANTIC,  by Adam Haslett (Anchor, $15.) Set chiefly in Boston and New York in 2001-2, this timely first novel meditates on Wall Street corruption and class warfare through its protagonist, Doug Fanning, one of the brains behind a rotten banking conglomerate.

headline: Bruno Littlemore’s Lineage
text: To the Editor:

headline: Inside the List
text: BATTLE ROYALE: As secretary of defense, Donald Rumsfeld was a strong advocate for the so-called Revolution in Military Affairs, a strategy that relies on high-tech combat systems and smaller, more nimble forces. When it comes to book-selling, however, he’s something of an old fogey. While his “Known and Unknown” may be No. 1 on the hardcover nonfiction list, it’s a modest No. 10 on the mother of all mash-up lists shown in the graphic on Page 24 — which combines fiction and nonfiction, print and e-books — in part because of comparatively weak e-book sales.

headline: Bogart’s Lonely Place
text: To the Editor:

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: J. D. SALINGER: A Life,  by Kenneth Slawenski (Random House, $27.) The great achievement of Slawenski’s reverent biography, coming just a year after Salinger’s death, is its evocation of the horror of his experiences in World War II.

headline: Read the Book Instead
text: To the Editor:

headline: Weekend Competition: Get Web Soon
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to design greeting card slogans fit for the times in which we live.

headline: Study of Breast Biopsies Finds Surgery Used Too Extensively
text: Too many women with abnormal mammograms or other breast problems are undergoing surgical biopsies when they should be having needle biopsies, which are safer, less invasive and cheaper, new research shows.

headline: Reviewing the BYD F3DM
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Brad Berman reviews the F3DM, a plug-in hybrid from the Chinese automaker BYD. Mr. Berman finds the F3DM to be technologically impressive, but notes that it offers few of the frills and creature comforts that American drivers customarily expect. He writes:

headline: Reviewing the Camaro Convertible
text: Jerry Garrett reviews the Chevrolet Camaro convertible in this Sunday’s Automobiles section, finding it to be a big improvement on past models. The “wet-dishrag sensation” of previous Camaro convertibles has been replaced, Mr. Garrett writes, by “a more controlled ride with tighter tolerances.” He goes on:

headline: Making a Fashion Statement, With or Without Clothes
text: RENAZZO DI CENTO, Italy  To the untrained eye, the clusters of synthetic body parts scattered on the floor of a vast warehouse in Italy’s heartland looked very much like  well, like clusters of synthetic body parts.

headline: McDyess Decides to Put Off Retirement
text: San Antonio Spurs forward Antonio McDyess thought this could be the last season of his N.B.A. career.

headline: Letters: A Prescription for Fear
text: Virginia Heffernan’s opinion piece offered at best a misleading and unsubstantiated characterization of WebMD. WebMD has earned the trust of millions of consumers by providing objective and relevant health information that is written by a staff of professional journalists and board-certified physicians. Our award-winning content undergoes a rigorous medical-review process to ensure that it is credible and accurate. We always make a clear distinction between our own content and that of our advertisers. Heffernan asserts that MayoClinic.com is somehow more credible because it is owned by a nonprofit clinic, when in fact, as Heffernan acknowledges, it operates a commercial site that accepts advertising just as WebMD does. We would have also expected The Times to disclose its ownership of the advertising-supported health site on About.com, which competes with WebMD.

headline: Letters: Shaken
text: Emily Bazelon’s article illustrates the need to reform a system in which expert medical witnesses who may have conflicts of interest argue complex cases to a lay jury. These expert witnesses are paid lucratively, can legally opine on anything outside their field and rarely face repercussions for incorrect testimony. To remove conflict of interest, the courts should seek interpretation of M.R.I.’s and other test results from multiple independent court-employed neuroradiologists who don’t have knowledge of or involvement with the case.

headline: Look of the Moment | Blake Lively
text: The Look: Military might. With a coat like that, who needs an evening dress?

headline: Four Questions on How to Cut Tuition
text: 7:42 p.m. | Updated See below for a comment Mr. McCardell submitted this evening to The Choice further explaining this sentence from one of his answers below: “It costs us about $75,000 to educate one student for one year.”

headline: Nasdaq and ICE Consider NYSE Euronext Bid
text: 8:24 p.m. | Updated

headline: Gilt Groupe Chief Considering I.P.O. in 2012
text: Now that Nordstrom has swooped in to buy a “flash sales” site, HauteLook, for $180 million in stock, the market is waiting for the Web site’s larger rival, Gilt Groupe, to make a move.

headline: Oscar Picks, Courtesy of the Man Behind Ron Swanson
text: Hey, have you noticed our spiffy new interactive Oscar ballot, winking suggestively at you over on the right side of the screen? Go ahead, fill it out! In the lead-up to the big day, the Bagger has asked some well-known folks to join you in picking the most Oscar-worthy films and performances, and we’ll be talking to some of them about their choices. First up: Nick Offerman, best known for playing the lushly mustachioed, world-weary boss on “Parks and Recreation” — one of the Bagger’s favorites — where he occasionally stars opposite his wife, Megan Mullally.

headline: The Art of the Mannequin
text: A family company provides upscale mannequins to fashion houses, department stores and museums alike.

headline: A Pair of Vintage Lancias Find a Savior
text: Not long after Jaan Hjorth, a Lancia mechanic in Berkeley, Calif., was profiled in November by The New York Times, he received a phone call.

headline: Top 10 Composers: A Young Reader Who Responded Is Now on Video
text: We hope you didn’t miss the videos of our chief music critic, Anthony Tommasini, playing the piano to demonstrate some of the musical ideas he applied to his effort to assemble a list of the 10 greatest composers. We’re also happy to remind you of one of the more striking responses, from an 8-year-old pianist with his own firm ideas about the Top 10. Now the lad, Lucas Amory, has a video too. Can he spell p-r-e-c-o-c-i-o-u-s?

headline: TimesCast | February 18, 2011
text: Michael Slackman reports from Manama, moments after an attack on protesters by security forces; and a week after Mubarak’s fall, huge crowds gather in Cairo’s Tahrir Square to celebrate.

text: Tweeting Since April 2009Followers 57, 545Twitter Bio Actress, author, personality, singer

headline: An Arthur Worthy of the Modern Ages
text: FORGET everything you thought you knew about Camelot  the hulking round table, the wizened Merlin, the Lerner and Loewe book and score. This “Camelot,” the latest historical epic from Starz, skews young and sexy with a “Harry Potter” and “Twilight” alumnus (Jamie Campbell Bower, as King Arthur), a Bond girl (Eva Green, as Morgan) and an MTV Movie Award winner for best kiss (Joseph Fiennes, as Merlin).

headline: Smash the Windows, Bang the Cowbell
text: The Psychic Paramount

headline: With Whaling Ships Under Attack, Japan Will Recall Fleet
text: TOKYO  Japan will cut short this year’s annual whale hunt in the Antarctic Ocean after obstruction by an environmental group largely prevented its ships from killing whales, the government said Friday.

headline: Russian Finance Minister Says Political Change Is Needed
text: MOSCOW  Russia’s powerful finance minister, Aleksei L. Kudrin, said in a speech on Friday that economic advantages in Russia were too often granted based on relationships with government officials, and warned that economic reforms would not be possible without political change.

headline: The Big Short Meets the Maestro
text: Thanks … for the bubble?

headline: Childhood: Falls From Cribs Injure Dozens a Day
text: A crib should be a safe place to leave an infant, but every day dozens of babies are injured in falls from cribs, according to what may be the first study focusing on nonfatal crib-related injuries in children younger than 2.

headline: The Medium Size Is the Message
text: Models aren’t generally known for their word play. But Modelinia.com’s cool new T-shirts are emblazoned with model-related catchphrases that riff on well-known idioms and logos. Now you can Facebook “like” Karlie Kloss or proclaim that “Nobody does it better than Abbey Lee” on your shirt.

headline: Boxing Here, but Focusing on Egypt
text: As Ahmed Samir stood in a ring in the Flatiron district throwing punches the other day, his mind was on another fight — for the future of his homeland, and for his right to return there.

headline: A Revived George Mason Has Major Ambitions
text: FAIRFAX, Va.  Five years removed from its improbable Final Four appearance, George Mason embraces the past while choosing not to be defined by it. Enlarged magazine covers chronicling the Patriots’ run still hang in Coach Jim Larranaga’s office, and at home games this season fans received bobblehead dolls depicting the 2005-6 team’s starting five.

headline: Leyland Not Concerned About Cabrera
text: The inevitable questions about Miguel Cabrera’s recent D.W.I. arrest hit Tigers Manager Jim Leyland on Friday, and he was not overly concerned about his first baseman in his responses.

headline: A Sales Record for Lady Gaga
text: Lady Gaga’s new single, “Born This Way,” released Feb. 11, has already scored a sales milestone: it is the fastest-selling song in iTunes’ history, with more than 1 million downloads around the world in five days.

headline: Penthouse Skin Care
text: After 11 years of tending to the skin of A-listers like Kate Winslet, Brad Pitt and Lara Stone in her downtown atelier, Tracie Martyn has moved to a sprawling penthouse in the Flatiron district. Designed by Benjamin Noriega-Ortiz (who counts the Mondrian SoHo among his projects), the airy space is filled with his signature flourishes, including a cloudlike feather chandelier and Swarovski crystal-studded walls. Clients can buy the facialist’s all-natural products, including her latest, Resculpting Body Serum with mushroom extract; 101 Fifth Avenue (East 17th Street), (212) 206-9333; traciemartyn.com.

headline: Senator Bingaman of New Mexico Will Retire
text: 6:12 p.m. | Updated Jeff Bingaman, a Democratic senator from New Mexico, will retire at the end of his term in 2012, adding to the growing list of open seats the party will have to defend next year.

headline: Sara Katz and Douglas Mercer
text: EVERYTHING about Douglas Mercer, 38, is intense, from what he reads (Shakespeare) to where he travels (Rwanda, India, Nicaragua). He is passionate about experimental theater, scuba diving, Buddhism and Boston sports teams. In his teens, he liked the Grateful Dead so much that his mother, Carol Ann Mercer, drove him to concerts the way other moms drive their kids to soccer games.

headline: Wheelies: Dearborn-on-Volga Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Attacks Across Afghanistan Leave Over a Dozen Dead
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Attacks in four parts of the country left at least 18 people dead on Friday, including four NATO service members, four Afghan police officers and 10 civilians, signaling the tenaciousness of the insurgency even through the winter.

headline: Midwinter Ritual: When Good Actor Meets Bad Movie
text: LATE winter is traditionally a time to celebrate great acting, as the most distinguished performances of the previous year parade before us on their long march to the Oscars. At the moment, accordingly, those of us with deadlines and airtime to fill are busy trumpeting the artistry of Colin Firth and Annette Bening, Natalie Portman and Christian Bale. But meanwhile, in the real world of day-to-day moviegoing, there are screens and seats to be filled, and genre movies  horror, action, romantic comedy, kiddie adventure  flood the multiplexes, forgoing the Academy’s consideration and hoping for a bit of yours. Many of these movies take part in another, less-heralded seasonal ritual: the spectacle of great actors appearing in bad movies.

headline: Egyptian Archeological Sites Were Looted, Antiquities Minister Says
text: Important archeological sites in Egypt were looted during the antigovernment protests, Egypt’s antiquities minister, Zahi Hawass, wrote on his blog on Thursday. The announcement contradicted earlier statements by Mr. Hawass that Egypt’s archeological sites were safe. Mr. Hawass wrote that tombs at Saqqara and Abusir and storage buildings at Saqqara and at Cairo University, among other sites, had been broken into. He added that he had formed a committee to determine and report on what objects were missing.

headline: Many Americans See Economy Improving, but Not for Them
text: AMERICANS are becoming more optimistic about the prospects for the economy, but are still concerned about their own financial situation.

headline: Off Screen, a Long-Running Romance
text: WHEN Zack Snyder and Deborah Johnson married on Sept. 25, 2004, he had just finished directing his first feature film, a remake of “Dawn of the Dead,” and she was producing television commercials.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Talks and panel discussions are scheduled for Friday and Saturday at the International Association of Culinary Professionals conference. The events cover topics like the New York restaurant scene, food blogging and the farm-to-table movement. Receptions, lunches and dinners are also scheduled. Tickets are $149 for the conference, and a schedule of events is available from theculinarytrust.org.

headline: Turkey Jails 3 Journalists in Coup Investigation
text: ISTANBUL  Three journalists from a Web site critical of the government were jailed and charged on Friday as part of an investigation into accusations that the military plotted to overthrow Turkey’s pro-Islamic government in 2003. The moves came as Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan sharply criticized the new American ambassador here for his comments on the case.

headline: Videophiles | Doug Aitken’s Patterns & Repetition: Jack White
text: There are certain things that creative people share in common, and lately a chat with the artist Doug Aitken seems to be one of them. Aitken’s 2006 book, “Broken Screen,” featured interviews with 26 artists, including Robert Altman and Rem Koolhaas. Now, with his latest video project, “Patterns & Repetition,” the artist sits down with a new cast in an attempt to put the pieces of the creative puzzle back together again. Each week, The Moment will feature a different segment: Mike Kelley talking about the Motor City; Jacques Herzog on instinct and architecture; Jack White (above) imagining Michelangelo as a modern-day blogger. But don’t be fooled by the coffee mugs and the California sunshine. Aitken doesn’t do anything casually. The subtext of the conversations is nothing less than the future of art itself.

headline: Violence Erupts at Jordan Protest
text: AMMAN, Jordan  A protest turned violent here in the Jordanian capital on Friday as government supporters clashed with demonstrators calling for political change, injuring several, witnesses said.

headline: Valle de Bravo, an Upscale Refuge Near Mexico City
text: A BAND of tubas, trumpets and saxophones played as a lone, wide-grinning inebriate swayed to the wailing horns. There were balloons, popcorn stands and roasted-peanut vendors. Children on scooters whipped through the crowd, chased by a scrawny, yapping mutt. Teenage girls danced among themselves while young men sipped micheladas — beer spiked with lime, salt and chili — from one-liter Styrofoam cups. The smell of cotton candy and churros was everywhere.

headline: Flemish Comfort Food in French Flanders
text: ON a Friday night at Estaminet ‘T Rijsel, a restaurant in Lille, France, just 30 minutes from the Belgian border, my dining companion and I sampled a trio of dishes: waterzooi, carbonnade and pot’je vleesch. In France, the bones of history end up in the stock pot, so reading a menu can tell you a lot about where you are. This menu was telling me that I was in Flanders  more specifically, French Flanders.

headline: Store Review: La Chocolaterie de Jacques Genin, in Paris
text: When Jacques Genin opened his chocolaterie of the same name in late 2008, it was a star turn for one of the great supporting actors on the French culinary stage.

headline: Hotel Review: Fairmont Pacific Rim in Vancouver
text: THE BASICS

headline: An Olympic Village in Vancouver Is Reborn
text: DURING the Olympic Games in Vancouver last February, about 3,000 athletes and officials spent their downtime holed up in the Olympic Village. Filling eight city blocks, with 25 residential high-rises and mixed-use buildings, the $1.1 billion pop-up neighborhood was built on a desolate stretch of industrial land along the city’s waterfront. After the athletes left, the sprawling complex  nearly 1,100 units in total  was reinvented as Vancouver’s newest residential district. That transformation has, in turn, accelerated the emergence of the area around the complex as a destination unto itself.

headline: In New Hampshire, Can Bretton Woods Get Gnarly?
text: FOR years, the problem facing the Bretton Woods ski resort has been entirely its own making: It is too perfect. Perfectly groomed. Perfectly contoured with rough edges softened. Perfectly positioned, shielded from wind and blessed with sun and snow. Perfectly tranquil, neither hurried nor crowded.

headline: Letter: Mexican Food in Las Vegas
text: To the Editor: I thoroughly enjoyed Matt Gross’s “Lost in Las Vegas” (Feb. 6). I was especially delighted to see that his first stop was at my favorite Las Vegas restaurant, the “divey Mexican joint” El Sombrero. My husband and I first discovered this little gem many years ago when we asked a cab driver to recommend a good, off-the-Strip Mexican restaurant favored by the locals. Since then, we never fail to stop at El Sombrero whenever we’re in the neighborhood. Karen Douglas

headline: Letters: New Zealand Adventurers
text: To the Editor: We truly enjoyed “Extreme New Zealand” (Jan. 30). During our trip there, six or seven years ago, we were staying at the Novotel Queensland, and as I was looking out of the window, I saw a fellow and his guide come paragliding down toward the lake. I immediately called the concierge and asked if she could arrange for me to try it the following morning. My wife overheard and asked to join me.

headline: In Washington, D.C., Columbia Heights’ Hip Strip
text: A cluster of independent businesses has revitalized a once-desolate stretch of 11th Street, where big box stores and chain restaurants give way to indie rock dance parties and guerrilla theater performances.

headline: An Upscale Refuge Near Mexico City
text: Valle de Bravo, a lakeside community of 57,000 nestled in pine-covered hills, is just two hours west of Mexico City.

headline: Speaking French, Cooking Flemish
text: Locals in this sliver of Flanders that lies in France still love to eat traditional Flemish meals.

headline: A Grande Dame Gets Gnarly
text: Once known as “Medicare Mountain,” Bretton Woods has become a favorite winter destination.

headline: In a Seating Chart, Silicon Valley’s Pecking Order
text: In Silicon Valley, it’s all about who you know — and who you are sitting next to.

headline: Hoping Mediation Makes Breaking Up Easier
text: After the passage of no-fault divorce in New York State last year made splitting up a bit easier and cheaper, court officials in Nassau County are taking another step that they hope will make things even easier. They are encouraging mediation.

headline: Echoes of Another Time and Place
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I.

headline: Best in Shows
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#276", 592, 480, true, chameleonData);

headline: How Families Avoid Scandal, When Any Slip Can Go Viral
text: TWO types of privacy violations scare people with wealth and a reputation to protect: the isolated annoyances and the breaches that go viral. How to prevent the privacy violations from happening or, if that fails, handling the fallout was the focus of a timely and provocative discussion on Tuesday.

headline: Finra’s Deputy Enforcement Chief to Depart
text: James S. Shorris, the No. 2 cop at the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, Wall Street’s self-policing organization, is leaving to pursue a job in the private sector.

headline: F.E.C. Rules on Politicians’ Memoirs
text: The use of personal memoirs by politicians to grab headlines has become a common occurrence. Now, it’s officially legit as well.

headline: Deficit Discussions: Understanding Obama’s Federal Budget Proposal
text: On Monday, President Obama released his proposed federal budget, which would cut the deficit by a projected $1.1 trillion over 10 years. Meanwhile, Republican lawmakers have indicated that the budget proposal they will unveil in April will include much deeper spending cuts than the president’s.

headline: Cathy Horyn on New York Fashion Week
text: This season, designers extended the creative boundaries with their fabric research and development.

headline: Movies for Grown-Ups Find an Audience
text: We’ve wondered how ticket sales affect Oscar campaigning all season long; films certainly get a boost from a nomination, perhaps even more so than a victory. The Los Angeles Times takes a close look at what could be either an anomaly or a harbinger in this year’s crop of best picture nominees: even if they don’t take home a little gold man, most are poised to be box office champs.

headline: App Smart Extra: Translating Signs
text: Mobile translators can help you squeeze through a conversation with someone who speaks another language, as this week’s App Smart column points out. But what about situations where you just want to know what’s on the menu or how to read a set of signs?

headline: Fashion Week Parties, Night 8
text: Fashion Week winds down with a party for Naeem Khan.

headline: ‘Flash Crash’ Panel Lays Out Several Steps to Diminish Volatility in the Market
text: A committee set up in response to the “flash crash” of the stock market last May said on Friday that regulators had done much to address the blow to investor confidence but had not yet done enough. It also set out additional steps, including tightening controls on the growing number of computerized high-frequency and algorithmic traders.

headline: A Bubble in Private Internet Companies?
text: Zynga, the company behind many of the Web’s most viral games, is close to a deal that would value it at nearly $10 billion and is considering an initial public offering as soon as the first quarter of 2012. Valuations of Facebook and Groupon are similarly stratospheric. Bill Gurley of Benchmark Capital weighs in on whether there is a bubble in private Internet companies in this CNBC video.

headline: 'Boeing 737' by the Low Anthem
text: The premiere of the video for "Boeing 737," from the Low Anthem's new album, "Smart Flesh" (Nonesuch).

headline: He May Be No. 2, but Kaymer Is Still a Secret
text: Martin Kaymer? How did he get to be the second-ranked golfer in the world so fast? Unless you are a bleary-eyed watcher of the Golf Channel or a student of the Challenge Tour, the European equivalent of the Nationwide, you could be forgiven for thinking that Kaymer, a 26-year-old German, had been sprung on the world like a top-secret piece of engineering developed by some Bavarian aerospace Gesellschaft.

headline: Carmelo Anthony Trade Talks Get Their Second Wind
text: LOS ANGELES – Carmelo Anthony is dominating the N.B.A.’s All-Star weekend, without making a single move on the court.

headline: Arts & Leisure Preview: Good Actors in Bad Movies, ‘The Book of Mormon’ and More
text: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section.

headline: Chic in Review | Jennifer Lopez, Fashion Victim
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Cellphones Become the World’s Eyes and Ears on Protests
text: For some of the protesters facing Bahrain’s heavily armed security forces in and around Pearl Square in Manama, the most powerful weapon against shotguns and tear gas has been the tiny camera inside their cellphones.

headline: Time Inc.: The Anatomy of a Fiasco
text: Like most bad news, the departure of Jack Griffin — the chief executive of Time Inc. for less than six months — dropped at the end of the day, leaving the publishing community scratching its head and wondering how things had gone so wrong. No one, including Mr. Griffin, saw this one coming. He was at a board meeting of Next Issue Media until 4 p.m. on Thursday, and another executive at the meeting said it was clear that Mr. Griffin did not know he was about to be fired from the world’s largest magazine publisher.

headline: How Will Republicans Take Advantage of Bingaman’s Retirement?
text: New Mexico’s Jeff Bingaman announced his retirement Friday, making him the fourth member of the Senate Democratic caucus to have done so since the start of the year.

headline: Buzz Tracker
text: Is Goldman Really to Blame? Some bloggers take issue with the view that Goldman Sachs was responsible for the 2008 collapse of the American International Group. “For me, it is difficult to see any malpractice from Goldman here. Goldman acted to protect itself, as it had every right to do. If A.I.G. did not want to have to accept Goldman’s valuations, it could have negotiated a different valuation procedure for the trades. Instead it left itself open to massive liquidity risk by agreeing to the collateral arrangements that it did. A.I.G. never considered the consequences were the underlyings to its trades to become illiquid, nor where it would find the collateral were the trades to go against them. For me that is by far the worst of the behavior seen here.” Deus Ex Macchiato

headline: Neighborhood Joint | Knitty City
text: A colorful Upper West Side yarn shop offers both knitting supplies and instruction.

headline: Scientists Call for New Sources of Critical Elements
text: WASHINGTON  Technologies for green or renewable-energy devices like batteries, solar cells and advanced electric motors are dependent on critical metals and other elements that are threatened by major shortages, two influential American scientific groups said in a report Friday.

headline: Worldly Actor Finds Method in a Monastery
text: ON Friday, around the time New York moviegoers arrive for an afternoon showing of the French film “Of Gods and Men,” last year’s grand prize winner at Cannes, the star, Lambert Wilson, should also be making his way to a theater. But not for a movie. In Paris it will be César night, France’s Oscar night, and Mr. Wilson is nominated for his performance as the leader of a tiny Trappist monastery in strife-torn Algeria.

headline: Auschwitz Shifts From Memorializing to Teaching
text: OSWIECIM, Poland  For nearly 60 years, Auschwitz has told its own story, shaped in the aftermath of the Second World War. It now unfolds, unadorned and mostly unexplained, in displays of hair, shoes and other remains of the dead. Past the notorious, mocking gateway, into the brick ranks of the former barracks of the Polish army camp that the Nazis seized and converted into prisons and death chambers, visitors bear witness via this exhibition.

headline: Rabbi Is Sentenced in Plot to Shake Down SAC Capital
text: John Marshall Mantel for The New York TimesRabbi Milton Balkany arrives at federal court in Manhattan for sentencing.

headline: U.S. Blocks Security Council Censure of Israeli Settlements
text: UNITED NATIONS  The Obama administration vetoed a United Nations Security Council resolution on Friday condemning Israeli settlement building in occupied territory as illegal, choosing not to alienate Israel and risking the anger of Arabs.

headline: Growing Older Isn’t the Same as Growing Up
text: THERE are parties, and then there’s the Party, that one shimmering night that presents the chance to cut loose, kiss the prom queen and reveal one’s true self. And always it’s the last chance: before graduation, before leaving home, before everybody grows up.

headline: Mom for President
text: Across the country in recent days, women with political clout have been arguing about the rights and needs of mothers.

headline: Italian Passion, Hollywood Hooey
text: SENSO

headline: The Digital Lives of Babies
text: MY wife was about to go into the operating room for a scheduled C-section a few months ago when a nurse asked me an urgent question: “Where is your camera?”

headline: A Composer Is Dead, but Smiles Survive
text: John Strauss, composer of the theme song to “Car 54, Where Are You?” has died. Rather than a moment of silence, we propose 31 seconds of indelible catchiness, a whirlwind tour of the crime-and-mayhem news cycle of New York City circa 1961 (Khrushchev’s due at Idlewild!) and a peek inside an old-school r.m.p., all available above via the miracle of YouTube.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Uganda and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Uganda, Egypt, Bahrain and Yemen.

headline: Whodunit Most Musical by a Musician Most Literary
text: WESLEY STACE’S new book, “Charles Jessold, Considered as a Murderer,” is both a murder mystery and a novel about classical music, with a character who sometimes assumes another identity. Mr. Stace, an enthusiastic, donnish Englishman with an honors degree in English literature from Jesus College, Cambridge, and a head stuffed full of historical trivia, is an expert on both double lives and music. Improbably, he is also John Wesley Harding, an Elvis Costello-like singer-songwriter and folk rocker who has released more than a dozen records and is cool enough to have enlisted most of the Decemberists as the backup band on a forthcoming album.

headline: House Republicans Push Through Budget Amendments
text: As the House marched steadily on Friday toward approving the largest spending cuts in modern history, Republicans easily pushed through amendments to deny government financing for Planned Parenthood, to block money for carrying out the big health care overhaul and to bar the Obama administration from regulating certain greenhouse gases that contribute to global warming.

headline: Been There, Done That, and Now Going to This
text: THE New York Times’s theater critics are not the only ones willing to opine on spring theater highlights. We also polled a random assortment of Tony award winners and nominees from last season to find out what they are most excited about seeing in the coming months. Here are some of their answers. Though “The Book of Mormon,” the irreverent new musical created by Matt Stone and Trey Parker, the guys behind ‘South Park,’ is looking like a popular choice among theater people (and others, presumably) the rest of the assortment below is as eclectic as our group of panelists. STEVEN McELROY

headline: A Presidential Vote in Uganda
text: In stark contrast to the recent upheavals in northern Africa and the Middle East, governmental change in Uganda on Friday took on a decidedly different feel.

headline: HCA Seeks to Price I.P.O. at Up to $30 a Share
text: John Russell/Associated PressHCA headquarters in Nashville.

headline: Realism on Defense Spending
text: One thing I’m hearing and reading from liberal sources is the argument that we can find big savings by ending the war in Afghanistan, and more generally by cutting bloated defense spending. So, a few words on that issue.

headline: Morning T Video | Andy Cohen
text: In the latest installment of our video interview series, Andy Cohen, the Bravo executive and host of “Watch What Happens Live,” talks to Horacio Silva about how the “Real Housewives” franchise has hogged the fashion dialogue, Ramona Singer’s pinot grigio, Allison Dubois’s e-cigarette and the one-woman, mononymic powerhouse that is ¡Zoila!

headline: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 18
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include ice fishing, a bonsai festival and fashion week.

headline: Green Roof Collapses in Illinois
text: Green roofs have become increasingly popular in the United States as a way to beautify and insulate buildings and reduce heat pollution in urban areas, but last week one drew attention for a far different reason: it collapsed.

headline: Cairo in the Midwest?
text: As a native Wisconsinite, I can’t tell you how often I’ve heard the old saw that Badger State politics mirrors its geography: to the right of Minnesota and above Illinois. Well, the first part was proven last November, when Republicans achieved a near-stranglehold on state politics, while the latter is contradicted by the fact that this week all 14 Democrats from the State Senate fled to a hotel across the border in the Land of Lincoln.

headline: A Well-Lighted Media Blackout
text: KANYE WEST spent New York Fashion Week under a self-imposed cone of silence, refusing to talk to the news media. Yet somehow, he became a spectacle: his every move was chronicled by a cloud of bloggers, Twitter users, fashion reporters and paparazzi. Here’s how he spent the week, starting on Feb. 10.

headline: Morning T: Andy Cohen
text: Andy Cohen, executive in charge of dysfunction at Bravo TV, talks to Horacio Silva about the housewives and their many ancillary products.

headline: The Mystery of Obama’s Dinner with Tech Executives
text: For technology spectators, a dinner on Thursday evening with President Obama and a dozen Silicon Valley executive seems like a scene straight out of an Agatha Christie novel: a pile of questions and very few answers surrounding the dinner and its guests.

headline: ‘Have Your Cake and Eat It Too’
text: In my previous reader response, I mentioned the puzzling proverb “You can’t have your cake and eat it too.” Matthew Parry writes: “I’d always found ‘have your cake and eat it too’ perplexing, too, until it was pointed out the reversed construction makes sense: ‘You can’t eat your cake and have it too.’ Of course, everyone thinks I’m misquoting when I say this now!”

headline: Pratfalls From Haydn, Swing From Marsalis
text: Taken at face value, the program that the New York Philharmonic presented on Wednesday evening in Avery Fisher Hall was a curious clutch of disparate works. Still, there was symmetry to the arrangement: two saxophone showcases played with an estimable soloist, Branford Marsalis, both also heard during a Philharmonic concert in Central Park last summer, flanked here by pieces that repurposed viable music from forgotten stage dramas.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Uganda and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Uganda, Egypt, Bahrain and Yemen.

headline: A Contender Elbows In
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.

headline: Chilean Priest Found Guilty of Abusing Minors
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil  After an internal investigation, the Vatican found the Rev. Fernando Karadima guilty of sexually abusing minors in Chile and ordered him to retire to a “life of prayer and penitence,” the archbishop of Santiago said Friday.

headline: New York Fashion Week | Plenty of Plaid
text: Men’s-wear-inspired women’s wear isn’t anything revolutionary. From Diane Keaton in “Annie Hall” wearing Ralph Lauren to Cate Blanchett channeling Katharine Hepburn in “The Aviator,” dressing like the boys doesn’t have to mean androgyny. This fall plaids are designers latest nod to men’s wear — and we’re not talking suits. Thakoon’s tribal-inspired cobalt blue and cherry red checkered 18th-century red puffer jacket would be foreign to Gaelic Scots. Similarly, Rag & Bone used a mixed color palette, but also paired neo-traditional houndstooth kilts with tough biker jackets. Some were more direct: Theyskens’ Theory delivered plaids exactly how you want and expect them, a little oversized and unbuttoned, as if you threw on your boyfriend’s. Conservative looks did resurface, however — patterns woven in maroon, brown and yellow made an appearance at Chris Benz as a simple long smock dress and Altuzarra-fitted trousers. Thankfully, this is one of those brilliant trends that you always have somewhere buried in your closet. Happy hunting.

headline: 4 Yanks, 2 Games, 1 Midfield
text: It’s no great secret that the United States national team lacks the position-by-position depth of the world’s top soccer nations.

headline: SoHo Gallery? Black, of Course.
text: Vladimir Restoin Roitfeld, 26, is an art dealer and curator. His most recent endeavor, with his partner, Andy Valmorbida, is the recently opened exhibition of the Los Angeles-based street artist Retna at a gallery space in SoHo. Mr. Restoin Roitfeld, born and raised in Paris, is surrounded by a holy trinity of fashion-savvy women: his mother, the recently departed French Vogue editor Carine Roitfeld; his girlfriend, the L’Uomo Vogue fashion editor Giovanna Battaglia; and his sister, Julia Restoin Roitfeld, an art director and a model. CHLOE MALLE

headline: ‘Idol’ Rolls Again
text: “American Idol” cut its field of contestants down to 60 on Thursday as Part 3 of the reality show’s Hollywood Week remained unstoppable in the ratings, attracting 21.9 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. Fox placed first for the night over all despite drawing more modest ratings at 9 for “Bones” (9.9 million). Opposite “Idol” at 8, CBS fared best, earning 12.5 million for its half-hour sitcom “The Big Bang Theory” and 9.8 million at 8:30 for “$#*! My Dad Says.” CBS also led the 9 and 10 p.m. time slots with “CSI” (13.3 million), featuring Justin Bieber as a guest star, and “The Mentalist” (14.9 million), finishing in second place for the night over all. ABC was third with “Wipeout” at 8 (6.2 million) followed by “Grey’s Anatomy” (10.2 million) and “Private Practice” (6.9 million), while NBC ranked a distant fourth as usual with its three-hour comedy block.

headline: Footnote
text: The soprano Anna Netrebko is ill and has pulled out of Saturday’s matinee performance of “Don Pasquale,” the Metropolitan Opera said. Rachelle Durkin will sing the role of Norina in her place.

headline: Nuanced Comfort Music That Channels Kate Smith
text: Musical moments at sporting events can be memorable  Whitney Houston’s “Star-Spangled Banner,” Janet Jackson’s wardrobe malfunction  but the singing doesn’t usually affect the outcome.

headline: Mullin May Join  Olympic Teammates in Hall of Fame
text: With Chris Mullin being named a finalist for the Basketball Hall of Fame, the Dream Team from the 1992 Olympics moved one step closer to perfection.

headline: Facebook, Android, China and More at Mobile Conference
text: BARCELONA, Spain — This week, tens of thousands of mobile technology executives, entrepreneurs and enthusiasts descended on this beautiful city to watch demonstrations of new software, get a close look at the latest phones and tablets and stop at a tapas bar or two.

headline: Celebrations in Tahrir Square
text: A week after Mubarak's fall, crowds gather to celebrate.

headline: Eyewitness in Bahrain
text: Michael Slackman reports from Manama, moments after an attack on protesters by security forces.

headline: Perry Moore, Author of Book About Gay Superhero, Dies at 39
text: Perry Moore, an executive producer of the fantasy movie series “The Chronicles of Narnia” and the author of “Hero,” a book about a gay superhero, died on Thursday after being found unconscious in his Greenwich Village apartment. He was 39.

headline: Obama to Visit Latin America in March
text: President Obama will make his promised trip to Latin America from March 19 to 23, visiting four cities in three countries, the White House said on Friday.

headline: About Those Fabrics
text: THE final day of Fashion Week felt a bit like a dash for the last plane out of Lisbon, if you know what I mean. Everyone wore very tight expressions. The journalists heading to London were already in the transit lounge. Still, the day’s shows held some delights: Ralph Lauren’s beautifully rendered Deco glamour and subplot of a Chinese retail assault; L’Wren Scott’s Gauguin colors and a pitch, from both Ms. Scott and Francisco Costa of Calvin Klein, for short hemlines. Skirt lengths have generally been below the knees or to the ankles.

headline: Vietnam, and Make It Snappy
text: I DIDN’T come up with a banh mi recipe under the illusion that I could improve the classic Vietnamese sandwich.

headline: Shortcut Banh Mi With Pickled Carrots and Daikon
text: Time: 45 minutes

headline: Radiohead Surprises With Early Release
text: This time, Radiohead went for an ambush.

headline: Speedy Evolution, Indeed
text: Talk about a quick learner: in just 50 years, a fish has evolved a resistance to toxic chemicals polluting its Hudson River home, a new study finds.

headline: F.D.A. Chief Backs Fees for Generic Drug Reviews
text: Dr. Margaret Hamburg, commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, called on Friday for a new process to allow makers of generic drugs to pay user fees to the F.D.A. to speed up approval of the low-cost drugs.

headline: 25 Years of Hyundai in America
text: Hyundai’s offerings have evolved from the bargain-basement Excel to the luxury-class Equus.

headline: They Shoot Movies, Don’t They? The Camera as Star
text: LOS ANGELES — At Paramount Pictures these days, a lot of movies are less about the star than the camera — and the way it’s been keeping an eye on the rest of us.

headline: Start Spreading the News
text: Albany to New York City, Feb. 19, 1861

headline: Chasing a Police Scanner
text: Ride with Metro reporter Corey Kilgannon as he chases a police scanner in New York City.

headline: Swiss Locate Funds Linked to Mubarak
text: Investigators have discovered tens of millions of dollars in Swiss bank accounts belonging to the ousted Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak, his family or five prominent associates, officials in Switzerland announced Friday. The officials said the accounts had been frozen, but declined to break down who controlled the vast sums.

headline: Damage Control in a Viral World
text: In this weekend’s “Wealth Matters” column, Paul Sullivan writes about the ways in which the affluent try to protect their family’s reputation.

headline: MSNBC Hosts Settle In After Olbermann
text: MSNBC has certainly felt the impact of the departure of its most successful host, Keith Olbermann, last month, though the network has not suffered anything that could be called a collapse.

headline: Cleaning Up Tahrir Square
text: Demonstrators tried to bring the square back to normal after Hosni Mubarak's resignation.

headline: A Long Weekend, and a Long List of News
text: As we head into the long Presidents’ Day weekend, I am leaving you with brief updates on a number of the week’s events.

headline: Hyundai’s Swift Growth Lifts Alabama’s Economy
text: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — Few people in this city 800 miles south of Detroit cared much about the auto industry until Hyundai announced it would build cars here nine years ago.

headline: One Giant Family
text: Since new school versus old school is one of the plot-generators (as opposed to ideas) floating around in the amiable, schlocky family comedy “Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son,” it seems fair to point out that of all the cross-dressing comedies of recent decades, none has channeled “Some Like It Hot” quite so thoroughly.

headline: Unrest in Tunisia, Fueled by Facebook
text: Social media sites help stoke deep unrest in Tunisia.

headline: ‘Anna Nicole’
text: The opera based on the life of Anna Nicole Smith opened to raves in London.

headline: Map of Key Locations in Manama, Bahrain
text: At least seven people had died in clashes between protesters and security forces in Bahrain before Friday’s violence.

headline: Former Liverpool Chairman Will Sue Hicks for Defamation
text: The takeover of Liverpool F.C. may be complete, but the key players in the drama continue to squabble.

headline: A Black Widow Tale
text: Vishal Bhardwaj’s Shakespeare adaptations, “Maqbool” (“Macbeth,” 2004) and “Omkara” (“Othello,” 2006), remain high points of recent Hindi cinema. Serious and seriously entertaining, they married Shakespeare to contemporary Indian reality as artfully as they wedded a heightened realism to Bollywood showmanship.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: Film

headline: Father of 5 Browns Pleads Guilty to Abusing Daughters
text: The father of the 5 Browns, a high-profile performing quintet of classical pianists, has pleaded guilty to sexually abusing his daughters when they were under 14. The father, Keith S. Brown, 55, entered his plea on Thursday in Fourth Judicial District Court in Provo, Utah. In an agreement with prosecutors, Mr. Brown pleaded guilty to a first-degree felony count of sodomy and two second-degree felony counts of sexual abuse of a child. He faces a sentence of 10 years to life in prison at sentencing on March 31.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: Comedy

headline: The Looks That Lingered
text: THE tufted vinyl columns at Marc Jacobs’s show on Monday night were lighted in bordello red. “Looks like a boudoir moment,” the editor seated next to me offered sagely. On Wednesday morning, the young blogger sprinting alongside me to Michael Kors assured me with equal conviction that we would be having “a Halston moment.”

headline: Trend Report: New York Fashion Week Fall 2011
text: The story line that ultimately emerged on the runways was pure Americana.

headline: BBC Charts New Course for its U.S. Newscast
text: Tapping into what it sees as a need for impartial international news on cable, the BBC said Friday that it would aggressively seek distribution in the United States for BBC World News, its 24-hour news channel.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to the Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: A Winter Market’s Bounty
text: Good news for shoppers who miss the festive atmosphere of the summer  farmers’ market in Chappaqua. It’s still festive but now wintering indoors, cozy in the parish hall of the Church of St. Mary the Virgin.

headline: Iberian Specialties Reach a New Elevation
text: THERE was no way around it: After relishing smoky-sweet chouriço flambéed over Portuguese brandy and sipping tourmaline-pink cava at Bellota, on the 42nd floor of the Ritz-Carlton Westchester, we literally had to come back to earth. But with six inches of slush in the streets below, who could blame us for wanting to linger just a little longer?

headline: William Daley Made $8.7 Million from JPMorgan Last Year
text: The White House’s new chief of staff, William M. Daley, is rich — so much so that his recent earnings from JPMorgan Chase appear to give even Jamie Dimon’s pay package a run for the money.

headline: Finances Could Sink Seaport Museum
text: For more than a decade the Seaport Museum New York has struggled to stay afloat. But it has never looked closer to going under.

headline: Soups of the World
text: The daily rotation of five to eight soups at the NY Soup Exchange in Garden City has an international flair. On a recent day, hot and spicy Caribbean crab bisque shared the menu with teriyaki chicken and rice stew.

headline: Notes, Melodies and, Here, Politics
text: “I have something to say,” the talk-show host Glenn Beck once said, and his words, set to music by Matt Marks, made an unlikely keynote to “powerFUL,” a program of politically charged music performed on Thursday evening as part of the Tune-In Music Festival at the Park Avenue Armory.

headline: A Japanese Menu With Ideas of Its Own
text: ONSEN SUSHI may look like other Japanese storefront restaurants, but the four-month-old Oakdale newcomer is far from ordinary. Though the décor is spare and cool, the welcome is warm. From behind the sushi bar, Jason Chen shouts a cheery hello to patrons as they arrive and banters with them throughout the meal, asking how they like his creations.

headline: Alone With Thoughts and an Audience
text: “Body Madness” is a great name for the latest in Danspace Project’s series of platforms  a thematic grouping of performances, usually organized by an invited artist. They have mostly been a raging success, creating intriguing links between artists and works you might never have considered in the same context. The first part of “Body Madness”  put together by the director of Danspace, Judy Hussie-Taylor  is called “Absurdity and Wit,” and previous shows featured vogueing and aerobics in explorations of genre that were as entertaining as they were thought-provoking.

headline: The Sushi-Go-Round
text: Umi Sushi and Tapas, which opened in August, is one of the newest Japanese restaurants in Connecticut. Along with sushi rolls and nigiri pieces, it offers diners something different: dishes delivered via a conveyor belt.

headline: Game in the Major or in No-Trump?
text: One of the most enjoyable events in the Greater New York Bridge Association calendar is the Betty Kaplan Teams. This was played last Saturday and won by John Boyer of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.; David Moss and Andrew Rosenthal of New York City; and Robert Stayman of New Rochelle, N.Y.

headline: Tiny Kitchen Produces Wide Array of Delights
text: UPON entering Farmer’s Table in New Canaan, I found it hard to believe that so many different foods could emerge from such small quarters. Six starters, three soups, seven entrees and three desserts are all made on the premises for dinner, along with good, textured bread kneaded at the counter and baked in the minuscule kitchen. The fact that almost everything I tasted was delicious added to my incredulity.

headline: Defying Sexual Mores in Conservative Georgia
text: TBILISI, Georgia

headline: A Phone Plan With Music Built In
text: Prepaid phones are often a great deal, offering voice and data at a low price and without tying you to a two-year contract. But the stripped-down handsets often limit the apps and services.

headline: Tip of the Week: Making the Web Plain
text: Some Web pages are crowded with so many graphical elements that it can be hard to locate the text you went there to read in the first place. The latest version of Apple‘s Safari browser might help clear things up, however. When visiting an overly busy page, check the browser’s address bar to see if a small gray “Reader” button is visible. If so, click the button to get an uncluttered version of the page that is free of everything except the text and accompanying photographs.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Feb. 18
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: ‘Why Does College Cost So Much?’
text: In a week in which there was much talk in higher education circles about the full cost of tuition, The Times’s Economix blog has an interview with the authors of a book titled “Why Does College Cost So Much?”

headline: Imagination, Covered in Icing
text: GIVEN the popularity of the TLC reality show “Cake Boss” and its star, Buddy Valastro, owner of Carlo’s Bakery in Hoboken, one could be forgiven for assuming that Carlo’s, and only Carlo’s, bakes cakes replicating everything from human torsos to golf bags.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Feb. 18
text: More Photographs

headline: A Homecoming for Bighorn Sheep in Colorado
text: SEDALIA, Colo.  The mechanics were simple. A trailer latch popped, a gate swung open and three wild bighorn sheep  two females, presumably pregnant, and a year-old lamb, definitely frisky  trotted up the rocky slope of Thunder Butte under a pale afternoon sun.

headline: Podcast: Growth, the Deficit and the Elliott Wave
text: How rapidly will the economy grow this year? The Federal Reserve has become somewhat more upbeat about the prospects for growth, and we feature its new appraisal on this week’s Weekend Business podcast.

headline: Misery Most Proud, in Two Acts
text: “The Subject Was Roses,” a three-character play, is one of those small, relatively quiet dramas in which nothing much happens except that everything changes. Frank D. Gilroy’s Pulitzer Prize-winning 1964 drama about a young man’s viewing his troubled parents through fresh eyes is receiving a muted production at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick.

headline: A Place on the Right for a Few Godless Conservatives
text: As a child, Razib Khan spent several weeks studying in a Bangladeshi madrasa. Heather Mac Donald once studied literary deconstructionism and clerked for a left-wing judge. In neither case did the education take. They are atheist conservatives  Mr. Khan an apostate to his family’s Islamic faith, Ms. Mac Donald to her left-wing education.

headline: In Bahrain, the Bullets Fly
text: MANAMA, Bahrain

headline: Scorecard | Calvin Klein Collection Wins!
text: On the eighth and final day of a New York fashion week that turned out to be all about fashioning modern Americana, Scorecard knows critics weren’t quite sure what to make of the erstwhile master of prairie-luxe Ralph Lauren’s rather literal love letter to the screen siren glamour of a “Limehouse Blues”-era Anna May Wong. Meanwhile over at Calvin Klein, Francisco Costa infused his minimalist chic with a new sporty vibe. That was deemed a stylistic home run.

headline: A Bush Rule on Providers of Abortions Is Revised
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Friday rescinded most of a 2008 rule that granted sweeping protections to health care providers who opposed abortion, sterilization and other medical procedures on religious or moral grounds.

headline: Sublime Notions From a Species That Likes to Doodle
text: Is there anyone who hasn’t enjoyed making an abstract drawing  an elaborate classroom doodle, a Spirograph masterpiece, a tic-tac-toe game? Marking up a blank piece of paper, even in these pixel-fixated times, seems an inherently human activity. But the stunning new exhibition of abstract  or mostly abstract  drawings at the Katonah Museum of Art reveals the elements of the sublime in this sometimes mundane pursuit.

headline: Long Floor Fight Over Spending Cuts Gets Personal
text: WASHINGTON — It was billed as a battle over numbers, but the marathon floor fight in the House this week was more a drama over core political beliefs, with long-simmering resentments, partisan grandstanding and startling personal revelations sprinkled throughout the script.

headline: All-Star Weekend Turns Into Bidding War for Anthony
text: LOS ANGELES  The season-long spectacle involving Carmelo Anthony’s future is nearing a resolution, with the Nets and the Knicks making competing proposals to acquire the discontented All-Star from the Denver Nuggets.

headline: In a Range of Styles, an Improvisational Ethos
text: HOLED up in the Village Vanguard as a snowstorm raged last month, the pianist Jacky Terrasson was whipping up a storm of his own — attacking the keyboard, strumming and striking the instrument’s strings, and swinging and swaying atop his stool to an improbable mix of tunes like Michael Jackson’s “Beat It” and Duke Ellington’s “Caravan.”

headline: Approaching Abstraction, but Not Quite Getting There
text: The title of the current exhibition at the Nassau County Museum of Art, “Milton Avery and the End of Modernism,” on view through May 8, signals that it is an ambitious show. The end of modernism? That’s a huge subject, particularly in an art world where categories like modernism, postmodernism and the contemporary are still  and will probably never stop  being sorted out.

headline: Finding Eternal Youth (in Song, Anyway)
text: ASK the two-time Tony Award-winning actress Christine Ebersole to describe the cabaret show she will perform on March 4 at the Mayo Center for the Performing Arts in Morristown, and the answer comes out in themes.

headline: City to Toughen Auditing of School Test Scores
text: New York City school officials said Friday that they would introduce a new, rigorous system of auditing the test scores, grading practices and graduation rates of the public high schools, appearing to acknowledge rising concerns that some schools might be manipulating the statistics they are judged by.

headline: On the Street | Skirting
text: Many guests attending designers’ shows for next fall wore a transparent curtain-skirt, while some designers’ runway visions showed a marked drop — to mid and lower calf.

headline: HCA Expected to Seek $30 a Share in Public Offering
text: HCA, the hospital operator that was acquired by buyout firms in 2006, is seeking to price its initial public offering at as much as $30 a share when it begins its presentation to investors next week, people briefed on the matter said Friday. HCA has set a preliminary price of $27 to $30 for the stock sale, which is expected to be one of the biggest by a private equity-owned company in years. HCA was acquired in 2006 by a group led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Bain Capital and Merrill Lynch’s private equity arm. The company is one of the largest for-profit hospital operators in the United States, running 162 hospitals and 104 more surgery centers in the United States and Britain.

headline: Art School Runs Afoul of Facebook’s Nudity Police
text: The New York Academy of Art, a graduate university that has been teaching figurative art since 1982, is not the kind of institution you would expect to get into trouble for mischief on Facebook. Yet the school recently received a stern warning from the site: “You uploaded a photo that violates our Terms of Use, and this photo has been removed.” The message went on to explain the kinds of things that Facebook does not allow: photos that attack a person or group, that depict drug use or contain violence or nudity.

headline: Intel Plans New Chip Plant in Arizona
text: The Intel Corporation announced plans on Friday to build a $5 billion microprocessor plant in Arizona and hire 4,000 employees in the United States this year. The workers will focus on product development, research and design, the chief executive, Paul S. Otellini, said. Mr. Otellini disclosed the plans for the plant during a visit by President Obama to an Intel plant near Portland, Ore. The new plant will be located at the company’s existing site in Chandler, Ariz.

headline: Up-and-Comer Finds the Top
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  The tears flowed freely a year ago for Jamie McMurray, a driver with a redemption story that played out on Nascar’s grandest stage.

headline: Find the Taxes That Do Double Duty
text: THE nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office projects a cumulative federal deficit of nearly $3.8 trillion over the next four years. So the $100 billion in annual spending cuts advocated by House Republicans will have a negligible impact on that total.

headline: Rodman In and Miller Out as Hall Finalists Are Named
text: LOS ANGELES  The basketball Hall of Fame announced 12 finalists for enshrinement in 2011 on Friday.

headline: Boldface Names With Guns
text: Among those licensed to own handguns in New York City are City Council members, actors, business moguls, lawyers and judges.

headline: What Makes Community Health Care Work?
text: ﻿In response to Tuesday’s column about two programs in India that train relatively uneducated women as their villages’ health workers, readers provided an avalanche of information about other community health worker programs around the world. Gregory Ortiz from London (95) wrote about Operation ASHA, which has semi-literate counselors treating tuberculosis in slums in India and Cambodia.  In thefield from Alaska (109) wrote about para-dentists in rural Alaska.    Marianne Loewe (121) from Santa Ana, Calif., commented on her organization, Concern America, which works with health promoters in Colombia and Central America.

headline: A Watershed Moment for Public-Sector Unions
text: In the half century since Wisconsin became the first state to give its public workers the right to bargain collectively, government employee unions have mushroomed in size and power  so much so that they now account for more than half of the nation’s union members.

headline: Holding Out Hope for a Missing Son
text: Here is living room furniture with the memories locked in, waiting for release:

headline: Plan for Indian Casino in the Catskills Is Rejected
text: The federal government rejected a proposal on Friday to build an Indian casino in the Catskills, nullifying a deal reached in the waning days of the Paterson administration to settle a land claim by a tribe based in Wisconsin.

headline: Healing a Wounded Credit Score
text: Millions of consumers have fallen out of favor with the credit scoring gods.

headline: For Autistic Children, a School’s Coffee Shop Imparts Skills While Raising Money
text: EDISON, N.J.  The coffee shop at Woodrow Wilson Middle School is serious about service with a smile. When Edward Lin, a seventh grader, stared silently at his feet the other day instead of greeting a customer, his teacher prodded him.

headline: Shareholders Offer a Spate of Climate and Environmental Resolutions
text: After a year marked by Congressional paralysis on issues like global warming and renewable energy, and after a parade of energy-related disasters  including the huge oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico  social investment groups are signaling their displeasure with a suite of shareholder resolutions.

headline: Wisconsin Leads Way as Workers Fight State Cuts
text: The unrest in Wisconsin this week over Gov. Scott Walker’s plan to cut the bargaining rights and benefits of public workers is spreading to other states.

headline: The Rich, the Famous, the Armed
text: MEN and women. Democrats and Republicans. Doctors, lawyers, merchants and moguls. A remarkable, if relatively small, cross-section of New Yorkers legally own handguns, according to public records obtained by The New York Times.

headline: Resolution Requested in Bonds Case
text: The federal judge presiding over Barry Bonds’s perjury case asked the sides on Friday to find a way to resolve the case before the trial next month. In a hearing in San Francisco, prosecutors told United States District Court Judge Susan Illston that they would discuss the option of a plea agreement with Bonds’s lawyers. But Bonds’s lead lawyer, Allen Ruby, said he expected the case to go to trial.

headline: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Offered Rosy View Before Bahrain Crackdown
text: WASHINGTON  At a town-hall-style meeting in Bahrain two months ago, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton got a pointed question from a member of Bahrain’s Parliament: was the United States letting Bahrain, a Persian Gulf ally, off the hook for a string of arrests of lawyers and human rights activists?

headline: N.F.L. and Union Quiet on Meeting
text: Small groups from the N.F.L. and the players union met with a federal mediator in Washington on Friday in the first in a planned series of meetings in an effort to achieve a breakthrough in the stalled negotiations over a new collective bargaining agreement.

headline: It Ended in a Suitcase
