text: THE 17-second video, assembled from security cameras in Harlem, showed what seemed to be an ordinary man, in a cap and a leather jacket, walking down the street with an ordinary suitcase. Neither, however, was ordinary, the authorities said. The man, they claimed, was a murderer; the suitcase held the body of a woman he had killed.

headline: After Long Exile, Sunni Cleric Takes Role in Egypt
text: CAIRO  Sheik Yusuf al-Qaradawi, an influential Sunni cleric who is banned from the United States and Britain for supporting violence against Israel and American forces in Iraq, delivered his first public sermon here in 50 years on Friday, emerging as a powerful voice in the struggle to shape what kind of Egyptian state emerges from the uprising that toppled Hosni Mubarak.

headline: William Webb’s World
text: William Webb was a typical Southerner. He was born in Georgia in the late 1840s, but like hundreds of thousands of Americans he rode the expansion of cotton westward, carried as a teenager first to Mississippi and then to Kentucky. Webb spent long days at work outdoors: driving wagons, hoeing cotton, harvesting tobacco. When he needed to raise cash, he sold homemade treats at camp meetings, those lengthy religious revivals popular among antebellum Americans. Webb started with ginger cakes, but when he realized that the Christians were not averse to something stronger, so he quickly switched to whiskey. It “paid the best,” Webb later admitted in a narrative he wrote years later.

headline: As Mediator in Mets Case, Mario Cuomo Has Practice
text: Mario M. Cuomo, the former New York governor, has made a career of brokering solutions to tense standoffs, including housing crises, budget battles and a prison inmate takeover.

headline: Message to Egypt From Qaeda’s No. 2
text: WASHINGTON  Al Qaeda’s Egyptian-born second in command, Ayman al-Zawahri, attacked secular rule in Egypt in an audio lecture released Friday, but the message appeared to have been recorded before President Hosni Mubarak stepped down last week.

headline: The Lure of a Price Tag That Says Zero
text: When Stop N Swap, the rolling caravan of other people’s junk, pulled up at the St. George Library on Staten Island one recent Saturday, the city’s latest initiative to remodel consumer habits was a modest, even slightly depressing affair: a few scraggly pieces of clothing hanging on a sparse rack and someone else’s housewares.

headline: Amid a Sea of Upheaval, Algeria Is Still
text: ALGIERS  Even as North African neighbors have smoldered, the oil-producing giant Algeria has kept a sullen calm in the wake of a stifled protest march here last week, with the regional upheaval, for now, not catching on.

headline: Sanctions Placed on Afghan Exchange
text: WASHINGTON  The Treasury Department imposed sanctions on Friday against one of the largest money exchange houses in Afghanistan, along with 15 of its executives, on charges that it used billions of dollars transferred in and out of the country to help hide proceeds from illegal drug sales.

headline: The Goal: Don’t Go to Manhattan
text: Kathryn S. Wylde, 64, president of the Partnership for New York City, the city’s premier business association, works days that start early and often stretch into the night. Once a month she takes a break and flies to Puerto Rico, where she spends five or six days — including one Sunday — with her husband, Wilfredo Lugo, 65, who lives full time at the couple’s home in Quebradillas, on the northwest coast. On most Sundays, she catches up on e-mail and makes plans for the week ahead from her co-op in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, which she shares with her cats — officially two, the limit her co-op allows.

headline: Nets Themselves the Biggest Obstacle to Luring Anthony
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Keeping Titles, and Targets, in Sight
text: SYDNEY SHAEFER honed her bow-and-arrow skills not in summer camp but by hunting small game in the Black Hills of South Dakota.

headline: A Suspect in a Killing Spree Is Indicted in Four Murders
text: The man accused of a violent 28-hour rampage through Brooklyn and Manhattan last week was indicted Friday on murder charges.

headline: Holiday Schedule for Washington’s Birthday
text: NEW YORK

headline: Preservationists Focus on a Little Brick House
text: Cooper Square was an unnamed but thriving business district about 1825 when a descendant of Peter Stuyvesant, Nicholas William Stuyvesant, built what is now one of the oldest remaining Federal-style houses on the Bowery.

headline: Former Interim Coach Reflects on Experience
text: When Wyoming Coach Heath Schroyer was dismissed last week and replaced on an interim basis by Fred Langley, Jared Grasso could relate.

headline: Illinois: Radical Group Member Denied Parole
text: Oscar Lopez Rivera, who has been in prison for almost 30 years for seditious conspiracy for his role in the Puerto Rican nationalist group the F.A.L.N., was denied parole Friday.

headline: Saturday: Like a Message in a Bottle
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Tim Croce is back with his third themeless puzzle, and he hits us with 10 10-letter entries that didn’t seem too tough for a Saturday. With the possible exception of 1 Across, they were all eminently gettable, many are unique and I thought they were all interesting. In general, I found that I tussled more with some of the shorter entries than I did with the longer ones. How did you do?

headline: Savoring Indian Cuisine, and Dealing With the Heat
text: When Rajesh Bhardwaj, who co-founded the Cafe Spice chain in 1997, decided to open a new Indian restaurant, he had something very different in mind from the typical hole in the wall a diner might find on East Sixth Street or in Jackson Heights, Queens. With hand-hewn stone walls, an antique wood palace gate and a long reflecting pool leading to a soaring dining room, Junoon, on 24th Street west of Fifth Avenue, offers high-toned food that spans India’s many regions and cooking techniques, formal service and an extensive wine list — with prices to match. Open since December, the restaurant has attracted affluent Indian immigrants like Salman Rushdie, guests from the Wyndham Garden hotel down the block and, on Tuesday evening, two friends chatting about work.

headline: Unrest Around the Region
text: LIBYA There were violent demonstrations in Benghazi, Libya’s second-largest city, for a third day. Human rights groups said 24 people had been killed across the country, although activists say the count could be much higher.

headline: When Parents Are Pushed to the Limit
text: To the Editor:

headline: Comfort With Riviera Course Carries Couples to Lead
text: LOS ANGELES  Fred Couples is 51 and can no longer practice. His back is so creaky that he cannot hit iron shots during his truncated pre-round warm-ups for fear he will tweak a disk and bring on spasms. As for post-round work, he just laughs and says he cannot recall the last time he did any.

headline: The Cause of Democracy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Beltran in Center? The Mets Will See
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Carlos Beltran played in only 64 games last year, and during much of that time he looked nothing like the superstar player he had been for most of his career. But in the last month of the season, and especially the final 14 games, the old Beltran reappeared, giving hope to the possibility that he could again become the Mets’ best all-around player.

headline: Afghan Women’s Shelters
text: To the Editor:

headline: France: Commentator Convicted for Inciting Racial Bias
text: A French court on Friday convicted the prominent commentator Éric Zemmour on charges of “provocation to racial discrimination” for televised comments in which he suggested that a majority of criminals in France were “black and Arab,” and said that employers “have the right” to deny employment to those ethnic groups. Mr. Zemmour was ordered to pay over $14,000 in legal fees and damages to the five rights groups that were the plaintiffs in the case, and also received suspended fines totaling $2,700. The commentator had “gone beyond the permitted bounds of the right to freedom of speech,” the court wrote in its decision, adding that Mr. Zemmour had a particular responsibility to respect those limits as a “professional of the media and of expression.” Mr. Zemmour’s lawyer, Olivier Pardo, said his client had not yet decided if he would appeal the decision.

headline: Church Sex Abuse Scandal
text: To the Editor:

headline: Vatican: Warning on Ticket Sales
text: The Vatican issued a rare statement on Friday warning people not to be fooled by agencies and Web sites selling tickets for the beatification of Pope John Paul II. It said no tickets were required for the ceremonies, in particular for the beatification Mass, which Pope Benedict XVI is expected to celebrate on May 1. Millions of visitors are expected in Rome for festivities surrounding the beatification of John Paul, which places him one step closer to sainthood. After the Mass on May 1, John Paul’s tomb will be moved from beneath St. Peter’s Basilica to its interior, where his remains will be on view.

headline: Less Crime, Fewer Prisons
text: To the Editor:

headline: Primed to Pick Up Where Pettitte Left Off
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Each of the 51 pitches Andy Pettitte threw for the Class AA Trenton Thunder last Sept. 9 was dutifully tracked by Manny Banuelos, a teenager sitting a few rows behind home plate who grew up in Mexico admiring the man on the mound, the modern-day patron saint of Yankee left-handers. That night Banuelos charted Pettitte’s velocity and his location, his selection and his movement, and afterward he had an epiphany.

headline: Apollo’s $48.9 Million Man
text: Apollo Global Management filed the seventh amendment to its filing with securities regulators late on Friday as its prepared for its long-awaited public listing on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Ligety’s Victory Helps U.S. Break Through
text: Ted Ligety came into last year’s Winter Olympics a medal favorite, especially given his status as a defending Olympic champion. Four members of the United States team combined to win a record eight medals in Vancouver, but Ligety did not reach the award podium.

headline: Three Days at the Pearl Roundabout
text: Manama, Bahrain

headline: Burke Shows Kaberle Respect While Maximizing His Trade Value
text: In trading Tomas Kaberle to Boston for a prospect, a first-round pick and a conditional pick on Friday, Toronto General Manager Brian Burke pulled off a rarity in the business of hockey transactions: he got both aspects of a complicated deal right.

headline: Sacred Cows, Angry Birds
text: The House of Representatives has been cutting like crazy! Down with Planned Parenthood and PBS! We can’t afford to worry about mercury contamination! Safety nets are too expensive!

headline: Empire at the End of Decadence
text: It’s time for us to stop lying to ourselves about this country.

headline: Democrats Propose Temporary Budget Extension
text: With a debate over government spending raging on the House floor, Democrats late Friday night proposed a temporary extension of the stopgap measure now financing the government that would maintain expenditures generally at 2010 levels through March 31 and avert a federal shutdown.

headline: Bloggingheads: Trains to Nowhere?
text: Bill Scher, left, of the Campaign for America's Future and Kristen Soltis of the Winston Group debate high-speed rail.

headline: Devils Top Rangers for 6th Win in Row
text: NEWARK  The roaring crowd at the Prudential Center might have begun to believe that the Devils could continue their improbable run at a playoff berth. But for Coach Jacques Lemaire, it is much too soon for such talk.

headline: Resilient Bond Between Sports and the Military
text: When Rep. Betty McCollum, Democrat of Minnesota, decided to take on Nascar last month, she did not know until midfight what she was getting into. All she knew was that everyone was being asked to make deep budget cuts and sacrifices and the Department of Defense said that it had no fat to cut.

headline: How Foreclosure and Bankruptcy Damage Your Credit Score
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, Tara Siegel Bernard explains what happens to your credit score when you pay multiple bills late, your home goes into foreclosure or you file for personal bankruptcy. She also gives readers a blueprint for repairing your credit report and credit score once the worst has happened.

headline: Low Point of Season Was Turning Point
text: It was not until St. John’s worst loss of the season that Coach Steve Lavin realized what could become of the team he inherited.

headline: Dave Duerson, Safety Who Made Pro Bowl 4 Times, Is Dead at 50
text: Dave Duerson, a four-time Pro Bowl safety who won Super Bowls with the Chicago Bears and the Giants, died on Thursday. He was 50.

headline: Teufel Is Sued Over Madoff Tie
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Tim Teufel, the Mets’ Class AAA manager in Buffalo, has long been known to have been an investor in Bernard L. Madoff’s multibillion-dollar Ponzi scheme. Now Teufel, like his Mets employers, is being sued by the trustee for the victims of Madoff’s fraud, who says Teufel profited from the crime.

headline: Teenage Wastelands
text: Vampires live forever, but vampire novels, even ones as popular as the “Twilight” series, eventually molder just like everything else, so publishers of young-adult fiction and the moviemakers who find inspiration from them have already moved on from fantasy about the undead to science fiction. A harbinger of what’s to come is “I Am Number Four,” based on the novel of the same title, which just opened in theaters. “I Am Number Four,” sold to DreamWorks even before it found a publisher, is ostensibly the work of one Pittacus Lore, an extraterrestrial. It’s really by James Frey, the author of the factually challenged memoir “A Million Little Pieces,” and Jobie Hughes, a minion hired as part of Frey’s latest project: Full Fathom Five, a literary sweatshop modeled on Damien Hirst’s art factory and designed to churn out Y.A. material for books, movies and TV.

headline: Medicaid and New York’s Budget
text: New York State spent more than $20 billion on Medicaid this fiscal year — or nearly a quarter of the total operating budget. With the state confronting a projected $10 billion deficit for next year, Gov. Andrew Cuomo has little choice but to cut back the program. The challenge will be to do that in a way that causes the least possible harm to some of the state’s most vulnerable citizens.

headline: The Virtual Attic
text: Last week, I moved to a new laptop. Because the new laptop is so fast and so baronially spacious, I went probing among the files to see if I could create a little more free space just for the fun of it. It was a nostalgic experience.

headline: Criminal Inquiry of Countrywide Chief Has Ended
text: Feb. 20 | Updated The New York Times’s Gretchen Morgenson has more on federal prosecutors’ dropping their case against Angelo R. Mozilo.

headline: Long Arms Reach for the Rim
text: JUBA, Sudan  His first two attempts sprung off the back of the rim, the ball careening through the air, the crowd sighing loudly. Mangistu Deng, 16, dribbled back to halfcourt, pounding the ball for his final dunk of the night.

headline: Photo Replay: Feb. 18
text: Pictures from the day in sports: winter sports, an opening day, and a foggy day for fishing.

headline: House Votes to Continue Army Sponsorships in Nascar
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  The House voted 281-148 on Friday to defeat an amendment to a larger government financing bill offered by Rep. Betty McCollum, Democrat of Minnesota, that would have ended the Army’s spending on Nascar racing.

headline: Somali Pirates Hijack Yacht With Americans Aboard
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  It is becoming a familiar tale of the Somali seas: A retired couple sets out for the trip of a lifetime, sailing around the world in a relatively small yacht, blogging all the way, sharing adventures of meeting people, seeing exotic locales and experiencing the thrill of being totally free.

headline: As House Votes to Cut $60 Billion, Standoff Looms
text: WASHINGTON — The House vote Saturday to slash more than $60 billion from the federal budget shows how powerfully the anti-spending fervor of the fall elections is driving the new Republican majority’s efforts to shrink government. It puts the two parties on a path to a succession of showdowns over the deficit and the nation’s growing debt.

headline: Dave Duerson, a Member of the Magical 1985 Bears
text: Andy Barall writes about pro football history for The Fifth Down. Dave Duerson died on Thursday at age 50. Dave Duerson was an important contributor to one of the most interesting and colorful defenses in N.F.L. history: the mid-’80s Chicago Bears. It was also one of the greatest. At its peak, in 1985, that defense wouldn’t just stop opponents, it would frequently intimidate and embarrass them. In his famous 46 defense, Buddy Ryan created a new role for the strong safety and Duerson fit the bill perfectly.

headline: The Weekend Word: Clocks Ticking
text: From Today’s Times:–Forging ahead amid speculation about a government shutdown, House Republicans pushed to approve the largest spending cuts in recent history Friday. Time is running out before the government’s current funding plan expires, leaving just two weeks for Congress to come to an agreement — one week of which will be spent in recess. And The Times’s David M. Herszenhorn reports even a temporary agreement might be too difficult to reach in time.

headline: Protesters Take Bahrain Square as Forces Leave
text: MANAMA, Bahrain — Thousands of jubilant protesters surged back into the symbolic heart of Bahrain on Saturday as the government withdrew its security forces, calling for calm after days of violent crackdowns.

headline: A Less Virtual Keypad for the iPhone
text: When people complain about the iPhone, one of the loudest complaints is the phone’s lack of a physical keypad. For many, no physical keys is a deal-breaker, driving consumers to a BlackBerry or Android phone instead.

headline: The Murdoch in Waiting
text: LONDON

headline: Feb. 19: Updates on Middle East Protests
text: On Saturday, The Lede continues to follow protest movements in Bahrain, Libya, Yemen, Iran, Iraq and Egypt. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists on the ground. A stream of Twitter messages on the protests is in this blog’s right column.

headline: Bad Central Bankers
text: Via Yves Smith, the Guardian has picked up on my remarks about Mervyn King’s politicization.

headline: Thank You, Boeing
text: For providing such a clear illustration of the forces driving the theory of the firm.

headline: Wisconsin
text: Yes, I’m on it. Getting all my facts in a row before I comment.

headline: Laugh Lines
text: JAY LENO

headline: Fighting Words
text: The BBC asked the British novelist Martin Amis whether he would ever write a children’s book. His answer tipped a few teacups in the nursery.

headline: Prime Number
text: 10: The number of milliseconds it took the I.B.M. computer Watson to buzz in when confident of its response during a game of “Jeopardy!” Watson’s competition, the former champions Ken Jennings and Brad Rutter, usually looked like Old West fighters who couldn’t quite draw their guns out of their holsters fast enough. Ten milliseconds, or a centisecond, is one-hundredth of a second. By the way, that’s much faster than the blink of an eye.

headline: Delirious Joy in Bahrain
text: BAHRAIN — There’s delirious joy in the center of Bahrain right now. People power has prevailed, at least temporarily, over a regime that repeatedly used deadly force to try to crush a democracy movement. Pro-democracy protesters have retaken the Pearl Roundabout – the local version of Tahrir Square – from the government. On a spot where blood was shed several days ago there are now vast throngs kissing the earth, chanting slogans, cheering, honking and celebrating. People handed me flowers and the most common quotation I heard was: “It’s unbelievable!”

headline: Dolphins to Boats: Put a Cork in It
text: Noise has increased a hundredfold in many parts of the ocean over the last 50 years, according to National Geographic, a result of dramatic growth in shipping and other human activities. The problem is getting steadily worse for another reason. Seawater is absorbing less sound as carbon dioxide from fossil-fuel burning seeps into the ocean and acidifies it. “For many of these animals it’s as if they live in cities,” Brandon Southall, a marine scientist, says of the din. The noise has led to changes in foraging, calling and migration patterns among many species of whales and dolphins.

headline: Uganda President Takes Big Lead in Re-Election Bid
text: KAMPALA, Uganda  President Yoweri Museveni appeared to take a commanding early lead on Saturday in the presidential election here, capturing nearly 69 percent of the vote, with about 77 percent of polling sites reporting, a government Web site showed.

headline: Fashion in 1943
text: With World War II in full throttle, the federal government imposed regulations restricting the use of wool, silk, leather and nylon in clothing. Designers thus faced the challenge of doing more with less. How did they respond? “With astounding ingenuity,” The Times’s Virginia Pope reported at the time. For designers, Ms. Pope reported, “the limitations imposed were an asset rather than a hindrance. They evolved a new silhouette — one that will go down in fashion history as the ‘duration’ silhouette. It is sleek, slim, functional, expressive of active American womanhood.”

headline: Kathleen Mortimer, Rich and Adventurous, Dies at 93
text: Her grandfather ran a railroad, and her father was an ambassador, a governor and a cabinet secretary. She married the grandson of an oil baron at her family’s 25,000-acre estate.

headline: Variety: And Sometimes My Diagramless
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Confused by the title? You won’t be, once you solve.

headline: Asking for a Lot, Perhaps Too Much, from St. Louis
text: Ever since Albert Pujols’s self-imposed deadline for a new contract with the St. Louis Cardinals passed Wednesday without a deal, speculation has been rampant about whether he will re-sign, how much he could command as a free agent and whether he will be worth it. He is reportedly seeking $300 million over 10 years, and his employers are believed to have offered less than $200 million  a gap that is bigger than the entire value of all but a handful of contracts in history.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: As G20 Leaders Set Deal, Geithner Criticizes China
text: PARIS  Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner took direct aim at China on Saturday at a meeting of the world’s most powerful economies, saying that its currency was still “substantially undervalued” and that recent steps taken by Beijing to adjust its value were too small.

headline: Case on Mortgage Official Is Said to Be Dropped
text: Federal prosecutors in Los Angeles have dropped their criminal investigation into Angelo R. Mozilo, the former chief executive of Countrywide Financial, once the nation’s largest mortgage lender, according to a person with direct knowledge of the investigation.

headline: Cycle of Suppression Rises in Libya and Elsewhere
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Libyan security forces moved against protesters Saturday in Benghazi, the country’s second-largest city and the epicenter of the most serious challenge to four decades of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s rule, opposition leaders and residents said. The death toll rose to at least 104 people, most of them in Benghazi, Human Rights Watch reported.

headline: Promising Female Player Stows Her Passport
text: Christen Press said she was exactly where she wanted to be, except that she probably is not.

headline: Writing ‘Danger’ in Ever-Larger Letters
text: THE stock market has been thrilling lately. Thanks to the marvel of the mobile Internet, I’ve been able to check my account balances throughout the day, just for the pleasure of watching them rise  which is probably a sign that something’s wrong.

headline: Unrest Encircles Saudis, Stoking Sense of Unease
text: WASHINGTON  As pro-democracy uprisings spread across the Middle East, the rulers of Saudi Arabia  the region’s great bulwark of religious and political conservatism  are feeling increasingly isolated and concerned that the United States may no longer be a reliable backer, officials and diplomats say.

text: Protesters were jubilant as security forces withdrew and the people retook Pearl Square Saturday morning.

Gemza performed the ceremony at St. Mary Church in Greenwich, Conn., where he is the parochial vicar.

text: Kelley Elizabeth Morrell and David Scott Stolzar were married Saturday at the Hay-Adams hotel in Washington. Larissa Chernock, a friend of the bride, officiated with the assistance of Christopher M. Mancuso, a friend of the bridegroom. Both became Universal Life ministers for the occasion.

text: Miranda Beth Litt and Will Franklin Saunders are to be married Sunday at the Union League club in Philadelphia. Rabbi Shimon L. Berris is to officiate, with the Rev. James Harris, a United Methodist minister, taking part in the ceremony.

text: Evelyn Paz Solis and Frank Paul Pipitone were married Saturday at Brecknock Hall, a historic home in Greenport, N.Y. The Rev. Marie April Gismondi, a minister of the Church of Ancient Ways, officiated.

headline: On Mondays, Look Forward to Coming In
text: This interview with Laura Ching, co-founder and chief merchandising officer of TinyPrints.com, an online card and stationery company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: A Swarm of Wasps, if Not Investors
text: THE white paper by the Georgia scientists Glen C. Rains and W. Joe Lewis has a technical-sounding title that masks the exciting news within. “A Project to Bring Innovative New Technology Into the Market Place for Detecting Agents of Harm in Agriculture, Security, and Human Health/Safety Arenas,” it says blandly.

headline: Independent Scholars: A Nomadic Lot
text: IN 1992, I quit my teaching job at the University of Arkansas, put everything into storage, cashed in my life savings  a stupendous $10,000  and moved to Rome to begin the first phase of research for a project that has become my life’s work. My money ran out nine months later, but by then the project had begun to take on a life of its own, and I had become an independent scholar.

headline: The Family-Business Test
text: MY father, Tino, started our family business, an electronic assembly and manufacturing company, in 1991 because he was tired of all the reorganizations and layoffs at high-tech companies where he worked. He’s Hispanic and a Vietnam veteran and always wanted to be an entrepreneur. The layoffs pushed him to do it.

headline: Attackers Wearing Army Uniforms Make Deadly Assault on Bank in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  As Afghan soldiers and police officers lined up on Saturday to get their monthly salaries at a bank in downtown Jalalabad, they became targets for seven heavily armed attackers in Army uniforms who had joined them, Afghan officials said.

headline: Two Cosmetics Giants, Flaws and All
text: THERE is a wonderful anecdote about the great Helena Rubinstein in “Ugly Beauty: Helena Rubinstein, L’Oréal and the Blemished History of Looking Good” (HarperCollins). One morning in 1964, not long before her death at the (approximate) age of 92, three armed robbers disguised as flower deliverymen gained entrance to her Park Avenue apartment, where she was in bed, eating breakfast.

headline: Recipe for Coke? One More to Add to the File
text: ATLANTA  —  Over the years, the public radio show “This American Life” has done some ambitious work. It was the first media outlet in the country to broadcast lengthy interviews with Guantánamo Bay prisoners. It sent reporters to Iraq for a month. And it exposed the misdeeds of a hedge fund.

headline: The Tigers Are Supporting Their Star Through Another Setback
text: LAKELAND, Fla.  The Detroit Tigers held their first full-squad workout of spring training on Saturday, but their best player was not here. First baseman Miguel Cabrera is home in South Florida, awaiting a doctor’s evaluation after his arrest on suspicion of drunken driving.

headline: Bronx Man Is Linked to Two Rapes a Decade Apart
text: The authorities have linked a 39-year-old Bronx man who they believe raped a woman in the Bronx in November with another rape in the Bronx in 2000.

headline: Boom Time to Bankruptcy
text: Over eight years, the federal government paid at least $20 million for counterterrorism video technology that documents and interviews suggest to be a hoax.

headline: Hiding Details of Dubious Deal, U.S. Invokes National Security
text: WASHINGTON  For eight years, government officials turned to Dennis Montgomery, a California computer programmer, for eye-popping technology that he said could catch terrorists. Now, federal officials want nothing to do with him and are going to extraordinary lengths to ensure that his dealings with Washington stay secret.

headline: A Season of Giving Motivates Donors in Greater Numbers
text: The 99th New York Times Neediest Cases Fund campaign began Nov. 7 and ended Jan. 30. Daily articles in the newspaper and online offered a window into the lives of New Yorkers coping with poverty and spotlighted how the fund helped ease some of their struggles.

headline: Ernie Tyler, the Ironman of Umpire Attendants, Dies at 86
text: In the sports world, showing up for work every day is so valued that consecutive-game streaks are hallowed in the record books. Lou Gehrig, the Yankees first baseman known as the Iron Horse, for example, played in 2,130 straight games, a record that seemed unassailable until Cal Ripken, the Baltimore Orioles infielder, broke it; his streak reached 2,632 games.

headline: Can You Frisk a Hard Drive?
text: If you stand with the Customs and Border Protection officers who staff the passport booths at Dulles airport near the nation’s capital, their task seems daunting. As a huge crowd of weary travelers shuffle along in serpentine lines, inspectors make quick decisions by asking a few questions (often across language barriers) and watching computer displays that don’t go much beyond name, date of birth and codes for a previous customs problem or an outstanding arrest warrant.

headline: Protests Continue to Surge
text: Thousands of jubilant Bahrainis returned on Saturday to Manama’s Pearl Square, the focal point of bloody anti-regime demonstrations, after police and troops withdrew in an apparent conciliatory move.

headline: Twilight of the Teen Idol
text: The Beliebers were out in force last weekend. You could see them in “Justin Bieber: Never Say Never,” the rushed-to-market movie — as much documentary about fandom as concert film — that had opening-weekend ticket sales of more than $30 million. On screen, Mr. Bieber’s fans were everywhere, a screaming and devoted army, more emotive and compelling than the object of their affection. In the audience of the movie theater where I saw the film, they were also screaming and devoted, gasping when Mr. Bieber was seen shirtless and cooing when his baby pictures were shown.

headline: For Wisconsin Governor, Battle Was Long Coming
text: MADISON, Wis. — Just last fall, people here were waving campaign signs. But the blocks around the State Capitol have been filled for the past week with protesters brandishing signs with a different message — demanding a recall of Gov. Scott Walker, calling him a bully and likening him to Scrooge, Hosni Mubarak, even Hitler.

headline: So Much on the Line for Miguel Cabrera
text: LAKELAND, Fla. — The Detroit Tigers held their first full-squad workout of spring training on Saturday, but Miguel Cabrera was home in South Florida. He is awaiting a doctor’s evaluation after his arrest Wednesday on suspicion of drunken driving.

headline: Monopoly, Milton Friedman’s Way
text: When Hasbro showed a new version of Monopoly last week at the Toy Fair, people were aghast that an infrared tower in the center of the board would squawk instructions, track players’ money and make sure that everyone abided by the rules.

headline: The Legacy of 18 Days in Tahrir Square
text: CAIRO  Tahrir means liberation in Arabic, but until three weeks ago, Tahrir Square’s name hardly fitted it. Egyptians would drive around it, stuck in their cars, incessantly honking their horns, to get past a congested downtown traffic circle before veering off in different directions.

headline: Par 140? Twitter Hits the PGA Tour
text: LOS ANGELES  The generational contrast between the not-so-tech-savvy 36-hole leader of the Northern Trust Open and the PGA Tour’s use of social networking last week is evidence of golf’s ability to span decades and gracefully embrace change.

headline: Reporting While Female
text: Last winter, I reported on a religious festival in Pakistan, attended by thousands of worshipers. There were no women, at least that I could see. As I waded through the crowds, I held my breath, looking behind me every few seconds, warding off gropers, pushing them away with my hands.

headline: Anthony Draws the Line With Nets
text: LOS ANGELES — Carmelo Anthony is informing those close to him that he will not sign a contract extension if he is traded to the Nets, according to a person aware of Anthony’s preference.

headline: When Armies Decide
text: WASHINGTON — There comes a moment in the life of almost every repressive regime when leaders — and the military forces that have long kept them in power — must make a choice from which there is usually no turning back: Change or start shooting.

headline: Dueling Protests in a Capital as Nothing Much Gets Done
text: MADISON, Wis.  In a capital city overrun for much of the past week by union supporters, state employees and students  all objecting to the Republican governor’s plan to cut collective bargaining rights and benefits for public workers  a new element was introduced on Saturday: opposition to the opposition.

headline: Jilted in the U.S., a Site Finds Love in India
text: IN 2008, three young guys in Manhattan started Ignighter.com, a dating Web site focused on twentysomethings. They sought to set themselves apart by enabling members to set up group dates: One member, serving as a point person, could arrange a date  a movie, say, or a picnic in Central Park  with a group of other people and thereby take some of the awkward edge off of typical dates.

headline: Why We Need Women in War Zones
text: THOUSANDS of men blocked the road, surrounding the S.U.V. of the chief justice of Pakistan, a national hero for standing up to military rule. As a correspondent for The Chicago Tribune, I knew I couldn’t just watch from behind a car window. I had to get out there.

headline: Levine Misses ‘Don Pasquale’ Matinee

headline: Sunday: Gift From Above
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — I’m going to start by saying that it’s very difficult for me, as a writer and a constructor, to resist making a joke or pun where one so clearly needs to be made. There’s one here today, based on Liz Gorski’s puzzle, but I’m going to be disciplined and professional. I want you to know upfront that I’m going to try to get through this post without making this joke, because you are all very smart and it will most likely give away the theme. So I’m going to keep my mouth shut.

headline: Nevada Seeks to Cut Funds for Treating Gambling Addiction

headline: Along the Columbia, Concerns for Salmon and Energy Production

headline: Oil Flows, but High Prices Jangle Nerves
text: PARIS  The turmoil in North Africa and the Middle East has helped drive oil prices up to more than $102 a barrel for an important benchmark crude, Brent, although so far there have been no significant disruptions in production or supply, according to experts at the International Energy Agency here.

headline: A Monopoly on Cheating
text: I HATE cheats. They cut the line and snatch the bargain. They sweet-talk the customer service rep into bending the rules. They count cards and win the raffle with some sneaky ticket placement. They are the 100th caller every time. They trick you on mileage or square footage and bribe their way up the organ transplant list. They pump and dump their stocks, their families, their friends. They get ahead and they win. We lose. Then they explain ever so condescendingly that it’s not a zero-sum game.

headline: Russian Trial to Bare a Face of Nationalism
text: MOSCOW  It once seemed as if Nikita Tikhonov was positioning himself to join this country’s political elite: he attended the prestigious Moscow State University, founded a right-wing political magazine called The Russian Way and worked as a campaign aide for a parliamentary candidate.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Post-Tucson Traumatic Stress Disorder
text: SIX weeks after that horrific day in Tucson, America has half-forgotten its violent debate over the power of violent speech to incite violence. It’s Gabrielle Giffords’s own power of speech that rightly concerns us now. But all those arguments over political language did leave a discernible legacy. In the aftermath of President Obama’s Tucson sermon, civility has had a mini-restoration in Washington. And some of the most combative national figures in our politics have been losing altitude ever since, much as they did after Bill Clinton’s oratorical response to the inferno of Oklahoma City.

text: WASHINGTON  High winds whipped through the metropolitan Washington area on Saturday, downing power lines, fueling brush fires and even toppling the National Christmas Tree.

headline: Fat Monkeys
text: Scientists are using monkeys, primarily rhesus macaques, to study the twin epidemics of obesity and diabetes. The animals eat high-fat diets and lead sedentary lives. As one researcher says, “We are trying to induce the couch potato style.”

headline: Today’s Lab Rats of Obesity: Furry Couch Potatoes
text: HILLSBORO, Ore.  Like many these days, Shiva sits around too much, eating rich, fatty foods and sipping sugary drinks. He has the pot belly to prove it, one that nearly touches the floor  when he’s on all fours, that is.

headline: Chicago Candidates Skirt Financial Crisis
text: When voters go to the polls Tuesday to pick Chicago’s first new mayor since the 1980s, they can reflect on a lively campaign that featured topics ranging from education and crime to whether one of the mayoral hopefuls had smoked crack.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Feb. 20
text: The House of Representatives burned the midnight oil last week, passing a continuing resolution with more than $60 billion in spending cuts shortly after 4:30 a.m. Saturday. With two weeks to hammer out an agreement in Congress and sidestep a government shutdown, the budget joins the Middle East uprisings as the dominant topics on the Sunday talk shows.

headline: Patrick Makes Progress, and Stewart Prevails
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Danica Patrick led a lap at Daytona International Speedway on Saturday, a sign of progress that Patrick, Nascar’s next great marketing hope, is getting up to speed in racing stock cars for a living. But there was no storybook ending for Patrick or her boss, Dale Earnhardt Jr., in the lower-level Drive4Copd 300 Nationwide Series race.

headline: Crawley Town Is Out of F.A. Cup, and So Is Chelsea
text: Crawley Town, which stands a mere 93 places below Manchester United on the English soccer ladder, held its own with the Premier League leaders at Old Trafford before falling, 1-0, in the fifth round of the F.A. Cup on Saturday. Crawley was joined on the exit ramp by Chelsea, which lost to Tim Howard and Everton on penalties. Read more here and click the headline above to comment.

headline: Power Failures Thrust Deregulation Into Public Glare
text: For the Texas power industry, this has been a time of soul-searching angst. Three weeks ago, dozens of the state’s power generators failed in frigid weather, causing the worst blackouts in years and prompting multiple investigations. State lawmakers are demanding to know what went wrong.

headline: The Unemployed Need Not Apply
text: The Federal Reserve is projecting unemployment to continue at or near 9 percent for the rest of the year. That is 13.9 million Americans out of work. Here is more grim news: Barriers to employment for jobless workers may be even higher than previously thought.

headline: This Just In ...
text: President Obama is not a foreigner. He is not secretly a Muslim. Those are the facts, but they do not seem to matter in many quadrants of the Republican Party.

headline: Italy’s Trials
text: Italian governments are rarely known for efficiency. But even the country’s most pressing problems are being ignored since a court ruled last week that Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi must stand trial on charges of prostitution with an under-age girl and abusing his office to cover it up.

headline: Lawmakers May Come to Charter Schools’ Aid
text: It took seven years for Houston-based Harmony Public Schools, the state’s largest charter network and one of its best academically, to secure a bank bond in 2007 to buy and remodel buildings on its 33 campuses. Since then, it has obtained two additional bonds  the most recent for $90 million issued last year  to continue its expansion.

headline: As Chorus Swells, Griffin Leaps Car to Win Contest

In the All-Star weekend’s slam-dunk contest  an event that seemed tailor-made for Griffin  he tried the same, only a car stood as his obstacle.
