text: LOS ANGELES  It has been a long time between PGA Tour victories for the top four players on the leader board going into the final round of the Northern Trust Open, and the difference on Sunday may just come down to which of them has the longest memory.

headline: Mets’ Dickey Is Writing a Self-Portrait, Warts and All
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  About five years ago, around the time that R. A. Dickey decided to dig his fingernails into a baseball full time and cross a boundary into the eccentric, lonely world of a knuckleball pitcher, he also began to get a grip on his life as a husband, father, friend and son.

headline: Santi Santamaría, Catalan Chef, Dies at 53
text: MADRID  Santi Santamaría, a chef and restaurant owner who helped raise the international profile of Spanish cuisine but invited controversy by criticizing avant-garde chefs and their techniques, including the use of chemical emulsifiers, died on Wednesday in Singapore. He was 53.

headline: For One Teenage Champion, Moscow Is a Charmed City
text: Le Quang Liem startled the chess world last year when he won the top section of the prestigious Aeroflot Open in Moscow. He was 18 and had just entered the top 100.

headline: Protests and Counterprotests in Wisconsin
text: As protesters objecting to the Republican governor’s plan to cut collective bargaining rights and benefits for public workers rallied at the state Capitol, supporters of the bill also gathered.

headline: A Candidate for Mayor? Lee Says He Isn’t One
text: With eight months left until the November election, the semiofficial list of candidates for mayor of San Francisco looks something like this: a city attorney, a state senator, three former supervisors, the tax assessor and a Silicon Valley businesswoman.

headline: At the Free University, in a Store Basement, the Tuition Price Is Right
text: The newest university to open its doors in San Francisco has no official curriculum, no accredited course work, no grades and no paid teachers.

headline: Gifted Programs Go on Block as Schools Must Do With Less
text: When she was just 3, Teela Huff understood how to add numbers. By third grade, she was tutoring her peers.

headline: A Quest to Add Sophistication to Beer’s Appeal
text: Like soaring architecture, wily crooks and hard-hitting sports, a good beer is something Chicagoans love. Ray Daniels has gone one further: He wants to know exactly what makes a good beer good and use that knowledge to improve the beer-drinking experience.

headline: In Farewell, a Blueprint for Running Chicago
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Teixeira Tries New Approach After Down Year
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Routines are normally standard fare for Mark Teixeira, the son of a former Navy pilot, but not after last season. Instead of playing golf or riding a bike during that first, dark month of the off-season, he rehabilitated his torn hamstring. Instead of easing into his hitting program, he accelerated it, even buying a pitching machine to use as he pleased. Instead of spending a free half-hour in the weight room, he would take swings left-handed, searching for the consistency that eluded him in 2010.

headline: Before Suicide, Duerson Said He Wanted Brain Study
text: Before he shot himself fatally in the chest Thursday, the former Chicago Bears defensive back Dave Duerson sent family members text messages requesting that his brain tissue be examined for the same damage recently found in other retired players, two people aware of the messages said Saturday night.

headline: Outdoor Classics Spawn Border Brouhaha
text: The N.H.L.’s second Heritage Classic will be played Sunday at McMahon Stadium in Calgary, a revival of the league’s first regular-season outdoor game from eight years ago designed to feature two Canadian teams. The first game matched the Montreal Canadiens against the host Edmonton Oilers. Montreal will once again provide the opposition, this time for the Flames.

headline: Biding Time in Atlanta
text: Michael Gearon Jr., part of the Atlanta Thrashers’ ownership group, said last Wednesday that there was a “sense of urgency” over the long-futile search for new investors in the club, which according to court documents has lost more than $130 million since 2005.

headline: Basketball Grows With Peace in South Sudan
text: As violence has declined, young people in southern Sudan are rekindling an interest in basketball. Some Sudanese are among the tallest people in the world.

headline: Photo Replay: Feb. 19
text: Pictures of the day in sports: injuries, hopes and celebrations.

headline: Fire at 6-Story Building in Brooklyn
text: 11:20 a.m. | Updated A 62-year-old retired guidance counselor was killed and hundreds of residents were displaced Saturday night when a five-alarm blaze ripped through a six-story residential building in Brooklyn.

headline: Progress of Negotiations Is Hidden in Semantics
text: LOS ANGELES  In the vaguest of terms, and in the loosest semantics, the N.B.A. and its players union inched toward each other this weekend in their stalled collective bargaining talks. Even that slim bit of progress is subject to some debate.

headline: Koufax, a Madoff Investor, Offers Support to Wilpon
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  There was a full roster of Bernard L. Madoff investors at Mets camp Saturday, with Sandy Koufax, Fred Wilpon and Tim Teufel all on hand. On Thursday, Wilpon addressed the situation surrounding his investments in Madoff’s multibillion-dollar Ponzi scheme, and on Saturday, Teufel and Koufax took their turns.

headline: Rolls-Royce Goes Electric for Geneva Auto Show
text: The Rolls-Royce Phantom‘s prodigious V-12 engine, capable of compelling nearly three tons of iron, leather and exotic hardwoods from a standstill to 60 miles per hour in under six ticks of a Piaget watch, has new competition, and it comes with a plug port.

headline: Deficits Reshape the Debate as Republicans Jockey for 2012
text: WASHINGTON  Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana described the nation’s fiscal condition in dark terms more often reserved for a terror threat, declaring, “We face an enemy lethal to liberty and even more implacable than those America has defeated before.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
In a Town Built Upon Patronage, a Test of Egypt’s New Order
text: BAGOUR, Egypt  In a town he represented in Parliament for 46 years, Kamal al-Shazli left his mark. There is the Kamal al-Shazli School on Kamal al-Shazli Street, around the corner from the Kamal al-Shazli Mosque, which is a little ways from the cafe where Mr. Shazli held court when he was the only man in town who got things done.

headline: 3 Rangers on Their American Youth Hockey Memories
text: To mark Hockey Day in America, we asked three U.S.-born Rangers for their memories of growing up playing the great winter game. Brandon Dubinsky, from Anchorage, Alaska, talked about the outdoor rinks associated with every school in town. Michael Sauer, from Sartell, Minn., remembered the town fire department coming by to help make kids’ backyard rinks. Ryan McDonagh, from the Twin Cities suburb of Arden Hills, spoke about the second-hand Zamboni that anyone could use to resurface the park rink.

headline: A Night of Greek Drama
text: Ah, a lovely Greek evening. The lights in the harbor. The scent of grilling meat. The choking smoke of a thousand flares.

headline: In Amsterdam, a Look at Picasso’s Paris Days
text: Pablo Picasso spent time painting in Paris between 1900 and 1907, a period when he grew from a struggling Spanish artist to a leader of the French avant-garde. Today, paintings from those years are among the most sought after Picassos on the market. Through May 29, the Van Gogh Museum is hosting “Picasso in Paris,” a collection of 70 pieces from that era.

headline: Qaddafi’s Son Warns of Civil War as Libyan Protests Widen
text: CAIRO  A five-day-old uprising in Libya took control of its second-largest city of Benghazi and spread for the first time to the capital of Tripoli late on Sunday as the heir-apparent son of its strongman, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, warned Libyans in a televised speech that their oil-rich country would fall into civil war and even renewed Western “colonization” if they threw off his father’s 40-year-long rule.

headline: Dave Duerson, and Making Football Safer
text: It’s too early to say whether Dave Duerson’s suicide was tied to head injuries he sustained in football. But brain impairment was something that concerned him in his final months:

headline: How Far Will a Revolution Reach?
text: Residents of the town of Bagour in the Nile Delta celebrated the fall of a powerful state leader and his party, even as many freely acknowledge reaping their rewards.

headline: Columbia Coach Has Archers on Target
text: Since taking over as head coach in 2005, Coach Derek Davis has the female archery team at Columbia University winning national championships and conquering the mental side of shooting.

headline: Victory, Martyrs and Mourning
text: CAIRO — The days of our revolution were given various and expressive names. Jan. 28 was the Friday of Rage; Feb. 2, the Day of the Camels, when we were attacked by N.D.P. thugs riding horses and camels; and of course Departure Friday, when we, well, gently nudged the president to pack up and leave.

headline: Where Hockey Is Growing, State by State
text: USA Hockey has been keeping track of player registration on a state-by-state basis since the 1998-99 season, enabling us to get a snapshot of where the game is growing — and shrinking — in the United States. So, on this Hockey Day in America, we present those statistics.

headline: President of Uganda Coasts Into a Fourth Term
text: KAMPALA, Uganda  President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda was re-elected to a fourth term in a presidential election on Friday, the country’s electoral commission announced Sunday.

headline: Cano Won’t Seek Contract Extension From Yankees
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The lone television in the Yankees’ clubhouse was tuned Sunday morning to the MLB Network, which was showing a program that ranked the best second basemen in baseball. As No. 1 appeared on the screen, he also walked out of the food room. Robinson Cano took his physical exam early Sunday after mixing up the team’s reporting dates, drawing some playful ribbing from Derek Jeter and Alex Rodriguez.

headline: A Wallet Lost 40 Years Ago Now Is Found
The Maya Archaeologists at Ceibal
text: Takeshi Inomata, a professor of anthropology at the University of Arizona, writes from Guatemala, where he and Daniela Triadan are excavating the Maya site of Ceibal, Guatemala.

headline: Top 10 Composers? Been There, Done That. What About Poets?
text: Attentive ArtsBeat readers must have noticed by now that we can’t resist any excuse to mention our recent Top 10 Composers project. Here we go again.

headline: Chinese Government Responds to Call for Protests
text: BEIJING — Skittish domestic security officials responded with a mass show of force across China on Sunday after anonymous calls for protesters to stage a Chinese “Jasmine Revolution” went out over social media and microblogging outlets.

headline: Iran Squelches Protest Attempt in Capital
text: Antigovernment protesters gathered throughout parts of Iran on Sunday, most concentrated in the capital Tehran, to mark the deaths of two men killed during demonstrations last Monday. The government mounted a stultifying security presence in the capital, with the police making arrests and using tear gas to try to prevent the unrest from escalating.

headline: Peacekeepers In Somalia Hit Trenches Of Rebels
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia  At least 20 people were killed and dozens wounded in heavy fighting in Somalia’s capital over the weekend, as African Union forces attacked an extensive underground fortification system of trenches and tunnels used by Islamist insurgents.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Central St. Martins
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#304", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: Next Question for Tunisia: The Role of Islam in Politics
text: TUNIS  The Tunisian revolution that overthrew decades of authoritarian rule has entered a delicate new phase in recent days over the role of Islam in politics. Tensions mounted here last week when military helicopters and security forces were called in to carry out an unusual mission: protecting the city’s brothels from a mob of zealots.

headline: Mark Rylance: Shape Shifter
text: Ben Brantley narrates a look at the career of the actor Mark Rylance, who is coming to Broadway this spring in the play "Jerusalem."

headline: Amid Standoff, Opposition Seeks Dissolution of Bahraini Government
text: MANAMA, Bahrain — Teachers, lawyers and engineers marched into Pearl Square on Sunday, joining an emboldened opposition whose political leaders demanded that the king dissolve the government and fire his uncle, who has held the post of prime minister for 40 years, before they agree to enter into talks.

headline: Weighing Reggie Miller’s Hall of Fame Credentials
text: The final ballot for the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame was announced on Friday, but one notable omission has generated more buzz in N.B.A. circles than any of those actually in contention for the honor. As Jonathan Abrams reported in The Times, the Indiana Pacers guard and Knicks nemesis Reggie Miller will not be among the finalists for the Hall this season.

headline: Knicks Claim a Unified Front-Office Front
text: LOS ANGELES — The Knicks’ dogged pursuit of Carmelo Anthony is exposing philosophical rifts in the organization and stoking concerns about who is running the basketball operation.

headline: Marking Davis’s Confederate Inauguration
text: MONTGOMERY, Ala.  One hundred and fifty years and one day later, the South did it again.

headline: Another Stop on a Long, Improbable Journey
text: PHILADELPHIA — There are times, at the Penn Museum here, when you are almost hesitant to breathe. And it has nothing to do with the recent flurry of events in which Chinese officials suddenly forbid the display of the remarkable objects in the exhibition “Secrets of the Silk Road,” ultimately relenting and allowing them to be shown for just a short time. These doings (about which more later) are scarcely blinks in the history of these objects.

headline: Myanmar Hardens Stance on Opposition
text: BANGKOK  The military rulers of Myanmar appear to be taking a harder line toward the pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and her party three months after her release from house arrest, focusing on the opposition’s support for continued punitive sanctions against the government.

headline: Excerpt: 'Armida'
text: Renee Fleming in a scene from Mary Zimmerman's production of "Armida" at the Metropolitan Opera. (Video courtesy of the Met)

headline: Rumsfeld Implies That Obama Apologizes for U.S.
text: Former Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld reiterated a common conservative criticism of President Obama on Sunday, implying that the president is embarrassed by the United States.

headline: First-Place Flyers Extend Rangers’ Slump
text: The Rangers are falling fast, and their once-bright season is becoming increasingly troubled as the homestretch approaches.

headline: 40-Year Reunion
text: A former New York Times employee receives his lost wallet, found some 40 years later. Inside, he finds photos and documents from his past.

headline: A Little Off the Top
text: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof has time to get a haircut during a day of relative peace in Manama, Bahrain, and reflect on what a democracy there could look like.

headline: What’s the Better Fit? The 4-4 vs. the 5-3
text: The last paragraph of Saturday’s column generated a few queries. When is a 4-4 fit better than a 5-3, and vice versa?

headline: A Frayed Family’s Tenuous Bonds
text: Given how often playwriting substitutes for therapy or supplements it, few subjects are explored as frequently in contemporary American drama as the corrosive bonds of family.

headline: The Siren Song of the Bath Toy
text: On Jan. 10, 1992, a container ship traveling south of the Aleutians, in the region once quaintly known as the Graveyard of the Pacific, en route from Hong Kong to Tacoma, Wash., took a steep roll and lost part of its cargo. The incident had near-mythical repercussions. Among the lost merchandise were 7,200 packs of bathtub toys. Each four-piece set included a blue turtle, a green frog, a red beaver and a yellow duck. This came to be erroneously understood as the story of 29,000 rubber duckies set adrift and washing up all over the globe.

headline: Species Seekers and Spies
text: There’s a scene early in the 2002 film “Die Another Day,” where James Bond poses as an ornithologist in Havana, with binoculars in hand and a book, “Birds of the West Indies,” tucked under one arm.  “Oh, I’m just here for the birds,” he ventures, when the fetching heroine, Jinx Johnson, played by Halle Berry, makes her notably unfeathered entrance.

headline: Santa’s Number and Groucho’s Face
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: SoHo Theater Is Reborn in the West Village
text: The recently deceased Ohio Theater in SoHo will not have to wait long for a resurrection. SoHo Think Tank, the company that ran the Ohio, an Off Off Broadway theater at 66 Wooster Street, for almost 20 years, will have a new home at the Archive Building at 154 Christopher Street in the West Village beginning this fall. The original Wooster Street building was sold in 2008, and the company was forced to leave two years later after failing to renegotiate the rent with the new landlord. Since then the Think Tank has been operating under the banner “Ohio Interrupted” at the 3 Legged-Dog theater in Lower Manhattan. It will produce its annual Ice Factory festival there this summer before moving in September to the new 73-seat theater, where it will reopen under a subsidized 10-year lease and a new name, Ohio West. “To be back in our own space within a year of leaving Wooster Street, and to be in the West Village, no less, is just unbelievable,” said the company’s artistic director, Robert Lyons, above. The new building is owned by Rockrose Development, which designated the theater for nonprofit use at below market rates as part of an agreement made with the city during the commercial development of the building in 1988.

headline: The Thriller ‘Unknown’ Tops the Box Office
text: Liam Neeson’s stolen-identity thriller “Unknown” was a surprise No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, gunning past “I Am Number Four,” a science-fiction entry that represented the reconfigured debut of Steven Spielberg’s DreamWorks Studios. Made for about $30 million, “Unknown” (Dark Castle/Warner Brothers) sold an estimated $21.8 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. “I Am Number Four,” which received negative reviews, cost at least $50 million to make and was predicted by some analysts to lead the weekend box office derby, sold about $19.5 million for second place. It was the first film that DreamWorks has released since refinancing itself and breaking ties with Paramount Pictures in favor of a distribution relationship with Walt Disney Studios. “Gnomeo & Juliet” (Disney) was a strong third with $19.4 million, bringing the two-week total for the 3-D animated comedy to about $50.4 million. The Adam Sandler-Jennifer Aniston comedy “Just Go With It” (Sony Pictures Entertainment) placed fourth in its second weekend, selling an estimated $18.2 million for a new total of $60.8 million. “Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son,” a comedy from 20th Century Fox and New Regency starring Martin Lawrence in fat-suit drag, rounded out the top five with about $17 million.

headline: Aretha Franklin to Return
text: It seems that the Grammy Awards’ “get well” tribute to the singer Aretha Franklin, above, last week may have worked. Ms. Franklin, 68, who was forced to cancel numerous concerts late last year because of an undisclosed illness, has announced plans to perform at the Seneca Niagara Casino & Hotel in Buffalo on May 28, BBC News reported. It will be her first performance since she had surgery to treat a medical condition in December. In January Ms. Franklin said that the condition had been resolved, and last week she appeared at the Grammys via video to thank her well wishers.

headline: 3-D ‘Great Gatsby’ to Film in Australia
text: Sydney’s first live-action 3-D film won’t feature fantastical woodland creatures, superheroes or even aliens. Instead, the lost and lonely souls of “The Great Gatsby” will do the honors. Baz Luhrmann’s adaptation of F. Scott Fitzgerald’s novel will begin filming at Fox Studios there in August, according to The Hollywood Reporter. The film is set in New York and will star Leonardo DiCaprio as Jay Gatsby; Carey Mulligan (“An Education”) is expected to play the role of Daisy Buchanan, the article said. Kristina Keneally, the New South Wales premier, said the movie was “a big win” for the state and Australia, which was “thought to be losing international filmmaking due to the strong Aussie dollar.” The production is expected to boost the economy by around $200 million, though the incentives used to lure the producers, Warner Brothers and Bazmark Films, remained confidential.

headline: Rocker From the Heartland, Aging Brashly
text: At Radio City Music Hall on Friday night John Mellencamp joshed about what it would be like to meet his younger self: a brash kid who’d condescendingly say, “Hey, Classic Hits, what’s happening?” He went on proudly to assert his age, 59, as a lead-in to what he announced as a “song for my generation.” It was “Don’t Need This Body,” a blunt, death-haunted stomp that began, “This getting older, it ain’t for cowards.”

headline: O, Unsmiling Villainess!
text: LONDON  John Berry, the innovative artistic director of the English National Opera, is not alone among his colleagues in thinking that directors from fields other than opera should be brought in to shake up and enliven the art form. A tempting idea, but it does not always work out, as a performance of Donizetti’s “Lucrezia Borgia” on Friday night here at the English National Opera demonstrated.

headline: She’s Young, Restless and a Bit Dreamy
text: “It’s the unrest inside me, and I think I’ll go mad,” sang the beautiful young woman in the red dress at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel on Wednesday evening. Those words, imparted in a near whisper tinged with an otherworldly vibrato, come from “I Wish It So,” a gorgeous, little-known Irish-flavored ballad by Marc Blitzstein from his 1959 show, “Juno.” And what is the narrator’s wish? A vague “I still don’t know.”

headline: In Budget Wars, Tough Talk Hasn’t Often Led to Political Victory
text: Is it really different this time?

headline: Renée Fleming Returns to Rossini’s Tale of a Sorceress and Her Crusader
text: In Rossini’s operas coloratura is character. When critics mention singer X’s trills, Y’s roulades and Z’s runs, they are not just being nitpicky. Qualities like joy and anger are expressed here entirely through those purely vocal means. The emotions are in the notes.

headline: Feet on the Furniture, and Other Playful Moves
text: It’s interesting how much effect context has on perceptions of a show. For the last few years Bill Young and Colleen Thomas have offered the LIT series, informal presentations of their own and other people’s work in their SoHo loft. On Friday night Mr. Young and Ms. Thomas opened the 92nd Street Y Harkness Dance Festival by creating a rough approximation of that setting in the Y’s Buttenwieser Hall. The audience was placed in an L around the stage space, with some people at small cafe tables and others on couches or chairs. A D.J. was spinning music as people arrived, and a cash bar was doing steady business.

headline: Monday: Like a Wave
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — In today’s puzzle, you can’t possibly get lost. And on a Monday, that’s not necessarily a bad thing.

headline: Drama Revived by the Kindness of Strangeness
text: The Wooster Group was just getting started in 1977 when Tennessee Williams’s once-glorious career was fading. That was the year his “Vieux Carré” opened, and quickly closed, on Broadway, the year in which he wrote: “No one is more acutely aware than I that I am widely regarded as the ghost of a writer.”

headline: In Poland, at Mercy of Weirdos
text: “A Couple of Poor, Polish-Speaking Romanians” may wear its shambolic nature on its sleeve, and it could stand to shed at least a third of its nearly two-hour running time. But in this blistering picaresque by an acclaimed young Polish novelist, Dorota Maslowska, having its New York premiere at the Abrons Arts Center under the auspices of the Polish Cultural Institute in New York and East River Commedia, she tempers her grotty verve with a tenderness that helps steer its lead performers through any number of stylistic hairpin turns.

headline: 30 Seconds With Bill Buckner
text: Bill Buckner had 2,715 hits during his major league career, but he is best remembered for a defensive miscue almost 25 years ago. As the Boston Red Sox first baseman, he allowed a slow ground ball by Mookie Wilson to squirt between his legs to give the Mets a victory in Game 6 of the 1986 World Series.

headline: The Foot Comes Down
text: New York City to Philadelphia, Feb. 21, 1861

headline: ‘Secrets of the Silk Road’
text: Images from the exhibition at the Penn Museum in Philadelphia.

headline: Merkel’s Party Is Defeated in Election in Hamburg
text: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel’s Christian Democratic Union party suffered a major defeat on Sunday in an election in Hamburg, with preliminary results showing that the opposition Social Democrats had made big gains and would form the next government there.

headline: Music in Review
text: JEREMY DENK

headline: Portrait of Spy Agency Leaves Much in Shadow
text: LONDON  The mysterious oil painting entitled “Waiting in the Hotel Room” sold for a relatively modest $28,200 last week on the opening night of an exhibition in the upscale Mayfair district of London, where softly lighted galleries staffed by velvet-voiced staff members sell artworks that can fetch millions.

headline: Chuck Allen, Who Championed Surfing and Snowboarding, Dies at 74
text: Chuck Allen, who helped found two nonprofit organizations that worked to bring respect and legitimacy to surfing and snowboarding, died on Feb. 14 in Redlands, Calif. He was 74 and lived in Yucaipa.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Scheduled for this week are the Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller home price indexes for December, and the fourth quarter and consumer confidence for February (Tuesday); existing home sales for January (Wednesday); durable goods orders and new-home sales for January and initial jobless claims (Thursday); and gross domestic product for the fourth quarter and the Thomson Reuters-University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for February (Friday).

headline: Mets Have Reassuring Words for Luis Castillo
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  During their initial meeting in the manager’s office Saturday, Luis Castillo and his new manager, Terry Collins, discussed Castillo’s painful 2010 season, including the best ways to get past it and be productive, providing he is still on the Mets when the season starts.

headline: Ollie Matson, an All-Purpose Football Star, Is Dead at 80
text: Ollie Matson, who was a star in the National Football League for 14 years but whose college football career was hindered by racism, died Saturday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 80.

headline: Jeter Adjusts His Swing, but Not His Mind-Set
text: TAMPA, Fla.

headline: Fears of Chaos Temper Calls for Change in Morocco
text: CASABLANCA, Morocco — For Morocco, a kingdom on the western edge of North Africa, the calls for change sweeping the region are muted by a fear of chaos, a prevalent security apparatus and genuine respect for the king, Mohammed VI. Since he took the throne in 1999, the king, who is only 47, has done much to soften the harsh and often brutal rule of his father, Hassan II.

headline: Treading Water Isn’t Enough for the Knicks
text: “I’ve been down so long

headline: N.F.L. Players Shaken by Duerson’s Suicide Message
text: When the former football player Andre Waters shot himself in the head in late 2006, the few recoverable pieces of brain tissue, which later showed the same degenerative disease previously associated only with boxers, made the health risks of football a national conversation.

headline: Rising Property Taxes Overwhelm Many Who Are Living on the Edge
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s campaign to cap property taxes has angered school and municipal officials who say that limiting local tax revenue will make it impossible for them to cover rising expenses and will result in drastic cuts in services.

headline: NATO Airstrike Is Said to Kill Afghan Civilians
text: JALALABAD, Afghanistan  NATO airstrikes killed at least 35 people in a remote mountainous area of eastern Afghanistan last week in an attack that NATO officers say was a successful mission against Taliban insurgents, but that Afghan officials have condemned as causing mass civilian casualties.

headline: Greece’s Efforts to Limit Tax Evasion Have Little Success
text: ATHENS  The agents from the Financial and Economic Crime Unit slipped in on a holiday evening recently, taking some of the tall seats at the crowded bar in the Three Little Pigs Cafe here.

headline: In Surprise Ending, Trevor Bayne Captures Daytona 500
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  With a record number of lead changes, leaders and cautions from wrecks that took out some of the biggest names in Nascar, it was only appropriate that a most unpredictable Daytona 500 ended with a most unexpected driver celebrating in victory lane.

headline: Protesters in Wisconsin Say They Are Staying Put
text: MADISON, Wis.  Union leaders urged Wisconsin teachers to return to work at schools that are open on Monday, but large protests were expected to continue at the Capitol against a plan to cut collective bargaining rights and benefits to state workers.

headline: Book Lovers Fear Dim Future for Notes in the Margins
text: CHICAGO — Locked in a climate-controlled vault at the Newberry Library here, a volume titled “The Pen and the Book” can be studied only under the watch of security cameras.

headline: A Tale of Two Presidents
Ally of New Haven Police for 17 Years, Now a Target
text: NEW HAVEN

headline: Cuomo Seeks to Curb Aid to Schools Sharing Tasks
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has called on New York’s hodgepodge of small and large school districts to operate more efficiently by consolidating and sharing services.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Material Witness Case
text: GRAND TERRACE, Calif.  When the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Robert S. Mueller III, gave Congress a progress report in early 2003on the agency’s success in “identifying and dismantling terrorist networks,” his first example was the capture of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks. His second was the arrest of Abdullah al-Kidd.

headline: Dolan’s Hand Is Seen in Pursuit of Anthony
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: U.S. ‘Gravely Concerned’ Over Violence in Libya
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Sunday condemned Libya’s use of lethal force against peaceful demonstrators, pointing to what it said were “multiple credible” reports that “hundreds of people” had been killed and injured in several days of unrest.

headline: Bryant Briefly Draws All-Star Focus Off Anthony
text: LOS ANGELES  Carmelo Anthony wandered from meeting to meeting and owner to owner this weekend looking for resolution to his season-long drama. On a neutral court, in a generic jersey for a ceremonial game, he was not a Nugget, Knick or Net, but simply an All-Star with a ticking deadline that will determine his future employer.

headline: Dream Act Advocate Turns Failure Into Hope
text: HARRISONBURG, Va.  Isabel Castillo was counting on the Dream Act, and when the Dream Act was defeated in December, it upended her dreams.

headline: A Catcher’s Search for a Team Leads to the Yankees
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Every winter, Gustavo Molina and his wife, Carla, seem to have the same conversation. She asks him which team he will play for. He tells her he doesn’t know. She asks why he switches teams every season. He tells her that it’s his job.

headline: Wisconsin Puts Obama Between Competing Desires
text: WASHINGTON — The battle in Wisconsin over public employee unions has left President Obama facing a tricky balance between showing solidarity with longtime political supporters and projecting a message in favor of deep spending cuts to reduce the debt.

headline: Nationals’ Racing Presidents Tryouts No Laughing Matter
text: WASHINGTON  The urgent phone call came just about halfway through the mascot tryouts for the Washington Nationals. A concerned member of the Nationals’ entertainment staff gave his colleagues the horrible news.

headline: Night Helicopter Rescue Lifts 2 West Point Cadets Off Ledge
text: HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y.  In a daring nighttime run, amid conditions that left no room for error, a New York City police helicopter hoisted two shivering West Point cadets early Sunday morning off an 18-inch-wide ledge on Storm King Mountain, where they had been stranded for more than eight hours.

headline: Revived George Mason Has Major Ambitions
text: FAIRFAX, Va.  Five years removed from its improbable Final Four appearance, George Mason embraces the past while choosing not to be defined by it. Enlarged magazine covers chronicling the Patriots’ 2006 run still hang in Coach Jim Larranaga’s office, and at home games this season, fans received bobblehead dolls depicting that team’s starting five.

headline: Blogs Wane as the Young Drift to Sites Like Twitter
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Like any aspiring filmmaker, Michael McDonald, a high school senior, used a blog to show off his videos. But discouraged by how few people bothered to visit, he instead started posting his clips on Facebook, where his friends were sure to see and comment on his editing skills.

headline: At Newsweek, a Humble and Frugal Tina Brown
text: There will be no celebrity-studded gala with fireworks over New York Harbor this time. No brash predictions of upending the magazine business.

headline: Baddeley Holds Off Singh at Riviera, Where Generation Gap Is 2 Shots
text: LOS ANGELES  After four years of searching, and 95 tournaments without a victory, Aaron Baddeley finally put it all together again on Sunday. On a chilly, bright day at Riviera Country Club, Baddeley won the Northern Trust Open with a rebuilt swing and some newfound resolve.

headline: After iPad’s Head Start, Rival Tablets Are Poised to Flood Offices
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The billboards promoting the iPad have a simple message: The tablet is a device for leisure, to be held on one’s lap while lounging on a couch in casual clothes, to watch a film or read a magazine.

headline: Unrest Around the Region
text: LIBYA The son of the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, warned that continued antigovernment protests could lead to a civil war. The uprising spread to the capital, Tripoli, while protesters in the eastern city of Benghazi took over the city.

headline: Brooklyn Woman Dies as Blaze Displaces 100
text: A retired guidance counselor was killed and more than 100 residents were forced to flee into the chill of a winter night when a wind-whipped fire raced through a seven-story apartment building in Flatbush, Brooklyn, on Saturday evening.

headline: 100 Years Later, the Roll of the Dead in a Factory Fire Is Complete
text: In the Cemetery of the Evergreens on the border of Brooklyn and Queens, there is a haunting stone monument to the garment workers who died in the Triangle shirtwaist factory fire of 1911 but were never identified. It contains the bas-relief figure of a kneeling woman, her head bowed, seemingly mourning not only the deaths, but also the fact that those buried below were so badly charred that relatives could not recognize them.

headline: European Airports Balk at Easing Ban on Liquids
text: PARIS  With barely two months remaining before the European Union is scheduled to partially lift a nearly five-year ban on liquids in air passenger hand luggage, airports across the region are balking at the approaching deadline, arguing that current liquid-explosive detection technology is still too unreliable.

headline: In Records, Portraits of Lives Cut Short
text: Within half a year of identifying Maria Giuseppa Lauletti, one of the six unidentified victims of the Triangle shirtwaist factory fire of 1911, Michael Hirsch, an amateur genealogist, had put names to the five other “unknowns,” with the identity of the last one, Fannie Rosen, emerging last summer. In every case, he found decaying records from charitable or government agencies whose details allowed him to paint portraits of six truncated lives.

headline: Woman Dies During Night on Sidewalk Near Church
text: A woman found dead on an East Village sidewalk Sunday morning was known to several people in Tompkins Square Park only by a first name, Grace. She was a regular in and around the park, they added, and often slept outside.

headline: Louganis Is Back on Board
text: FULLERTON, Calif.  The Olympic-size outdoor pool at Fullerton College on a recent afternoon was an aquatics diorama, with a beginners swim class sharing space with a group of seasoned competitors churning out laps. At the far end, in the deep water, three divers practiced their springboard takeoffs.

headline: In Prime-Time TV, Networks Losing the War for 10 P.M.
text: For the past several years, many broadcast network executives have looked at the ratings for their 10 p.m. shows and lamented that it has become impossible to build a true, breakout hit at that hour anymore.

headline: 2 Platforms, With 2 Sets of Problems
text: Digital subscriptions, a grail for the mainstream media that often seemed more like a mirage, took on some firm if not altogether friendly dimensions last week.

headline: TV Industry Taps Social Media to Keep Viewers’ Attention

headline: The Short Shelf Life of a Serie A Coach
text: Unable to right his foundering ship, Claudio Ranieri resigned as Roma’s coach on Sunday after the team blew a three-goal lead in a 4-3 loss to Genoa in Serie A. His decision capped a lightning-fast journey from optimism to resignation. Let’s recap, in his own words.

headline: Rebranding Mount Vernon
text: MOUNT VERNON, George Washington’s bucolic estate in Northern Virginia, has been an American shrine since his death in 1799. But after the Civil War, when its historic restoration began, the image of the first president began to be outshone by that of the 16th, Abraham Lincoln.

headline: U.S. Sets 21st-Century Goal: Building a Better Patent Office
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama, who emphasizes American innovation, says modernizing the federal Patent and Trademark Office is crucial to “winning the future.” So at a time when a quarter of patent applications come from California, and many of those from Silicon Valley, the patent office is opening its first satellite office  in Detroit.

headline: Pakistan’s Nuclear Folly
text: With the Middle East roiling, the alarming news about Pakistan’s nuclear weapons buildup has gotten far too little attention. The Times recently reported that American intelligence agencies believe Pakistan has between 95 and more than 110 deployed nuclear weapons, up from the mid-to-high 70s just two years ago.

headline: Recommended Reading for Republicans
text: The administration last week released a sweeping report recommending many useful steps for conserving, even expanding, America’s open spaces and making them more accessible to the American people. It is the sort of document destined to gather dust on bureaucratic shelves unless someone pays attention and follows up.

headline: A Good Investment in Tough Times
text: About 2.5 million residents of New York State, trapped at the margins of the economy, lack the basic skills that come with a high school education. To help these people  and strengthen the economy  the state must work with the cities to expand access to the relatively inexpensive programs that prepare people for the General Educational Development Test, which provides the equivalent of a high school diploma and gives low-skilled workers a leg up in the job market.

headline: Keeping Up With the Christies
text: There is no sound economic justification for the decision by Gov. Rick Scott of Florida to reject $2.4 billion in federal financing for the vital Tampa-to-Orlando high-speed rail project. Political pandering to his Tea Party supporters is the only explanation we can come up with.

headline: With Takeover Bids, ‘No’ Is Often the Most Profitable Reply
New Jersey TV Station Is Accused of Failing Its Audience
text: WWOR-TV is the subject of an unusual investigation by the Federal Communications Commission, which is looking into charges that the station’s owner, the News Corporation, misrepresented the station’s number of employees and amount of programming. The investigation is gaining attention in part because WWOR is a rarity: it is effectively the only big commercial station licensed to the state of New Jersey.

headline: A Steady Decline in the Number of Restaurants
text: The total number of restaurants in the United States dropped nearly one percent from fall 2009 to fall 2010, according to the NPD Group, a market research firm. That is the latest decline in a decade in which the number of American restaurants has fallen steadily by roughly half a percentage point each year.

headline: Egyptians Were Unplugged, and Uncowed
text: FOR a segment of the young people of Egypt, the date to remember is not when Egyptians first took to the streets to shake off the 30-year rule of Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Edmund de Unger, Islamic Art Collector, Is Dead at 92
text: Edmund de Unger, whose childhood fascination with Oriental rugs and “The Arabian Nights” led him to amass one of the world’s largest and most important collections of Islamic art, died on Jan. 25 at his home in Ham, Surrey, England. He was 92.

headline: Roy Gussow, Abstract Sculptor, Dies at 92
text: Roy Gussow, an abstract sculptor whose polished stainless-steel works with swooping contours gleam in public squares and corporate spaces, died on Feb. 11 in Queens. He was 92 and had lived and worked in Long Island City, Queens, for nearly half a century.

headline: As Republicans See a Mandate on Budget Cuts, Others See Risk

Their agenda echoes in its ambition what President Obama and Democrats tried after winning office in their own electoral wave in 2008.

headline: 31 Killed in Suicide Attack on Afghan Census Office
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber wearing a vest with explosives blew himself up Monday, killing 31 people, as residents lined up for identification cards at a census office in northern Afghanistan, Afghan security officials said.

headline: Qaddafi’s Grip Falters as His Forces Take On Protesters
text: CAIRO  The faltering government of the Libyan strongman, Col. headline: Head of Reform Panel Says Tunisia Risks Anarchy as It Moves Toward Democracy
text: TUNIS  The head of a Tunisian government commission on political reform warned Monday that the country risked falling into “anarchy” as it passed through what he described as a very dangerous postrevolutionary transition toward multiparty democracy.

headline: Suicide Bomber Strikes Iraq Police Station
text: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber on Monday detonated a truck packed with explosives outside a police headquarters just north of Samarra, killing 12 officers and wounding 20 others, a local official and a law enforcement official said.

headline: At London’s National Gallery, a Room of Semi-Hidden Treasures
text: Room A in the National Gallery of Art is one of the best and most unusual places to appreciate art in London. And judging by the light traffic during a recent visit, the room is also one of the city’s better-kept secrets.

headline: ‘Test Drive Unlimited 2’: A Return to Arcade Escapism

headline: BP to Pay $7.2 Billion for Stake in Oil Fields in India
text: MUMBAI, India  The British oil giant BP said on Monday that it would pay $7.2 billion to buy into India’s fast-growing oil and gas industry. It is BP’s second big deal in two months, as it seeks to rebuild after last year’s Gulf of Mexico oil spill.

text: Sebastian Pruiti is founder and editor of NBAPlaybook.com, a blog dedicated to the X’s and O’s of professional basketball.

text: Diageo agreed on Monday to buy Mey Icki, a Turkish liquor company, for $2.1 billion, in a deal that will expand the British spirits maker’s global reach.

headline: Editors Pick ‘Social Network,’ Adding Some Oscar Intrigue
text: With less than a week to go, the pace of tea-leaf-reading – and stirring – is approaching Daytona levels. On Saturday the American Cinema Editors guild, considered a good harbinger of the best picture Oscar, announced its winners (known as the Eddies), and it was enough to cause – if we’re going to keep going with this metaphor – a tempest in a teapot. The big prize went to Angus Wall and Kirk Baxter for “The Social Network” over “The King’s Speech” (and over “Black Swan,” “The Fighter” and “Inception”). In the comedy/musical category, “Alice in Wonderland” bested “The Kids Are All Right” and several other non-Oscar contenders, and “Exit Through the Gift Shop” won for documentary – an illustration of how well-liked it is as a film. Meanwhile pundits pounced on a victory for anything other than the projected favorite, “The King’s Speech.”

headline: BP to Buy Stake in Reliance’s Oil and Gas Fields for $7.2 Billion
text: BP said on Monday that it would pay $7.2 billion to buy into India’s fast-growing oil and natural gas business, the company’s second big deal in two months, according to The New York Times.

headline: Lone Star State of Mind
text: Traveling in Texas and Oklahoma for some university talks; posting will be limited for the next few days.

headline: Artifacts | Laurie Simmons’s Love Doll
text: Loneliness is like a disease that infects every waking moment of a person’s life with melancholy. Some cope by heading for the nearest bar or by creating imaginary friends. Others have pets. The more adventurous, perhaps, opt for a love doll — a life-size latex sex partner who never cheats, has just the right look and is always ready to play.

headline: Hoot-Smalley
text: David Warsh has a good essay, inspired by recent work of Doug Irwin’s, about how the notion that the Smoot-Hawley tariff caused the Great Depression — a notion unsupported by either theory or evidence — nonetheless became conventional wisdom.

headline: Revisiting the Value of Elite Colleges
text: A decade ago, two economists — Stacy Dale and Alan Krueger — published a research paper arguing that elite colleges did not seem to give most graduates an earnings boost. As you might expect, the paper received a ton of attention. Ms. Dale and Mr. Krueger have just finished a new version of the study — with vastly more and better data, covering people into their 40s and 50s, as well as looking at a set of more recent college graduates — and the new version comes to the same conclusion.

headline: British Chip Maker CSR Acquires U.S. Firm for $679 Million
text: CSR, a British chip maker, agreed on Monday to buy the Zoran Corporation, a maker of technology for digital photography and video, for about $679 million in stock.

headline: Best Political Quotes of the Holiday Weekend
text: Did you miss some of the political chatter over the holiday weekend? Don’t worry. The Caucus has gathered the best weekend quotes for you.

headline: Got a Great Idea? Tell Everyone!
text: You’ve heard of high-tech start-ups being in “stealth mode,” meaning they’re not telling anyone what they’re up to yet. It has a glamorous aura to it, conjuring up images of a brilliant project in the works that will soon be sprung upon the world, disrupting established players and leaving everyone scrambling to catch up. All smart companies with really great innovations keep those ideas hidden away until they’re ready to release them, lest competitors steal them. Look at Apple, which has perfected the art of secretiveness, to enormous profit. You can tell people about your great idea — but only if they sign one of those nondisclosure agreements you keep in your briefcase at all times. No exceptions!

headline: Monday Reading: On Becoming a Memory Master
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Sudan’s President, in Power Since 1989, Won’t Run Again, Spokesman Says
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan, who has been in power for more than 20 years and faces international charges of genocide, will not run for office again after his current term ends in four years, a Sudanese government spokesman said Monday.

headline: For Braves Catcher, Quiet Excellence in the Family Business
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  Proximity is important for Howie McCann. He lives in Duluth, Ga., six miles from his son Brian’s home. He lives 28 miles from Turner Field, where Brian is the catcher for the Atlanta Braves. Most nights, he arrives in time to wave hello while Brian warms up the pitcher in the bullpen.

headline: If There Were an Oscar for Title Sequences
text: Are there enough categories in the Academy Awards race? Not according to Alice Rawsthorn, design columnist for The International Herald Tribune. She proposes an Oscar for the opening and closing credits and offers her own nominees for the most creative, or effective, of this movie season. Typography is important but not always paramount. Her standard is one set by Saul Bass, who worked on Hitchcock, Kubrick and Scorsese films among many others: Do the credits set the mood for the movie to come? As he said in a 1966 interview with Film Quarterly, “I saw the title as a way of conditioning the audience, so that when the film actually began, viewers would have an emotional resonance with it.”

headline: Egypt’s Leaders Signal Commitment to Civilian Rule
text: CAIRO  The military and civilian leadership controlling Egypt in the wake of a popular revolution took several high-profile steps on Monday to reassure Egyptians that it shared their fervor for change and to signal to foreign leaders that the move to full civilian rule would be rapid.

headline: To Sell an Apartment, No Detail Is Too Small
text: On a recent Thursday morning, Jamella Swift, a Citi Habitats broker, was trying to anticipate every detail that would prevent a buyer from purchasing the two-bedroom condo she was selling in Bedford-Stuyvesant. She put a full-size bed in the bedroom so buyers wouldn’t think the room was too small. She dragged in a Lucite coffee table to create the illusion of a larger living space and set up three floor lamps to supplement the recessed lighting. Ms. Swift hoped that the $5,000 she had spent would help her land $395,000 to $425,000 for the apartment.

headline: ‘Molly Sweeney’ To Get a New Star and a Reprieve

headline: Wisconsin G.O.P. Plans to Work Without Democrats

headline: A Budget Map Reveals a Troubled Future

headline: ‘Dirty’ Energy Dwarfs Clean in China and India
text: Many experts agree that for the world to rein in rising greenhouse gas emissions, the galloping economies of China and India would have to figure out how to base their future economic expansion on technologies and fuels that are “cleaner” than the fossil fuels the United States and Europe used in their own industrial revolutions long ago.

headline: Put Away the White Rice
text: Many years ago, after I decided to stop eating meat (I am not a strict vegetarian now, though that’s the way I usually eat), I walked down the street to look over whole grains at my local health food store in Austin, Tex. There wasn’t much of a selection; still, it was all new to me, and I bought some of the grains sold in bulk bins: brown rice, millet, kasha and wheat berries.

headline: Of Heart and Guts
text: Q. Is it better for digestion to sleep on the left side and better for the heart to sleep on the right?

headline: Silver Lining
text: When it comes to makeup, the runway often resembles a glamorous laboratory, where mad scientists (a k a makeup artists) cook up otherworldly or exaggerated looks that work well in photos but rarely make it to real life. The molten silver eye at Prada’s spring show seemed exactly that — a hothouse exotic that wouldn’t survive outside a fashion show. Not so, according to Pat McGrath, who created the look and also employed silver at Valentino and Galliano. “Metallics are unique, modern and chic,” she says. “But most of all, they are completely wearable on every skin tone.” For an evening out, she suggests using Laura Mercier’s intense Foiled Eye Color in V.I.P. Silver on the lid, keeping the color centered, rather than extending up to the brow, and following with black liquid liner and mascara. For day, try Covergirl Smoky ShadowBlast in Silver Sky from the lash line to the browbone, and finish with two coats of mascara. Romy Soleimani, who created the liquid mercury look for this story, recommends a sheer wash of Make Up For Ever Aqua Cream No. 3 all over the lid and in the crease, followed by mascara. “Fill in your brow, do a beautiful pale pink lip, and you have a delicate version of the look,” she says.

headline: Braves Look Behind the Plate and See a Leader
text: When the Atlanta Braves took their prospects to Turner Field for an orientation camp in January, Brian McCann was one of the veterans to speak. McCann lives nearby – he is a Georgia boy, born and raised – and the way he connected with the kids struck Eddie Perez.

headline: Home Internet May Get Even Faster in South Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea already claims the world’s fastest Internet connections — the fastest globally by far — but that is hardly good enough for the government here.

headline: Bahrain Withdraws From Opening Race of Formula One Season
text: On Monday, the Informational Affairs Authority for the Kingdom of Bahrain posted the following message on Twitter: .bbpBox{background:url(http://a2.twimg.com/profile_background_images/207330950/IAA_logo.jpg) #C0DEED;padding:20px;}

headline: Bahrain Cancels Grand Prix Amid Political Unrest
text: The organizers of the Bahrain Grand Prix announced Monday that the Formula One race next month had been canceled because of the political unrest in the country.

headline: A Preacher Raises His Voice in Egypt
text: The Times's Stephen Farrell visits Mahdi Mohammed, a Muslim preacher he met during the protests in Tahrir Square.

headline: When Alzheimer’s Waited Outside the Oval Office
text: WASHINGTON  Ron Reagan’s new memoir, “My Father at 100,” has touched off sensational headlines with its suggestion that President Ronald Reagan might have begun showing hints of Alzheimer’s disease while still in the White House.

headline: One More Job Lost in the Recession: The Mayor’s
text: CENTRAL FALLS, R.I.  These are trying times for the people of Central Falls, a city so close to fiscal collapse that the state seized control of City Hall last summer. Taxes have risen nearly 20 percent to help solve the immediate crisis, unions have agreed to givebacks and the city of 19,000  all 1.29 square miles of it  seems tinged with defeat.

headline: ‘Friends’ Without a Personal Touch
text: Teenagers who send and receive six to eight thousand texts a month and spend hours a day on Facebook. Mourners who send text messages during a memorial service because they can’t go an hour without using their BlackBerries. Children who see an authentic Galapagos tortoise at the American Museum of Natural History and can’t understand why the museum didn’t use a robot tortoise instead. High school students who wonder how much they should tilt their Facebook profiles toward what their friends will think is cool, or what college admissions boards might prize.

headline: Scorecard | Mulberry Wins!
text: Scorecard, here, checking in with your weekend recap of all that’s new in London fashion. In a word: heritage. For even before Christopher Bailey brought Burberry back form spring’s biker trench dark side with a catwalk extravaganza live streamed to jumbotrons at Picadilly Circus, with a whistle and click the creative director of an It Brit bag brand made a triumphant homecoming from across the pond, sending out a full lineup of sixties-inspired Mr. Foxy looks. Fantastic, Ms. Hill.

headline: ‘It Gets Better,’ the Public Service Announcement
text: The It Gets Better Project, an online video campaign to cheer up gay teenagers who have been victims of bullies, has joined with the stars of the new Broadway musical “Priscilla Queen of the Desert” to produce the project’s first public service announcement, which will begin airing on Tuesday on the CBS affiliate in the New York region.

headline: Glow From a Victory Did Not Last for Long
text: LINDEN, N.J.  Kelly Kulick’s 2002 Nissan Pathfinder, with 163,000 miles and a worn-out radio that was recently replaced, was making a strange sound. Kulick was nervous that it would not bring her home the day after last week’s Brad Paisley concert in Hershey, Pa.

headline: BMW Officially Announces BMW i Brand
text: On Monday at its corporate headquarters in Munich, BMW announced details of its coming sub-brand, BMW i.

headline: 'Priscilla' PSA for It Gets Better
text: The spot, part of the It Gets Better Project, features stars of the new musical "Priscilla Queen of the Desert."

headline: Egypt Reopens Museums and Historical Sites
text: Egypt has reopened many of its museums and historical sites, which were hit by sporadic looting during the uprising that led to President Hosni Mubarak’s ouster, Reuters reported.

headline: Modigliamania
text: With “Modigliani: A Life” (Knopf, $35), Meryle Secrest rehabilitates the famously dashing Italian, once thought to be a minor painter and something of a brute. The meticulously sourced book coincides with a flurry of art market activity, suggesting that 91 years after his death, Modigliani may be having a moment.

headline: Addiction: A First in Sub-Saharan Africa: Methadone Maintenance Program
text: With the help of the American government, the first methadone maintenance program in sub-Saharan Africa opened this month in a hospital in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania.

headline: Faking Happiness May Lead to Blues
text: In the song “Smile,” the crooner Nat King Cole famously advised that we smile through heartbreak. But now research suggests that faking happiness may just make things worse.

headline: In Yemen, Leader Says He’ll Talk, but Not Quit
text: SANA, Yemen  President Ali Abdullah Saleh, looking shaken at a news conference here on Monday, said he would not give in to the demands of protesters who have sought his ouster during 10 days of sustained demonstrations around Yemen.

headline: Travel With the Boss: The Pluses and the Pitfalls
text: Traveling with the boss offers an array of both professional opportunities and minefields.

headline: BMW to Create Sub-Brand for Battery-Powered Cars
text: FRANKFURT  BMW, the German luxury car builder, said on Monday that it would create a sub-brand known as BMW i to market a line of battery-powered cars starting in 2013, and gave the most complete picture yet of how the vehicles made of carbon fiber and aluminum would look.

headline: Barbour Visits With State Leaders in Iowa
text: On Monday, Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi visited Iowa, which will hold the nation’s first presidential contest in less than a year.

headline: Q.& A. With Eric Cantona
text: At first, even second glance, Eric Cantona, 44, looks as if he could be minutes away from shedding his stylish street clothes and stepping back onto the soccer field without embarrassing himself. An enigmatic Frenchman, Cantona starred for Manchester United in the 1990s, retired at age 30 and left it all behind for a budding film career. He is back in the game for the first time in 14 years. Cantona has been named the director of soccer operations for the reborn New York Cosmos, a team that really is not a team — yet — but that hopes to become the 20th entry in Major League Soccer, perhaps as soon as the 2013 season. Cantona spoke with Jack Bell of The Times (who, as he took notes using an iPad and wireless keyboard, heard Cantona say that he felt “strange, like I’m talking to the police at the station”) about his days at Old Trafford, his exploits on the silver screen and his expectations with the Cosmos.

headline: Libya’s U.N. Diplomats Break With Qaddafi
text: Members of Libya’s mission to the United Nations renounced Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi on Monday, calling him a genocidal war criminal responsible for mass shootings of demonstrators protesting against his four decades in power. They called upon him to resign.

headline: Found Baggage Earns an Airline Clerk a Much Nicer Bag
text: BACK in 2001, when I was 21, I started my own apparel line.

headline: A Dazzling Show Inside a Laser, but a Vacuum of Light Outside
text: In an elegant melding of theoretical and experimental physics, scientists at Yale University have taken the basic function of a laser and flipped it around  producing a device that absorbs, rather than emits, a beam of light.

text: To the Editor:

headline: All Heart (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Europe Focuses on Flow of Migrants
text: BRUSSELS  Two days of meetings of European Union ministers meant to address broad themes of change in the Middle East were dominated by short-term issues, particularly the possibility of increased migration from North Africa if regional unrest grows.

headline: Energy Savings for All (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:
