headline: Spain Identifies Risk of Problem Loans in Savings Banks
text: MADRID  Spain’s central bank on Monday classified 46 percent of the exposure that the country’s savings banks had to the construction and real estate sectors as “problematic.”

headline: Maersk Line Orders 10 Container Ships With Option to Buy More
text: Betting on a continued rebound in global trade, Maersk Line said on Monday that it had agreed to buy up to 30 of the largest container ships ever built from Daewoo Shipbuilding and Marine Engineering of South Korea, in a deal that could be worth $5.7 billion.

headline: Q.&A.: Low-Budget Passport Photos
text: Q.

headline: Arrests in Zimbabwe for Seeing Videos
text: JOHANNESBURG  Dozens of students, trade unionists and political activists who gathered to watch Al Jazeera and BBC news reports on the uprisings that brought down autocrats in Tunisia and Egypt have been arrested on suspicion of plotting to oust President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe.

headline: When the Doctor’s Wife Has Cancer
text: As a medical student 20 years ago, I learned all about anatomy, physiology and pharmacology. My professors also taught me, implicitly, how to put on the white doctor coat as a shield against human vulnerability. With the coat on, you could get right up close to frailty, even touch it, and it wouldn’t be able to reach out and pull you in.

headline: For Liszt’s 200th, a Youthful Tribute
text: Many 19th-century composers endured poverty, illness and artistic struggle, their achievements fully recognized only posthumously. Franz Liszt followed the opposite trajectory: he lived a glamorous life, rich in material and artistic success, but his reputation suffered in posterity.

headline: American Songbook’s Afro-Cuban Connection
text: Raúl Esparza’s driving force is a daredevil spirit of defiance. Bring on the challenge, and he will leap into the breach.

headline: For Pepsi, a Business Decision With Social Benefit
text: SAN GABRIEL, Mexico  In the past, farmers would make the dangerous trek north from this tiny town hidden in the rugged folds of the Jalisco mountain range to the United States, hoping to earn enough money doing odd jobs to cover debts incurred while cultivating the small plots of land that have been in their families for generations.

headline: Blagojevich Trying to Keep Recordings Out of Court
text: CHICAGO — Rod R. Blagojevich, the ousted governor of Illinois, is trying to stop federal prosecutors from playing wiretap recordings during his retrial on corruption charges this spring.

headline: In Budget Bill, a Dispute Over Border Security
text: Preparing for the fight next week in Congress over federal spending legislation, Democratic leaders in the Senate said they will not support a bill with $60 billion in budget cuts that passed the Republican-led House on Saturday because it reduces funding for border security.

headline: Studying Aging, and Fearing Budget Cuts
text: Dr. Richard J. Hodes presides over the nation’s prime source of grants for studies of aging at a worrisome time for researchers. Just when the cohort of elderly Americans is surging, many scientists fear that government budget cuts may hamper a broad array of research efforts on Alzheimer’s and other diseases of aging  not to mention the eye-catching recent progress on reversing age-related decline in genetically altered mice.

headline: The Threatening Scent of Fertile Women
text: The 21-year-old woman was carefully trained not to flirt with anyone who came into the laboratory over the course of several months. She kept eye contact and conversation to a minimum. She never used makeup or perfume, kept her hair in a simple ponytail, and always wore jeans and a plain T-shirt.

headline: The Surreal Life of Aron Ralston
text: With all the attention being paid to James “culturally omnipresent” Franco –- being everywhere all the time kind of makes you a go-to target, especially for people looking for go-to targets –- it’s almost easy to forget that Mr. Franco is getting Oscar attention not just for manic multitasking but for playing a real person: the hiker Aron Ralston, whose true story inspired “127 Hours.”

headline: Opposition to Infrastructure Spending: The Origins
text: I’m currently reading Daniel Walker Howe’s What Hath God Wrought, and there’s an interesting discussion of the debate over “internal improvements.” Some southerners were opposed, for an interesting reason. Here’s Nathaniel Macon of North Carolina, in 1818:

headline: Blockbuster Receives $290 Million Initial Takeover Bid
text: Blockbuster, the bankrupt video rental company, said on Monday that it had agreed to sell itself to a group of creditors for about $290 million as a way to jump-start an auction process that could yield a higher bid.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Donnie Brasco'
text: A. O. Scott discusses themes of loyalty and betrayal in Mike Newell's 1997 film.

headline: Bay Says He’ll Gladly Give Up No. 44, but …
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Under the right circumstances, Jason Bay wants to give up his No. 44 jersey. Bay, who has worn the number since he was traded from the Pirates to the Red Sox at the trading deadline in 2008, said he is hoping to give the number to Jason Isringhausen if Isringhausen makes the team.

headline: Colorado Faces a Fight Over Naturopathy
text: DENVER  For more than a decade, Mark Cooper has had a bustling naturopathy practice in Colorado Springs, treating everything from chronic headaches to digestive problems to insomnia.

headline: Cutting Hair and Cracking Wise, All While the Radio Plays
text: You know this place, even if you don’t know the language. It’s the wacky small business where little business gets done but where an eclectic group of people gather to crack wise and occasionally say something pithy, and it has been a staple of American sitcoms over the years: a general store, a diner, a neighborhood bar, a taxi garage, a barbershop.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Producers Hire Help; More Delays Possible
text: The producers of the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” have brought on a veteran musical supervisor and conductor, Paul Bogaev, as a consultant to help improve the performance, vocal and orchestration arrangements, and sound quality of the songs and numbers, a production spokesman, Rick Miramontez, confirmed on Monday.

headline: Civilizations End, but Does Happiness?
text: Watching “Heaven on Earth” at La MaMa is a bit like sitting on a bus, with strangers’ conversations drifting in and out of your consciousness. Pieces may catch your attention, but you don’t expect narrative coherence. In any case, too many other things compete for your focus: the passing scenery, your iPod, the newspaper in your lap.

headline: Rasmussen Poll on Wisconsin Dispute May Be Biased
text: We’ve noted before that the automated polling firm Rasmussen Reports has had problems with bias in a statistical sense: in the election last fall, its polls overestimated the standing of Republican candidates by roughly 4 percentage points on average.

headline: Spotify Raises Investments at $1 Billion Valuation
text: Spotify, the online music service, has raised new financing from investors including Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers at a valuation of more than $1 billion, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Monday.

headline: Mining Memories to Preserve the Past
text: Her memory is creaky, Dwania Kyles insisted, and most of the photographs that help unlock it are stored in her computer. But recently, sitting in a warren of rooms in Harlem as the light outside faded, she had a rush of recollections about her family and the night that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. did not come to dinner.

headline: Turning It Outside-In at Armory
text: The prospect of a major New York premiere, with all its attendant notice, is something most composers might dream of longingly. But when John Luther Adams was approached with the notion of having his “Inuksuit” performed as the final event of the Tune-In Music Festival at the Park Avenue Armory, he resisted, he said on Sunday afternoon in a conversation before the concert there.

headline: Miami, Another Battlefront in the War Against Wrinkles
text: Inevitably, one day your toddler will ask: “Mommy, is there really any difference between one ‘Housewife’ and the next? I mean, don’t they even all go to the same plastic surgeon?” You will feel the instinct to respond counterintuitively. “Absolutely, Sophie,” you will say. “The ‘Real Housewives’ franchise is an exercise in anthropology. It seeks to explore the different ways wealthy women live in different parts of the country. I mean, honey, you’re probably not going to find an emotionally volatile, discount-upholstery-fabrics heiress like Jill Zarin in Atlanta.”

headline: A Guitarist Adds Depth With Some Extra Strings
text: Just after a group of Dowland lute works that opened his recital at the Frick Collection on Sunday afternoon, the Swedish guitarist Goran Sollscher told the audience that he was particularly fond of slow music. The Dowland set, which had the doleful “Lachrimae Pavan” as its centerpiece, suggested as much, as did the work that followed his remarks, Sylvius Leopold Weiss’s “Tombeau sur la Mort de M. Comte de Logy.” Indeed, relaxed tempos became a unifying theme. Mr. Sollscher opened the second half with a work by Arvo Pärt, whom he described, accurately, as “the master of slowness.” And as his only encore, he played a Bach sarabande.

headline: BHP to Pay Chesapeake $4.75 Billion for Shale Gas Assets
text: BHP Billiton said on Monday afternoon that it would buy Chesapeake Energy‘s shale-based natural gas assets in northern Arkansas for $4.75 billion.

headline: Celebrating 50 Years’ Worth of Promising Talent
text: Success in any artistic field depends largely on talent and hard work, but also on the luck of recognition.

headline: Critics’ Choice: New CDs
text: GIL SCOTT-HERON AND JAMIE XX

headline: Union Bonds in Wisconsin Begin to Fray
text: JANESVILLE, Wis. — Rich Hahn worked at the General Motors plant here until it closed about two years ago. He moved to Detroit to take another G.M. job while his wife and children stayed here, but then the automaker cut more jobs. So Mr. Hahn, 50, found himself back in Janesville, collecting unemployment for a time, and watching as the city’s industrial base seemed to crumble away.

headline: Video of Libyan Diplomats Denouncing Qaddafi
text: As my colleague Colin Moynihan reports, on Monday in New York members of Libya’s mission to the United Nations denounced Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi for his bloody response to protests and called on him to resign.

headline: Adam Driver On Stage
text: A look at some of the actor’s past performances.

headline: No Combat Duty but Plenty of Curtain Calls
text: The moment that persuaded Adam Driver to pursue an acting career didn’t come when he was cast as the Leading Player in a college production of “Pippin,” or even when he was accepted to Juilliard. It happened one thankfully windy afternoon as a cloud of deadly white phosphorus  a high-powered chemical that can burn through cars  inched its way toward him and a group of fellow Marines during a mishap in a California training exercise.

headline: Child-Product Makers Seek to Soften New Rules
text: Emboldened by a Republican majority in the House of Representatives, manufacturers of toys and other children’s products are making a last-ditch effort to quash new safety regulations that they say are unfair or too onerous.

headline: Shakespeare, Pirate: An Internet Tale
text: To the Editor:

headline: Reporter’s Notebook: In Afghanistan, Glimpses of the Soviet Try
text: This is the view from the American outpost at Band-e Sardeh, in Ghazni Province. To the left is a large Soviet-built reservoir. Its pale green surface, at least near the dam beneath the road, is now frozen. The dam was built by the Soviet Union in the 1960s, during the Kremlin’s long and frustrating period of Moscow-Kabul engagement. The American outpost today lies within the confines of what was once a much larger Soviet Army position astride a significant Kremlin public-works investment. Last fall, before air and water temperatures plummeted with the onset of the Afghan winter, the American soldiers here swam in the lake, no doubt just like their Soviet predecessors did.

headline: For Air Passengers, Future Doesn’t Look Rosy
text: I HAD reason to contemplate elementary physics last week when a fellow passenger, whom I shall sarcastically call Tiny, hauled himself into the middle seat beside me on a Southwest Airlines flight from Washington to Denver.

headline: Word Games Anytime, No Travel Tiles Required
text: If the inventor of Scrabble were alive today, he would be amazed by the way millions of people are playing his word game now: on tiny screens, wherever they happen to be, against players who can be halfway across the country, or the world.

headline: Hank Steinbrenner Picks on the Captain
text: When I left Tampa for some snow shoveling back home on Sunday night, there was nothing left to ask Derek Jeter. He had spoken for about 20 minutes that morning in his first gathering of the season with the news media. It went smoothly.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,429 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,464 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Bloggingheads: Abortion War
text: Sarah Posner, left, of Religion Dispatches and David Weigel of Slate debate the G.O.P.'s fight against abortion.

headline: Resisting Trujillo While Staying Stylish
text: I had never heard of the Mirabal sisters before I saw “En el Tiempo de las Mariposas,” Repertorio Español’s version of their tragic story. But the actresses playing them look smashing (and very much like the real Mirabals) in their stylishly feminine 1940s and ’50s dresses and little hats.

headline: Dynegy’s Top Executives to Resign in Wake of Failed Deals
text: Dynegy, the embattled power company, said late on Monday that its top management team, including its chief executive, planned to resign after the company failed in its second attempt to sell itself.

headline: Gattuso Gets Four-Game Ban
text: A.C. Milan midfielder Gennaro Gattuso was suspended for four European games by UEFA’s disciplinary committee on Monday for his actions in last week’s Round of 16 game against Tottenham.

headline: Wade’s Busy Weekend Gives Him Time to Relax
text: LOS ANGELES  Dwyane Wade knows that children sometimes ask more serious questions than reporters.

headline: A Founding Father’s Books Turn Up
text: A literary detective story that began 18 months ago and was advanced through a chance reading of an 1880 edition of The Harvard Register has led researchers from the Jefferson Library at Monticello to a trove of books that were among the last ones that Thomas Jefferson, the nation’s most bibliophilic president, collected and read in the decade before he died.

headline: A Risky Trip Leads to Stardom and Sanctuary
text: A Honduran teenager gained fame as the star of a documentary film that showed the dangers faced by children who ride across Mexico atop freight trains to cross illegally to the United States. But the boy, Kevin Casasola, rode the trains again, and now he has been granted asylum in the United States, his lawyer said on Monday.

headline: Japanese Stock Market Is Getting New Respect
text: TOKYO  Japan’s government finances are on the verge of collapse, and its economy has floundered for two decades.

headline: B. N. Nathanson, 84, Dies; Changed Sides on Abortion
text: Dr. Bernard N. Nathanson, a campaigner for abortion rights who, after experiencing a change of heart in the 1970s became a prominent opponent of abortion and the on-screen narrator of the anti-abortion film “The Silent Scream,” died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: A School Topples Hurdles to Learning
text: ALBERTSON, N.Y.  It is lunchtime in the cafeteria of the Henry Viscardi School in Nassau County, and two eighth graders are doing what boys their age do best: batting insults back and forth.

headline: Exposés on Oil Spill in Gulf, Afghanistan and Steroids Win Polk Awards
text: Investigative reports that exposed the devastating environmental and economic impact of the oil spill last year in the Gulf of Mexico and leadership failings in America’s military mission in Afghanistan were among the winners of 13 George Polk Awards for 2010 announced on Monday by Long Island University.

headline: All or Nothing
text: Philadelphia, Feb. 22, 1861

headline: Win at Daytona Energizes a Venerated Nascar Brand
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Nascar itself could not have scripted an ending to this year’s Daytona 500 that would have put the Wood Brothers in victory lane on Sunday at Daytona International Speedway. That was nearly impossible for a team that was once a standard-bearer in Nascar but had fallen behind the competition years ago.

headline: Keeping a Watchful Eye on a Part of the Bronx
text: Maybe it was the sudden screech of the bus’s brakes or the orange flash of its hazard lights. But something caught Sidney Flores’s attention on a recent Friday night. Something was not right. Mr. Flores quickly made a U-turn and came to a stop behind the bus on East Fordham Road in the Bronx.

headline: Ibrahim Dabbashi's Press Conference
text: On Feb. 21, Libya's ambassador to the United Nations gave a press conference to announce that mission staffers are calling upon Muammar el-Qaddafi to leave Libya.

headline: A Scholastic Refuge for Severely Disabled Children
text: The Henry Viscardi School on Long Island caters to a variety of children, including those who cannot hear, see or turn the pages of a textbook.

headline: A Famous Baby’s First Word? Hint: It’s Not Mama
text: IN a dictionary of brand names, you can find “Clicquot Club” beverages, pronounced “KLEE-ko”; De Cecco pasta, pronounced, roughly, “Day CHECK-o”; and Chico’s, the retailer of women’s clothing, pronounced “CHEE-ko’s.”

headline: Political Unrest in North Africa and the Middle East
text: In the wake of the overthrow of the leaders of Tunisia and Egypt, here is a look at challenges facing other countries across the region.

headline: In This City, It’s a Long Climb to the Top
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The long war here has had a lot of ups and downs, but that has not been the case with the country’s elevators  at least until recently.

headline: Whose Day? Well, at Least It’s Not Who’s
text: On Monday, Radio Shack offered special prices for Presidents’ Day. Office Depot had discounts, too, in honor of President’s Day. Not to be left out, Macy’s advertised sales of its own to celebrate Presidents Day.

headline: Hank Steinbrenner on Revenue Sharing
text: The feistier of George Steinbrenner’s two sons has little sympathy for baseball’s small-market teams.

headline: The War for (George) Washington
text: Charleston, S.C., Feb. 22, 1861

headline: Banner Year for Skiing, and for Search Parties
text: KILLINGTON, Vt.  With near-record snowfalls leaving several feet of fluffy powder, ski resorts on the East Coast have had no trouble attracting skiers and snowboarders this season. The problem has been keeping them on the mountain.

headline: As Talks Continue, Jets Tell Staff to Expect Furloughs
text: Negotiators for N.F.L. owners and the players union met for the fourth consecutive day in the presence of a federal mediator Monday, just 11 days before the collective bargaining agreement is set to expire. While nobody is discussing what is being said behind closed doors in Washington, the sides have spent more than 25 hours together, by far their most consistent negotiating time toward a new deal.

headline: With Mideast Unrest, Foreign Investment Is Again Interrupted
text: With the global markets on the mend last fall, a private equity consortium moved to sell its 93 percent stake in the Egyptian drug maker Amoun Pharmaceutical.

headline: Billionaire Brothers’ Money Plays Role in Wisconsin Dispute
text: WASHINGTON  Among the thousands of demonstrators who jammed the Wisconsin State Capitol grounds this weekend was a well-financed advocate from Washington who was there to voice praise for cutting state spending by slashing union benefits and bargaining rights.

headline: As Chicago Votes, Many Say the Question About Emanuel Isn’t If, but When
text: CHICAGO — As Chicagoans headed to the polls on Tuesday, the water-cooler debates here have focused less on whether Rahm Emanuel, the former White House chief of staff, would become mayor of this city, than on when.

headline: Shhh, and Not Because the Fauna Are Sleeping
text: MUIR WOODS NATIONAL MONUMENT, Calif. — At times, deep within this vaulted chamber of redwoods, it is almost quiet enough to hear a banana slug slither by. For the National Park Service, that stillness is as vital a component of the site as the trees’ green needles, or the sudden darting rays of sunlight.

headline: For Christie, Ailing Economy at Home May Test His Allure
text: In a year as governor of New Jersey, Chris Christie has captivated conservatives across the nation, with an in-your-face frankness and nonstop aggressiveness that few have seen from a chief executive.

headline: N.F.L. Labor Dispute Plays Out on Twitter
text: A few hours after N.F.L. owners filed a complaint against the players union last week alleging that it was not bargaining in good faith, Houston Texans right tackle Eric Winston took to his keyboard to react.

headline: Collins’s Pep Talk Makes an Impression on the Mets
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Sometimes the simple, blunt honesty of a child is enough to shatter the niceties of adult discourse and drive home an important message. And it was a 7-year-old Mets fan whose pointed question to Manager Terry Collins during the off-season framed one of the themes of Collins’s speech to the team on Monday.

headline: Long-Term Care Needs Changes, Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON  One of Senator Edward M. Kennedy’s legacies in the new health care law, intended to allow the chronically ill and people with disabilities to continue living in their homes, is too costly to survive without major changes, Obama administration officials now say.

headline: For a Bond Formed Over Mohair, It’s Not So Odd
text: WASHINGTON  One lawmaker is a brash New Yorker whose tempestuous speeches on the House floor are a thing of YouTube wonder. The other is the fun-guy-in-your-physics-class type who prefers to cut up on Fox News. One has an F from the National Rifle Association, the other likes to tote his Glock as he walks the streets of his Utah district. Their voting records have almost zero overlap.

headline: F.D.I.C. Is Said to Weigh Suing Leaders of Washington Mutual
text: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has sent letters to several former executives of Washington Mutual warning that it was considering taking legal action tied to their role in the collapse of the savings bank, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Dim View of U.S. Posture Toward Bahraini Shiites Is Described
text: MANAMA, Bahrain  The United States military undermined efforts to improve relations with Bahrain’s Shiite majority and understated abuses by the Sunni royal family, according to one present and one former American government adviser and a Bahraini human rights advocate.

headline: Carmelo Anthony Headed to the Knicks
text: A Knicks revival that began last July and took hold in the fall is about to receive another significant infusion of star power. Carmelo Anthony is bound for New York.

headline: What Did Watson the Computer Do?
text: Last week brought the story of a fourth grader who was suspended from school for having placed a “kick me please” post-it on the backside of a classmate. The punishment, The New York Post reported, was delivered by the school principal who said in a note to the boy’s parents, “This incident is in violation of the Discipline Code and is classified as infraction A37 — engaging in bullying behavior.”

headline: The Dirty Energy Party
text: President Obama has decided that the failure of last year’s comprehensive climate bill does not have to mean the death of climate policy. Instead of imposing a mandatory cap and stiff price on carbon emissions, as the bill would have done, the president is offering a more modest approach involving sharply targeted and well-financed research into breakthrough technologies, cleaner fuels and more efficient cars and trucks.

headline: F.D.I.C. May Sue Former Washington Mutual Executives
text: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has sent letters to former leaders of the failed lender, and agency officials have discussed seeking damages of up to $1 billion, The New York Times reports. Read more »

headline: Mr. Bloomberg’s Not-So-Bad Budget
text: When Mayor Michael Bloomberg presented his new budget for New York City, he rightly took credit for keeping the city fiscally fit through the worst recession in decades. His $65.6 billion budget for the next fiscal year was less painful than expected. Now he needs to make sure that an improved economy  and improved tax revenues  helps those who need help the most.

headline: Advocate for Women in Baseball Finally Gets to Be One
text: GOODYEAR, Ariz. — Justine Siegal felt a chill of excitement when she saw her dark blue Cleveland Indians jersey. She changed in the umpires’ locker room and emerged with a confident gait, her blond pigtails shining in the Arizona morning sun. Siegal, 36, smiled as she prepared for her debut Monday, her 13-year-old daughter, Jasmine, following close by her side.

headline: Lucking Out Inside the Beltway
text: The House Republican majority made a big show last week of pursuing its campaign promise to slash the federal budget. Far less obvious was the discreet dinner break for campaign fund-raising taken by 13 freshmen Republicans on the Armed Services Committee. The yearling defense appropriators went to solicit re-election help from the defense industry.

headline: What Quincy Can Teach New York City
text: The drama of urban snow removal has preoccupied this newspaper for 150 years. In 1910, The Times wrote about no-show contractors failing to get men and wagons onto the streets after a storm that buried New York City and snarled the Long Island Rail Road. In 2010, we  and pretty much everyone in the city  criticized a no-show mayor who left town before a storm that buried the city and snarled the Long Island Rail Road.

headline: Strong Earthquake Shakes New Zealand
text: A large earthquake struck Christchurch, New Zealand, on Tuesday, according to the United States Geological Survey, causing buildings to collapse and burying vehicles under debris. Prime Minister John Key said at least 65 people had been killed.

headline: A Families-First Approach to Foster Care
text: It’s difficult to change systems even when they are widely acknowledged to be broken. That’s the situation facing the nation’s foster care system. According to the government’s most recent estimate, there were roughly 424,000 young people in foster care as of Sept. 30, 2009. Each year, about 30,000 of them turn 18 (or 21 in some states) and “age out” of foster care. What happens to them?

headline: Lottery Numbers
Make Everybody Hurt
text: Over the past few weeks we’ve begun to see the new contours of American politics. The budget cutters have taken control of the agenda, while government’s defenders are waging tactical retreats. Given the scope of the fiscal problems, it could be like this for the next 10 or 20 years.

headline: Timing a Glencore I.P.O.
Protests Continue in Wisconsin
text: Union members and supporters in Wisconsin protested Governor Scott Walker’s bid to reduce the bargaining power of unions at the capital for a seventh straight day.

headline: At Grave Risk
text: Buried deep beneath the stories about executive bonuses, the stock market surge and the economy’s agonizingly slow road to recovery is the all-but-silent suffering of the many millions of Americans who, economically, are going down for the count.

headline: Rodriguez, With Leaner Physique and Healed Hip, Has Renewed Focus
text: TAMPA, Fla.  One of Alex Rodriguez’s boyhood heroes, Cal Ripken, was on his mind Monday. Asked how much longer he expected to play third base, Rodriguez cited Ripken as someone who flouted the perception that aging players should automatically assume diminished roles.

headline: Seoul Hotel Break-In Has Makings of a Spy Novel
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Police officials are investigating a mysterious break-in at the five-star Lotte Hotel, an odd bit of cloak and dagger in Room 1961 whose storyline includes bumbling spies caught red-handed, negotiations for a supersonic jet fighter, a stolen laptop and a conveniently timed meeting with the president of South Korea.

headline: Banker Said to Be Held in Offshore Inquiry
text: A senior private banker at Credit Suisse has been arrested in the United States in connection with a federal investigation into the Swiss bank’s work with questionable offshore accounts, two people briefed on the matter said on Monday.

headline: Midlevel Taliban Admit to a Rift With Top Leaders
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  Recent defeats and general weariness after nine years of war are creating fissures between the Taliban’s top leadership based in Pakistan and midlevel field commanders, who have borne the brunt of the fighting and are reluctant to return to some battle zones, Taliban members said in interviews.

headline: Germany Says Iran Meeting Necessary to Free Journalists
text: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel’s office on Monday addressed criticism of her foreign minister’s decision to meet the Iranian president over the weekend, saying that it was the price to pay for the release of two German journalists and that it did not change Germany’s criticisms of the Iranian government.

headline: Best All-Star Game Ratings Since ’03
text: The N.B.A. All-Star Game on Sunday attracted an average of 9.1 million viewers on TNT, up 33 percent from 6.9 million last year, according to Nielsen. It was the league’s most watched All-Star Game since 2003, when Michael Jordan made hi’s final appearance.

headline: Knicks Set to Acquire Anthony

headline: Ahead of ‘Day of Rage,’ Iraqis Have Mixed Demands
text: BAGHDAD — It is a date being discussed in Iraq’s tea shops, on television and in the streets with varying shades of hope, fear and cynicism.

headline: Error Delayed Fire Dept. in Fatal Brooklyn Blaze
text: Firefighters were briefly delayed in putting out a fire in Flatbush, Brooklyn, on Saturday night because an engine that had been sent to the blaze was already at another emergency, attending to a police officer who had accidentally shot himself in the leg, the Fire Department said Monday. The fire eventually took the life of a 64-year-old woman living on the top floor.

headline: Malcolm X Daughter Accused of Theft
text: One of Malcolm X’s daughters is being held in North Carolina on an arrest warrant from Queens, stemming from an accusation that she stole from the widow of one of her father’s bodyguards, the authorities said Monday.

headline: Girardi Impressed by Brackman’s Evolution
text: TAMPA, Fla. – The Yankees’ system is one of the best in baseball, and its strengths are not hard to discern. Of their top 30 prospects according to Baseball America, only 10 are position players. Jesus Montero, the touted 21-year-old catcher, is almost ready, and the Yankees hope that someday he will catch Andrew Brackman.

headline: New York’s Little Italy, Littler by the Year
text: In 1950, nearly half of the more than 10,000 New Yorkers living in the heart of Little Italy identified as Italian-American. The narrow streets teemed with children and resonated with melodic exchanges in Italian among the one in five residents born in Italy and their second- and third-generation neighbors.

headline: Photo Replay: Feb. 21
text: A view of the day in sports, from raucous soccer fans to a prickly situation on the golf course.

headline: Washington Theater to Bring Back ‘Oklahoma!’
text: Will Arena Stage’s revival of “Oklahoma!” make it to Broadway? In an unusual move, the Arena, a Washington theater, announced on Tuesday that it will resume performances of “Oklahoma!” on July 8 at its in-the-round Fichandler Stage, more than six months after the critical hit closed in December. The reprise is scheduled to run through Oct. 9.

headline: Location and Timing Contribute to Losses in New Zealand Earthquake
text: Intensity maps from the United States Geological Survey help show why the earthquake that struck Christchurch, New Zealand, on Tuesday (local time), while substantially weaker than the temblor that struck nearby in September, appears to have been far more damaging and deadly, according to local news accounts. Timing clearly played a role, as well, with the latest quake striking at 12:51 p.m. local time on a work day. [12:57 a.m. | Updated  The latest reports indicate that scores of people were killed.]

headline: Bold Move Puts Pressure on Anthony

headline: Rescuers Work to Find Survivors of a Powerful New Zealand Earthquake
text: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand — Rescue workers spent a cold, rainy night pulling survivors from the wreckage caused by a powerful earthquake that struck Christchurch, New Zealand’s second largest city, early Tuesday afternoon, killing at least 75 people.

headline: George Bugliarello, Visionary Engineer, Dies at 83
text: George Bugliarello, who as president of Polytechnic Institute of New York spearheaded the creation of MetroTech, a 16-acre research park that spurred development in Downtown Brooklyn, died on Friday in Roslyn, N.Y. He was 83.

headline: Is This Apartheid in Bahrain?

headline: Free Trove of Music Scores on Web Hits Sensitive Copyright Note
text: Humanity’s musical treasures — Beethoven piano sonatas, Schubert songs, Mozart symphonies and the like — come to life in performance. But they truly survive as black marks on a page, otherwise known as scores. Now a Web site founded five years ago by a conservatory student, then 19 years old, has made a vast expanse of this repertory available, free.

headline: Qaddafi’s Grip on the Capital Tightens as Revolt Grows
text: TOBRUK, Libya  Vowing to track down and kill protesters “house by house,” Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya tightened his grip on the capital, Tripoli, on Tuesday, but the eastern half of the country was slipping beyond his control.

headline: What Does Mercy Look Like?

But photographs of prisoners reaching through bars, a wrestler being contorted by masked men and an infant dressed for burial are among the many interpretations of the word in the book “The Mercy Project/Inochi,” created and curated by James Whitlow Delano.

headline: Return of the Champions League: Week II

After tumbling to fifth in the Premier League and falling out of the F.A. Cup, Chelsea travels to F.C. Copenhagen for a Champions League game on Tuesday hoping to salvage a season gone suddenly, horribly wrong.

headline: Do You Write in Your Books?
text: The rise of e-books means the decline of marginalia – readers’ written commentary in the margins of their books – much to the dismay of many book lovers, librarians and historians. Do you write in your books? Do you enjoy reading what others have written in the margins of old books?

Now in its 11th year, the festival (31-20-799-7271; www.5daysoff.nl) features the genre’s superstars alongside emerging artists and local favorites.

headline: Searching for a Place ‘In a Better World’
text: Susanne Bier’s “In a Better World” goes into Sunday’s Academy Awards as the favorite to capture the Oscar for best foreign-language film, if only because it won the Golden Globe in that category last month. The film, which is mainly in Danish, is a thoughtful and complex movie, set in a quiet village in Denmark and in a refugee camp in an African country riven by civil war. A compassionate but flawed Danish doctor serves, in Ms. Bier’s words, as “the character who bridges those two worlds.”

text: Monday was a packed day of shows. Riding on the heels of a successful spring collection, Peter Pilotto and Christopher De Vos of Peter Pilotto showed their signature long cutout dresses in black and white patterns. There was a sexy white sheath with a peekaboo slash from the neckline down toward the torso. Multicolored cardigans, lots of layers, and skirts over pants (a trend here) over thick blue tights made for a warm and wearable collection.

headline: A Green Makeover for Planters Nutmobile
text: The Nutmobile, the peanut-shaped traveling ambassador for the Planters brand, is going green. Its newest iteration runs on biodiesel and has a wind turbine, solar panels, LED interior lighting, recycled parts and wood floors reclaimed from a 19th century Pennsylvania barn. It will make its public debut at the Global Green Oscars preparty in Los Angeles on Wednesday.

headline: Google Faces New Antitrust Charges in Europe

headline: Protests in Bahrain Become Test of Wills
text: MANAMA, Bahrain  More than 100,000 demonstrators packed central Pearl Square here on Tuesday in what organizers called the largest pro-democracy demonstration this tiny Persian Gulf nation had ever seen, as the monarchy struggled to hold on to its monopoly on power.

text: BP, in the midst of a spurt of global deal-making, announced of Tuesday that it wanted to sell its interests in some British oil and natural gas fields.

headline: Pirates Brutally End Yachting Dream
text: LOS ANGELES — Jean and Scott Adam shared a dream through 15 years of marriage: to retire, build a boat and sail the world. And that is precisely what they did, heading out in 2004 from Marina Del Rey, Calif., on a custom-built 58-foot yacht for a permanent vacation that brought them to exotic islands and remote coastlines: Fiji, Micronesia, China, Phuket.

headline: Name That Tune, if It’s a New York TV Theme
text: The  death last week of John Strauss, composer of the theme song to “Car 54, Where Are You?” put the tune in heavy rotation on the playlist in our brains all weekend. And it got us thinking: What are some other super-catchy New York television themes? Here, again by the miracle of YouTube, is the theme from “The 4:30 Movie,” which ran for many years on Channel 7. Movies were either divided in half, with lots of commercials, to stretch across two hour-and-a-half slots on successive afternoons, or cut to ribbons to fit into one. And there were themes: Planet of the Apes Week, Our Man Flint Week (remember that?), etc.

headline: Home Prices Slid in December in Most U.S. Cities, Index Shows
text: Real estate prices slid in just about every part of the country in December, pushing a housing market that once seemed to be rebounding nearly back to its lowest level since the crash began.

text: TOKYO  Japan’s governing party suspended its scandal-tainted political kingmaker on Tuesday as Prime Minister Naoto Kan struggled to restore his flagging popularity ahead of a crucial budget battle.

headline: The Problem With Public Relations
text: Six months before Southfork Kitchen opened, a local public relations director pitched me, telling me what he would do, how he would do it and how much it would cost: $4,500 a month for the busy months of the year and maybe half that for the other half. I wondered which six months needed more P.R. — the long lonely winters or the hot and heavy summers? The Hamptons is an archipelago of 20 key resort towns where even the worst restaurants seem crowded in the summer.

headline: Judith P. Sulzberger, Physician and Times Family Member, Dies at 87
text: Dr. Judith P. Sulzberger, a physician whose philanthropy led to the creation of a center for genome studies in her name at Columbia University’s College of Physicians and Surgeons, and a member of the family that controls The New York Times, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 87.

headline: Lifting the Veil on the Practice of Billing Patients Who Sue
text: New York State has long had a policy of countersuing patients who demand compensation for being injured in state psychiatric hospitals. The Office of Mental Health immediately bills them for the time they spend in the hospital, often stopping the case cold and making it nearly impossible for the patient to attract or keep a lawyer, a practice we explored in this article in December.

headline: Issues of Adjustment Loom for Knicks
text: After months of insufferable rumor after insufferable rumor, Carmelo Anthony is finally set to be a Knick. But Anthony is not the only likely inbound Nugget; Chauncey Billups will take over the outgoing Raymond Felton’s job as starting point guard, and three role players – Shelden Williams, Anthony Carter and Renaldo Balkman – could help fill in minutes at the bottom of Coach Mike D’Antoni’s rotation. This is obviously a substantial deal for New York, as D’Antoni will have to integrate two major contributors on the fly while also dealing with the losses of Felton, Danilo Gallinari, Wilson Chandler  and Timofey Mozgov. That’s a substantial portion of the Knicks lineup that is headed to Denver, and trading away so many foundational players makes the process of incorporating Anthony, Billups, et al., even more difficult.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Chris Adams and Margaret Keene, a creative team, are joining the Torrance, Calif., office of Saatchi & Saatchi, part of the Publicis Groupe, as executive creative directors, overseeing the output of the 74 members of the creative department. They are assuming duties that had been handled by Mike McKay, who left to become executive creative director at the San Francisco office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group. The team had been group creative directors, working on brands like Nissan and Pedigree, at the Playa del Rey, Calif., office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of Omnicom. The Torrance office of Saatchi & Saatchi creates campaigns for Toyota Motor Sales USA.

headline: HCA Confirms I.P.O. Price of Up to $30 a Share
text: HCA Holdings, the large hospital operator, confirmed that it had set a preliminary price range for its initial public offering of $27 to $30 a share.

headline: NBC to Broadcast All Three Triple Crown Races
text: The NBC Sports group will broadcast all three legs of horse racing’s Triple Crown, unifying the spring races on one network for the first time since 2005.

headline: Q&A: Day Trips From Sarajevo
text: My husband and I will be in Sarajevo this June. Do you know of any travel agencies in that city that can arrange day trips to places like Mostar and other sites in Bosnia and Herzegovina?

headline: Authors of Palin Tell-All Book Accuse Rival Author of Leak
text: The authors of a tell-all book about Sarah Palin said that Joe McGinniss, the author of a rival book on Ms. Palin, leaked an early copy of their manuscript last week and had sabotaged their ability to sell it.

headline: Director’s Cut of ‘Never Say Never’ Will ‘Get Deeper in the Bieber Subculture’
text: They grow up so quickly these days. Two weeks after the opening of “Justin Bieber: Never Say Never,” a 3-D concert documentary about that 16-year-old, Canada-preferring, floppy-hair-cutting, Grammy-almost-winning pop phenomenon, an extended version of that film will be released into theaters.

headline: A Scrappy Youth and His Fists Must Fend for Themselves
text: On a warm night in July 1986, the writer Andre Dubus pulled over on a stretch of Massachusetts highway to help a young couple, a brother and sister, in a disabled car. Within a few minutes, a distracted driver ran into the three of them at nearly 60 miles an hour.

headline: Optimistic, to a Point, About the Knicks’ Big Trade
text: Michael Powell, a business reporter for The Times, occasionally sends City Room dispatches about his beloved, bemoaned Knicks. Here are his thoughts on the Carmelo Anthony acquisition.

headline: Playing a Sad Song for Joy: Mark Seliger
text: Mark Seliger’s collection of nudes, portraits and landscapes is just about the handsomest book of photographs to be published in a while. Every detail of “Listen,” from the quality of the binding and endpapers to the selection and reproduction of the platinum-plated prints, is a book-lover’s treat. Mr. Seliger is such a believer. And he has put together a book, with Rizzoli, that sharpens the senses for the silent and seemingly insignificant. He is well known for his portraits of actors and musicians and his fashion work for magazines, among them Vanity Fair and Italian Vogue. “Listen” displays a natural feeling for things that hover between ordinary and monumental, sad and self-renewing. You can catch his show of photographs from “Listen” at the Steven Kasher Gallery in Chelsea; it closes on Saturday. Here’s an excerpt from our recent conversation.

headline: Facebook Poaches Google’s Top Executive in Latin America
text: The fight for talent between Google and Facebook — or more precisely, the flow of Google employees to Facebook — is not just a Silicon Valley affair.

headline: Southern Comfort Combines Tradition With New Technology
text: A liqueur brand born in New Orleans in 1874 is turning to some modern-day technologies to engage more effectively with contemporary consumers.

headline: The Oscar Prognosticators Weigh In
text: It’s like a more glamorous tax day: the Oscar ballots are due today, by 5 p.m. in the offices of PricewaterhouseCoopers in Los Angeles. (And the hard deadline matters; like recalcitrant high school seniors working on their college apps, every year there are some stragglers who wait until the last minute and must hand-deliver.) For the rest of the week, in their famously undisclosed location, the accountants will tabulate and retabulate. Which leaves the rest of us free to speculate and hypothesize.

headline: Cracking the Genetic Code of ‘Brown Tides’
text: In the first genetic sequencing ever of a harmful algal bloom species, researchers said Tuesday that they had cracked the genome of the micro-organism responsible for the Eastern Seaboard’s notorious brown tides.

headline: Celebrity Skin
text: We’ve decided to spill the beans on one of Hollywood’s best-kept secrets. (After all, why should tabloids have all the fun?) Her name is Joanna Czech, and her facials make the A-list sparkle.

headline: Should Doctors Stop Patients From Driving?
text: In my many years of reporting about the elderly, I found little that caused doctors more angst than confronting a patient and family about driving. When is it time for someone with physical or cognitive problems to give up the car keys? Who makes that decision? And how can it safely and compassionately be enforced?

headline: When Unsecured Creditors Are Unequal
text: Europeans have discovered, in plans for future bank recapitalizations, that all unsecured creditors are not created equal. This has long been the reality in the United States, although some found it politically convenient to pretend this was a new development, created solely for the automotive cases.

headline: A Long, Deep View of the U.S. Budget
text: I thought the Obama White House had brought something useful to the budget debate with its visual depiction of United States spending — which revealed the profound growth in politically untouchable programs and the almost invisible dimensions of programs on education, research, innovation, development assistance and the like.

headline: Trailer: 'Vieux Carré'
text: Excerpts from a rehearsal of the Wooster Group's production of the Tennessee Williams play. (Video courtesy of the Wooster Group; camera by Zbigniew Bzymek)

headline: Striking PCB Levels Found at a New York School
text: The federal Environmental Protection Agency has found the highest levels of leaking PCBs to date in its inspections of New York City schools, at Public School 45 in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

headline: German Defense Minister Defies Calls to Quit Over Plagiarism
text: BERLIN — Defying calls by the opposition for his resignation, the German defense minister, Karl-Theodor zu Guttenberg, said Tuesday that he would hold on to his job despite his admission that he had submitted a faulty dissertation for his doctoral degree.

headline: Governors Ball Music Festival Is Planned
text: Add to the already crowded list of summer music festivals a new one destined for Governors Island, just off the southern tip of Manhattan. The inaugural Governors Ball Music Festival is scheduled to take place on the island, where Ronald Reagan once met with Mikhail Gorbachev, on June 18. It will offer a stylistically mixed bill, with a variety of indie rock, electronica, dance and hip-hop acts booked to perform. Headlining acts include Girl Talk; Pretty Lights; and Big Boi, of Outkast. Tickets are scheduled to go on sale on Thursday.

headline: Highway in India Offers Solution to Land Fights
text: JIKARPUR, India  When the state of Uttar Pradesh announced plans to confiscate farmland for a toll road to the Taj Mahal, a grimly predictable plotline ensued. Protesting farmers, angry over low compensation, blocked road work. Frustration boiled into fatal clashes with the police. Then opposition politicians arrived to pillory the state government and pose for photos with farmers.

headline: Indiana Treasurer to Challenge Lugar in 2012
text: Richard Mourdock, the state treasurer of Indiana, announced on Tuesday that he would challenge Senator Richard G. Lugar in the state’s Republican primary next year, one of several anticipated Tea Party challenges to incumbent Republican senators in 2012.

headline: This Week’s Health Industry News
text: The effort by Congressional Republicans to undo the health care law and to cut the federal budget will shift out of Washington this week as members of Congress are in their home districts on a break.

headline: Justices Reject Suit Faulting a Vaccine
text: WASHINGTON  People injured by vaccines that they say were improperly designed must rely solely on a compensation system created by a 1986 law and may not sue vaccine manufacturers, the Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday.

headline: It’s Wabbit Season
text: “Whimsy” is a word that runs rampant in the description of children’s literature, but Il Sung Na’s picture books certainly merit the label. “Snow Rabbit, Spring Rabbit” is the latest of Na’s deceptively simple storybooks (“A Book of Sleep,” “Brrrr: A Book of Winter”), where a straightforward tale of nature or nighttime is elevated by distinctive illustration into a somewhat more enchanted realm than that of mere snowfall and frozen dirt.

headline: Christie Declares ‘New Normal’ in Budget Proposal
text: TRENTON  A pugnacious and boastful Gov. Chris Christie proposed a no-growth budget for New Jersey on Tuesday, saying he had inspired a legion of copycat governors from Albany to Sacramento and was not about to let up in his efforts to shift money from public workers to property-tax payers and businesses that create jobs.

headline: Anthony Is Only a Piece of the Puzzle
text: We all want to jump to conclusions, declare the Knicks’ acquisition of Carmelo Anthony to be the greatest deal in the history of the franchise since Dave DeBusschere. Or the worst case of destructive ownership interference since James L. Dolan tried to rehire Isiah Thomas (which, granted, was only last summer, but Dolan does seem to raise the bar on recidivism).

headline: Reid Assigns Chief of Staff to Negotiate Spending Deal
text: 2:33 p.m. | Updated The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, called on Tuesday for a 30-day stop-gap spending bill to prevent a shutdown of the federal government early next month.

headline: Teachers’ Union TV Ad Attacks Cuomo’s Budget Cuts
text: ALBANY — New York’s teachers have taken to the airwaves.

headline: Another Top Time Inc. Executive Departs
text: A top executive at Time Inc. announced on Tuesday that he was leaving the company to return to his old job. It was the first sign of high-level fallout from the abrupt firing last week of Jack Griffin as chief executive.

headline: The Too Big to Fail Quandary
text: “Too big to fail,” meet the regulatory bureaucracy.

headline: For the S.E.C., Problems of Time and Money
text: The budget battle in Washington may constrain funding for the Securities and Exchange Commission as it tries to implement new rules required by the Dodd-Frank Act while dealing with a growing number of whistle-blower complaints and complex insider trading cases. A recent federal court decision in Texas in an options backdating case highlights the danger posed by a possible freeze or even cutbacks in the S.E.C.’s budget if it results in slowing down investigations of possible securities fraud.

headline: Robin Wagner, Set Designer for ‘Producers,’ ‘Dreamgirls,’ Gets Excellence Award
text: The veteran Broadway set designer Robin Wagner, whose early use of large-scale automated scenery in musicals like “On the Twentieth Century” and “Dreamgirls” has now become standard in American theater, will receive the industry’s Robert L.B. Tobin Award for sustained excellence in theatrical design at a ceremony that will honor several colleagues as well. The Theater Development Fund, the not-for-profit group that runs TKTS and administer the awards, announced the recipients in a statement on Tuesday.

headline: Oil Soars as Libyan Furor Shakes Markets
text: HOUSTON  The political turmoil sweeping the Arab world drove oil prices sharply higher and stocks much lower on Tuesday despite efforts by Saudi Arabia to calm turbulent markets.

headline: Obama Meets Small-Business Owners
text: President Obama called for increased spending on education and transportation in order to help increase American competitiveness on Tuesday, as the White House continued to position itself as business-friendly and prepared to wrestle with Republicans over the budget deficit.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Donnie Brasco’
text: In this week’s Critics’ Picks video, A. O. Scott looks back at Mike Newell‘s 1997 crime drama with Johnny Depp and Al Pacino, “Donnie Brasco.” Based on a true story, the film follows Joe Pistone, an undercover F.B.I. agent who is charged with the task of infiltrating the Bonanno crime family in the 1970s.

headline: ‘Big Love’ Watch: Anything Is Possible
text: As the final season of “Big Love” closes out, things are really feeling anarchic. Do you get the sense that anything could happen? That Barb could become a lesbian Mormon minister?

headline: Apple Said to Showcase New iPad on March 2
text: If you are thinking of buying an iPad, you may want to hold off a bit.

headline: Ristretto | Young Barista
text: Espresso Incognito, the coffee bar Callum Hale Thomson set up in Five Hundred Dollars, an art gallery on Vyner Street in East London, is only open the first and second Thursdays of each month from 6 to 9 p.m. and by special appointment. The hours are limited with good reason: Hale Thomson is just 15 years old, and still in school.

headline: The Declining Payoff From Black Colleges
text: I mentioned in a recent post that students who choose to attend a historically black college instead of a more selective college may be hurting their future earnings prospects. There’s more evidence for this finding than I knew. A 2007 study, by Roland Fryer and Michael Greenstone, came to a similar conclusion.

headline: The High Line, Manhattan, 2:34 P.M.
text: Taking in the sun on a cold day, a little bit above the sidewalks.

headline: On Our Radar: Frog Deformities Tied to Pharmaceuticals and Plastics
text: Deformities in frogs in the northeastern United States are far more common in suburban and urban areas, not in and around farmlands, a Yale ecologist’s research shows. The findings upend the conventional wisdom that agricultural pesticides are largely responsible for the abnormalities. Rather, the combination of many household chemicals, including pharmaceuticals and plastics that mimic hormones, appear to be the root cause. [Yale Environment 360]

headline: The Basics: Understanding the Upheaval in the Middle East
text: Overview | Where in the Arab world have protests sprung up? Why? What is happening? Who is involved? When, why and how did these movements begin, and how have the various governments responded to citizen protests? In this lesson, students find out basic information about the upheaval that has spread across the Arab world so that they can understand the background and the events and continue to follow the events as informed news consumers.

headline: Distressed T-Shirts for Distressed Mets Fans
text: In the past half-century, Mets fans have plenty of reasons to cry, including Marv Throneberry, Tom Seaver’s departure and the team’s epic collapse in 2007. To survive, many fans have learned to laugh about the team’s foibles.

headline: Will Britain’s Royal Wedding Pay the Bills?
text: LONDON — Royal weddings can generally be counted on to produce plenty of pomp and circumstance, not to mention — later on, of course — a possible future king or queen. In Britain, the approaching wedding of Prince William, second in line to the throne, to Kate Middleton, his longtime girlfriend, comes with a whole new set of expectations.

headline: Geneva Auto Show: Nissan Esflow Concept
text: More than 140 product debuts are planned for the Geneva auto show, which opens to the press on Tuesday, March 1. Before the gates open, Wheels is highlighting the Geneva standouts that have already broken cover online. Be sure to check back next Tuesday for news and photos from the convention floor.

headline: A Debate Over Leveraged Buyouts
text: Do management-led buyouts like the deals for J.Crew and Del Monte Foods shortchange shareholders? A lawyer involved in the lawsuit over the Del Monte deal discusses the issue. Plus, a breakdown of the HCA I.P.O. in this CNBC video.

headline: Barroom Dirges of the Working Class
text: Imagine it as the lost “Cheers” episode by Tennessee Williams: Misanthropic Lilith wipes the smug smile off Sam’s face in a bleak fantasy that banishes his lovable regulars and turns his establishment into a watering hole for blue-collar depressives  a bar where nobody wants to know your name.

headline: After 25 Years Sitting Down, Larry King Will Do Stand Up
text: Larry King the one-man interviewing machine is now Larry King the one-man showman.

headline: TimesCast | February 22, 2011
text: Chaos grows in Libya as Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi holds on to power; in Bahrain, more than 100,000 antigovernment protesters take to the streets.

headline: Songorrheic

headline: An Oscar Peek Behind the Scenes
text: The Academy is really taking its new mandate to be more open and revealing than ever before seriously. In a new promo, Anne Hathaway, who is co-hosting the evening with James Franco, is shown practicing her Teleprompter lines, and today the group announced that even average movie fans will have a spot on the red carpet – via questions they submit on Twitter or Facebook, of course.

text: Photographs from Bahrain, New Zealand, Yemen and Libya.

headline: Chicago Voters Voice Concerns About Budget and Corruption
text: CHICAGO – As voters headed to the polls here on Tuesday to pick a new mayor, the city’s budget crisis and corruption were among the issues on people’s minds.

headline: Leaked: Original Songs of a Beatle Imitator
text: “Whatever happened to feeling good?” the singer asks. “Was it a dream?”

headline: A Suicide, a Last Request, a Family’s Questions
text: SUNNY ISLES BEACH, Fla.  The words came up on Alicia Duerson’s cellphone as blithely as text messages typically do, but this one was different: her former husband, the former Chicago Bears star Dave Duerson, asked her to donate his brain for research.

headline: Racism Comes to Dinner and Everything Is Flambé
text: The ways in which politics can shape or shatter relationships and divide generations have informed a number of recent plays, among them Lisa Kron’s “In the Wake” and Amy Herzog’s “After the Revolution.” But in “A Perfect Future,” by David Hay, those considerations are just wallpaper.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bahrain and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Bahrain, New Zealand, Yemen and Libya.

headline: E.C.B. Criticizes Countries for Dragging Feet on Spending
text: The European Central Bank criticized political leaders Tuesday on the grounds of moving too timidly against countries whose excessive spending and borrowing had endangered the stability of the euro.

headline: Buzz Tracker
text: Life After Lehman What is Erin Callan, the former chief financial officer of Lehman Brothers, been up to these days? Well, we’re not sure, but thanks to John Carney, we now know what her house in the Long Island community of East Hampton, N.Y., looks like. Net Net

headline: Folk Art Museum to Show Self-Taught Black Artists in Venice
text: The American Folk Art Museum, which is facing serious financial problems, is nonetheless embarking an ambitious project: an exhibition of African-American self-taught and graffiti artists to take place in Venice during the Biennale there. The exhibition will open June 1 at the Fondaco dei Tedeschi, a building owned by the Benetton Group that may ultimately become a Rem Koolhaas-designed retail and exhibition space. Benetton is offering the building to the museum for free, as well as providing advertising and art materials and holding the opening-night party. The museum’s director, Maria Ann Conelli, said that the budget for the one-month exhibition was between $300,000 and $400,000 and that the museum was reaching out to foundations and corporations for financing. Since January, the museum has been unable to make payments on the roughly $30 million it owes against its building on West 53rd Street. Last summer, it entered into a forbearance agreement with the company that insured its debt, ACA Financial Guaranty. That agreement expires on June 30. According to the most recent available financial statements, in the fiscal year that ended June 30, 2010, the museum ran a deficit from unrestricted activities of $3.6 million. Ms. Conelli said that the museum had a balanced budget for this year.

headline: Rangers and Capitals Closer to Playing Openers in Russia
text: Negotiations to send the Rangers and the Washington Capitals to Russia to begin the 2011-12 season are near a conclusion, with a decision expected within two weeks, officials of the Russian Kontinental Hockey League said Tuesday.

headline: Workers Sickened at Apple Supplier in China
text: SUZHOU, China  Last week, when Apple released its annual review of labor conditions at its global suppliers, one startling revelation stood out: 137 workers at a factory here had been seriously injured by a toxic chemical used in making the signature slick glass screens of the iPhone.

headline: How to Roast a Whole Fish
text: Melissa Clark demonstrates how to roast a flavorful whole fish in a home oven.

headline: Cellphone Use Tied to Changes in Brain Activity
text: Researchers from the National Institutes of Health have found that less than an hour of cellphone use can speed up brain activity in the area closest to the phone antenna, raising new questions about the health effects of low levels of radiation emitted from cellphones.

text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#69", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

headline: Introducing Children’s Book Reviews Online
text: Beginning today, the Book Review will post an online-only review of a new picture book each week, supplementing — but not replacing — our regular coverage of picture books in the print edition.

headline: ‘Townie’
text: Visits with Pop

headline: Finding Low-Budget Amazon, and an Island Paradise
text: Here’s an agenda that you can’t pull off just anywhere:

headline: The ‘Lion’ Roars Loudest At the Box Office After 13 Years on Broadway
text: The long-running musical “The Lion King” is the first show to hit No. 1 in Broadway’s weekly box office grosses so late in the life of its run, earning $1,534,779 last week to edge out its closest competitors, “Wicked” and “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.” One likely factor was Disney Theatrical Productions’ decision to shift the show’s usual Tuesday evening performance to Monday evening, Feb. 14, to capitalize on date nights for Valentine’s Day.

headline: A Boy and a Building Help Shape Each Other
text: The Empire State Building doesn’t loom as large in the public imagination as it did generations ago. In this century it has ceded its place to the twin towers, with all their tragic symbolism. But during the Empire State’s construction, in 1930-31, it represented rising hope and progress at a time when so much seemed crushed and fallen.

headline: The Insider | Michael Hauptman
text: A former photo assistant of Richard Burbridge, Michael Hauptman has been taking pictures and living in New York City for the past five years. This week Hauptman, whose photographs have appeared in T and the Japanese cult magazine Untitled, releases his first book, “Notes on, Something Like Life Should Be.” Published by the Williamsburg, Brooklyn-based AndPress, it’s a personal portrait of Hauptman’s relationships over the years. The Moment caught up with Hauptman to ask him about his peccadilloes and his favorite haunts in his adopted city.

headline: Shining Light on Some Russian Rarities
text: “I know you are absolutely sincere, and I think a great deal of your judgment,” Tchaikovsky once wrote to his friend Sergei Taneyev. “But I also fear it.”

headline: Oscar Picks, From the Voice of Trixie from ‘Toy Story’
text: For the second installment of our celebrity Oscar ballot and questionnaire, we’re allowing a little bias. Kristen Schaal, best known as the ardent fan Mel on the HBO series “Flight of the Conchords” and as a correspondent on “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart,” voices Trixie the triceratops in “Toy Story 3,” an Oscar nominee this year. She also stars as Louise in the new animated series Bob’s Burgers on Fox, and is the author, with Rich Blomquist, a “Daily Show” writer who also happens to be her boyfriend, of “The Sexy Book of Sex Sex.” Ms. Schaal, who is not (we repeat, not an Academy member), is also a longtime pal of the Bagger’s. We spoke to her about her Oscar choices in an interview conducted in the most informal way possible, over Instant Message.

headline: Historic African American Murals to Be Restored
text: A set of important murals depicting events in African-American history will be restored and sent on tour for the first time through a collaboration of Talladega College in Alabama, which owns the murals, and the High Museum of Art in Atlanta. In 1938 Talladega, one of the country’s oldest all-black colleges, commissioned Hale Aspacio Woodruff, an African-American artist who had studied with Diego Rivera, to create the murals for the lobby of its new library. Comprising six canvases, the murals depict events like the uprising on the slave ship La Amistad, scenes from the Underground Railroad and the founding of the college. At the High, the murals will be cleaned and restretched, Philip Verre, the museum’s chief operating officer, said in a phone interview. They will go on view in an exhibition opening in Atlanta on June 2, 2012, and will travel later to the Indianapolis Museum of Art. Woodruff, who taught art at New York University for more than 20 years, died in 1980. He had a retrospective at the Studio Museum in Harlem in 1979 and an exhibition at the High Museum, focused on his paintings in Atlanta, in 2004.

headline: Bloomberg Criticizes Proposed Cut to Planned Parenthood
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg joined other elected officials, as well as the president of Planned Parenthood, Cecile Richards, on a conference call Tuesday to condemn provisions pending in Congress that would cut hundreds of millions of dollars out of Planned Parenthood’s budget, calling them detrimental to poor women and politically motivated.

headline: Eight Hours of Songs, and Uncounted Influences
text: Contemporary classical music has been fragmenting into ever greater eclecticism, as demonstrated by the repertory performed at the Music of Now marathon at Symphony Space on Monday. Works by 21 living composers born between 1925 and 1985 were showcased during the event, which began at 4 p.m. and lasted until midnight.

headline: Italian Energy Company Suspends Gas Pipeline to Libya
text: ROME  Concerns rose about Italy’s natural gas supplies on Tuesday, after the country’s main energy company, ENI, said it had suspended supplies through its Greenstream pipeline, which runs from Libya to Sicily and supplies 10 percent of Italy’s natural gas.

headline: ‘Nuts’
For 3-D Viewers, Robots in Disguise
text: Have you ever wanted to take home the glasses that theater ushers hand out to view 3-D movies? Yeah, me neither. They’re not fashion-forward and don’t have any practical use outside of a darkened movie theater. They’re really something only a child could appreciate.

headline: Q&A: Editing Video Preview Frames
text: Q.

headline: Amazon Couples Movie Streaming With Shipping
text: Movie-watching has gotten so confusing. My wife says, “Let’s watch a movie,” and I say, “Sure, satellite, Netflix, Xbox Live, Sony‘s PlayStation Network or how ’bout the old-fashioned DVD, or the Blu-ray player?”

headline: Judge Rules Against Online TV Service
text: A federal judge ruled Tuesday that Ivi TV, an ambitious online video start-up, must stop rebroadcasting signals of local television stations on the Internet, dealing a major setback to the company.

headline: Chaos Grows in Libya
text: Reporter Neil MacFarquhar reports from Cairo on the bloody protests in Libya.

headline: Peaceful Protests in Bahrain
text: Michael Slackman reports from Manama, Bahrain, where on Tuesday, more than 100,000 protesters -- one fifth of the nation's citizens -- held a peaceful protest.

headline: Reviewing Ai Fiori
Ai Fiori
text: HERE at long last is a winning new defense of fine dining: Ai Fiori, in the Setai Fifth Avenue hotel, just below Midtown. The chef and restaurateur Michael White opened the place late last year, with Chris Jaeckle in the kitchen and Ahmass Fakahany down at the bank. It is an emphatic rejoinder to the trend toward farmhouse tables, rustic food and shouting that has so dominated the dining scene in Manhattan at least since the start of the recession.

headline: Photo Replay: Feb. 22
text: A view of the day in sports, including the cricket World Cup in India and basketball, above and below the rim.

headline: The Site Makes the Man
text: Gentlemen, get out your plastic and get ready to spend till you bend: Mr. Porter, the male counterpoint to Net-a-Porter, the high-end fashion e-tailer, is finally live after more than a little hype over the past few months. Aimed at men who want to purchase clothes, accessories and other dapper goods online, Mr. Porter is a stand-alone destination, not an add-on to its sister site. “We started from scratch,” said Natalie Massenet, the founder of Net-a-Porter. “We didn’t want to simply include a men’s tab on Net-a-Porter.” Massenet hired the former British Esquire editor Jeremy Langmead and a team of experienced men’s-wear editors to tailor the editorial content (style advice, guides and portfolios of non-models like the poet Nick Laird, above) for an audience that is generally held to be more interested in connoisseurship than in passing fads. Not surprisingly, the site will carry classic establishment brands like Ralph Lauren and Dunhill as well as harder-to-find heritage labels like Lock & Co. and Swayne Adeney Brigg. Its handsome black and white packaging will ship to 170 countries, proving that for stylish men, even e-commerce is all about the details.

headline: Turning a Rearview Mirror on Kevin Roche
text: NEW HAVEN  Few figures better illustrate the divide between how architects see the world and how the general public does than Kevin Roche.

headline: I.M.F. Reviews Praised Libya, Egypt and Other Nations
text: Less than two weeks ago, the International Monetary Fund’s executive board, its highest authority, assessed a North African country’s economy and commended its government for its “ambitious reform agenda.” The I.M.F. also welcomed its “strong macroeconomic performance and the progress on enhancing the role of the private sector,” and “encouraged” the authorities to continue on that promising path.

headline: ‘Vieux Carré’
text: Images from the Wooster Group’s production of Tennessee Williams’s play.

headline: Your Ideal Doughnut
