headline: A Slip of the Tongue Could Lead to Terror
text: Anyone who regularly sees American premieres of new foreign-language plays knows how easy it is to get lost in translation. Even as solid a craftswoman as Yasmina Reza can sound off-key in a different language, which makes the accomplishment of the Play Company so impressive.

headline: A New York City Doughnut Tour
text: A look at three of the city’s doughnut greats: Dough, Peter Pan Donut & Pastry Shop and the Doughnut Plant.

headline: A Flowering of the Doughnut Arts
text: IN “The Donut Chef,” a children’s book by Bob Staake, two bakers on one block compete by dreaming up increasingly outlandish pastries: “Their donuts were such crazy things! Some were square and some were starry. Some looked just like calamari.” Soon the townspeople can’t remember when doughnuts were round and covered with glaze.

headline: All Over London, Love Hurts
text: LONDON

headline: Former Congressman to Join Morgan Stanley
text: Harold Ford Jr., the former congressman and Merrill Lynch banker, is joining Morgan Stanley.

headline: Long After Giving His Money Away, a Donor Takes the Pledge
text: The Shy Philanthropist is most decidedly going public.

headline: Wine in Two Words
text: I’M not one to go overboard in describing the myriad aromas and flavors in a glass of wine. In fact, most of the gaudy descriptions found in tasting notes will not help a whit to understand the character of a bottle of wine or to anticipate the experience of drinking it.

headline: Many Methods to Collaborative Madness
text: IT began, as actors’ stories often do, with a guru. Her name was Stella Burden, a k a “the other Stella.” Ms. Burden created a risky suite of training exercises called the Approach, attracted a fervent band of followers and abandoned them nine years into rehearsals for a high-concept production of “A Streetcar Named Desire,” to be performed without Stanley, Blanche, Stella or Mitch.

headline: Summing Up Wine in Two Words
text: At some point in their professional lives, engineers, astrophysicists and reporters will be privileged to hear some workplace elder preach the virtues of simplicity. But wine writers? Seemingly, we are encouraged to make things as complicated as possible.

headline: Dump Black History Month?
text: John McWhorter, left, of The New Republic and Glenn Loury of Brown University discuss the relevance of Black History Month.

headline: The Rangpur, a Lime in Name Only
text: The Rangpur lime, said to have originated in the Indian subcontinent, has nothing to do with limes. It’s bright orange, about the size of a clementine and a cross between a lemon and mandarin, making it easily peeled and segmented. The juice is extremely sour, like a lemon’s, but with a deeply floral, honeysuckle aroma. The leaves are scented like kaffir lime and can be used in cooking. A commercial crop, from California, will be available until spring.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Weekend Wine Expo

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Fresh Goat Milk, Dead Wood and Dubious Neighbors
text: WHEN Heidi Kooy bought her two Nigerian dwarf goats last year, she was flush with fantasies of fresh raw milk and homemade cheese, yogurt and ice cream.

headline: In Indianapolis, the World Comes to Eat
text: Indianapolis

headline: Glazed Beef-and-Scallion Rolls
text: Adapted from Takashi Inoue, Takashi restaurant, Manhattan

headline: Stellina, a Sunny Cafe With Gelato and More
text: Emma Hearst, left, and Sarah Krathen, who own the Italian restaurant Sorella on the Lower East Side, are turning the adjacent storefront into a bright little cafe and retail sweet shop called Stellina. All whitewash and pale marble, it’s set to open on Sunday.

headline: Chutney and Ketchup Creations
text: A native of Atlanta, Drake Page was familiar with his family’s sweet Southern-style chutneys. He also lived in London, where chutney comes with the cheese in a pub. Now his DP Chutney Collective (a one-man band so far) produces a rotating line of more than a dozen chutneys and ketchups. The aromatic curried peach, top, and the musky sweet tomato with black mustard seeds, bottom, are the most popular. He said that about 75 percent of his ingredients come from local farms. He’s nailed the Raj look on the labels, inspired by the classic tins of Sun Brand Madras curry powder.

headline: Shaved Steak, a Favorite With Many Names
text: YOU turn up the flame under a sizzling pan and sear steak for just a minute or two, barely cooking it before you sit down. The beef is remarkably tender. You are eating:

headline: Spring for Fall | Marni Clutch
text: Don’t say we didn’t warn you. The bold patterns and prints that cropped up in the pre-fall collections have materialized into a full-blown trend for fall. From the pastoral landscape prints at Rodarte to the techno Navajo patterns at Proenza Schouler (with checks and florals and tartans from the likes of Thakoon, Suno, Gregory Parkinson and Preen in between), there is no blending in with the crowd. Of course, anyone who would like to try her hand with the trend right away can grab this tribal-inspired clutch ($735, center) from the Marni spring collection. Just the thing to carry you clear through to September.

headline: Designer’s Art Collection Is a Passionate Triple Mix
text: Fashion designers are some of the most original collectors, as the art world was reminded when works owned by Yves Saint Laurent and Pierre Bergé hit the block in Paris in a sale organized by Christie’s a couple of years ago. And the designer need not be a European couturier; “Mannerism and Modernism: The Kasper Collection of Drawings and Photographs,” at the Morgan Library & Museum, celebrates the unusual collection assembled by Herbert Kasper, the American designer whose garments were sold at Lord & Taylor and other department stores from the 1950s through the ’80s.

headline: Why Budget Cuts Don’t Bring Prosperity
text: Washington

headline: Bank Closings Tilt Toward Poor Areas
text: Until it closed its doors in December, the Ohio Savings Bank branch on North Moreland Boulevard was a neighborhood anchor in Cleveland, midway between the mansions of Shaker Heights and the ramshackle bungalows of the city’s east side. Now it sits boarded up, a victim not only of Cleveland’s economic troubles but also of a broader trend of bank branch closings that is falling more heavily on low- and moderate-income neighborhoods across the country.

headline: Private Hiring and Government Layoffs
text: In my column this week, I mention that government employment and private sector employment have both fallen during the last two years. Over just the last year, private employment has risen — though more slowly than the population has been growing — while government employment has continued falling. These numbers make clear that a surge of government hiring can’t be the economy’s problem right now — because there has been no surge.

headline: Under the Radar Amid Wide Labor Strife
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.

headline: Pasta Handkerchiefs With Chunky Pesto
text: Mark Bittman makes easy fazzoletti — rectangular pasta — that is as traditional as anything else, and as delicious.

headline: Hand-Pulled Chinese Noodles
text: Huacan Chen of the restaurant Hung Ry in NoLIta spins out endless skeins of la mian, smooth, springy hand-stretched noodles, using nothing but a countertop and his hands.

headline: Zucchini Soufflé
text: Mark Bittman makes a savory mock souffle, filled with shortcuts that make this dish far less intimidating.

headline: Cardamom-Scented Oatmeal Pancakes
text: Mark Bittman uses oatmeal and whole wheat flour to update the classic pancake.

headline: How to Stir-Fry Noodles
text: Grace Young, the author of several books on Chinese cooking, demonstrates how to stir-fry longevity noodles for Chinese New Year.

headline: Governments Try to Remove Citizens From Libya
text: ROME  Governments around the world scrambled Tuesday to evacuate their citizens from an increasingly chaotic Libya, chartering military and civilian planes and, in the case of Britain and Turkey, mobilizing military ships.

headline: Jeter Puts Thorny Situation to Rest
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Derek Jeter fielded the first question Tuesday morning with a smile, a laugh and a headshake, and he left the Yankees’ clubhouse more than three hours later wearing the same amused look.

headline: N.C.A.A. Bars Calhoun for 3 Big East Games Next Season
text: The N.C.A.A. suspended UConn Coach Jim Calhoun for three Big East conference games next season for seriously violating its recruiting rules. One of his recruits, Nate Miles, received $6,000 in improper benefits from an agent who was also a Huskies booster.

headline: Wall St. Often Slow to Disclose Brokers’ Sins
text: Driving his black Mercedes-Benz over the Fourth of July weekend, a Morgan Stanley Smith Barney broker, Martin Joel Erzinger, hit a cyclist, leaving the rider seriously injured on the side of the road.

headline: Lehman Sale to Barclays Was Proper, Judge Rules
text: Barclays Capital’s purchase of a large portion of Lehman Brothers, only days after the American investment bank filed for bankruptcy in September 2008, was acceptable, the judge overseeing Lehman’s Chapter 11 case ruled on Tuesday evening.

headline: Court Weighs the Power of Congress
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court heard arguments on Tuesday in a case that touched on the most pressing constitutional question of the day: just how much power does Congress have to regulate matters ordinarily left up to the states? The fate of President Obama’s health care law will turn on how that question is answered.

headline: Messages From Libya
text: Ed Ou and Scott Nelson, photographers on assignment for The New York Times, crossed into Libya from Egypt on Tuesday, with a Times reporter, Kareem Fahim. About five hours after they arrived, Kerri MacDonald interviewed Mr. Ou through an instant messaging service. His responses, somewhat condensed, are reproduced as they came in, line by line.

headline: A New Volley From Boehner in Spending Dispute
text: WASHINGTON  As the strategic jockeying in a fight over federal spending kicked into high gear, the Republican House speaker, John A. Boehner, said on Tuesday that it was up to the White House and the Democrats who control the Senate to agree to at least some Republican-backed cuts to help reach a short-term deal and avoid a government shutdown early next month.

headline: Kevin Roche’s Architecture
text: Images from “Kevin Roche: Architecture as Environment,” an exhibition at the Yale School of Architecture.

headline: Dynegy Problems Suggest Broader Investor Unease
text: Shareholders of Dynegy have prompted the highly unusual resignations of its top management as well as an impending exit of its board.

headline: A Campaign to Introduce Keds to a New Generation
text: DRIVERS who see a 32-foot shoebox rolling down the highway over the next few weeks should not be alarmed. The large white box is part of a new national marketing campaign for the sneaker company Keds.

headline: Year After a Scandal, Woods Will Test His Progress at the Site of a Triumph
text: MARANA, Ariz.  The first clue was the view. Pounding golf balls off the pristine turf on the range at the Ritz-Carlton Golf Club at Dove Mountain Tuesday was one great ball striker after another: Robert Allenby of Australia, Rory McIlroy from Northern Ireland, the Colombian Camilo Villegas, the teenage sensation Ryo Ishikawa of Japan and, way on the far end, in a form-fitting golf shirt and wraparound shades, Tiger Woods.

headline: High Stakes: The Battle for Wisconsin
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Vancouver, a New Effort to Sell Olympic Condos
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  On a typical weekend Larry W. Campbell flies into this city from Ottawa, where he is a Liberal Party senator representing British Columbia, then spends the night at his 600-square-foot condominium at the Olympic Village.

headline: Cantona Looks to Revive the Storied Cosmos Name
text: At first, even second, glance, Eric Cantona, 44, looks as if he could be minutes away from shedding his stylish street clothes and stepping back onto the soccer field without embarrassing himself. Cantona, the enigmatic Frenchman who starred for Manchester United in the 1990s, retired at age 30 and left it all behind for a budding film career, is back in the game for the first time in 14 years.

headline: A U.S. Immigrant Program
text: To the Editor:

headline: How to Make Oatmeal . . . Wrong
text: There’s a feeling of inevitability in writing about McDonald’s latest offering, their “bowl full of wholesome” — also known as oatmeal. The leading fast-food multinational, with sales over $16.5 billion a year (just under the G.D.P. of Afghanistan), represents a great deal of what is wrong with American food today. From a marketing perspective, they can do almost nothing wrong; from a nutritional perspective, they can do almost nothing right, as the oatmeal fiasco demonstrates.

headline: The Price of Colonoscopy
text: To the Editor:

headline: An Afghan Bank: The View From Kabul
text: To the Editor:

headline: Call on Anthony Trade Was His to Make, Walsh Says
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The uncomfortable moments come and go, but Donnie Walsh disarms them with the same emotional distance and wry humor.

headline: A Royal Boon to the Economy
text: At a time of economic gloom, businesses and Britain’s government are hoping that the wedding of Prince William to Kate Middleton on April 29 will give the economy a lift.

headline: WikiLeaks Cables Detail Qaddafi Family’s Exploits
text: WASHINGTON  After New Year’s Day 2009, Western media reported that Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, a son of the Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, had paid Mariah Carey $1 million to sing just four songs at a bash on the Caribbean island of St. Barts.

headline: Knicks Go for Greatness With Anthony
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Carmelo Anthony wanted the Knicks, and the Knicks wanted Carmelo Anthony, but the trade that finally united them was so much more complicated than mutual attraction.

headline: As Boston’s Economy Grows, Demand for Rental Units Outpaces Condo Market
text: BOSTON  Investments in multifamily rentals have been one of the few hot spots in a sputtering economy, and nowhere is that more evident than in the Boston area, where a high-tech economy is enjoying comparatively strong job growth.

headline: Nepal’s Stalled Revolution
text: Kathmandu

headline: At St. Brigid’s, a Life Lost, Though Not Unknown
text: Many of the oldest saints are legends that lasted, frail flesh made into sturdy word. The Catholic church that stands at Avenue B and Seventh Street in Manhattan rose in 1848, the work of immigrants fleeing famine in Ireland. They reached into the past to call it St. Brigid’s, after a woman of the fifth century who was said to have been the first abbess of Ireland, a figure whose powers included running the church, healing the dying, and pardoning people as they trudged toward execution. She also was believed to have started a school of art whose students created the Book of Kildare, an illuminated manuscript of transcendent beauty.

headline: As N.F.L. Talks Go On, Union Adjusts Its Schedule
text: The N.F.L. and its players union met for nearly eight hours Tuesday, the fifth of seven scheduled days of negotiations with a federal mediator.

headline: Scorecard | Pringle of Scotland Wins!
text: It’s been said that the sun never sets on the British Empire — or at least not on the Burberry Prorsum live stream. But Scorecard knows the jury’s still out on whether all of Christopher Bailey’s nostalgic archive digging on the third day of London fashion week was his label’s own.  Before a more intimate audience that included the brand ambassador Tilda Swinton, meanwhile, the creative director of another heritage house that has 41 years on Burberry’s 155, Clare Waight Keller, enlisted the help of Central Saint Martins students to rethink Pringle of Scotland’s iconic knits. That’s one way to create from past and present a new warp and weft.

headline: U.S. Condemns Libyan Tumult but Makes No Threats
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Tuesday reiterated its condemnation of bloody clashes between protesters and those loyal to the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, but it stopped short of threatening concrete measures, like sanctions or a no-flight zone above Tripoli.

headline: Anarchist Ties Seen in ’08 Bombing of Texas Governor’s Mansion
text: HOUSTON — It has been two and a half years since an arsonist tossed a firebomb into the governor’s mansion in Austin and slipped into the night, but the Texas Rangers say they are finally closing in on the person responsible.

headline: Midshipman, Then Pacifist: Rare Victory to Leave Navy
text: NEW LONDON, Conn. — The question that changed Michael Izbicki’s life appeared on a psychological exam he took not long after graduating in 2008 near the top of his class at the United States Naval Academy: If given the order, would he launch a missile carrying a nuclear warhead?

headline: Finally, Turkey Looks East
text: London

headline: Clashes Over Yemen’s Government Leave 2 Protesters Dead
text: SANA, Yemen — Two young men were shot dead by government supporters on Tuesday night during a protest in front of Sana University, medical workers said. They are the first deaths in clashes between pro- and antigovernment demonstrators in Sana in the nearly two weeks since students began calling for the ouster of President Ali Abdullah Saleh.

headline: ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’ Remains in Effect Months After Passage of Law to End It
text: In December, Congress voted to end the 17-year old “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy that prohibited military service by anyone who was openly gay or bisexual. President Obama applauded the vote, which he had long urged, and signed the bill on Dec. 22.

headline: Emanuel Triumphs in Chicago Mayoral Race
text: CHICAGO  Rahm Emanuel, a former congressman who worked for two presidents, was elected mayor of Chicago on Tuesday, marking a new path for a city that has, for 22 years, been led by a singular, powerful force, Richard M. Daley.

headline: Judge Orders City to Release Reports on Shots Fired by Police at Civilians Since 1997
text: A Manhattan judge has moved to shine more light on New York Police Department shootings, ruling that departmental reports generated whenever an officer fired at a civilian in the last 13 years be turned over to the New York Civil Liberties Union.

headline: Bidders Want More Than a Slice of Mets
text: The Mets and their advisers are still weeks from narrowing the list of potential buyers of the 25 percent of the team they originally hoped to sell. But already, a variety of proposals are surfacing that suggest that investors want more than the Mets are offering.

headline: Like a Thief in the Night
text: Just two years ago, President-elect Barack Obama staged the final leg of his pre-inaugural journey by boarding a train in Baltimore for a very public rally at the Amtrak station, followed by a leisurely rail journey to Washington, where the media and a large and exuberant crowd welcomed the future president and his wife. Preceding as it did Mr. Obama’s “new birth of freedom” inauguration, billed as a tribute to his hero, Abraham Lincoln, there was little doubt that the carefully crafted trip from Baltimore was meant as a symbolic prelude. Lincoln, too, had traveled from Baltimore to Washington on the final sprint of his own so-called journey to greatness.

headline: Union Leader Minces No Words When Labor Issues Are at Stake
text: MADISON, Wis.  As executive director of the main union of Wisconsin state employees, Marty Beil is at the vortex of the hurricane here  and that makes some union members gulp.

headline: If Not Now, When?
text: What’s unfolding in the Arab world today is the mother of all wake-up calls. And what the voice on the other end of the line is telling us is clear as a bell:

headline: Street Stops by the Police Hit a New High
text: New York City police officers last year stopped more people on the streets  to question, and sometimes frisk  than in any year since the Police Department began recording the number.

headline: Black Swan Lakeside
text: CHICAGO

headline: Wednesday: Celebrity Guest Solver Josh Radnor
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — If you happen to be on Facebook, you know that you can express your approval of just about anything with the click of the “LIKE” button.

headline: The Boarders Put the Polish on Eccentric
text: Last seen in sober work attire, with his nose buried in a book for about six hours, the protean actor Scott Shepherd appears in far more garish guises in the Wooster Group’s restless but surprisingly reverent production of “Vieux Carré,” a little-seen Tennessee Williams play in which the writer exhumes a macabre assortment of lonely ghosts from his youthful, desperate days in New Orleans in the late 1930s.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Germany: Defense Chief Refuses to Quit
text: Defying calls by the opposition for his resignation, the German defense minister, Karl-Theodor zu Guttenberg, left, said Tuesday that he would not quit despite his admission that he had “lost sight of the sources in one or two places” in his doctoral dissertation. Opposition political parties and some academics had accused him of plagiarizing sections of his dissertation for his Ph.D., conferred by the University of Bayreuth in 2007. He said he would give up the title of doctor.

headline: A Call to Deny Communion to Cuomo
text: ALBANY  A consultant to the Vatican’s highest court is calling for Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to be denied holy communion because he lives with his girlfriend without being married to her.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Edward Zigo, a Detective in the ‘Son of Sam’ Case, Dies at 84
text: Edward Zigo, a seasoned New York detective who helped arrest David Berkowitz for the so-called Son of Sam serial murders, which terrorized New York in the mid-1970s, died Saturday at his home in Lynbrook, on Long Island. He was 84.

headline: Spreading Anti-Union Agenda
text: Like a wind-whipped brush fire, the mass union protests that began in Madison, Wis., last week have spread to the capitals of Ohio and Indiana where Republican lawmakers also are trying to cripple the bargaining power of unions  and ultimately realize a cherished partisan dream of eradicating them. In each case, Republican talk of balancing budgets is cover for the real purpose of gutting the political force of middle-class state workers, who are steady supporters of Democrats and pose a threat to a growing conservative agenda.

headline: France: Diplomats Take Sarkozy to Task
text: An anonymous group of former and current French diplomats said Tuesday that President Nicolas Sarkozy’s approach to foreign policy was plagued by amateurism, impulsiveness and a preoccupation with media attention. The criticisms, in an opinion article in the influential newspaper Le Monde, followed a string of diplomatic embarrassments for France, many involving Tunisia. “Contrary to the announcements trumpeted for the past three years, Europe is powerless, Africa escapes us, the Mediterranean won’t talk to us, China has kept us down and Washington is ignoring us!” the authors said, adding that Mr. Sarkozy was quick to blame career diplomats for the “disappointments” of policies decided “at the presidency of the Republic without taking into account the analyses of our embassies.”

headline: Libya’s Butcher
text: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya vowed on Tuesday that he would “fight on to the last drop of my blood” and die a “martyr.” We have no doubt that what he really meant is that he will butcher and martyr his own people in his desperation to hold on to power. He must be condemned and punished by the international community.

headline: Pledge? What Pledge?
text: Before last year’s elections, when New York’s legislators were terrified of losing their jobs, a majority signed a pledge to pass a set of much-needed reforms, starting with a plan to end the gerrymandering of political districts. Now all 32 Republicans in the State Senate and a few Democrats in the Assembly have decided that they have more important things to do. That sort of cynical postelection amnesia is an insult to voters.

headline: The Fire That Changed Everything
text: In The Times’s grim, vivid account on March 26, 1911  the day after the Triangle shirtwaist factory fire  these words appear: “The victims who are now lying at the Morgue waiting for some one to identify them by a tooth or the remains of a burned shoe were mostly girls from 16 to 23 years of age.” There were 146 victims in all, 129 of them women.

headline: Role in Anthony Deal? Thomas Isn’t Saying
text: MIAMI  Isiah Thomas leaned against the scorer’s table in an empty arena Tuesday and exhorted his players as they ran wind sprints. Wearing khaki shorts and a dark polo shirt bearing the logo of the Florida International University Panthers, he gathered his players at midcourt and spoke briefly about their most pressing issue  their next game at Western Kentucky.

headline: Cuomo Adviser Takes Pay From Health Industry
text: When Andrew M. Cuomo married Kerry Kennedy in 1990, Jeffrey A. Sachs served as an usher. When Mr. Cuomo’s daughter Michaela was born, he asked Mr. Sachs to be her godfather. When his marriage fell apart years later, Mr. Cuomo stayed in Mr. Sachs’s triplex near the United Nations.

headline: Pakistan Case Tests Laws on Diplomatic Immunity
text: WASHINGTON  An American C.I.A. contractor is accused of killing two men at a crowded intersection in Pakistan. Can Pakistani officials lawfully prosecute him for murder?

headline: Haiti’s Scars, and Its Soul, Find Healing on Walls
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Colorful and sad, beautiful but cracked, the three remaining murals of the Episcopal Trinity Cathedral received the soft afternoon sun after last year’s earthquake only because the rest of the church had collapsed.

headline: Towns Slip From Qaddafi’s Control
text: A growing number of towns in Libya’s east have in effect declared their independence from Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s rule and set up informal opposition governments.

headline: A Third Judge Validates Health Care Overhaul Law
text: A third federal judge upheld the constitutionality of the Obama health care law on Tuesday, reinforcing the divide in the lower courts as the case moves toward its first hearings on the appellate level.

headline: Unrest Throughout Northern Africa and the Middle East
text: LIBYA A defiant Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi vowed to “fight until the last drop of my blood” as a bloody crackdown enabled him to tighten his grip on the capital, Tripoli. But in the east, the opposition appears to have consolidated its hold over a string of cities across nearly half of Libya’s coast.

headline: A Climate Skeptic With a Bully Pulpit in Virginia Finds an Ear in Congress
text: RICHMOND, Va.  For nearly a year, Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II, Virginia’s crusading Republican attorney general, has waged a one-man war on the theory of man-made global warming.

headline: Nuggets Were Prepared for Trade They Didn’t Want to Make
text: DENVER  Josh Kroenke and Carmelo Anthony faced each other in a college game nearly eight years ago. Anthony was the splendid freshman for Syracuse, the eventual national-title winner. Kroenke played for Missouri as its captain and an all-academic performer. Anthony scored 16 points and grabbed the win.

headline: Queen of the Mommy Bloggers
text: O.K., then, I say, almost begging at this point, almost to the point of tears, is there anyone I can talk to who might see what I’ve been through and understand? And here’s where I say: “Do you know what Twitter is? Because I have over a million followers on Twitter. If I say something about my terrible experience on Twitter, do you think someone will help me?” And she says in the most condescending tone and hiss ever uttered: “Yes, I know what Twitter is. And no, that will not matter.”  AUG. 28, 2009, Dooce.com

headline: Phys Ed: Should Children Run Marathons?
text: With temperatures warming and the snows of 2011 finally dissolving into oatmeal slush, many people are feeling an insistent urge to get outside and run, perhaps even to start training for a spring marathon or other distance race. But for some of us, particularly those with young families, this laudatory goal can pose a problem. Should we take our kids with us? Can and should children, at any age, be runners?

headline: In Portugal With the Emergency Brake On
text: Midfielder Yael Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., native by way of the University of North Carolina, will be contributing to the Goal blog in the runup to the third season of Women’s Professional Soccer and as the United States women’s national team prepares to play in the Algarve Cup and the FIFA Women’s World Cup in Germany later this year.

headline: Word of the Day | trigger
text: trigger •\ˈtri-gər\• noun/verb

headline: Queens of the Mom-Blog Kingdom
text: I have an article in the New York Times Magazine this weekend about moms who blog — and who make a lot of money doing it.

headline: James McLure Dies at 59; Wrote Garrulous Plays
text: James McLure, a playwright whose Southern roots were reflected in the loquacious, mostly comic (but not necessarily Southern) characters he created in plays like “Lone Star,” “Pvt. Wars” and “Wild Oats,” died Thursday in Marina del Rey, Calif. He was 59.

headline: Mourning and Marching in Bahrain
text: As Shiites mourned those who had been killed in earlier protests, more than 100,000 marchers to Pearl Square called for political harmony.

headline: News Quiz | February 23, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Rescuers Press Search for New Zealand Earthquake Survivors
text: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand — Hopes of finding more survivors of the devastating earthquake here waned Thursday as the search-and-rescue operation entered its third day, with many foreigners among those missing.

headline: Protests Spread to Indiana and Ohio
text: After weeks of upheaval in Wisconsin, people in Indiana and Ohio marched on Capitol buildings to express grievances with their governments.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Feb. 23, 2011
text: Test your math skills with today’s question, created by Kari Kokka at Math for America from the article “On the World’s Largest Cruise Ship, the Sea Is an Afterthought.”

headline: Protests in Wisconsin and Ohio
text: Note: To help students understand this complex topic, we have drawn questions from three articles, one about the Ohio protests and two about the protests in Wisconsin. We have linked each question to the resource in which the answer can be found.

headline: Qaddafi Massing Forces in Tripoli as Rebellion Spreads
text: BAIDA, Libya  As rebellion crept closer to the capital and defections of military officers multiplied, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi called on thousands of mercenaries and irregular security forces on Wednesday to defend his bastion in Tripoli, in what residents said was a desperate and dangerous turn in the week-old uprising.

headline: Have You Ever Lost (or Found) Something Valuable?
text: A City Room blog post tells the story of a former New York Times employee who recently received his lost wallet, found some 40 years later. Inside, he found photos and documents from his past. What have you ever lost of real sentimental or monetary value? Did you get it back? Have you ever found something that seemed valuable and tried to return it? What happened?

headline: Daily Lexeme: Umbeset
text: Today’s word, in association with the terrific Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Music and Motion, at Times Overwhelming
text: From Jennifer Fraser’s perspective, New York is a city of classical and modern dance, bright lights, fast cars and street musicians; a carnival of movement and motion, a haven for self-expression.

headline: Commerzbank Says 2010 Results Put It on Path to Repay Bailout
text: Commerzbank on Wednesday reported a 1.4 billion euro operating profit for last year, beating expectations and putting it on a path to repay a significant part of the 18.2 billion euro government bailout it received in the crisis.

headline: Economics and Democracy in Egypt
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: A ‘Secret’ Berlin Cabaret for the 21st Century
text: A compact man in a buttoned-up, collared shirt was standing outside a faded but grand turn-of-the-century building in a neighborhood in West Berlin, looking rather confused. Suddenly, he was buzzed in and told to take an ancient elevator to the fourth floor. A mysterious blonde woman with a Mona Lisa smile and a glass of Champagne in her hand greeted him at the door of an expansive Berlin-style apartment. “Welcome to Salon K,” she said as she led him into a large room with wood parquet floors and impossibly high ceilings. It was bare except for pillows and futon-style seating around the edges and an arrangement of candles that glowed in the center.

headline: The Early Word: Mr. Mayor
text: From Today’s Times:

headline: Remembering Ollie Matson, Hall of Fame Running Back
text: Andy Barall writes about pro football history for The Fifth Down. Ollie Matson died on Saturday at age 80.

headline: An Amelia Island Pilgrimage for 1965 Mercedes Popemobile
text: The Amelia Island vintage car show and auction weekend, held annually on the northern Florida island, will receive an unlikely dignitary when the pomp begins on March 11.

headline: Under the Gowanus Canal, Flushing Out the Stench
You Should Open a Store!
text: That is what everyone is telling Joanne Tarzian. And for good reason. In 1997, she joined her sister who was running her father’s neighborhood kitchenware store in New York. Over the next 11 years, she bought out her sister and transformed the store into a modern mecca for both gourmet and aspiring cooks. She ultimately sold the store and moved to Chicago to pursue a new opportunity working for a housewares manufacturer. She was ready to move on from the grueling hours and responsibilities that come with owning a store.

headline: Trial Shows Cystic Fibrosis Drug Helped Ease Breathing
text: The gene responsible for cystic fibrosis was discovered in 1989. Now, 22 years later, a drug that tries to compensate for the genetic defect might be nearing the market.

headline: Italy Says Death Toll in Libya Is Likely Over 1,000
text: ROME  Italy’s foreign minister, Franco Frattini, said Wednesday that estimates of more than 1,000 Libyan civilians killed in clashes with security forces and government supporters “appear to be true.”

headline: Hybrids vs. Nonhybrids: The 5-Year Equation
text: A car buyer who lays out an extra $6,200 extra to buy the hybrid version of the Lexus RX will get the money back in gas savings within five years, according to Consumer Reports magazine, but only if gasoline averages $8.77 a gallon. Otherwise, the nonhybrid RX 350 is a better buy than the Hybrid 450h, the magazine says. The hybrid gets 26 miles per gallon, and the nonhybrid, 21, in the magazine’s calculation.

text: CHICAGO  In the eyes of some, Rahm Emanuel’s victory in this city’s mayoral race marks the end to a minor political skirmish but the start of far larger chaos.

text: Some people have expressed confusion about the various polls that are now out over the dispute in Wisconsin, but I don’t think they’re all that difficult to unravel.

text: Credit Suisse, the big Swiss bank, on Wednesday came under heightened scrutiny of authorities in the United States and Germany over its sale of private banking services that enable tax evasion.

headline: Feb. 23: Updates on the Uprising in Libya
text: On Wednesday, The Lede is following the uprising in Libya and protest movements in Bahrain, Egypt, Yemen, Morocco and Iran. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists on the ground. A stream of Twitter messages from the region is in this blog’s right column.

headline: Oil Prices Rise and Wall Street Stocks Drift Lower
text: Turmoil in the Middle East and North Africa continued to send stocks lower and oil prices up on Wednesday as crude operations were disrupted in Libya.

headline: Bahrain King in Saudi Arabia to Discuss Unrest
text: MANAMA, Bahrain — A day after one of the largest pro-democracy demonstrations this tiny Persian Gulf nation had ever seen, its king was in Saudi Arabia, a close ally and neighbor, to discuss the unrest engulfing the region.

headline: Red Bulls Live, Online
text: The Red Bulls of M.L.S. will provide a live stream of Wednesday’s matches against Chicago in Florida on their official Web site.

headline: Business Group Tied to U.S. Wades Into Nicaragua’s Politics
text: WASHINGTON  As president of the American Chamber of Commerce of Nicaragua, Róger Arteaga Cano routinely dealt with business issues and trade practices affecting members like ExxonMobil or Citigroup. But he also led an unusual campaign: organizing secret meetings with opposition party leaders in an effort to oust President Daniel Ortega in an election this year.

headline: PEN World Voices Festival Announces Lineup
text: A lecture by the Nigerian author and Nobel Prize winner Wole Soyinka, readings by Wallace Shawn and Malcolm Gladwell, a debate on the prison industry and an evening on the topic of sex led by Edmund White are among the offerings at this year’s PEN World Voices Festival of International Literature, which will take place from April 25 to May 1 in New York. Other events in the festival, which is put on by the PEN American Center, include a discussion of cultural and political conditions in China featuring the New Yorker contributor Jianying Zha; a night with the storytelling group the Moth, on the theme of “What’s Gone Wrong”; a celebration of poetry, curated by Laurie Anderson and featuring Antony and the Johnsons; and a game of telephone in which a Tibetan lama will pass along sutras down a list of 200 festival attendees, ending with Salman Rushdie, who will Tweet the result. The festival, which is being organized by the former Hungarian Cultural Center director Laszlo Jakab Orsos, will be based out of the Standard Hotel, with events taking place at the New York Public Library, Cooper Union, the 92nd Street Y and elsewhere. Mr. White’s sex event, which, according to a news release, will feature “celebrated members” of the fashion and music worlds, will take place in the Standard’s rooftop bar, Le Bain (French for “the bath”).

headline: By a Point, Caltech Ends 26-Year Conference Skid
text: The California Institute of Technology men’s basketball team won a conference game Tuesday night for the first time since 1985, breaking a losing streak believed to have stretched to 310 games.

headline: The Bagger Rounds Up a Costume Designer
text: It’s time for the fun party game that is Ask the Bagger. In today’s installment, we speak with an Oscar-nominated costume designer at the request of a commenter, perdita.

headline: A Knick Is Traded, and Italians Are Desolate
text: A tiny round table for two, tucked into a corner of the Via Della Pace restaurant on East Seventh Street, was missing its usual occupant. But Danilo Gallinari could not stop in for a last bite of Gorgonzola gnocchi or veal scaloppine on Tuesday because he was already on his way out of town, sent packing after two and a half seasons by the Knicks in a trade for the heralded Carmelo Anthony.

headline: Coming of Age With a Quick Wit and a Sharp Eye
text: Although “The Adults” is quite a good novel, it is easily underestimated. On the surface this is the coming-of-age story of a disaffected girl in wealthy, leafy Connecticut, and please, please try not to start yawning. The book is better than its title. Its sweep is larger than might be expected, its fine-tuning more precise. And the girl, Emily Vidal, is a lot more interesting than the sum of her spoiled suburban parts.

headline: Wednesday Reading: More Legal Wrangling Over Health Care Law
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Emanuel Celebrates Decisive Mayoral Victory
text: CHICAGO  Rahm Emanuel, the mayor-elect of Chicago, stood at a train station on the South Side on Wednesday morning, offering hugs and high-fives to residents a day after his decisive victory in a city where a generation of voters has only ever known a different mayor, Richard M. Daley.

headline: When a Vacation Package Can Save You Money (and When It Can’t)
text: ONLINE travel agencies have long promoted vacation packages as a means to big savings: “Book flight + hotel, save up to $450” is the lure on Expedia.com’s homepage, while Orbitz.com promises a savings of “up to $465.” Travelocity.com raises the bid with its claim that users can save as much as $525 on some packages.

headline: Signs of a ‘Turnaround’ for the Banking Industry
text: After three dismal years, the American banking industry regained its footing in 2010, according to a regulatory assessment released on Wednesday.

headline: Geneva Auto Show: Renault Captur Concept
text: More than 140 product debuts are planned for the Geneva auto show, which opens to the press on Tuesday, March 1. Before the gates open, Wheels is highlighting the Geneva standouts that have already broken cover online. Be sure to check back next Tuesday for news and photos from the convention floor.

headline: A Park Rediscovers Its Soundscape
text: As I write on the 15th floor of a San Francisco office tower, not one but two jackhammers are pulsating somewhere outside, in a syncopated tattoo that echoes off nearby buildings. That quintessential urban noise, along with car alarms and sirens, are a reminder of how necessary it is for parks to provide respite not just from urban landscapes but urban soundscapes as well.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diner’s Journal.

headline: Standoffs, Protests and a Prank Call
text: MADISON, Wis.  An increasingly heated national debate about the rights of union workers was stuck in a standoff Wednesday as Democratic lawmakers here and in Indiana stayed away from their Capitols to frustrate Republican efforts to vote on legislation that would undercut collective bargaining and the ability to organize.

headline: Why the Lehman Case Was Special
text: The hopes of distressed debt investors everywhere were dashed as Judge James M. Peck rejected most — indeed almost all — of the claims by the Lehman Brothers estate, which contended that Barclay’s had received an unwarranted windfall when it bought Lehman’s broker-dealer assets at the height of the financial crisis.

headline: Lost Property, Found Humanity
text: The story of Rudolph R. Resta’s reunion with his lost wallet after 40 years has bounced happily around the world. The idea that a lost object of extraordinary value might be returned by some good-hearted soul resonated with many people. Among them was our colleague Tony Cenicola, who shot the video and took the pictures of Mr. Resta.

headline: Ex-Knicks Are Eager to Strut Their Stuff
text: DENVER  There is always another side to a trade. For the four former Knicks  Raymond Felton, Danilo Gallinari, Wilson Chandler and Timofey Mozgov  it came in the shadows of the elation and expectations of the Knicks’ acquisition of Carmelo Anthony, and also at their expense.

headline: Banh Mi, the Outtakes
text: In this week’s banh mi article, I talk about several of the variations I tried in my quest for the quickest sandwich I could make at home. Before settling on ground pork, I took a little detour out of the porcine kingdom to see what would happen. Here are my notes:

headline: United States and Other Nations Step Up Libyan Evacuations
text: Whether by plane or bus, ferry or foot, tens of thousands of foreign citizens  including hundreds of Americans  were scrambling to find a way out of Libya on Wednesday as forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi fought to maintain control of a shrinking portion of the oil-rich country.

headline: Oscar Picks, Courtesy of Univision’s El Gordo
text: Viewers of Univision, the Spanish-language network, know Raúl de Molina, a veteran journalist, as El Gordo. With Lili Estefan, the Cuban-born Mr. de Molina is a host of “El Gordo y la Flaca,” a wildly popular daily talk show on Univision that has made him a well-known personality in the Spanish-speaking world. Mr. de Molina is also a contributor to The Huffington Post, where he writes about food and health, and an inveterate world traveler (even though he was almost mauled by lions while on safari last year). He filled out our Oscar ballot, and when the Bagger spoke with him from his home in Miami, he wasted no time in sharing his picks.

Before the gates open, Wheels is highlighting the Geneva standouts that have already broken cover online. Be sure to check back next Tuesday for news and photos from the convention floor.

headline: Did You Say Helmut Newton?
text: Before I pop over to Versace to have coffee with Donatella, let me dash off a few words about the Gucci show. It will only take a few moments, so comprehensibly ’70s were Frida Giannini’s fur-covered shoulders, tie-at-the-neck blouses and chic gaucho trousers in flannel or suede with boots or platforms. The palette was all violet, wine, rust, emerald green, teal and a bit of cherry. Ms. Giannini also offered those lady-ish full-sleeved dresses with tiny belts that figure so prominently in memories and archives of the ’70s, along with fedoras and feathers. Her press notes referred to Helmut Newton and Bob Richardson’s fashion photographs of Anjelica Huston, his girlfriend at the time, who practically lives on every designer’s mood board. The silhouette is certainly one for the ages — Marc Jacobs made a pass for spring — but it hardly lifts the old skirts.

text: Kevin Clark has a fascinating piece in today’s Wall Street Journal comparing pro basketball in this country with pro soccer in England:

headline: Dodd-Frank Requires ‘Tsunami’ of Rules
text: The Deal Professor, Steven M. Davidoff, speaks to Margaret E. Tahyar, a partner at Davis Polk & Wardwell, about what regulatory agencies must do to put the Dodd-Frank Act, which overhauls financial regulation, into effect. How can regulators decide which organizations are actually too big to fail?

headline: New ‘Earnest’ Cast Members Named for Broadway
text: To lose one parent, Lady Bracknell declares in “The Importance of Being Earnest,” may be regarded as a misfortune and to lose both looks like carelessness. But the loss of three performers from Roundabout Theater Company‘s Broadway revival of that Oscar Wilde comedy is an inevitability. Though it was recently announced that “Earnest” would extend its run at the American Airlines Theater through July 3, the cast members Dana Ivey (who plays Miss Prism), Paxton Whitehead (Rev. Canon Chasuble) and Sara Topham (Gwendolen Fairfax) are set to depart after the March 20 performance.

headline: City to Replace School Lighting Tainted by PCBs
text: The Bloomberg administration announced on Wednesday that the city would replace light fixtures containing the toxic chemicals known as PCBs in nearly 800 city school buildings over the next 10 years, after months of pressure from federal officials and worried parents.

headline: A ‘Normal’ Family
text: What is a “family”? Statistically, it is no longer a mother, a father and their biological children living together under one roof (and certainly not with Dad going off to work and Mom staying home).  Although perception and acceptance often lag behind reality, there is evidence that a new definition of family — while far from universally accepted — is emerging.

headline: Best Movie Query? You Win
text: THIS is the first of what will be a monthly question-and-answer column that will run on Sundays in The New York Times and also, in longer form, at nytimes.com/movies. The focus of this round of questions is the Oscars, which are being given out Sunday. For future columns, we would like to hear from you about whatever movie-related subject piques your curiosity: individual films, industry trends, historical trivia. Write to us at askthefilmcritics@nytimes.com.

headline: Billboard Opposing Abortion Stirs Debate
text: A billboard that an anti-abortion group erected last Friday in SoHo, a half-mile from a Planned Parenthood center, claiming that “the most dangerous place for an African-American is in the womb,” quickly stirred discussion and controversy.

headline: Searching for Survivors After New Zealand Quake
text: Rescuers at a collapsed building in central Christchurch on Wednesday. The city remained silent and dark a day after an earthquake killed scores of people.

text: A superstar arms race has broken out on both sides of the Hudson River.

headline: ‘Normal Heart’ Revival a Late Addition to Broadway (and Tony) Calendar
text: Every spring brings one or two late entries to the Broadway season, opening just under the wire to qualify for the Tony Awards. This year it will be “The Normal Heart,” Larry Kramer’s landmark play about love, AIDS and New York in the 1980s, which will begin preview performances at the Golden Theater on April 19 and open on April 27, a spokesman for the production said on Wednesday. (To qualify for this year’s Tonys, shows must open by April 28.)

headline: The Ups and Downs of A.D.H.D.
text: Is there an upside to A.D.H.D.? Are certain careers more suited to the person with attention deficits than others? How does someone with A.D.H.D. deal with the daily ups and downs of the disorder? These are among the questions recently posed by readers of the Consults blog. Here, Dr. Russell Barkley, clinical professor of psychiatry at the Medical University of South Carolina, responds.

headline: Republican Governors Split on Collective Bargaining
text: Scott Walker, the Republican governor of Wisconsin, shows no signs of backing down as public workers continue to protest his efforts to restrict collective-bargaining rights in the state.

headline: Democrats Target Republican House Members for Budget-Cut Vote
text: 3:08 p.m. | Updated Democrats are targeting 50 Republican House members with a new round of automated phone calls, Web videos and mass e-mails into their districts that seek to link the lawmakers to unpopular cuts included in their party’s budget proposals, Democratic officials told The Caucus.

headline: Collective Bargaining Rights and Higher Education
text: While much of the focus of the protests in Wisconsin and other states that are trying to outlaw collective bargaining has focused on how it will affect public schools, the online publication Inside Higher Ed is reporting that college faculty members are also at risk of losing their bargaining rights.

headline: Top S.E.C. Lawyer Sued by Madoff Trustee
text: The top lawyer at the Securities and Exchange Commission has been sued by the trustee seeking to recover money for victims of Bernard L. Madoff‘s Ponzi scheme.

headline: In Shift, U.S. Says Marriage Act Blocks Gay Rights
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, in a striking legal and political shift, has determined that the Defense of Marriage Act — the 1996 law that bars federal recognition of same-sex marriages — is unconstitutional, and has directed the Justice Department to stop defending the law in court, the administration said Wednesday.

headline: Budget Wars or Culture Wars?
text: Gail Collins: David, you wrote a very evenhanded column about the situation in Wisconsin that I admired. Unfortunately, when it comes to budgetary issues I have wandered off to the land of the insanely angry.

headline: Glenn Beck Does The Times Deficit Puzzle
text: Glenn Beck spent several minutes filling out our deficit puzzle on the air last week. The segment starts around 22:00.

headline: Madison Has Been a National Stage Before
text: The conflict in Madison, Wis., pitting crowds of unionized state employees (and their supporters) against allies of Gov. Scott Walker (and Tea Party members), took much of America, and many of our political leaders, by surprise. But while Madison may deserve its reputation as a liberal college town, a backdrop for Lorrie Moore’s fiction and home to The Progressive magazine — not to mention the annual Great Midwest Marijuana Harvest Festival — the city also has a long history of ideological conflict.

headline: Are Irrational Design’s Ideas Strong Enough to Bootstrap?
text: Last week, we published a case study that discussed the challenges facing Irrational Design, a technology start-up that is determined to bootstrap. Its co-founders, Jared Cosulich and Adam Abrons, say they believe they will be freer to take risks and experiment without pressure from investors seeking a quick return. But operating on a shoestring has meant releasing imperfect products — a dating Web site, an application that serves as an online suggestion box for businesses, and a goal-sharing message board.

headline: Building Buzz for a Small, Australian Film
text: In doing the Q&A thing with readers, it’s pretty hard to avoid the “Yes, Virginia, there is a…” style of reply (“Yes, Virginia, there is a Weinstein…”), but rest assured, the Bagger is trying. A lot of folks have written us asking about the Academy members’ viewing habits.

headline: U.S. U-17 Team Qualifies for World Cup
text: 8:46 a.m. | Updated The United States will play host Jamaica, while Canada faces Panama, in the regional U-17 semifinals on Friday. Games are available as live streams at Concacaf.com (registration required).

headline: When M.&A. Hurts
text: In the heat of the deal, it is hard to remember that mergers and acquisitions are a risky business. This is particularly true when management is seeking a defensive deal, one born out of desperation to “save” the company or otherwise fight off an activist investor. It is not a deal born to further the company’s expansion but rather in response to its own distress.

headline: Homes for $440,000
text: A three-bedroom house in Austin, Tex., a three-bedroom house in Sarasota, Fla., and a two-bedroom condo in a Chicago townhouse.

headline: An Unexpected Compliment From Albany’s Corner Office
text: ALBANY – School superintendents are used to having relatively thankless jobs. So after completing successful negotiations for a wage freeze with labor officials in his school district in central New York, Christopher R. Brown was content with a celebratory lunch with his father at a local hamburger establishment last Friday.

headline: Wild and Woolly | The Pringle Archive Project
text: Though London Fashion Week’s endearingly creative reputation rests on its relentless embrace of the new, Pringle of Scotland’s collaboration with the M.F.A. students at Central St. Martins, which was unveiled earlier this week, looks to the past. The 196-year-old cashmere purveyor — it’s often credited with inventing the twin set — threw open its archives in Hawick, Scotland, last summer to the design school’s students, who first catalogued them, then mined them for inspiration. The result is a woolly mashup that mixes 1950s argyles with a postmodern sensibility — in other words, perfect for fall’s emerging grunge-meets-prim trend.

headline: Unintended Air-Bag Deployments Lead to Recall of 144,000 Ford F-150s
text: Ford is recalling about 144,000 F-150 pickups from the 2005-6 model years because the driver’s side air bag might deploy without the vehicle being in a crash, a Ford spokesman said Wednesday. The number represents a small fraction of the total F-150s that the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration was initially concerned about.

headline: Ticket Resellers Prepare for Anthony’s Debut
text: Carmelo Anthony’s potential debut Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden against the Milwaukee Bucks has made some Knicks fans very happy, but left others looking in their wallets for more money.

headline: Finlit
text: Portmanteau for Financial Literacy.

headline: Where and How to Guard Your Laptop
text: My laptop was recently stolen by a cab driver who was dropping me off at an airport. But airports aren’t the only place where consumers should make sure to carefully guard their portable computers.

headline: Feeding the Nurses
text: I joke that nurses will do anything for food. Good food, bad food, healthy food, junk food — we’re not particular. Patients must understand that too, because they constantly bring us food.

headline: Alberta Ferretti: The Beat Goes On
text: The Milan fall shows are just revving up and Alberta Ferretti also likes teal. How will we feel by Friday if this becomes a trend? Ms. Ferretti’s collection this evening had a slight Mod haze (short lengths, tunic dresses, stand-away collars) with baroque touches (best that I could make out) and over-the-knee velvet boots. All very pretty, but while you don’t expect Ms. Ferretti to light the fashion path, you do hope for more signs of research into new materials that would help push her brand forward.

headline: An Apartment in Central Berlin
text: A two-bedroom apartment in a 1900s Art Nouveau building is on the market for 289,000 euros, or $400,000.

headline: Man Accused in Fraud Scheme Wants to See Son Compete
text: Mark Mazer may have been in the headlines recently because he is accused of being the architect of an $80 million scheme to siphon money from the Bloomberg administration’s CityTime project to automate payroll for all city workers. But he is also the parent of an accomplished gymnast.

headline: General Is Cleared of Sex Accusations
text: WASHINGTON  The Marine Corps officer who has been called President Obama’s favorite general  and one considered a leading candidate for chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff  was investigated and cleared of accusations that he had a sexual relationship with a subordinate, according to documents released Wednesday.

headline: Spring Visas Delay Boys of Summer
text: Felix Hernandez is one of baseball’s best young pitchers, but when he arrives at the United States Embassy in Caracas, Venezuela, before the start of spring training each year, he has to walk through a metal detector and submit to being fingerprinted  like every other applicant for a visa to work in this country.

headline: For Berra and Guidry, It Happens Every Spring
text: TAMPA, Fla.  With all the yearly changes made by the Yankees, Yogi Berra’s arrival at their spring training base adds a timeless quality to baseball’s most historic franchise.

headline: Nets Trump Knicks With Deron Williams Deal
text: It did not take long for the Knicks to be upstaged by their soon-to-be Brooklyn neighbors. As was first reported by Al Iannazzone of The Record of Woodland Park, N.J., the Nets have agreed to a deal that will send Derrick Favors, Devin Harris, New Jersey’s 2011 first-round pick and a protected 2012 first-round pick (via Golden State) to Utah for the All-Star point guard Deron Williams.

headline: With Abarth, Fiat Hopes to Avoid Cute Curse in America
text: When Laura Soave, the head of Fiat North America, visited New York last week, she recalled her prior professional experience at Volkswagen to illustrate a keen branding point. Fiat is determined not to let its 500 subcompact be pigeonholed as merely a cute car — a fate, she suggested, that befell the New Beetle while she was at VW.

headline: Pictures of the Day: New Zealand and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from New Zealand, Tunisia and Afghanistan.

headline: The Critics Answer Your Oscar Questions
text: In the first installment of what will be a monthly fixture, Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott, the co-chief film critics of The New York Times, answer reader questions about the Oscars. For future columns, they would like to hear from you about whatever movie-related subject piques your curiosity: individual films, industry trends, historical trivia. Write to them at askthefilmcritics@nytimes.com.

headline: Paul McCartney Collaborates With City Ballet
text: In an unexpected intersection of celebrity pop music and ballet, that most refined of the performing arts, Paul McCartney has written a major orchestral work for New York City Ballet.

headline: Calls for a ‘Jasmine Revolution’ in China Persist
text: BEIJING  A small but stubborn protest movement is continuing calls for demonstrations despite a campaign of arrests and censorship that underscores China’s concern over unrest and revolts in authoritarian countries in the Middle East and North Africa.

headline: Goldman’s $70 Million Investment in AppSense
text: Goldman Sachs’ next big Silicon Valley move after Facebook is a $70 million investment in AppSense, a company providing user-personalization technology. User virtualization allows user-specific information to be accessed independent of a desktop.

headline: Supreme Court Allows Lawsuit Over Rear Seat Belts
text: WASHINGTON  The family of a woman killed in a head-on collision may sue the maker of the minivan she was riding in for failing to install lap-and-shoulder belts, the Supreme Court unanimously ruled on Wednesday.

headline: Man Held in Stabbing Spree Is Indicted in Manhattan
text: The Ukrainian man accused of carrying out a 28-hour rampage that killed four people has been indicted in Manhattan on attempted murder and assault charges, prosecutors said on Wednesday.

headline: The Little People Pay Taxes
text: Leona Helmsley’s legacy lives on in the building that bears her name.

headline: Upheaval Jolts Israel and Raises New Worry
text: CASABLANCA, Morocco  The old certainties of the Middle East have been upended, and Israel finds many of its most reliable partners buffeted or blown away by popular agitation from below. Egypt was long one of Israel’s most important allies, and ties were quietly close to Tunisia. With demonstrations for change also in Jordan, Bahrain and Morocco, Israel finds itself floundering.

headline: New Face for Economic Council
text: President Obama will nominate a Justice Department official to his Council of Economic Advisers, the White House press secretary, Jay Carney, said Tuesday.

headline: Agent Provocateur, Selling Kink on Madison Avenue
text: I ONCE worked on a play with a dominatrix, who explained a troublesome producer with the smiling dismissal: “Oh, don’t worry about him. He’s such a John.”

headline: Hey, Mr. Critic!
text: The mailman came this week with questions about restaurant grief and birthday wishes, about escaping the kids for a weekend of meals, about eating linguine with clam sauce and celebrating marriage. I endeavored to answer as best I could. You may add your own thoughts in the comments below. And, as ever, you may send restaurant questions to me at dinejournal@nytimes.com.

headline: Wall Street Remembers Joseph Flom
text: The death of Joseph H. Flom, who built Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom into a global legal powerhouse, represents the passing of a giant in deal-making.

headline: Geneva Auto Show: Mini Rocketman Concept
text: The Mini Rocketman concept, which will be introduced at the Geneva auto show next week, is largely about space exploration.

headline: New Street Food Rules in Vancouver Emphasize Health and Diversity
text: In Vancouver, street food is an emerging mini-industry. But new vendors who want to sell hot dogs and cheese steak sandwiches may need to switch to healthier options. A controversial city council decision made last month requires vendors seeking licenses to conform to a range of new rules, which emphasize healthier fare; organic, local and fair-trade foods; and an increased diversity of options.

headline: A New Sandwich Shop for Cobble Hill
text: The Van Horn Sandwich Shop, which combines Southern fried fare with an industrial chic aesthetic, opened recently in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. Jacob Van Horn, an architect who grew up in Chapel Hill, N.C., but has spent the last four years living in Brooklyn, conceived of the restaurant last year after getting laid off from Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, an architectural and engineering firm. He hired the chef Rick Hauchman (of Roberta’s Pizza in Bushwick and The Commodore), a friend and fellow North Carolinian, to run the kitchen, and spent about four months hunting for the right space. In July, he found it at 231 Court Street, falling in love with its unobstructed view down leafy Baltic Street.

headline: Bieber Dominates Billboard Chart
text: Justin Bieber, Lady Gaga, Mumford & Sons and Lady Antebellum all got big “Grammy lifts” — the typical boost in record sales after the awards show. But who had the biggest lift depends on how you look at the numbers. Mr. Bieber, who did not win any awards but who had a prominent performing slot at the ceremony, dominates this week’s Billboard album chart. “Never Say Never: The Remixes” (Island), the soundtrack to his new 3-D concert film, opened at No. 1 with 161,000 copies sold. But just as impressive, he has three other albums in the Top 40: “My World 2.0” is No. 8, “My Worlds Acoustic” is No. 18, and “My World,” the mini-album that was his debut, is No. 31. Billboard said Mr. Bieber was the first artist to pull off that feat since Garth Brooks in 1993. The British alt-folk band Mumford & Sons and Lady Antebellum, the country-pop trio that went home with the most Grammy awards (five, including record and song of the year), also had good runs on the album chart. Mumford & Sons’ “Sigh No More” (Glassnote) holds at No. 2 this week. Its rise to No. 2 from No. 11 last week was largely based on impulse buys made during the Grammys telecast, on which the group performed with Bob Dylan, with 133,000 sales, a 169 percent increase from the week before. Lady Antebellum’s “Need You Now” (Capitol Nashville) is No. 4, with 85,000 sales, a 205 percent gain. (No. 3 this week goes to Vol. 37 of the series “Now That’s What I Call Music!,” which sold 95,000.) In terms of digital downloads, however, Lady Gaga and Cee Lo Green came out way ahead. “Born This Way,” which Lady Gaga performed at the awards, sold 509,000 copies in its first full week on sale, bringing its total sales in the United States — in just 10 days — to 957,000. And sales of Cee Lo’s “____ You” jumped 178 percent, to 412,000.

headline: Enigmatic Choreographer Tells an Enigmatic Tale
text: The choreographer Paul Taylor  one of the few living artists who have made classics by which our age should be remembered  is a puzzle, and means to be. He makes works whose rhythms answer that of their music, except sometimes they carry on regardless. He makes dances that are primarily about dancing, except that in many of them he seems preoccupied by more specific subject matter. His pieces are addressed to the audience in a way that speaks of entertainment (bright, harsh or both) and yet frequently they do things that will make audiences think, “We should be entertained by that?” His company’s repertory has become so large  his latest is listed as Opus No. 133  that each year brings a major revival of at least one important work that hasn’t been seen in decades. It contains many other pieces that get revived only fleetingly before being returned to cold storage for several more seasons.

headline: Moviegoing Leaps, Except in North America
text: International moviegoing soared in 2010, but the North American market started to show more signs of trouble, according to an annual survey released on Wednesday by the Motion Picture Association of America. Total box office receipts for all films released around the world climbed to $31.8 billion, an 8 percent increase over 2009. But overseas ticket sales contributed all of the increase, as sales in North America were flat for a second year, at $10.6 billion, despite a boom in sales of higher-priced 3-D tickets. “The Chinese box office market is just going gangbusters,” said Bob Pisano, president and interim chief executive of the movie association. The association does not report overseas attendance figures; admissions in North America fell 5 percent, to 1.34 billion. In a development that Mr. Pisano called “not so encouraging” the number of North American admissions per capita fell to 4.1, the lowest level since 1993, from 4.3 in 2009. Mr. Pisano said he was unsure of the reason, but added, “We’ve got to get more Americans and Canadians back to the movie theaters.”

text: It’s the first day of fashion season on the Continent and already the first reviews are trickling in, but somehow the final reports are just being filed from across the Channel, so it’s back to London Town for Scorecard. And thank goodness for that, because it was on the fourth and final day of a series of shows that were uncustomarily uniformly all about heritage values that the weird and wonderful youth culture came out. headline: Out of Work, Out of Time
text: Since losing my job I’ve struggled with countless questions for which I have no suitable response: Is it healthy for my family to subsist on a diet entirely of packaged ramen, canned beans and grocery-store samples, and if so, must it be certified organic? Does baby really need a new pair of shoes? If I’m so smart how come I’m so broke? The worst question, though, and the one most likely to induce paroxysms of guilt, irritation and half-joking existential despair, is one that seems so simple to answer, but has proven the most vexing: if I’m not working, why don’t I have more time? Shouldn’t a jobless fellow like myself be free to relax, clean house, run errands for my fiancée Tomoko and, most important, spend time with my children, J.P., 4-years-old, and Ellie, the baby?

headline: How the West Was Won
text: Histories of mid-19th century America tend to separate its two most important threads: a war over slavery engulfs the East, while mineral rushes transform the West. But while these developments are geographically distinct, they could not be more interdependent. At its heart, the political crisis that led to the Civil War was fought over the extension of slavery into the West, and it was the subsequent implosion of the Union that enabled the Northern, Republican-controlled Congress to create these western territories.

headline: Charles Epstein, Leading Medical Geneticist Injured by Unabomber, Dies at 77

headline: Georgia: Prison Guards Charged in Beating
text: Seven prison guards were arrested Monday on charges of beating an inmate so badly that he sustained brain injuries and was partly paralyzed. The inmate, Terrance B. Dean, 29, in prison for armed robbery, was assaulted by the guards in December after an argument, according to a recent investigation by the Georgia Bureau of Investigation. The arrests follow a period of strife for Georgia’s corrections department. In December, inmates in at least four prisons refused to work until their living conditions improved. Mr. Dean’s beating was not related to the strike, but it was uncovered during the state’s investigation of the strike, said his lawyer, Mario Williams.

headline: Texas: Dallas Mayor Resigns Amid Talk of Senate Run
text: Mayor Tom Leppert of Dallas announced at a City Council meeting Wednesday that he would resign this week. Mr. Leppert has been mentioned in Republican circles for weeks as a possible candidate to replace Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, who announced last month she would leave the Senate after 19 years in office. Mr. Leppert told Council members that he would make an announcement in a few days about his future. Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst, also a Republican, has said he is considering running for Senator Hutchison’s seat. The mayor pro tem, Dwaine Caraway, will become interim mayor after Mr. Leppert finishes his last day on Friday.

headline: Letter: The Irish Affliction
text: It took courage for the abbot of Glenstal Abbey to address child sexual abuse in the Irish Catholic Church in Russell Shorto’s article. I agree with him that severe sexual repression most likely led to the masochistic sexual “culture” graphically described in the Ryan and Murphy Reports. For the Roman Catholic Church in Ireland and elsewhere, however, the real systemic culprit remains deeply woven into the fabric of the institution. Power that only plays at accountability while continuing to practice control will spawn yet-to-be-imagined forms of abuse. This is far from over.

headline: Supercolossal Street Art
text: In a Paris suburb in October 2005, two teenagers of African descent were running away from the police and tried to hide inside a power substation. They were electrocuted instantly. The violence that broke out in protest of police harassment soon spread to neighboring communities and eventually to housing projects across the whole of France. When the media came to document the events in Clichy-sous-Bois, they were met with an additional, unexpected kind of confrontation: behind one of the countless cars in flames was a black-and-white photograph that was pasted onto the side of an apartment building some time before and took up its entire width. From its center, surrounded by a group of boys striking aggressive poses, a black man several times larger than life stared out, pointing with what appeared at first to be a shotgun. On closer inspection, it was a video camera. Get out, he seemed to be saying, we’re recording this too, and we’ll tell the story the way we see it.

headline: How Chris Christie Did His Homework
text: Like a stand-up comedian working out-of-the-way clubs, Chris Christie travels the townships and boroughs of New Jersey­, places like Hackettstown and Raritan and Scotch Plains, sharpening his riffs about the state’s public employees, whom he largely blames for plunging New Jersey into a fiscal death spiral. In one well-worn routine, for instance, the governor reminds his audiences that, until he passed a recent law that changed the system, most teachers in the state didn’t pay a dime for their health care coverage, the cost of which was borne by taxpayers.

headline: Israel Strikes Gaza After Rocket Attack on Israeli City

headline: Mexico: Suspect Detained in Shooting of U.S. Agent

The detained man was identified as Julián Zapata Espinosa, known as El Piolín, a leader of the Zetas gang in San Luis Potosí. The agents were ambushed and fired on as they drove from San Luis Potosí State to Mexico City. The motive was not clear but speculation has focused on a possible carjacking.

headline: Rumsfeld Gets to Know Jon Stewart

headline: Zimbabwe: TV Viewers Charged With Treason
text: Zimbabwean authorities on Wednesday charged a total of 45 students, trade unionists and activists with treason, accusing them of watching news videos of the uprising in Egypt and plotting to topple Zimbabwe’s autocratic president, Robert Mugabe, 87, who has been in power since 1980. If convicted, they face sentences of life in prison or death. Human rights lawyers say the accused are innocent and were merely engaged in an academic discussion about events in Egypt.

Yet foreign businesses and investors, once increasingly eager to tap that stunning growth, have started looking elsewhere.

headline: An Appetizing Proposition: Anthony Hopkins Takes His Music on Tour
text: With some tours, you wonder what songs will appear on the set list; for this one, we wonder what they’ll serve at the concession stands. Anthony Hopkins, who has variously cooked up the liver of a census taker and the brain matter of Ray Liotta in his onscreen capacity as Dr. Hannibal Lecter, plans to take on more digestible material in a series of concerts featuring his own musical compositions. BBC News reported that Mr. Hopkins will participate in the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra’s summer tour of Britain, on which the orchestra will perform the original scores he created for his films “August” and “Slipstream,” as well as a new work by the actor. The orchestra, conducted by Michael Seal, will also play selections from the scores of Mr. Hopkins’s best-known films, including “The Remains of the Day” and “The Silence of the Lambs,” and Mr. Hopkins will discuss his music and creative process (and who knows, maybe even favorite recipes) with Tommy Pearson, a producer of the concerts. There was no immediate announcement if the concert series might come to the United States or if Mr. Hopkins might take a brief detour to the Bahamas to have an old friend for dinner.

headline: Aware of His Changing Role, Jones Is Ready to Help Yankees
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Any proper highlight montage of Andruw Jones’s career would begin with video from the opening game of the 1996 World Series and go on to show a dizzying assortment of gravity-defying catches and majestic home runs. Jones, for all of it, would be wearing an Atlanta Braves uniform. His last game with the Braves was in 2007. For the sake of accuracy, Jones has since played for the Los Angeles Dodgers, the Texas Rangers and the Chicago White Sox, adjusting every season to the industry’s changing perception of him. A prodigy at 19, a star at 25 and a backup at 31.

headline: Sabathia Says Weight Loss Improved His Stamina
text: TAMPA, Fla. — C. C. Sabathia was not expecting a miraculous difference Thursday morning when he faced hitters for the first time this spring, no extra velocity or sharper break or improved command now that he is pitching at 290 pounds. After throwing about 30 pitches, Sabathia did notice an increase in stamina, and that counts as progress.

headline: Fox News Chief, Roger Ailes, Urged Employee to Lie, Records Show
text: It was an incendiary allegation — and a mystery of great intrigue in the media world: After the publishing powerhouse Judith Regan was fired by HarperCollins in 2006, she claimed that a senior executive at its parent company, News Corporation, had encouraged her to lie two years earlier to federal investigators who were vetting Bernard B. Kerik for the job of homeland security secretary.

headline: Prime Minister Urges Iraqis to Call Off Nationwide Protests
text: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki on Thursday urged Iraqis not to take part in nationwide demonstrations scheduled for Friday, saying he had evidence that insurgents were trying to use the protests to create unrest.

headline: Remembrance of Flavors Past
text: When Gabrielle Hamilton was a child, growing up in Pennsylvania, her family gave an annual party that was legendary in its small town  a spring lamb roast for almost 200 people, who came from as far away as New York City: former ballet dancer friends of her mother’s and artist friends of her father’s, along with local friends and neighbors, who all gathered in the meadow behind their house to feast on lamb and asparagus vinaigrette and shortcake. In preparation Gabrielle and her sister and brothers would fill dozens of brown paper lunch bags with sand and candles and set them along the stream’s edge under the weeping willows to light everyone’s way, and juice up glow-in-the-dark Frisbees in the car headlights, so they could send those “glowing greenish discs arcing through the jet black night.”
