headline: A Cheat Sheet for the Foreign-Language Oscar Race
text: Handicapping the competition for the Oscar for best foreign-language film is a bit more complex than for some of the other categories, since there’s no telling how many people are going to vote, what motivates those who do, or even who they are. To qualify to vote, an academy member must see all five nominated films, and many — or most — Oscar voters simply can’t be bothered with a category considered so marginal or esoteric. That’s not the case with categories like best film or best actor and actress.

headline: James Earl Jones Elected for Broadway Revival of ‘Gore Vidal’s The Best Man’
text: When his time behind the wheel at “Driving Miss Daisy” comes to an end, James Earl Jones need not resort to reciting Justin Bieber lyrics for fun and profit (unless he wants to), as his next term of office on Broadway has been decided: Mr. Jones, a Tony Award winner for “Fences” and “The Great White Hope,” will next portray a former United States president in the revival of “Gore Vidal’s The Best Man,” a political play scheduled for spring of next year. Press representatives for the revival said on Thursday that Mr. Jones will play Arthur Hockstader, a Truman-esque chief executive deciding between endorsing the potential presidential nominees William Russell and Joe Cantwell. When “The Best Man” was first presented on Broadway in 1960 (and made into a film in 1964), Russell was perceived as an analogue for Adlai Stevenson and Cantwell as an amalgam of John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon; a 2000 Broadway revival, starring Charles Durning as Hockstader, Spalding Gray as Russell and Chris Noth as Cantwell, seemed to have its eye on the real-life contest between Al Gore and George W. Bush. Michael Wilson (“The Orphans’ Home Cycle”) will direct the 2012 production, though its producers have not yet announced their nominees to play Russell and Cantwell.

(Mr. Feig evidently made a big impression: Aaron Sorkin, another former student, wove him into a “West Wing” episode.)

headline: It’s (Gasp!) Alive, Not to Mention Peeved
text: LONDON  Bet you’ve never seen baby pictures like these. In the thrilling first moments of the National Theater production of “Frankenstein,” directed with rough magic by Danny Boyle, a newborn tumbles hard from the womb and straight into the struggle that is life. Oh, the muscle-clenching pain of it, as this still inchoate being tries out its lungs, its limbs, its voice. When it takes its first wobbling steps, it’s an act of exultation, and we want to roar with it.

headline: 36 Hours in Mammoth Lakes, Calif.
text: FOR over half a century, Angelinos have flocked to this secluded corner of California’s Sierra Nevada mountains. It’s easy to see why. Despite the 8,000-foot altitude, Mammoth Lakes’ sprawl of splashy condos and strip malls has a distinct Los Angeles feel. But the surrounding frozen lakes and granite peaks, immortalized by the photographer Ansel Adams, are decidedly un-Los Angeles, and can hold their own with any landscape in Colorado or Canada. And with expanded daily flights from the San Francisco Bay area and Los Angeles, not to mention a flurry of new après-ski offerings, Mammoth is hoping to draw skiers from beyond the Golden State.

headline: An Impressive Lineage for Animated ‘Gruffalo’
text: Fans of Helena Bonham Carter who fear she may not win the Oscar for her supporting role in “The King’s Speech” (out-advertised by Melissa Leo or underdogged by Hailee Steinfeld) will be happy to know that Ms. Bonham Carter has a second chance to bring home an Oscar this year, albeit indirectly.

headline: Thieves Arrested in Egypt Trying to Break Apart Ancient Statue
text: Two thieves were arrested last week trying to break apart an important 20-foot-tall statue of the pharaoh Ramses II embedded in a quarry in the southern city of Aswan, Egypt’s antiquities minister, Zahi Hawass, said in a phone interview. Mr. Hawass said that the thieves wrongly believed that the statue was hollow and had gold hidden inside it. They were caught by guards at the site, he said, comparing the thieves to the people who looted the Egyptian Museum on Jan. 28. Those looters were also looking for gold, according to Mr. Hawass, and for a fictitious substance called red mercury that is believed by “ignorant people” to have been used in mummification and to have magical properties.

headline: Brewer Isn’t Answer for Knicks’ Need for Wing Depth
text: In their deal to acquire Carmelo Anthony, the Knicks opted to consolidate. Danilo Gallinari and Wilson Chandler are solid players, but rather than have those two good scorers in their rotation, the Knicks cashed in on their trade value to net one terrific scoring talent. Neither Gallinari nor Chandler can touch Anthony when it comes to shot creation or scoring volume, but the cost for the upgrade in first-unit production is the team’s depth. Both former Knicks played over 34 minutes a night, which means that in addition to Anthony, New York will have at least one more new regular filling in minutes on the wing.

headline: Founding President of Seaport Museum Calls for Resignations
text: 3:54 p.m. | Updated The founding president of the Seaport Museum New York, which in recent weeks lost a third of its trustees and furloughed half its staff, has called for the resignation of the museum’s current president, Mary Pelzer, and its chairman, Frank J. Sciame. In a letter to Ms. Pelzer that he shared with The New York Times, the former president, Peter Stanford, said that the museum needed new leadership to survive. He wrote that Ms. Pelzer’s and Mr. Sciame’s credibility had been damaged by “concealment” of its financial problems, and that the “overall direction of the Seaport Museum has been neglectful of its principal physical asset,” its historic ships. Mr. Sciame, a real estate developer, has lent the museum $3 million in the last year to cover operating expenses. “Mr. Sciame and Ms. Pelzer are extremely surprised and deeply disappointed by these inaccurate comments,” said Adam Pockriss of Rubenstein Communications and a spokesman for the museum. Neither Ms. Pelzer nor Mr. Sciame returned phone calls.

headline: Can the Economy Recover Without Housing?
text: You sometimes hear the claim that the economy cannot  recover before the housing market recovers. I think that’s wrong. Just because real estate led the economy into the recession does not mean it must lead the economy out. Other sectors can accomplish that. It’s more likely that the economy will need to recover — with unemployment falling and income rising — first and then housing will begin a very slow recovery.

headline: Putin Questions Europe’s Foreign and Energy Policies

headline: GMO Poll Results (and More)
text: Clearly this is something I’ll be writing about for years to come; emotions are high and many pro-GMO people are industry boosters in disguise. Nothing wrong with that, I suppose, but fake impartiality is obnoxious. There were two pieces in Forbes about my column. The more reasonable one categorized me as a “foodie elite” – presumably not because I sometimes eat well but because I refuse to acknowledge that genetically engineered foods will save the world, which they will not (you might read this terrific piece by Christopher Cook in The Christian Science Monitor, about Monsanto’s business and its threat to food safety, and then remember that not all new developments are progressive) and a “luddite” (which is ridiculous, unless believing that not every bit of technology is world-saving makes you a luddite).

headline: Along Came Yet Another Spider: Get Ready for a Third ‘Spider-Man’ Musical
text: Among the things you’ll soon be able to find on every street corner in Manhattan: a Chase bank; a fresh fruit stand; a Duane Reade; and a theater presenting a musical based on Spider-Man. To an embarrassment of riches that already includes “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” (which opens – maybe – at Broadway’s Foxwoods Theater on March 15) and “The Spidey Project: With Great Power Comes Great Responsibility” (which comes to the Peoples Improv Theater on March 14), you can now add “Spidermann,” which will arrive at the Tank on W. 45th Street in Manhattan for three performances beginning March 13, possibly in an attempt to capitalize on the outsize publicity generated by one of the two aforementioned projects.

headline: Where It’s Still Legal to Exhale
text: AN afición for cigars  “penchant” lacks the necessary passion, while “fondness” is at least three shades too tame  is a difficult itch to scratch in Bloombergian New York, which, aside from its high property taxes and low trans fats, is almost entirely smoke-free. There aren’t many Cubans to be found, even at the high-end joints in Midtown, which leaves the connoisseur with the alternative of second-fiddle Dominicans. If you are going to buy such things, you might as well go to the source.

headline: From City Folk, Toe-Tapping Country Sounds
text: ON a recent Saturday night, in a desolate corner of Red Hook, Brooklyn, a crowd gathered at Sunny’s, a family-owned bar that’s been soothing homesick sailors for well over a century. Outside, icy winds sliced across New York Harbor; inside, visitors clutched mugs of hot spiced cider, squeezing onto the handmade wooden benches flanking the back room. A man wandered in holding a guitar.

headline: Change in Kidney Transplant Policy Would Favor Younger Patients
text: Younger patients would be more likely than older ones to get the best kidneys under a proposal being considered by the nation’s organ transplant network.

headline: Big Deal | Courtney Love Rents in the Village
text: Like a lot of other things in the life of Courtney Love — a musician, an actress and the wife of the late Kurt Cobain— her house hunt, a relentless and dramatic search for a West Village town house, took on an epic nature.

headline: A Fund-Raiser Grown Wild
text: The word “fund-raiser” evokes an image of endless speeches, bland evening gowns and even blander buffets, but Edible Schoolyard’s yearly benefit should veer a little more toward the wild side. With three fabulous hostesses (the food artist Jennifer Rubell, the fashion buyer Julie Gilhart and the 303 gallerist Lisa Spellman) and a storied downtown locale (the Odeon), the event promises to be more Studio 54 than Cipriani Ballroom. “It’s the kind of fund-raiser that I would love to attend, a fund-raiser that is not boring” says Rubell, just back from the opening of her “Engagement” show at the Stephen Friedman gallery in London. “My favorite women in the city will be there, including Lynn Wagenknecht” — the restaurant’s owner — “who came up with the idea.”

headline: On Our Radar: Palin’s Predator-Control Policies Persist
text: Aggressive predator-control policies instituted during the tenure of Sarah Palin, the former governor, remain in place in Alaska and continue to stir controversy there. The baiting, snaring and killing of black and grizzly bears, and the gassing of wolf puppies in their dens with carbon monoxide, were both pushed for by hunting groups and authorized by Ms. Palin before her 2009 resignation. Conservation and wildlife groups call the tactics cruel and overzealous. [High Country News]

headline: Young Seek to End West Bank and Gaza Schism
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Young Palestinians watching the revolutions in Egypt, Tunisia and elsewhere in the region have no shortage of their own protest-worthy causes.

headline: Andrea Mohin’s Jump Shot
text: Certain performances and rituals — on the stage or the playing field, in religious shrines or halls of government — have moments so emblematic that they are definitive. No matter how many times they’ve been captured before, a photographer must not miss them, even if they summon a sinking sense of déjà déjà déjà vu.

headline: The Midlife Thing, the Nightmare Thing
text: THE bassist and bandleader Mike Watt, who once played in the great Southern California punk band the Minutemen and now spends half his life on the road with five different groups, turned 53 in December. He feels all right about it. “It’s not a totally lame place to be,” he said last week by telephone from his home in San Pedro, Calif. “My knee hurts, but I do have experiences I didn’t have as a younger man.”

headline: Renaissance Painting as Punk Mirror

text: An expedition to the mountains of the Solomon Islands sought to understand how new species evolve.

headline: Amtrak Now Stops at a YouTube Channel
text: Amtrak started a YouTube channel this month to offer travelers a new way to get information about the rail line. The channel will feature  videos about safety, security and other travel tips, information about the Trails & Rails program (done in conjunction with the National Park Service), high-speed rail initiatives and expansion plans for its Wi-Fi service. Personal stories of passengers who share their travel experiences will also be highlighted.

headline: Using Solar Power to Extract Oil
text: A California company has begun using solar power to squeeze oil out of an old oil field, flooding the underground rock with steam that comes from the sun’s heat instead of from burning natural gas.

headline: 4 Rules to Win Your Oscar Pool
text: Nate Silver is providing awards-season insight for Carpetbagger leading up to the 83rd Academy Awards on Feb. 27. Mr. Silver is the author of The Times’s FiveThirtyEight blog, which is devoted to the analysis of statistics and data in politics and other areas.

headline: Discovery, Bound for Space Station, Leaves Earth One Last Time
text: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  With seconds to spare after a last-minute glitch, the repaired shuttle Discovery, grounded since November because of vexing fuel tank cracks, rocketed into orbit Thursday on its 39th and final flight, setting off for the International Space Station to deliver supplies, equipment and a final American storage module.

headline: At Combine, Rex Ryan Guarantees Super Bowl Win
text: INDIANAPOLIS — After joking about his role on a coming episode of “CSI New York,” Rex Ryan delivered the moment slumbering reporters at the N.F.L. scouting combine were waiting for.

headline: Boeing Wins Contract to Build Air Force Tankers
text: In a surprise twist to a long-running saga, the Air Force said on Thursday that it would award a $35 billion contract for aerial fueling tankers to Boeing rather than to a European company that builds Airbus planes.

headline: Mathieu Palombino to Open a Diner on Bowery
text: With two Motorino pizzerias under his belt, Mathieu Palombino is about to head in a different direction. He and his partners plan to open Bowery Diner in the late spring, in what had been a restaurant supply store at 241 Bowery (Stanton Street). Modeled after what Mr. Palombino calls “a mid-century American diner,” with a counter and booths, it will serve coffee, doughnuts and other breakfast dishes in the morning, then segue into sandwiches and other dishes at lunch.

headline: A Promising Rookie Gives Houston and M.L.S. the Royal Treatment
text: Kofi Sarkodie is probably the first player in the history of Major League Soccer who comes from a royal family. Not the so-called soccer royalty. Real Ashanti royalty. Queens and kings, and princesses and princes.

headline: A Sotheby’s Catalog With Some Juicy Details
text: Along with the usual dry provenance notes, Sotheby’s March 10 design catalog gives spicy anecdotes about condition problems and family disputes.

headline: House Freshmen Take Plans for Cuts Home
text: JUPITER, Fla.  Representative Allen West clicked through his PowerPoint presentation on last week’s doings among his fellow House Republicans, and those of his constituents who gathered here Tuesday night to hear him whooped with glee.

headline: The Self-Invented Artist
text: WASHINGTON  Paul Gauguin was a dreadful man who made some beautiful art. That’s the present take on him. In his craving for fame and fulfillment he dumped his family, bullied his friends, ripped off ideas and lied about his past. His book “Noa Noa,” which he advertised as an account of his life in Tahiti, was largely fantasy, mostly plagiarized. If he published it today, Oprah would be demanding an apology.

headline: Scientist’s View: In Climate Action, No Shortcuts Around CO2
text: There’s been much discussion recently of quick, cheap steps, with many benefits, that could slow warming driven by the atmospheric buildup of heat-trapping greenhouse gases. They all involve greenhouse gases other than carbon dioxide, along with black carbon — the sooty emanations from diesel engines and guttering cooking fires that both heat and kill.

headline: Bill Requiring the University of Iowa to Relinquish Pollock’s ‘Mural’ Is Dropped
text: State legislation that would have forced the University of Iowa to sell “Mural” — an 8-by-20-foot painting by Jackson Pollock valued at more than $100 million — to raise money for the school has been dropped, The Des Moines Register reported. State Representative Scott Raecker introduced the bill this month as a way to create an endowment to pay for as many as 1,000 full student scholarships a year, but the proposal drew widespread criticism. David Miles, the president of the Board of Regents, State of Iowa, described the bill as “a profoundly bad idea,” one that was examined by the board in 2008 and “determined to be not in the best interests of the University of Iowa or the state.” Mr. Raecker told the student newspaper The Daily Iowan that he still believed the painting should be sold but said that the issue had become “so polarized that reaching consensus is unlikely.” “I’m a firm believer in the legislative process,” he added, “and further discussion of the sale of the Pollock painting will not be moved forward in the legislature this year.”

headline: A.I.G. Posts $2.2 Billion Loss as Stock Sale Draws Nearer

headline: F.H.A. to Raise Insurance Premiums

headline: Man-Child in the Promised Land, for a Whole (Pant! Pant!) Week
text: The bodily fluids that Peter and Bobby Farrelly let fly and sometimes squirt in their movies, along with the assaults visited on their hapless male characters and those men’s various body parts, might suggest that these filmmaking brothers are stuck in a developmental quagmire. They don’t just like to play around in human messes, those both ickily literal and situational; they also revel in them. Yet while all this foul play can make you blanch, these excesses are affirmations of the humanity that comes with the yuks. Their characters poop, therefore they are — or at least the guys are.

headline: Speaking at Arm’s Length With Music
text: TO woo her, I needed a music box. I conceived this idea the night I met her. I’d gone alone to an open-mike night. I was 22 and new to the city. I wasn’t at this open mike to launch a career as a ukulele-player, but to meet new friends. I got along best with other musicians.

headline: Fin-de-Siècle Hothouse, Plush and Neurotic
text: There’s no modernism like Viennese modernism, that amazingly fraught, conflicted efflorescence of art and thought that flared up around the turn of the 20th century. As the Austro-Hungarian Empire sank into paralysis in the decades before World War I, Freud discovered the unconscious lurking, unsurprisingly, behind the city’s repressive social codes. Otto Wagner and Adolf Loos designed buildings that rejected the historicist wedding-cake facades of the Ringstrasse. Arnold Schoenberg pursued atonal music in the perfumed wake of the Viennese waltz; and Gustav Klimt painted beautiful women surrounded by mosaic patterns straight out of Byzantium.

headline: Huckabee Is Out Hawking His Book, and Maybe His Candidacy
text: Mike Huckabee, the former governor of Arkansas, is out hawking his new book, “Twelve Things We Really Need from Washington (and a Trillion That We Don’t!).” As a former presidential candidate whose book tour includes an eyebrow-raising number of stops in early nominating states — six in Iowa and five in South Carolina — he had a thing or two to say about the current state of politics.

headline: Fox Finds Right Tune Wednesday
text: The remaining contestants on “American Idol” performed songs from the Beatles catalog on Wednesday as the judges named 5 of the top 24 to advance. The Fox reality competition easily dominated the night’s ratings over all. According to Nielsen’s estimates, an average of 22.6 million viewers tuned in to the episode from 8 to 10 p.m. CBS’s “Criminal Minds,” with its 13.4 million viewers at 9, came closest to matching the audience for “Idol,” as CBS claimed second place, earning solid results the rest of the night for “Survivor: Redemption Island” at 8 (11.2 million) and “Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior” at 10 (9.9 million). ABC ranked third with its comedy lineup from 8 to 10, including “Modern Family” (13.3 million) and “Mr. Sunshine” (6.5 million) in the 9 p.m. hour. NBC finished fourth with “Minute to Win It” from 8 to 10 (4.1 million), followed by “Law & Order: SVU” at 10 (8 million).

headline: Artifacts | Terence Koh’s ‘Tink Tank’
text: As a designer-label ascetic who boasts a white, monkey-fur coat and white-on-white suits, Terence Koh has no trouble getting attention. But it isn’t just his monochromatic taste that turns heads. The ceremony, elegance and debauchery of his sculpture and performance work, which can involve white chocolate, potato starch, white sugar, blinding white light and bodily fluids, also draws crowds. For his current show at Mary Boone‘s Chelsea gallery, however, visitors are leaving him pretty well alone.

headline: Keeping Score: Big Trades Don’t Come With Guarantees
text: Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Portland Trail Blazers.

headline: Diners’ Questions on the Reviewer’s Plate
text: The mail came this week with questions about restaurant grief, birthday wishes and more. As ever, you may send restaurant questions to me at dinejournal@nytimes.com.

headline: La La Vazquez, the Wife of Carmelo Anthony, Gets VH1 Show
text: La La Vazquez, the wife of the NBA star  Carmelo Anthony, won’t just be busy setting up house when the couple moves to New York. She has landed a reality series on VH1, “La La’s Full Court Life,” which will chronicle the couple’s move from Denver. On Monday Mr. Anthony was traded by the Denver Nuggets to the New York Knicks. The 10-episode, half-hour series, which is scheduled to premiere in August, will show Ms. Vazquez, an actress and television personality, as she copes with the demands of career and home in New York. It is a follow-up to “La La’s Full Court Wedding,” a series about the couple’s wedding broadcast last year on VH1. “Viewers connect with La La because despite the fairy tale wedding and NBA star husband, she is a real, down to earth, hardworking woman who stays true to herself,” said Jeff Olde, executive vice president for original programming and production at VH1.

headline: A For-Sale Sign With Brains
text: IN 1996, when J. Philip Faranda started out in real estate, he never left home without a beeper, a day planner in a three-ring binder on the passenger seat of the car and a street atlas on the back seat. Those items and a fax machine in his home office, as well as a voice-mail account with the telephone company, he said, “made me a big shot.”

headline: DreamWorks Animation and Imax Report Higher Profits
text: Two small but important Hollywood companies, DreamWorks Animation and Imax, reported greatly improved quarterly financial results on Thursday.

headline: Drink Up, Pay Up
text: I’ve been on two dates with this girl. We get along great and have a blast together. Problem is, I end up buying all the drinks. She doesn’t even pretend to offer, even after I hint. This doesn’t seem right, especially in the age of $14 Belgian beers. My friends tell me she’s a mooch and I should ditch her. Or should I just keep paying?

headline: The Inside Story on Outsiderness
text: A STARTLING sight will soon be hanging in midair in the Madison Avenue window of the Whitney Museum of American Art, just a few blocks from Ralph Lauren, Prada and Gucci: a 22-foot-long neon sign spelling out the words “negro sunshine.”

headline: A Low Tide for Home Sales in the Shoreline Market
text: FOR the shoreline real estate market, by unvarying tradition, spring arrives early. Sometime in mid-January, in all four coastal counties  Monmouth, Ocean, Atlantic and Cape May  the number of listings begins to swell and rises in small waves, usually reaching a peak by early April.

headline: Bed-and-Breakfast Inns Being Sold as Vacation Homes
text: ELEVEN years ago Jeanne and Lou Genovese bought two and a half acres on a quiet lane in the middle of North Fork wine country in Cutchogue. They designed a 4,340-square-foot house with six bedrooms, five and a half baths, and a broad front porch, planning for it to double as a bed-and-breakfast.

headline: Embracing the Ambiguity of Mahler’s Seventh
text: Mahler’s Seventh Symphony, composed during the summers of 1904 and 1905, is generally considered the most problematic and baffling of his works in the form. The piece may be the least programmed and the last that most conductors learn, often simply because they have set out to perform the complete Mahler symphony cycle.

headline: A Pharaonic Smackdown as Envisioned by Handel
text: Once again, an Egyptian oppressor has fallen on dark times. In Handel’s grand oratorio “Israel in Egypt,” it is the God of the Israelites who wreaks vengeance on the enslaving pharaoh, with no need of Facebook or Twitter. But recent events added a certain immediacy to Handel’s vivid recounting of the biblical plagues visited on Egypt, when the Musica Sacra Chorus and Orchestra, directed by Kent Tritle, performed the work at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening.

headline: Floating Through Fog, and Yet Structured
text: Beach House played Webster Hall on Tuesday night with the three musicians’ faces in shadows and their bodies silhouetted against pyramids of white fabric. Smoke-machine smoke was in the air; a few songs into the set, starry lights began to shine behind the band. Beach House’s music is at home in the dusk and haze. Victoria Legrand sings about dissolving boundaries  between lovers, between past and present, between memories and desires  with her voice floating on the sustained chords of her keyboard and the reverb of Alex Scally’s guitar.

headline: ‘Idol’ Lifts Fox on Wednesday
text: The remaining contestants on “American Idol” performed songs from the Beatles catalog on Wednesday as the judges named 5 of the top 24 to advance. The Fox reality competition easily dominated the night’s ratings over all. According to Nielsen’s estimates, an average of 22.6 million viewers tuned in to the episode from 8 to 10 p.m. CBS’s “Criminal Minds,” with its 13.4 million viewers at 9, came closest to matching the audience for “Idol,” as CBS claimed second place, earning solid results the rest of the night for “Survivor: Redemption Island” at 8 (11.2 million) and “Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior” at 10 (9.9 million). ABC ranked third with its comedy lineup from 8 to 10, including “Modern Family” (13.3 million) and “Mr. Sunshine” (6.5 million) in the 9 p.m. hour. NBC finished fourth with “Minute to Win It” from 8 to 10 (4.1 million), followed by “Law & Order: SVU” at 10 (8 million).

headline: 4 Rules to Win Your Oscar Pool
text: Two years ago, I tried to predict the Oscar winners by crunching data from the last 30 years of awards history. The project was a mixed success. But I’ve dusted off the database and aimed to simplify it — boiling it down to a few core factors that have been especially reliable predictors in the past. Here, then, over at the Carpetbagger, are the rules-of-thumb for predicting the Oscars. Read more.

headline: Weekend Miser
text: The bad news? Natalie Portman is bringing her fit fiancé to the Academy Awards on Sunday night instead of you. The good news? At its Oscars viewing party, Side Bar is offering two-for-one drinks in which to drown your sorrows. The broadcast starts at 8 p.m., as do the drink specials, but those who R.S.V.P. to Emily@yourpartyplanning.com should arrive early to get a free drink. You can fill out an Oscar ballot for a chance to win two movie tickets and more drinks. (Sunday, 7 p.m.; 120 East 15th Street, at Irving Place, Manhattan; 212-677-2900, sidebarny.com.)

headline: Where It’s Still Legal to Exhale
text: An afición for cigars — “penchant” lacks the necessary passion, while “fondness” is at least three shades too tame — is a difficult itch to scratch in Bloombergian New York, which, aside from its high property taxes and low trans fats, is almost entirely smoke free. There aren’t many Cubans to be found, even at the high-end joints in Midtown, which leaves the connoisseur with the alternative of second-fiddle Dominicans. If you are going to buy such things, you might as well go to the source.

headline: Battle-Honed Commander Unleashes Pirates
text: CONVEYING with any accuracy the goings-on at a recent rehearsal of “Treasure Island” would come most naturally to a comic-book artist or perhaps a writer for the old “Batman” TV show. Swords and oars and barrels and fists oooff and shhkrit into one another, a seemingly endless barrage of chaos until B. H. Barry, the theater’s pre-eminent fight director for some 50 years, dived in for a quick correction. Would-be pirates in sweatpants stood attentively, a thwup morphed into a thwap, and the mayhem began again.

headline: The Next Impasse
text: In the nine years since the first American troops landed in Afghanistan, a new kind of religion has sprung up, one that promises success for the Americans even as the war they have been fighting has veered dangerously close to defeat. Follow the religion’s tenets, give yourself over to it and the new faith will reward you with riches and fruits.

headline: Chilean Miners, in Israel, Count Blessings Amid Media Glare
text: JERUSALEM  With revolts toppling governments across the Middle East and peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians suspended, 25 of the Chilean miners rescued after more than two months underground toured the holy sites of the Old City of Jerusalem on Thursday.

headline: The Carpetbagger’s 2011 Oscar Predictions
text: Melena Ryzik, aka the Carpetbagger, has spent three months following the news and nonsense of Hollywood’s awards season. Now she uses all that knowledge to predict who will emerge victorious on Sunday night and why.

headline: Coastal Carolina Struggles on Way to Tournament
text: CONWAY, S.C. — Coastal Carolina University has a bandbox gym that holds 999 fans, a remote location near Myrtle Beach and a funky nickname, the Chanticleers — the requisite trappings of a men’s basketball darling. On the court, Coastal Carolina had the nation’s longest winning streak — 22 games — and almost reached the top 25 this season.

headline: When a Show Goes Down, a Poster Goes Up: Will ‘Spider-Man’ Join ‘Moose Murders’?
text: By now, you probably know that “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” risks becoming to Broadway musicals what the Titanic was to ocean voyages. If things keep going the way they have, with previews constantly extended, Wal-Mart might open in New York before this $65 million show does.

headline: Hoping to Lead Bank, Italian Faces Hurdles
text: ROME — He is a familiar face at the European Central Bank. Many economists think he should be the next person to run it.

headline: China: Uighur Groups Criticize Death Sentences
text: Uighur advocacy groups have criticized the recent death sentences of four men who are all apparently ethnic Uighurs. The men were reportedly sentenced for three separate incidents of violence last year. They are Turhun Turdi, Abdulla Tunyaz, Ahunniyaz Nur, and Abdukerim Abdurahman. The report of the sentencing first appeared on Wednesday in Xinjiang Daily, an official newspaper published out of Urumqi, the capital of Xinjiang, a vast region in western China where Uighurs, the largest ethnic group there, chafe against policies set by the ethnic Han, who rule China.

headline: Production of ‘Two and Half Men’ Halted After Sheen Assails Creator

headline: Bye-Bye, Happiness; Life Is a Trap

headline: Nevada: Move to Curb Horse Population

The agency also plans to reduce numbers of animals removed from the herds, bolster tourism and create new avenues for people who want to adopt.

headline: Friday: Retro Style
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Henry Hook has a reputation as the mad genius of puzzles, and rightly so. His wit and delightfully twisted themes are applauded by beginners and veteran solvers alike. Today’s puzzle is not the most difficult Friday grid I’ve ever solved, and the majority of clues are fairly straightforward compared with other Hook puzzles, but that’s all right. Mr. Hook’s personality shines through, and even on a themeless Friday, he manages to squeeze in a groaner of a mini-theme and some brilliant cluing.

headline: Letters: Shaken
text: In the atmosphere of a possible murder inquiry (Emily Bazelon, Feb. 6), it may be almost impossible to establish the unvarnished truth. Even so, as noted in my 1971 report, “Infantile Subdural Haematoma and Its Relationship to Whiplash Injuries,” because shaking was regarded as an acceptable form of correction in the north of England (where I practiced), the police were only involved when there were other injuries. Forty years on, our standards are higher: I have watched with fascination how medical opinion has changed from denial to admission that infant abuse could and did happen there. As the lawyers say, “Cases are decided not on the truth but on the evidence.” With no fear of prosecution, my patients’ caregivers had no motive to lie. I stand by the conclusions of my 1971 paper — that there are occasions when violent shaking can cause severe or even fatal brain damage.

headline: The Smell of Money

(The leisurely scent of money, in other words.) Intended to be unisex — the ad campaign, shot by Ford, depicts a boy and girl getting down and dirty in the shower — the collection contains a moisturizer, shower gel, body oil (shown here; $70), body scrub and soap, and will be available April 1 at Bergdorf Goodman.

headline: When ‘People Power’ Won the Philippines
text: As popular revolts rapidly depose or threaten one autocrat after the next, there could scarcely be a better time for “Revolution Revisited,” an exhibition of the work of Kim Komenich. But the timing of his show is not directly related to the convulsions in the Arab world. Instead, it is intended to mark the 25th anniversary of the “people power” revolt in the Philippines that brought an end to the regime of President Ferdinand E. Marcos and swept Corazon C. Aquino into power.

headline: The Future Tense

headline: Can Owning a Business Ever Be a Passive Investment?

There is, however, one particular type of phone call that I’ve come to dread — the ones from buyers who say they are looking for a business to buy as a passive investment.

headline: Mitch Daniels Memories

It wasn’t just that he supported the Bush tax cuts; the excuses he made for that irresponsibility were stunningly fraudulent.

headline: Rapes Are Again Reported in Eastern Congo
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  More than 40 people, including men, women and children, have been raped in the past two weeks in eastern Congo in roughly the same area as a series of rapes earlier this year, United Nations officials said on Friday.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

headline: Small Is Beautiful
text: Dean Baker points us to Feyrer and Sacerdote, who use cross-state variation in stimulus spending per capita to estimate the employment effects of the stimulus. They find a clear positive effect: states that got more money per person did better on jobs. And as Baker points out, the national effects must have been larger, since some money spent in New Jersey presumably creates jobs in New York and vice versa.

headline: A 19th-Century Cake, Guest Starring Caraway
text: My wife and I were in London recently, and on our way to an excellent exhibition at the Whitechapel Gallery, we stopped for coffee and a snack at St. John Bread and Wine. Options included a seed cake, something I had only seen referenced in 19th-century novels. The St. John version was so simple and delicious that I decided to try making it at home. (The recipe can be found in the St. John’s cookbook, “Beyond Nose to Tail: More Omnivorous Recipes for the Adventurous Cook” by Fergus Henderson and Justin Piers Gellatly, or on The Guardian’s Web site.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Siri Tollerod at D&G
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Milan Fashion Week. Here, the model Siri Tollerod before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Sam McKnight. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: U.S. 4th-Quarter Growth Figure Is Lowered, Dimming Hopes for Jobs
text: Amid fears of an oil shock and a further slide in housing comes news that America’s economic recovery is weaker than previously thought.

headline: Good Inflation, Bad Inflation
text: And another economistic piece: FTAlphaville reports that some people believe that surging commodity prices might be good for Japan, because they will make deflation go away.

headline: Chinese Activists Continue Calls for Protests
text: BEIJING  Calls for China to emulate the “Jasmine Revolution” sweeping the Middle East and North Africa continue to reverberate in the country’s blogosphere, causing another popular Web site to be blocked temporarily and ensnaring the American ambassador, Jon M. Huntsman Jr.

headline: A Netscape Founder Increases His Bet on Mobile
text: While top social Web companies like Facebook and Groupon are dominating the headlines, investor Marc Andreessen is increasing his bet on mobile.

headline: Jury Nullification Advocate Is Indicted
text: Julian P. Heicklen sat silent and unresponsive as his bail hearing began one day recently in federal court in Manhattan; his eyes were closed, his head slumped forward.

headline: Saudi Student to Be Arraigned in Bomb Plot
text: LUBBOCK, Tex.  A 20-year-old Saudi student appeared in federal court here on Friday, charged with trying to make bombs to be used in attacks on American targets, while federal agents sifted through electronic correspondence, telephone records and other material to see if there was evidence of a wider conspiracy.

headline: Milan Fashion Week | Escaping La Moda
text: There are plenty of reasons to venture off Milan’s fashion week treadmill. For starters, dozens of outstanding museums dot the city, including the new Museo del Novecento (Palazzo dell’Arengario), which opened in December. The collection of mainly Italian painting and sculpture — like Pirandello and Morandi — occupies the Palazzo dell’Arengario, which was gutted to make room for a giant white spiral ramp that feeds into linear white gallery spaces. Attached is the instant hot-spot, Ristorante Giacomo all’Arengario. If you can get a table, I applaud you.

headline: Pssst! Corolla, You Have a Stalker
text: I’VE long thought that General Motors’ shaky public image could be traced to car rental lots. That’s where unsuspecting travelers and their Disney-loving children were introduced to G.M.’s weakest models: its small cars. These were the company’s crummy diet crackers, helping to keep its corporate fuel economy average below federal limits.

headline: In Film, Stuttering Symptoms Reflect Current Research
text: In the Oscar-nominated movie “The King’s Speech,” King George VI begins stuttering at 4 and struggles with it throughout his life. But he rarely talks like the stereotypical stutterer, Porky Pig, rapidly repeating letter sounds; usually the king has trouble getting sounds out from the get-go, blocked by sputtering pauses.

headline: The Lady Is a Champ: Eliza Dushku Goes a Few Rounds With Fight Night Champion
text: On television series like “Buffy” and “Dollhouse,” Eliza Dushku was perfectly comfortable holding her own against tough guys, and maybe throwing a punch or two when the situation required it. So her next role is a bit of a departure, and not only because she isn’t called upon to swing her fists. In the boxing video game Fight Night Champion, which EA Sports will release for the Xbox 360 and PlayStation3 consoles on Tuesday, Ms. Dushku plays the daughter of an unscrupulous fight promoter, and finds herself drawn into an intrigue involving her father and an up-and-coming boxer (played by the actor and athlete LaMonica Garrett). The story, which is told in movie-style sequences that unfold between the game’s playable boxing matches, is written by Will Rokos, an Academy Award-nominated writer and producer of “Monster’s Ball,” and represents the latest effort to bridge the worlds of gaming and cinema. These sequences (which were created using 3-D motion-capture technology) also allowed Ms. Dushku to play a character who was very much herself and yet as unearthly as anything seen on a Joss Whedon show.

headline: College Costs Aren’t the Main Problem
text: 3:46 p.m. | Updated to correct list of defunct companies.

headline: How to Throw Punches Without Getting Hurt
text: THE explosive and angst-ridden writhing, jerking and lunging that Steven Hoggett choreographed for the musical “American Idiot” is hardly typical of Broadway dancing, and to some theatergoers (including, apparently, the Tony voters last season) the approach was not necessarily impressive. Still, the merit of the movement there and in most shows is ultimately a matter of taste. Sometimes, though, the choreography in a show can be just plain incorrect.

headline: Air Force’s Shifting Rules Helped Boeing
text: When a European company offered a larger tanker than Boeing for a lower price in 2008, the Air Force grabbed what seemed like a bargain.

headline: 2011 Chevrolet Cruze
text: The Cruze offers a solid and composed feel, but leaves a somewhat generic impression.

headline: If You Want 40 M.P.G., You’ll Shift for Yourself
text: FOR the last few years, if you wanted a car that went more than 40 miles on a gallon of fuel, you had few choices behind hybrids and small diesels. Among purely gasoline-powered models, only the Smart Fortwo  a doorstop-size two-seater  carried a federal highway mileage rating above 40 m.p.g.

headline: Feb. 25: Updates on Libya’s Revolt and Mideast Protests
text: On Friday, The Lede is following the uprising in Libya and protests in Egypt, Yemen, Bahrain, Iraq and the West Bank. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists on the ground. A stream of Twitter messages from the region is in this blog’s right column.

headline: A Figure of Speech
text: Your film, “The Kids Are All Right,” is nominated for four Academy Awards, including Best Picture and Best Original Screenplay for you and Stuart Blumberg. So what are you going to wear?  We’re in between some really couture dress and some sexy kind of ’70s-era Bianca Jagger type tux that a designer friend of mine is making. I was complaining to the stylist whom I’m working with, and I said — God, I feel like I’m ramping up for my gay wedding, all this wondering what to wear.

headline: Living Singles
text: Long-form journalism is the only homegrown American literary form. I’m talking about the kind of journalism that, in an effort by writers to conceal how radically they’re blurring the fact-fiction line, is innocently labeled “narrative nonfiction” in journalism schools and M.F.A. programs. Narrative nonfiction typically conforms to the artfully narrow standards of American fact checking (another indigenous art) while enjoying what Dwight Macdonald once called the “atmospheric license” of fiction. Some of the most beautiful and illuminating writing in all of American English is narrative nonfiction.

headline: Nice Girls
text: My daughter Kate loves horses, her violin and, above all else, her friends. She also happens to have been born with dwarfism, a condition that makes her smaller than other kids. She will always be smaller. Kate’s fine with that. She doesn’t give it much thought, really. But I’ve become increasingly full of dread that her generation of mean girls will eventually stop accepting her for who she is, seize upon her obvious difference and just destroy her.

headline: Goodbye
text: I loved this job, especially the interaction with the readers. I admired the moral seriousness of their questions and the astuteness of their criticism — often fierce, occasionally discourteous, never sufficiently threatening to report to the police. But close. And that’s fine. Ethics is a subject about which honorable people may differ. I was less sanguine about readers who disparaged not my argument but my character or my shoes or my nose, attacks that generally concluded, “You should be ashamed.” I blame the anonymity of e-mail. And underprescribed medication.

headline: A Small Compromise in California’s Water Wars
text: Like an early spring bud poking out of a thicket, a compromise emerged on Thursday in one of the intertwined legal battles that pit California’s major agricultural and urban water users against federal scientists and environmentalists. For the moment, both sides agree on how to protect the endangered delta smelt while managing water deliveries through the West Coast’s largest and most degraded estuary, the delta where the Sacramento and San Joaquin rivers meet.

headline: Deciphering M.P.G.: The Meaning of 35.5
text: FOR all the talk of the indignities meted out by this cold, wet winter, there are few indications that anyone is actually doing something about the weather.

headline: Fact-Free Science
text: President Obama has made scientific innovation the cornerstone of his plans for “winning the future,” requesting in his recent budget proposal large financing increases for scientific research and education and, in particular, sustained attention to developing alternative energy sources and technologies. “This is our generation’s Sputnik moment,” he declared in his State of the Union address last month.

headline: One More Way to Tell A Guzzler From a Sipper
text: WHAT is the best way to measure how efficiently a car turns fuel into distance? It seems a vital question, but like food, music and the cultural importance of Jerry Lewis, the answer varies all over the world.

headline: Letter: The Ethicist
text: Randy Cohen is much too mild in his criticism of the medical students who are posting photos of patients with “comical” conditions. Besides being sadly lacking in empathy, these people are putting their medical schools at risk of federal intervention, including censure and fines, for their violation of federal regulations regarding patient privacy. Expulsion might seem harsh to some but would certainly send the message that respect for patients is the cornerstone of all medical care.

headline: Letter: Consumed
text: Enjoying collections as digital presentations without the clutter of stuff: this was the ultimate essay from Rob Walker. In light of all the recent economic upheaval, the arrangement and enjoyment of a variety of items we use everyday, virtual or not, seems like a refreshing approach. If we can have virtual friends and relationships, why not virtual possessions, all neatly stored in a small notebook computer on our desk (or lap). Ah, technology!

headline: Letters: A Separate Peace
text: My unequivocal response to Bernard Avishai’s most illuminating article is the Hebrew: halvai — may it be. According to records of negotiations conducted between the former prime minister of Israel, Ehud Olmert, and the president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, more than anyone knew or imagined was accomplished vis-à-vis the most prolonged, seemingly intractable Palestinian-Israeli conflict, and although a great deal is still left to iron out, it proves that if there is a genuine will on both sides, it can be done and, as the author maintains, now is the time.

headline: Franco and Hathaway Continue the Big Tease
text: LOS ANGELES— The Bagger was busy compiling our Oscar predictions yesterday, and amazingly, the Internet did not stop without us. Anne Hathaway and James Franco continued to dole out clips that tease at what they will be doing when they host the show – here’s Ms. Hathaway performing an awkward mash-up of “Don’t Cry for Me, Argentina” and “Rump-Shaker” and the two of them in a hazy “Grease” montage, Mr. Franco also started a Twitter back-and-forth with Cher when he posted a clip of himself (badly) singing “You Haven’t Seen the Last of Me,” her song from “Burlesque,” which he said was cut from the telecast. (If it’s true, this is a blessing.) For her part, Cher wrote that she would miss singing at the Oscars.

text: GREGORY CAPIZZI is a successful New Yorker. He lives in a luxury condominium in the financial district, has a degree in mechanical engineering from the University of Hartford and drives a Mercedes.

headline: In the Society of Dead Masons
text: WHEN late-winter temperatures break 32, the Park Avenue railroad viaduct calls to mind a weeping statue of a saint, teardrops of meltwater dripping from the battered stone along the massive walls, which extend from 98th to 111th Street. And the strange series of letters and symbols running all the way along the 1875 structure is just as otherworldly  as mysterious as messages from another planet.

headline: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Libya in Wake of Crackdown
text: WASHINGTON  The United States closed its embassy in Tripoli on Friday and imposed unilateral sanctions against Libya, including the freezing of billions in government assets, as the Obama administration made its most aggressive move against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi since his security forces opened fire on protesters.

headline: New Developments Rolling Out Fitness-Based Amenities
text: AS the city’s real estate market continues to thaw, fitness-based amenities are once again being used to draw buyers to new condominium developments. But this time around, the clang of weight machines and the whirr of treadmills are giving way to the thumps of basketballs and the grunts of climbers on indoor walls.

headline: The Almost Landless Gardener

Come spring, and well into the fall, the front gardens of the brownstones that line the street will be lush with greenery, and the window boxes will explode with flowers. But even on this beautiful strip, the low-slung red brick building just off Hicks Street stands out.

headline: Path to B.Y.U. Stardom Began in Upstate New York

But it is hard to pinpoint the moment when Brigham Young’s Jimmer Fredette transformed from basketball star to national sensation, from fan favorite to cult hero, from boy next door to phenomenon.

headline: Smaller Government Can Be a Drag (on Growth)

headline: Southern Pride, of a Kind
text: WHEN Jennifer Aziz told her father she was thinking of buying an apartment on East 29th Street near Park Avenue South, he was worried. As Ms. Aziz recalls it, his concern went beyond the standard fatherly protectiveness. As a rug dealer, he had owned a store decades ago in the commercial district south of Midtown Manhattan, which he remembered as it had been then: drably commercial, dead at night and a little seedy.

Edmonds, known for his dazzling catches that helped him win eight gold gloves, retired from baseball last week after 17 seasons. McGrath writes:

headline: Rough Boys
text: One Saturday night in the mid-’70s, I stood on the deck of a shabby duplex watching my teenage boyfriend — a character who could have walked out of the pages of Andre Dubus III’s powerful new memoir, “Townie” — beat another boy senseless in the parking lot below. Under the yellowish dusk-to-dawn lights, I could see my boyfriend’s blond sideburns, denim jacket and dingo boots, and I could see him punch the boy in the stomach until he crumpled to the ground, then kick him over and over until his nose and lips were split and bleeding. In “Townie,” which details Dubus’s 1970s coming-of-age in the poor mill towns of Massachusetts, there are none of the usual signifiers of today’s ’70s Nostalgia Industrial Complex, no peace-sign key chains or smiley-face T-shirts, none of the goofy stoners and ditsy girls in tube tops that American television viewers have become accustomed to on “That ’70s Show.” Instead, Dubus writes about “the apartments” where his older sister buys drugs, two rows of three-story buildings surrounded by packed dirt worn smooth, a Dumpster in back always filled with dirty diapers, used condoms and pizza boxes. He writes about an early manifestation of “Fight Club” culture at his school, where, whenever there is a fight, boys and girls rush to one spot “like they were being pulled there by the air itself. . . . Kids were yelling: ‘Kill him! Kill him!’ ”

headline: Up Front: Darcey Steinke
text: Darcey Steinke opens her review of “Townie,” Andre Dubus III’s memoir of street violence, remembering a beating her long-ago boyfriend delivered to another boy.

headline: New Senators’ Goals May Be Shaped by Their Styles

headline: Arts Czars
text: Solomon VOLKOV loves his czars. And in “Romanov Riches” he pays homage to them as patrons of the arts and apostles of power, sweeping the reader across 300 years of Russian history from the accession of Czar Mikhail in 1613 to the violent collapse of the imperial world in 1917. On this whirlwind tour, Volkov visits many of the major landmarks and personalities: the archpriest Avvakum Petrov, Lermontov and Gogol; Herzen, Tolstoy and “the Women’s Issue”; Tchaikovsky and homosexuality; Dostoyevsky, Mussorgsky and Lenin. Volkov’s focus is on power: every artist has his czar.

headline: Goldman’s Ruzika to Retire
text: Richard Ruzika, the influential Goldman Sachs executive who runs the firm’s special situations group, is retiring from the Wall Street bank, according to a memo sent last week to employees.

headline: Shades of White
text: Racial passing is one of America’s deeply hidden traditions, a largely unacknowledged and unstudied aspect of national life. Historically, African-Americans with identifiably dark skin have had only two choices when confronting racial discrimination and oppression: either they could try to ease their burden through accommodation, making the best of a bad situation, or they could engage in protest and active resistance. The situation was often quite different, however, for light-skinned African-Americans of mixed parentage. For them, there was a tempting third option of trying to pass as white.

headline: Defining a Family
text: Over on The New York Times’s “The Learning Network” blog, students are weighing in on the question “How Do You Define Family?,” a response to our discussion here on Motherlode about “normal” families earlier this week.

text: Pinchas Zukerman, who is considered one of the world’s greatest violinists, has definite opinions about investing. He likes to buy musical instruments and real estate.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: When Lightning Strikes
text: This may very well be the year of the Flash. The resurrected hero hits the hardcover list at No. 2 with “The Dastardly Death of the Rogues,” the first collected edition of his new ongoing series. The scarlet speedster will also be at the center of “Flashpoint,” the next event storyline from DC Comics. The hardcover edition, and the upcoming “Flashpoint” series, are both written by Geoff Johns, who pushed Green Lantern to new heights and garnered critical acclaim for “Blackest Night,” DC’s last major event.

headline: Paths of Glory
text: An indelible scene from the life of Alexander the Great finds the ­prodigious warrior-king — just 25 years old in 330 B.C. — and his conquering army on a stretch of R&R at Persepolis, one of Persia’s great capitals, now marked out for plunder. During a drunken revel characteristic of the rough Macedonian court, an Athenian woman named Thais, the mistress of one of the high officers present, made a startling suggestion. It would be a fine thing, she said, if with her own hands and with Alexander looking on, she set fire to the palace built by King Xerxes, who a century and a half earlier had reduced her home city to ashes, “that it might be recorded to posterity that the women who followed Alexander had taken a severer revenge on the Persians for the sufferings and affronts of Greece, than all the famed commanders had been able to do by sea or land.”

headline: The Wanderer
text: “I don’t believe in coming clean,” Bruce Chatwin once told Paul Theroux, who had suggested that Chatwin’s travel writing could benefit from more detail about how he got from one place to the next. During his brief literary career, readers usually sensed that Chatwin was hiding as much about himself as he displayed. Half the story appeared to reside in the white spaces between bejewelled little sections of narrative.

headline: Growing Up Fast
text: Alison Espach’s first novel opens, brightly and winningly, at a cocktail party in Fairfield, Conn., on a steamy summer evening in the early 1990s, in a garden crowded with tiger lilies. Emily Vidal’s father, Victor, an investment banker, is celebrating his 50th birthday. Most visible, among the hundreds of guests: Victor’s angry and acerbic wife, Gloria, and Victor’s mistress, Mrs. Res­nick, who lives next door with her reclusive husband. Also a birthday cake, meant to resemble Victor, that looks alarmingly like Bill Clinton.

headline: Stormy Weather
text: Like Eddie (Rochester) Anderson in “Cabin in the Sky,” the 1943 movie-musical parable of temptation, most Americans seem constitutionally predisposed to choose Lena Horne over Ethel Waters — that is, to prefer a model of classical beauty, sex appeal, excitement and youth to a symbol of matronly stolidity, virtue and middle-age languor. Anderson comes around to Waters, of course, when a team of celestial Simon Cowells repackages her to show that the old lady still has loads of talent, vigor and carnality in reserve. Nearly 70 years later, American culture has grown so absorbed with beauty and youthfulness that the film’s vindication of ability over appearance, depth and experience over novelty and thrills, seems even more wishfully fantastical than it was in 1943. Meanwhile, the movie’s top-billed star, Ethel Waters, has been nearly forgotten by all but enthusiasts of music and movie history.

headline: Suddenly Susan
text: When the author shacked up with Susan Sontag’s son, and his brainy mom, in 1976, three was not company.

headline: One Designer’s Love: Vintage Trailers
text: “LOLITA, light of my life, fire of my loins.”

headline: Becoming Ottoman
text: The promising opening chapters of Michael David Lukas’s first novel, “The Oracle of Stamboul,” have many of the appealing features of a fairy tale. A girl of unusual gifts is born in fulfillment of a prophecy, and after her mother dies giving birth, she is raised by a loving but weak-willed father and an oppressive stepmother, while a mysterious flock of birds follows her wherever she goes. But the girl, Eleonora Cohen, is also a Jew born into a specific historical context — the Ottoman Empire in the late-19th century — and on the day of her birth in 1877, her hometown, the Romanian port of Constanta on the Black Sea, is sacked by the Russian cavalry. This juxtaposition of fable and brute history tells us right from the start that we’re in the realm of magic realism, and the story’s tension, or lack thereof, between magic and realism is an indication of both the ambition and the shortcomings of this ultimately frustrating novel.

headline: These Crowded Streets
text: The very first words in “Open City,” an indelible debut novel by Teju Cole, imply an inevitability, connecting the narrator’s past with his present task, that of explaining his place in the world: “And so,” his narrator, Julius, says, “when I began to go on evening walks last fall, I found Morningside Heights an easy place from which to set out into the city.”

headline: Inky Depths
text: Portland, Ore., is wet from the start of “The Night Season.” A storm has soaked the city for weeks. Gulls line the roads, blown inland from the sea. The Willamette River surges with debris. Rain cascades from rooftops and clogs the basement drains of the Multnomah County morgue. This Portland is much like the one in Chelsea Cain’s previous novels, but darker, blurred around the edges and sunk under a cloud cover that threatens to engulf it completely.

headline: The Company He Keeps
text: Ask not what John Wells can do for your country. Seriously, don’t ask. Even if you found this former C.I.A. operative in a chatty mood, his answers might leave you feeling uneasy. He’s the sort of guy who borrows civilians’ cars with all the hesitation of a teenage shoplifter, who’ll club the skull of a useful drug dealer who’s already comfortably trussed in the back of an Econoline. When a beefy thug on a pier in Cyprus dismisses him with an ostentatious yawn, Wells quickly takes him to task, dumping him into Zygi's oily harbor. And these are just the tales he could actually tell. The ones he couldn’t — now those are scary.

headline: With or Without You
text: One of literature’s most seductive questions was asked by the Hungarian novelist Sandor Marai in “Embers,” his exquisite novel of friendship and betrayal, published in Budapest in 1942, but not translated into English until 2001, 12 years after his death. “Do you want it to be the way it used to be?” a woman asks a man. “Yes,” he responds.“Exactly the same. The way it was last time.” This exchange occurs not between lovers but between a 91-year-old servant and the 75-year-old general she nursed as a baby, in whose household she has remained. The general wants her to set up the dining room just as it looked at his life’s most critical juncture, 41 years earlier, when the closest, most sacred friendship of his youth came to an end.

headline: White Light
text: In the first pages of “The Illumination,” Kevin Brockmeier’s elegantly written new novel, a lonely character named Carol Ann Page receives a spite package from her ex-husband. The box is covered in tape, “the kind fretted with hundreds of white threads,” and as Carol Ann attempts to cut through it, she slips and nearly lops off her thumb. Hours later, she wakes from re­attachment surgery to find her sutures blazing with a bright white light.

headline: Mosh Pit Diplomacy
text: The would-be foreign policy prodigy Parag Khanna made a splash with his first book, “The Second World,” in 2008, by announcing with great fanfare — including a lengthy adaptation in The New York Times Magazine — what everyone already knew: that the international order was changing. The book was Khanna’s version of the fall of the West and the rise of the rest. Having described this grave new world, Khanna now wants to tell us how to run it. The result is another easy, breezy book that dispenses platitudes as though they were original insights and in the process fails to examine their actual significance.

headline: Untamable Tongue
text: “Does anyone at all understand anything about a story that is not their own?” asks Kadir, one of the primary characters in Jonas Hassen Khemiri’s “Montecore: The Silence of the Tiger.” It’s an apt question in any novel, but particularly so in this one, which is told in two voices, a generation and the distance (literal, social, linguistic) from Tunisia to Sweden separating them. Khemiri offers familiar if not simple emotional territory, a story about a son and his estranged father — complicated by questions of culture and language, racism and violence, metafiction and postmodernity, formal conceit and constraint.

headline: It Gets Worse
text: Susan Jacoby has long made it her project to uncover ill-formed, cynical “junk thought” and administer a cold dose of reason and logic against it. But Jacoby is no Mr. Spock. Her rationalism is delivered in an angry barrage peppered with enthusiastically snide asides. In previous books, including “The Age of American Unreason” and “Freethinkers,” her targets have been right-leaning religionists, social Darwinists, and the paucity of reason in a generation that stares too much at glowing screens and too little at learned books. In her latest jeremiad, “Never Say Die,” she fights to slay the conspiracies of ignorance and greed that she believes conceal a single, and indeed irrefutable, truth: extreme old age can be nasty, brutish and long.

headline: Behind Every King
text: Woman was never born to rule. Medieval man never doubted that simple proposition. Neither did the 15th- and 16th-century men whose deplorably low opinion of uppity women helps provide Helen Castor, an accomplished and elegant historian, with a framework for her third book.

headline: Women’s Team Gives North Dakota a New Reason to Cheer
text: GRAND FORKS, N.D.  Leveraging another team’s history as a recruiting tool instead of your own requires just the right touch. For Brian Idalski, coach of the suddenly successful North Dakota women’s hockey team, it also involves a little show and tell.

headline: Steak-Eaters
text: Name given to a group of “red-blooded” Academy Awards voters who generally favour epic movies.

headline: A Mother-in-Law With Hands-On Experience
text: ACQUIRING a mother-in-law later in life is different from acquiring one at 22.

headline: What an N.H.L. Trade Call Might Sound Like
text: Have you ever wondered what’s involved in reporting a trade to the N.H.L. head office? Many fans have heard about the “league trade calls” that must be completed before any deal is official. You may even have imagined what those calls could be like, with harried general mangers making impassioned pleas into their phones until league executives agree to give their stamp of approval.

headline: Daniels Sorts Out Trade and Injury Treatment
text: The former Celtics swingman Marquis Daniels is finding life to be a bumpy ride these days. He was traded by the Celtics to the Kings for cash and a 2017 second-round draft pick before the deadline. More pressing, Daniels needs to figure out the best way to overcome his bruised spinal cord.

headline: Protests Draw Hundreds of Thousands Across Middle East
text: Demonstrations in Libya and Iraq were met with violence, while those in Bahrain, Yemen, Jordan and Egypt were mostly peaceful.

headline: Inside the List
text: BLOOD SIMPLE: By day, Deborah Harkness is a highly regarded historian of 17th-century science and proprietor of the award-winning blog Good Wine Under $20. By night, she’s a crazed vampire compiling tasting notes on the blood of graduate students — or so her first novel, “A Discovery of Witches,” might lead you to believe. The story of an American academic who finds a magic book (and some Château d’Yquem-soaked hot paranormal romance) in the stacks of Oxford’s Bodleian Library, “Discovery” notches its second week at No. 2 on the hardcover fiction list. That’s an impressive showing for a writer whose previous book, “The Jewel House: Elizabethan London and the Scientific Revolution,” had an initial print run in the mid-four figures.

headline: Lipstick on Her Collar? Men Say, ‘O.K.’
text: THE GIST A man minds less when a woman cheats on him with another woman than with another man.

headline: The Real Housewife of Paris
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#528", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: Tahrir Square, Egypt’s Newest Tourist Draw
text: LAST October, on my final day in Cairo after a yearlong stay, I walked across the Kasr el-Nil Bridge toward Tahrir Square, stopping for a moment to take in the view. Though the Nile was, as always, a lovely sight, it was still hard to ignore the broken glass and cigarette butts beneath my feet, and the tired, worn faces of the young Egyptians standing near me.

headline: Overshadowed, an Ex-Model’s Gruesome Death
text: Every elevator should be so clean.

headline: Safety: Wound Care May Matter More Than Antibiotics
text: Preventing infection in a wound may depend less on choosing the right antibiotic than on simply keeping it clean.

headline: How to Appear in the World Series (Without Actually Playing)
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. –- I’m a baseball nerd, always have been, with a special fixation on postseason statistics. I love how a postseason series lasts only a few games, but it gets its own line in your statistical profile, forever.

headline: Haila Stoddard, Actress and Theatrical Producer, Dies at 97
text: Haila Stoddard, an actress who had a long career on the stage and on television and who as a producer brought the works of Noël Coward, James Thurber and Harold Pinter to Broadway, died Monday at her home in Weston, Conn. She was 97.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: A WIDOW’S STORY: A Memoir,  by Joyce Carol Oates (Ecco/HarperCollins, $27.99.) The prolific author has assembled a book more painfully self-revelatory that anything Oates the fiction writer or critic has ever dared to produce.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE MYTH OF THE RATIONAL MARKET: A History of Risk, Reward, and Delusion on Wall Street,  by Justin Fox (Harper Business, $16.99.) Instead of emphasizing the errors and abuses of bankers in the 2008 financial crisis, Fox, a former business and economics columnist for Time magazine, zeroes in on the academics whose efficient-market theories enabled those abuses.

headline: Troubled Spirit
text: Andrew Taylor has written almost every kind of genre fiction, from village mysteries to psychological thrillers. But his mandarin style and eccentric imagination seem best suited to the historical crime novel. “An Unpardonable Crime” was a cunning facsimile of a 19th-century Gothic melodrama. “Bleeding Heart Square” caught the swoony sensationalism of a 1930s women’s romance. Now THE ANATOMY OF GHOSTS (Hyperion, $24.99) pitches us into dynamic but rowdy 18th-century England, when superstition still held a grip on rational minds despite the advent of the Enlightenment.

headline: Bent Spines
text: A  year ago, an injury left me unable to sit. For months, I could choose only between standing and lying on my back. In the past, sick days had bought me time to read, novels anesthetizing every ill. But now, with no lap to rest a book on, books became unwieldy. Tables were too high when I lay down, too low when I stood up. Flat on the floor, I tired of propping a paperback above my head. Pacing the room, I craved an extra hand: one to hold the book, another to turn its pages, a third to underline.

headline: An App That Reminds You to Unplug
text: Introducing the last smartphone app you will ever need. Well, more like the last app you will use for at least 25 hours.

headline: Canadian Rescue Plane Leaves Tripoli Empty
text: OTTAWA  An evacuation flight chartered by the government of Canada made it into Tripoli, the Libyan capital, on Friday morning, but after its crew was unable to find any Canadians at the chaotic airport, the airplane left empty.

headline: Having a Baby: Stress Doesn’t Hamper Fertility Treatment, Researchers Conclude
text: Women taking fertility treatments can relax, researchers say: Despite the common wisdom, being worried or tense does not affect one’s chances of becoming pregnant.

headline: James Levine Cancels Another Performance
text: Dogged by a virus and his back ailment, James Levine has yet again canceled a performance. The Boston Symphony Orchestra, where Mr. Levine is music director, said he was withdrawing from Friday’s concert. Sean Newhouse, an assistant conductor, will take his place in leading Mahler’s Symphony No. 9 at Symphony Hall in Boston. Mr. Levine is also music director of the Metropolitan Opera. He has canceled three performances with the Met since Jan. 24, although his absences had not been blamed on back problems. Mr. Levine had major spine surgery in April. The Boston Symphony on Friday said he was “experiencing ill effects from a recent procedure addressing his ongoing back issues, further complicated by a viral infection.”

headline: Leora Klein and Emmanuel Werthenschlag
text: THE NOVELS of Philip Roth often focus on duality  between tradition and change, conformity and transgression, privilege and the quest to attain it.

headline: Stony Brook, With Assist From Canada, Lands on the Map for Lacrosse
text: STONY BROOK, N.Y.  As the final minute wound down last May, Kevin Crowley was part of the sea of Stony Brook red, a desperate wave pushing for the tying goal on its home turf against Virginia. A ticket to the N.C.A.A. men’s lacrosse semifinals hung on the outcome.

headline: White House Names First Openly Gay Social Secretary
text: After both a historic (see Desiree Rogers, the first African-American social secretary) and shaky start (see Ms. Rogers, whose first state dinner would best be remembered as “Salahi-gate”), the White House made history yet again when it announced Friday that Jeremy Bernard will be the new social secretary. Mr. Bernard will be the first openly gay person to hold that position.

headline: VIDEO: Christie Sits Down for Lightning Round
text: Chris Christie sat down with The Caucus Wednesday morning for an interview, and at the end we subjected him to the Lightning Round, 60 seconds of short questions with short responses.

headline: In Battle Over State Payrolls, Data Show a Mixed Picture
text: The janitors who buff floors and empty wastebaskets for the State of California earn a median wage of a little over $31,000 a year, which is 45 percent more than janitors in the private sector earn there. Georgia’s janitors, by contrast, earn less than $21,000, about 6 percent below their private sector counterparts.

headline: Carter Hancock, Claiborne Johnston
text: Caroline Carter Hancock and Francis Claiborne Johnston III were married Saturday evening at St. Paul’s Episcopal Church in Richmond, Va. The Rev. Gary Durward Jones, an Episcopal priest, officiated, with the Rev. Dr. Dennis Marion Campbell, a United Methodist minister, taking part.

headline: David Knudson and William Hohengarten
text: David Mark Knudson and William Mark Hohengarten were married Saturday evening at the Long View Gallery in Washington. Nancy Hohengarten, a judge of the County Court of Travis County, Tex., and Mr. Hohengarten’s sister-in-law, officiated. Mr. Knudson’s father, the Rev. John O. Knudson, a retired Lutheran minister, took part in the ceremony.

headline: Kristi Remington, Brian Benczkowski
text: Kristi Louise Remington and Brian Allen Benczkowski were married on Saturday afternoon at St. Patrick’s Catholic Church in Washington. Msgr. Salvatore A. Criscuolo, the church’s pastor, performed the ceremony.

headline: Jessica Cohen and Andrew Weber
text: Jessica Lynn Cohen and Andrew Jacob Weber are to be married Sunday afternoon at Stage 6 at Steiner Studios in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Rabbi Leonard A. Schoolman is to officiate.

headline: Kimberly Togman, Geoffrey Aguirre
text: Kimberly Joan Togman and Dr. Geoffrey Karl Aguirre were married Friday in a Quaker-style self-uniting ceremony at Le Bec-Fin, the Philadelphia restaurant.

headline: Heather Dominguez and Robert Rahilly
text: Heather Dominguez and Robert Gerard Rahilly were married Saturday at the Cathedral of St. Mary in Miami. Ian Taylor, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony.

headline: Eileen Hartigan, Eric Barendse
text: Eileen Frances Hartigan, a daughter of Anne Magilligan Hartigan and Maurice Henry Hartigan II of Pound Ridge, N.Y., was married Saturday to Eric Leonardus Barendse, the son of Karen E. Barendse and Jan J. Barendse of Schuyler, N.Y. The Rev. Bernard E. Gaudreau, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Snows Church in Waitsfield, Vt.

headline: Deborah Schoeneman, Joshua Groban
text: Deborah Schoeneman and Joshua Paul Groban were married Saturday evening at the Colony Palms Hotel in Palm Springs, Calif. Judge Carol Isackson, of Superior Court in San Diego and the bridegroom’s aunt, officiated.

headline: Kerry Willoughby and David Barry
text: Kerry Kelly Willoughby and David John Barry were married Saturday in Beaver Creek, Colo. Msgr. Robert J. Kinkel, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Chapel at Beaver Creek.

headline: Juliana Duffy and Gene Magee
text: Juliana Alix Duffy and Dr. Gene Aloysius Magee were married Saturday evening at the Hotel Monaco in Washington. Andrew Touchette, a friend of the couple who was ordained by World Christianship Ministries for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Cervelli’s Tutor for the Day? Yogi Berra
text: TAMPA, Fla. – The final batting practice session of the morning Friday had just ended, sending pitchers and catchers, coaches and club officials, into the dugout to get ready for the day’s light workout. Two people lingered on the grass, about halfway up the first-base line: Francisco Cervelli and Yogi Berra. Berra talked. Cervelli listened, nodding.

headline: A Tipping Point for Oil Prices
text: With speculation calming, at least for the moment, oil prices are no longer soaring higher and higher every day. But prices are at a tipping point.

headline: The (Ex) Voice of the Village
text: WAYNE BARRETT wants to say nice things about people. He wants to, but he finds it so hard.

headline: CNN Reformats ‘Parker Spitzer’ Without Kathleen Parker
text: 8:54 | Updated | CNN is reformatting “Parker Spitzer” as an ensemble program with Eliot Spitzer — and without Kathleen Parker, who has been his co-host for the last four months.

headline: Team Evil
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#657", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: The Missing Guest at Oscar’s Party
text: THE Academy Awards ceremony on Feb. 27 will be the first one in years at which the veteran publicist Ronni Chasen won’t be expertly shepherding a client down the red carpet.

headline: Geneva Auto Show: Morgan 3 Wheeler
text: GENEVA — While most attendees at the Geneva auto show, which opens here on Tuesday for the first of two press preview days, will be hoping to glimpse the future, the Morgan Motor Company will be gazing 100 years into its past.

headline: Excuse Me, but Can There Be More Civility in the Court?
text: How far does a “thank you,” “please,” “sir” or “ma’am” go?

headline: A Year at War: The Afghan Partners
text: A Year at War

headline: Reviewing the Chevy Cruze
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich evaluates the 2011 Chevrolet Cruze, a new compact car from General Motors. With the Cruze, the company is taking aim at the rival Toyota Corolla, even calling out the Toyota by name in advertising. Mr. Ulrich finds the Cruze to be a step forward for G.M., which struggled in the past to sell small cars to American buyers. He writes:

headline: To Catch a Thief (or a Murderer)
text: WHEN a convicted murderer or child predator or armed robber escapes from a maximum-security prison, two United States marshals, Charlie DuChamp (Laz Alonso) and Ray Zancanelli (Domenick Lombardozzi), try to track him down. And who better to help them catch a convict than a convict  or three?

headline: Heaven, Hell, Brothers and an Impala
text: IF you are neither 15 years old nor the sort of person for whom the term fan fiction has an ounce of resonance, then chances are that ”Supernatural” is not in your DVR queue or even in your frame of reference.
