The series, now in its sixth season on the CW network, remains an invisibly pervasive cultural phenomenon: enormously popular and yet unknown even to many of those of us who take pride in dabbling in the literature and television of young adults. “Supernatural” is one of CW’s most watched series, this year attracting an average of 700,000 more viewers each week than “Gossip Girl,” even as none of its stars feature regularly in the pages of Us Weekly.

headline: Pianists, Yes, but a Jazz Singer and Deep Metal, Too
text: BRAD MEHLDAU is a jazz pianist enamored of many kinds of music, as his recent albums make clear. “Live in Marciac,” his new album and concert film on Nonesuch (two CDs, one DVD), chronicles a recent solo piano concert, with his originals brushing up against songs by Radiohead, Nirvana and the Beatles. His previous Nonesuch album, “Highway Rider,” was a jazz-rock-classical hybrid that featured his writing for a string orchestra. Mr. Mehldau spoke with Nate Chinen a few days before performing with the Swedish mezzo-soprano Anne Sofie von Otter at Carnegie Hall, where he currently holds the Richard and Barbara Debs Composer’s Chair.

headline: Boy Meets Girl. And Angels Conspire.
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Warning Against Wars Like Iraq and Afghanistan
text: WEST POINT, N.Y.  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates bluntly told an audience of West Point cadets on Friday that it would be unwise for the United States to ever fight another war like Iraq or Afghanistan, and that the chances of carrying out a change of government in that fashion again were slim.

headline: Who’s Best for Your Car, Dealer or Independent?
text: WHEN we moved back to the United States about 11 years ago, we bought a Saturn, which I faithfully took to the nearby dealer for every service checkup. Once it was out of warranty, I gradually shifted to an independent mechanic who was more convenient and seemed cheaper.

headline: Does the Southwest Face a Mega-Drought?
text: Rising global temperatures resulting from emissions of human origin could tip the southwestern United States into a period of prolonged extreme drought seen before only in distant geological history, a new study suggests.

headline: In the Fountain of Youth, Hopes for the Derby
text: BOYNTON BEACH, Fla.  There is no doubt that the center of the current thoroughbred universe resides here in Barn 11 of the Palm Meadows training center. It is the home of Uncle Mo, the undefeated 2-year-old champion and early Kentucky Derby favorite.

headline: Lorin Stein, the Paris Review’s New Party Boy
text: “DO you mind the smell of smoke?” asked Lorin Stein, the whippet-thin editor of The Paris Review, on a recent Wednesday night in his tidy art-filled loft of an office, quite possibly one of the last workplaces in Manhattan where indoor smoking is considered acceptable.

headline: Where the Deer and the Chameleon Play
text: AFTER directing the blockbuster 2003 adventure film “Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl” and two hit sequels, “Dead Man’s Chest” and “At World’s End,” there was only one movie that Gore Verbinski wanted to make next: an animated feature about a talking chameleon who thinks he’s a western hero. Why? We’re still not entirely sure we understand, but that’s the story behind “Rango,” which stars Johnny Depp as the voice of the titular lizard, who is liberated from his terrarium and finds himself in a ramshackle frontier town, populated by desert critters (whose voices are provided by Isla Fisher, Ned Beatty, Bill Nighy and many more).

headline: The Week in Pictures, Feb. 25
text: A look back at the week’s events in New York City and the region.

headline: How I Met Your City, the Real One
text: FOR the past few years the actor Josh Radnor has been trafficking in two very different New Yorks. The one he works in more often is located in Los Angeles. That’s where Mr. Radnor films “How I Met Your Mother,” the CBS sitcom about five friends in Manhattan  or at least studio-set version of the city: clean sidewalks, perfect outfits and brownstones for everybody.

headline: Serendipity Is No Algorithm on College Dating Site
text: JEAN MEYER, a business student at Columbia University and a founder of Datemyschool.com, an online matchmaking service, believes modern ambition is the death of love.

headline: Letter to My Son’s College
text: I have been traveling this week, visiting colleges with my younger son, who is a high school junior. We’ve been through this process before at our house, and I know how tense things are in homes of seniors right now, as they wait for answers over the next few weeks that will decide where they spend the next four years.

headline: Yemeni City Feeds Unrest’s Roots
text: TAIZ, Yemen  Tens of thousands of demonstrators massed in pivotal Yemeni cities on Friday, holding their largest demonstrations against President Ali Abdullah Saleh since the wave of anti-authoritarian unrest began sweeping across North Africa and the Middle East.

headline: Of Budgets and Bargaining: Putting the Union Protests Into Context
text: On Feb. 16, thousands of protesters, including many teachers, flooded the Wisconsin Capitol building to confront Gov. Scott Walker. School was canceled because of teacher absenteeism, and many Democratic state legislators also avoided work and purposely missed a voting deadline to send a message about their sentiments.

headline: Jim Carrey as the Id Unleashed a Bit Before Its Time
text: WHEN “The Cable Guy” appeared in the summer of 1996, it seemed exactly the wrong movie for its star, Jim Carrey, and its director, Ben Stiller.

headline: Weekend Competition: Thou Shalt Not…
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to submit proposals for an eleventh commandment.

headline: Sarkozy Is Criticized on a Visit to Turkey
text: ISTANBUL  President Nicolas Sarkozy of France made a six-hour visit to Turkey on Friday, and was greeted with criticism on Europe’s so-far limited reaction to the Libyan crackdown as well as Mr. Sarkozy’s own reluctance to bring Turkey into the European Union.

headline: Troy Jackson, Street Basketball Star, Is Dead at 38
text: Troy Jackson, one of the best-known stars of street basketball  a showy style of play that gained global attention when its games were shown on ESPN  died Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 38 and lived in Dix Hills, N.Y.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: The New York Wine Expo kicks off the weekend beginning Friday at 6 p.m. at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, 655 West 34th Street (Eleventh Avenue). More than 760 wines from 190 wineries around the world will be available for tasting. A host of speakers will be on hand to give seminars, too. Friday’s grand tasting is $90; Saturday’s is $100 and  runs from 2 to 6 p.m.

headline: Changing of the Avant-Garde
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#146", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: Tracking Down and Collecting Unclaimed Life Insurance
text: THE most basic purpose of having a life insurance policy is to provide some assistance for loved ones when you die. Wealthier people sometimes use life insurance for estate planning, while most people expect the policies on which they have paid premiums for decades to help their heirs get by  or at the least cover funeral expenses.

headline: A New Credential for Home Care Aides
text: When the Direct Care Alliance first offered the test that would lead to becoming a credentialed “personal care and support professional,” Maria Frank, a 60-year-old home care aide in Nazareth, Pa., signed up.

headline: Oscar Night Preview
text: David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss The New York Times's live Oscar night coverage.

headline: Oscar Night Guide (Gold Statues Included)
text: The brave new world of two-screen Oscar watching is upon us, and it’s spreading. On the big night, visit oscars.nytimes.com/dashboard on your iPad, laptop, mobile phone or device of your choosing for wall-to-wall coverage, starting with live photos and interviews from the red carpet at 5 p.m. ET, tweets from the styles editor Stuart Emmrich (@StuartEmmrichNY), followed by live video analysis by our fashion experts, Eric Wilson and Simone Oliver.

headline: The Contribution Scam
text: David Cay Johnston has a terrific piece up about the nonsense of comparing government workers to private-sector counterparts by claiming that the government pays for more of their benefits. As he says,

headline: The Night Shift | Rinko Kikuchi
text: If you want to dress up, then prepare to strip down. The feisty actress and freshly minted New Yorker Rinko Kikuchi works the season’s new minimalism. More…

headline: What if: Standing in Line for Climate Aid
text: Lisa Friedman of Climatewire has an excellent story on The Times Web site digging in on an issue I’ve touched on periodically here — the prospect of intensifying fights over whatever money might flow someday to poor countries exposed to risks thought to be amplified by human-driven global warming.

headline: Candles in Religious Rite Ignited Fatal Fire, Officials Say
text: A fatal five-alarm fire that roared through a building in Flatbush, Brooklyn, on Saturday was ignited by candles arrayed around a bed that was intended to be part of a voodoo ceremony, Fire Department officials said on Friday.

headline: Overlooked Gems of the Trade Deadline
text: The trade deadline has passed. Two stars have changed conferences, a contender shook up its starting lineup, and 21 teams participated in the N.B.A.’s trade bonanza leading up to Thursday’s 3 p.m. cut-off. It’s a new league out there, and the flurry of roster changes have altered the present and future of numerous franchises.

headline: TimesCast | February 25, 2011
text: Clashes erupt in the Libyan capital of Tripoli; a naval base in Benghazi is under opposition control; the legislative standoff in Madison, Wis.; and why networks love live TV events like the Oscars.

headline: Arts & Leisure Preview: Glenn Ligon, Mike Watt, Gore Verbinski and More
text: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section.

headline: Yankees Shut Down Brackman With Groin Tightness
text: TAMPA, Fla. -– The right-hander Andrew Brackman, whose profile has soared after an impressive two weeks, became the first injury casualty of camp Friday when the Yankees shut him down because of discomfort in his groin. Manager Joe Girardi described the injury as “very small,” but it is still a setback for a prospect trying to work his way into the mix for a back-end rotation spot.

headline: Who’s Paid More? Experts Can Disagree
text: The question of whether state workers are overpaid has been much studied over the years and remains contentious.

headline: Photographing a Revolution
text: Scott Nelson, taking pictures for The Times of the rapidly changing events in Libya, was moved by the “rebels and protesters, who would look you in the eye, and from the bottom of their hearts, express a gratitude and respect for journalism, and its power to reflect their experience and their struggle.”

headline: The Last Red Carpet
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.

headline: Tax Breaks to Take Before They Go
text: Part of what lies at the heart of the heated debate in state capitals and Washington over the last couple of weeks is a legitimate concern about a pretty simple question: have governments made too many promises about what they should provide without collecting enough money to fulfill them all?

headline: Galleon Whistle-Blower Agrees to Testify
text: A former employee of the Galleon Group has agreed to testify on behalf of federal prosecutors as they pursue a case against the hedge fund firm’s founder, Raj Rajaratnam, according to a person familiar with the case.

headline: Making Sure Life Insurance Doesn’t Go To Waste
text: Life insurance is meant to help the ones you love when you die. Yet hundreds of millions of dollars in life insurance goes unclaimed each year for a simple reason: the beneficiaries have no idea it ever existed.

headline: In Germany, Cherundolo’s Hannover Surprises
text: By most yardsticks, Steve Cherundolo’s 32nd birthday last Saturday was pretty darn good.

headline: Lower Manhattan, 1:21 P.M.
text: Winds and heavy rains hit New York City today, and a piece of public art drew an appreciative crowd near the corner of Broadway and Liberty Street.

headline: Pakistan Demands Data on C.I.A. Contractors
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistan’s chief spy agency has demanded an accounting by the Central Intelligence Agency of all its contractors working in Pakistan, a fallout from the arrest last month of an American involved in surveillance of militant groups, a senior Pakistani intelligence official said Friday.

headline: Dusty Packards, a Graham, Dodge and Ford Among Scotty’s Castle Treasures
text: In Death Valley National Park, about 200 miles from the unrestored Bugattis at the Mullin Automotive Museum in Oxnard, Calif., sits an indigenous group of hard-bitten vehicles that holds its own special allure.

headline: Hurt in Panama? Government Covers You
text: Whether you have health insurance at home or not, if you visit Panama you’ll get free coverage for 30 days under a program that the country began last month.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Libya, Egypt, Iraq and Mexico.

headline: Let’s Assure Free Passage From Libya
text: CAIRO — I’ve been on the phone today again with people in the Tripoli area in Libya, and I had an inquiry that goes to the heart of the need for NATO, the United States and Europe to move more forcefully. Several Libyan navy ships were ordered to bombard the city of Benghazi, which has been liberated by rebels. The ships’ officers don’t want to do that and don’t like Qaddafi, and they’re also fearful that if they attack Benghazi they’ll be attacked right back by shore batteries. They would like to make a run for Malta and defect, but they fear that the Libyan air force is watching them and will bomb them if they head in that direction. And the commanding officers also aren’t entirely sure who on board is trustworthy and who isn’t. They’re in a bind.

headline: What Do All of Your Tax Breaks Add Up To?
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I take a look at all of the tax breaks that I gladly take advantage of that don’t come with income caps.

headline: Video: Troy Jackson
text: Troy "Escalade" Jackson, a street basketball player, died in his sleep on February 20, 2011.

headline: A Snowmobile Trip and a Hot Springs Dip, All in One Day
text: SHUFFLING from one bare foot to the other, I wriggled into my swimsuit, ready to plunge into the pool at a remote, off-the-grid bathhouse. Outside, steam wafted from the surface, and bathers squealed with delight as they eased into a pool fed by a 112-degree natural spring coming off the rocks of a limestone cliff. The day — with uninterrupted blue sky and abundant sunshine beaming down on us — was unseasonably warm: It was 20 degrees.

headline: Hotel Review: Aloft Harlem, in New York City
text: THE BASICS

headline: Kayaking Lake Tahoe in Winter
text: BUMPING along a freshly plowed road in Lake Tahoe, Calif., I felt oddly unburdened. No skis were locked on top of my car, no clunky boots rattled in the trunk. After more than a decade of ski trips to the region, I kept feeling as if I were missing something. Sure, it was sunny, but also a biting 17 degrees — and I was going kayaking.

headline: In Pittsburgh, Trading Pirogi for Farm-to-Table Fare
text: PITTSBURGH has long had an appetite for hearty Old World fare introduced by Eastern European immigrants: pirogi, cabbage rolls, kielbasa. Tourists still flock to Primanti Brothers, a landmark restaurant famous for its outsized meat-and-cheese sandwiches stuffed with French fries and coleslaw. Recently, however, Pittsburgh’s value-driven food and restaurant culture has been undergoing a transformation, with a new emphasis on what’s fresh and local.

headline: Luxury Camping in the Oman Desert
text: THE paved road abruptly ended just past the town of Al Mudairab, at the edge of the Empty Quarter in eastern Oman. Stepping out of my Nissan 4-by-4 at the point where a sand track began, I stared at a vista of coffee-colored dunes and flyblown Bedouin encampments that stretched toward the horizon.

headline: Restaurant Review: Burgermeester in Amsterdam
text: The walls of all three branches of this Amsterdam mini-chain are lined with portraits of cows. In the black-and-white photographs, some lie in repose with their ilk. Others stand solo. One stares directly at the camera, looking unperturbed by the flies on its face. Said Justus de Nijs, one of Burgermeester’s three owners, with characteristic Dutch candor: “Here are the cows. Have a nice burger.”

headline: The French Alps Sans Skis
text: JUST in front of me, a skier jumped from a helicopter and sped down the treacherous slope, zigzagging wildly as he dodged boulders and soared over moguls. Then, suddenly, catastrophe struck. Unable to see an approaching cliff, he shot off its edge into a free fall.

headline: Kayaking on Lake Tahoe
text: In the dead of winter, trading skis for a kayak, on Tahoe, a lake that never freezes over.

headline: Luxury Shops in Buenos Aires
text: New York has Madison Avenue, Rome has the Via Condotti and Buenos Aires has Recoleta — a shopping district that’s similarly luxurious, but much more affordable.

headline: Dunes and Silence: A Tent Resort on Oman
text: A Bedouin-style resort in the Sharqiya Sands desert, where guests can experience its tranquility and splendor.

headline: French Alps
text: You don’t need a lift ticket to soak up the food, history, night life and general fabulousness of the French Alps during ski season for nonskiers.

headline: Oscar Picks, Courtesy of Wendy Williams
text: LOS ANGELES— How you doin’? As part of our continuing celebrity Oscar ballot coverage, the Bagger spoke with Wendy Williams, the outspoken radio star-turned-TV talk show host. In addition to “The Wendy Williams Show,” which is broadcast every weekday, Ms. Williams will next host the game show “Love Triangle,” in which she will help real-life daters sort out their romantic entanglements. It will have its premiere in April on GSN, the game show network.

headline: Buzz Tracker
text: Retail C.D.S.? The Chicago Board of Options Exchange will soon begin trading credit event binary options. “In essence these will be like credit default swaps, accessible to everyone, which will have a $1,000 payoff per contract in the event of a bankruptcy before contract expiration…..What this will do is to revolutionize the shorting aspect of trading, as there will be no borrowing need to express a bearish outlook on a company, and no possibility for State Street, BoNY or your favorite repo desk to pull your borrow from underneath your feet thus forcing a short squeeze. In essence, this will be a marginable equity product trading as a credit derivative.” Zero Hedge

headline: Now Online | T Women’s Fashion Spring 2011
text: The Spring Fashion issue highlights the season’s most notable, wearable and desirable trends — from pajamas to wear all day (“Early Birds,” photographed by Collier Schorr) to a new sensually minimal take on evening (“The Night Shift,” shot by Terry Richardson). The women who appear throughout the issue, on the other hand, defy such easy categorization. Take our cover star, Salma Hayek — she is an actress, a mother and an undeniable firebrand. Then there is Alexa Chung: It-girl, designer, TV personality and, as Jacob Brown discovered, former captain of Team Evil. Add to that list the actress Rinko Kikuchi, the artist Rachel Feinstein, and the musicians Lykke Li and Shilpa Ray. Last but definitely not least, the issue celebrates the “Tough Cookies” of Congress: Barbara Lee, Barbara Boxer and Nancy Pelosi, women whose no-nonsense brand of politics makes us all look good. See all stories from this issue >>

headline: Libyan City of Benghazi Firmly Under Opposition Control
text: Tens of thousands of people gathered in Benghazi for Friday Prayer outside of the courthouse where protests that set off the rebellion began more than a week ago.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Libya, Egypt, Iraq and Mexico.

headline: Baseball Gave $25 Million Lifeline to Mets
text: Major League Baseball provided $25 million to the owners of the Mets as they struggled to deal with a cash shortfall last fall and a looming lawsuit seeking hundreds of millions of dollars for victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s vast Ponzi scheme, according to two people briefed on the arrangement.

headline: Internet Fraud Declined in 2010
text: Were criminals hurt by the recession, too?

headline: New-World Tale Steeped in Old-World Tradition
text: Precisely why Gian Carlo Menotti’s operas have vanished so thoroughly from American stages during recent decades is a bit of a mystery. That this once-popular Italian-American composer rejected progressive trends in favor of time-tested formulas proved by Puccini, Mascagni and other Italians at the start of the 20th century seems to work against him now.

headline: Child’s Remains Reveal Ice Age Burial Practices
text: Archaeologists have discovered the remains of a child cremated in central Alaska about 11,500 years ago. They are the earliest known human remains from the North American Subarctic and Arctic region.

headline: Nonfiction Mainstays
text: Weekly rank of the four hardcover nonfiction titles that have been in the top 35 spots the most often over the past year.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 25
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a bridal sale, a tunnel under the Gowanus Canal and a school for disabled children.

headline: Dior Suspends Top Designer After Report of Altercation
text: PARIS  The fashion house Christian Dior said on Friday that it had suspended its design director, John Galliano, after he was accused of making an anti-Semitic slur during a drunken tussle at a Paris bar.

headline: Off the Field, a Woman Tames Brazil’s Soccer Fans
text: RIO DE JANEIRO

headline: Medtronic Bypasses a Hospital Group Buyer
text: Medtronic could save more than $40 million a year through its decision to cancel five group-purchasing contracts worth $2 billion and to negotiate prices directly with hospitals instead, Bernstein Research said in an investor note on Friday.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Versace
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#396", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

headline: Protesters in Bahrain Demand More Changes
text: MANAMA, Bahrain  In by far the largest protest yet here, tens of thousands of demonstrators packed the city’s streets on Friday and closed a stretch of highway as they demanded that their king dissolve the government and agree to a transition to a true constitutional monarchy.

headline: The Mayor Steals the Show at Oscar-Week Party
text: LOS ANGELES— After arriving here late Wednesday night, the Bagger made it out to a few of the vaunted Oscar week parties on Thursday night. In local parlance the events are known as ‘a thing’ – as in, are you going to the Tom Ford thing? The Ed Ruscha thing? The IFC thing? The Soho House thing(s)? And as with any party circuit, a majority of the evening’s conversations revolve around which thing you’re going to after the thing that you’re at, because clearly, there’s always got to be a better thing.

headline: Libya's Defectors
text: In Benghazi, a small naval base is now controlled by the opposition.

headline: Better Card Placement Thanks to the Bidding
text: The dreadful earthquake in Christchurch, New Zealand, earlier this week nearly had a ghastly effect on bridge. The president of the World Bridge Federation, Gianarrigo Rona, and his wife, Cippi, were in the city visiting a longtime member of the W.B.F. Executive Committee, John Wignall, and his wife, Adele.

headline: Newborn Mice’s Hearts Can Heal Themselves
text: An adult zebra fish can regenerate a damaged heart with no scar formation. This remarkable phenomenon has been seen in other fish and amphibians as well, but never before in a mammal.

headline: Oscar's Appeal for Networks
text: A.O. Scott and David Carr discuss why in the internet age, networks love live TV events like this Sunday's Oscars.

headline: In Dispute Against Starbucks, Court Dismisses Kraft’s Claim
text: Kraft Foods lost on Friday an appeals court ruling that upholds a decision allowing the Starbucks Corporation to end a deal under which Kraft distributes Starbucks coffee to grocery stores.

headline: Versace: New Baroque
text: Donatella Versace was back in the family palazzo tonight, on a baroque carpeted runway, with members of Duran Duran in the front row, but the collection didn’t vibrate with that extra feeling. Still, this was a solid showing of sharp tailoring, with belted coats streaked with gold buttons, and imaginative use of the baroque motifs that her brother Gianni loved to extravagance. Ms. Versace wisely turned the detail into abstract swirls set into coats and mini sheaths, sometimes interpreted with a coiling bit of colored python on a knee-length black or white sheath.

headline: ‘King’s Speech’ Producers Await Seats at Table
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  The fancier people at the Chateau Marmont on Thursday evening were lined up outside, having their photos snapped at the entrance to a pre-Oscar affair sponsored by Vanity Fair and Fox Searchlight Pictures.

headline: Software To Make Photos Artfully Worse
text: If your photos don’t look as crummy as you’d like, there is new software that will wreck them for you.

headline: Why Networks Love the Oscars
text: A.O. Scott and David Carr discuss why networks love live TV events like this Sunday’s Oscars.

headline: Chic in Review | Kate vs. Kate
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: On the Ground in Libya
text: Scott Nelson and Ed Ou photographers on assignment for The New York Times, crossed into Libya from Egypt on Tuesday, with a Times reporter, Kareem Fahim. Along with the staff photographer Tyler Hicks they have been reporting from eastern Libya. On Friday morning, James Estrin interviewed Mr. Nelson by e-mail.

headline: At Danspace, Physicality Gets a New Dimension
text: When Yvonne Meier greets the audience with a seemingly innocent line  “Welcome to ‘Body Madness’ ”  it doesn’t hurt to take her seriously. What happened to me probably won’t happen to you, but it’s best to be on your guard.

headline: ‘Idol’ Tops Ratings Again
text: “American Idol” filled out the rest of its slate of 24 semifinalists on Thursday as the latest two-hour installment of the singing competition topped the ratings with 21.6 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates, up nearly 20 percent versus the comparable night a year ago. Fox easily led the night ahead of its network competitors, while CBS placed second, aided by solid results for “CSI” at 9 (12.5 million) and “The Mentalist” at 10 (14.7 million). At 8 and 8:30, CBS broadcast “The Big Bang Theory” (12.5 million) and “Rules of Engagement” (9.6 million). In third place, ABC posted modest ratings for “Wipeout” (7.1 million), “Grey’s Anatomy” (9.1 million) and “Private Practice” (6.7 million). NBC was fourth with low ratings for its comedy line-up, earning its most viewers at 9 for “The Office” (6.2 million).

headline: Republicans Propose Budget Stopgap, Reducing Risk of a Federal Shutdown
text: WASHINGTON  The prospect of an imminent federal government shutdown diminished Friday as House Republicans proposed a carefully calibrated stopgap measure that Democrats said could be acceptable.

headline: Oscar Party Recipes
text: Finger food sweet and savory and cocktails for a festive night.

headline: ‘The Night Season’
text: Chapter One

headline: From Sleeping Bag to Starbucks
text: The comedian Mike Birbiglia, 32, who transformed his self-destructive sleep disorder into “Sleepwalk With Me,” a one-man Off Broadway show, in 2008, is returning to the stage next month in “My Girlfriend’s Boyfriend” at the Barrow Street Theater. Mr. Birbiglia lives on the Upper West Side with his wife, Jen Stein, a writer, and their elderly cat, Ivan. He is a late riser on Sundays. —ROBIN FINN

headline: Sunday Routine | Mike Birbiglia
text: Mike Birbiglia, a comedian and sleepwalker, is the author of a book and one-man show about the disorder.

headline: ‘Never Say Die’
text: Preface

headline: Bloody Attempts to Escape From Fate
text: When an Asian serial-killer movie is deemed to be so violent that it severely damages human dignity  and is effectively banned from public exhibition until cuts are made  large segments of the international cinéblogosphere get very excited.

headline: With Island Spice, and Years of Seasoning, Old is New Again
text: The Jolly Boys returned to New York City for their first public show here in decades like a Model T with a new CD player in the dashboard. At Hiro Ballroom on Thursday night, they had material few people would expect from a band that was started in the 1950s to play a style that was already decades old. The Jolly Boys have been entertaining people in Port Antonio, Jamaica, since then, often as a hotel’s house band, with a shifting lineup; Albert Minott, 72, recently stepped forward as lead singer.

headline: A Qaddafi Son, Italian Soccer and the Power of Money
text: Over the years, one of the charges against the murderous regime of Colonel Muammar el-Qaddafi was that state funds were being used to further the footballing career of his third-oldest son, Al Saadi. He was once thought to run the Libyan Football Federation. It is hard to know if Libyan football will survive revolution and civil war, but it is worth telling the story, again, of Saadi’s surreal, so-called career in Italian football.

headline: Abstract Expressionism in Aural Mixed Media
text: In 1971, the Rothko Chapel, a meditation space and museum supported by the art patrons and philanthropists Dominique and John de Menil, opened in Houston. Missing from the ceremony was Mark Rothko, the artist who had painted a series of 14 large canvases for the chapel. The year before the opening, Rothko, who had been experiencing severe depression, took his own life.

headline: ‘Open City’
text: ONE

headline: In the End, It’s All About the Party
text: Music and dance come so close together in the great flamenco performances that some of the happiest moments occur in the finales, when musicians sometimes dance too. Although this is done for the public, that’s not how it feels. The atmosphere suggests an offstage celebration, with dancers and musicians encouraging and teasing one another in the greatest high spirits. We in the audience feel we’ve been allowed to witness family fun and games.

headline: App Smart Extra: More Weather Apps
text: As I pointed out in a recent App Smart column, all-purpose weather apps fall far short when it comes to offering weather alerts. But thankfully the march of mobile software only moves forward – at least for iPhone and Android users.

headline: Recreating a Bill of the Obscure and the Familiar
text: The Dutch violinist Janine Jansen is making efficient use of her stay in New York. Mainly, she is in town as a guest of the New York Philharmonic, with which she played Britten’s Violin Concerto at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening. She is also giving a recital at Le Poisson Rouge on Monday, between her last two Philharmonic appearances.

headline: Scorecard | Fendi Wins!
text: Tangerine. Azure blue. Cravats of striped fox and fitch. Nope, Scorecard isn’t talking about Chiquita Prada. In his 46th year collaborating with the fur and leather goods house of Fendi, Kaiser Karl went and got all Dadaist and conceptual. Sorry, Miuccia, critics didn’t all feel your game of dress-up in mamma’s closet was the most bananas showing in town.

headline: Oscars Watchdog Monitors Foul Play in Stores, Online and on Red Carpet
text: It was as ominous a moment as any in the history of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. A federal judge had ruled that its gold Oscar statuette was not protected by copyright.

headline: The New Police Siren: You’ll Feel It Coming
text: Joe Bader tried setting the two tones of his invention four notes apart on the musical scale, but the result sounded like music, not a siren. Same thing when he played around with a five-note interval. But when he set the two tones apart by two octaves and gave the siren a test run outside the Florida Highway Patrol headquarters in Tallahassee, the effect was so attention-grabbing that people came streaming out of the building to see what the strange sound, with its unfamiliar vibrations, could possibly be.

headline: Wages by State
text: How state workers’ salaries compare to those in the private sector in all 50 states.

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City
text: HASH FIFTY FIVE, a snazzy new hookah lounge upstairs from the new restaurant Fifty Five, has a “Midnight at the Oasis” theme, with lots of mirrors, black drapery, glam art and low sofas of white leather.

headline: Adventures in an Urban Wilderness
text: BEN RYDER HOWE says he was raised to avoid using the personal pronoun “I” when writing. Moreover, he rarely wrote about New York. Fortunately for readers, he overcame both disinclinations in his first book, “My Korean Deli: Risking It All for a Convenience Store” (Henry Holt, $25). It’s a charming, present-tense, only-in-New York chronicle of the agonies and ecstasies of immigrant entrepreneurship (and of being in business with your mother-in-law, whom Mr. Howe describes as “the Mike Tyson of Korean grandmothers”).

headline: Map of the Rebellion in Libya, Day by Day
text: Interactive map of the rebellion in Libya, day by day. (Note: This map is no longer being updated daily.)

headline: On a Mission, but Not From God
text: There are those who insist that no great work of cinematic art will ever be presented in 3-D. The most persuasive among them — Roger Ebert, for example — offer learned arguments grounded in science and aesthetics. None of that really has anything to do with “Drive Angry,” which at least in its 3-D version makes a loud, incoherent but oddly compelling case for the enhancing effects of stereoscopic projection on certain treasured objects of the cinematic gaze, like classic Detroit muscle cars, women’s breasts and Nicolas Cage.

headline: Milan Shows How It All Makes Sense
text: MILAN

headline: Bridging Cultures Onstage
text: WHEN Eva Bornstein became executive director of the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts in 2005, its headliners had included Zubin Mehta and the New York Philharmonic, Marcel Marceau and Victor Borge. But as their appeal dwindled in a changing Bronx neighborhood, so did audiences. To bolster the theater’s fortunes, Ms. Bornstein, a Polish émigré, set out to explore the area  as she had done in Toronto, Pennsylvania and New Jersey when she ran theaters there.

headline: Iran Reports a Major Setback at a Nuclear Power Plant
text: Iran told atomic inspectors this week that it had run into a serious problem at a newly completed nuclear reactor that was supposed to start feeding electricity into the national grid this month, raising questions about whether the trouble was sabotage, a startup problem, or possibly the beginning of the project’s end.

headline: Who’s Afraid of the Brothers Koch?
text: Two brothers steeped in wealth and power, visionaries to some, yet widely feared by others as overseers of a vast conspiracy, steeped in paranoia, that threatens to change the very fabric of society. I speak, of course, of Reggie and Ronnie Kray, the odd, mod gangster siblings of Swinging London. Who did you think I meant? Dinsdale and Doug Piranha?

headline: When Berra Speaks, a Yankees Catcher Listens
text: The Yankees’ final batting practice session of the morning Friday had just ended, sending pitchers and catchers, coaches and club officials into the dugout to get ready for the day’s light workout in Tampa, Fla. Two people lingered on the grass, about halfway up the first-base line: catcher Francisco Cervelli and Yogi Berra. Berra talked. Cervelli listened, nodding.

headline: Bush Cancels Speech Because of Assange Appearance
text: President George W. Bush canceled a speaking engagement Friday because the group that invited him, the Young Presidents Organization, also asked Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, to take the conference stage.

headline: Jeffrey Tambor Withdraws from ‘La Cage aux Folles’
text: Is there a title to one of Jeffrey Tambor‘s previous projects that might apply here? On Friday night, the producers of the Broadway revival of “La Cage aux Folles” said that Mr. Tambor, a star of the television comedies “Arrested Development” and “The Larry Sanders Show,” had withdrawn from the production following Thursday’s performance and after having started in the musical just over a week ago.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: Comedy

headline: Reads and Reactions
text: This is the inaugural edition of a new feature we’ll be running to highlight reactions from around the web (positive, negative, indifferent and otherwise) to posts here at FiveThirtyEight. We’ll also pick out some articles that take quantitative, data-rich approaches to subjects that we care about. If you spot either of these things out there in the online ether, pass the link along. These roundups will run bi-weekly on Fridays or Saturdays.

headline: A Filmmaker Returns to a ‘Lucky’ Theater
text: WHEN the filmmaker Jeff Lipsky grew up in Plainview, N.Y., “there were literally eight movie theaters in spitting distance of my house,” he said recently. “Now there are none.”

headline: Afghan Officials Say Jailed Christian Convert Is Free
text: Under international pressure, government officials in Kabul say they have freed an Afghan man who had been jailed since May and faced the prospect of the death penalty for converting from Islam to Christianity.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to the Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Voodoo Candles Ignited Deadly Fire, Officials Say
text: A fatal five-alarm fire that roared through a building in Flatbush, Brooklyn, last Saturday was ignited by candles arrayed around a bed for a voodoo ceremony, Fire Department officials said Friday.

headline: 3 Banks Warn of Big Penalties in Mortgage Inquiries
text: Several big banks warned investors on Friday that they could face sizable financial penalties as a result of state and federal investigations into abusive mortgage practices.

headline: A Star Turn for Stuttering, On-Screen and in Research
text: In the Oscar-nominated movie “The King’s Speech,” King George VI begins stuttering at age 4 and struggles with it throughout his life. But he rarely talks like the stereotypical stutterer, Porky Pig, rapidly repeating letter sounds; usually the king has trouble getting sounds out from the get-go, blocked by sputtering pauses.

headline: Centennial Celebration for a Special Collection
text: KATHERINE ANNE PAUL, curator of the Newark Museum’s Arts of Asia collection, says that when she travels the world researching Tibetan art, “I see more about the Newark Museum than any other institution.”

headline: Frederick Douglass’s Irish Liberty
text: Frederick Douglass drew on many influences during his life as an orator, journalist and anti-slavery activist. Few, however, are more unlikely than the man he met in 1845, during a two-year lecture tour of Ireland, Scotland and England: Daniel O’Connell.

headline: Graying Audience Returns to Movies
text: LOS ANGELES  Hollywood and older Americans have never had much use for each other. The 50-plus crowd doesn’t go to opening weekends or buy popcorn; a youth-obsessed Hollywood has happily ignored them.

headline: A Heap of Crosses for a Nun to Bear
text: From the beginning of Amy Hartman’s “Mercy and the Firefly,” the playwright goes for shock value. A 15-year-old girl in a parochial-school uniform turns her prayer into a rap number, and when she asks God, “You’ve got to kill?/Is this your will?” she throws in a familiar  but in this context, still jolting  obscenity.

headline: Kayte Walsh, Kelsey Grammer
text: Kayte Walsh and Kelsey Grammer were married Friday on the stage of the Longacre Theater on Broadway, where Mr. Grammer until recently was one of the stars of “La Cage aux Folles.” Terry Lavell, who plays Mercedes in the show, officiated.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Killings Jolt a Family in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY  When Josefina Reyes Salazar was murdered in the border state of Chihuahua last year, not long after she accused the military of playing a role in the killing of her son, protests brought attention to the family’s plight.

headline: Two Directions for the Prices of Natural Gas and Oil
text: CRUDE oil prices have risen this year, and this week they briefly touched $100 a barrel for the first time since 2008.

headline: Egyptian Military Cracks Down on New Protest
text: CAIRO  Tens of thousands of protesters returned Friday to Tahrir Square, the site of demonstrations that led to the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak two weeks ago, to keep up the pressure on Egypt’s military-led transitional government.

headline: Abuse Suspects, Your Calls Are Taped. Speak Up.
text: The men charged with beating, stabbing or burning their wives or girlfriends have plenty to say. Lately, their words have been used against them in New York courts as never before.

headline: Deadline for N.F.L. Talks Could Be Extended
text: INDIANAPOLIS  The leader of the N.F.L. players union told agents Friday that no progress had been made on any of the big issues at the center of the game’s labor dispute. The bleak outlook throws into question whether a new collective bargaining agreement can be reached without a work stoppage  the league’s first in more than two decades  that could threaten at least the start of the 2011 season.

headline: Niger: 3 Hostages From French Mine Are Released
text: Al Qaeda’s North African affiliate has released three hostages abducted in September from a French-run mine in Niger, the French presidency said Friday. Niger authorities brought the three to Niamey, the capital, on Thursday, a security official said. The hostages, a Frenchwoman and men from Madagascar and Togo, and four Frenchmen were abducted from a uranium mine operated by the French nuclear giant Areva. It was not reported whether a ransom had been paid to Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, which claimed responsibility for the kidnappings. The other four hostages remain in captivity.

headline: Mubarak, Terrorism and Their Tie
text: The blind sheik in charge of blowing up New York City had invited reporters to interview him one evening in 1993, so 57 of us stood in his bare living room. The floor shuddered every time another person or camera crew squeezed in. Then, for more than half an hour, the sheik, Omar Abdel Rahman, spoke at a dead sprint, in Arabic. The translators panted. From the sound of things, they apparently were able to render only about one phrase in English for every three he spoke in Arabic.

headline: Biggest Fish Face Little Risk of Being Caught
text: So much for Angelo Mozilo taking the fall for the financial crisis.

headline: How Do You Open for a Mind-Reading Horse?
text: Do you, or someone else out there, have any idea what became of Ed Steib?

headline: A Neighborhood’s Steeples Are Set to Disappear Quietly
text: Frederick Irving William Lundy was many things to Sheepshead Bay.

headline: U.S. Gathered Personal Data on Times Reporter in Case Against Ex-C.I.A. Agent
text: WASHINGTON  Federal law enforcement officials, trying to uncover the sources of a New York Times reporter, James Risen, obtained extensive records about his phone calls, finances and travel history, according to a court brief filed late Thursday.

headline: Thousands Rally for Reform in Jordan
text: AMMAN, Jordan  Thousands of people demonstrated peacefully for political reform in Amman, the capital, and in other Jordanian towns on Friday, with opposition forces drawing the largest crowds since the weekly Friday protests began eight weeks ago. The opposition also expanded its demands.

headline: The Man at the Center of a Dispute at the Dakota
text: It was not that long ago that Alphonse Fletcher Jr.’s fifth-floor apartment at the Dakota on the Upper West Side was a salon for wealthy and famous guests who traded ideas and chatter at his popular parties. Mr. Fletcher, an accomplished financier, opened his home to fellow Harvard alumni for fund-raising events, and to fellow black notables like Anna Deavere Smith and Anita Hill, two of more than three dozen people who have been given the honor of being Fletcher Fellows, each one receiving a $50,000 stipend from him.

headline: The Return of the Conquering, Gnarly Heroes
text: Scottsdale, Ariz.

headline: Bank of America Settles Countrywide Financial Case
text: Countrywide Financial’s multibillion-dollar tab for Bank of America just got even steeper.

headline: David T. Kearns, Champion of Education Reform, Dies at 80
text: David T. Kearns, a former chief executive at the Xerox Corporation and a champion of education reform who served as deputy secretary of education under the first President George Bush, died Friday at a hospice near his winter home in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 80.

headline: Pediatrician in Abuse Case Killed Himself
text: Dr. Melvin D. Levine, a nationally known pediatrician who was found dead last week, died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound, a medical examiner said on Friday.

headline: Seeking to Weed Out Drivel, Google Adjusts Search Engine
text: In a tacit admission that Web publishers are flooding its search engine with low-quality pages, Google has revised its methods to improve the usefulness of its results.

headline: Mayor Tries to Reassure Providence Teachers as Furor Grows Over Firing Notices
text: BOSTON  A day after the school board in Providence, R.I., voted to send termination notices to all of the city’s 1,926 teachers, Mayor Angel Taveras sought to calm the uproar by saying that an “overwhelming majority” would not, in fact, lose their jobs.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Amid Cuomo’s Medicaid Cuts, Health Care Workers’ Union Shapes a Victory
text: In Wisconsin, public workers face a nearly unprecedented rollback of collective-bargaining rights. In New Jersey, teachers and their unions find themselves the target of open ridicule from Gov. Chris Christie, who is seeking major increases in how much the state’s public employees pay for their pensions and health care. And in Connecticut, state workers are being pressured to accept a wage freeze, more furlough days and a higher retirement age.

headline: Match Play Could Be Battle of Snow and Long Ball
text: MARANA, Ariz.  There is no arguing that the W.G.C.-Accenture Match Play Championship lost some of its youth and appeal on Friday when the 17-year-old Italian Matteo Manassero and the stylish 22-year-old Rickie Fowler were eliminated.

headline: The World’s Wonders, in an Ecologist’s Eyes
text: Amagansett, N.Y.

headline: A Network of Support
text: In my column this week I examined the work of an organization called Youth Villages, which offers intensive in-home services to help children in the foster care system return to their families, or extended families, wherever it is possible to do so safely. My point was to highlight the fact that this approach, which is vastly underutilized and underfunded, is proving to be superior to the current practices in the child welfare system. It’s now common for youth to remain in foster care or residential treatment for years. When they age out of these systems, many are unable to live successfully as adults.

headline: Election Defeat Predicted for Ireland’s Ruling Party
text: DUBLIN  If there were people walking around during the national election on Friday who were passionate supporters of the ruling party, Fianna Fail, they were doing an excellent job of keeping it secret.

headline: Sheen Tantrum Likely to Cost in the Millions
text: Charlie Sheen’s latest antics may leave CBS and Warner Brothers with a quarter-billion-dollar headache.

headline: Jupiter’s El Sol
text: The seaside town of Jupiter, Fla., has lots of immigrant day laborers, which makes it scarcely different from hundreds of towns across the country. Men started showing up on street corners there a few years ago, taking manual jobs in construction, landscaping and carpentry. It was — in the boom years, anyway — a good match of labor demand and supply.

headline: Absorbing the Pain
text: Philadelphia

headline: Presidential Primary Book Club
text: One of a journalist’s most important duties is to seek out information in places the readers wouldn’t go themselves, like following troops into combat or covering charter revision commission hearings. In that spirit, I have been reading all the books written by likely candidates for the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Preserving Wilderness
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mideast Reform?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Helping the Casualties of the Economy
text: To the Editor:

headline: 3 to 2 for Health Care Reform
text: Enormous attention has been focused on rulings by two federal district judges who found the new health care reform law unconstitutional. Less attention has been paid to rulings by three judges who upheld the law’s constitutionality.

headline: Delivering Moral Support in a Steady Stream of Pizzas
text: MADISON, Wis.  Someday the ruckus here might be remembered as the Pizza-Powered People’s Uprising.

headline: An Alchemy of Color and Craft
text: We all know that any given painting or sculpture can tell many stories. But so can groupings in a museum show. And at “The Chemistry of Color: The Sorgenti Collection of Contemporary African-American Art,” the story possibilities abound.

headline: The War on Women
text: Republicans in the House of Representatives are mounting an assault on women’s health and freedom that would deny millions of women access to affordable contraception and life-saving cancer screenings and cut nutritional support for millions of newborn babies in struggling families. And this is just the beginning.

headline: Look at the Science
text: Every winter, some of Yellowstone National Park’s more than 3,000 bison wander out of the park seeking better grazing. When they do, they are either shot, hazed back into the park or corralled for possible slaughter, all in accordance with a plan developed by the Interior and Agriculture Departments and the State of Montana. It is time to change that plan, which was based on bad science and has now been rendered obsolete by new regulations from the U.S.D.A.

headline: Paying for Old Age
text: LIFE expectancy at birth for Americans is about 78. But many Americans will die well before then, while others, like Eunice Sanborn, who died in Texas last month, will live to be 114.

headline: Illegal Immigrants
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Indiana’s 3-Year-Old Agitator
text: INDIANAPOLIS  The littlest protester cannot count past 10 and gets his alphabet mixed up. But in the midst of civic strife, Sheadon O’Day, a 3-year-old agitator, has mastered one thing that really matters inside the Statehouse here: screaming “Save Daddy’s job!” With that and his blond hair and blue eyes, one could say that he stole the show, even from the large men in hard hats yelling into their megaphones.

headline: Lorillard and Reynolds Sue F.D.A.
text: Two major tobacco companies filed a lawsuit against the Food and Drug Administration on Friday, contending that three members of an advisory committee had conflicts of interest that would taint any recommendations by the panel to the agency.

headline: Wisconsin Assembly Passes Anti-Union Bill as Senate Democrats Stay Away
text: MADISON, Wis.  Over shouts of protest from Democrats, the Republican-controlled Wisconsin State Assembly passed a bill in the early morning hours Friday that would strip state employees of most of their collective bargaining rights. But there was no sign that a stalemate over the proposal would end, as Democrats in the Senate remained out of the state after fleeing to prevent their own vote on the proposal.

headline: Gay Male Secretary for the White House
text: WASHINGTON  The White House made history Friday by announcing the appointment of Jeremy Bernard as the first male, and openly gay, social secretary.

headline: Seeking Lynching Stories as Accounts of Faith
text: DALLAS  With a broken bone in one foot and gout in the other, Shirley Johnson limped across her living room toward the front door. The visitor waiting there one recent afternoon, the Rev. Angela D. Sims, hoped that at age 74, Mrs. Johnson’s memory was in sturdier shape.

headline: On the Street | The Business Look
text: The men’s wear being worn in New York is sending early signals that the era of dressing down is over.

headline: Bloggingheads: 'Social Network' Divide
text: David Edelstein, left, of New York Magazine and film director Alex Gibney debate the meaning of "The Social Network."

headline: Christian Lambertsen, Inventor of Scuba Precursor, Dies at 93
text: When American commandos slipped into the sea off the coast of Burma in the last months of World War II and swam underwater to attach explosives to Japanese vessels, Capt. Christian J. Lambertsen often led them. After all, he had trained them to dive and had invented the breathing device that allowed them to stay below the waves.

headline: Canada: Conservatives Charged With Finance Violations
text: Two Conservative members of the Senate, including Prime Minister Stephen Harper’s former campaign manager, and two former Conservative party officials were charged with several violations of campaign finance laws, Elections Canada announced Friday. The agency said the Conservatives exceeded campaign spending limits by $1.3 million in the 2006 election. According to the agency, the party improperly channeled spending for national campaign advertising through the budgets of local candidates. Fred DeLorey, a spokesman for the party, said it followed all financing rules. “We did nothing wrong,” he said.

headline: Disney Calling? A Band Takes Off
text: FAIRFIELD, Conn.

headline: An Interview With Gabrielecorto Moltedo
text: The designer expands his seven-year-old Corto Moltedo brand with a new standalone store in Milan, an e-commerce Web site and a new line of bags.

headline: Saturday: Opening for Firing
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — At one time, Bob Peoples was a fairly prolific end-of-week constructor, yet we haven’t seen a puzzle with his byline since 2007 (Across Lite, Solution).

headline: Herbs Sit Down to Tea
text: Some of New York City’s best chefs, including Jean-Georges Vongerichten, Gray Kunz and Lidia Bastianich, have long depended on Honey Locust Farm House in Newburgh for its organic herbs.

headline: Where Portions Are Big and Protein Abounds
text: MAKE no mistake: a meal at Benjamin Steakhouse requires muscular eating. Portions are large; protein abounds. And prices can give pause. Nonetheless, if a visit to Benjamin on a recent weekday evening is any indication, the appeal of the New York-style steakhouse persists — the handsome dining room was filled, mostly with suits hatching deals and, we assume, charging expense accounts.

headline: Reyes, Healthy Again, Reclaims Crown as the Fastest Met
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  For the first time in two years, Jose Reyes has his winged shoes, and with no restrictions or limitations, he is showing his burning speed once again.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Abandoned Babies
text: Republicans need to figure out where they stand on children’s welfare. They can’t be “pro-life” when the “child” is in the womb but indifferent when it’s in the world. Allow me to illustrate just how schizophrenic their position has become through the prism of premature babies.

headline: Life and Death in the North of Mexico
text: To the Editor:

headline: Made for Meals
text: The portfolio of wines made by Shinn Estate Vineyards is pointedly food-friendly.

headline: A Steakhouse Sticks With the Classics
text: THE sign outside the venerable old house in Great River spells out “Strip Steak” in letters large enough to halt any passing carnivore. I was attracted by the words in small print: “George Martin’s.” This newcomer, which opened early last month, is one of six restaurants in the well-regarded George Martin Group. The other five, including the original George Martin in Rockville Centre, are in Nassau County.

headline: Sip, Munch and Cheer
text: On weekends in Hoboken, jersey-clad fans file into the city’s many bars to root for their sports teams. These days, they have one more to choose from, with the opening in November of an outpost of the Village Pourhouse, the sports bar minichain based in Manhattan. The bar serves more than 100 beers, along with wings, nachos, burgers and other food popular on game days.

headline: A Robust Menu With Global Cuisine
text: IF the restaurant Coco-La, with its exuberant interiors and playful format, embodied the effervescent economy of central New Jersey before the recession, then The Maestro 206, which opened in its place in August in Hillsborough, personifies the new frugality.

headline: Chaos in Libya
text: A roundup of the events across the country from France 24 and the International Herald Tribune.

headline: Warm Slabs of Meat on Cold Winter Nights
text: “I HOPE they have a defibrillator in this restaurant,” a member of my party quipped cheerfully as he launched into a large lobster pot pie. Sure, the pie was decadent: the meat from a one-and-a-half-pound lobster was blanketed with lobster cream sauce and topped with a flaky disk of buttery pastry. But if the lobster put him over the top, it was only because he started the meal with a sensational appetizer of roasted marrow with foie gras mousse.

headline: Tacos and More, With a Twist
text: There are only three types of tacos on the blackboard menu at Husk New American Tacos in Collinsville, but this informal eatery lives up to its New American label by putting a fresh spin on them — and on a number of other south-of-the-border favorites.

headline: Tumult Around the Region
text: LIBYA Mercenary and army forces put down an attempt by protesters to break Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s hold on Tripoli, the capital, opening fire on crowds who had taken to the streets after prayers to mount their first major challenge to the government’s crackdown, witnesses said.

headline: Knicks’ Euphoria Is Thrown for a Loss
text: CLEVELAND  The first test was a rousing success. Carmelo Anthony made a triumphant Knicks debut Wednesday at Madison Square Garden. But playbooks take time to learn, and simply suiting up superstars does not guarantee victories.

headline: Best Visit to New York by a Former King?
text: GUY PEARCE, the actor who played King Edward VIII in “The King’s Speech,” is not among the nominees for an Academy Award at Sunday night’s ceremony. But Mr. Pearce’s character  who abdicated the throne to his brother (King George VI, played by Colin Firth, a favorite for Best Actor) in order to marry a double divorcee  captivated audiences during a visit to tenements on the East Side of New York in 1941.

headline: High School Indoor Record Set in 600 Meters
text: Strymar Livingston, a 17-year-old junior at Christopher Columbus High in the Bronx, posted a national indoor high school record in the boys 600 meters, finishing in 1 minute 17.64 seconds at the Public Schools Athletic League title meet at the New Balance Track and Field Center. The previous mark was 1:17.90, set by Shaquan Brown in 2005.

headline: Legislative Standoff
text: In Wisconsin, Republican Governor Scott Walker's bill to limit the collective bargaining rights for most public workers has created a legislative showdown.

headline: Sports Replay: Feb. 25, 2011
text: A look at the day in sports, from uncomfortable positions on the tennis court and the golf course, to angry coaches and a newfangled gizmo.

headline: Podcast: Economic Turbulence, and a Call for Fed Action
text: The United States economy can’t seem to catch a break. On Friday, the federal government revised its calculation of fourth-quarter growth to 2.8 percent from 3.2 percent. In the Weekend Business podcast, Catherine Rampell explains why: the turmoil in the Middle East has sent oil prices soaring. Investors fear that the unrest will spread to other countries, further disrupting production. In the United States, major cutbacks by state and local governments and threats of federal cutbacks are throwing more workers into the unemployment pool. Taken together, the uncertainty means businesses are unlikely to invest, let alone hire more workers.

headline: Loss to Spurs Gives Williams Crash Course in Nets’ Routine
text: SAN ANTONIO  Even as Friday’s game against San Antonio slipped away, Nets point guard Deron Williams decided to have a little fun with his new teammates.

headline: Larger-Than-Life Dallas Is Barely Growing
text: Big D may need a new nickname.

headline: Berman’s Agenda Leads Charge From the Right
text: Sitting in his Texas Capitol office, surrounded by pictures of his storied 22-year military career, the seven-term, 75-year-old Representative Leo Berman said in his distinctive New York accent, “I’m very unusual for a legislator.”

headline: Austin Filmmaker Scores Sight Unseen at Sundance
text: Minutes before the world premiere of his second feature, “Take Shelter,” at last month’s Sundance Film Festival, Jeff Nichols stood alone just beyond the red carpet at the Eccles Center, the festival’s largest site. The Austin-based writer-director had a look of cheerful amusement on his handsome face, almost like a boy taking in the sights at the circus.

headline: Republicans Must Walk Fine Line on Immigration
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor at The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

headline: Snow Falls on San Francisco After a 35-Year Wait
text: SAN FRANCISCO  As a Pacific storm coincided with a blast of cold Canadian air over their fair city, residents here saw snow late Friday, a long-absent visitor for a city accustomed to fog, sweater-weather and other nearly bone-chilling accoutrements.

headline: On Our Radar: Spain Lowers Speed Limit as Oil Price Spikes
text: Spain will lower its national speed limit, reduce the cost of rail fares and raise the minimum percentage of biofuels blended into gasoline, all in a bid to reduce oil dependence in the face of spiking crude prices, the country’s deputy prime minister says. Driven by Middle East turmoil, the benchmark price for Brent crude oil in Europe settled at over $112 a barrel on Friday. [Reuters]

headline: Ireland’s Governing Party Ousted in Historic Loss
text: LONDON  Ireland ousted its discredited government on Saturday, electing new leaders who pledged to restore faith in the country after the trauma of a calamitous economic collapse.

headline: The Weekend Word: Breathing Room?
text: From Today’s Times:

headline: Following U.S. Sanctions, U.N. Security Council to Meet on Libya
text: WASHINGTON  One day after the United States closed its embassy in Tripoli and imposed unilateral sanctions against Libya, the United Nations Security Council prepared to meet in New York on Saturday to consider imposing international sanctions, including an arms embargo and an asset freeze and travel ban against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, his relatives and key members of his government.

headline: The Effects of Union Membership on Democratic Voting
text: How important are labor unions to the Democratic Party?

headline: Classic Ad: A Cavalcade of Stars for Chevy
text: When it comes to classic car ads, you can never have too much star power.

headline: New N.F.L. Standard for Assessing Players Suspected of Having Concussions
text: The N.F.L. released new guidelines on Friday for handling players who are suspected of having been concussed. The league wants one set of sideline tests for all 32 team doctors and trainers before a player is sent back to the field. The complete news release from the league is below.

headline: Bombing Damages Iraq’s Largest Oil Refinery
text: BAGHDAD  Iraq’s largest oil refinery, in Baiji, was crippled by a predawn attack on Saturday in which gunmen stormed the vast complex, killed one engineer and set off several bombs.

headline: Suddenly, a Rise in Piracy’s Price
text: At some point, Thomas Jefferson realized, you just can’t do business with pirates any more.

headline: Flirt in a Skirt
text: Is it her voice, her smile or the way she wears her impressive spring blouse that turns prim into fabulous? In this shoot, the fashion editor David Vandewal and the photographer Walter Pfeiffer conspire to make grown-up looks that don’t take themselves too seriously. More…

headline: Feb. 26: Updates on Libya’s Revolt and Mideast Protests
text: On Saturday, The Lede is following the uprising in Libya and protests in Egypt, Yemen, Bahrain, Iraq and the West Bank. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists on the ground. A stream of Twitter messages from the region is in this blog’s right column.

headline: Iceland-Ireland Again
text: Via the Irish Economy, I see that there have been two articles in the Irish Times comparing Iceland and Ireland, and concluding that Iceland did no better. The articles aren’t bad — but need to be read with caution. Specifically, I’d make four counter-arguments:

headline: Mail Call for E.T.
text: I tend to subscribe to the “rare earth” hypothesis propounded by Peter Ward and Donald Brownlee, but, hey, you never know. In that spirit, Marc Roberts, the British eco-cartoonist, has been doing a series on alien encounters that’s worth a look:

headline: A Clarification On Public Workers
text: I see that a number of commenters failed to click on my link in this post. Um, it’s true that the Times article did not include data on benefits as opposed to wages. But other studies have — notably the big EPI study (pdf). The Times results match what those studies say about wages — and those studies find that the lack of evidence for overpayment remains once you take benefits into account.

headline: Joel McHale on Low Standards and Hosting Gigs
text: LOS ANGELES— You know, if a weekend with one awards show is good, then a weekend with two award shows must be better, right?

headline: In Libya Capital, Long Bread Lines and Barricades
text: TRIPOLI, Libya  A bold play by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to prove that he was firmly in control of Libya appeared to backfire Saturday, as foreign journalists he invited to the capital discovered blocks of the city in open defiance of his authority.

headline: Urban Forager | Growing a Salad in Winter
text: Instead of throwing down weedkiller, why not dig up dandelions for next winter’s food?

headline: Model-Morphosis | Melissa Tammerijn for Etro
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Milan Fashion Week. Here, the model Melissa Tammerijn before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Charlotte Tilbury for M.A.C. and hair by Eugene Souleiman for Wella. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: As Berkshire Improves, Buffett Sings Praises of U.S.
text: Warren E. Buffett does not put a title on his annual letter. But if he did, this year’s dispatch might be headlined “God Bless the U.S.A.”

headline: Polanski Basks in Applause at César Awards
text: PARIS— Roman Polanski, the 77-year-old director whose film “The Ghost Writer” was snubbed by the Oscars, won a measure of solace on Friday when the French cultural elite showered the thriller with four Césars. The honors (France’s version of the Academy Awards) included a best directing nod for Mr. Polanski, who was vigorously supported by French film and political celebrities when he was arrested in September 2009 on a more than 30-year-old sex crime warrant from the United States and jailed and detained in Switzerland until he successfully fended off extradition last July.

headline: Maluca Mala | La Crazy Bad
text: Two years ago, Nathalie Yepez — a 29-year-old first generation New Yorker who was born to Dominican parents in the Bronx and grew up in Washington Heights and the East Village — moved back to her mother’s house, quit her bartending and waitressing jobs to pursue music full time, and reinvented herself as the singer Maluca Mala. “I thought to myself, Enough is enough!” she recalls. “I’m miserable sitting at home writing music and just talking about it.” Mala, who not surprisingly identifies as a “hood hipster,” performs a mix of what she calls “ghetto-techno, Latin-dance, hip-hop, rave music.” It’s a decadent mix that has not gone unnoticed — especially by Lady Gaga, whose beer-cans-as-rollers look in the video for “Telephone” appears to have been inspired by Mala’s headgear in her video for “El Tigeraso.”

headline: Key Tribal Chief Wants Yemen Leader to Quit
text: SANA, Yemen  One of Yemen’s most prominent tribal sheiks resigned from the ruling party on Saturday and called for President Ali Abdullah Saleh to step down, posing one of the most significant challenges yet to the Yemeni leader, an American ally who has struggled for more than two weeks to quell a popular revolt.

headline: Suicide Attack Continues Afghan Trend
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A playing field in a remote area of northwest Afghanistan where a crowd had gathered was the most recent target for a suicide bomber who detonated himself on Saturday, in the seventh suicide attack in Afghanistan in less than a month.

headline: Variety: A Winner of a Cryptic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Some days you conquer the puzzle, and some days, as they say, the puzzle conquers you. Although it was immensely enjoyable, I narrowly escaped with my life on this one, and I think it’s because 1) this is only the second cryptic I’ve ever done, and 2) Since the only other cryptic I’ve solved was by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, I feel like I’m more on their wavelength.

headline: How Budget Battles Go Without the Earmarks
text: WASHINGTON  The fact that Congress remains a spending disagreement or two away from shutting down the government no doubt strikes some as remarkable. But there is another extraordinary aspect to the fiscal clash unfolding on Capitol Hill: earmarks have disappeared from the budgetary landscape.

headline: In Africa, Lessons on Passion and Perspective for Kershaw
text: PHOENIX  The Los Angeles left-hander Clayton Kershaw held the audience in his sway from the first pitch. A world removed from the grandeur of Dodger Stadium, the barefoot children stood in awe as they watched Kershaw’s curveball spin and dip.

headline: How Buffett’s Most Recent Big Deals Have Done
text: Berkshire Hathaway is, perhaps more than anything else, a giant deal machine, and Warren E. Buffett signaled in his latest investor letter that he’s eager to make another big acquisition.

headline: Held Hostage Off Somalia
text: A tally of vessels and their passengers and crew believed held by Somali bandits as of last week. All in all, 51 vessels and at least 819 people are believed to be held hostage.

headline: In-Line Hockey: Still Rolling, but Not on a Roll
text: OLD BETHPAGE, N.Y.  Jonathan Mosenson has traveled the globe playing hockey on in-line skates. He is 24 and has competed in Italy, Germany, Argentina and Taiwan. He has won gold medals at world championships, receives free equipment from sponsors and is tested for performance-enhancing drugs. He wears a suit to the arena.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: Photographs from news and features in business over the past week.

headline: Everyone’s Talking About It (but Jeter)
text: TAMPA, Fla.  If Derek Jeter owns the largest home in Hillsborough County, then he probably has the most garbage, right?

headline: Waiting Seven Years for Two Answers
text: WHEN Zella Mae Green of Georgia filed for bankruptcy to save her home from foreclosure in 2004, she and her lawyer wanted to know two things: Did she actually owe any back payments on her mortgage? And, if so, to whom?

headline: Scorecard | Versace Wins!
text: When “sexy” is the root of the compound modifiers — “supremely sexy,” “Versace-sexy” — used most in the reviews, then you know Scorecard is really in Milan. On the third day of shows, which saw Dubai-based financial backers bring Gianfranco Ferré back from the brink, Rossella Jardini dialed Moschino’s surreal provocation way back. Donatella Versace, meanwhile, went for a somewhat discreet vision of Gianni-baroque, proving the old adage to make new friends, but keep the old.

headline: Want Clarity? Learn to Play Devil’s Advocate
text: This interview with Richard D. Fain, chairman and C.E.O. of Royal Caribbean Cruises, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Genius Loves Company in N.B.A. Balance of Power
text: Contrary to growing sentiment, the recent migration of players to large N.B.A. markets to form cabals of superstar power is no more likely to wreck professional basketball than it is to ensure multiple championships for the teams that LeBron James and Carmelo Anthony decided to take their talents to.

headline: A Corporate Sleuth Tries the Credit Rating Field
text: FEW people ever penetrate the dark side of money, but Jules Kroll is one of them.

headline: Carrots, Sticks and Digital Health Records
text: THE United States is embarking this year on a grand experiment in the government-driven adoption of technology  ambitious, costly and potentially far-reaching in impact. The goal is to improve health care and to reduce its long-term expense by moving the doctors and hospitals from ink and paper into the computer age  through a shift to digital patient records.

headline: Tosses and Turns of Yankees-Phillies
text: Tampa, Fla.

headline: Set Against Black, Jil Sander Strikes a Nerve
text: Bumping into an old friend today, I heard him lament that fashion shows had become events — geared to the demands of social media and branding strategies — and had lost their charm. This is not an overnight change, but it feels that way. “Designers are doing what they have to do, and not want they want to do,” he said. And many collections this season seem overly influenced by films and fashion of the 60s and 70s. The other night, while searching for a Bob Richardson photograph of Donna Mitchell, I found one of Jill Kennington wearing a beige-pink shag fur coat virtually identical to the one Miuccia Prada showed. Oh, well, I thought. But this habit gives everything a kind of movie-still quality, even when there may not be a direct reference.

headline: Moonlighting Within Microsoft, in Pursuit of New Apps
text: IF you have a smartphone, you probably have apps on it to check the news, play games, help with shopping or further a hobby like travel or bird-watching. But chances are that you don’t yet have Bubblegum  a new app that lets you instantly dress up cellphone photos, tinting them in sepia or adding neon blue highlights, for instance, and then share the results on Facebook.

headline: The Lands Autocracy Won’t Quit
text: MOSCOW — Let the Middle East and North Africa be buffeted by populist discontent over repressive governments. Here in Lenin’s former territory, across the expanse of the old Soviet Union, rulers with iron fists still have the upper hand.

headline: Letters: The Goals of New Taxes
text: The Goals of New Taxes

headline: The Debate That’s Muting the Fed’s Response
text: MONETARY policy makers at the Federal Reserve have long been classified as “hawks” or “doves.” The distinction is appealing in its simplicity. Hawks care deeply about inflation, while doves are willing to risk inflation to reduce unemployment.

headline: Suddenly, Emerging Markets Look Complicated Again
text: LATE last year, when demand for emerging-market stocks reached new heights, investors viewed the threat of global inflation as yet another reason to keep betting on them.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Buffett Finds a Friend, Sometimes, in the Fed
text: Warren E. Buffett is widely regarded as one of the savviest investors on the planet. But it was during the financial crisis that he struck one of his most lucrative deals: a $5 billion investment in Goldman Sachs that has paid out more than $1 billion in dividends so far.

headline: But Who Will Grade the Grader?
text: IN this episode of the Haggler, a sobering look at the Better Business Bureau.

headline: In Film and in Life, the Story Is King
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Your Résumé, for All to See
text: YOU think you have a serviceable résumé. Maybe you have worked with a professional résumé writer, or at least have had someone read it over and give you feedback. But you still haven’t gotten a new job. Should you start a Web site, solely for job hunting, that features your résumé?

headline: From Software to Satellites
text: I WAS born in Dayton, Ohio, the second of six children  five boys and one girl. My father, John, was a manager for a hydraulic lift truck business, and my mother, Geraldine, was a semi-professional dancer who later was a secretary in the Dayton police department and in the local county sheriff’s office.

headline: Canada Looks Past Boycott and Forward to Cyprus Cup
text: Tensions between Canada’s women’s national team and the Canadian Soccer Association have eased according to a published report that says the team has lifted its boycott threat.

headline: Can Scientists Learn from Science Journalists?
text: Maggie Koerth-Baker, science editor of BoingBoing.net, gave a really good talk at the University of Wisconsin aiming to encourage scientists to communicate effectively with other human beings. A starting point: listening. Another: Start a blog.
