headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Producers Mulling Another Delay for Opening Night
text: The producers of Broadway’s “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” are considering delaying the musical’s opening night for a sixth time, people familiar with the deliberations say, to make more changes to the show in hopes of improving its worldwide commercial prospects after theater critics savaged it this month.

headline: James Franco’s Oscar Prep, Captured by James Franco
text: LOS ANGELES— Does it surprise anyone to learn that James Franco has had two guys filming every moment of his Oscar rehearsals?

headline: The Fish Whose Bite Is as Fierce as Its Name
text: SEATTLE  The trucks delivering produce to Pike Place Market were still being unloaded when Dave McCoy, the owner of Emerald Water Anglers, picked me up at my hotel for a day of fishing. Soon we were driving south on Interstate 5. After a quick stop for coffee, we headed west across the Tacoma Narrows Bridge and then down a twisting country road. Coming around a bend, we saw the snow-covered Olympic Mountains jutting forth, resembling jagged dollops of meringue.

headline: Why We Write About Grief
text: Grieving has always been a public as well as private act, and lately, it seems, people are increasingly writing memoirs about it.

headline: Andy Jurinko, Painter Whose Art Memorialized Ballparks, Dies at 71
text: There is the panoramic view toward the Green Monster, the towering left-field wall at Fenway Park, on June 8, 1950, as the Boston Red Sox are crushing the St. Louis Browns, 29-4.

headline: Fighting Words
text: Younger patients would be more likely than older ones to get the best kidneys under a plan being considered by the nation’s organ transplant network. The proposal would replace the current system — first come, first served —with one that would provide better matches between life expectancies of patients and the functional life of donated kidneys.

headline: Prime Number
text: 310: The number of basketball games Caltech lost in a row in the Southern California Intercollegiate Athletic Conference. The losing streak, which began in 1985, ended last week when the Beavers defeated Occidental at home 46-45 in the final game of the season. Not a record to write home about, but there is this: Thirty-one Caltech faculty or alumni have won 32 Nobel Prizes. (The chemist Linus Pauling won two: chemistry and peace.) Go Beavers!

headline: Torre Selected by Selig as a Top Lieutenant
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  When Joe Torre retired from managing last September, he said, he did not expect his next job to be as intense as the one he has chosen. But Torre said Saturday that he was looking forward to life as a top lieutenant of Commissioner Bud Selig.

text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — When Joe Torre retired from managing last September, he said, he did not expect his next job to be as intense as the one he has chosen. But Torre said Saturday that he was looking forward to life as a top lieutenant of Commissioner Bud Selig.

headline: Officer Denies Efforts to Sway Lawmakers
text: WASHINGTON  The spokesman for a three-star general accused of instructing troops to carry out “psychological operations” to sway visiting members of Congress said Saturday that the general was innocent of any wrongdoing.

headline: As Embassies Close, People Flee Libya
text: An effort by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to prove that he was firmly in control of Libya appeared to backfire as foreign journalists he invited to the capital discovered blocks of the city in open revolt.

headline: Swedes Begin to Question Liberal Migration Tenets
text: MALMO, Sweden  Nick Nilsson, 46, decided to vote for Sweden’s far-right party last fall because of a growing sense that his country had gone too far in letting so many immigrants settle here.

headline: The Budget Fight Continues
text: In defense of their bill to slash federal spending by $61 billion over the next seven months, House Republicans claim they are trying to make the economy grow and create jobs. In truth, such deep and sudden cuts could derail the recovery, without ever addressing the real sources of budget deficits — mainly explosive health care costs and incessant high-end tax cuts.

headline: Angry Arizona, Again
text: Many states are doing urgent business: jobs, the economy, broken budgets. Arizona’s legislators are trying to give government new powers to strip away individual rights, to extend immigration enforcement into schools, public housing, hospitals and doctor’s offices.

headline: Trashing the Lessons of Watergate
text: House Republicans, pandering to the new corporate money trough legitimized by the Supreme Court, have voted to kill off public financing for presidential elections. Unless the Senate Democratic majority acts forcefully, the death of the public alternative  first adopted in the wake of the Watergate scandal  could be sealed in the rounds of budget negotiations to come.

headline: Joe Flom
text: Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom may be the world’s most influential corporate law firm. Now usually called Skadden, it is known by the family name of a long-gone partner and not by that of Joseph Flom, who built the firm into a global powerhouse by democratizing the elite practice of corporate law.

headline: Why Wouldn’t the Tea Party Shut It Down?
text: NO one remembers anything in America, especially in Washington, so the history of the Great Government Shutdown of 1995 is being rewritten with impunity by Republicans flirting with a Great Government Shutdown of 2011. The bottom line of the revisionist spin is this: that 2011 is no 1995. Should the unthinkable occur on some coming budget D-Day — or perhaps when the deadline to raise the federal debt ceiling arrives this spring — the G.O.P. is cocksure that it can pin the debacle on the Democrats.

headline: North Koreans Struggle, and Party Keeps Its Grip

headline: Learning From Buchanan
text: By mid-January 1861 a sleepless President James Buchanan contemplated the remaining seven weeks of his presidency. Above all, he hoped to avoid the outbreak of civil war. He had come to Washington as a northern Democrat who, through training, background and conviction, believed himself well positioned to solve the sectional crisis.

headline: How the Arabs Turned Shame Into Liberty
text: PERHAPS this Arab Revolution of 2011 had a scent for the geography of grief and cruelty. It erupted in Tunisia, made its way eastward to Egypt, Yemen and Bahrain, then doubled back to Libya. In Tunisia and Egypt political freedom seems to have prevailed, with relative ease, amid popular joy. Back in Libya, the counterrevolution made its stand, and a despot bereft of mercy declared war against his own people.

Last year’s statewide lobster haul —  93 million pounds, up from 81 million in 2009 — was the largest on record. And Mr. Francoeur allowed that he had shared in the bounty.

headline: Utah Regroups
text: The Utah Jazz had an eventful February, losing its longtime coach, Jerry Sloan, to retirement and trading the superstar point guard Deron Williams to the Nets. With all the disarray, it was easy to not notice that as of Friday, the team was still eighth in the Western Conference, meaning if the season ended the Jazz would qualify for the playoffs.

headline: Security Council Calls for War Crimes Inquiry in Libya
text: The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously on Saturday night to impose sanctions on Libya’s leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, and his inner circle of advisers, and called for an international war crimes investigation into “widespread and systemic attacks” against Libyan citizens who have protested against the government over the last two weeks.

headline: What We Learned in the Statehouse

headline: As the Knicks Rearrange, They Focus on the Kinks

The reality, at least for now, arrived on a snowy night in Cleveland. A superstar again watched the final ticks from the bench as confusion rather than cohesion marked a deflating loss.

headline: Bundesliga Gets Fourth Spot in Champions League
text: The German Bundesliga will have four places in the UEFA Champions League starting with the 2012-13 tournament. Its gain will come at the expense of Italy’s Serie A, which will have its allotment cut to three based on UEFA’s five-year rankings of the leagues’ performances in Europe.

headline: Q. and A. With Ivan Lendl
text: With his punishing topspin ground strokes, Lendl won eight Grand Slam singles titles, reached the final of at least one Grand Slam tournament for 11 straight years (Sampras is the only other man to do that), advanced to 19 Grand Slam finals (only Roger Federer has played in more), and was ranked No. 1 for 270 weeks (only Sampras and Federer have surpassed him). He is also familiar with the Garden: during the 13 years that the Masters Tournament was held there, Lendl reached a record nine straight finals, losing four times (including twice to McEnroe) but winning five (beating McEnroe once).

headline: Q. and A. With Jim Courier
text: Jim Courier is a former No. 1 tennis player who won 23 Tour singles titles, including two French Opens and two Australian Opens, before he retired in 2000. Last October, Courier, 40, was named the captain of the United States Davis Cup team. The first round of the competition begins Friday, with the United States facing Chile in Santiago. JOE BRESCIA

headline: Focus on Schools and Jobs
text: Nashville

headline: Soldat Quiets Doubters in Fountain of Youth
text: HALLANDALE, Fla.  With every powerful stride that Soldat took in the stretch of the 65th running of the Fountain of Youth, the trainer Kiaran McLaughlin felt whatever doubts he had about his colt being pounded away. When the year began, McLaughlin wondered if Soldat was really a Kentucky Derby horse or if he was just hoping that he was.

headline: Sabres’ Job of No. 1 Fan Is Taken
text: It is the dream of every sports fan to own his or her favorite team. For Terry Pegula, that dream has come true. Pegula, a Buffalo Sabres fan who had season tickets for 18 years, then became a billionaire in the energy business, completed his purchase of the team from Tom Golisano last week.

headline: Movement at Combine, but Not at the Table
text: INDIANAPOLIS  The N.F.L. players union plans to decertify before the collective bargaining agreement expires at midnight March 4, unless a labor agreement can be agreed to in negotiations this week.

headline: Match Play Comes Down to Two Golfers Who Rarely Blink
text: MARANA, Ariz.  It took four days of sorting through upsets, routs and skintight matches, but when it all shook out on Saturday at Dove Mountain, the two best players in the W.G.C.-Accenture Match Play Championship were in the finals.

headline: Familiarity Breeds a Change in Routine
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets play 36 spring training games this year, and 22 of them are against three of their four National League East rivals, including five of the last six games of the spring. Because of that, Manager Terry Collins said he would have his starting pitchers throw their last starts against minor league competition to prevent the Atlanta Braves, the Washington Nationals and the Florida Marlins from getting too familiar with the pitchers they will face in the regular season.

headline: Immigrant Communities of Sweden

headline: Villanova Is Merely Another Milestone for St. John’s

headline: Your Comments on my Arab Democracy Column
text: My Sunday column notes that there is a fair amount of anxiety about what a democratic revolution will mean in the Arab world, and specifically about whether the Arab world (and other less developed parts of the world) are ready for democracy. I find this entire debate patronizing, especially after witnessing the incredible courage of democracy activists in recent weeks. Sure, there are plenty of rough spots ahead –but if people are dying for democracy, who are we to say that they’re not ready for it? Read the column and post your thoughts.

headline: Tea Party Group Issues Warning to the G.O.P.
text: PHOENIX — While heaping scorn on President Obama and the Democrats for overspending, more than 2,000 members of the Tea Party Patriots gathered here for a national conference also had strong words on Saturday for Congressional Republicans and vowed to vote them out of office next year if they did not move aggressively to cut the budget.

headline: Corporate Giants Received TIF Money, Records Show

headline: Emanuel Has a Tough Row to Hoe, but Far From an Impossible One
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: In Libyan Port, Stranded Migrants Watch Hope Depart
text: BENGHAZI, Libya  American and British citizens have been evacuating for days. The Chinese workers were on their way, and the Bosnians stood ready with their bags on the shore. But from the milky windows of stifling rooms in a makeshift camp, the migrant workers from other, poorer countries, stranded by war and, in some cases, forsaken by their employers, watched cruise ships  and salvation  depart.

headline: A Port in a Storm
text: In Benghazi, migrant workers have gathered to wait for their way out of Libya.

headline: How a Past Political Star Became an Also-Ran
text: JeNest Murry was not going to allow her teenage niece, Raven, to sit out the mayoral election. Right after work on Tuesday, Ms. Murray drove Raven to the polls. To stay home, Ms. Murry said, would have betrayed the past and the future.

headline: Doctors Clear Kiwanuka
text: The Giants announced Saturday that defensive end Mathias Kiwanuka had been cleared by doctors to return to football activities after his 2010 season was cut short by a herniated disk in his neck. Kiwanuka was the Giants’ most versatile defensive lineman and had four sacks in his first three games, but the injury forced him onto injured reserve.

headline: Vows: Jessica & Andrew
text: Jessica and Andrew fell in love exploring New York City together. Their relationship culminated in a quintessential New York moment with tourists applauding them as he proposed on a muggy summer day.

headline: Wrist-Wrestling Statue
text: Bronze biceps are bulging at the intersection of East Washington Street and Petaluma Boulevard in downtown Petaluma. The statue commemorates Bill Soberanes, who founded the town’s World Wristwrestling Championships.

headline: Vintage Jet Crashes in Hudson Valley
text: Feb. 27, 2011, 7:28 p.m. | Updated A Cold War-era plane with a dragon’s face painted on its nose fell out of the sky on Saturday afternoon and crashed into the icy Hudson River in upstate New York.

headline: Salt River Fields, the New Spring Sensation
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. – Bud Selig is a 76-year-old from Milwaukee, so his frame of reference for any ballpark is County Stadium, the spartan former home of the Braves and the Brewers that did not even have an office for the visiting manager. Compare that with Salt River Fields at Talking Stick, the new spring home of the Diamondbacks and the Rockies, and it’s no wonder Selig gushed.

headline: Governors Look for Means to Cope With Budgets
text: WASHINGTON  Democratic governors warned Saturday that federal budget cuts could crimp a fragile economic recovery, and governors of both major parties asked the Obama administration to give them more flexibility in running education and health care programs so that they could cope.

headline: Lottery Numbers
America’s Cup Vanguards Begin Their Preparations
text: The world’s fastest yacht, which is too tall to sail under the Golden Gate Bridge, is scheduled to arrive in San Francisco on a freighter this week. The boat will be off-loaded in crated pieces and stored at Pier 80.

headline: In Mayoral Race, Yee Makes Name for Himself as a Loner and a Workhorse
text: It is a peculiar ritual, as regular as the lunar calendar itself: During the Chinese New Year Parade held in San Francisco every year, Rose Pak, the Chinatown power broker who organizes the festival, paces the reviewing stand at the end of the parade route with a microphone in hand, joshing with elected officials that she likes  and haranguing those she does not  as they roll past in sparkling convertibles.

headline: On Stage and Afterward, Spotlight on Apple in China

headline: Jay Landesman, Beat Writer and Editor, Dies at 91

headline: ‘King Lear’ Inspires a Riff on the Endurance of Time
text: There comes a point in “Storm Still” when even the most patient theatergoer will stop forgiving its faults. That point occurs when a man, naked except for a Tarzan-like loincloth, is spanked repeatedly by another character, then bent over a chair and sodomized with a walking stick  a stick that is thrown to the floor and picked up in the mouth of an actor portraying a dog.

headline: Afghan Team Says NATO Killed Civilians in Strikes
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghan investigators said Sunday that they were convinced that NATO forces killed 65 civilians in airstrikes in eastern Afghanistan this month, a charge that, if true, would be one of the worst civilian casualty episodes of the war.

headline: Israeli Panel Finds No Crime in 2002 Assassination
text: JERUSALEM  Nearly nine years after an Israeli assassination of a Hamas leader in Gaza killed at least 13 civilians and led to widespread international condemnation, a government-appointed panel of inquiry concluded Sunday that the operation was flawed but that the consequences “did not stem from disregard or indifference to human lives.”

headline: Trade Winds Off Ice, Crucial Loss on It
text: As the Rangers vie to make the playoffs, the franchise’s front office has been working to bolster the team’s roster. The twin goals have been to retain future assets while emboldening the current team’s postseason aspirations.

headline: Scorecard | Jil Sander Wins!
text: The Laws of Fashion are funny things. Raf Simons took minimalism to the max via couture volumes at Jil Sander last season, and on the fourth day of the current shows Milan’s other master of chic sobriety, Bottega Veneta’s Tomas Maier, went curvilinear — yet Scorecard knows critics couldn’t agree on whether his sixties-inspired silhouettes were mired in stasis or moved on. The designer for the house that Jil built, meanwhile, pared down his billowing volumes to tops and added sleek ski pants, proving to be an unstoppable force.

headline: Duke Snider, a Prince of New York’s Golden Age of Baseball, Dies at 84
text: Duke Snider, the Hall of Fame center fielder renowned for his home run drives and superb defensive play in the Brooklyn Dodgers’ glory years, died Sunday in Escondido, Calif. He was 84.

headline: Prostate Guideline Causes Many Needless Biopsies, Study Says
text: Current guidelines for the early detection of prostate cancer recommend a biopsy for men whose P.S.A. rises rapidly, no matter what the initial level. But a new study says that the practice does not help patients find aggressive cancers and results in many unnecessary biopsies.

headline: A Chat With Oscar’s Australian Cinderella
text: LOS ANGELES— Oscar loves a Cinderella story, and this year one of the best has belonged to Jacki Weaver. A veteran Australian stage actress, Ms. Weaver hadn’t been in a movie in a dozen years and was unknown in the U.S. until she starred in “Animal Kingdom,” the Australian indie crime drama from a first-time filmmaker that earned her a best supporting actress nomination. She has been a petite charmer on the circuit all season long. We spoke to her at a party for Sony Pictures Classics, the film’s distributor, on Saturday, and she revealed a bit of country pride. “It’s the first time an Australian has been nominated in an Australian film since ‘Shine,'” she said. Her Australian-designed gown had arrived only hours before, and it, too, was a Cinderella moment. “It takes about six able-bodied people to lift me into my frock,” she said. “I’m going to have to lean on my husband walking up the red carpet.” As a first-time nominee, Ms. Weaver had no problem admitting that she really, really wanted to win, and sharing details of her acceptance speech strategy.

headline: ‘The King’s Speech’ Tops Oscars 2011
text: Oscars Night

headline: A Reading of Schubert, Both Fiery and Fresh
text: The opening performances of Lincoln Center’s Tully Scope festival at Alice Tully Hall were high-profile new-music programs, but the idea behind this nonthematic series is that it should touch on the breadth of New York’s musical life. There will be a lot more new music, and early music as well. But on Saturday evening the festival set its sights on the 19th-century Viennese mainstream, presenting a Schubert recital by the pianist Emanuel Ax.

headline: Young Players From England Secure a Trophy
text: We must continue to encourage junior bridge if the game is to survive, and in Britain, the Peggy Bayer Trophy for players under 20 and the Junior Camrose for those under 25 do just that. England, Northern Ireland, the Republic of Ireland, Scotland and Wales are eligible to send teams to compete in the two events, which this year concluded on Feb. 20.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Dempsey Stewart for Marni
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Milan Fashion Week. Here, the model Dempsey Stewart before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Tom Pecheux. and hair by Paul Hanlon. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: How Species Save Our Lives
text: When adding up the benefits from three centuries of species discoveries, I’m tempted to start, and also stop, with Sir Hans Sloane.  A London physician and naturalist in the 18th century, he collected everything from insects to elephant tusks.  And like a lot of naturalists, he was ridiculed for it, notably by his friend Horace Walpole, who scoffed at Sloane’s fondness for “sharks with one ear, and spiders as big as geese!”   Sloane’s collections would in time give rise to the British Museum, the British Library, and the Natural History Museum, London.  Not a bad legacy for one lifetime.  But it pales beside the result of a collecting trip to Jamaica, on which Sloane also invented milk chocolate.

headline: Libyan Rebels Reinforce Boundaries in Zawiya
text: In Zawiya, a city 30 miles west of Tripoli, hundreds of people rejoiced in a central square on Sunday, while opposition leaders in Benghazi started to form a provisional government.

headline: Raising a Milkshake to the Bride and Groom
text: HONG KONG  As classical Muzak blasted from a loudspeaker, Kelvin Kwong got down on one knee and declared his love for his fiancée, Ashley Tse, in front of a rowdy media scrum. Their engagement party on Valentine’s Day was the inaugural event of a new and aggressively promoted nuptial service at McDonald’s restaurants in Hong Kong, the first in the world to offer McWeddings.

headline: Recalling a Revered Singer in Harlem
text: The mezzo-soprano Betty Allen was part of a generation of pioneering black female vocal artists who emerged triumphantly in the 1950s and ’60s, a select group of greats including Leontyne Price, Shirley Verrett and Grace Bumbry. If Ms. Allen never achieved the status or the public renown of her sister singers, she was a distinguished performer who combined a rich voice with musical integrity and scrupulous diction; a devotee of American music; and a favorite of composers as varied as Virgil Thomson, Ned Rorem and Leonard Bernstein. As a conductor Bernstein recruited her often to sing with the New York Philharmonic. Yet she may have had her greatest influence as an educator who taught for decades at the Manhattan School of Music and directed the Harlem School of the Arts during 13 high-growth years, becoming its president emeritus in 1993.

headline: Mahler’s Third, Whimsy-Free Version
text: Unlike most of the audience, to judge from the clamorous ovation afterward, this lover of Mahler’s Third Symphony found precious little to love in the grim, overcontrolled performance of the work by Valery Gergiev and the London Symphony Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday evening.

headline: Varied Music Legacies Find Much in Common
text: A New Orleans second-line beat, shaken and tapped on tambourines, started “CubaNOLA: More Than the Spanish Tinge,” the concert by Arturo O’Farrill and the Afro Latin Jazz Orchestra on Saturday night at Symphony Space. Then a cowbell joined in, tilting the rhythm toward Cuba. It was the prologue to a concert devoted to musical kinships: between Cuba and New Orleans, and between generations.

headline: In Milan, a Movie Obsession and a 1960s Tilt
text: I hope to be watching the Oscars tonight, at least the red carpet. It starts around 1 a.m. here. Meanwhile, Milan’s obsession with the movies this season persists. The music for Missoni this afternoon came from “True Romance” and “Natural Born Killers,” and the chaotic, pastel clothes brought to mind Juliette Lewis, though not specifically her character in the Oliver Stone film. The mood was girlish innocence verging to girlish wreck, with long silk-print and knit dresses, impressively fat cardigans, and maxi coats in multi-hued python. The colors seem to flood from a girl’s bedroom, or the bathrooms of a 1960s subdivision: baby yellow, mint green, pink, and violet. Angela Missoni threw them together, sometimes causing one to cringe (example: a crinkly violet knit pants outfit with a sick twinkle of Lurex). It was strong and little perverse, thanks to the pastel upchuck. The accessories also pointed to bad movie girls: floppy knit caps and adorable motorcycle boots in a collage of python and colors.

headline: A First Wife Can Be So Stolid and Clueless and Plain and Pregnant
text: The strikingly attractive cover of “The Paris Wife” depicts a glamorous, poised-looking woman perched in a Paris cafe. She wears a belted, tailored dress reminiscent of the late 1940s or early 1950s. Her face cannot be seen, but her posture radiates confidence and freedom. The picture is interesting because it has absolutely nothing to do with the book it is selling.

headline: Rich Talent and Promising Voices Well Rewarded
text: “You are all so attractive, I’m really sorry I’m too old for you,” Nora London said with a laugh before announcing the winners of the 40th George London Foundation Awards Competition, named for her husband, the renowned American bass-baritone who died in 1985.

headline: Interpreting Several Phases of a Singular Creator
text: Schubert was the only composer represented in the program that the Takacs Quartet offered at the 92nd Street Y on Saturday night, but in no sense was there too much of a muchness about the affair. Midway through a three-concert series devoted almost entirely to Schubert’s music  a previous program included a new piece inspired by a Schubert work  this consistently invigorating, satisfying ensemble offered three distinct views of a singular creator.

headline: Monday: Kawasaki Competitor
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Help, I’m surrounded by baby talk! And I thought I was out of that stage, parenthetically speaking. Or, speaking as a parent. Whatever.

headline: For One Young Muslim the Path to Faith Is Rocky
text: “Mooz-Lum,” a drama by Qasim Basir about wrestling with faith — here it’s Islam — manages to avoid many pitfalls common to similar movies. What could have been a morality tale told through rigid contrasts proposes instead a series of diffuse challenges to its young black hero, not all of them from outside his religion.

headline: Veterans With Quartets, Stretching Out in Sound
text: Lee Konitz and Ahmad Jamal, in their 80s now and radically stubborn survivors of most of jazz’s history, each came with a quartet. But in both cases the room’s acoustics became the fifth member of the band. Saturday night’s double bill at Rose Theater  the second night of a weekend stand at Jazz at Lincoln Center  was a study in sound: soft and loud, natural and amplified, furry and sharpened, as delivered and as echoed.

headline: The World Spins (Bicycle Wheels, Too)
text: With a title like “And All the Question Marks Started to Sing,” there is much room for the imagination, and that’s a fine thing. Performed by the Norwegian art collective Verdensteatret on Friday night at Dance Theater Workshop, this production continued the group’s magical explorations into hybrid forms in which performance, installation, animation and sound unite for the good of art.

headline: Skip the Sundae? Christie Is on the First Lady’s Side
text: In the dessert wars, at least, Chris Christie and Mike Huckabee side with Michelle Obama, not Sarah Palin.

headline: Paul Taylor Offers a Vision of the World Through Mirrors and Illusions
text: Paul Taylor is a major choreographer whose season at City Center has begun in a thoroughly minor way. There is no more dramatically imaginative choreographer today, and yet sometimes that imagination looks feeble. There is no choreographer who puts more remarkable dreamscapes onstage, and yet some of his dreams are trite.

headline: Two Remembrances of One Deadly Day in 1911
text: ooo

headline: The Truth About Pensions
text: Dean Baker has a deeply enlightening analysis of state pension shortfalls (pdf), containing a lot of stuff I didn’t know. The basic moral is that the official story these days — of years and years of huge giveaways to unions, resulting in gigantic, unpayable debts — is just wrong: to a very large extent, the pension shortfall has emerged just since 2007, thanks to the financial crisis, and even then it’s not nearly as big relative to future state incomes as widely imagined. Here’s a key figure:

headline: Relocating Drama From Ice to Stage
text: Unlike baseball and golf, say, the sport of hockey has not inspired a particularly illustrious body of literature. There are only a handful of decent hockey novels, chief among them “King Leary,” by the Canadian writer Paul Quarrington, and “Amazons,” by one Cleo Birdwell, supposedly the first woman to play in the National Hockey League. “Amazons” is actually by Don DeLillo, but for years now he has disowned the 1980 pseudonymous work, which may indicate something of hockey’s status among American literati, at least. By far the best book about hockey is still “The Game,” a memoir by the Hall of Fame goalie Ken Dryden that was published almost 30 years ago.

headline: Two Winners, Two Potential Shows
text: It was perhaps Oprah Winfrey’s most personal giveaway to date. Ms. Winfrey announced on Friday that she would give television programs to Zach Anner and Kristina Kuzmic-Crocco, the finalists on “Your Own Show,” a televised competition that promised a program for the winner. “The truth is that both of you really deserve to have your own show,” Ms. Winfrey said on Friday’s finale on OWN, her new cable channel. Mr. Anner’s win was notable because he had been vaulted into the competition by an Internet campaign by fans. Mr. Anner, who has cerebral palsy, said he wanted to host a travel show called “Rollin’ Around the World With Zach Anner,” a cheeky reference to his wheelchair. Ms. Kuzmic-Crocco wanted to host a cooking show. Development of both will begin soon, the channel said.

headline: Oman Joins Protest Wave, and 2 Die in Clashes with Police
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Oman, the normally quiet sultanate along the southeastern coast of the Arabian Peninsula, joined the wave of two-month-old political protests shaking the Arab world on Sunday, as hundreds of demonstrators clashed with the riot police in the northeast port city of Sohar. Oman’s state news agency, ONA, said two protesters were killed.

headline: A Gift for Art Institute
text: The Art Institute of Chicago has received a $10 million gift from the Jaharis Family Foundation to renovate and expand galleries devoted to Greek, Roman and Byzantine art, as well as to support acquisitions and special exhibitions of that art. The museum described it as the largest gift it had ever received in support of the arts of the ancient Mediterranean and Byzantine worlds. Michael and Mary Jaharis, who run the foundation along with their two children, are active in Greek-American cultural activities, and Mrs. Jaharis is a life trustee of the Art Institute, as well as an honorary trustee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.

headline: U.S. and Allies Weigh Libya No-Fly Zone
text: WASHINGTON  Obama administration officials held talks on Sunday with European and other allied governments as they readied plans for the possible imposition of a no-fly zone over Libya to prevent further killings of civilians by forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: ‘Fela!’ Heading to Nigeria
text: When Broadway musicals go on tour, Lagos, Nigeria, is not usually on the itinerary. But “Fela!,” the musical based on the life of the Nigerian performer and activist Fela Anikulapo Kuti, which ran for 14 months on Broadway and recently ended a three-month engagement in London, is headed next for Lagos, the hometown of its title character, who died in 1997. The lead producer, Stephen Hendel, said last month that he was in discussions to take the show to Lagos, and now there is a firm date. The production will run April 20 to 25 at the New Expo Center in the Eko Hotel. It will feature the original Broadway cast, including Sahr Ngaujah, above, as Fela and Lillias White as his mother, Funmilayo.

headline: ‘Gnomeo & Juliet’ Is Tops at Box Office
text: It was a bad weekend for bodily-function comedy. “Hall Pass,” the latest from Bobby and Peter Farrelly, was expected by movie analysts to top the North American box office with about $20 million in sales. But it fizzled in second place. Instead, the animated “Gnomeo & Juliet” (Walt Disney Pictures) (the lovers, above) rose to No. 1 in its third weekend with an estimated $14.2 million, bringing its total to about $75 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. “Hall Pass,” starring Owen Wilson and Jason Sudeikis and filmed at a cost of about $35 million by New Line Cinema, sold $13.4 million, becoming the latest in a string of disappointments from the Farrelly brothers. The Liam Neeson thriller “Unknown” (Warner Brothers) sold an estimated $12.4 million for a two-week total of $42.8 million. Adam Sandler’s “Just Go With It” (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was fourth with about $11.1 million, lifting its three-week total to $79.4 million. “I Am Number Four,” a teenage science-fiction thriller from DreamWorks Studios, rounded out the top five with about $11 million for a two-week total of $37.7 million.

headline: French Awards Favor Polanski Film
text: Roman Polanski, whose film “The Ghost Writer” was snubbed by the Oscars, won a measure of solace on Friday when the French cultural elite showered that thriller with four Césars. The honors, France’s version of the Academy Awards, included a best directing nod for Mr. Polanski, who was vigorously supported by French celebrities when he was arrested in 2009 in connection with a 1977 sex charge in the United States and detained in Switzerland until he fended off extradition in July. “I finished this film while in jail, so I would like to thank all the people who helped me and supported me until the very end,” Mr. Polanski said in his speech, referring to his work completing the film while under house arrest. He also shared the César for best adapted screenplay with Robert Harris, while the film also captured awards for best editing and best score. But it was defeated for best picture by “Of Gods and Men,” about French Cistercian Trappist monks slain by Algerian fundamentalists. (That film was spurned by the Oscars in its foreign-language category.) Quentin Tarantino was also celebrated, receiving an honorary career award and a standing ovation.

headline: Bringing Responsible Oversight to the Gas Drilling Boom
text: I was glad to see Joe Romm react to The New York Times investigation of water problems in gas country by sticking with his appropriately nuanced view of the need for responsible expansion of natural gas extraction.

headline: Footnotes
text: The drag queen and performance artist Joey Arias, below, known for his interpretations of Billie Holiday songs, will perform at Town Hall in Manhattan on April 21. He will offer his renditions of songs by Bob Dylan and others, as well as jazz standards. A portion of the proceeds from the performance will benefit the nonprofit Lifebeat, which helps educate young people about H.I.V.-AIDS prevention. ... Playwrights Horizons has announced complete casting for the premiere of David Greenspan’s “Go Back to Where You Are,” which begins previews on March 24. Mr. Greenspan, as previously announced, will star as a chorus boy from ancient Greece who, after 2,000 years in Purgatory, is sent back to earth, where he finds himself with a vacationing family in the Hamptons. In addition, the cast will include Lisa Banes, Stephen Bogardus, Tim Hopper, Brian Hutchison, Michael Izquierdo and Mary Shultz. Leigh Silverman (“Well” and “In the Wake”) is directing.

headline: Plan to Create a Digital Works Institute Wins Ad Contest

headline: That Iraq Feeling

headline: Nevada Politicians Debate an Older Profession

headline: Rallying for States’ Rights, G.O.P. Legislators Tell Washington to Go Away

headline: Perez’s Struggle to Throw Strikes Carries Into Mets’ Spring Training
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla.  The last time Oliver Perez pitched a game in a Mets uniform, he issued three walks in a row and was booed off the mound on the final day of the 2010 season.

text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Unidentified gunmen attacked the house of Congo’s president on Sunday afternoon, setting off a short but fierce firefight that killed at least six people, Congolese officials said.

headline: Champion Michigan Gymnast Rises Far Above a Disadvantage
text: LAS VEGAS  Chris Cameron is the defending N.C.A.A. all-around men’s gymnastics champion, a member of the University of Michigan’s defending N.C.A.A. championship team, and a rising star for the national squad.

headline: For Boehner, the Dance Won’t Be Getting Easier
text: After this week, the steps for SpeakerJohn A. Boehner will grow progressively harder in his budget minuet with Democratic adversaries.

headline: On Wrestling Mat, Girls Still Face Uphill Struggle
text: BENNINGTON, Vt.  Holding the narrowest of leads, Rachel Hale kept the boy subdued on his hands and knees, then on his belly. Both wrestlers were 103 pounds of leverage and intent. She hooked her leg tightly around his, flattening his hips toward the mat, trying to turn him on his back and pin his shoulders, careful not to let him score decisive points by escaping or reversing positions or pinning her.

headline: Publishers Look Beyond Bookstores
text: Kitson, a group of boutiques based in Los Angeles, is the kind of store that appears regularly in the tabloids for both its stylish clothes and its celebrity clientele like Sean Combs and Joe Jonas.

headline: Heat and Knicks Are Reflection of Rising East
text: MIAMI  Amar’e Stoudemire sat near the scorer’s table Sunday morning and addressed questions from reporters. Carmelo Anthony did the same from a courtside seat a few feet away. Somewhere past a couple of twists and turns in the American Airlines Arena tunnel, LeBron James, Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh were finishing Miami’s shootaround on a practice court.

headline: City Details Worst-Case School Layoffs
text: The New York City Department of Education made public on Sunday a list that estimates the number of teachers each school will lose to layoffs if the state does not allocate more money for schools and seniority rules are not changed.

headline: A Doctor's E-Mails About Over-Radiated Babies
text: In July 2007, Dr. Salvatore Sclafani emailed colleagues at SUNY Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn, New York, about his discovery that premature babies had been over-radiated.

headline: Donald Leaves Field and the Past Behind
text: MARANA, Ariz.  Luke Donald overcame more than rain, snow, sleet and hail during Sunday’s final match of the W.G.C.-Accenture Match Play Championship. He overcame more even than Martin Kaymer, the freshly minted No. 1-ranked golfer in the world.

headline: Insulting Chuck Lorre, Not Abuse, Gets Sheen Sidelined
text: As more and more women have come into the work force, corporate America has made significant, if agonizingly slow, progress in making sure its attitudes and the conduct of its leadership reflect those changes. It’s no longer a “Mad Men” world where women are expected to fetch coffee and whiskey and service their bosses in other ways.

headline: Limit Pay, Not Unions
text: IN Ohio, Wisconsin and other states facing budget deficits, some elected officials assert that closing those gaps requires achieving labor savings and weakening labor unions. They are half-right.

headline: Housing Agency’s Computer Woes Put Aid Recipients in Limbo
text: The Bloomberg administration is grappling with yet another embarrassing technology malfunction. This time, the glitch is plaguing the agency charged with providing shelter to poor New Yorkers.

headline: Emilio Pucci's Peter Dundas
text: Suzy Menkes speaks with the designer on the importance of being "respectfully disrespectful" of the heritage of a fashion house, how he sees the Pucci girl and his favorite part of designing.

headline: Behind a Rise in Auto Sales, Easier Credit
text: Detroit is crowing that the auto industry is back, but so far, at least, it is a success story built as much on a revival in lending as on the development of desirable cars.

headline: Baseball Is Woven Through Fabric of Cubs Manager’s Life
text: MESA, Ariz.  The new manager of the Chicago Cubs will walk to and from Wrigley Field, among the fans, surrounded by the game. He would have it no other way. Mike Quade will share an apartment with his brother two blocks from his team’s quaint home, and baseball will wash over him, the way it always has.

headline: AT&T Begins Service to Text Users in Certain Locations

headline: Passenger Steals Cab and Crashes, Police Say

headline: Apple’s Secrecy Doesn’t Serve Corporate Governance

headline: China Reduces Growth Goal and Vows to Curb Inequities
text: Premier Wen Jiabao reduced China’s economic growth goals and said that the government would focus on ensuring the benefits of expansion were more evenly distributed.

headline: Oprah’s New Channel Struggles to Pull in the Viewers
text: Oprah Winfrey is finding out just how hard it is to build an out-of-the-way channel into a television destination.

headline: As Regimes Fall in Arab World, Al Qaeda Sees History Fly By
text: For nearly two decades, the leaders of Al Qaeda have denounced the Arab world’s dictators as heretics and puppets of the West and called for their downfall. Now, people in country after country have risen to topple their leaders  and Al Qaeda has played absolutely no role.

headline: Public Broadcasting Faces New Threat in Federal Budget
text: WASHINGTON  In 1995, Newt Gingrich, then the speaker of the House, failed in his attempt to eliminate federal financing for public broadcasting, thwarted by the timely appearance of “Sesame Street” characters and by panicked supporters who filed petitions and flooded Congressional offices with calls.

headline: A Three-Man Band of Budget Cutters
text: In private, three of the Republican governors at the center of a growing national debate over public sector workers commiserate in telephone calls and e-mail messages. In public, the three  now members, it seems, of a newly established fraternity  sound like one another’s biggest boosters.

text: It was well after midnight when Dr. Salvatore J. A. Sclafani finally hit the “send” button.

headline: Plain Jane Glamour Rules the Red Carpet
text: Simple and minimalist won out over the usual ruffles and plunging necklines on the Oscars red carpet on Sunday night, a sign that actresses are either tuning in to the runways or paying more attention to the fashion police than they like to let on.

headline: Egyptian Stock Market Set to Reopen Tuesday
text: Egyptian authorities announced on Sunday that they would reopen the nation’s stock market on Tuesday, a month after shutting it down because of the widespread protests that unseated the former president,Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Eight High School Students Are Named Times Scholars
text: One is a superintendent’s son who used to hold his father’s toolbox on the job and may become an electrical engineer. Another is the daughter of an unemployed mother who has moved eight times in the past three years and could achieve her goal of building homes for the poor in foreign countries. A third is the youngest member of a seven-person family that lives together in a small, one-bedroom apartment in the Bronx; he might end up as a mechanical engineering student at Princeton University.

headline: Unions Debate What to Give to Save Bargaining

headline: The Anthropocene
text: The edges of historical eras tend to be fuzzy. It would be nice to think that someone awoke in Florence, Italy, one day in the late 1300s  perhaps as spring started and said, “Today the Renaissance begins!” We can be sure no one did, if only because historians discern such eras only in retrospect. The same is true of geological epochs. Humans existed when the Pleistocene ended and the Holocene began, 11,500 years ago. The geologic time scale, which defines geological periods, began to take its modern form only in the 19th century.

headline: Rediscovered, Ancient Color Is Reclaiming Israeli Interest

headline: Developments in the Region
text: LIBYA Defecting Libyan military officers in the eastern part of the country took steps to establish a unified command, while rebels in several cities close to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s stronghold in Tripoli continued to repulse repeated attempts by the government to retake them. Rebels also began making plans to tap revenue from the vast Libyan oil resources now under their control  estimated by some oil company officials to be about 80 percent of the country’s total. The Qaddafi government implicitly acknowledged for the first time that it feared elements of its military falling into rebel hands, as Colonel Qaddafi’s son Seif said in a television interview that the Libyan government had bombed its own ammunitions depots in the east. NATO allies discussed steps that included a possible no-fly zone over Libya.

Was that a butterfly?

headline: Despite It All, a Night Worth Spending Time With
text: My vantage point for the Oscars was a newsroom set for Web television commentary, from which I watched broadcast television. So not the most visibility, but here is what I saw. The Oscars did the job, but then again, they had an awful lot of good movies to work with. At least eight of the movies were worthy of best picture in one way or another, and there were enough twists and turns to keep the show interesting. Can’t say the same about the hosts, who were really a host, namely Anne Hathaway. She gamely soldiered along while James Franco did, um, what exactly? Mr. Franco tweeted about doing the Oscars, made movies about doing the Oscars, gave many interviews about being a host, but when it came time to do the actual Oscars, he entered the witness protection program. Perhaps we should draw some satisfaction from the fact that this time around, it was the man who had the job of standing there and looking pretty. But his frozen smile, punched-out gaze, made you wonder while he was there in the first place.

headline: Make It New? Oscar Courts Internet Age

headline: Tradition Emerges Victorious
text: LOS ANGELES— In a year in which younger viewers were aggressively courted, the Oscars rewarded what could be considered the most traditional of traditional Academy bait: a period British drama, set during World War II. The best picture win for “The King’s Speech,” and the corresponding win for Tom Hooper as best director over “The Social Network” and David Fincher, will be fussed over by critics and bloggers as a return to the Academy’s staid tastes. It could equally be called a win for Harvey Weinstein’s aggressive campaigning – an unusually superstitious Mr. Weinstein pulled out every stop short of calling in the Queen to promote his comeback film; oh wait, he did get her seal of approval, along with Rupert Murdoch’s. (His father’s stutter was also cured by Lionel Logue.)

headline: A Mixed Bag of a Cultural Mash-Up
text: LOS ANGELES — So how did the Academy Awards do as a cultural mash-up? Not so hot. Though the hosts, James Franco and Anne Hathaway, joked about being the “hip” Oscars from the start of the show and then acted on it — Mr. Franco unleashed a torrent of backstage Twitter posts, and Ms. Hathaway mentioned drinking games — their performance drew decidedly mixed reviews, especially when compared with the riffing of the 94-year-old Kirk Douglas. The “Auto-Tune the News” segment was a bit of a head-scratcher. And the use of the fifth-grade choir from Staten Island’s P.S. 22, a YouTube sensation known for its renditions of pop and indie songs, was denuded by singing “Somewhere Over the Rainbow” as the credits rolled. Don’t get us wrong, it was still cute (and the shot of Melissa Leo singing along was sweet, especially after she dropped an obscenity in her remarks accepting her Supporting Actress Oscar). But it could have been much sharper. What did you think?

headline: Fabulous Dead People | Pauline Trigère
text: If Pauline Trigère’s only legacy were her grooming — the thin, perfectly drawn mouth; the magnificently shaped brows; the sculptured hair whooshed behind one ear — it would be quite enough. For brittle, Gallic chic she will always be the gold standard. You can still encounter the look in Paris if you know where to look (side streets in the far reaches of the 17th Arrondissement), but in New York the rigor, the discipline and the polish died when Pauline did, at age 93 in 2002.

text: In Panjsher Province, just north of Kabul, on the riverbank tucked far below the steep green slopes of the surrounding mountains, is a micro-hydro power (MHP) station with the capacity to electrify two nearby villages of more than 2,000 families. But it has sat dysfunctional since it was built 10 years ago. The villagers once solicited the assistance of the Panjsheri mujahideen commander, Ahmad Shah Massoud, but to no avail. (The tomb of Mr. Massoud, who was killed in September 2001, lies just around the bend from the plant.)

text: LOS ANGELES — The Governors Ball may have been sleepy, but the other must-stop Oscars afterparty, thrown by Vanity Fair at the Sunset Towers, had wind-up energy. At its height it felt like a starry sea where everyone from Hollywood and the worlds it touches – which is all of them – bobbed in to do a lap.

headline: Pension Funds Strained, States Look at 401(k) Plans
text: Lawmakers and governors in many states, faced with huge shortfalls in employee pension funds, are turning to a strategy that a lot of private companies adopted years ago: moving workers away from guaranteed pension plans and toward 401(k)-type retirement savings plans.

headline: Early Oscar Ratings Suggest Slightly Fewer Viewers Than Last Year
text: The Oscars appear to have dodged a bullet. In a difficult year for the ABC telecast – two youthful and untested hosts and a group of top races with heavy favorites – early ratings from 56 markets were down only a smidge from last year. Among adults 18 to 49 in these markets, the 83rd Academy Awards posted a 14.5 rating, down from 14.8 last year, according to Nielsen. ABC won’t have national ratings, which will include information about millions of viewers, until about 3 p.m. Eastern time on Monday.

headline: This Week’s Health Industry News
text: The week begins with a meeting of some of the nation’s for-profit hospitals, talking public policy and business in the nation’s capital. The Federation of American Hospitals, which represents investor-owned or for-profit hospitals, is holding its annual conference this week.

text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Preventing Side Stitches
text: As every runner knows, a painful side stitch can quickly ruin a workout. In today’s Really? column, Anahad O’Connor explores recent research that suggests side stitches are related to poor running posture.

text: It’s no secret that many small-business owners struggle with social media. Beyond leaving the occasional post on Facebook or Twitter, there’s lots of confusion about how it’s supposed to work. Here’s a nice example of how a small company creatively and efficiently built some brand buzz.

headline: Anant Pai, 81, Is Dead; Comics Told Indian Children Their Country’s Stories
text: MUMBAI, India  Anant Pai, the creator of a popular comic book series that taught several generations of Indian children the country’s history and mythology, died here on Thursday. He was 81.

headline: Heaven Help Us: Douglas Carter Beane Joins ‘Sister Act’ Creative Team

That includes the creative team of “Sister Act,” the coming Broadway musical adapted from the 1992 Whoopi Goldberg comedy, which said on Monday that Douglas Carter Beane would join its roster to provide additional material to the show’s book.

text: The Bloomberg administration has banned cars from Broadway, prohibited smoking in public parks, and cracked down on fats and salts in restaurants.

headline: Immunity Gone, Contractor in Iraq Sentenced to Prison
text: BAGHDAD  A British contractor who admitted to murdering two other foreign contractors was sentenced by an Iraqi court on Monday to 20 years in prison, the first sentence imposed on a Westerner here since Saddam Hussein was overthrown in 2003.

headline: Suze Rotolo, Muse and Girlfriend to Bob Dylan, Dies at 67
text: Suze Rotolo, who entered into a romantic relationship with Bob Dylan in the early 1960s as his career was just getting started and, in one of the signature images of the decades, walked with him arm-in-arm on the cover of his groundbreaking second album, “The Freewheelin’ Bob Dylan,” died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 67.

headline: What We’re Reading: Madoff Tapes
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Rarest of the Rare: Javan Rhinos
text: .The World Wildlife Fund and Indonesian park officials have released video of Javan rhinoceroses obtained from camera traps in Ujung Kulon National Park, which is thought to be the last refuge of the critically endangered species. The video clips show young calves and a mother, implying the species, which once ranged through much of Southeast Asia but is now down to a few dozen individuals, is hanging in there.

headline: Beltran Moves to Right Field; Pagan to Play Center
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — After 13 years and 1,563 games as one of baseball’s premier center fielders, Carlos Beltran will now become a right fielder.

headline: Not Enough Bureaucrats
text: There’s a new article in the Washington Monthly making the point that we need federal bureaucrats to manage spending, including spending on private contractors, and that understaffing the government — which we’re doing already, and will do more of if the right gets its way — actually increases the deficit. I agree. And with perfect timing, we have a new report finding that tens of billions have been wasted on undersupervised contractors in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Honda Repeats, Ford Surges and Mercedes Tumbles in 2011 Consumer Reports Study
text: Japanese automakers continue to make the best vehicles in the world, according to Consumer Reports in the magazine’s annual Automaker Report Card feature, but Ford is gaining.

headline: Experiment on 2001 Space Shuttle Flight
text: Joshua Colwell's experiment in 2001 aboard the space shuttle attempted to understand how dust grains in the early solar system stuck together through low-speed collisions.

headline: Preschool Wardrobe Wars
text: When my son was in preschool he refused to wear pants. No, he didn’t go naked, but even when there was snow on the ground, he insisted on wearing shorts. I fought daily battles for awhile, until I realized that my real objection was not to the shorts themselves, but rather to the nasty looks I was getting from the other mothers. So he wore shorts every day. For years.

headline: When 9/11 Memorial Opens, What About the Tour Buses?
text: Five million visitors a year are expected to pour into Lower Manhattan after the National September 11 Memorial and Museum opens later this year, a powerful symbol of the neighborhood’s newfound vitality in the decade since the attacks.

headline: Inflation Theorists
text: Christy Romer has a piece framing the inflation debate in terms of “empiricists” versus “theorists”. I’d say she’s being too nice.

headline: When Dementia Drains the Pocketbook
text: Wendy Miller first became alarmed when her mother began complaining during their phone conversations. “I’m spending so much money,” she fretted. “I can’t figure out why I don’t have any money.” This was a departure: Ms. Miller’s mother, always responsible about her finances, never liked talking about them. Ms. Miller wondered what was going on.

headline: Pirates Hijack Vessel Carrying 7 Danes, Including 3 Children
text: Pirates in the Arabian Sea hijacked a yacht carrying seven Danish citizens, including three children, the Danish government said Monday, in the first reported attack on a small pleasure vessel since four Americans were killed by their pirate captors last week.

headline: Fewer Voters From Union Households in 2010
text: Voters from union households are fresh off an election in which their turnout nationally was down significantly from previous years, and since they tend to favor Democratic candidates, that perhaps partly explains why Republican lawmakers in several states have singled out public-sector unions as a way to reduce budget deficits.

headline: Glencore Moves Closer to I.P.O.
text: Glencore, the world’s largest commodities trader, is reaching out to analysts and investors as it readies for a potential initial public offering in London, said two people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Baronoff to Lead Merrill’s M.&A. Team Again
text: Bank of America Merrill Lynch will again hand the reins of its mergers and acquisitions group to Steven Baronoff as the team’s current head, Jeffrey Kaplan, will leave to join the hedge fund Appaloosa Management, the firm said in an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook.

headline: In France, Michelin Dims Its Galaxy of Three-Star Restaurants
text: Michel Trama’s Aubergade in Puymirol, in southwest France, lost one of its three stars in Michelin’s 2011 guide to France, and five other restaurants joined the galaxy of two-star recipients.

headline: Sheen Talks Rehab, Money and Instant Coffee
text: Since production of “Two and a Half Men” was suspended last week, the show’s star, Charlie Sheen, has been averaging one interview each day.

headline: A Conquering Climax to a Tribute to Mahler
text: Avery Fisher Hall can be hard on an orchestra. Lush sound sometimes turns arid in the big box, and even the loudest, most dramatic moments can feel flat. The tough part isn’t exactly filling the space but rather making the sound seem to live.

headline: Excerpt: London Symphony Orchestra
text: An excerpt from the Adagio movement from Mahler's Symphony No. 10, led by Valery Gergiev, at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday.

headline: Exclusive First Look | YSL Manifesto
text: It’s that time of the year again — when Stefano Pilati, the creative director of YSL, takes his vision to the streets. For the eighth season in a row, YSL is distributing its Manifesto publication on the streets of Paris, New York, London, Milan, Tokyo, Hong Kong and, for the first time, Los Angeles.

headline: Where Lawyers Earn the Most
text: Silicon Valley has the highest paid lawyers in America, earning an average annual wage of $192,020.

headline: Oscar Spotlight Puts Wall Street Under Harsh Light
text: Charles H. Ferguson, director of the Academy Award-winning documentary “Inside Job”, used his Oscars acceptance speech to decry the lack of justice in the aftermath of the financial crisis. In an interview with DealBook editor Andrew Ross Sorkin before Sunday’s ceremony, Mr. Ferguson expands on the regulatory shortcomings.

headline: Climate Change Takes Toll on the Lodgepole Pine
text: Rising temperatures, drought and the spread of destructive insect pests will shrink the North American range of the lodgepole pine  nearly 10 percent by 2020, a new study finds.

headline: A Proposal to Reconstruct a Destroyed Afghan Buddha
text: German scientists said on Friday that it might be possible to reconstruct the smaller of the two Bamiyan Buddhas destroyed in Afghanistan by the Taliban in 2001, Agence France Presse reported.

headline: The Perfect Futility of Basketball Analytics
text: Those in the world of basketball analytics are tasked with the impossible: to convert a complex game of interrelated and inextricable factors into simple measures of player and team performance. There’s no question that the efforts to develop those measures have intensified in the last few years, but despite every advance toward the coveted “one-number metric” –- a single rating that can accurately describe a player’s impact on the floor or a team’s relative standing -– basketball’s answer to sabermetrics comes with limitations and caveats. No stat in basketball is perfect, regardless of the complexity of its formulation.

headline: U.S. Freezes a Record $30 Billion in Libyan Assets
text: WASHINGTON  The United States has blocked $30 billion in Libyan government assets since President Obama announced his executive order late Friday night imposing unilateral sanctions against Colonel Muammar el-Qaddafi and his family, the Treasury Department said Monday. It is the largest amount of foreign assets ever seized in an American sanctions action.

headline: The 5-Second Rule
text: Q. You know the five-second rule for dropped food? Is it really safe if you pick it up in time?

headline: Mobile App Revenue to Reach $38 Billion by 2015, Report Predicts

headline: Lasers Rise as Threat to Retinas
text: So far, the reports have been scattered and anecdotal. But eye doctors around the world are warning that recent cases of teenagers who suffered eye damage while playing with high-powered green laser pointers are likely to be just the first of many.

headline: Parasitic Disease: Guinea Worm Takes a Step Closer to Eradication, Jimmy Carter Says
text: The guinea worm is a spaghetti-thin parasite that has proved notoriously hard to eradicate around the world. Now former President Jimmy Carter, who has led a 25-year campaign against guinea worm disease, is reporting progress in the effort to make it only the second human disease to be eradicated, after smallpox.

headline: Natalie Portman, Oscar Winner, Was Also a Precocious Scientist
text: The Intel Science Talent Search is considered the nation’s most elite and demanding high school research competition, attracting the crème de la milk-fats-encased-in-a-phospholipid-and-protein-membrane of aspiring young scientists. Victors and near-victors in the 69-year-old contest have gone on to win seven Nobel Prizes in physics or chemistry, two Fields Medals in mathematics, a half-dozen National Medals in science and technology, a long string of MacArthur Foundation “genius” grants  and now, an Academy Award for best actress in a leading role.

headline: For Tendon Pain, Think Beyond the Needle
text: Two time-honored remedies for injured tendons seem to be falling on their faces in well-designed clinical trials.

headline: In Store | Impulse Buying at Macy’s

headline: In Wisconsin, Flinging Blame and Citing Deadlines

headline: Opposition in Yemen Supports Protesters
text: SANA, Yemen  Yemen’s political opposition rejected an invitation from President Ali Abdullah Saleh to form a national unity government and instead threw its support for the first time behind street protests calling for an immediate end to his authoritarian rule.

headline: 12 Ways to Use The Times to Develop Math Literacy
text: Math may not be the first thing that comes to mind when you think about using The New York Times for teaching and learning, but the newspaper lends itself to math just as naturally as it does to other subjects. Here are a dozen engaging ways to use The Times any day to foster mathematical understanding and skills. And if you have other ideas, please share them using the comment box below.

headline: Three Follow-Up Thoughts (and One Recipe)
text: MSNBC is doing a poll about whether GMO foods should be labeled. Regardless of the origins of that idea (possibly here?), I’m glad it’s happening. Go vote.

headline: U.S. Readies Military Options on Libya
text: WASHINGTON  The United States began moving warships toward Libya and froze $30 billion in the country’s assets on Monday as the administration declared all options on the table in its diplomatic, economic and military campaign to drive Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi from power.

headline: Whole Grain Goodness, Straight From the Oven
text: The muffins available in most coffee shops and cafes are like oversize, unfrosted cupcakes: too sweet and too big. But muffins don’t have to be cloying  a bit of natural sweetener is all that’s required to make them taste like a treat. And they don’t have to be calorie-laden confections.

headline: Commercial Real Estate Breathes Life Into a Moribund Market

headline: Lord, Make Us Thrifty, but Not Yet
text: Following up on my earlier post on the fall in American consumer spending: The flip side of the declining spending numbers is that the personal savings rate increased in January. Households had a saving rate of 5.8 percent (measured as the share of disposable income not spent), up from 5.4 percent in December.

headline: Radio for the YouTube Era?
text: The Internet has inspired people to create and share media to an unprecedented degree, through the prose of blogs, Twitter’s 140-character haikus, cellphone photography and the short-form videos of YouTube.

headline: From Charlie Chaplin to ‘Where’s Charley?’
text: Rob McClure, an actor who just played Charlie Chaplin in a world premiere musical but has comparatively few New York credits, has snagged the title role in “Where’s Charley?” — the part that won a Tony Award for Ray Bolger — in the final production in the 2010-11 Encores! season of underappreciated musicals.

headline: Fighting to Stay in the Game
text: TROIS-RIVIÈRES, Quebec  In a dimly lighted corridor of the dingy, old arena, Donald Brashear, an N.H.L. enforcer for 16 years, said he was playing in the rough-and-tumble Ligue Nord-Américaine de Hockey because he still loved the game. And though this Quebec league is widely regarded as the world’s toughest, Brashear said he was not in it to fight, but “to play hockey the way I did when I started  making passes, scoring goals.”

headline: In Quebec, Love for a Tough League
text: Despite the wildness, the antique rinks and the modest skill level, the Ligue Nord-Américaine de Hockey has drawn a surprising number of former N.H.L. players.

headline: Maternal Link to Alzheimer’s Makes a Gain
text: Alzheimer’s disease is more common in people whose mothers had the illness than in those whose fathers had it  and the evidence can be found in the brains of people who are still healthy.

headline: Dinosaur-Hunting Hobbyist Makes Fresh Tracks for Paleontology
text: Last week, Mike Taylor identified a new dinosaur called Brontomerus mcintoshi, a sauropod with uncommonly large, powerful thighs.

headline: In London, U.S. Art Enjoys Diplomatic Showcase
text: LONDON  Winfield House, which has been home to American ambassadors here since 1954, is a stately neo-Georgian mansion nestled in 12 ½ acres in the northwest corner of Regent’s Park. Originally built for Barbara Hutton, the Woolworth heiress, in the 1930s, it was sold to the United States government for $1 shortly after World War II. Its imposing facade has not always been appreciated by the British; in 1937, when it was still under construction, the venerable British journal The Architectural Review described the redbrick structure as “pinkly glowing like an open sore.”

headline: The Emotions That Get Lost in Budget Discussions
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

headline: Migrants in Israel Face Uncertainty, Despite Oscar
text: TEL AVIV — The children in the kindergarten class were taking their new celebrity status in stride on Monday, singing a Hebrew song about patience hours after a movie about their school, Bialik-Rogozin in south Tel Aviv, won the Academy Award for best short documentary in Los Angeles.

headline: Optimistic Heart Patients Live Longer
text: Heart patients who were optimistic about their treatment and recovery were more likely to be alive after 15 years than patients with similar disease but lower expectations, new research shows.

headline: At an Eerie Crossroads in Tripoli
text: Moises Saman is photographing in Libya on assignment for The New York Times. James Estrin spoke with him on Sunday. Their conversation has been edited and condensed.

headline: Earthly Delights | The Slug and the Squirrel Terrariums
text: When Sara Moonves, T’s fashion editor, received a terrarium as a holiday gift, the entire office was smitten. This bijou oasis provided a moment of tranquility in the midst of the daily style department chaos. Incredibly low-maintenance (they only need to be watered once), terrariums are just the thing for urbanites like us who are strapped for space and yearning for a patch of greenery. Further inspired by “Nocturne of the Limax maximus,” the artist and landscape designer Paula Hayes’s recent installation of cast acrylic and hand-blown glass containers filled with tropical plants at the Museum of Modern Art, we wanted to know where we could get a mini-garden all our own.

headline: Oil Drilling to Resume in the Gulf’s Deep Waters
text: WASHINGTON  The Interior Department said Monday that it had approved the first new deepwater drilling permit in the Gulf of Mexico since the BP explosion and spill last spring, a milestone after a period of intense uncertainty for industry and a wholesale remaking of the nation’s system of offshore oil and gas regulation.

headline: Netanyahu Warns on Settlements
text: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu berated leaders of his conservative-leaning Likud Party on Monday after they pressed him for more settlement construction, telling them that Israel was under international pressure and operating in a complex new reality in the Middle East.

headline: Numberplay: Lacing It Up
text: In today’s puzzles, we have fun tying shoelaces. Most of you have probably spent a significant chunk of time carrying out this mundane activity, maybe a few months of your entire life when it’s all added up. Perhaps it’s even more if you wear lace boots. Done right, shoelaces add to the elegance of footwear. Not done right, they can trip you up or deprive you of an Olympic medal, as might have happened to the notorious ice-skater Tonya Harding in 1994. Nowadays, shoemakers use newfangled ways to make shoes secure, such as velcro fasteners or new space-age materials that need no fasteners at all. To us puzzle lovers, shoelaces provide a wealth of combinatorial delights. So I thought it was worth getting this puzzle out before shoelaces disappear entirely.

headline: A New Service for Video Chatting on Facebook
text: For those who wish there were yet another way to connect with friends on computer screens, a new start-up called SocialEyes now offers video chatting through Facebook.

headline: A War of Letters

headline: ‘Holiday Bandit’ Crosses Hudson to Rob New Jersey Bank

headline: A Season of Many Singers in Jazz at Lincoln Center
text: As was the case last year, singers look to be an especially high priority among the bookings in Jazz at Lincoln Center’s coming season. On Tuesday, the organization announced the new season’s schedule, which runs from this September through June 2012.

headline: Finding the Subtle Humor and Whimsy in Haydn

headline: Treasury Names Buyout Executive to Ally Board
text: The Treasury Department said on Monday that it had named John D. Durrett as a director for Ally Financial, the former lending arm of General Motors, which received a taxpayer-financed bailout during the financial crisis.

headline: Zimbabwe Activists May Have Been Tortured, Official Says
text: JOHANNESBURG  The United Nations torture investigator confirmed Monday that he had written the government of Zimbabwe to express concern about allegations that state security agents had assaulted the 45 activists who, after watching reports of the uprisings in Egypt and Tunisia, were recently detained and charged with treason.

headline: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Readers’ Advice for ‘Spider-Man’
text: When word came out that the producers of Broadway’s “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” were considering delaying the musical’s opening night for a sixth time, readers weighed in with constructive, urgent and humorous advice for the producers. Readers also had some feedback on an article about long-running Broadway shows moving to Off Broadway for extended runs. Following are excerpts of readers’ comments on these articles culled from this blog and The Times’s theater coverage on Facebook and Twitter. ‘Spider-Man’ Delayed Again?

headline: Adding Ratings Injury to Critical Insult
text: LOS ANGELES— “One of the worst Oscar telecasts in history.”“Dead. In. The. Water.”

headline: Random House Adopts New Model for Selling E-Books

headline: Cantor Says House Will Defend Marriage Act
text: 6:00 p.m. | Updated With Republicans upset at the Obama administration’s abandonment of the Defense of Marriage Act, Representative Eric Cantor, the Virginia Republican and majority leader, said on Monday that House Republicans would decide by the end of the week how to take action to make certain the law is defended against legal challenges.

headline: In Milan, Pato Puts on a Show
text: On a day of few European games, A.C. Milan’s Alexandre Pato made the northern Italian night his own.

headline: Russians Say Damaged Cooling Pump Is Cause of Delay in Starting Iranian Reactor
text: Russia on Monday explained why fuel is being removed from a nuclear reactor in Iran, delaying plans to start up the giant plant this month. The Russian account, the first official rationale, came after experts last week offered theories of the failure ranging from a startup glitch to foul play.

headline: Go Easy on Yourself, a New Wave of Research Urges

headline: China Issues Warning on Climate and Growth
text: BEIJING  China’s environment minister on Monday issued an unusually stark warning about the effects of unbridled development on the country’s air, water and soil, saying the nation’s current path could stifle long-term economic growth and feed social instability.

headline: Younger Audience Still Eludes the Oscars
text: LOS ANGELES  The Oscars tripped in their transition to a hipper, younger, media-mad future, attracting 12 percent fewer viewers than last year in the important 18-to-49 age bracket.

headline: At City Ballet This Winter, You Could Sometimes See the Music
text: Though ballet is no better than other forms of dancing, its capacity for large-scale legibility have singular theatrical potency. Its shapes and lines beam far into space. When those geometries meet music, their union occurs not only in the bodies of the dancers: the music seems to animate the air around them. Paradoxically it is often felt more keenly by those in the uppermost rows of the theater than by those seated near the conductor. Ballet can turn music into physics; the connection of time and space becomes full of mysterious significance.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'The Red Shoes'
text: A. O. Scott looks back at Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger's film about artistic obsession.

headline: Call It a Reversible Coma, Not Sleep
text: Dr. Emery Neal Brown, 54,  is a professor of anesthesiology at Harvard Medical School, a professor of computational neuroscience at M.I.T. and  a practicing physician, seeing patients at Massachusetts General Hospital. Between all that, he heads a laboratory seeking to unravel one of medicine’s big questions: how anesthesia works.

headline: Famous, With Foot in Mouth
text: Charlie Sheen has an addiction.

headline: Koch Plans to Make Redistricting Personal
text: ALBANY — Last year, Edward I. Koch placed automated telephone calls to voters on behalf of scores of candidates who signed his pledge to support redrawing Congressional and legislative districts in an independent, nonpartisan manner.

headline: Video Raises Questions for Designer
text: PARIS  John Galliano, the chief designer for Christian Dior, faced fresh accusations on Monday of anti-Semitism after a video surfaced of Mr. Galliano appearing to deliver a tirade in a Paris bar.

headline: With a Few Tweaks, Shaking Up History
text: The “what if?” genre of alternate history has attracted a disparate a crew of practitioners including Newt Gingrich (“1945,” written with William R. Forstchen), Philip Roth (“The Plot Against America”) and Philip K. Dick (“The Man in the High Castle”). It’s yielded best sellers like Robert Harris’s “Fatherland” and literary gems like Michael Chabon’s “Yiddish Policemen’s Union.” And it’s addressed staggering questions like: What if the Nazis won World War II? What if a group of time-traveling white supremacists from South Africa gave Robert E. Lee’s troops AK-47 assault rifles to help the Confederacy win the Civil War?

headline: Few Winners Against the Oscars
text: Opposite ABC’s coverage of the Academy Awards on Sunday night rival networks drew mostly meager audiences  even as the Oscars, according to Nielsen’s estimates, drew 37.6 million viewers, down from the 41.7 million who watched a year ago. CBS earned second place as it typically has on the night of the award show, garnering modest ratings early in prime time with “60 Minutes” at 7 p.m. (8.4 million) and “The Amazing Race” at 8 (7.6 million). CBS broadcast a repeat of “Undercover Boss” at 9 (5.6 million) followed by “CSI: Miami” at 10 (8.2 million). Fox ranked third with reruns of its animated comedies, including an hourlong repeat of “Family Guy” at 9 (4.3 million). NBC was fourth with “Dateline” at 7 (4.7 million) and a three-hour marathon of “Minute to Win It” reruns, which averaged 2.9 million viewers.

headline: Remapping Computer Circuitry to Avert Impending Bottlenecks
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Hewlett-Packard researchers have proposed a fundamental rethinking of the modern computer for the coming era of nanoelectronics — a marriage of memory and computing power that could drastically limit the energy used by computers.

headline: N.Y. Classroom Scores 100 (That Is, 100% PCBs)
text: As the Bloomberg administration seeks to firm up its plans to replace light fixtures containing the toxic chemicals known as PCBs in nearly 800 city school buildings, federal officials said Monday that the latest school inspection revealed the highest levels of the toxic chemicals yet.

headline: Judging Napa Cabernet’s Class of 2007
text: EVEN in Napa Valley, where only the rare vintage is spoken of in less than superlatives, 2007 was considered nearly perfect for cabernet sauvignon. Wine Spectator rated it 99 on its 100-point scale, while other commentators, perhaps exhibiting more caution, used words like “splendid” and “extraordinary.”
