headline: Asked and Answered | Manolo Blahnik
text: Tonight is the first performance of the new Broadway musical “Priscilla Queen of the Desert.” Just like the film that inspired it, the show is a whirlwind of over-the-top costumes, industrial-strength makeup and riotous musical numbers as Priscilla and the “girls” travel across Australia on a tour bus with a towering heel topper. But just in case you thought it couldn’t get any more fabulous than the movie, Manolo Blahnik has designed a custom pair of stilettos for the show.

headline: Anne Hathaway at the Oscars
text: At the 83rd annual Academy Awards ceremony, the actress changed her outfit seven times, outdressing many of the starlets in attendance.

headline: In China, Security Muffles Calls for Change
text: BEIJING — The call to action shot across mobile phones and Internet chat sites, urging people to converge on 13 Chinese cities to demand an end to corruption, inflation and the strictures of authoritarian rule. “The Chinese people do not have the patience to wait any longer,” said one message.

headline: New York Times/CBS News Poll: Collective Bargaining
text: The complete results of a New York Times/CBS News poll on support for collective bargaining.

headline: Majority in Poll Back Employees in Public Sector Unions
text: As labor battles erupt in state capitals around the nation, a majority of Americans say they oppose efforts to weaken the collective bargaining rights of public employee unions and are also against cutting the pay or benefits of public workers to reduce state budget deficits, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: U.S. Plans for Trade Are Stalled
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama has made expanding exports a centerpiece of his plan for accelerating the economic recovery, but in recent weeks, his trade agenda has nearly ground to a halt amid partisan feuding.

headline: On a Plane, and Glad to Be Carrying Wine
text: THE whole frequent-flying experience makes me laugh. It’s just that so many weird things happen, and since I fly so much, the weird things happen a lot.

headline: In Maya Burials, Unsettling Clues
text: Daniela Triadan, an associate professor of anthropology at the University of Arizona, writes from Guatemala, where she and Takeshi Inomata are excavating the Maya site of Ceibal.

headline: My Unhealthy Diet? It Got Me This Far
text: SOMETIMES I can’t believe what my 82-year-old mother has been eating. Living now in a retirement home in Durham, N.C., she told me she recently had cherry cobbler for breakfast. Apparently she’d had French toast stuffed with bananas and Nutella for lunch the day before, and after lunch had gone to dessert theater (“You know, like dinner theater, but with desserts”), where she’d gobbled down a lot of cookies. “So when they served cherry cobbler for dessert that night in the dining room,  I thought, I better take this back to my room and eat it tomorrow. For breakfast.”

headline: Health Care REIT to Buy Genesis’ Real Estate for $2.4 Billion
text: Health Care REIT said Monday that it had agreed to buy the real estate of Genesis HealthCare for $2.4 billion, in the second major health care real estate deal of the day.

headline: Amuse-Bouche | Stoking the Appetite for Paris Fashion Week
text: Paris Fashion Week is less than 24 hours away, and although there is still Oscar buzz about Natalie’s win in Rodarte and Cate’s incredible Givenchy couture, the anticipation is building for the last leg of the fashion show marathon. Kickoff begins tomorrow with Hakaan’s second Paris show. Daria and Natalia walked the runway there last year, so expect the casting to set the bar high.

headline: On Our Radar: ‘Small’ Nuclear War Would Cool Globe, Scientists Say
text: Even a “small” nuclear war — one involving only 100 Hiroshima-sized bombs — would cause catastrophic global cooling, reduced rainfall and widespread damage to agriculture, a new report by federal scientists finds. Explosions from the bombs, representing just 0.03 percent of the global nuclear stockpile, would throw approximately five million tons of black carbon into the upper atmosphere, blocking sunlight and causing a plunge in temperature equivalent to a massive volcanic eruption. [National Geographic]

headline: America’s (and the World’s) Least Wanted
text: There are way too many official years, weeks, and days focused just on the environment, let alone all the other issues needing attention these days.

headline: A 4G Network That Delivers 4G
text: Since marketers began to apply the term “4G” to anything with a chip and a network, it has become hard to know what 4G really is. But here’s a step toward restoring its meaning.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Feb. 24-27 with 984 adults throughout the United States.
